summary: The European Commission is considering introducing a new data retention law to store communications data of EU citizens to fight terrorism. The previous law was struck down by the European Court of Justice due to privacy concerns. EU Home Affairs Commissioner Dimitris Avramopoulos plans to launch a consultation to determine whether a new law can be prepared over the next year, balancing the need to combat terrorism with respect for privacy rights.

images.alt_text: The European Commission is mulling a new law requiring telecoms companies to store communications data of EU citizens as part of its efforts to fight terrorism, after a top court struck down the previous one on privacy concerns.

site_title: Raiffeisen says oil price will dictate bets in emerging stocks
summary: Raiffeisen Capital Management predicts emerging stocks in Turkey and central Europe will perform well in 2015 due to low oil prices. Andras Szalkai, who manages $2 billion of emerging Europe assets, suggests betting on Turkey and central Europe as long as oil stays near $50. However, if oil prices rebound in the second half, Russian shares may benefit. Investors should consider transportation companies and banks in Turkey, and stocks with high dividend yields in Poland, while being cautious about Russian banks facing financing trouble.

images.alt_text: Equity investors should bet on Turkey and central Europe this year as long as the oil price remains near an almost six-year low, and shift to Russian shares if crude rebounds, according to Raiffeisen Capital Management.

site_title: European investment fund set for September start
summary: A European investment fund, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, is set to start by September, according to EU Vice President Jyrki Katainen. The fund, which aims to boost growth in the EU economy, can invest in projects such as infrastructure and small business expansion, and has a planned budget of 315 billion euros. The fund's start date may be delayed, with EU leaders expected to finalize its setup in June. The fund's success depends on government investments, with some officials expressing concerns about the EU's economic outlook.

site_title: Spotify mute about reported US$500m funding round
summary: Spotify is reportedly raising $500 million in funding, potentially delaying a public listing, according to the Financial Times. The Swedish music streaming giant hired Goldman Sachs to secure the funds, which would push back its stock exchange listing. Spotify has 15 million paying listeners worldwide and has paid out $2 billion to artists and record labels since its launch in 2008. The company has yet to turn an annual profit, with 70% of revenue going to record labels and artists. Spotify declined to comment on the funding round.

site_title: Euro recovers ground, franc down 6% this week
summary: The euro gained 0.2% against the dollar to US$1.1345 by midday in Europe, marking its first weekly rise since mid-December. The yen also gained 0.5% to 117.69 yen per dollar. This follows the European Central Bank's quantitative easing programme, which has seen some consolidation of aggressive selling since its announcement on January 22. Despite being down over 8 cents against the dollar since the start of the year, the euro's weekly gain brings it closer to its pre-quantitative easing levels.

images.alt_text: The euro and the yen gained robustly against the dollar on Friday, putting the single currency on track for its first weekly rise since the middle of December.

site_title: Germany suspends minimum wage for foreign transit truckers
summary: Germany has temporarily suspended its minimum wage for foreign truck drivers transiting the country, following opposition from Poland. The decision was made "out of consideration for neighbours" and will continue until European rules on the issue are clarified. The suspension applies only to transit journeys, not deliveries by foreign truckers. The move was welcomed by Poland, which had raised objections to the German measure, which requires Polish-based firms to pay their drivers the German minimum wage for periods spent on German soil.

site_title: India revises up 2013/14 GDP growth to 6.9%
summary: India's economic growth has been revised up to 6.9% for the fiscal year to March 2014, from the initial 4.7% estimate. This change in measurement includes under-represented sectors and new items like smartphones and LED TVs. The government adjusted the method of calculating national accounts and used 2011/12 as the new base year. This change aims to make it easier for the government to meet fiscal deficit goals. The revised growth rate for 2012/13 has also been updated to 5.1%.

site_title: Germany: Greek aid extension only makes sense if Athens upholds reforms
summary: Germany's finance ministry spokesman Martin Jaeger stated that Greece can only extend its aid program if it upholds promised reforms. Jaeger emphasized that the 'troika' of international lenders must assess Greece's progress, and an extension would only be possible if Greece carries out reforms. Announcements from Athens appear to contradict these efforts, raising concerns about the program's relevance.

site_title: Shooting of Scorsese new film delayed after accident
summary: Hollywood director Martin Scorsese has postponed filming his new movie "Silence" in Taipei after a ceiling collapsed, killing one worker and injuring three others during pre-production. The original start date was set for Friday but has been pushed back. Scorsese expressed condolences to the deceased's family and visited the wounded at the hospital. The film, starring Liam Neeson, Andrew Garfield, and Adam Driver, is based on a novel by Shusaku Endo and is set to be released in 2016.

site_title: Work anxiety kills thousands of Americans every year
summary: Workplace stress in the US contributes to $190 billion in health-care expenses and over 120,000 deaths annually, surpassing deaths from diabetes, Alzheimer's, and the flu. Researchers at Harvard Business School and Stanford's Graduate School of Business found that anxiety about employment, lack of health insurance, heavy workloads, and conflicts between work and family are the most costly workplace stressors. The study's findings highlight the significant impact of workplace stress on American health and the economy.

site_title: Oil rises, but set for record run of monthly falls
summary: Oil prices rose above $49 a barrel on Friday, supported by renewed violence in Iraq, but are still on track for a seventh straight month of declines, the longest bear run on record. Global supply glut and rising inventories continue to pressure the market, with analysts predicting a 14% fall in January prices. The International Energy Agency notes that a price rebound could take time, despite easing signs of the downturn, with lower US shale production and higher demand due to low prices. Oil prices are set to average $58.30 a barrel in 2015, down $15.70 from last month's forecast.

site_title: Asia: Shares mixed, Japan shrugs off weak inflation data
summary: Asian stock markets were mixed on Friday, with Tokyo's main index rising 0.39% as traders took heart from Japan's lowest jobless rate since 1997 and weaker inflation. Despite this, mainland China's shares fell nearly 4% due to concerns about market liquidity and regulatory inspections. The benchmark Nikkei-225 index rose, boosted by a weaker yen and lower energy costs. Global markets followed the US, where benchmark indices rallied after generally positive corporate earnings.

site_title: Google to change privacy policy after investigation by UK data watchdog
summary: Google has agreed to revise its privacy policy after a UK investigation found it to be too vague. The Information Commissioner's Office required Google to sign a formal undertaking to make changes by June 30 and take further steps in the next two years. The investigation followed Google's 2012 privacy policy, which pooled data from its services, including YouTube and Gmail. Regulators in Spain and France had previously fined Google for the policy, with total fines of $1.02 million and $150,000.

site_title: EU air safety body urges 'extreme caution' in Pakistan airspace
summary: The European Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) has urged airlines to exercise "extreme caution" when flying over Pakistan due to a heightened risk of terrorist attacks. EASA recommends flying above 24,000 feet and not entering Pakistan airspace unless absolutely necessary. This warning applies to flights into, out of, or within the country. National aviation authorities have reported an increased risk to flight operations, prompting the cautionary measure.

site_title: Palm oil posts worst start to year since 2010 as demand slows
summary: Palm oil futures dropped 5.3% in January, the largest decline since 2010, due to a supply glut and weakening demand. Output in top suppliers Malaysia and Indonesia is expected to reach a record this year, while global soybean crops reach an all-time high, making soybean oil an attractive alternative. Economists predict a slowdown in demand, citing a decline in petroleum costs and slowing world economies.

site_title: Ex-EU economic chief Olli Rehn to run for Finnish parliament
summary: Ex-EU economic chief Olli Rehn announced his candidacy for Finland's April parliamentary election, joining the opposition Centre party. His decision comes as Finland's economy faces challenges, including a slowdown in the eurozone and Russia, and problems in key industries. The Centre party leads opinion polls with 25% support, ahead of the ruling National Coalition and Social Democrat parties, which trail neck-and-neck with eurosceptic party The Finns.

site_title: Japan looks at 2030 energy targets in shadow of Fukushima cleanup
summary: Japan begins deliberating its 2030 energy targets, with a potential 15-20% ratio for nuclear power, down from 29% before the Fukushima disaster. The government supports nuclear power but public opinion remains opposed to restarting reactors. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aims to reduce reliance on nuclear energy, while industry advocates for reactors to cut energy costs. A clear stance on nuclear power is needed to determine the energy mix, with the government set to decide by early June.

site_title: New Saudi king in major government shake-up
summary: Saudi Arabia's new King Salman has tightened his hold on power by firing two sons of his predecessor and replacing key agency heads, including intelligence and religious police. The shakeup, made a week after Salman took the throne, aims to chart a steady course on foreign and oil policy. Top officials from the Ports Authority and the National Anti-Corruption Commission were among those let go. Analysts see the move as a sign of stability in the kingdom.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's new King Salman has tightened his hold on power, firing two sons of his predecessor and replacing the heads of intelligence and other key agencies in a sweeping shakeup.

site_title: India's fiscal deficit overshoots full-year target in December
summary: India's fiscal deficit for the fiscal year ending in March exceeded its target by 5.12 trillion rupees (US$85.90 billion) in December, reaching 5.32 trillion rupees (US$85.90 billion) or 100.2% of the target. This is a significant increase from the same period last year, when the deficit was 95.2% of the target.

site_title: Alibaba finance arm said to plan 2016 initial public offering
summary: Alibaba's finance arm, Zhejiang Ant Small & Micro Financial Services Group Co, is planning a 2016 initial public offering (IPO) with an estimated value of around $50 billion, according to people familiar with the matter. Ant Financial, which runs China's biggest e-commerce payments business, is weighing a private placement before going public. The IPO would be valued twice the minimum threshold required, and Alibaba Chairman Jack Ma would control voting rights but have a reduced stake. The company is considering a dual listing in China and abroad, with a potential A-share sale in China.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals pick up in December, consumer credit slows
summary: British mortgage approvals rose to 60,275 in December, the first increase since June, amid tighter mortgage lending rules. Consumer credit slowed, with borrowing by consumers dropping 1.2 billion pounds in December, below forecasts. Lending to non-financial businesses also fell sharply, while lending to small businesses declined by 1.0 billion pounds. Despite a slowdown in spending, consumer confidence rose to its highest level since August, suggesting a possible turnaround in the economy.

site_title: AirAsia X CEO Azran to leave
summary: AirAsia X CEO Azran Osman-Rani is leaving the company, with Benyamin Ismail taking his place. Azran will take a break, while Kamarudin Meranun will oversee affiliates in Thailand, Indonesia, and Malaysia as Group CEO. AirAsia X plans to raise RM395 million (US$109 million) by selling new shares to repay debt and boost working capital.

site_title: Eurozone deflation accelerates in January to -0.6%: Eurostat
summary: Eurozone consumer prices fell 0.6% in January, accelerating deflation and confirming it may be settling in for the long term. The drop was driven by plummeting oil prices. The European Central Bank's bond-buying spree aims to drive up inflation. Unemployment slipped to 11.4% in December, down from 11.5% in November and 11.8% a year ago.

site_title: Global Premium Hotels Q4 profit up 61% on tax writeback
summary: Global Premium Hotels reported a 61% increase in net profit for Q4 2014, reaching S$8.4 million, driven by a S$3.4 million tax writeback. Excluding tax, operating profit fell 17.2% to S$4.9 million. For the full year, net profit rose 9.7% to S$21.2 million. The company cited fiercer competition and lower occupancy rates, but expects positive press for Singapore tourism to boost tourist arrivals.

site_title: Turkey's lira slides to fresh record low against dollar
summary: Turkey's lira slid to a fresh record low against the dollar, weakening to 2.4265 from 2.4036. The decline followed a surprise Russian central bank rate cut, adding to pressure from an expected Turkish interest rate cut. The Turkish central bank governor's indication of an extraordinary monetary policy committee meeting also contributed to the currency's decline.

site_title: Three partners said to leave former Goldman trader's hedge fund
summary: Morgan Sze, former Goldman Sachs trader, is making changes to his Hong Kong-based hedge fund, Azentus Global Opportunities Master Fund, after planned senior departures. Three partners will leave by March, leaving two partners to run the $615 million fund, which has shrunk in assets. Sze aims to boost returns, and investors can accelerate redemptions. The fund returned 1.1% last year, extending cumulative gains to nearly 12% since inception, after a 6.8% loss in 2011. Sze is also trying to win back investors after a tough year in the hedge fund industry.

site_title: Oil price will average less in 2015 than during financial crisis
summary: Crude oil prices are expected to average $58.30 a barrel in 2015, down $15.70 from last month's forecast, marking the lowest average since 2005. This is attributed to OPEC's decision to maintain output despite growing US shale production. A mild recovery in the second half of the year is predicted, but prices will remain lower than during the 2008-2009 financial crisis. The forecast revision is the largest month-on-month change since 2008-2009.

site_title: UK peer-to-peer lending hit US$2b in 2014: trade body
summary: The UK's peer-to-peer lending industry lent over $2 billion in 2014, with total lending reaching $2.1 billion, more than double the amount at the end of 2013. The industry has grown rapidly since the 2007-2009 financial crisis, providing low-cost loans to individuals and businesses through online platforms. This growth is attributed to the scarcity of bank credit for small businesses. The Peer-to-Peer Finance Association reports continued growth in the consumer market and a significant increase in lending to businesses.

site_title: Russian central bank makes surprise interest rate cut
summary: Russia's central bank cut its key interest rate by two points to 15% on Friday, citing medium-term inflation reduction conditions. The move comes as the economy slides towards recession due to global oil price collapse and Western sanctions. The bank previously hiked its key rate by 11.5 percentage points last year to combat currency market panic and soaring inflation, which reached 11.4% in December.

site_title: German retail body sees 2015 sales up by 1.5%
summary: German retail sales are projected to increase by 1.5% in 2015 to around 466 billion euros, driven by a strong labor market and rising wages. Consumer sentiment has surged to its highest level in over 13 years, fueled by lower oil prices and spare cash. This growth is attributed to consumers having little incentive to save due to low interest rates. The figure differs from official data, which showed a 1.7% increase in nominal retail sales last year.

site_title: Singapore curbs public drinking after first riot in four decades
summary: Singapore has passed a law restricting the sale and consumption of alcohol in public areas between 10.30pm and 7am, following the city's first riot in over four decades. The curbs aim to prevent inconvenience to residents and mitigate law and order risks. The law will prevent drinking in public places and the sale of alcohol in retail shops during the restricted hours, with Second Minister for Home Affairs S Iswaran stating that proactive measures are needed to address public concerns.

images.alt_text: Singapore on Friday passed a law to restrict the sale and consumption of alcohol in public areas after the city's first riot in more than four decades.

site_title: Oil on track for seventh monthly fall as supply glut weighs
summary: Oil prices remain steady near $49 a barrel, poised for a seventh monthly fall due to a global supply glut. US crude oil inventories reached record levels, and Brent crude oil futures are on track for a 14% drop in January. Analysts attribute the decline to high global stock levels and weak fundamentals, despite some short-term support from China's new commercial crude reserve regulations. The International Energy Agency expects a price rebound to take time, and producers are adjusting to a lower-price environment, making voluntary supply cutbacks difficult.

site_title: China Eastern Airlines expects up to 60% rise in 2014 earnings
summary: China Eastern Airlines expects a 40-60% increase in 2014 earnings, driven by a 40% drop in fuel prices. The airline's net income is estimated to be 2.38 billion yuan (US$380.83 million) for the previous year. Other Chinese carriers, such as Air China and China Southern Airlines, are also benefiting from the fuel price fall. In response, Chinese carriers have reduced fuel surcharges for domestic routes multiple times since September.

images.alt_text: China Eastern Airlines Corp Ltd said on Friday it expected an up to 60 per cent jump in its 2014 earnings thanks to falling fuel prices.

site_title: Japan government advisers say watch GDP deflator in push for inflation
summary: Japan's policy makers should monitor the GDP deflator to measure progress in stoking inflation, according to influential advisers to the government. Despite falling oil prices, the GDP deflator is expected to rise, suggesting Japan will avoid deflation and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government may not urge the Bank of Japan to ease policy further to meet its 2% inflation target. The GDP deflator, which reflects wages and corporate profits, has been rising since last year, showing progress in pulling away from 15 years of deflation.

site_title: India's banks say no room to cut lending rates, thwarting RBI easing
summary: India's 45 commercial banks have failed to pass on the Reserve Bank of India's (RBI) surprise rate cut of 25 basis points to 7.75% on January 15, leaving the government's efforts to boost business investment hindered. Only three banks have cut their base lending rates since the rate cut, with executives citing tight cash conditions and a lack of change in money markets as excuses. The RBI is under pressure to inject more funds into the banking system to spur credit growth, which has been sluggish, and analysts predict a potential increase in liquidity to force banks to lower lending rates.

site_title: Singapore's Ezra Holdings closes loan facility for new vessel
summary: Ezra Holdings Ltd, a Singapore-listed oilfield service company, has successfully closed an increased loan facility to finance the construction of its new vessel, Lewek Constellation. The vessel is on track to be fully operational by March 2015 and has outstanding contracts worth nearly US$0.5 billion. Additionally, Ezra's subsea services division has secured multiple contract wins worth US$65 million, bringing the company's total year-to-date contract wins to over US$355 million.

site_title: AirAsia X announces rights issue to raise US$109m
summary: Malaysian long-haul budget carrier AirAsia X announced a US$109m rights issue to raise funds for debt repayment and working capital. The company aims to raise RM395 million, with shares suspended for trading ahead of the announcement. The price and entitlement of the rights shares will be determined later, along with free warrants to shareholders.

site_title: China central bank says injected 855b yuan through short-term liquidity operations in Dec
summary: China's central bank injected 855 billion yuan (US$136.81 billion) into the money market through short-term liquidity operations in December, supplementing its monetary policy tools. This move aims to provide commercial banks with one- to three-day loans and support the rising money markets, driven by month-end tax payments and the upcoming lunar new year holiday.

site_title: Russian sovereign bonds take into account possible credit downgrade: central bank governor
summary: Russian central bank Governor Elvira Nabiullina stated that the risks of a further credit downgrade are already factored into the country's sovereign bonds. She noted, however, that risks of rising yields still exist. This comes as the Russian economy faces challenges.

site_title: Greek bank shares recover more ground, lifting Athens market
summary: Greek bank shares recovered 8.6% in early trading, lifting the Athens stock market. The Athens Stock Exchange FTSE Banks Index rose 12.9% from Wednesday's slump, with Bank of Piraeus and National Bank of Greece gaining 11.4% and 6.4%, respectively. European Commission Vice President Jyrki Katainen urged Greece's new government to stick to agreed reforms, but hinted at possible additional time to meet goals.

site_title: AirAsia resumes online promos, adverts after Indonesia jet crash
summary: AirAsia resumed online promotions and advertising after a month following the Indonesia AirAsia plane crash, which killed 162 people. CEO Tony Fernandes stated the airline's sales in Indonesia are slowly recovering, with a 50% drop in sales after the crash, but are now about 12% behind. Competitor Garuda Indonesia reported an increase in passenger load factor this month, while some customers expressed concerns about flying AirAsia.

site_title: German watchdog eyes Deutsche Bank Q4 disclosure protocol
summary: Germany's financial watchdog, Bafin, is investigating Deutsche Bank's fourth-quarter disclosure protocol, following the publication of the results on Thursday. Bafin reviews hundreds of cases annually, a process typically taking two to four weeks, which may result in a fine if rules were violated. This examination is routine and not uncommon, as Deutsche Bank declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end lower
summary: Singapore shares ended lower on Friday, slipping 27.85 points to 3,391.2, with 1.52 billion shares valued at S$1.76 billion traded. The Straits Times Index closed with 231 losers and 212 gainers. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Malaysia completes a third of undersea search for MH370
summary: Malaysia's undersea search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 has covered almost a third of its target area in the southern Indian Ocean. The search, which began months after the Boeing 777 disappeared on March 8, 2014, with 239 passengers and crew, is expected to be completed by May. Authorities remain confident that the aircraft is in the search zone, but acknowledge that poor weather after May may hinder progress. The country's civil aviation authorities plan to release an interim report on the investigation on March 7, a day before the first anniversary of the flight's disappearance.

images.alt_text: The undersea search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 has covered almost a third of its target area, Malaysian authorities said on Friday, adding that they were confident the aircraft is in the zone.

site_title: Asian currencies fall a fifth month in longest streak since 1998
summary: Asian emerging-market currencies experienced their fifth consecutive month of decline, the longest streak since 1998, due to monetary easing by nations including Singapore and India, which spurred demand for dollars. The Bloomberg-JPMorgan Asia Dollar Index dropped 0.5% in January, contributing to a 3.8% retreat since August. Key currencies, such as the ringgit, rupiah, and yuan, declined due to factors including a stronger US dollar, slowing Chinese economy, and capital outflows.

site_title: Japan's total oil sales fall 4% in 2014: METI
summary: Japan's total oil product sales fell 4% in 2014 to 3.19 million barrels per day, with crude oil imports also declining 5.2% to 3.44 million barrels per day. Domestic oil demand is expected to fall due to a shrinking population and increasing fuel-efficient vehicles. Oil product sales in December fell 1% from the previous year, reaching 3.8 million barrels per day.

site_title: Rouble slides past 70 per dollar after Russia's surprise rate cut
summary: The Russian rouble slid past 70 against the dollar after the Bank of Russia reduced its key interest rate to 15% from 17%. The currency weakened 2.6% to 70.5575 a dollar, its first time surpassing 70 since December 17. The rate cut came despite economists predicting no change, with inflation accelerating to 11.4% in December. The move may be seen as a response to the domestic banking system's risk from a previous drastic rate hike. The economy is expected to shrink 4% this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Friday, closing at 1,781.26 after 1.19 billion lots were traded. The index slipped 0.92 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 440-344. This marks the end of a trading session with mixed global markets, as the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: Global markets: Dollar set for record run, European shares rise
summary: The dollar is poised for its best run since 1971, with a seventh consecutive month of gains, as European shares rise for their best monthly performance in over three years. German retail sales posted their biggest annual rise in 2-1/2 years, boosting the FTSEurofirst 300 index. The euro also edged higher, despite being down 6% for the month, its worst performance in 2-1/2 years. The dollar's gains have helped it rise 5% against a basket of currencies this year, as traders expect the US Federal Reserve to be the first to raise interest rates.

site_title: India's biggest asset sale to raise US$3.6b lures investors
summary: India's Coal India Ltd has received a full subscription for its asset sale, raising at least $3.6 billion. The government initially offered 5% of its stake, with a minimum price of 358 rupees per share, and received 662 million shares, exceeding the 631.6 million shares available. The sale is seen as a significant step in India's efforts to raise funds and meet its fiscal deficit targets.

site_title: Singapore hacker jailed for 56 months for attack on bank, town
summary: A Singaporean hacker, James Raj Arokiasamy, was sentenced to 56 months in jail for hacking into a bank and defacing government websites. Raj, 36, pleaded guilty to 40 charges, including stealing confidential data from Standard Chartered Plc and using illicit drugs. The sentence was lower than the prosecutors' sought five or six years. This conviction follows another recent case where a 28-year-old man was sentenced to two months in jail for unauthorized code entry into the Prime Minister's office website.

site_title: Korean Air chief says he scolded daughter over nut rage
summary: Korean Air Lines Chairman Cho Yang-ho testified in court that he scolded his daughter, Heather Cho, for expelling a crew member from a flight over a dispute with in-flight service. The incident, known as "nut rage," has sparked public outrage and raised questions about the power of South Korea's conglomerates. Cho apologized to the crew chief and promised not to face reprimand, while his daughter faces trial for breaking aviation laws and conspiring with executives to force crew members to lie about the incident.

site_title: Oil's next casualty: Government budgets
summary: Oil's 56% drop in the last six months is impacting oil-producing nations' budgets. Saudi Arabia, the world's top crude producer, is expected to experience a 4.7% budget deficit this year, the first since 2009, according to IMF data. This is due to the sharp decline in oil prices.

site_title: Perennial leads consortium to acquire AXA Tower for S$1.17b
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings Limited (PREH) has led a consortium to acquire AXA Tower in Singapore for S$1.17 billion, or S$1,735 per square foot. PREH, in partnership with Kuok Khoon Hong, will hold a 41.3% stake in the property, with a 31.2% equity investment of about S$117.9 million. AXA Tower, a 50-storey landmark office development, has a total net lettable area of 674,000 sq ft and unutilized plot ratio allowing for an additional GFA of over 212,000 sq ft. The consortium plans to explore efficient asset plans and strata-sale of office space.

site_title: China regulator says to punish 5 fund management firms for insider trading
summary: China's securities regulator announced it will punish five fund management firms for insider trading, prohibiting them from issuing new mutual fund products for three to six months. The firms include China Asset Management Co Ltd and HFT Investment Management Co Ltd. The regulator, China Securities Regulatory Commission, made the announcement at a news conference. This move aims to maintain market integrity and prevent insider trading, which is a serious offense in China's financial markets.

site_title: Swiss franc falls past 1.05 per euro, down 5% on week
summary: The Swiss franc fell past 1.05 per euro, its lowest level since the Swiss National Bank removed the 1.2 francs cap two weeks ago. The franc has weakened 5.5% against the euro and 5% against the dollar this week, amid speculation about the bank's intervention. The decline also pushed the franc to a two-week low of 0.9285 francs per dollar.

site_title: Japan's biggest airlines project smooth annual earnings
summary: Japan's two biggest airlines, All Nippon Airways (ANA) and Japan Airlines (JAL), posted mixed nine-month results, with ANA's net profit rising 57% to 52.36 billion yen, while JAL's profit fell 3.1%. ANA attributed its growth to increased international flights at Tokyo's Haneda airport and rising fuel costs. Despite JAL's decline, the airline raised its full-year earnings forecast to 139 billion yen, citing falling fuel costs and stronger revenue in its cargo business.

site_title: Oil prices fall as output remains high, producers slash costs
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday, dipping below $49 a barrel, as global production remained high and producers reduced costs to adjust to lower export revenues. Benchmark Brent crude futures opened with losses and fell to $48.95 a barrel. Analysts say the market outlook remains weak, with producers unlikely to cut supply voluntarily due to low prices. The Volatility Index has fallen to its lowest since 2009, indicating decreasing price swings.

site_title: China: Stocks have biggest weekly loss in year on margin risk
summary: China's stocks suffered their largest weekly decline in a year, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 1.6% to 3,210.36, as concerns over regulatory scrutiny of margin lending and economic growth weighed on the market. Margin traders increased holdings of shares purchased with borrowed money for a seventh day, with the outstanding balance of margin debt on the Shanghai Stock Exchange rising to $124.5 billion. The Shanghai index is still the best performer among 93 global indexes, but its rally is losing momentum amid efforts to cool the growth of margin loans.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB may look at property sales to cut huge debt burden: sources
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB state firm may consider selling property assets to cut its massive debt burden of RM41.9 billion. The company, under new CEO Arul Kanda, is conducting a strategic review to explore options for generating maximum value from its assets. Property worth over RM20 billion, including the Tun Razak Exchange and Bandar Malaysia projects, could be sold. The decision is still preliminary and would come after the planned IPO of its power plants, valued at US$3 billion.

site_title: Standard & Poor's cuts Malaysia GDP growth forecast as oil tumbles
summary: Standard & Poor's has lowered Malaysia's GDP growth forecast to 4.6% in 2015 and 5.0% in 2016 due to the collapse in global crude prices. The country, a major liquefied natural gas and oil exporter, is expected to be hurt by reduced exports, lower investment, and decreased spending power. The rating agency also revised its policy rate forecast, expecting the Malaysian central bank to keep the benchmark rate at 3.25% through 2016.

images.alt_text: Standard & Poor's said on Friday it had lowered its economic growth forecast for Malaysia to 4.6 per cent in 2015 and 5.0 per cent in 2016 as oil prices continue to slide.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise, head for best month in 5-1/2 years
summary: Europe's FTSEurofirst 300 index advanced 0.3% to its best monthly performance in 5-1/2 years, driven by Germany's strong retail sales data and expectations of a European Central Bank bond-buying program. The DAX index rose 0.6%, while Swedish company SCA surged 7.9% after posting higher-than-expected quarterly profit. This marks the best month for European shares since mid-2009.

site_title: Swiss leading indicator edges lower as outlook worsens
summary: Switzerland's leading economic indicator, the KOF economic barometer, fell to 97 points in January, below expectations and the long-term average of 100 points. This decline reflects the country's economy contracting due to the Swiss National Bank's decision to scrap the Swiss franc cap, which has sent the currency soaring and stoked fears for the export-driven economy. The KOF institute attributes the decline to participants' responses before the cap's repeal, indicating a worsening climate for the Swiss economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 0.39%
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.39% higher on Friday, driven by Wall Street's advance and a weaker yen boosting exporter shares. The Nikkei 225 index rose 68.17 points to 17,674.39, while the Topix index gained 0.11% to 1,415.07.

site_title: French tourists arrested for nude photos at Cambodia's Angkor
summary: Three French tourists were arrested at Cambodia's Angkor temple complex for taking nude photos of each other inside the Banteay Kdei temple. The tourists admitted to making a mistake and are being investigated by Cambodian police. The arrest comes after a series of nude photos of Asian women at ancient Cambodian temples went viral online, sparking outrage. The Angkor Archaeological Park is a world heritage site and a popular tourist destination, with many Cambodians offended by the tourists' behavior, which is seen as inappropriate and disrespectful to the temple's cultural significance.

images.alt_text: Three French tourists have been arrested by Cambodian authorities for taking nude photos of each other inside the country's famed Angkor temple complex, officials said Friday.

site_title: Total to cut exploration costs by 30% in 2015: Le Monde
summary: Total's new chief, Patrick Pouyanne, announced plans to cut exploration spending by 30% in 2015 due to falling oil prices. This move aims to reduce costs and cope with the market shift. The decision was made in an interview with Le Monde, and shares in Total rose 1.8% in early trade.

site_title: BP to hand back two exploration blocks to Indonesia on risk concerns
summary: BP to relinquish two exploration blocks in Indonesia due to high risk and commercial challenges. The blocks, West Aru I and West Aru II, were awarded to BP in 2011, but a 3D seismic evaluation found them to be technically high risk and commercially challenging. The blocks, located in eastern Indonesia's Maluku province, have water depths ranging from 200 to 2,500 meters. BP will hand back the blocks to Indonesia, citing the risks as a major factor in their decision.

site_title: Thai central bank consumption index falls in Dec month-on-month
summary: Thailand posted a record high current account surplus of $5.52 billion in December, up from $1.66 billion in November. The Bank of Thailand's private consumption index fell 0.7% and investment index rose 0.1%. Exports increased 2.3% year-over-year, contrasting a 1.8% decline in November. These data suggest a stable economy despite global economic pressures.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close down 0.36%
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.36% on Friday, closing at 24,507.05 points, amid mixed Asian markets. This follows a rise on Wall Street and Japan's inflation slowdown in December. In mainland China, the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.59% to 3,210.36 points. The week saw a 4.22% decline in the Shanghai index.

site_title: Rallying: Toyota to return to world championship in 2017
summary: Toyota announces its return to the world rally championship in 2017 with a Yaris car prepared in Germany. The Japanese manufacturer, which won four drivers' and three manufacturers' world titles in the 1990s, will field a team led by Frenchman Eric Camilli. Toyota's decision is seen as a boost to the sport, with the WRC promoter welcoming its return as "marvellous news." The company's return to rallying comes after an 18-year absence, during which it focused on endurance racing, including its recent Le Mans victory.

images.alt_text: Former champions Toyota will return to the world rally championship in 2017 with a Yaris car prepared in Germany, the Japanese manufacturer announced on Friday.

site_title: 77% of Singapore manufacturers expect stable business prospects in H1 2015
summary: Singapore manufacturers expect stable business prospects in H1 2015, with 77% expecting stable conditions and 13% foreseeing slower business. The chemicals cluster is the most optimistic, with a net weighted balance of 12% expecting improved business conditions. This is attributed to declining crude oil and feedstock prices.

site_title: Quick take: Further MAS easing depends on forecasts downgrades and job market cracks
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate remained low at 2% overall in 2014, with a seasonally adjusted 1.9% in the fourth quarter. However, a total of 12,800 workers were laid off, higher than the 11,560 in 2013. Economists suggest further Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) easing depends on forecasts downgrades and job market cracks. The labor market remains tight, with supply constraints and elevated price levels posing risks to inflation expectations.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Oil prices down in Asian trade
summary: Crude oil prices fell in Asia on Friday, dropping three cents to $44.50 for US benchmark West Texas Intermediate and 35 cents to $48.78 for Brent. The US Senate approved a bill to build the Keystone XL oil pipeline from Canada to the US Gulf Coast, adding to concerns over a supply glut. Oil prices have lost more than half their value since June 2014 due to robust US shale oil production and weak demand from slowing economies worldwide. The US Department of Energy reported record-high crude oil stockpiles and production levels.

site_title: New chief executive at CPF Board from March 15
summary: Ng Chee Peng, the current deputy secretary of the Ministry of Manpower, will become the new chief executive of the Central Provident Fund Board (CPF Board) on March 15, succeeding Yee Ping Yi. Ng has a background in the military and holds degrees from Oxford and Harvard. Yee will return to the civil service after his tenure ends. This change is part of a leadership shift within the CPF Board.

site_title: Singapore charges forex traders for cheating HSBC, Deutsche Bank
summary: Two former forex traders, Ivan Chng from HSBC and Toh Hway Khuan from Deutsche Bank, were charged in Singapore for allegedly cheating their employers by making false trades. They made a combined US$1.1 billion in trades in 2009, resulting in wrongful gains of around S$370,000 and S$140,000, respectively. Both men are out on bail and face up to 7 years in jail and fines of up to S$250,000.

site_title: Taiwan's economy slows in fourth quarter 2014
summary: Taiwan's economy grew 3.17% in the fourth quarter of 2014, slower than expected due to lower overseas demand and weaker domestic spending. Exports rose 0.45% despite declining demand for gasoline and diesel, while private consumption grew 2.33%. The full-year GDP growth was 3.51%, higher than forecast, driven by record-high exports and rising domestic consumption. The economy's growth weakened towards the end of the year due to shrinking demand in most overseas markets.

site_title: Indian central bank urges companies to hedge FX exposure
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), is urging companies to hedge their foreign exchange exposure to prepare for potential currency turmoil. The RBI is reducing its own dollar buying in forward markets to make hedging more affordable for companies, which currently costs 10-12%. The RBI has also instructed banks to report quarterly data on corporate customers' foreign currency exposure. The move comes amid concerns about the US Federal Reserve raising interest rates, which could lead to selling in emerging markets and a potential crisis for the Indian rupee.

site_title: Spanish economy grows by 1.4 per cent in 2014: stats office
summary: Spain's economy grew by 1.4% in 2014, marking the first full-year growth since 2008. The growth was driven by consumer demand, a recovery in the construction sector, and tourism, with record 65 million foreign visits. The jobless rate decreased to 23.7%, but remains high. The government predicts 2.0% growth in 2015 and 2.5% if oil prices and the euro remain low.

site_title: Curbing threats to payment systems a priority: Fed's Rosengren
summary: US Federal Reserve President Eric Rosengren emphasized the need for public investment to curb threats to payment systems, citing potential vulnerabilities in accounts of consumers, merchants, third-party providers, and banks. He warned that attacks on electronic payment systems could be extremely disruptive and potentially cripple an economy. Rosengren advocated for a national defense-grade security level for payment systems, which would be more resilient but expensive. This comes after recent security breaches at retailers like Target and Home Depot, which have raised concerns about payment safety.

site_title: Iron ore set for worst month since May as rout extends
summary: Iron ore prices are expected to post their biggest monthly fall since May 2014, with a 12.5% loss in January. China's steel demand is slowing due to winter construction activity and economic slowdown, leading to a glut in the market. The country plans to cut its growth target to around 7% in 2015, the lowest goal in 11 years, and invest $128 billion in infrastructure projects. Benchmark iron ore prices fell to $62.30 a tonne, their lowest since May 2009.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific gets approvals for rights issue in Singapore, Philippines
summary: Del Monte Pacific has received approvals for a renounceable underwritten rights issue in Singapore and a stock rights offering in the Philippines, raising up to 641.9 million new ordinary shares at a discounted price of S$0.325 or 10.60 Philippine pesos. The issue is expected to raise approximately S$208.6 million, with net proceeds to be used for debt repayment and to deleverage the company's balance sheet. The rights issue is part of the company's efforts to repay a bridging facility and strengthen its financial position.

site_title: Qatar Airways takes 9.99% stake in BA-owner IAG
summary: Qatar Airways has acquired a 9.99% stake in International Airlines Group (IAG), the parent company of British Airways and Iberia, for around $1.7 billion. The move aims to strengthen commercial ties and develop IAG's Westwards strategy. Qatar's CEO, Akbar Al Baker, stated that the investment represents an "excellent opportunity." Non-European shareholders, including Qatar Airways, are subject to an overall cap on ownership due to EU regulations.

site_title: Philippine central bank sees room to keep current policy stance
summary: The Philippine central bank's governor, Amando Tetangco, expects to maintain its current policy stance due to easing inflation and strong economic growth. Average inflation this year is seen within the government's 2-4% target, with the benchmark interest rate at 4.0%. The bank is expected to hold the rate steady, possibly for the first half of the year, as inflation slows. The Philippines closed 2014 as the fastest-growing economy in Asia, driven by farm output and construction activity.

site_title: 17% of Singapore services firms expect slower business for January-June
summary: Singapore services firms predict a neutral outlook for January-June 2015, with 70% expecting no change, 17% foreseeing slower business, and 13% anticipating better prospects. This is partly due to seasonal factors, with firms generally less optimistic in the first half of the year. The accommodation and transport services industries expect less business activity, while the financial and insurance services industry is more optimistic about revenue growth. Overall, operating receipts are expected to remain at a similar level for the first quarter of 2015.

site_title: Honda investigating possible exploding airbag death
summary: Honda is investigating a deadly crash in the US possibly linked to a faulty Takata airbag inflator, which may have caused the death of at least one driver. The incident is part of a global recall of millions of vehicles due to the risk of excessive explosive power from Takata-made airbags. Honda has worked with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to determine the cause of death and has no records of the repair work being done on the vehicle.

site_title: Honda lowers profit forecast after vehicle recall costs mount
summary: Honda Motor Co. has lowered its profit forecast for the fiscal year ending March, citing mounting recall costs related to flawed airbags and hybrid systems in its vehicles. The company now expects a net income of 545 billion yen, down from a previous forecast of 565 billion yen. This is Honda's second profit forecast cut this year, and the company's first profit drop in three years. The recall issues have disrupted its plans to introduce new models and led to a 20% cut in President Takanobu Ito's monthly pay.

site_title: German retail sales climb for fifth year running in 2014
summary: German retail sales increased for a fifth consecutive year in 2014, rising by 1.4% in real terms, driven by a robust labor market, rising wages, and low inflation. Private consumption helped drive a 1.5% increase in gross domestic product. Retail sales rose by 0.2% in December, with the biggest yearly increase in 2-1/2 years, attributed to an extra shopping day. Consumer sentiment is expected to continue supporting growth in 2015, with lower oil prices providing consumers with more spare cash.

site_title: If your kid were a car, this is what you'd sound like to everybody else
summary: A social media post from 2015 features humorous accounts of people's experiences and emotions as new car owners, showcasing the unique bond between a car and its owner. The posts range from excitement and pride to frustration and sacrifice, highlighting the unique relationship between a car and its owner. The author reflects on the challenges and joys of car ownership, from the initial thrill of driving to the financial and emotional sacrifices made.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 1.04%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 1.04% higher on Friday, driven by gains on Wall Street and the dollar's rise against the yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose 182.52 points to 17,788.74. The dollar's strength is positive for Japanese exporters, while investors largely ignored Japanese government data showing consumer inflation slowed in December. The dollar rose to 118.25 yen, up from 117.70 yen in Tokyo earlier Thursday.

site_title: Tencent inks exclusive online partnership for NBA games in China
summary: The National Basketball Association (NBA) has signed a five-year exclusive online partnership with Tencent Holdings Ltd in China, making Tencent the only company in the country to stream the league's online content. The deal allows Tencent to offer the NBA's League Pass package, enabling subscribers to watch live and on-demand games. Financial terms were not disclosed, but the partnership is expected to expand the NBA's reach via one of China's leading Internet brands, reaching hundreds of millions of daily users.

site_title: No growth in bank lending in December: MAS
summary: MAS reported no growth in bank lending in December, with loans standing at S$608 billion. This follows a 0.6% increase in November. Business loans contracted 0.4% to S$372 billion, while consumer loans gained 0.5% to S$236 billion. This is the weakest growth since March 2010, with consumer loans showing a slight improvement.

site_title: BlackRock holds 3.2% of Keppel Land shares
summary: BlackRock, an associate of Keppel Corp, now holds approximately 49.57 million shares in Keppel Land, representing about 3.2% of the total issued shares. This increase from 48.05 million shares announced on Thursday. BlackRock's latest shareholding is based on 1.55 billion issued shares as of January 23.

images.alt_text: KEPPEL Corporation, via its financial advisers DBS Bank and Credit Suisse (Singapore), on Friday announced that BlackRock Inc, an associate of Keppel Corp, now holds some 49.57 million shares in Keppel Land (KepLand), up from 48.05 million shares announced on Thursday.

site_title: China's 2014 fiscal revenue up 8.6% year on year
summary: China's fiscal revenue increased 8.6% year-over-year to 14 trillion yuan in 2014, with total expenditure rising 8.2% to 15.2 trillion yuan. This data may signal slower GDP growth, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: China's fiscal revenue rose 8.6 per cent from a year earlier to 14 trillion yuan (S$3 trillion), the Ministry of Finance said on Friday.

site_title: Greek government set for first talks with eurozone partners
summary: Greece's new anti-austerity government, led by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, is set to hold its first talks with eurozone partners on Friday to discuss its ambitions to reduce its massive debts. The talks come despite warnings from the European Union and Germany that there is little support for reducing the debts, which the government hopes to cut in half. The Greek government has already begun to roll back years of austerity measures and will negotiate with eurozone finance ministers to reach a comprehensive agreement to rebuild its social economy.

site_title: S&P raises rating for Hyundai Motor, Kia
summary: Standard & Poor's upgraded Hyundai Motor Co and Kia Motors Corp's credit rating to A- due to their significant cash piles and stable global market positions. The companies' cash and equivalents total 22.5 trillion won, with a cash flow of 8.3 trillion won from operations. This upgrade is expected to reduce borrowing costs and make Hyundai more competitive in auto financing products, potentially boosting sales. The rating is line with competitors Daimler AG and Nissan Motor Co, but lags Toyota Motor Corp's AA- rating.

images.alt_text: Standard & Poor's upgraded its credit rating for Hyundai Motor Co and sister company Kia Motors Corp on Friday by one notch to A-, citing the companies' significant cash pile as a long-term buffer in the cyclical auto industry.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, YuuZoo, Del Monte
summary: Singtel announced a joint-venture startup, HOOQ, to offer over-the-top video services in Asia with Sony Pictures Television and Warner Bros Entertainment. YuuZoo Corporation signed a new partnership agreement for live game streaming services. Del Monte Pacific obtained approvals for a renounceable underwritten rights issue in Singapore and the Philippines to raise up to S$202.5 million in net proceeds, mainly to repay a bridging facility and deleverage its balance sheet.

site_title: VietJet Air wins US$400m credit line to buy Airbus planes
summary: VietJet Air has secured a US$400 million credit line from Vietnamese lender TPBank until 2020 to purchase Airbus planes under a US$9 billion order. The airline, Vietnam's first privately owned carrier, aims to buy 92 planes by 2024. This agreement follows a US$21 million credit granted by TPBank in September 2014 to aid VietJet Air's downpayment for the Airbus order. VietJet Air currently operates a fleet of 20 Airbus planes, including two new A-320s delivered last year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.53% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.53% in early trading on Friday, mirroring solid gains on Wall Street. The benchmark Hang Seng Index increased 129.34 points to 24,725.19. The gains come after mixed economic data from Japan and ahead of US-EU trade talks. The stock market's resilience is seen as a sign of traders brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Maritime Port Authority of Singapore board gets four new members
summary: The Maritime Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) has appointed four new board members, effective February 2, 2015. The new members include Carl Krogh Arnet, Luke Goh, Kam Soon Huat, and Quek Bin Hwee. Four board members will be stepping down, including Thomas Tay, James Wong, Robert Yap, and Jude Benny, whose appointment will be extended until March 31. The appointments will run for a period of three years.

site_title: Shell says 'optimistic' on US refinery contract talks
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc expressed optimism about reaching a new three-year agreement with the United Steelworkers union representing US refinery workers. The current agreement expires at midnight on Sunday, and the union has rejected two proposals since talks began. The USW is seeking annual pay raises, reduced out-of-pocket healthcare payments, and tighter policies to prevent workplace fatigue. The union has called a day of action in support of its contract proposals, which may lead to a strike. A mutually satisfactory agreement is seen as possible, but the outcome is uncertain.

images.alt_text: Lead industry negotiator Royal Dutch Shell Plc said on Thursday it was "optimistic" a new three-year agreement could be reached with a union representing hourly workers at 63 US refineries that account for two-thirds of US refining capacity.

site_title: Apple's China expansion in retail seeks hires in six new cities
summary: Apple is expanding its retail presence in China, advertising job openings for store workers in six new cities, including Chengdu, Guangzhou, Shenyang, Tianjin, Nanjing, and Dalian. This move aims to more than double the company's stores in the country, with CEO Tim Cook expecting China to surpass the US as its largest market. Apple has already doubled iPhone unit sales in mainland China in the final three months of last year and plans to open 25 more stores in Greater China by mid-2016.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc., aiming to more than double its stores in China, is advertising openings for retail workers in six cities where it currently doesn't have any shops.

site_title: Strange world where stock investors chase dividends, bond investors chase capital gains
summary: US stock investors are chasing dividends, while bond investors are seeking capital gains due to low yields. Fidelity's global chief investment officer Dominic Rossi notes this is a "curious world." The US bull market shows no signs of stopping, with profit margins expected to rise due to low labor costs and a strong US dollar. This could lead to upward pressure on earnings multiples, boosting the market. Despite tariff uncertainty, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records, with investors staying positive.

site_title: Singapore's labour force participation rate rises to new high of 67% in 2014
summary: Singapore's labour force participation rate reached a new high of 67% in 2014, driven by increased participation from women and older residents. The employment rate of residents aged 25-64 rose to 79.7%, while median income continued to rise, with a 1.8% increase in nominal terms and 0.7% in real terms. Over the past five years, median income grew 29% and low-wage workers' income rose 31% in nominal terms, with 12% growth after adjusting for inflation.

site_title: Taiwan Q4 preliminary GDP up 3.17% on year, 2014 growth fastest in three years
summary: Taiwan's economy grew 3.17% year-on-year in Q4 2014, the fastest in three years, according to preliminary GDP figures. This brings full-year growth to 3.51%. The rise was mostly in line with forecast, surpassing the government's estimate of 2.83%.

site_title: Chinese banks back risky stock margin finance in face of regulator crackdown
summary: Chinese banks have increased their involvement in stock margin finance, a practice that allows them to profit from the country's stock market frenzy despite regulatory efforts to curb debt-fueled speculation. Banks have found loopholes to channel credit into the stock market via brokerages, exposing the banking system to greater risks. Margin finance has grown significantly, with 18-20% of loans ending up with banks, and is seen as a major risk if the rally turns into a rout. Regulators have cracked down on credit flows, but Beijing is reluctant to stop margin financing due to its positive impact on the stock market.

site_title: Singapore's unemployment stays low at 2% for 2014
summary: Singapore's unemployment rate remained low at 2.0% overall in 2014, with 2.7% for residents and 2.9% for citizens. Employment growth was higher in the fourth quarter, but lower than in the previous year. Total employment increased by 129,000, while 12,800 workers were laid off. Median monthly income from work rose by 30% in nominal terms and 11% in real terms.

site_title: Singapore banks can withstand pressure from property market correction: Fitch
summary: Singapore's domestic banks, OCBC, DBS, and UOB, are expected to withstand pressure from a property market correction due to relatively healthy household balance sheets and adequate collateralization. Mortgage delinquencies remain extremely low, with a 0.36% rate in Singapore and 0.02% in Hong Kong. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is expected to remain vigilant for signs of stress. Fitch Ratings notes the potential for second-order effects, such as weaker private consumption and rising construction company defaults, but believes the banks' losses from mortgages will be minimal.

site_title: UK consumer confidence posts biggest jump in a year
summary: UK consumer confidence jumped 5 points in January, the largest monthly increase in a year, driven by plummeting oil prices. This boost in consumer sentiment is seen as a welcome news for Prime Minister David Cameron ahead of the May election. The index has returned to its August 2005 level, its highest since 2005. Forecasters predict a similar economic expansion in 2015, fueled by rising wages and low interest rates.

site_title: Japan's factory output rises 1% in December
summary: Japan's factory output increased 1.0% in December from the previous month, surpassing a median market forecast of 1.3%. This rise indicates the economy is slowly recovering. Manufacturers expect a 6.3% increase in January output and a 1.8% decline in February.

site_title: Obama's India visit moves bilateral ties into new trajectory
summary: US President Barack Obama's visit to India marked a significant shift in bilateral ties, with both countries agreeing on key security and technology issues. The US sees India as an alternative power center in Asia, aiming to balance China's dominance. The two nations signed a joint statement on cooperation in maritime security, tackling terrorism, and economic development, including joint development of four frontier defense technologies. The visit also marked progress on the long-stalled nuclear deal, with a compromise formula agreed upon. The visit has created optimism among Indian business leaders, with the potential for increased investment and economic growth.

site_title: Ascott makes first foray into Turkey
summary: The Ascott, a serviced residence business unit of CapitaLand, has secured a contract to manage its first property in Turkey, Somerset Maslak Istanbul. Scheduled to open in 2016, the 159-unit property will be part of an integrated development in Istanbul, expanding The Ascott's presence to 90 cities across 25 countries. This marks a significant entry into the Turkish market, which is seen as an attractive destination for foreign investors due to its strategic location and growing economy.

site_title: China: Shares higher in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares rose 0.62% in morning trade on Friday, following overnight gains in US stocks. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 20.35 points to 3,282.66, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.52% to 1,537.27. The gains were attributed to positive market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Chinese shares were higher in morning trade on Friday following overnight gains in US stocks, dealers said.

site_title: Oil drop puts US$390b hole in investors' pockets since june
summary: US oil investors have seen a total loss of $393 billion since June, with oil prices falling below $45 a barrel. This decline has affected companies in the Bloomberg Intelligence North America Exploration & Production index, with shares declining by 353 billion and high-yield energy bonds losing nearly $40 billion. The crash has caught investors and lenders by surprise, with struggling energy firms seeing their bonds and stocks decline significantly. Institutional investors, including pension funds and insurance companies, have been hit hard, with their energy stock holdings totaling $963 billion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 6.11 points to 1788.29. The index saw 161 gainers and 51 losers, with a total trading volume of 58.29 million lots worth RM32.27 million.

site_title: US: Stocks rally after two down days
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, rebounding from two down days, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 225.48 points to 17,416.85. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose, with analysts citing a modest increase in oil prices as a source of calm. Earnings reports from companies like McDonald's, Boeing, and Apple contributed to the rally, while Alibaba and Qualcomm were negatively impacted by disappointing sales and profit forecasts.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down as risks seen on near-term growth
summary: Taiwan's stocks declined 0.3% on Friday, with the TAIEX index falling 21.79 points to 9405.66, due to risks to near-term growth. The economy grew 3.17% in the fourth quarter, its fastest pace in three years, but the government warned of potential moderation in the first quarter. Electronics stocks, including Pegatron Corp, were buoyed by contract PC sales, while the optoelectronics subindex dropped 0.45%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened against the US dollar.

site_title: US warns Russia, welcomes new EU sanctions
summary: The US has warned Russia that it is considering fresh sanctions over the fighting in Ukraine, following an EU agreement to broaden existing sanctions on Moscow. The US State Department said the EU move was a "positive step" and a "further sign that the actions of the last several days and weeks are absolutely unacceptable." The US has pledged to increase pressure on Russia, with President Barack Obama stating he would consider all available options to address the issue, excluding military confrontation.

site_title: YuuZoo co-founders to launch new live game streaming services
summary: YuuZoo co-founders Thomas Zilliacus and Ron Creevey have signed a partnership agreement to launch live game streaming services via multicast social broadcasting. The services will focus on the world's fastest growing and largest developing markets, leveraging YuuZoo's 85 million registered users and 700 million television viewers. The live streaming will be integrated into YuuZoo's Virtual Shopping Mall, attracting more users and increasing spending. The move aims to capitalize on the rapid growth of game event streaming, following Twitch's recent $1 billion sale.

site_title: Boeing sees Dreamliner sales yielding more cash in 2015
summary: Boeing reported a strong fourth quarter, with its fourth-quarter profit topping analysts' expectations and its stock rising over 6% in early trading. The company forecast better cash flow in 2015, with operating cash flow expected to top $9 billion, and plans to deliver 750-755 commercial planes, up from 723 in 2014. Boeing expects to make a profit on each Dreamliner sale in 2015, with revenue rising to $94.5-96.5 billion.

site_title: Zero profit growth expected for US companies in 1st quarter
summary: US companies are expected to see no earnings growth in the first quarter of 2015, the worst quarter since 2009, due to falling oil prices, a soaring dollar, and weaker global demand. Revenue is forecast to decline 2.0% from a year ago, with energy companies suffering the most. The outlook is bleak for the US stock market, which has started the year off weakly, and analysts predict a storm that could crack the market.

images.alt_text: Falling oil prices, a soaring dollar and concern about weaker global demand have increasingly pessimistic analysts predicting Standard & Poor's 500 companies will see no earnings growth at all in the first quarter of 2015.

site_title: Obama budget seeks boost for military, domestic programmes
summary: US President Barack Obama's 2016 budget proposal calls for a 7% increase in domestic and military spending, aiming to end "sequestration" caps. The budget would fund various programs unlikely to be supported by Republicans, who have rejected previous proposals. The White House hopes to find common ground with lawmakers to prevent sequester cuts from returning. The proposal includes $530 billion in non-defence spending and $561 billion in defence outlays, both above the sequester limits.

site_title: Malaysia tycoon Krishnan to help 1MDB repay RM2b loan: sources
summary: Malaysia's second-richest man, Ananda Krishnan, will lend 1MDB RM2 billion to settle a loan to local banks, helping pave the way for a potential US$3 billion IPO by the state investor. Krishnan is currently negotiating the terms of the loan with 1MDB. The move comes after the state investor missed payments on its RM2 billion bridge loan, fueling investor concerns about Malaysia's economy. The loan is seen as a step towards 1MDB's goal of cutting its debt and expanding its business through an initial public offering.

site_title: China overtakes US as world's top investment magnet
summary: China surpassed the US as the world's top investment magnet last year, with foreign direct investment (FDI) reaching $128 billion, compared to the US' $86 billion. The decline in US FDI was largely due to a Verizon-Vodafone deal that reversed $130 billion of foreign investment. China's FDI growth is driven by investments in the services sector and high-tech manufacturing, with a new draft foreign investment law expected to further liberalize regulations. Global FDI flows fell 8% to $1.26 trillion, the second-lowest level since the financial crisis.

site_title: Singtel in tie-up with Sony Pictures, Warner Bros to offer video services in Asia
summary: Singtel has partnered with Sony Pictures Television and Warner Bros Entertainment to launch HOOQ, a joint-venture startup offering over-the-top video services in Asia. The service will deliver Hollywood blockbusters, TV series, and local content to customers via streaming and download. HOOQ will be rolled out in Singtel's Asian footprint from Q1 2015, with a catalogue of over 10,000 titles. Singtel will provide market access and billing expertise, while the studios will offer premium content and know-how. The partnership aims to meet growing demand for on-demand entertainment in Asia.

site_title: Google takes hit on slower-than-expected growth
summary: Google reported a 41% year-over-year increase in net profit to $4.76 billion in the fourth quarter of 2014, but fell short of market expectations. Revenues rose 15% to $18.1 billion, slower than anticipated due to slowdowns in online advertising metrics. Shares initially fell but later recovered. Analysts attributed the results to a strong dollar and slowing internet growth worldwide, which may lead to Google losing control over its core Android platform and struggling to adapt to changing user behavior.

images.alt_text: Google on Thursday reported that its profit jumped in the recently ended quarter, but the leap fell short of market expectations.

site_title: Yellen tells US senators no rate rise soon amid concerns abroad
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen told Senate Democrats the US economy is improving, but job creation still needs work, and there's concern about the global outlook. Despite this, she expressed no immediate plans for interest rate hikes. The Fed upgraded its assessment of the US economy and mentioned "international developments" as a cause for caution. Economists believe the Fed is likely to raise interest rates this year, but Yellen's comments suggest it's not ignoring the global economic weakness. US stocks rose after the meeting.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen told Senate Democrats she's encouraged by the national economy even as she expressed some concern about the pace of hiring in the US and the weakening global outlook.

site_title: Reddit reveals requests for user data by outside agencies
summary: Reddit released its first transparency report, revealing 55 requests for user data, mostly from law enforcement agencies, and 218 requests for content removal, with 68 complied. The majority of user data requests came from the US, with only five from outside the country. Reddit only provided information in response to slightly more than half the requests and refused to comply on jurisdiction grounds. The report aims to provide insight into the company's efforts to protect user privacy.

site_title: Japan's inflation slows more than forecast
summary: Japan's inflation rate slowed more than forecast in December, rising 2.5% from a year earlier, below the median projection of 2.6%. Core inflation, excluding fresh food, was 0.5%, down from the Bank of Japan's previous forecast. The central bank's chief, Haruhiko Kuroda, will adjust monetary stimulus to keep inflation on track with its 2% goal, as expectations for price gains among companies and consumers deteriorate. Economists predict inflation will continue to slow until it hits bottom around July or August.

site_title: South Korea's December factory output growth at over 5-year high
summary: South Korea's industrial output grew at its fastest pace in over five years in December, rising 3.0% from the previous month, exceeding analyst forecasts. This marked the highest growth since a 3.7% gain in September 2009. On an annual basis, output rose 0.4% in December after a 3.6% fall in November. The growth in industrial output provided some relief to concerns about the country's cooling economy, but service-sector output showed no growth in December.

site_title: New Saudi king announces major government shake-up
summary: Saudi Arabia's King Salman announced a major government shake-up, replacing the Chief of General Intelligence and removing part of his cabinet. Two sons of the late King Abdullah were also fired: Prince Mishaal, governor of Mecca region, and Prince Turki, governor of Riyadh. The move is seen as further entrenching King Salman's power.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's King Salman on Thursday named a new intelligence chief, replaced part of his cabinet and fired two sons of the late king Abdullah in a major government shake-up seen as further entrenching the new monarch's power.

site_title: Ascendas Reit appoints new agent bank, issuing agent
summary: Ascendas Reit appoints Bank of New York Mellon as new issuing and paying agent, effective March 2, replacing OCBC. The London branch will handle non-CDP notes, while the Singapore branch will handle CDP notes. The Bank of New York Mellon is also appointed as A-Reit's new agent bank.

site_title: Ponzi schemer gets 25 years in jail for US$105m fraud
summary: An Illinois man, Daniel Spitzer, was sentenced to 25 years in prison for running a $105 million Ponzi scheme that bilked 280 investors, including his brother-in-law. Spitzer collected money by lying about returns, using the funds to repay other clients. He pleaded guilty to 10 counts and ordered to pay $34 million in restitution. The judge rejected defense claims that Spitzer invested clients' money and imposed a sentence almost as long as prosecutors sought. Spitzer expressed remorse, saying he would assist in making things right.

site_title: Sax to the max
summary: Kenny G, one of the world's best-selling instrumentalists, has released his 14th album, Brazilian Nights, 40 years after his debut. The album marks his first foray into bossa nova, a genre he fell in love with after hearing Cannonball Adderley's version of Corcovado. Comprising half standards and half originals, the 10-track album was inspired by masters such as Adderley, Paul Desmond, and Stan Getz. Kenny G spent 18 months studying bossa nova and composing melodies that come from his heart, solidifying his position as a global artist with 75 million records sold.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Japan to cut beef, pork tariffs, expand rice access in TPP talks
summary: Japan is set to cut its high import tariffs on beef and pork, and ease restrictions on rice imports, in a bid to finalize a Pacific trade deal with the US. The country is prepared to reduce its 38.5% beef tariff to 10% over 10 years, and slash pork duties from 482 yen to tens of yen. Japan will also negotiate expanding "minimum access" quotas for rice, currently protected by 778% tariffs. These concessions come as talks accelerate to seal a bilateral deal, considered key to a Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement among 12 nations.

site_title: Delhi Uber passenger who alleges driver rape sues in US
summary: A Delhi resident sued Uber in US federal court, alleging the company failed to maintain basic safety procedures after she claimed being raped and beaten by an Uber driver in India. The woman seeks an overhaul of Uber's safety practices, including 24-hour customer support and in-car video cameras. The lawsuit comes after Uber was banned in New Delhi following the driver's arrest and amid a global debate about the safety of women in Asia. The woman is seeking unspecified damages from the US-based company, valued at $40 billion.

site_title: Better the regulatory performance, better the quality of the market
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is expanding its regulatory powers to improve enforcement and quality of the market. The new measures include a Listings Disciplinary Committee and Listings Appeals Committee, which will have a wider range of disciplinary actions, including composition fines and public reprimands. The committees will be independent of SGX and their decisions will be transparently published. SGX believes that better regulatory performance will lead to a better quality market and greater benefits to investors. The move aims to address concerns of potential conflicts of interest and maintain public trust in the market.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a close price of S$1.80 on January 29, 2015, with a target price of S$1.86. No recent updates are available from this article.

site_title: Amazon surprises with US$214m quarterly profit
summary: Amazon reported a quarterly profit of US$214 million, exceeding expectations, with sales jumping 15% to US$29.3 billion. The adjusted profit per share was 45 cents, beating the consensus estimate of 17 cents. Amazon's Prime subscription service contributed to the profit, with worldwide paid membership growing 53% last year. The company's investments in online video, smartphones, and delivery drones are expected to continue, despite facing increased competition globally, particularly from China's Alibaba. Amazon's shares rose 7.8% in after-hours trading following the release.

site_title: Nerve and sinew
summary: The Federal Reserve hinted at potential rate hikes in the coming months, despite global turmoil, citing a "solid" US economy with expanding growth, low unemployment, and boosted spending due to cheap oil. However, inflation remains a concern, with core prices increasing slightly faster than expected. The Fed's confidence in the American economy may shield it from international developments, but any changes could be significant. The Fed is poised to raise rates gradually, potentially in June or next year, in contrast to other central banks that have taken more aggressive measures.

site_title: Greece needs a debt service holiday
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras faces a daunting task as he navigates the country's debt crisis. Tsipras must either renege on a large portion of Greece's debt, which could cut the country off from global markets, or ask for a five-year debt service holiday. The latter option would save Greece around 7 billion euros annually and allow it to manage its public finances. However, it may not be enough to meet the demands of Tsipras' voters and could face opposition from creditors, particularly Germany.

site_title: In brief
summary: AirAsia will suspend trading on Friday ahead of a "material announcement", according to the company. Infinio Group entered a conditional cooperation agreement with an Indonesian firm for a gold ore project. Far East Orchard's subsidiary disposed of interests in two properties for S$38.1 million.

site_title: Investors narrow bets to 50-50 on Aussie rate cut next week
