summary: Investors have shifted their bets to a 50-50 chance of a Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) interest rate cut on February 3. The move follows global central banks easing monetary policy to combat falling commodity prices and weak demand. The RBA cash rate is expected to be cut by a quarter of a point, with some economists predicting two cuts this year. The decision is influenced by global trends, including the US Federal Reserve's dovish policy statement and the European Central Bank's sovereign debt purchases.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close mostly up
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mostly up on Thursday, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris' CAC 40 indices rising 0.25% and 0.44% respectively. London's FTSE 100 slipped 0.22% due to low crude prices. Despite the decline, overall gains were driven by mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: McDonald's CEO Don Thompson leaving after tumultuous run
summary: McDonald's CEO Don Thompson will leave the company at the end of February, replacing chief brand officer Steve Easterbrook, who led the UK business to a turnaround. Easterbrook's experience in turning around the UK business and leading digital initiatives will be crucial in addressing McDonald's weak sales and declining market share in the US. The company's shares jumped 3.2% following the announcement, with analysts praising Easterbrook's track record and ability to drive growth. The challenge for Easterbrook will be to revive McDonald's brand and drive same-store sales growth in a competitive market.

site_title: SMRT Q3 earnings up 58.4% at S$22.6m
summary: SMRT Corp reported a 58.4% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$22.55 million for Q3 FY15, driven by improved performances in its fare business and non-fare segment. Revenue rose 6.8% to S$313.19 million, while operating profit from the non-fare business surged 54.4% to S$31.04 million. Despite cost pressures, SMRT expects the impact to be partially mitigated by fare adjustments and productivity efforts.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Apple pips Hermes as No 1 luxury gift in China
summary: Apple surpassed Hermes as the No 1 luxury gift in China, according to a Hurun luxury report, with a 70% rise in sales in the last three months of 2014. This comes as spending on gift-giving dropped 5% in 2014, and domestic luxury spending in China dipped for the first time. The report also found that 7 out of 10 luxury goods bought by Chinese are now purchased overseas, changing the dynamics of luxury in China.

site_title: Big banks fail to stop US currency rigging lawsuit
summary: A federal judge ruled that US investors can pursue a nationwide antitrust lawsuit against 12 major banks, including Bank of America, Barclays, and JPMorgan Chase, for allegedly rigging the US$5.3 trillion foreign exchange market. The lawsuit, filed in 2013, alleges that the banks conspired to manipulate currency rates since 2003, using tactics such as "front running" and "banging the close." The judge rejected the banks' arguments that there was a lack of evidence, stating that the complaint "fairly read" alleges a long-running conspiracy to manipulate the market to the banks' advantage.

site_title: IMF seeks deadline on governance changes after US impasse
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is seeking a five-month deadline to adopt a temporary alternative to governance changes blocked by US lawmakers. The changes, approved in 2010, would increase the proportion of quotas held by emerging markets such as China, India, and Brazil. The IMF plans to impose an interim solution by June 30 as its board examines alternatives, including a threat to end the US veto power. The US Treasury Department supports the changes, while Republicans in Congress have blocked ratification, citing a general aversion to foreign aid and bailouts.

site_title: Philippine growth up for best three years since mid-1950s
summary: The Philippine economy experienced its best three-year expansion since the mid-1950s, with a 6.9% growth in the last quarter of 2014. This surpassed economists' expectations and beat the previous quarter's 5.3% growth. The country's industrial production and government spending also rose, while inflation is expected to ease. The government aims to reach 7-8% growth this year and next, with low oil prices helping to boost consumption and slow inflation. The benchmark stock index rose, and the peso weakened slightly.

site_title: Japan's Skymark files for bankruptcy after A380 buying plan fails
summary: Japan's Skymark Airlines Inc, the country's third-largest carrier, filed for bankruptcy protection after failing to purchase six Airbus A380 superjumbos. The airline had 71 billion yen (S$814 million) in liabilities and will be delisted on March 1. Skymark had struggled to compete with Japan's two largest carriers, Japan Airlines and ANA, and had sought tie-ups with them to survive. The airline will keep all employees in their jobs and meet creditors on February 4.

site_title: From world-class races to heart-racing pageants
summary: The Singapore Turf Club is organizing four major racing events in May, including the Singapore Airlines International Cup, Krisflyer Sprint, Longines Singapore Gold Cup, and the Emirates Singapore Derby. The events, which take place on May 18, offer significant purses, including S$3 million for the SAIC and S$1 million for the Krisflyer Sprint. The Turf Belles beauty pageant and the Emirates Singapore Derby also take place on the same day, with purses of S$6,000 and S$1.15 million, respectively. The events are expected to attract a large crowd, with guests encouraged to attend in their finest outfits.

images.alt_text: Bel Sprinter, Australian candidate for the Singapre Airlines (SIA) Cup/Krisflyer Sprint 2013, on the Polytrack at the Singapore Turf Club on May 16, 2013.

site_title: Fed change of language raises rate worries
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a weak session on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index slipping 0.10 points to 3,419.05, amid cautious sentiment following the US Federal Reserve's hawkish statement. The Fed's change in language raised concerns about potential interest rate hikes, leading to a decline in stocks and an increase in bond yields. The 30-year Treasury yield dropped to a record low of 2.3%, while the 10-year yield fell to its lowest level since May 2013.

site_title: Labyrinthine plot twists for a pothead private eye
summary: Inherent Vice, a long, complex film by Paul Thomas Anderson, revolves around a private eye named Doc Sportello who investigates a mysterious disappearance in 1970s Los Angeles. Doc, a pothead, gets caught up in a plot involving murder, kidnapping, and deceit, along with a cast of flawed characters. The film's convoluted plot may leave the audience dazed, and its conclusion may not make sense. Director Anderson's masterful storytelling is put to the test in this challenging and indulgent film.

images.alt_text: Forever high Larry "Doc" Sportello (Joaquin Phoenix seen with Katherine Waterston) tries his best to stay awake.

site_title: Midas Holdings' JV bags China train deal
summary: Midas Holdings' Sino-foreign joint venture, Nanjing SR Puzhen Rail Transport Co, has secured a 1.73 billion yuan contract with Shanghai Rail Transit Line 13 Development Co for Shanghai Metro Line 13 Phases 2 and 3. The contract, valued at S$374.7 million, is expected to contribute positively to Midas Holdings' financial performance for FY16 and FY17. The company's CEO, Patrick Chew, believes NPRT is well-positioned to ride the positive trend in China's passenger rail industry.

site_title: Side-splitting outing with comedian Burr
summary: Bill Burr, a 46-year-old American comedian, will perform in Singapore for the first time next week. He is known for his "uninformed logic" comedy style, which has made him a favorite on American television. Burr has appeared on various talk shows, including David Letterman, Conan O'Brien, and Jimmy Fallon, and has recorded four comedy specials. He will perform at Kallang Theatre on February 6.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Burgundy bounty of 2005
summary: A recent wine-tasting session of 2005 White Burgundy Premier Cru wines showcased the vintage's quality and potential. The tasting featured 12 wines from various producers, with three standing out: Domaine Henri Boillot's Puligny-Montrachet Les Pucelles, Domaine Louis Carillon ET Fils' Puligny-Montrachet Les Perrieres, and Maison Roche de Bellene's Chassagne-Montrachet Les Macherelles. However, one wine was corked and another oxidized, highlighting the importance of proper storage. Overall, the vintage is considered worthy of its reputation, with many wines still young and fresh, but some requiring further ageing.

images.alt_text: Three wines stood out from the 12 that were tasted: the Boillot Puligny Pucelles, Carillon's Puligny Perrieres, and Roche de Bellene's Chassagne Macherelles, the last being especially noteworthy as it is from a negociant house, and a new one at that.

site_title: Malaysia short sellers target record equity rally
summary: Malaysia's record equity rally is under threat as short sellers target the country's shares, with short interest in the iShares MSCI Malaysia ETF doubling to 20% of outstanding shares. The benchmark equity index has advanced 116% from its 2008 low, but analysts predict the weakest profit growth since 2009 and overseas investors are pulling money from the market. The government has cut its 2015 economic growth forecast to 4.5% and predicted a bigger budget deficit. Short sellers are betting on deteriorating fundamentals, but some investors remain optimistic, citing the nation's shares trading at a 33% premium.

site_title: Greece puts austerity on trial
summary: Greece's left-wing party Syriza has won the country's election, prompting a shift in the debate on austerity measures. The new government, led by Alexis Tsipras, proposes renegotiating Greece's public debt and slowing state-owned business privatization. The move is seen as a challenge to Europe's austerity policies, which have been criticized for causing economic pain. The European Troika, comprising the European Commission, ECB, and IMF, will negotiate with Greece to resolve their differences, with failure potentially leading to catastrophic consequences for the country, including a possible exit from the euro.

site_title: BOE governor urges eurozone to take the plunge on fiscal union
summary: Bank of England governor Mark Carney urged the eurozone to adopt fiscal union to escape its debt trap, citing the need for more supportive fiscal policy. He criticized the eurozone for failing to act on reforms, including making the single currency area more like the US, where states cushion each other against economic shocks. Carney suggested options for sharing fiscal risks, including a transfer union or pooled employment insurance mechanism, to help countries hit hardest by the eurozone debt crisis and achieve stronger growth.

site_title: SIA, Vistara launch frequent flyer tie-up
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Vistara, its joint venture airline, have launched a partnership between their frequent flyer programmes, KrisFlyer and Club Vistara. KrisFlyer members can earn miles on Vistara flights and redeem Vistara tickets with their miles, while Club Vistara members can redeem points on SIA and SilkAir flights. The tie-up starts in March and allows for miles and points accrual and redemption from May. This partnership aims to create greater synergies between SIA's airlines, following similar partnerships with Scoot and Tiger Airways.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Subsidies for first 2 years of MediShield Life scheme increased
summary: Singapore citizens will receive higher transitional subsidies for the first two years of MediShield Life, a universal health insurance scheme. In the first year, they will receive a 90% subsidy, and in the second year, a 70% subsidy. This is higher than the earlier announced rate of 80% and 60%, respectively. The subsidies will be phased out in the fifth year, but lower-to-middle income households will continue to benefit from premium subsidies.

site_title: Seeing the 'forest' for the trees
summary: Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%, below forecast, while the country's agency is set to seize approximately RM3 billion of assets from Daim Zainuddin. Meanwhile, GoTo shares are expected to rebound after a $2.2 billion sell-off. Foreign investors have also returned to Vietnam, boosting stocks. The SMCCI and Maybank have signed a MOU to support Malay or Muslim-owned enterprises in Singapore and Malaysia. A rate cut has been implemented, signaling growth jitters amidst tariff threats, aiming to shield the economy.

site_title: 13,000 hipsters rock to Laneway 2015
summary: Thousand hipsters attended the 2015 St Jerome's Laneway Festival in Singapore, enjoying a diverse musical lineup and affordable food options. The event featured 19 acts across three stages, with amenities such as charging stations and a barber shop. Despite some logistical challenges, including set time clashes and inclement weather, the festival was deemed a success, with attendees praising the event's organization and overall experience. The festival has set a high standard for future events, offering a unique experience beyond just music.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Frasers Hospitality beats forecasts in maiden results
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust has announced a distribution income of S$35.7 million for the period July 14 to Dec 31, 2014, exceeding forecasts by 5.3%. Gross revenue was S$50.2 million, in line with expectations, while net property income was S$41.8 million, 2.3% above forecasts. The trust expects to commence asset enhancement plans for InterContinental Singapore in April and faces headwinds from the increasing supply of hotel rooms in Singapore.

site_title: Oil prices seen recovering in H1 this year
summary: Harold Hamm, CEO of Continental Resources Inc, predicts oil prices will recover in the first half of 2015 as producers cut back and drillers reduce spending by 50-75%. Continental will idle wells and reduce spending by 41% to $2.7 billion, with production increasing by 20% this year. Hamm expects other drillers to follow suit, leading to a quicker recovery in oil prices. Despite low prices, Continental can weather the downturn due to its low debt-to-equity ratio and healthy credit line.

site_title: Visa reports better-than-expected quarterly profit
summary: Visa Inc, the world's largest credit and debit card company, reported a better-than-expected quarterly profit of $1.57 billion, or $2.53 per share, driven by a strengthening US job market and cheaper gasoline prices. Total operating revenue rose 7% to $3.38 billion, and cross-border volume growth was 8% on a constant dollar basis. The company reaffirmed its 2015 revenue and margin forecasts despite a 2 percentage point negative impact from foreign exchange rate changes. Visa's shares rose 4.4% in extended trading after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Visa Inc, the world's largest credit and debit card company, reported a better-than-expected quarterly profit as a strengthening US job market and cheaper gasoline prices encouraged people to spend.

site_title: Joy ride
summary: Equestrian sports in Singapore are experiencing a surge in popularity, with clubs reporting higher membership numbers and increased interest from Singaporeans. The Year of the Horse has contributed to this trend, as well as improved facilities and accessibility. While horse ownership remains expensive, with prices ranging from $5,000 to $500,000, leasing and purchasing retrained horses from other sports, such as polo or racing, are becoming more affordable options. The sport is attracting working professionals seeking exercise and mental well-being benefits, with riders citing improved posture, balance, and focus as benefits of horse riding.

images.alt_text: Therecia Tay (above), marketing manager for luxury house Chanel, spends a chunk of her free time with Hofdame, her prized Hanoverian mare, as the duo gallop the grounds of the Bukit Timah Saddle Club, breathing new life into the equestrian sport.

Therecia Tay, marketing manager for luxury house Chanel, spends a chunk of her free time with Hofdame, her prized Hanoverian mare, as the duo gallop the grounds of the Bukit Timah Saddle Club (above), breathing new life into the equestrian sport.
Riders going through the paces at the Singapore Turf Club.

site_title: Existing home sales fall most in a year in Dec
summary: Existing US home sales contracts fell 3.7% in December, the largest decline in a year, according to the National Association of Realtors. The drop was attributed to fewer available properties, higher prices, and tight credit, but employment gains and low mortgage rates are expected to sustain demand. The industry's recovery remains uneven, with first-time buyers remaining reluctant to enter the market.

site_title: Changi Airport handles record 54.1m passengers in 2014
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore handled a record 54.1 million passengers in 2014, with a modest 0.7% year-on-year growth. Cargo also increased by 0.3%. Despite challenges in Southeast Asia, including travel demand slumps in China and Thailand, air traffic to South Asia and North-east Asia rose 6% and 4% respectively. Dubai International Airport became the world's busiest airport with over 70 million passengers, surpassing Heathrow. Changi Airport Group aims to boost capacity to 135 million by 2025 with new terminals and attractions like Jewel, set to open by 2018.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Doomed jet rose to unauthorised altitude rapidly
summary: Indonesian investigators have described the final moments of AirAsia Flight 8501, which crashed into the ocean on December 28, killing 162 people. The plane, operated by an Indonesian affiliate of Malaysia-based AirAsia, climbed to an unauthorized altitude of 37,400 feet in 30 seconds before descending slowly for three minutes before disappearing. The pilots were conscious and trying to control the aircraft, with the co-pilot at the controls and the captain monitoring. Satellite images show storm clouds reaching as high as 44,000 feet. The cause of the crash remains unclear, with authorities ruling out terrorism and concluding that the plane likely stalled after climbing steeply.

site_title: EU tries rebooting the economy
summary: The European Union is attempting to reboot its economy by doubling down on debt with new strategies for job creation, sustainability, and innovation. Despite stagnant growth and a dire economic situation, the EU is committed to reaching five ambitious objectives by 2020, including employment, innovation, education, social inclusion, and climate/energy. The EU aims to create a smart, sustainable, and inclusive economy by protecting the environment, reducing resource use, and promoting resource efficiency. Key measures include tradable permits, increased recycling, and reduced energy consumption, with a focus on conserving resources and minimizing waste.

site_title: China launches new probe into margin trading
summary: China's stock regulator has launched a new probe into brokerages that engage in margin trading, amid concerns of over-leveraging and vulnerability to a market crash. The investigation will inspect 46 companies, following a previous crackdown on three top brokerages. Banks have also been ordered to tighten lending supervision to prevent loans from being used for stock market speculation. The move aims to manage risks in the market, which has surged by 40% since November, with outstanding margin loans reaching record highs.

site_title: Malaysia declares MH370 an accident, its passengers dead
summary: Malaysia has declared Flight MH370 an accident, presumed dead, to facilitate family assistance and compensation. The Boeing 777-200 vanished on March 8, 2014, while en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing, with no distress signal. Investigators conclude the jet flew back over Malaysia and into the Indian Ocean before crashing into the sea. The search remains a priority, with Australia leading efforts to locate debris. Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak stated the plane was deliberately steered off course, and the government assures families the search will continue.

site_title: CapitaRetail China Trust ready for asset growth; Q4 DPU up 12.7%
summary: CapitaRetail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 12.7% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.48 Singapore cents in the fourth quarter, driven by strong portfolio income. The Reit manager is "geared for growth" with potential targets on the table, but is cautious about acquisitions. CRCT's annualised distribution yield is 5.7%, and its net property income (NPI) grew 30.1% year on year to S$33.5 million. The Reit manager plans to apply its distribution reinvestment plan (DRP) to the distributions for the second half of 2014.

site_title: US firms urge China to defer new cybersecurity rules
summary: US business groups, including the American Chamber of Commerce in China, have urged China to delay new cybersecurity regulations that would require technology vendors to hand over source code and adopt Chinese encryption algorithms. The rules, approved by China's Central Leading Small Group for Cyberspace Affairs, would also force US tech vendors to set up research and development centers in China and obtain permits for workers servicing technology equipment. The groups warned that the regulations would harm China's economic growth and limit access to secure technologies.

site_title: Tuan Sing's Q4 profit dips 4% to S$24.3m (Amended)
summary: Tuan Sing's Q4 net profit fell 4% to S$24.34 million due to higher operating expenses and finance costs, despite a 72% year-on-year surge in revenue to S$112.1 million. The company's full-year revenue grew 17% to S$354.8 million, while net profit rose 18% to S$61.2 million, driven by strong contributions from its property division. The group is cautiously optimistic about achieving satisfactory operational performance in 2015.

site_title: Kooky couple who shocked US art world
summary: The film "Big Eyes" tells the true story of Walter and Margaret Keane, an art couple whose Big Lie, involving the creation and sale of their popular "big-eyed" portraits, shocked the US art world. The case, which took place in the 1950s and 60s, raises questions about the line between art and commerce. The film, directed by Tim Burton, explores the couple's force of personality that subjugated the truth, and their instance of art fraud that garnered significant attention. The story is set against the backdrop of growing affluence and a desire for display among the American public.

site_title: IMF calls for debt securitisation to be revived
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is calling for the revival of debt securitization, citing its potential to boost bank lending, particularly to credit-starved small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The IMF argues that the practice, which was criticized for its role in the 2008 global financial crisis, was not the problem itself, but rather the abuse of it. The IMF sees debt securitization as a tool to promote economic growth and financial stability.

images.alt_text: Debt securitisation earned itself a bad name from the global financial crisis of 2008, but the International Monetary Fund (IMF) is now seeking to reform and rehabilitate the practice on the grounds that it can bolster economic growth and the stability of the financial system.

site_title: Obama set to propose spending boost in next budget
summary: US President Barack Obama is set to propose a major spending boost in his fiscal 2016 budget, aiming to increase discretionary spending by up to $68 billion, a 7% increase above sequestration levels. The proposal, to be released on February 2, includes funding for domestic programs and the military, and will be met with opposition from Republican lawmakers who want to make deeper cuts to federal spending. The budget submission marks the beginning of a nine-month battle over the federal government's bottom line, with Republicans expected to write their own version in response.

site_title: Alibaba's Q3 profit misses estimates
summary: Alibaba's Q3 profit missed estimates, falling 28% to 5.98 billion yuan due to compensation expenses and a one-time charge. Revenue was 26.2 billion yuan, lower than the estimated 27.6 billion yuan. The company's mobile ad revenue growth may slow due to lower ad space and fees. Alibaba faces a credibility crisis in China, with the government accusing the company of allowing unauthorised merchants and selling counterfeit goods. Shares fell 8% in pre-market trading.

images.alt_text: Mr Ma is investing in shopping apps and platforms to reach a target of working with more than 10 million small businesses outside China.

site_title: Tiny satellites for weather prediction?
summary: Spire, a satellite-powered data company, plans to launch a network of nanosatellites to provide unparalleled insight into weather and climate changes. The shoebox-sized satellites, costing a fraction of traditional satellites, will measure temperature, pressure, and humidity with higher accuracy and resolution. This could mitigate the US$5.7 trillion annual impact of weather on the US economy and improve forecasting. The network will also aid in environmental protection and security, such as tracking illegal fishing and burning, and could be upgraded every two years to keep up with rapid technological advancements.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Thakral subsidiary to acquire property investment unit
summary: Thakral Corporation's wholly-owned subsidiary, Thakral Capital Holdings, has entered into a share sale agreement to acquire 49% of Thakral Capital Australia's share capital from four vendors. The acquisition will see Thakral's shareholding interest in Thakral Capital Australia diluted by up to 25% upon completion. The merger is expected to consolidate the Thakral investment division's business and enhance the value of the merged entity. Shareholder approval is required for the proposed acquisition, adoption of the Thakral Capital Holdings Employee Share Option Scheme, and consequent dilution.

site_title: Kaisa woes: junk-rated China developers face crisis
summary: Kaisa Group, a Chinese property developer, faces a debt crisis after missing a US$26 million interest payment on its bonds due to mature in 2020. Standard & Poor's Ratings Services downgraded Kaisa to SD or selective default, warning of potential financing difficulties for other developers with weak liquidity and high refinancing needs. A default could result in low recovery rates for bond holders, with less than 20% seen in other default cases. The crisis has affected the sector, with debt issuance by junk-rated issuers coming to a halt.

site_title: Fed policy fails to stem Dow's biggest two-day sell-off
summary: The US Federal Reserve failed to stabilize the stock market, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average experiencing its biggest two-day sell-off in a year, despite a vow of patience on interest rates and record earnings from the world's largest company. The Dow sank 2.8% during the two-day policy meeting, while the Standard & Poor's 500 Index fell 1.4%. Investors are focusing on company earnings, with some economists suggesting the Fed's decision may not be as sensitive to low inflation as previously thought.

site_title: Tembusu raises S$1.2m for cryptocurrency development
summary: Tembusu Systems, a Singapore-based cryptocurrency startup, has raised S$1.2 million in bridge funding, bringing the company's valuation to S$11 million. The funding will be used for product and business development, and to expand the team. The company has recalled its Bitcoin ATMs to focus on its core product, the Trust platform, which offers innovative features such as proof-of-identity and pre-paid wallets. Trust aims to solve challenges faced by first-generation blockchain technology, enabling governments and corporations to launch their own asset-backed cryptocurrencies and payment-processing systems.

site_title: Incentives galore for new US homebuyers
summary: US builders are offering incentives, such as discounts and freebies, to attract new homebuyers amid a buyers' market. The move aims to boost revenue, offsetting narrowing profit margins due to rising land and labor costs. Sales of new houses are expected to increase 26% this year, driven by job growth, rising consumer confidence, and low mortgage rates. Builders like D.R. Horton and KB Home are adjusting prices to meet sales goals, with some offering discounts to attract buyers. However, the ability of builders to increase sales depends on the US economy, which is mixed.

site_title: UK home prices rise at slowest annual pace in 14 months
summary: UK home prices rose 0.3% in January, the fourth consecutive monthly increase, but at their slowest annual pace in 14 months. The 6.8% annual gain is the lowest since November 2013. The slowdown in housing market activity and low new buyer enquiries have led to this decline. Despite this, an improving labour market and shortage of homes for sale are expected to support future demand. The average house price stood at £188,446.

site_title: Artful utopia in nature
summary: Contemporary artist Maryanto showcases his intimate sketches of nature at Gillman Barracks during Singapore Art Week. The series, titled "In a Space of Exception," invites viewers to contemplate a utopian space teeming with life. The artist draws inspiration from nature, using graphite, watercolor, and other mediums to create detailed and charming pieces. Two drawings, "The Sisyphus Stone Is Not There" and "The Sisyphus Stone Is Not There Either," have a more political slant, critiquing corruption in Indonesia and the futility of struggling against it.

images.alt_text: Indonesian artist Maryanto's nature sketches are perhaps the "tamer" of his works, a departure from the grim, fable-like drawings portraying the effects of economic activity on the urban landscape.

site_title: BOJ freezes monetary easing as Abe advisers urge caution
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has put monetary policy on hold, defying expectations of another stimulus package, amid concerns that further easing could drive the yen to damagingly low levels. Advisers to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, including Economics Minister Akira Amari, have urged caution, citing the yen's recent rise and potential offsetting effects on consumer purchasing power. The BOJ, led by Governor Haruhiko Kuroda, may hold policy steady until October, months after many economists expect it to be eased, as oil prices continue to fall and inflation expectations remain low.

site_title: Art on an experimental, experiential pivot
summary: Singapore's Gillman Barracks, an experimental art enclave, is set to become a destination in itself with plans to expand its space and host a Request for Proposal for a new creative business development. Not-for-profit organization Platform Projects has launched the Lohia Mentorship Series, pairing a mid-career Singaporean artist with acclaimed Indian artist Jitish Kallat. Local artist Wong Lip Chin's solo show, "Thousand Knives," features immersive installations that engage the audience's senses, marking a new era of experimental art in Singapore, where he feels more freedom to push boundaries and prioritize artistic expression over commercial success.

site_title: When real life is reflected on stage
summary: Local actors make their debut with Pangdemonium in the comedy drama "Circle Mirror Transformation," which kicks off the company's 2015 season. The play, written by Pulitzer Prize-winner Annie Baker, follows a group of individuals taking an acting class, blurring the lines between their real lives and theatrical performances. The cast, including veteran actors Adrian Pang and Neo Swee Lin, and newcomers Nikki Muller and Selma Alkaff, bring to life the story of lost souls seeking change and new beginnings. The play runs at DBS Arts Centre until February 15.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC posts US$3.5m Q4 profit
summary: STATS ChipPAC, a Singaporean semiconductor packaging and test services company, reported a net income of US$3.5 million for the fourth quarter of 2014, reversing a US$12.1 million loss from the same period last year. Revenue rose slightly to US$406.7 million, driven by higher wireless communications revenue. The company ended the year with a net loss of US$21.8 million and US$1.59 billion in revenue, marginally lower than the previous year.

site_title: Higher Optus Centre valuation boosts AA Reit's Q3 DPU
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) posted a 2.83 Singapore cent DPU for Q3, a 2.2% increase from the previous year. The higher distribution was boosted by a 21% rise in unitholder distribution to S$17.7 million and a 21% increase in the valuation of its Optus Centre stake in Sydney to A$195 million. The Reit's gross revenue rose 8.8% and net property income grew 9.7%. Despite increased space supply, the Reit remains cautiously optimistic for the year, with a diversified portfolio and improved financial flexibility.

site_title: City buzz
summary: In Singapore, a pop-up market called Lepak is being held at the National Museum of Singapore on January 31, featuring local vendors, food, and a movie screening. The event, organized by The Kueh Kakis, aims to celebrate the spirit of "lepak," or socializing with friends over drinks and food. Meanwhile, a carpooling app called Tripda has launched in Singapore, offering a community-moderated platform for users to find and book rides. Additionally, the month of February is being promoted as "Singavore Month," encouraging people to eat local produce and supporting local farmers.

images.alt_text: The pop-up event is organised by The Kueh Kakis, a newly formed pop-up events organiser, made up of a group of pals who work in the media, F&B and design and culture community
Tripda works on a community- moderated platform such as Airbnb or Uber, where users' reviews and ratings are what will make or break a driver
Portico will be serving Pan- seared Pulau Ubin Sea Bass, using fish from a marine farm in Singapore, and herbs grown in Portico's own garden
Japanese composer and multi-instrumentalist, Otomo Yoshihide
POMI-T health supplement promotion

site_title: Creative loss deepens to US$9.19m for Q2
summary: Creative Technology reported a net loss of US$9.19 million in Q2 FY15, down from US$4.17 million in the same period a year ago. Revenue decreased to US$31.3 million, compared to US$37.79 million in Q2 FY14. The company warned that H2 revenue may be below target, with operating loss similar to that in H1, due to uncertain and difficult market conditions.

site_title: Facebook's revenue up, but expenses rose faster
summary: Facebook reported a 49% increase in revenue for the fourth quarter, exceeding Wall Street's expectations, with $3.85 billion in revenue and $701 million in net income. However, expenses rose 87% due to a significant increase in stock payouts to employees. The company's mobile advertising revenue accounted for 69% of its total advertising revenue. Despite strong video engagement, analysts question the accuracy of the numbers due to algorithm manipulation. Facebook is investing heavily in measurement technology to prove ad effectiveness, but is not rushing to monetize its separate services, including Instagram and WhatsApp.

site_title: Can Singapore lead in global health?
summary: Singapore is poised to play a key role in global health efforts, having established 10 collaborating centers with the World Health Organization (WHO) and hosting major health conferences in February. The country's track record in healthcare and medical research is recognized globally, with a 6th-ranked health system efficiency and one of the highest life expectancies at birth. However, global health challenges, such as infectious diseases, require international cooperation and collaboration. Singapore's role in bio-surveillance, disease control, and response to global health threats will be highlighted through the Raffles Dialogue and Ministerial Health Summit.

site_title: America's home-improvement industry gets a major boost
summary: US home renovation spending is expected to reach a record this year, driven by homeowners choosing to remodel rather than move due to low interest rates and rising rents. The industry is expected to grow, with homeowners in metropolitan areas accounting for the majority of spending, and the average homeowner spending around $5,000 on improvements in cities like Washington, DC. Shares of home-improvement chains Lowe's and Home Depot have surged in recent years, and the industry is expected to be bolstered by factors such as job growth and low oil prices.

site_title: New McDonald's boss has the right ingredients
summary: McDonald's new CEO Steve Easterbrook, a veteran of the company, is set to lead the struggling fast-food chain after a week of weak results and a food safety scandal. Easterbrook, who joined in 1993, has been spearheading efforts to reinvent the brand and menu. The company faces a supersize challenge, including tough competition from fast-casual competitors like Chipotle and a backlash against fatty foods. Easterbrook's past experience running hip UK restaurants and his efforts to reinvent the brand may help McDonald's adapt to changing consumer tastes and revive sales.

site_title: Hollywood's 'bank to the stars' sees London expansion under RBC
summary: Royal Bank of Canada (RBC) is set to expand its entertainment business in London, with City National Corp, a "bank to the stars," potentially becoming the premier entertainment bank in the English-speaking world. RBC acquired City National for $5.4 billion, offering the opportunity to establish a private bank and entertainment bank in London within five years. This expansion aims to tap into the UK film industry, which contributed £2.9 billion to the economy in 2012, and Canada's entertainment industry, with Vancouver and Toronto being key hubs.

site_title: Forest City: Healthy foreign investment or blight on Iskandar?
summary: A mega development, Forest City, is set to rise in southwest Johor Bahru, Malaysia, on nearly 2,000 hectares of land, including reclaimed land. Led by China's Country Garden Holdings, the project aims to be a "very high-end" luxury development with spacious villas and water features. However, concerns over the project's environmental impact and potential loss of livelihood for native residents have sparked worries about the real estate market and Iskandar's growth prospects. The project's approval has raised concerns of a real estate glut in the region, with property prices already sliding and local developers deferring launches and slashing sales projections.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Push for greater govt role in home finance
summary: A group of investors at a conference on housing finance have promoted "lease purchase" schemes, which allow tenants to rent a home with the option to buy it at a later date, often with the owner covering costs such as taxes and maintenance. The product is touted as a way to increase profits for investors, but critics argue it exploits consumers' lack of financial savvy, with many tenants unable to afford the down payment. The US is facing a shortage of rental housing, and the influx of financial firms has raised concerns about neglect of home maintenance. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is needed to protect tenants, while there is debate about the government's role in housing finance.

site_title: Greek banks rebound as Athens clarifies remarks
summary: Greek bank stocks rebounded 18.1% on Thursday after the government clarified remarks made by ministers, including a pledge to increase the minimum wage and halt privatisations, which had sparked a sell-off. The sell-off followed statements by new ministers, including a pledge to increase the minimum wage and to halt privatisations, amid uncertainty over the country's financing prospects under the Syriza-led government. The government's initial statements have reinforced fears that negotiations with creditors will be difficult, with Standard & Poor's warning of a possible credit rating cut.

site_title: Taste of the Anti-Cafe
summary: Singapore's first timed cafe, Coffeemin, has introduced a unique concept where customers pay for the time they spend, rather than ordering food and drinks. Customers are charged S$6 for the first hour and S$1 for every subsequent 10 minutes, capped at S$30 for a full day. This fee covers unlimited snacks, drinks, and facilities such as WiFi and board games. The concept has been popular among foreigners, but locals are still accepting it, with a high return rate. Another timed cafe, the halal Wednesday Cafe, has also opened in Tanjong Katong Road with similar pricing.

site_title: Outlook for hedge funds is about to worsen: Citigroup
summary: Citigroup predicts a worsening outlook for hedge funds, citing a 30% decline in industrywide profits in 2014 to $21.9 billion. Hedge funds returned an average 1.4% in 2014, their sixth straight year of underperforming US stocks. Smaller funds, with $100 million in assets, are particularly at risk due to operating shortfalls, totaling $615 million. The industry's shift to larger managers and record-high assets has increased management fees, now accounting for 2.5 times more of total profit than performance fees.

site_title: Samsung Q4 profit meets guidance; outlook cautious
summary: Samsung Electronics reported its first annual earnings decline in three years, with Q4 operating profit of 5.3 trillion won, in line with guidance. The semiconductor division's profit was a bright spot, while the mobile division saw a 64% decline in earnings due to weak smartphone sales. Despite higher average prices for the Galaxy Note 4, Samsung's smartphone and tablet shipments declined. Apple's market share in South Korea reached a record 33% and its gains in China suggest it is rapidly gaining ground on Samsung. The company's 2014 profit fell to 25 trillion won.

site_title: MAS surprise on S$ also reflects low pricing power of local companies
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) surprised the market by easing monetary policy and allowing the Singapore dollar to appreciate at a slower pace, citing disinflationary pressures from global oil price drops and the US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hikes. The move reflects the low pricing power of local companies, with MAS noting that wage pressures from the tight labor market have not yet passed through to consumer prices. The MAS also raised concerns about the health of Singapore's businesses, which may be facing poor consumption demand and escalating costs.

site_title: When Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 disappeared
summary: Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 vanished on March 8, 2014, after changing course an hour after takeoff from Kuala Lumpur, resulting in the deaths of all 239 people on board. Despite extensive searches by 26 countries, no wreckage was found, with the plane believed to have plunged into the southern Indian Ocean due to a sudden loss of oxygen. The investigation suggests the plane continued to fly on automatic pilot until fuel ran out, with the most credible explanation being a fall in oxygen levels rendering the crew and passengers unconscious.

site_title: China said to summon banks to stress push against foreign tech
summary: China's China Banking Regulatory Commission summoned banks to stress the need to cut reliance on foreign technology, following a national strategy to purge foreign tech by 2020. The directive, aimed at domestic products or foreign brands that comply with government demands, threatens sales for foreign companies like Microsoft, IBM, and Cisco. US business groups have expressed concern over the move, citing concerns about security, global market isolation, and the impact on cybersecurity. China has seen a surge in sales of domestic servers and technology products, with Inspur and Huawei Technologies Co posting significant increases.

site_title: 99.co gets Series A funds, expands scope
summary: Property search portal 99.co has raised S$2 million in Series A funding from Sequoia Capital and Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin, taking its total investment to S$2.7 million. The startup aims to improve the apartment hunting experience with a simple, beautiful search experience, prioritizing the end-consumer. It will expand its offerings to include properties for sale and features an elegant, intuitive map-based search powered by its proprietary "ListRank" algorithm. The service is free for users, and agents will be charged S$35 a month for listing privileges after a six-month free trial.

images.alt_text: Property search portal 99.co, the latest venture by serial entrepreneur Darius Cheung (left), has raised S$2 million in Series A funding from investors such as Sequoia Capital and Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin (right), taking its total investment to date to some S$2.7 million.

site_title: US pending home sales slide in December
summary: US pending home sales declined to 100.7 in December from 104.6 in November, marking the first drop in 16 months, according to the National Association of Realtors. Tighter inventory and higher prices may have contributed to the decline. The index was up 6.1% from a year ago, indicating a stabilized market. Despite this, NAR chief economist Lawrence Yun forecasts a strong market this year, driven by low mortgage interest rates, job creation, and increasing consumer confidence.

site_title: Local SMEs struggle even as bigger firms fare better: DP Info
summary: Singapore's top 1,000 small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) saw a 8.7% year-on-year drop in combined revenue to S$28.3 billion, while their combined profit decreased 0.8% to S$3.4 billion. The number of loss-making SMEs increased to 130, up from 114 in 2014. In contrast, the top 1,000 companies (S1000) generated S$2.98 trillion in revenue, a 8.28% increase, with a net profit of S$149.78 billion.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
Singapore's top 1,000 small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are facing drops in their revenue, with a growing number even falling into the red.

site_title: Bill Gross says slow unwind of zero rates will support US stocks, bonds
summary: Bill Gross, a prominent bond investor, expects the Federal Reserve to slowly raise US interest rates this year to normalize financial market distortions. He believes bonds and equities won't be heavily affected by interest rate hikes. Gross notes that the Fed recognizes the system's distortion, particularly with inflation decreasing, and aims to address the long-standing issue of low interest rates.

site_title: Aer Lingus, IAG deal opposed by pilots group
summary: Aer Lingus Group Plc's potential takeover by IAG SA is opposed by a pilots group, citing concerns over job losses and loss of connections between Irish airports and the UK. The head of the pilots group, Evan Cullen, stated that Aer Lingus does not need IAG and that the takeover would benefit IAG instead. The deal requires the state to sell its 25% stake in the company, and Prime Minister Enda Kenny is considering the impact on the wider economy. The airline's shares dropped 4.9% following the news.

site_title: Putin says Russia to remain part of global economy
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin stated that Russia will remain part of the global economy, but needs to strengthen its financial and economic sovereignty. This comes amid the country's economic struggles, including sanctions and falling oil prices.

images.alt_text: President Vladimir Putin said on Thursday Russia will remain a part of the global economy but needs to strengthen its financial and economic sovereignty.

site_title: Bringing the Ascot experience to S'pore
summary: China Horse Club (CHC) is hosting the first international racing event, the China Equine Cultural Festival (CECF) Singapore Cup, at the Singapore Turf Club over the Lunar New Year period. The event, featuring thoroughbred horses from Europe, the US, Australia, and Singapore, boasts a prize money of S$3.05 million, making it the richest race in Singapore. CHC, founded by Malaysian-born tycoon TEO Ah Khing, aims to promote horse racing and breeding in China, with Singapore serving as a hub for international connections and cultural exchange. The event also features a charity cocktail party and networking opportunities.

images.alt_text: Queen Elizabeth II presiding over the Royal Ascot races (above) in Ascot, southern England. Singapore will be the host venue for CHC's first international racing event, bringing a taste of the royal equestrian tradition to the Singapore Turf Club over the Lunar New Year period.

Queen Elizabeth II presiding over the Royal Ascot races in Ascot, southern England. Singapore will be the host venue for CHC's first international racing event, bringing a taste of the royal equestrian tradition to the Singapore Turf Club over the Lunar New Year period.

"Singapore is the perfect gateway to connect the Chinese to the world and the world to China."- Mr Teo (above) on the China Equine Cultural Festival, which will be the local version of the glitzy Ascot races in the UK.

site_title: Hedge fund profits drop 30% in 2014, bonus pool shrinks
summary: Hedge fund profits dropped 30% in 2014 to $21.9 billion, down from $31.2 billion in 2013, due to poor returns. The reduced profits led to a 61% decrease in the bonus pool, from $23.1 billion to $9.2 billion. The industry, which manages 4% of assets under management, now relies more on fixed management fees for survival, with a fund needing at least $310 million to break even.

site_title: VW could save much more than 5b euro at core brand: labour chief
summary: Volkswagen's works council chief, Bernd Osterloh, suggests the carmaker can cut costs at its troubled passenger-car brand by "substantially more" than the 5 billion euros planned, with potential for even bigger savings across the multi-brand group. Osterloh cites plans to rein in costly vehicle equipment and cease unprofitable models as key steps to boost savings. New truck chief Andreas Renschler will need to assess the need for possible acquisitions to integrate VW's truck units.

site_title: Pimco expands dividend offerings with launch of two new funds
summary: Pimco has launched two new dividend funds, the Pimco US Dividend Fund and the Pimco International Dividend Fund, aiming to invest in regional stocks offering attractive yields, growing dividends, and long-term capital appreciation. The US fund will invest in 25-35 domestic dividend-paying stocks, while the international fund will invest in 40-80 dividend-paying companies in developed and emerging markets outside the US. This expansion is part of Pimco's efforts to diversify its investment offerings.

site_title: US: S&P 500 opens flat, Qualcomm weighs on Nasdaq
summary: The US stock market opened flat on Thursday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 40.91 points to 17,232.28, while the S&P 500 gained 1.98 points to 2,004.14. However, the Nasdaq Composite dropped 4.71 points to 4,633.29 due to weakness in Qualcomm shares. The strong labor market data helped the Dow rebound from two days of losses.

site_title: Alibaba says SAIC report flawed, preparing formal complaint
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has stated that a Chinese regulator's report criticizing the company for failing to stamp out illegal business on its platforms was flawed. Executive Vice Chairman Joe Tsai said the company is preparing a formal complaint after the report was made public. The report summarized a July meeting between Alibaba and the State Administration for Industry and Commerce (SAIC). Alibaba reported a 40% increase in quarterly revenue to $4.22 billion, falling short of analysts' expectations.

site_title: Shell wants to resume drilling in Arctic this summer
summary: Shell plans to resume Arctic oil drilling this summer, despite environmental concerns and legal challenges. The company, which has spent $1 billion preparing for the project, aims to start oil production in Alaska's Chukchi Sea before the pipeline's capacity is depleted. Environmentalists, including Greenpeace, have expressed fears of an oil spill, but Shell's CEO says the company will proceed if logistics and permits are in place. The project's success is crucial for Shell's shareholder value and the company's ability to maintain pipeline operations.

site_title: Business class you win, economy you lose: BA faces backlash over points changes
summary: British Airways is facing backlash over changes to its Avios frequent flyer programme, which ties points earned to ticket pricing tiers rather than miles flown. Passengers earning points on economy class tickets will see their earnings slashed to a quarter of previous levels, while those on business class tickets will earn more points. The move has sparked criticism on social media, with some threatening to switch to rival airlines like Virgin Atlantic and easyJet. Analysts say the changes could encourage higher ticket spend and potentially push customers to budget rivals, but also praise the move as a potential financial gain for the airline.

site_title: Asia eyes rate-cut window before Fed shift
summary: Asian central banks are preparing for interest-rate cuts as the Federal Reserve prepares to end its six-year, zero-rate policy. Singapore eased policy ahead of its scheduled April meeting, while Thailand and India are projected to cut rates further due to the slide in oil prices and inflation rates. The Fed's decision to stick to plans to raise interest rates this year may spur capital flight from emerging markets, prompting some economists to predict rate cuts in the next couple of months.

site_title: India overtakes China as world's leading gold consumer: GFMS
summary: India surpassed China as the world's largest gold consumer in 2014, driven by a 14% increase in Indian jewellery demand to a record 690 tonnes, while Chinese demand fell 33% to 608 tonnes. Global physical gold demand declined 19% due to slower economic growth and a crackdown on corruption in China. Analysts forecast that gold prices will bottom out this year, with prices expected to average $1,170 an ounce, marking the low point of a 12-year bull run.

site_title: Mashable gets US$17m funding led by Time Warner
summary: Mashable, a technology and entertainment news website, raised US$17 million in funding led by Time Warner Investments to fuel expansion plans. The funding will support 100 new employees and strategic growth areas, including video production. Founded in 2005, Mashable attracts 40 million unique visitors and 20 million social media followers. The investment is part of a growing trend in digital media sector investments.

site_title: Alibaba holiday-quarter revenue disappoints
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd reported a 40% increase in holiday-quarter revenue to $4.22 billion, missing analyst estimates of $4.45 billion. Despite the revenue shortfall, the company's margins on earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) bounced back to 58% from 50.5% in the previous quarter. This marks a positive sign for the Chinese e-commerce company's growth during the holiday season.

site_title: Airbus shake up to get A400M military plane back on track
summary: Airbus has announced a shakeup in its A400M military plane programme to address production delays and over-budget issues. Fernando Alonso will replace Domingo Urena-Raso as head of military aircraft, while industrial-related activities will be shifted to the operations group. The company aims to deliver seven A400Ms in service by the end of this year, despite criticism from Germany's defence minister over delays affecting NATO reliability. Airbus acknowledged "shortfalls" in integrating military capabilities and industrial ramp-up, and Germany's military has found 875 failings in the aircraft, including missing insulation on wiring.

site_title: AirAsia X says shares to be halted on Friday ahead of "material announcement"
summary: Malaysian long-haul budget carrier AirAsia X announced that its shares will be halted on Friday due to a "material announcement". The company is set to make a rights issue to close a growing cash-flow gap and may also announce the departure of two key executives. Trading will be suspended from 0900 am local time (0100GMT) pending the announcement.

site_title: In China, US tech firms turn to domestic rivals for survival
summary: US technology companies in China are forming alliances with domestic firms to operate more easily in the country's increasingly restrictive environment. The move comes after China's government pushed for the use of more Chinese and less foreign-made technology, in response to Edward Snowden's leaks about US cyber surveillance. US companies like IBM, Intel, and Dell have already partnered with domestic firms, sharing technology and investing in local companies, in an effort to localise their operations and stay competitive in China's growing tech market.

site_title: EU tourism hits record in 2014
summary: The European Union recorded a record 2.7 billion nights of tourist stays in 2014, a 1.7% increase from 2013. France topped the list with 403 million visitor nights, while Spain increased by 3.1% to 401 million nights. Latvia saw the largest rise in tourism, up 11%, and Greece and Portugal experienced solid recoveries. Spain and Italy attracted the most foreign tourists.

site_title: US jobless claims plunge 14%
summary: US jobless claims dropped to a nearly 15-year low of 265,000 in the week ending January 24, a decline of 43,000 from the prior week. This is the lowest level for initial claims since mid-April 2000. The unemployment rate fell to 5.6% in December, its lowest level since June 2008, as the economy added nearly three million jobs in 2014. The decline in claims was steeper than expected, with no particular factor influencing the data. The four-week moving average fell to 298,500 last week.

site_title: Chinese premier calls on Malaysia to settle families' MH370 claims
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang urged Malaysia to fully investigate and settle claims with families of passengers on the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370. The Malaysian government declared the disappearance an accident, paving the way for compensation to the victims' families. The search for the jet, which vanished in March 2014, continues.

site_title: Xiaomi's Barra gets snared in border dispute with India map flub
summary: Xiaomi Vice President Hugo Barra sparked controversy in China after announcing the company's expansion in India, where he displayed a map showing the disputed Aksai Chin region as part of India. The image was later deleted, but not before it was shared on Chinese microblogging platforms. The move reignited a decades-old border dispute between China and India, with some Chinese users expressing outrage and vowing to boycott Xiaomi products. Xiaomi declined to comment on the incident, which has raised concerns about the company's commitment to China's national interests.

site_title: Iron ore prices at new 5-1/2 year low as rout takes hold
summary: Spot iron ore prices hit a new 5-1/2 year low of $62.30 a tonne due to a deepening iron ore glut and concerns over a slowing Chinese economic growth. China plans to cut its growth target to 7% this year, and iron ore futures rebounded slightly on interest from bargain hunters. However, analysts predict a weak year for steel demand, with output from China's large steel mills falling 5.1% in January. The low prices are expected to force high-cost miners to exit the market, with 50-70 million tonnes of Chinese production potentially exiting this year.

site_title: Thakral to acquire remainder of Australian real estate investment unit
summary: Thakral Corporation and its subsidiary Thakral Capital Holdings entered into a share sale agreement to acquire 49% of Thakral Capital Australia's share capital. The deal will see 250,000 new shares issued at S$80.80 each to vendors, diluting Thakral's shareholding by up to 25%. The merger aims to consolidate Thakral's investment division's business and remove conflicts with minority vendors. The acquisition, along with a proposed employee share option scheme, is contingent on shareholder approval.

images.alt_text: Mainboard-listed Thakral Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiary, Thakral Capital Holdings (TCH), on Thursday entered into a share sale agreement to acquire 49 per cent of Thakral Capital Australia (TCAP)'s share capital from four vendors.

site_title: Far East Orchard unit disposes of Bassein Road properties stake for S$38.1m
summary: Far East Orchard's wholly owned subsidiary, OPH Marymount, sold its stake in two Bassein Road properties to Transurban Properties for S$38.1 million, at its net book value sum. The properties, zoned for residential purposes, were jointly acquired by OPHM and TPPL in 2010, but the group decided not to proceed with a residential development due to changes in market circumstances. The disposal will free up resources for the group to focus on other aspects of its business, with Far East Orchard's counter closing down 0.295% at S$1.69.

site_title: ECB probes bankers' bonuses with eye on preserving capital base
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has launched an investigation into how banks reward staff with bonuses to ensure they align with capital goals. The probe, announced on January 29, will assess variable remuneration policies in light of a bank's capital situation. This move follows EU regulations banning awards of more than twice fixed pay, aimed at tackling a perceived "gambling culture" that contributed to the 2008 financial crisis. The ECB's move is part of a broader effort to strengthen the financial system, with regulators having tripled minimum core capital requirements since the crisis.

site_title: China to expand limited FTZ reforms nationwide
summary: China plans to expand limited free trade zone (FTZ) reforms nationwide, including allowing game console production, foreign-invested credit evaluation firms, and paperless customs clearance. 22 measures from the Shanghai FTZ will be replicated across the country by June. The move comes ahead of China's annual legislative session, where leaders are expected to proclaim support for economic reforms. However, foreign business groups have expressed disappointment over the slow pace of change, particularly in service sector liberalization and interest rate liberalization.

site_title: ConocoPhillips has quarterly loss, cuts capex again
summary: ConocoPhillips reported a quarterly loss of $39 million, citing lower crude prices, and cut its 2015 capital expenditures to $11.5 billion, down from a prior projection of $13.5 billion. The company's fourth-quarter loss was $3 cents per share, compared to a loss of $2.00 per share in the same quarter last year. This marks the second consecutive reduction in capital expenditures, as the company adjusts to the current market conditions.

site_title: Standard Chartered board to discuss CEO succession at meeting: sources
summary: Standard Chartered's board will discuss CEO succession at a meeting in Washington, DC, amid inevitable issues around the departure of Chief Executive Peter Sands. The meeting is a regularly scheduled meeting, but Sands' succession is expected to be a key topic. The bank's spokesman declined to specify the agenda, but Sands' departure is a significant development for the bank.

images.alt_text: Standard Chartered's board will discuss succession planning at a meeting in Washington, DC, on Thursday, people familiar with the matter said.

site_title: Creative Technology suffers further losses in Q2
summary: Creative Technology reported a net loss of US$9.19 million for Q2 FY15, down from US$4.17 million in the same period last year, due to uncertain market conditions. Revenue fell to US$31.3 million, compared to US$37.79 million in Q2 FY14. The company's profit margins were squeezed by increased marketing expenses, while research and development expenses decreased 22% due to cost-cutting actions. The overall market for Creative's products remains challenging, with the company expecting no major improvement in revenue and an operating loss for the second half of the year.

site_title: Brent oil holds above US$48 after US stocks hit record high
summary: Brent oil futures remain above $48 a barrel, driven by speculative buying despite record-high US crude stocks. US crude traded at $44.26 a barrel, down 19 cents, while Brent rose 20 cents to $48.67. Analysts expect stockpiles to continue building due to high production and refiner utilization rates. Some traders believe the buying is holding the price for now, but a selloff is expected when storage becomes full or economics no longer work. Brent may test $40 or lower, with Shell's CEO predicting prices will stabilize at $90 in the long run.

site_title: Shell CEO sees long-term oil price at US$90/barrel
summary: Royal Dutch Shell CEO Ben van Beurden predicted oil prices will reach a long-term equilibrium of $90 per barrel. He noted it's impossible to predict when prices will return to those levels and that prices will remain volatile in the mid-term.

images.alt_text: Oil prices should reach a long-term equilibrium of US$90 per barrel, Royal Dutch Shell's Chief Executive Ben van Beurden told a conference call on Thursday.

site_title: Ford Motor profit beats street, maintains 2015 profit forecast
summary: Ford Motor Co. reported a quarterly earnings beat, with 26 cents per share excluding special items, surpassing analyst expectations. The company maintained its 2015 profit forecast, citing a pretax profit of between $8.5 billion and $9.5 billion. Net income fell to $52 million, or one cent per share, due to a one-time charge of $800 million for an accounting change in Venezuela. Revenue of $35.9 billion topped expectations, with North America's pretax profit reaching $6.9 billion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 1,782.18, down 13.7 points on Thursday. The index saw 1.89 billion lots traded, with 262 gains and 581 losses.

site_title: Transitional subsidies raised in first 2 years of MediShield Life
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Gan Kim Yong announced higher transitional subsidies for the first two years of MediShield Life, a universal health coverage scheme. Citizens will receive 90% and 70% subsidies for the first and second years, respectively, with a maximum premium increase of less than S$3 per month. Subsidies will phase out after the fifth year, with lower-to-middle income households continuing to benefit from premium subsidies.

site_title: Infinio Group enters into conditional cooperation agreement on gold ore project
summary: Infinio Group, through its subsidiary Infinio Resources, has entered into a conditional cooperation agreement with PT Napal Umbar Picung (PT NUP) for the cooperative processing of gold ore in Lampung, Indonesia. PT NUP owns a mining concession in the South Lampung district, which requires refurbishment and licensing to restart production. The project presents an opportunity for Infinio to generate a one-off profit with a relatively low investment. Infinio is also exploring the possible acquisition of PT NUP's entire share capital, subject to conditions.

site_title: Nomura's quarterly profit boosted by strong share market
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc reported a 45% rise in third-quarter net profits to 70 billion yen, driven by a strong performance from its retail equity business, which rose 6% to 50.05 billion yen. The company's retail client assets grew to a record 104.8 trillion yen. However, its fixed income business fared poorly, with a 23% decline in broking revenue. The results beat analysts' estimates and marked the biggest jump in quarterly profits in a year, thanks to a renewed appetite for equities that propelled the Nikkei index to a 7-1/2 year high.

site_title: Turkey, Lebanon restart Baghdad flights after shooting, Gulf waits
summary: Turkey's Turkish Airlines and Lebanon's Middle East Airlines resumed flights to Baghdad after halting them due to a shooting incident. The incident occurred when a bullet hit a plane as it landed in Baghdad, causing at least seven airlines to suspend flights. The airlines include Dubai Aviation Corp, Emirates Airlines, Air Arabia, Etihad Airways, and Qatar Airways, with the suspension expected to last until February 5. The Iraqi Transport Minister attributed the incident to gunfire from a light machinegun at an altitude of 600 meters.

images.alt_text: Turkish Airlines and Lebanon's Middle East Airlines (MEA) resumed flights to Baghdad on Thursday after halting them earlier in the week when bullets hit a plane as it was landing in the Iraqi capital.

site_title: China says closely watching Greek policy after port stake stopped
summary: China's Ministry of Commerce is closely monitoring Greece's new government after Athens halted the sale of a majority stake in Greece's biggest port, Piraeus Port Authority, citing a halt in privatisation plans. China's Cosco Group was shortlisted as a potential buyer. The reversal has pummeled Greece's financial markets, with bank stocks plummeting 26%. China urges the Greek government to protect the legitimate interests of Chinese companies in Greece, including Cosco.

site_title: Economic powers warn Greece not to renege on reforms
summary: Greece's new anti-austerity government, led by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, has rolled back several austerity reforms, including the privatization of key ports and energy providers. European powers Germany and China have warned Greece against reneging on reforms tied to its massive international bailout, with markets still jittery over fears of a potential default. The Greek stock market has been volatile, with stocks diving by over 9% on Wednesday before rebounding slightly on Thursday. The EU and IMF have threatened to cancel Greece's debt if it fails to comply with reforms, while China has expressed concern over the decision to abandon port privatization plans.

site_title: German jobless rate drops to lowest since fall of Berlin Wall
summary: Germany's jobless rate has dropped to its lowest level since the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1990, falling to 6.5% in January, according to the Federal Labour Office. The unemployment number decreased by 9,000 to 2.8 million, beating analyst forecasts. The fourth consecutive monthly drop demonstrates the resilience of Germany's jobs market, with the economic slowdown and introduction of a new national minimum wage showing no significant impact. Experts attribute the decline to the strong economy and job growth.

site_title: Apple takes top gifting spot in China: report
summary: Apple has taken the top spot in luxury gifting in China, surpassing Hermes International, according to a Hurun luxury report. Apple's focus on high-end stores and prices contributed to a 70% rise in sales in China last year. Meanwhile, spending on luxury gifts dropped 5% in 2014, and domestic luxury spending in China dipped for the first time. The shift is attributed to increasing numbers of Chinese shoppers looking to spend money overseas, with 7 out of 10 luxury goods now bought abroad.

site_title: Midas Holdings JV secures 1.73b yuan metro train contract
summary: Midas Holdings' joint venture, Nanjing SR Puzhen Rail Transport Co, has secured a 1.73 billion yuan contract for Shanghai Metro Line 13 Phases 2 and 3, with delivery scheduled between 2016 and 2017. The contract was awarded by Shanghai Rail Transit Line 13 Development Co. Midas Holdings CEO Patrick Chew expressed optimism about the growing demand for metro train cars in China's expanding passenger rail network.

site_title: Indonesia narrows auto output gap with Thailand, set to take regional crown
summary: Indonesia narrowed its car output gap with Thailand to its smallest ever, 69% in 2014, after growing 7% to 1.30 million vehicles. Thailand's output shrank 23% to 1.88 million due to political turmoil. Indonesia is expected to overtake Thailand in output within the next 7-10 years, driven by foreign investments and government reforms. Despite this, Thailand's well-developed supply chain and component manufacturers will remain a major player, with a focus on raising Indonesia's product quality to suit the global market.

site_title: Uber, other taxi-hailing apps hit new roadblock in New Delhi
summary: New Delhi's transport department has issued a deficiency memo to Uber, detailing problems with the company's application for a licence in the city. Uber must resubmit a portion of its application, which lacks proof of its registered office in New Delhi and details of its call centre. The company's services have been banned since December due to a rape accusation against one of its drivers. Similar letters have been sent to Uber's rivals, TaxiForSure and Ola, which are still operating in the city. Uber will have to comply with new rules requiring emergency buttons and tracking devices.

site_title: Tuan Sing Q4 profit dips 4% to S$24.3m, dragged down by other operating expenses
summary: Tuan Sing's Q4 net profit dropped 4% to S$24.3m due to increased other operating expenses and finance costs, despite a 72% year-on-year revenue rise to S$112.1m. The company attributed the revenue growth to its property segment and the consolidation of revenue from Grand Hotel Group. Full-year revenue grew 17% to S$354.8m and net profit rose 18% to S$61.2m. The group's order book and revenue for 2015 are expected to come from existing development projects.

site_title: Eurozone faces 'another lost decade': Bank of England governor
summary: Bank of England governor Mark Carney warned the eurozone faces "another lost decade" due to lack of fiscal solidarity, criticizing leaders for timidity. He urged the bloc to share fiscal sovereignty, contrasting with Germany's dominant role. Carney praised the European Central Bank's quantitative easing program but expressed concerns about the lack of fiscal union. The warning comes after Greece's Syriza coalition won elections, threatening to renegotiate the country's EU-IMF bailout and scrap austerity measures.

site_title: UK banks pay out less than half refund pot for swaps mis-selling
summary: UK banks have paid out less than half of the £4.4 billion set aside to cover mis-selling of complex interest rate hedging products. The Financial Conduct Authority ordered banks to review 29,500 cases in 2013 after finding "serious failings" in the sales process. Banks have paid out £1.8 billion in compensation so far, leaving £2.6 billion remaining to cover costs including early termination and staff review.

site_title: Malaysia declares MH370 an accident, all 239 people presumed dead
summary: Malaysia has declared the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 an accident, with all 239 people on board presumed dead. The declaration aims to facilitate compensation for families. The search for MH370, led by Australia, continues in the Indian Ocean, despite no distress signal being sent before the plane vanished on March 8. The declaration does not affect the ongoing search efforts, which remain a priority.

site_title: Visa Europe profits jump as consumers switch from cash
summary: Visa Europe reported a 30% increase in profits to 344 million euros, driven by a 9% increase in card transactions to 1.5 trillion euros in Europe. Payments on Visa cards now account for one euro in every six euros spent. The industry has moved past a dispute with EU governments over debit and credit card fees, with retailers expected to pass on estimated 6 billion euros in savings to customers. Visa Europe aims to further reduce cash transactions using digital technology.

site_title: Samsung spending US$21b to supply rivals as Galaxy slides
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to spend over $21.4 billion this year to supply chips and displays to rivals, including Apple, as its Galaxy smartphone sales decline. The company aims to boost processor chip output to compete with Apple, which has surged into a tie with Samsung as the biggest smartphone maker. Samsung's earnings have fallen for three straight quarters, and the company is cutting its smartphone lineup to focus on products where it has a competitive edge. The next version of its Galaxy S range will be critical to turning around earnings from smartphones.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end lower
summary: Singapore shares ended lower on Thursday, closing 0.1 point at 3,419.05, with 1.25 billion shares valued at S$1.19 billion. The Straits Times Index had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Gainers outnumbered losers 196-265.

site_title: SMRT's Q3 net profit jumps 58%
summary: SMRT Corp posted a 58.4% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$22.55 million for the third quarter ended Dec 31, 2014. Revenue rose 6.8% to S$313.19 million, with earnings per share increasing to 1.5 Singapore cents. Despite challenging business conditions, SMRT attributes the improvement to better performances in its business segments and ongoing cost management efforts. The company expects partial mitigation of rising costs next year with recently approved fare adjustments and declining energy prices.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Russia's Gazprom profits slide 61% in third quarter
summary: Russia's Gazprom reported a 61% decline in profits to 105.7 billion roubles in the third quarter of 2014, mainly due to suspended gas supplies to Ukraine, one of its main customers. Revenues dropped 6% year-on-year to 1.133 billion roubles.

site_title: STATS ChipPAC records net income of US$3.5m in Q4
summary: STATS ChipPAC, a semiconductor packaging and test services company, reported a net income of US$3.5 million in the fourth quarter, a significant improvement from the net loss of US$12.1 million in the same period last year. Revenue for the quarter was US$406.7 million, slightly higher than the previous year. The company attributed the better-than-expected results to higher wireless communications revenue driven by new smartphone ramps and stronger demand in China. For the full year, STATS ChipPAC reported a net loss of US$21.8 million, slightly lower than the previous year.

site_title: Shoppers help eurozone confidence improve in January
summary: Economic morale in the eurozone rose slightly in January, with shopper confidence improving in Germany, Spain, and Italy, but falling in France. The European Commission's economic sentiment index rose 0.6 points to 101.2, exceeding expectations. This marks a small step towards recovery, with the Commission predicting modest growth in 2016. A separate business climate indicator also improved, despite still being lower than in November. Deflation and economic struggles have damaged business confidence, prompting the European Central Bank to implement a money-printing plan to revive inflation.

images.alt_text: Economic morale in the eurozone rose slightly at the start of this year as shoppers appeared more optimistic in Germany, Spain and Italy, but the divisions in the weak economy were underscored by a fall in overall sentiment in France.
