site_title: Dollar rises on Fed's interest-rate outlook
summary: The US dollar rose to its highest close on record, surpassing the previous record in 2004, amid speculation that the Federal Reserve is the only developed nation's central bank considering raising interest rates this year. The dollar gained 0.2% against the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index, while the yen weakened 0.5% against the euro. The Fed maintained its pledge to be "patient" on raising interest rates, citing global risks and international developments. The dollar's surge is attributed to the Fed's stance and the expectation of no interest rate hikes from other major central banks.

site_title: Malaysia plans update on flight MH370 as relatives fume
summary: Malaysia's government plans to make a statement about missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, potentially declaring it "lost" and clearing the way for families to seek compensation and insurance claims. The announcement, originally scheduled for a news conference, was cancelled after distraught relatives rushed to the venue. A formal declaration would be a heavy emotional blow to the families, who have lived in uncertainty for 10 months. The statement is expected to provide some closure, but the families' desire for answers remains.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's government said it would make a statement on Thursday regarding missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, as rumours swirled the plane was to be formally declared "lost".

site_title: UK house price growth slows again in January: Nationwide
summary: British house price growth slowed to a 6.8% annual increase in January, the fifth consecutive month of decline, according to Nationwide. This is slightly stronger than expected, but down from a 7.2% increase in December. On a monthly basis, house prices rose 0.3%, in line with expectations.

images.alt_text: British house price growth slowed on an annual basis for a fifth month in a row in January, figures from mortgage lender Nationwide showed on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end lower on falls in regional bourses
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 1.1% to 24,595.85 points on Thursday, amid weakness in regional markets, particularly losses on the mainland, and concerns over a potential rise in US interest rates. Chinese shares dropped for a third day due to an investigation into 46 companies' margin business. Investors were also nervous about a possible Fed interest rate hike, leading to a decline in Hong Kong's Hang Seng index.

site_title: Uber steers anti-taxi idea to become global phenomenon
summary: Uber, founded by Travis Kalanick and Garrett Camp in 2008, has grown into a global phenomenon, valued at $40 billion with operations in over 200 cities worldwide. Initially conceived as a "timeshare limousine" service, Uber now sees itself as a crusade against an entrenched taxi industry, which it claims fails to serve consumers. Despite regulatory challenges and criticism, Uber has raised $1.2 billion in funding and aims to create over one million jobs globally by 2015, with a focus on technology and the "sharing economy".

site_title: AirAsia plane rose to unauthorised altitude minutes before crash
summary: An AirAsia plane, Flight QZ8501, crashed into the ocean minutes after climbing to an unauthorized altitude of 37,400 feet from a cruising altitude of 32,000 feet. Investigators say the pilots, experienced in flying, were trying to avoid bad weather but likely stalled the aircraft after climbing steeply. The co-pilot was at the controls when the plane disappeared from radar on December 28, killing 162 people. Authorities have recovered 70 bodies and ruled out terrorism as a factor, but the cause of the crash remains unclear.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall early after bullish Fed
summary: European shares fell 0.5% in early trading on Thursday after the US Federal Reserve expressed confidence in the US economy, signaling a potential interest rate hike this year. Vallourec, a steel pipes maker, declined 6.5% after warning of an impairment charge. The FTSEurofirst 300 index dropped to 1,467.16 points.

site_title: Oil near six-year lows after US stockpiles hit record high
summary: Oil prices fell to nearly six-year lows after the US Energy Information Administration reported record-high domestic crude oil stocks of 407 million barrels. Analysts expect stockpiles to continue rising, pushing prices down further due to refineries entering maintenance season. The global market remains under pressure due to a glut, with the US stockpiles reaching the highest level since 1982.

site_title: Thai finance ministry trims 2015 GDP growth forecast to 3.9%
summary: Thailand's finance ministry has revised its 2015 GDP growth forecast to 3.9%, down from its previous estimate of 4%, and 2014 growth to 0.7%, lower than its previous estimate of 1%. The ministry also reduced its export growth estimate to 1.4% from 3.5%. The policy interest rate is expected to remain unchanged at 2% this year. The revisions come as the military government struggles to revive the economy, which has been impacted by prolonged political tensions and weak exports.

site_title: MTI announces board changes at EDB, A*Star
summary: The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) announced board changes at the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) and the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star), effective from February 1. At EDB, four new members were appointed and four re-appointed, while four board members will step down. At A*Star, Chong Tow Chong was appointed and 11 board members were re-appointed, with four stepping down. MTI thanked the outgoing members for their service.

site_title: China's CNOOC may export first diesel and gasoline cargoes in Q1
summary: China's CNOOC may start exporting diesel and gasoline cargoes in February or March, following an expanded quota for shipments this year. The refinery, located in Guangdong province, will export 10,000-tonne parcels to neighboring countries such as the Philippines and Vietnam. This move is expected to increase supply in the region, potentially dragging on margins for oil products. CNOOC's exports will be limited by the refinery's capacity, which is currently 240,000 barrels per day.

site_title: Chinese banks back risky stock margin finance in face of regulator crackdown
summary: Chinese banks are backing margin finance in the stock market despite regulatory efforts to curb debt-fueled speculation. Financial institutions are using brokerages to channel credit into the market, increasing the risk of a market downturn. Regulators have not closed loopholes, exposing the banking system to greater risks. While some market watchers caution against panic, the move highlights the challenges in managing China's economic slowdown and the pressure on policymakers to stimulate growth.

site_title: Lending in eurozone falls in December but at slower pace
summary: Eurozone lending to households and firms fell 0.5% in December, a slower pace than the previous month, while money supply grew 3.6%. The European Central Bank laid out a plan to spend hundreds of billions of euros on government bonds. Lending to companies remains scarce, hindering the struggling eurozone economy.

site_title: Co-pilot at controls when AirAsia plane crashed: investigator
summary: An AirAsia plane crashed into the sea in Indonesia on December 28, killing all 162 people on board, with the French co-pilot at the controls when it went down. Investigators revealed that the plane had climbed sharply in stormy weather, reaching 37,400 feet before descending into the sea. The captain, Iriyanto, was supposed to be in control, but was instead monitoring the flight. The investigation found that the plane's stall alarms were sounding before the crash, and the crew held valid licenses. A final report is expected in 7-8 months.

images.alt_text: The French co-pilot was at the controls of an AirAsia plane when it crashed into the sea last month after flying through an area of towering clouds, killing all 162 people on board, investigators said on Thursday.

site_title: India not ready for full capital account liberalisation: central bank deputy
summary: India's central bank deputy governor H R Khan stated that the country is not ready for full capital account liberalization due to the pros and cons of such a move being a contentious issue. Currently, India allows foreign investors to buy up to $81 billion of Indian debt, but there are no limit restrictions for stock market investments. The Reserve Bank of India is instead focusing on developing derivatives products with caution.

site_title: Vietnam's 'king of shrimp' courts foreign investors
summary: Vietnam's largest seafood exporter, Minh Phu Seafood Corp., plans to sell half of itself to foreign investors to fund overseas expansion. The company aims to complete the stake sales this year after delisting from the Ho Chi Minh City Stock Exchange. CEO Le Van Quang forecasts a 55% increase in net income and $1 billion in sales, with the goal of becoming a global shrimp company by 2020. Quang, known as the "king of shrimp," seeks strategic foreign investors to maximize the company's advantages.

site_title: Germany says nobody wants new sanctions but Russia must observe ceasefire
summary: Germany's Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel stated that Europe has no interest in imposing new sanctions on Russia, but Russia must abide by the Minsk ceasefire terms to improve relations. Gabriel emphasized that Russia's participation in global conflicts and challenges is crucial, and that a breakthrough in European-Russian relations can be achieved by following the agreed steps in Minsk.

site_title: Deutsche Bank posts surprise profit in fourth quarter
summary: Deutsche Bank reported a surprise pre-tax profit of 253 million euros in the fourth quarter of 2014, beating analysts' expectations of a pre-tax loss of 83 million euros. The bank's litigation costs were lower than expected, and it also received a one-off tax gain. This marked a significant improvement from the previous year, with the full-year pretax profit more than doubling to 3.1 billion euros.

site_title: Shell to cut spending by US$15b over next 3 years
summary: Royal Dutch Shell plans to cut spending by US$15 billion over the next 3 years in response to lower oil prices. The company reported a fourth-quarter earnings of US$4.2 billion, in line with expectations, and maintained its dividend at US$0.47 per share. Shell will lower its capital investment in 2015 and reduce overall spending to adapt to the lower oil prices. This move is expected to help the company navigate the current market conditions.

site_title: China to raise commercial oil storage more than 10% in 2015: sources
summary: China plans to increase its commercial oil storage capacity by over 10% in 2015, with a total of 42 million barrels, enough to cover one week of net crude oil imports. The move is aimed at capitalizing on speculative demand for crude, which could support global oil prices, currently below $50 a barrel. Several storage companies, including Vopak and Brightoil Petroleum, are adding new tank capacity to meet this demand, with some expecting prices to recover towards late 2015.

site_title: Indonesia inflation seen easing on oil prices, exports to fall
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation is expected to ease to 7.50% in January, down from 8.36% in December, due to lower domestic fuel prices following a decline in global oil prices. Analysts forecast a 16.18% decline in exports and a 9.70% decline in imports in December. The country is expected to post a US$110 million trade surplus in December, according to Bank Indonesia Governor Agus Martowardojo's prediction.

site_title: Indonesian state enterprises to raise more capital: minister
summary: Indonesian State Enterprises Minister Rini Soemarno announced plans to encourage state enterprises to raise more capital by taking on debt or issuing rights. Export-oriented firms can issue dollar-denominated debt in the global market, while the ministry is considering injecting 500 billion rupiah into struggling state airline PT Merpati Nusantara Airlines to resolve payroll issues.

site_title: Fair and compassionate approach in calibrating additional premiums under MediShield Life: Health Minister
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Gan Kim Yong announced a "fair and compassionate approach" in assessing additional premiums for those with pre-existing medical conditions under MediShield Life. Those with pre-existing conditions will pay 30% higher premiums for the first 10 years, but the government aims to ensure these premiums are not too onerous. The approach balances fairness with compassion, reflecting the higher risks associated with pre-existing conditions while avoiding excessive financial burden.

site_title: Seoul: Won falls on rate-cut outlook, short-covering; equities slide
summary: The South Korean won fell 9.4 to the dollar on Thursday, driven by expectations of a Bank of Korea interest rate cut, following Singapore's policy easing. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) slipped 0.54% to close at 1,951.02 points, despite a hawkish US Federal Reserve stance. Dollar/won shorts were squeezed out as exporter demand for won increased ahead of month-end settlements.

site_title: DBS to gain the most from higher short-term funding rates: Nomura
summary: DBS is expected to benefit the most from higher short-term funding rates in Singapore, according to Nomura. The Singapore central bank's surprise move to ease the appreciation of the Singapore dollar has led to an increase in interest rates, benefiting DBS as its assets get repriced faster and in a bigger magnitude than liabilities. With approximately 40% of its Singapore-dollar loans pegged to the swap offer rate or Sibor, DBS is likely to see a significant increase in revenue.

site_title: Microsoft gives away more Office software to attract mobile users
summary: Microsoft has released free versions of its Word, Excel, and PowerPoint applications on Android tablets and an app for Outlook on Apple's iPhone and iPad. The move aims to attract mobile users and build a base of users that can later be persuaded to sign up for Office 365. This is part of CEO Satya Nadella's strategy to regain the initiative in the mobile market, where Microsoft has fallen behind Apple and Google. The new releases follow the success of a free, touch-friendly version of Office for Apple's iPad released last March, with 80 million downloads since then.

site_title: Asia's rich chase dollar rally as volatility haven
summary: Asia's wealthy individuals are snapping up dollars as a haven from financial market volatility, driving the US currency to a decade-high. Rich families are allocating 90% of their US$200 million holdings to the greenback, with Stamford Management Pte and other family offices boosting dollar assets. The US economy's outperformance and increasing demand for dollar-denominated assets are fueling the dollar's rally, with speculation of an imminent interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The greenback has risen for seven consecutive months, with 54% of investors predicting it will offer the best opportunities in the next year.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 20-week high as rate cut hopes temper oil turmoil
summary: Australian shares reached a 20-week high, closing at 5569.5, driven by hopes for an interest rate cut within days. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3% despite oil prices hitting multi-year lows, which negatively impacted energy stocks. New Zealand's NZX 50 index also reached a record high before retreating.

site_title: Thai junta orders German NGO to cancel press freedom briefing
summary: A German NGO, the Friedrich Ebert Foundation, has been ordered by Thailand's junta to cancel a briefing on media freedom in the country, amid a growing clampdown on freedom of expression. The briefing was part of a series of annual reports on the challenges faced by journalists in Asia. The move comes as two former ministers from the ousted government of ex-premier Yingluck Shinawatra were summoned by the military, escalating its campaign to crush dissent. The junta's restrictions on media freedom have been criticized by human rights groups, who warn that peace has been paid for with the severe curtailment of basic liberties.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall 1.06% by the close
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 1.06% by the close on Thursday, with Nintendo and Canon losing ground after disappointing earnings. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 189.51 points to 17,606.22, while the Topix index lost 1.14% to 1,413.58. This decline followed a sharp fall on Wall Street.

site_title: Singapore's top 1,000 companies see 11.3% compounded annual revenue growth in 5 years
summary: Singapore's top 1,000 companies saw an 11.3% compounded annual revenue growth in the last 5 years, adding S$1.23 trillion in revenue. The commerce-wholesale sector led the growth with a 13.3% CAGR, followed by the information and communications sector (12.9%) and commerce-retail sector (10.2%). The only sector to contract was hospitality and food & beverage, with a 7.7% decline. This growth helped Singapore recover from the Global Financial Crisis and maintained its technological edge.

site_title: AirAsia jet was in sound condition before crash: investigators
summary: An AirAsia passenger jet that crashed into the sea last month killing 162 people was in sound condition and all crew members were properly certified, according to Indonesia's National Transportation Safety Committee. The flight data recorder provided a clear picture of the accident, which occurred when the first officer was flying the plane. The cause of the crash remains under investigation, but the committee's findings suggest that mechanical failure was not the primary cause.

site_title: ECB QE could cause "competitive depreciation": China
summary: The European Central Bank's quantitative easing (QE) measures may trigger "competitive depreciation" of currencies worldwide, according to China's commerce ministry. The ECB's plan to buy 60 billion euros monthly could worsen international cross-border capital flows, affecting bilateral trade between China and the EU. China's exports to Europe and investment in the EU may face risks, while imports from Europe could increase due to a weaker euro. The long-term effects of the stimulus on the eurozone economy are uncertain, raising concerns about stagnation and growth.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank's new quantitative easing (QE) measures could trigger "competitive depreciation" of currencies around the world, China's commerce ministry warned Thursday.

site_title: Oil prices rise, gains capped on supply glut concerns
summary: Oil prices rose, but gains were limited by concerns over a global supply glut. US crude reserves surged to a record high, with 406.7 million barrels in stockpiles, and analysts said this data added to pressure on benchmark prices. Despite low refinery utilization rates in the US, US production continues to increase, making it challenging for oil bulls. The US Federal Reserve's hawkish sentiment also put downward pressure on oil prices, as a rising dollar made dollar-priced crude more expensive.

site_title: Nokia beats profit forecasts in Q4
summary: Nokia reported stronger-than-expected quarterly profits for its core network equipment business, with core operating profit rising to 470 million euros (US$530 million) in the fourth quarter, a 14% increase from the previous quarter. The company's results beat analyst forecasts, and it plans to pay an annual dividend of 0.14 euros per share. Nokia's network equipment unit has seen growth from network roll-outs for faster 4G mobile services in China and North America, following the sale of its former flagship phone business to Microsoft last year.

site_title: China to expand some Shanghai free trade zone practices nationwide
summary: China plans to expand some free trade zone practices nationwide, including yuan settlements for individuals and foreign exchange retention for foreign-funded firms. The cabinet aims to let markets play a bigger role in the economy by streamlining approval processes and opening the services sector. This move follows China's launch of three new free-trade zones in Guangdong, Fujian, and Tianjin, modeled on Shanghai's free trade zone. The expansion is part of China's efforts to create a more open and streamlined environment for foreign firms to do business.

site_title: SGX FTSE China A50 Index Futures sets new record
summary: The SGX FTSE China A50 Index Futures set a new daily record of 594,551 contracts traded on Jan 27, surpassing the previous record. The open interest peaked at 591,501 contracts on Jan 26, and the tick size was reduced to 2.5 points, making the contract more cost-efficient. However, the recent outflow of funds from China-related exchange-traded funds signals a receding of bullish interest by global investors, affecting the market.

site_title: Singapore Airlines, India's Vistara launch frequent flyer programme tie-up
summary: Singapore Airlines and Vistara, a joint venture between Tata and SIA, have launched a partnership between their frequent flyer programmes, KrisFlyer and Club Vistara. KrisFlyer members can earn miles when traveling with Vistara and redeem Vistara flight tickets with their miles. Club Vistara members can also earn and redeem points on SIA and SilkAir flights. This partnership aims to expand travel options for members and enhance loyalty benefits.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: OMV drops 2016 output goal, takes Q4 charge
summary: Austrian energy company OMV will take a 700 million euro charge in Q4 due to impairments in its Petrol Ofisi and power business, preventing it from reaching its 2016 output target. Lower investment due to fallen oil prices and Libya uncertainty led to the decision. The charge is higher than the group's net profit of 665 million euros after minority interests for the first nine months.

images.alt_text: OMV will take a 700 million euro (US$790.5 million) charge in the fourth quarter, the Austrian energy company said, adding that lower investment due to fallen oil prices and uncertainty in Libya would prevent it from reaching its 2016 output target.

site_title: China to gradually reduce metal export quotas
summary: China plans to gradually reduce its export quotas for metals, complying with a WTO ruling that deemed the quotas discriminatory. The move aims to eliminate export tariffs on metals, which give domestic consumers an unfair advantage over foreign competitors. While the quota on primary aluminium has not been changed, the country's export tariff structure will be re-evaluated, potentially leading to further reductions over time.

site_title: Philippines posts stellar Q4 growth on construction, farm output
summary: The Philippine economy rebounded with a 2.5% growth in the fourth quarter, the best quarterly pace in Asia and above expectations, driven by strong farm output and construction activity. This puts the country on track for solid growth this year and cements expectations that the central bank will keep policy rates on hold for some time. The full-year growth is forecasted at 6.1%, exceeding market forecasts, and the government aims for 7-8% growth in 2015 and 2016.

site_title: Russell-Davison new head of debt capital markets at Standard Chartered
summary: Standard Chartered has appointed Aaron Russell-Davison as the new head of debt capital markets with immediate effect. Russell-Davison, who previously held the position of head of Asian bond syndicate, will report to Henrik Raber, global head of capital markets. Lynette Ortiz will take over as head of capital markets, Asean, on April 1. The appointment reflects the bank's efforts to strengthen its debt capital markets capabilities.

site_title: China to inspect brokerages over margin trade: Xinhua
summary: China's market watchdog, the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), will conduct an "on-site inspection" of nearly 50 securities firms for possible irregularities in margin trading. The move comes after a 7.7% crash in China's benchmark Shanghai Composite Index earlier this month, following a similar inspection that punished 12 brokerages for violating rules. Margin trading has fueled a 50% rally in the Shanghai index in 2014, but authorities fear it brings greater market volatility and risks small investors. The inspection aims to ensure a healthy stock market development.

site_title: Political tensions behind China-Japan economic issues: Beijing
summary: China's commerce ministry attributed Japan's 38.8% decline in investment to 2014 to "sluggish Japan-China trade and economic co-operation", with political tensions playing a role. The decline follows Japan's nationalist Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's 2013 visit to Tokyo's Yasukuni Shrine, which angered Beijing. Disagreements over a maritime territorial dispute and historical issues have strained relations. The ministry called for Tokyo to take concrete actions to improve bilateral relations and create positive conditions for trade recovery.

images.alt_text: Political tensions are partly to blame for Japanese investment in China recording its biggest fall for almost a quarter of a century, Beijing's commerce ministry said on Thursday.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall following Fed's unwavering stance
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.7% on Thursday, following the US Federal Reserve's unwavering stance on interest rates. The main TAIEX index closed at 9,444.19, down 61.73 points. Key sectors, including electronics and banks, declined, while construction traded flat. The Taiwan dollar dropped 0.153 against the US dollar. The US Fed's assessment of the domestic economy was upbeat, but interest rate expectations remained high.

site_title: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit's Q3 FY2015 DPU up 2.2% to 2.83 cents
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit announced a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.83 Singapore cents for Q3 FY2015, a 2.2% increase from the previous year. Total distribution to unitholders rose 21% to S$17.7 million, driven by a 9.7% growth in net property income (NPI) to S$20.5 million, mainly from completed developments and maiden rental contributions.

site_title: China: Stocks open down on news of regulator checks on margin trading
summary: China's stocks opened down 1.4% on Thursday as regulators launched an investigation into margin trading at 46 companies. The CSI300 index fell to 3,474.91 points, and the Shanghai Composite Index dropped to 3,259.00 points. This comes after a similar crackdown earlier this month, which led to a market collapse and regulators' reassurances. The move is part of regular supervision, and the outcome is unclear.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.73% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.73% in early trading on January 29, 2015, following the US Federal Reserve's pledge to be "patient" in raising interest rates. The benchmark Hang Seng Index dropped 180.96 points to 24,680.85. This decline mirrored sharp drops across Asian bourses.

site_title: Oil markets open up weak following record US stockpiles
summary: Oil prices opened weak in Asia following record US stockpiles, which sent crude tumbling to near six-year lows. US crude prices fell to $44.43 a barrel, while Brent crude was trading at $48.60 a barrel. Analysts predict the market will remain weak due to rising stockpiles, refineries entering maintenance season, and lower utilization rates. Experts say cheap oil will have a limited impact on Asian economic growth, with China's oil consumption expected to slow due to more efficient growth.

site_title: Changi Airport receives 54.1 million passengers in 2014, up 0.7%
summary: Changi Airport served 54.1 million passengers in 2014, a 0.7% increase from the previous year, despite a challenging aviation industry. Cargo volumes remained nearly flat at 1.84 million tonnes. The airport introduced the Growth and Assistance Incentive (GAIN) programme to support airlines and stimulate passenger traffic. Travel to and from Thailand and China showed signs of recovery, with increases of 6.6% and 1% respectively in December. Indonesia remained the top country market, followed by Malaysia, Australia, Thailand, and China.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Australia: Shares nudge 4 1/2-month highs before slipping on oil price
summary: Australian shares rose to a 20-week high before slipping on Thursday due to a rout in energy stocks caused by plummeting oil prices. Despite lower oil prices, energy companies cut spending and earnings, while banks and retailers gained as interest rates are expected to be cut at the Reserve Bank of Australia's February 3 meeting. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.1% to 5,559.3, with non-oil resources such as iron ore producers and retailers performing well.

site_title: Apple ties with Samsung as world's top smartphone vendor
summary: Apple tied with Samsung as the world's top smartphone vendor in the fourth quarter of 2014, with Apple shipping 74.5 million handsets and Samsung at 51 million. Apple reported a record net profit of $18 billion, while Samsung saw its quarterly profits slashed due to escalating competition. The shift marked a downturn in Samsung's market share, which fell from 30% to 19.6%. Apple regained its position as the world's top smartphone vendor, while Samsung remains the top vendor overall for the year, with 317.2 million shipments.

site_title: China to spend additional US$128b on railways this year: Caixin
summary: China plans to spend an additional 800 billion yuan (S$173.2 billion) on building railway tracks this year, exceeding its 2014 investment target. This is part of the government's efforts to boost infrastructure spending as the economy slows. The country has already approved $8.6 billion of railway projects in the northern and southwestern parts of China. China Railway aims to focus construction efforts on the central and western regions, and will promote local rail technology abroad. The total rail network length is expected to increase to 112,000 kilometers.

site_title: China urges six rare earth firms to consolidate the industry by year end
summary: China's six largest rare earth companies are being urged to consolidate the industry by the end of 2015, aiming to regulate the sector and eliminate illegal production and smuggling. The move is expected to reduce supply, push up prices, and strengthen China's pricing power. The consolidation is a response to China's failure to overturn a World Trade Organisation (WTO) judgment that branded its export tariff and quota system as discriminatory. The country has already abolished the quota system and will remove taxes on rare earth exports from May.

site_title: IMF sets June deadline for progress on governance reforms
summary: The IMF has set a June 30 deadline for member countries to make progress on governance reforms, which would give emerging countries more say in IMF decision-making. The reforms, adopted in 2010, aim to double the fund's resources and reduce Western dominance. The US has been unable to ratify the changes, prompting other countries to push for action. The IMF's board has recommended a resolution expressing "deep regret" over the delayed reforms and reiterating the importance of their implementation for the fund's credibility and effectiveness.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaRetail China Trust, AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit
summary: CapitaRetail China Trust reported a 12.7% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.48 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter, driven by a 30.1% increase in net property income (NPI) to S$33.5 million. AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit posted a 2.2% rise in DPU to 2.83 Singapore cents and a 9.7% increase in NPI to S$20.5 million for the third quarter.

site_title: Japan carrier Skymark's shares plunge after bankruptcy filing
summary: Skymark Airlines, Japan's third-largest carrier, filed for bankruptcy, citing penalties for cancelling a US$2.2 billion jet order with Airbus. Shares plummeted 25% to 237 yen (US$2) after the announcement, with trading halted due to sell orders vastly outnumbering buy bids. The airline acknowledged efforts to turn itself around had failed.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.72 points to 1791.59. The market saw 28.38 million lots traded worth RM13.08 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 88 to 67.

site_title: Greek government reverses austerity policies, stocks hit
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' hard-left government reversed austerity policies, halting key privatisation projects and pressing for debt relief. The move sparked a 9.0% decline in Athens' main stock index and raised concerns about a confrontation with European creditors. Tsipras vowed to find a "fair, mutually beneficial solution" with Brussels, while European leaders warned of no option to cancel Greece's massive debt. The new government's "New Deal" aims to encourage growth and help the continent deal with Greece's crisis, but time is short as the EU sets an end-of-February deadline for reforms in return for financial aid.

site_title: Malaysia short sellers target world's longest rally on oil
summary: Malaysia's benchmark equity index is under threat as short sellers target the world's longest-running equity rally. Short interest in the iShares MSCI Malaysia ETF more than doubled to 20% in the past month, reaching an eight-year peak. Analysts predict the weakest profit growth since 2009 due to lower oil prices, and foreign investors have pulled out US$1.9 billion from Malaysian stocks in 2014. The government has cut its 2015 economic growth forecast to 4.5%, and some analysts expect the market to continue de-rating.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index down 15.50 points to 3,403.65, amidst global market uncertainty. Losers outnumbered gainers 93 to 53, with volume reaching 65.6 million shares worth S$105.1 million. This marks a reversal from the previous day's 0.4% gain.

site_title: BlackRock holds 3.1% of Keppel Land shares
summary: BlackRock, an associate of Keppel Corp, now holds 48.05 million shares in Keppel Land, representing about 3.1% of the total issued shares. This follows Keppel Corp's launch of an offer to acquire all issued ordinary shares in KepLand. The acquisition is part of Keppel Corp's efforts to expand its portfolio.

images.alt_text: KEPPEL Corporation, via its financial advisers DBS Bank and Credit Suisse (Singapore), on Thursday announced that BlackRock Inc, an associate of Keppel Corp, now holds some 48.05 million shares in Keppel Land (KepLand).

site_title: Swiss face costly choice for SNB reserves hoard as dust settles
summary: Switzerland's Swiss National Bank (SNB) is facing a costly choice for its $546 billion reserve hoard, accumulated during years of market interventions. With interest rates negative on euro-denominated bonds, the SNB may accept negative yields or sell out, potentially boosting the franc and risking a backlash. The institution, under President Thomas Jordan, aims to maintain purchasing power, but alternatives, such as shifting holdings to less impacted currencies, are considered riskier. The SNB's decision could impact its annual payment of 1 billion francs to 26 cantons and the country's economy.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall on unexpectedly hawkish Fed; won falls on easing prospects
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.3% to 1,956.17 points, retreating from a seven-week high, due to the US Federal Reserve's hawkish stance on interest rates. The Fed signaled a steady course towards its first rate hike since 2008, contradicting recent market expectations. The won fell 7.3 points to 1,091.8 to the dollar, while commodity-linked shares underperformed due to oil price falls. Earnings season also had an impact, with Naver Corp shares slumping 3.9% and Samsung Electronics' profits meeting expectations.

site_title: Quick takes: FOMC leaves monetary policy intact, upgrades US growth assessment
summary: The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) left US monetary policy unchanged after a two-day meeting, upgrading its assessment of US growth. The committee acknowledged stronger disinflation and international developments. This decision comes as the US economy continues to show signs of improvement, with the FOMC upgrading its growth assessment.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

The Federal Reserve's policy arm, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), announced no changes to monetary policy Wednesday after a two-day meeting. It also upgraded its assessment of US growth while acknowledging stronger disinflation and international developments.

site_title: Ringgit falls as Asia's worst-performing currency weighed by oil
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell 0.4% to 3.6340 a dollar, reaching a new 2009 low, amid concern over a protracted drop in crude oil prices weighing on the oil-exporting nation. The currency declined for a second day after Brent slid 2.3% overnight on a US oil stockpile report. Despite Malaysia's central bank keeping borrowing costs steady, the nation's 10-year government bond yields are headed for the biggest monthly decline since 2008. The drop in oil prices has reduced the country's 2015 growth forecast to 4.5-5.5%.

site_title: McDonald's CEO Don Thompson to retire Jan 28
summary: McDonald's CEO Don Thompson is set to retire on March 1, effective January 28, after 25 years with the company. He will be replaced by Steve Easterbrook, who will also take over the president and board director roles. Easterbrook has previously served as senior executive vice president and chief brand officer, and as president of McDonald's Europe.

site_title: Australia rate cut speculation heats up as export prices fall
summary: Australia's Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to cut interest rates by a quarter of a point when it meets on Feb 3, with markets now implying a 50-50 chance of a rate cut. This follows global central banks easing monetary policy to combat falling commodity prices and lacklustre global demand. The decision comes as investors shift risk-reward in favor of cutting interest rates, with some economists predicting two cuts this year.

site_title: IMF begins work on 'Plan B' as US blocks reforms
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has begun working on "Plan B" as a five-year-old reform program stalls due to US opposition. The proposal, which includes salvaging parts of the 2010 reforms, aims to be completed by June 30. The US, as the IMF's largest shareholder, controls 16.7% of voting rights, effectively blocking major initiatives. The IMF hopes to implement the 2010 reforms, which doubled funding and increased voting power for emerging economies, without replacing them with "Plan B".

site_title: Australian cafe siege hostage killed by ricocheted police bullets
summary: A coronial inquest into the 2015 Sydney cafe siege revealed that one hostage, Katrina Dawson, was killed by police bullets that ricocheted off surfaces, striking a major blood vessel. Tori Johnson, the cafe manager, was shot in the back of the head by gunman Man Haron Monis. Monis was also killed in the shootout. The inquest's findings have raised questions about police tactics during the siege.

site_title: Dollar gains as Fed holds tight on policy
summary: The US dollar surged 0.8% to $1.1284 per euro, reversing two days of losses, after the Federal Reserve maintained its policy trajectory, indicating no immediate interest rate hike. The Fed described the economy as having a "solid pace" of growth, contradicting speculation that the Fed might pause its rate increase due to eurozone economic weakness and turbulence. This move is seen as a signal that the Fed will likely begin hiking interest rates around mid-year.

site_title: Samsung Elec Q4 profit down 36% on year, in line with guidance
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 36% year-over-year decline in Q4 profit to 5.3 trillion won (US$4.88 billion), in line with its guidance. The company's mobile division saw a 64% drop in profit to 1.96 trillion won, as the driver of its 2013 earnings. This marks Samsung's first annual earnings decline in three years. The company's decline is attributed to a decrease in smartphone sales and increased competition.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands profit beats estimates as Singapore's MBS surges
summary: Las Vegas Sands Corp reported fourth-quarter earnings of 92 cents a share, beating analysts' estimates. Profit in Singapore doubled, while revenue fell 6.6% to $3.42 billion. The company raised its dividend by 30%. Chairman Sheldon Adelson attributed the strong earnings to the company's continued performance.

site_title: Singapore startup Tembusu raises S$1.2m in bridge funding
summary: Singapore startup Tembusu Systems has raised S$1.2 million in bridge funding for its TRUST platform, valuing the company at S$11 million. The funding, from a Singapore-listed company, is seen as a "million-dollar vote of confidence" in the platform, which allows banks, governments, and corporations to launch their own asset-backed cryptocurrencies. TRUST's technology aims to address price stability and anonymity issues in Bitcoin, making it a more stable alternative. The funding comes as governments and companies explore cryptocurrency adoption, with Singapore's Monetary Authority allowing cryptocurrency use with regulation.

site_title: Singapore DBS CEO among potential candidates for StanChart's top job
summary: Standard Chartered is searching for a new CEO after Peter Sands' tenure was marred by a surge in bad loans and a 43% slump in its share price. Potential candidates include Piyush Gupta, CEO of Singapore-based DBS, and Antonio Horta-Osorio, CEO of Lloyds Banking Group, due to their Asian experience and regulatory clout. The bank is seeking someone who can navigate US regulators and address the challenges of slower Asian growth and a slump in oil prices. A succession plan has been called for by StanChart's No. 1 shareholder, Temasek, amid investor pressure.

site_title: S&P to pay US$1.37b in mortgage bond cases: sources
summary: Standard & Poor's is expected to agree to pay $1.37 billion to settle lawsuits over its grading of mortgage bonds in the 2008 financial crisis. The rating agency will not admit guilt but agree to a statement of facts on wrongdoing. This deal will wrap up one of the last major lawsuits related to the over-grading and deceptive marketing of securities, which led to billions of dollars in losses for investors. The settlement comes after numerous banks have already paid huge fines and settlements for their roles in packaging and selling the bonds.

site_title: Text of Fed's policy statement
summary: The Federal Reserve announced no changes to monetary policy following a two-day meeting, citing a solid pace of economic expansion and improving labor market conditions. The Committee expects moderate growth, with inflation declining further below its 2% target, but anticipates a gradual rise toward 2% as the labor market improves. The Committee reaffirmed its 0-1/4% target range for the federal funds rate, indicating patience in normalizing monetary policy, but may adjust the target range if progress toward its objectives is faster or slower than expected.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close mostly up
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mostly up on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.21% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 increasing 0.78%. Paris's CAC 40 fell 0.29%. The rally was driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares.

site_title: Boeing earnings rise on record commercial deliveries
summary: Boeing reported a 18.9% increase in quarterly profits to $1.5 billion, driven by record commercial deliveries of 723 jets in the fourth quarter. The company forecasts 750-755 commercial plane deliveries in 2015, citing strong demand from emerging markets and seasoned airlines. Boeing's CEO, Jim McNerney, attributed the growth to low fuel prices and positive traffic trends, despite costs for the 787 coming in above expectations. The company's free cash flow and robust backlog also reassured analysts.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 0.72%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened down 0.72% on Thursday, following a slump on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 128.82 points to 17,666.91. The strong dollar and falling oil prices led to a volatile session on Wall Street, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 plummeting 1.13% and 1.35% respectively.

site_title: Facebook says video is big, as daily views exceed 3 billion
summary: Facebook reports 3 billion daily video views, a three-fold increase from June, as it prioritizes showing videos in users' news feeds. The company aims to grow its ad business and capture more of the online-video ad market, which is projected to reach $7.77 billion this year. However, measuring the effectiveness of video ads remains a challenge, with no standard way to track views and returns. Facebook's method of counting views after just three seconds has raised concerns about the accuracy of its data.

site_title: Japan's trade balance to turn positive this year, JP Morgan predicts
summary: Japan's trade balance is predicted by JP Morgan to turn positive this year, with a projected surplus of 10.8 trillion yen, ending four years of a trade deficit. This shift is expected to boost the yen against the dollar, potentially reaching 124 to the dollar, and push inflation targets set by the Bank of Japan further out of reach. The improvement in trade balance is attributed to a pick-up in exports and a slowdown in imports, with exports projected to increase by 11 trillion yen and imports by 10 trillion yen.

site_title: CapitaRetail China Trust Q4 DPU rises 12.7% to 2.48 cents
summary: CapitaRetail China Trust (CRCT) reported a 12.7% increase in DPU to 2.48 cents for Q4 2014, driven by a 15.6% rise in distributable income and 30.1% growth in net property income. Stronger yuan against the Singapore dollar contributed to the increase. Gross revenue grew 27.7% to S$52.7 million, largely due to new contributions from CapitaMall Grand Canyon and rental growth from other malls.

site_title: Alibaba arm seeks to use police face scans to open bank accounts
summary: Alibaba's financial arm, Alipay, is seeking regulatory approval to use police face scans to open online bank accounts through its facial recognition system, Face++. The system matches facial features with those in the Ministry of Public Security database, which holds information on 1.3 billion Chinese citizens. Alipay plans to use this technology to allow consumers to set up accounts without physically visiting a bank. The company, backed by investors including Qiming Venture Partners, aims to create a biometric system for various businesses.

site_title: Amazon to offer business email, taking on Microsoft
summary: Amazon announced plans to offer a cloud-based email and calendar service, Amazon WorkMail, directly competing with Microsoft Outlook. The service, priced at $4 per user per month, will include 50 gigabytes of mailbox storage and be fully compatible with Microsoft Outlook. Amazon aims to target corporate customers currently paying for Microsoft Outlook or other services, offering a more cost-effective and secure solution. The service will be offered through Amazon Web Services and may be bundled with Amazon WorkDocs, a file storage service.

images.alt_text: US online giant Amazon announced plans Wednesday to offer a cloud-based email and calendar service to directly compete with Microsoft Outlook and others.

site_title: Spotify to replace Sony streaming music service
summary: Spotify has signed a deal with Sony to become the exclusive music streaming service for Playstation Music and Sony's smartphones and tablets in 41 markets. The partnership eliminates potential competition from Sony's Music Unlimited service, strengthening Spotify's position as the world's biggest music streaming service. The deal also marks the end of Sony's streaming music service. Spotify founder Daniel Ek hailed the partnership as a "huge opportunity" to provide gamers with an amazing music experience, while Andrew House, head of Sony's Network Entertainment Business, emphasized the importance of music in the entertainment offering.

images.alt_text: Swedish music streamer Spotify will provide the soundtrack for Sony devices, the companies said on Wednesday, spelling the end to the streaming music service from the Japanese tech giant that invented the Walkman.

site_title: S$ hits 4-year low; exports outlook still gloomy
summary: The Singapore dollar hit a 4-year low against the US dollar after the Monetary Authority of Singapore eased its appreciation pace, weakening the currency to 1.3548 per US dollar. Despite this, economists say anaemic exports will continue to be affected by structural factors, and poor global demand will remain a concern for Singapore's exports outlook. Analysts expect the Singapore dollar to weaken further to S$1.40 by the end of the year.

site_title: More going through mediation to resolve disputes
summary: The Singapore Mediation Centre handled 337 mediation matters in 2024, the highest since its inception in 1997. This surge in commercial disputes has led to a significant increase in mediation cases.

site_title: Japan's retail sales unexpectedly slump in challenge to Abe
summary: Japan's retail sales unexpectedly fell 0.3% in December for a third straight monthly decline, contradicting Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to stimulate the economy. This marks a challenge to Abe's recovery plans, which rely on consumer spending. Economists attribute the decline to a slow recovery in domestic consumption after a sales-tax hike last year. The government's reliance on pay gains to offset rising living costs remains uncertain, and talks between business and labor leaders this spring will determine the extent of pay increases.

images.alt_text: Japanese retail sales unexpectedly fell in December, underscoring challenges to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's effort to stoke a recovery in the world's third-biggest economy.

site_title: Chinese company limits US drone use after White House crash
summary: A Chinese drone maker, DJI, has announced a software update for its "Phantom" series drones to prohibit flight over the Washington, D.C. area, following a recent crash on White House grounds. The update will restrict flights within 25 kilometers (15 miles) of the capital, effectively limiting drone use in the US capital. This move comes in response to the incident, which raised concerns about drone security and safety.

site_title: Fed keeps 'patient' on rate hike amid 'solid' growth
summary: The Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged near zero, citing "solid" economic growth, as it assesses the economy's expansion and inflation. The Fed's policy arm stated that it can be patient in normalizing monetary policy, and inflation is expected to rise gradually towards 2% over the medium term. Despite concerns about the global slowdown, the Fed remains bullish on current economic conditions and the outlook, with the unemployment rate at 5.6% and strong job gains. The decision leaves the door open for a potential rate hike in June if labor data continue to improve.

site_title: Thailand accuses US of meddling in its politics
summary: Thailand accused the US of meddling in its politics after Assistant US Secretary of State for East Asia Daniel Russel criticized the ruling military junta. The US envoy's remarks were seen as a call for more inclusive politics and an end to martial law, which led to a deterioration in relations. The US has since scaled back its aid and security cooperation, including the Cobra Gold joint military exercise. Thailand's military government has promised reforms but critics say the army has stifled free speech, leading to a strained relationship with its long-time ally.

site_title: Bank of England's Carney urges Europe to take plunge on fiscal union
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney urged the euro zone to create a fiscal union to escape its debt trap, criticizing its lack of support for states during economic shocks. He praised the European Central Bank's bond-buying plan but said the euro zone needs to act on other reforms, such as federal government transfers. If the euro zone were a country, its fiscal policy would be more supportive, Carney said. The call is likely to be rebuffed by Germany.

site_title: Greek PM Tsipras freezes privatisations, markets tumble
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras freezes planned privatizations, defying international creditors, amid a third day of heavy losses on financial markets. The move sets the new government on a collision course with European partners, including Germany, which has refused to renegotiate the bailout deal. Tsipras announced the halt to appease voters who have suffered under austerity measures, warning that disappointing them would be unacceptable.

site_title: Bloomberry plans S Korea casino in first overseas foray
summary: Bloomberry Resorts Corp, a Philippine gaming and leisure company, plans to build a casino and entertainment complex in South Korea, its first overseas venture. The project, valued at at least S$1.2 billion, will be built on a 12.2-hectare plot of land in the Incheon Free Economic Zone. The company will invest alone, unlike other joint ventures, and aims to complete the resort within five years. The move follows South Korea's approval of two new casino resorts, which are expected to attract significant investment from operators.

site_title: Smithsonian envisions a London presence
summary: The Smithsonian, a network of world-renowned museums in Washington, plans to establish a London presence with a 40,000 sq. ft. exhibition space in the East End, set to open in 2021. The space, located on the site of the 2012 Olympics, will feature permanent and rotating exhibitions, programs, and activities, with permanent exhibitions being free to all. The Smithsonian will cover operating expenses with donations and admission fees. This marks the first time the organization has set up a long-term venue outside the US, with the goal of sharing its collection with an international audience.

site_title: Global funds buy US$288m of Indian airport notes
summary: India's Delhi International Airport Ltd sold $288.75 million of seven-year notes to global investors, the first time the company has tapped international markets. The sale will help refinance a $350 million loan due in 2021. India needs to spend $1 trillion on infrastructure between 2012 and 2017 to compete with China, and domestic funds cannot cover this amount. The sale reflects growing investor interest in India, with the rupee rallying 2.7% against the US dollar this year. This move is seen as a step towards revamping India's infrastructure and attracting foreign investment.

site_title: Ericsson expects North America slowdown as Q4 sales lag forecasts
summary: Ericsson reports Q4 sales below expectations, with comparable sales down 2% due to a slowdown in the North American market. The company's biggest customers have largely completed 4G network construction and are saving cash for acquisitions and spectrum auctions. Despite this, Ericsson's shares remain near seven-year highs. The company expects restructuring charges of 3-4 billion crowns in 2015 to mitigate price pressures. Growth is forecast in the Middle East, Western and Central Europe, and South-east Asia, where operators are starting to build 4G networks.

site_title: Nissan, Ford recall hundreds of thousands of cars
summary: Nissan and Ford issued recalls for hundreds of thousands of cars worldwide to address safety concerns. Nissan recalled 768,000 vehicles due to a potential hood latch issue and a wiring problem that could cause a fire. Ford recalled nearly 205,000 vehicles for doors that could open in a crash due to a problem with the handles. Additionally, Ford recalled 16,000 vans for incorrectly tightened seat-belt fasteners. No injuries have been reported in either case.

images.alt_text: Nissan and Ford issued recalls of hundreds of thousands of cars Wednesday to address problem parts that could lead to injuries.

site_title: Facebook tops Wall Street revenue target in 4th quarter
summary: Facebook Inc's revenue grew 49% in the fourth quarter, beating Wall Street's targets, driven by mobile advertising growth. The company's mobile ads accounted for 69% of advertising revenue, or $2.48 billion. Despite this, Facebook's operating expenses grew 87% due to increased research and development costs and marketing spending. The company earned 54 cents a share, beating analyst estimates. Facebook's shares fell 2.6% in after-hours trade, but analysts see video ads as a potential growth driver.

site_title: IMF decision could propel yuan past sterling and yen
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is considering adding the yuan to its Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket, which could propel the Chinese currency past the yen and pound, making it the third-highest weighted currency. This move would significantly boost the yuan's global adoption and impact. China is the world's largest exporter, contributing to the yuan's inclusion in the SDR basket. If successful, the yuan's value could increase, making it a more attractive investment option.

site_title: Indian vaccine maker working on a range of low-priced products
summary: Serum Institute of India Ltd, the world's largest vaccine maker, is developing low-priced vaccines that could undercut major pharmaceutical brands. The company is targeting vaccines for HPV, severe diarrhoea, and pneumonia, with one HPV vaccine potentially selling at a third of the price of Merck's Gardasil. Serum's new offerings could pose a significant threat to the global pharmaceutical industry, especially as the company is already producing vaccines in 65% of the world's children.

site_title: Guanxi in China 'can be a double-edged sword'
summary: In China, a "guanxi" relationship, built on trust, can help conduct business, but it can also enable fraud. Due-diligence experts warn that buying a company linked to someone powerful can lead to problems. Guanxi can "paper over" issues, but it's not a substitute for thorough investigation. The issue is particularly relevant in China, where relationships can be used to facilitate or hide wrongdoing. Experts emphasize the need for caution when conducting business in China, highlighting the importance of due diligence to avoid potential pitfalls.

site_title: AirAsia X planning rights issue, senior management shuffle: reports
summary: AirAsia X, a long-haul budget carrier, is planning a rights issue to address cash-flow issues, reportedly due to struggling with wage payments and underperformance. Senior management, including CEO Azran Osman-Rani and CFO Chew Eng Loke, could be departing the airline. The company's board is set to meet on Thursday to discuss the issue. Analysts predict a "hold" call on the stock, citing uncertainties that may negatively impact sentiment.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Aussie core inflation up, eases fears of interest rate cut
summary: Australia's core consumer prices rose 0.7% for the quarter and 2.2% for the year, within the Reserve Bank of Australia's preferred range, easing fears of a near-term interest rate cut. The Australian dollar rallied as oil prices plunged, with global crude costs falling 50% to near six-year lows. Economists say the latest data suggests a rate cut is unlikely, with some still open to cuts due to disinflationary pressures.

site_title: Stay-at-home small caps in vogue as dollar roils multinationals
summary: US small-cap stocks have outperformed multinationals, with the iShares Russell 2000 ETF absorbing over $1 billion in trading last week. The strong dollar has eroded sales for US companies with international exposure, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average tumbling 1.7% on Tuesday. In contrast, the Russell 2000 Index lost only 0.5% as investors seek less globally exposed stocks. The gap between the two indexes is the largest to start a year since 2012, with investors pulling $20 billion from large-cap funds and adding $1.1 billion to small-cap ETFs.

site_title: AT&T posts net loss of US$4b in Q4
summary: AT&T reported a quarterly net loss of $4 billion, beating Wall Street expectations by a penny. The second-largest US wireless carrier saw a 1.22% rate of customer defections and a 10.7% decline in average revenue per phone user. Despite this, AT&T attracted more customers and added over 2 million new wireless subscribers. The company expects margin expansion and adjusted earnings growth in the "low single-digit range" in 2015.

site_title: Shadow banking crackdown seen needed to tame stocks in China
summary: China's crackdown on borrowing for stock purchases, known as "umbrella trusts," has failed to curb excessive risk-taking by investors. The structures allow for higher leverage, exposing individuals to larger losses, and have been used to finance 500 billion yuan in stocks. Despite a recent Shanghai Composite Index drop, the benchmark has since rebounded, and China's economy continues to grow, albeit at its slowest pace since 1990. Regulatory measures, including lower leverage ratios, are needed to address the risks associated with shadow banking and umbrella trusts.

site_title: Boeing surveillance aircraft gets Pentagon budget boost
summary: The US Pentagon has approved a budget boost for Boeing's P-8A Poseidon maritime surveillance aircraft, with a requested $3.4 billion for 16 aircraft in fiscal 2016. This increase signals support for the US pledge to rebalance forces to Asia. The Pentagon's overall budget request for fiscal 2016 exceeds spending caps, with plans to spend $534 billion, $547 billion in 2017, and $570 billion in 2020. The proposal also includes a 1.3% pay raise for troops and $50.9 billion for war spending, including $42 billion for US-Afghanistan troop support.

site_title: In brief
summary: KepCorp appoints Credit Suisse as joint financial adviser for its KepLand bid. Mercator Lines recorded a net loss of $7.47 million in Q3 2014, with revenue plummeting 43% due to lower spot rates and unscheduled vessel repairs. Terratech Group entered a framework agreement to acquire a Chinese marble tile producer, Meilian Changchi, for approximately $15.44 million. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks rallied for five consecutive days ahead of GDP data release, and Citigroup set a mid-2026 target for MSCI's global equity index to reach 1,150.

site_title: Remanufacturing gains traction in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Advanced Remanufacturing and Technology Centre (ARTC) has moved to a new, 70,000-square-foot facility in CleanTech Two, aiming to drive growth in the remanufacturing sector. The centre, established by A*Star in 2012, has partnered with industry leaders, including Rolls-Royce, to develop remanufacturing technologies and reduce waste and energy consumption. Since 2012, ARTC has identified over 50 remanufacturing projects, and its number of completed projects is expected to reach 100 by year's end.

site_title: Jordan proposes prisoner swap, fate of Japanese hostage unclear
summary: Jordan has proposed a prisoner swap, offering to release Iraqi woman Sajida Al-Rishawi if a Jordanian pilot, Lieutenant Muath Al-Kasaesbeh, is released and his life spared. Al-Kasaesbeh was captured by ISIS after a bombing mission in December. The proposal was made in response to a video showing Japanese hostage Kenji Goto, a veteran war reporter, with a shorter time to live. Japan has confirmed the video's existence, and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has vowed to work with Jordan to secure Goto's release, but has refused to give in to terrorism.

site_title: Yuan now in world's top five as payment currency
summary: China's yuan surpassed the Canadian and Australian dollar to enter the world's top five as a payment currency, according to the Swift global transaction services organization. The yuan reached a record-high share of 2.17% in global payments by value, driven by the growth of offshore yuan clearing centers. Global yuan payments increased by 20.3% in value in December, outpacing the overall growth of 14.9% for all currencies. China is expected to push for the inclusion of the yuan in the IMF's in-house currency basket, with its G-20 partners potentially willing to reconsider due to the yuan's growing usability.

site_title: US$ inches up, caution ahead of Fed statement
summary: The US dollar rose against a basket of currencies on Wednesday, recouping some losses from the previous day, before a Federal Reserve statement. Interest-rate sensitive yields held above 0.50 percent, supporting the dollar. Despite strong consumer confidence and home sales data, the dollar could be vulnerable if the Fed shows unease with its strength. The dollar index was up 0.1 percent at 94.137, and the euro fell 0.2 percent against the US dollar. A surprise monetary easing by Singapore also lifted the dollar against Asian currencies.

site_title: Consumer confidence at 6-month high but sentiment over economy worsens
summary: Consumer confidence in Singapore has reached a 6-month high, with the ANZ-Roy Morgan index rising to 122.8 points in January, surpassing the 2014 average of 121.1 points. Despite this, sentiment over the economy has worsened, with fewer consumers expressing confidence in the economic outlook. This marks a mixed trend in consumer confidence, with optimism about family finances offset by concerns about the economy.

site_title: Singapore hosts SEA Games on S$324.5m budget
summary: Singapore will host the South-east Asian (SEA) Games on a budget of S$324.5 million, with 90% of tenders awarded to local companies. The event, scheduled for June 5-16, will feature 402 sporting events at 31 venues, including the new Singapore Sports Hub. Free admission will be offered to half of the Games' 36 sports, while ticket prices range from S$5 to S$20. The event is part of Singapore's golden jubilee celebrations and is expected to provide a boost to the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang
THIS year's South-east Asian (SEA) Games, which Singapore will stage over two weeks in June, will be organised with an estimated budget of S$324.5 million, the organisers announced on Wednesday.

site_title: Ireland eases mortgage cap plan to help first-time buyers
summary: Ireland's central bank has scaled back plans to limit mortgages, allowing first-time buyers to borrow up to 90% of a property valued at €220,000 (approximately $337,492), as the nation recovers from a real-estate collapse. The change aims to aid first-time buyers and was made in response to criticism from politicians and bankers. The new rules will be introduced in the coming weeks, while most non-first-time buyers must put down a minimum 20% deposit.

site_title: CDLHT declares 3.13¢ DPS for Q4, eyes more Japan assets
summary: CDL Hospitality Trust (CDLHT) reported a 7.2% increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 3.13 cents for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2014. The trust manager, Vincent Yeo, expressed interest in acquiring more hotel assets in Japan following the acquisition of two hotels in Tokyo last month. Gross revenue rose 14.4% and net property income grew 6% year on year, driven by contributions from the Jumeirah Dhevanafushi and Angsana Velavaru properties. Despite a soft patch in its Singapore portfolio, CDLHT's strategy to diversify into key markets has augmented overall portfolio performance.

site_title: Short-term borrowing rates including Sibor seen getting a boost (Amended)
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) cut the slope of its Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER), allowing for a slower pace of exchange rate appreciation. This move is expected to boost short-term SGD borrowing rates, including the Singapore Interbank Offered Rate (Sibor), which surged to 0.653% on Wednesday. Analysts predict further increases in Sibor and the swap offer rate (SOR), which could benefit Singapore banks' profits. Standard Chartered revised its forecasts, expecting three-month Sibor to reach 1% by the end of the year.

site_title: Solar, water-treatment key themes of projects
summary: Singapore's inaugural JTC-Spring Grant Call has selected six projects, with three focusing on solar energy and two on water-treatment solutions. Local startup Omega Solar's T-PV hybrid technology, which cools solar panels with a fluid, has shown up to four times higher energy output and will be tested at CleanTech One for two years. Ecosoftt's on-site wastewater recycling system, Poseidon, will also be tested at the facility, aiming to recycle up to 80% of wastewater and reduce water footprint by 50%.

site_title: Qatari-led group set to win bid for London's Canary Wharf
summary: A Qatari-led consortium is set to win the bid for London's Canary Wharf after Songbird Estates dropped its opposition to the US$4 billion offer. The consortium, led by Qatar Investment Authority and Brookfield Property Partners, has secured backing from 86% of shareholders and is now urging minority investors to accept. The deal, which values Canary Wharf at 350 pence per share, is seen as undervalued by Songbird, but the company believes it is the best option given the lack of rival bids. Shareholders have until Thursday to accept the offer.

site_title: Alibaba arm sets up consumer credit scoring service
summary: Alibaba's financial affiliate, Ant Financial, launched a consumer credit scoring service called Sesame Credit Management in China. The service analyzes customer behavior, including data from over 300 million registered users and 37 million small businesses on Alibaba's e-commerce platforms. Sesame Credit scores range from 350 to 950 points, allowing users to check their ratings in their Alipay Wallet mobile application. The system aims to provide credit services to those with little history at traditional credit agencies, promoting economic and social development in China.

site_title: Skillsave accounts will empower workers to get the training they need
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has pushed for a "Skillsave account" to empower Singaporean workers with their own training funds, allowing them to upgrade skills and choose courses independently. The initiative aims to address the country's need for lifelong learning in an uncertain global environment. The NTUC has been lobbying for this since the 1990s and has piloted similar training funds in the past. A portable Skillsave account could benefit workers, employers, and companies, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises, and is seen as a step towards a future-ready workforce.

site_title: Dubai house prices to ease in 2015: JLL
summary: Dubai house prices are expected to decline by up to 10% in 2015, following a 56% rise in the past two years, due to a slump in oil prices. The emirate's robust economy is helping to mitigate the impact, with a forecasted 4.5% growth in 2014 and above. A correction is expected to be "measured" rather than a repeat of the 2008-9 crash, with about 25,000 new properties set to be released in 2015.

site_title: Crisis deepens slide in living standards for Russian pensioners
summary: Russia's pensioners face a crisis as rising prices and declining living standards threaten President Putin's support. With annual inflation reaching 11.4% and prices for food and medicine increasing, pensioners are struggling to make ends meet. Many, like 86-year-old Boris Lisitsyn, are forced to cut back on luxuries and rely on home-grown produce. The government has promised to index pensions to inflation, but officials have cast doubt over its affordability, with the State Pension Fund projected to spend 7.6 trillion roubles this year.

site_title: Middle-East mess plagues US agenda
summary: US President Barack Obama is likely to face increased pressure to address the ongoing instability in the Middle East, six years after he committed to disengaging from the region. Despite his "pivot" strategy to focus on East Asia, the Middle East remains a pressing concern, with frequent political upheavals and threats of war. Obama's diplomatic and military responses only fuel anti-American backlash, leading to further American entanglement and criticism back home, with no end in sight.

images.alt_text: Last week, the Shiite Houthi militias that are affiliated with the powerful Houthi tribe succeeded in taking over Sana'a and appeared to emerge as the winning side in the long war the Houthis have been waging against the government.

site_title: Iraq's Syariah-compliant banks expect growth despite strife
summary: Iraq's Syariah-compliant banks expect growth despite sectarian violence, targeting a population of 36 million with low formal banking penetration. Elaf Islamic Bank aims for a 28% profit increase this year, while Cihan Bank reported a decline in income due to militant seizures. The lenders see opportunities in the growing population, which has limited access to formal banking services.

images.alt_text: About 11 per cent of Iraqis aged 15 years and older have accounts at formal banking institutions. Now the Cabinet has approved a draft law regulating the Syariah-compliant banking industry, which will now move to Parliament for passage.

site_title: MAS's lesson in the unexpected
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) unexpectedly eased its Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) policy, slowing the appreciation of the Singapore dollar. The move, described as a "surprise" and "unscheduled," came amidst a backdrop of global central bank action and the plunge in oil prices. MAS cited receding imported inflationary pressures and global oil prices as factors, emphasizing the need for a "measured adjustment" to more benign inflation conditions. The decision may signal a new policy cycle, with MAS re-centring the NEER or altering its policy stance, although the central bank reiterated its commitment to gradual appreciation.

images.alt_text: Wong Wei Kong

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore stocks ended a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the Straits Times Index up 0.5%. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned H2 revenue may be below target, with an operating loss similar to H1. Meanwhile, OCBC named Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing Helen Wong. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: MAS springs surprise: slower S$ gains
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) surprised markets by easing monetary policy, allowing the Singapore dollar to appreciate at a slower pace against a trade-weighted basket of currencies. The MAS reduced the slope of the S$NEER policy band and cut its 2015 inflation forecasts to -0.5 to 0.5% for headline inflation and 0.5 to 1.5% for core inflation. This decision was prompted by a sharp drop in global oil prices, which has resulted in overall import prices declining by an average of 6.5% year-on-year. The MAS's growth outlook for 2015 remains unchanged at 2-4%.

site_title: American Airlines shares fall 5% in fare squeeze with low-cost carriers
summary: American Airlines shares fell 5% after the airline reported a forecast of a 2-4% decline in passenger revenue per available seat mile due to low-fare domestic rivals adding seating capacity. This forecast overshadowed news of a US$2 billion stock buyback and US$5 billion in 2015 fuel savings. The airline attributed the decline to increased competition from low-cost carriers.

site_title: Oil slide to extend biggest LNG drop in 5 years
summary: LNG prices are set to drop 35% in Japan and 33% in India in 2015, the biggest declines in five years, due to new supply from Australia and the US. Global demand is expected to rise 9.8% this year, driven by increased imports by India and South-east Asia. The price drop will spur demand in emerging economies, with Indian buyers showing renewed interest. China, India, and South-east Asia will be the driving forces of incremental buying by 2020, according to Energy Aspects Ltd and BNEF.

site_title: Benalec shares up on approval for reclamation of land off Johor
summary: Malaysian reclamation company Benalec Holdings shares rose 3.2% to 80.5 sen after receiving approval from Malaysia's Department of Environment to reclaim 1,411 hectares of land off Tanjung Piai Johor for an integrated petroleum hub and maritime industrial park. The project has a binding land-sale agreement with 1MY Strategic Oil Terminal Sdn Bhd, but the sale of 1,000 acres is still pending. The DOE approval includes conditions for environmental recommendations and approvals, and Benalec considers it a major milestone.

site_title: Behind Singapore's monetary policy shock
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) implemented a monetary policy shock in 2015, which included a surprise 0.5% hike in the overnight policy rate. The move was aimed at cooling down the economy, which was experiencing rapid growth. The MAS also increased reserve requirements for banks and tightened lending standards. The policy change was seen as a bold move to manage inflation and stabilize the economy, but its impact was not immediately clear. The MAS has since maintained a cautious approach to monetary policy, with interest rates remaining low to support economic growth.

site_title: Indonesia FDI commitment growth slowed last year, may pick up in 2015
summary: Indonesia's foreign investment commitments grew 13.5% in 2014, slower than the 22.4% increase in 2013, due to a "wait and see" mood among investors during the election year. The new administration aims to speed up infrastructure projects and reduce red tape to boost growth. President Joko Widodo targets 5.8% GDP growth, mainly through higher investment, with a modest FDI goal of 343.7 trillion rupiah. Analysts suggest the government needs to improve the investment climate, address land acquisition issues, and provide tax incentives to attract more investors.

site_title: Mortgage revival expected in Spain after ECB easing
summary: Spain's mortgage market is expected to revive after the European Central Bank's (ECB) efforts to funnel cheap credit to banks. Residential mortgages rose 14% in November, with the total amount lent increasing 12%, according to the National Statistics Institute (INE). The ECB's bond-buying program and cheap loan program are likely to fuel this turnaround, with Spanish property website Fotocasa predicting incentives for mortgage financing. Home loan approvals are still low, but Spanish lenders have launched lower mortgage offers, with the average interest rate decreasing to 3.49% in November.

site_title: Apple shines on booming China sales
summary: Apple reported a record 74 million iPhone sales worldwide in the first quarter, driven by booming sales in China. Revenue grew 30% and earnings reached $18 billion, with the company surpassing analysts' expectations. Despite a strong dollar and stiff competition, Apple's pricing power and innovative products, such as Apple Pay and the Apple Watch, contributed to its success.
