Russel emphasized the importance of a "more inclusive political process" and urged an end to martial law and restrictions on free speech and assembly. The US has suspended $4.7 million in security-related aid to Thailand and is advocating for a swift return to democracy.

site_title: Microsoft's software license sales miss estimates
summary: Microsoft's software license sales to businesses fell short of estimates in the fiscal second quarter, with commercial licensing revenue reaching $10.7 billion, missing analysts' projections of $10.9 billion. Weak sales in Japan and China, as well as a corporate push to replace Windows XP, contributed to the decline. Despite this, the company's cloud software and Xbox video-game console sales grew, and total sales topped estimates. Microsoft's CEO, Satya Nadella, attributed the miss to execution and macroeconomic issues, and promised to address them.

site_title: UBS says Asia's rich show less love for Aussie: Australia Credit
summary: UBS Group AG reports that Asia's wealthy investors are losing interest in the Australian dollar, citing record-low yields and declining commodity prices. The currency has fallen 16% in the past six months, and experts predict it will continue to decline. The Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Glenn Stevens expects the currency to extend its losses, and a US interest rate hike could provide a respite for the Aussie dollar. Analysts predict the currency will end the year at 77-78 US cents, with some forecasting it could reach 70 cents.

images.alt_text: Asia's wealthy are falling out of love with the Aussie dollar as record-low yields and sustained declines persuade them to look elsewhere, according to UBS Group AG.

site_title: Huawei to ship 100 million smartphones amid overseas expansion
summary: Huawei plans to ship 100 million smartphones this year, a 33% increase from 75 million last year, as it expands into high-end devices and international markets. The company aims to boost sales from high-end devices to over 30% and increase its international market share to over 60%. This growth strategy aims to compete with top suppliers like Samsung and Apple, and surpass Xiaomi and Lenovo in global smartphone shipments.

site_title: 'Historic' blizzard strikes US northeast
summary: A historic blizzard, Winter Storm Juno, struck the US northeast on January 26, 2015, affecting tens of millions of people, with up to 1m of snow expected in parts of New England. The storm forced the cancellation of Broadway shows, NBA games, and postponed flights, with 6,560 cancellations on Monday and Tuesday. A travel ban was imposed in 13 counties of New York state, and states of emergency were declared in New York and New Jersey. The storm paralyzed swaths of the East Coast, with officials warning of poor visibility, dangerous winds, and power outages.

site_title: Qantas, Virgin use lower oil prices to absorb fuel surcharges
summary: Qantas Airways Ltd and Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd are restructuring their international tariffs to absorb fuel surcharges into base fares. Lower oil prices, about 60% cheaper than its June peak, prompted the move. Qantas will increase base fares to cover the scrapping of fuel surcharges, but restructure will benefit passengers using frequent flyer points. The airline aims to invest in new aircraft, lounges, and routes with lower oil prices, putting the industry on a more sustainable footing, according to CEO Alan Joyce.

site_title: Fed seen raising rates mid-year even with low inflation: economists
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates in mid-2015, despite low inflation, according to a survey of economists. 45% of respondents predict a rate hike in June, while 30% expect it to happen in September. The Fed is expected to overlook the impact of a stronger dollar and the European Central Bank's quantitative-easing program. Economists forecast US economic growth of 3.2% this year, with inflation expected to rise just 1% to 1.6% as measured by the personal consumption expenditures price index.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC keeps 'sell' rating on Tigerair
summary: OCBC Investment Research maintained its "sell" rating on Tigerair, citing concerns over the airline's profitability and turnaround strategy. Despite a profitable Q3 FY2015 with a net profit of S$2.19 million, analyst Eugene Chua believes the company's success is "overdone" and prefers to wait and see if improvements can be sustained. Tigerair's focus on Singapore operations and alliance with Scoot are seen as key to its long-term success, but costs and passenger traffic growth are expected to take time to materialize.

site_title: Opec's El-Badri says US$200 oil possible with lack of investment
summary: Opec's secretary-general Abdalla El-Badri warns that oil prices could reach $200 per barrel if producers fail to invest in new supply, citing a lack of investment due to current price collapse. A 46% decline in oil prices last year, driven by surging US shale oil production, has led to reduced investment, potentially leaving the market with limited oil supplies in the future. Analysts disagree on the likelihood of prices reaching $200, with some predicting a rebound above $100 per barrel that would deter shale oil drillers.

site_title: Australia business mood muted in Dec: survey
summary: Australia's business mood remained muted in December, with a measure of business conditions easing to +4, a point below its long-run average, according to a National Australia Bank survey. Profits, sales, and employment all softened, while confidence improved due to sharp falls in fuel costs. The survey's index of sales fell to +9, while profitability and employment eased to +6 and -1, respectively. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to ease policy, with consumer price figures expected to show headline inflation slowed to 1.8% in the last quarter of 2014.

site_title: Small drone crashes on White House grounds
summary: A small drone crashed on the White House grounds early Monday morning, prompting a security lockdown. The device, approximately two feet in diameter, was spotted by a Secret Service officer and crashed on the southeast side of the complex. The operator, a government employee, claimed he did not intend to fly the device over the White House grounds. An investigation has been launched to determine the origin of the device, motive, and identify suspects. The incident occurred while President Barack Obama and his family were in Washington, but not at the White House.

site_title: Ex-CIA officer in leak case found guilty of espionage
summary: A former CIA officer, Jeffrey Sterling, was found guilty of espionage charges for leaking classified details of a secret operation to thwart Iran's nuclear program. Sterling was convicted on all nine counts in a federal court in Alexandria, Virginia. The case has sparked outcry among media watchdogs, with over 100,000 supporters signing an online petition calling for an end to the prosecution. The conviction marks a victory for the Obama administration's crackdown on whistleblowers, who have used the Espionage Act to prosecute government officials suspected of leaking classified data.

site_title: IMF set to continue support Greece after election
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has stated its readiness to continue financial support to Greece after the country's leftist, anti-austerity party Syriza won a resounding victory in the general election. IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde expressed her commitment to discussing with the new government, led by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras. Greece's massive 240-billion-euro EU-IMF bailout terms will be renegotiated, with Syriza pledging to raise salaries and pensions, halt layoffs, and freeze privatization of state assets. The IMF's four-year loan program for Greece aims to ensure the government meets budget and reform targets before releasing a new tranche of the loan.

site_title: S&P downgrades Russia's sovereign credit rating to "junk"
summary: S&P downgrades Russia's sovereign credit rating to "junk" status, the first time in over a decade, citing weakened economic growth prospects due to low oil prices and Western sanctions. The rouble fell 5% to 67.98 against the dollar, and the cost of insuring Russian sovereign debt widened to 591 basis points. The downgrade is expected to harm Russia's image among investors and push up borrowing costs, with some analysts predicting a recession in 2015.

site_title: Mattel CEO out as toy sales suffer
summary: Mattel, a US toy maker, replaced its CEO Bryan Stockton after disappointing holiday sales sent net income plummeting. Stockton resigned as chairman and CEO, and Christopher Sinclair, a Mattel board member, took over as chairman and interim CEO. The board believes new leadership is needed to maximize Mattel's potential, citing the company's exceptional status.

images.alt_text: US toymaker Mattel, Inc. replaced its chief executive on Monday after disappointing sales for the Christmas holiday season sent net income plunging.

site_title: Bank sees year of low growth, high inflation in Brazil
summary: Brazil's central bank forecasts stagnant growth of 0.13% in 2015, down from a previous projection of 0.38%, with inflation expected to rise from 6.67% to 6.99%. This marks a significant downward revision from previous forecasts, with inflation surpassing the government's 6.5% ceiling and the central bank's 4.5% target. The bank attributes the slowdown to economic concerns, including low commodity prices and a weakening currency.

site_title: More relaxed investment guidelines for AIMS Property Securities Fund
summary: AIMS Fund Management has amended investment guidelines for its AIMS Property Securities Fund (APW), allowing for increased underwriting exposure and investment in any security up to 100% of fund value. The maximum exposure to any one manager is also increased to 100%. The minimum size of investee funds is reduced from S$20 million to S$5 million. APW has also acquired 11.7 million units in the AIMS Property Fund, increasing its stake to 89.96%.

images.alt_text: AIMS Fund Management is amending a number of investment guidelines for its AIMS Property Securities Fund (APW).

site_title: Southeast Asian bitcoin site charged with securities fraud
summary: A Southeast Asia-based bitcoin website, Bitcoinhyip.org, has been charged with securities fraud after 72 similar sites were seized in Manhattan. The site promised investors a return of 3,641% but instead used their bitcoins to cover earlier payments and fund personal expenses. The charge is part of a broader crackdown on unregulated digital currencies linked to money laundering. District Attorney Cyrus Vance Jr. warned that unregulated currencies make such conduct "too easy and untraceable," as the US seeks to regulate the bitcoin market.

site_title: Russian pullback from Dubai offset by shoppers from elsewhere
summary: Russian shoppers are pulling back from Dubai's Shopping Festival due to a currency crunch, but visitors from other countries, such as China, are expected to fill the gap. The event, which typically attracts Russian and Cantonese shoppers with discounts and raffles, is unlikely to be significantly impacted despite the decline in Russian attendance.

images.alt_text: Russian performers at the Dubai Festival City last week. Russian Travel operators reported a sharp drop in the number of tours booked to the emirate compared to last year, one by as much as 80 per cent.

site_title: Coinbase opens first US regulated bitcoin exchange
summary: Coinbase, a US-based bitcoin wallet operator, has launched the first regulated US exchange for the alternative currency. The move aims to bring stability to the bitcoin ecosystem, which has faced concerns over links to illegal activities and volatility. The exchange's launch comes after Coinbase raised $75 million in capital, bringing its total funding to $106 million. The value of a bitcoin was around $285 at the time of the launch, down from a peak of over $1,200 in 2013. The opening could provide a boost to the cryptocurrency.

site_title: Oil slides despite Opec talk of a floor
summary: Oil prices fell 1.3% to US$48.16, with US crude settling at US$45.15, its lowest in nearly six years. Despite Opec Secretary-General Abdullah al-Badri's comments that oil may have hit a floor and could move higher soon, traders discounted the statement. The market was influenced by a US snowstorm and a Greek election victory by the left-wing Syriza party, leading to muted trading volume.

images.alt_text: Oil fell in see-saw trade on Monday, with US crude ending at its lowest in nearly six years, as traders discounted comments from Opec's top official about the market finally finding a bottom.

site_title: Toyota to move to merit-based pay for factory workers: Nikkei
summary: Toyota Motor Corp plans to transition from a seniority-based pay system to a merit-based system for its factory workers, affecting about 40,000 employees aged 18-65. The new arrangement will evaluate employees twice a year and adjust wages every six months. Additionally, the company will restructure allowances for dependents to provide greater benefits to workers raising children. The proposal has been unveiled to the labor union, with a potential rollout in January next year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 1.04%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.04% on Tuesday, driven by gains on US and European markets despite concerns over Greece's anti-austerity Syriza party winning the weekend general election. The Nikkei 225 index gained 180.88 points to 17,649.40. European stocks also rose, with the euro recovering from its lowest level in nearly 12 years. The jump came as investors largely priced in the Greek election result, with Wall Street's Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also edging up.

site_title: UE E&C free float falls below 10%
summary: UE E&C's free float shares have fallen below 10% due to Southern Capital's acquisition of 81.15% stake, leaving Tong Teik with 9.2%. The acquisition ends on Wednesday with a final offer price of S$1.25 per share. If the free float drops below 10% or fewer than 500 shareholders remain, the Singapore Exchange can suspend or delist the stock. Southern Capital had earlier stated it would not restore the free float, potentially leading to the company's delisting.

site_title: Europe warns Greece's Syriza to stick to austerity
summary: The EU has warned Greece's new Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras to stick to austerity measures and debt commitments, threatening Greece's place in the eurozone if it fails to comply. Eurozone finance ministers, including Jeroen Dijsselbloem and Angela Merkel, have expressed concerns over Greece's debt levels and urged the new government to meet its commitments. The EU has ruled out debt cancellation, but is open to extending debt repayment deadlines or reducing interest rates. Tsipras' victory has boosted anti-austerity movements across Europe, and a tense negotiation period is expected ahead of a summit on February 12.

site_title: Saudi stock market to open to foreigners by mid-2015: regulator
summary: Saudi Arabia is set to open its stock market to foreign investors by mid-2015, with the final date to be announced after relevant regulations are issued. The move aims to attract large, sophisticated investors, excluding penny-stock players. This expansion is part of Saudi Arabia's efforts to increase its global presence and competitiveness, as it is a member of the G-20 group of major world economies.

site_title: South Korea Jan consumer sentiment snaps 3-month slide
summary: South Korea's consumer sentiment improved for the first time in four months in January, with a reading of 102, indicating that more consumers expect economic conditions to improve. Inflation expectations remained at a record low of 2.6% for the next 12 months. The Bank of Korea surveyed over 2,000 households and attributed the low inflation to the plunge in oil prices, despite its own downward revisions to its economic growth and inflation forecasts for 2015.

site_title: China bull market masks momentum breakdown
summary: China's stock market, which has been on a record-breaking rally, is showing signs of a potential downturn. Despite reaching a five-year high, turnover has declined 47% and new equity account openings have fallen 50%. The Shanghai Composite Index, which gained 63% in the past year, is expected to slow down in the first half of the year, according to Deutsche Bank and Windsor Capital. Experts warn that the economy is still weak and the market is driven by liquidity rather than fundamentals, making it a "mispriced market".

site_title: Ministers warn of danger of political one-upmanship
summary: Singaporean ministers DPM Teo and Chan Chun Sing warn of the dangers of political one-upmanship, where government policies with financial subsidies for the people could turn into an "auction" during national elections. They emphasized the need for parties to clearly state how they would fund proposed schemes to avoid imposing a burden on future generations. The ministers also cautioned against making promises that cannot be kept, highlighting the importance of sustainability and responsible governance.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Nomura says odds up of Abenomics derailing as tax pledge doubted
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc. has raised its probability of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic policies derailing to 10-20% or more by 2017, citing mounting signs of fiscal sustainability crumbling in Japan. The company's chief credit strategist, Toshihiro Uomoto, warns of a worst-case scenario where the economy contracts, Abe delays a sales tax rise, and the Bank of Japan boosts asset purchases, causing the yen to tumble. Japan's government debt has tripled since 1996, and the BOJ's bond buying program has pushed yields to record lows.

images.alt_text: Nomura Holdings Inc. says the probability that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic policies will end badly is increasing.

site_title: Euro recovers slightly after Greek polls; rouble sinks
summary: The euro recovered slightly against the dollar after Greece's leftist Syriza party won elections, potentially leading to tougher talks with creditors. The euro rose to $1.1234, while the dollar strengthened against the yen to 118.49. Meanwhile, the ruble sank after a deadly rocket attack in Ukraine raised the prospect of Western sanctions on Russia, cutting its debt rating to junk level. Investors expect Greek-led market volatility and the euro to weaken to parity with the dollar over the next six months.

site_title: US: Wall St rises after Greek elections; energy climbs
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 0.03%, the S&P 500 gaining 0.26%, and the Nasdaq Composite adding 0.29%. Energy stocks led gains after OPEC's secretary-general hinted that oil prices may have reached a floor. The Syriza party's victory in Greece's parliamentary elections was largely seen as priced into the market, and investors focused on other news, including a $16 billion packaging company merger and strong earnings from homebuilder DR Horton.

site_title: China's Li says to create 10m jobs in 2015: China Daily
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang pledged to create at least 10 million new jobs in 2015 to maintain healthy employment levels and social stability, amid a slowing economy. Last year, China created around 13 million jobs. Li emphasized the need to avoid sharp economic downturns, citing stress tests that suggest a large amount of unemployment could lead to social instability. This pledge comes as China's economy grew at its slowest pace in 24 years in 2014.

site_title: Microsoft profit falls on sluggish Windows, currency pressure
summary: Microsoft reported a fall in quarterly profit due to sluggish Windows sales and the impact of a strong US dollar. The company's shares fell 3% in after-hours trading, despite forecasted numbers. The Windows business has been under pressure for three years due to declining PC sales, but appears to be stabilizing. Analysts consider the results "good enough" but had hoped for a bigger beat.

site_title: Fly away with Elphy for a good cause
summary: Takashimaya Singapore has released limited-edition, 20-inch cabin trolley luggages with an elephant design by local child artist Gelyn Ong, priced at S$99 each. Eighty percent of proceeds will benefit The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund and The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. The luggages were designed as part of a charity program, with proceeds from previous auctions going to the Business Times Budding Artists Fund. The new luggages were colored by store staff and customers to increase their appeal, with all proceeds supporting a good cause.

site_title: JES places out shares to raise S$6.6 million
summary: SHIPBUILDING firm JES International has placed out shares to raise S$6.6 million, with 183 million new shares sold at S$0.036 a share. The placement, to investment firm Brilliant Choice International and private investor Sun Yiyi, represents a 15.5% stake in JES. The funds will be used to pay off a loan and settle a debt of S$11.2 million. As a result, JES' issued and paid-up share capital will increase by S$6.6 million, and its number of ordinary shares will rise from 1.2 billion to 1.4 billion.

site_title: Chinese actress buys into Alibaba Pictures as it warns of losses
summary: Chinese actress Zhao Wei and her husband Huang Youlong have invested over HK$3 billion (US$77.41 million) in Alibaba Pictures Group Ltd, taking a 9.18% stake in the film division. The move comes as Alibaba Pictures warned of potential losses of up to HK$600 million for 2014, citing delays in TV-series distribution and dropped magazine advertising revenue. The company's stock fell 1.26% on Monday. The investment is part of Alibaba's expansion into movies and entertainment content, with its first movie project unveiled this month.

site_title: Viva's Q4 distributable income 1.6% less than own forecast
summary: Viva Industrial Trust reported Q4 distributable income 1.6% lower than forecast, with net property income 8.6% higher than expected at S$11 million. Finance expenses were 40.9% higher than predicted at S$3.7 million. The trust attributed the underperformance to a planned asset enhancement initiative at Technopark@Chai Chee. Viva painted a cautious outlook for 2015, citing a fragile global economic outlook and mixed industrial property market prospects.

site_title: Nico founders sell controlling stake to investor at discount
summary: The founding family of Nico Steel Holdings sold a controlling stake to Parot Tovot, a private investor, at a discount price of 9.5 Singapore cents per share. The sale, completed on January 19, resulted in Parot Tovot becoming a 28.38% shareholder of Nico Steel Holdings.

site_title: Q4 and full-year GDP growth may be revised higher
summary: Singapore's Q4 and 2014 GDP growth may be revised higher after the manufacturing sector contracted less than expected in December, with a 1.9% year-on-year decline. The sector's performance was better than forecast, with some economists predicting Q4 GDP growth will be higher than the official forecast of 1.5%. Full-year GDP growth is now expected to be around 2.9%, according to some estimates, with the Ministry of Trade and Industry set to release final figures in February.

site_title: Wall Street left with skeleton crews down as blizzard bears down
summary: A blizzard bearing down on New York left Wall Street offices with skeleton crews, as many employees opted to work from home due to the severe weather. Major exchanges, including the NYSE and Nasdaq, remained open, while some retail banks closed branches in the region. Investment banks emphasized they were open for business, and some die-hards sought ways to get to the office. The storm prompted the US Treasury to reschedule government debt auctions and postpone municipal bond sales, with the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association recommending the domestic bond market remain open.

site_title: Hedge funds boost bearish bets on oil to 4-year high
summary: Hedge funds have increased bearish bets on oil to a four-year high, with US crude supplies reaching 397.9 million barrels in the week ended Jan 16. Despite Saudi Arabia's King Salman maintaining the country's production policy, hedge fund managers believe a rebound is unlikely due to growing US supplies and low prices. Net-long positions in oil fell for the first time in three weeks, and short positions in West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude increased to 94,203 futures and options.

site_title: US budget deficit to shrink this year: CBO
summary: The US budget deficit is expected to shrink in the current fiscal year to $468 billion, or 2.6% of GDP, the smallest shortfall since 2007. The deficit is projected to climb after 2017 due to increased spending on health and retirement benefits. The Congressional Budget Office predicts the deficit will reach $1.1 trillion by 2025. Despite this, the economy is expected to continue growing at a solid pace, with GDP growth projected at 3.0% in 2015 and 2016, and 2.5% in 2017.

images.alt_text: The US budget deficit is expected to shrink in the current fiscal year but climb after 2017 as spending mounts on health and retirement benefits, a government agency said Monday.

site_title: China property funding dries up as trusts exit
summary: China's investment trusts are pulling financing from the real estate industry as default concerns rise. Property trust products issuance fell 62% to 38.5 billion yuan in the fourth quarter, with builders expected to repay 241 billion yuan of trusts in 2015. Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd's missed payments and failed repayment of a 2.5 billion yuan trust have heightened concerns. This may lead to an increase in default risks for developers this year.

site_title: Global ETF market to almost double by 2020: PwC survey
summary: A PwC survey predicts the global ETF market will almost double to US$5 trillion by 2020, driven mainly by Asia's growth. Currently, ETFs hold US$2.6 trillion in assets, with Asia expected to contribute significantly despite distribution and innovation challenges. The industry is expected to grow at 6% per year, with Asia being a major driver, and the introduction of "passports" for cross-border sales could facilitate growth.

site_title: Big business potential of messaging apps
summary: Messaging apps have become a significant platform for businesses to reach their audience. With 40% of US mobile subscribers using instant messaging apps, and 103% global growth in mobile messaging app usage in 2014, the industry is expected to continue growing. Apps like Instagram, WeChat, and Snapchat are being used as distribution and revenue-generating platforms, with investors valuing messaging startups at billions of dollars. The convergence of media and communication is expected to lead to new opportunities for businesses to reach their audience, with original content being published directly to messaging apps.

site_title: How to stop Grexit
summary: Greece's newly elected government, led by Alexis Tsipras, is pushing for a potential Grexit, but it's unlikely to happen as Tsipras may be able to negotiate a compromise with European creditors. The European Central Bank will continue to provide liquidity to Greece's banks if an extension of the bailout programme is granted. A high-level meeting is suggested to discuss Tsipras' plans, but it should be conditional on him avoiding inflammatory rhetoric and compromise on long-term debt relief. Failure to do so could lead to default and capital controls, potentially allowing Greece to reconsider its eurozone membership.

site_title: Wanda to invest US$1b in Sydney property development
summary: Wanda Group, China's largest commercial real estate conglomerate, is investing US$1 billion in a Sydney property development project, including a hotel, apartments, and retail spaces. The investment includes purchasing Gold Fields House from Blackstone Group for A$415 million and constructing an adjacent building, Fairfax House. This marks Wanda's second large investment in Australia, following a previous project. The project will be located near Sydney Harbour and is expected to create new opportunities for the local property market.

site_title: Ten straight weeks of outflow for EM funds
summary: Emerging market equity funds have experienced their tenth consecutive week of outflow, totaling $3.2 billion for the week ending January 21, with a cumulative total of $24.3 billion. The outflow affects all sectors, with financials, energy, and utilities reporting the largest declines. Despite this, Asia's earnings are above their 2008 and 2010 peaks, driven by lower oil prices, while earnings in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa are down 35% from their 2008 peak, and in Latin America, they are down 50%.

site_title: Largest maritime lender pushes to clear bad debt; 1.5b euros deals on cards
summary: HSH Nordbank, the world's largest maritime lender, aims to clear 1.5 billion euros in bad debt this year by selling vessels to defaulting debtors. The bank expects to seal several transactions after some deals fell apart in 2014 due to disputes over ship prices. HSH has 21 billion euros in ship loans, 9.2 billion euros of which are non-performing, and has cut outstanding debt by about one billion euros in 2014. The bank is working to reduce potential losses through transactions and mergers among maritime companies, with a goal of stabilizing the shipping market and recouping outstanding loan amounts.

site_title: Ascott to manage three more properties in Beijing, HK
summary: Ascott, a CapitaLand business unit, has secured contracts to manage three more properties in Beijing and Hong Kong. The properties include 208-unit Citadines Fangshan Beijing and 70-unit Changyang World Serviced Residence Beijing in Beijing, and 92-unit Hotel Pravo Hong Kong in Hong Kong. The Beijing properties are expected to open in 2018, while Hotel Pravo Hong Kong is set to open in March 2015. This expansion reinforces Ascott's position as the largest international serviced residence owner-operator in China, with over 12,900 apartment units across 72 properties.

site_title: Better if Keppel has shareholders' nod for KepLand bid: observers
summary: Keppel Corp has been granted a waiver by the Singapore Exchange to take its real estate subsidiary Keppel Land private without shareholder approval. The waiver is due to the significant transaction exceeding 20% of Keppel Corp's market capitalization. However, market observers question the deal's merits, citing concerns over the premium paid and potential strain on cash resources. Analysts offer mixed views, with some arguing that the new gearing level remains low and others emphasizing the importance of good corporate governance practice.

site_title: SGX, Clearbridge to launch equity crowdfunding platform
summary: SGX and Clearbridge Accelerator are launching an equity crowdfunding (ECF) platform, targeting growth-stage firms in Asia to raise Series A and B money. The platform, open to accredited investors, allows individual investors to invest in companies in exchange for shares. This is believed to be the first ECF platform led by a stock exchange, aiming to support entrepreneurs and SMEs in raising capital.

images.alt_text: From left: SGX's Mr Mohamed and Clearbridge Accelerator's Mr Chen and Mr Fang. The platform is likely to launch in the middle of this year.

site_title: Euro sinks briefly to 11-year low vs US dollar
summary: The euro briefly reached an 11-year low of US$1.1174 against the US dollar after Greece's anti-austerity party Syriza won a general election, sparking concerns about a possible exit from the eurozone. Syriza's leader vowed to renegotiate Greece's 240-billion-euro bailout, while some analysts downplayed the prospect of Greece leaving the eurozone. The euro's decline was attributed to the European Central Bank's bond-buying program to boost the struggling eurozone economy.

site_title: Billionaire settles lawsuit against US Air Force over launch services
summary: Billionaire Elon Musk's SpaceX has settled a lawsuit against the US Air Force over launch services, dropping a protest against a "block buy" contract awarded to a joint venture between Boeing and Lockheed Martin. The settlement allows the Air Force to expand competitive opportunities for launch services and work with SpaceX to complete certification for US military satellites. Despite missing out on a key goal, SpaceX gains progress in pursuing future contracts, with the company preparing for another launch next month.

images.alt_text: Mr Musk campaigned at the Pentagon, before Congress and in the courts against what he called a monopoly.

site_title: NTUC calls for individual training accounts for workers
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore is calling for individual training accounts, dubbed "Skillsave accounts," to help workers plan their careers and stay "future ready" amidst economic restructuring. This move aims to empower workers to take control of their training needs.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: VietJet plans US$300m bond sale to finance Airbus orders while readying for IPO
summary: VietJet Aviation plans to raise up to $300 million from a corporate bond sale to fund expansion and prepare for an initial public offering (IPO). The airline aims to raise $200-300 million in the second quarter, with plans to select international advisers next month. The bond sale will help finance Airbus orders, while the IPO is expected to occur later.

site_title: US East Coast braces for potentially historic blizzard
summary: A potentially historic blizzard is expected to hit the US East Coast, with up to three feet of snow forecasted from Philadelphia to New York City to Maine. Airlines have cancelled nearly 1,800 flights, and cities along the coast have snow ploughs and trucks on standby. New York Mayor Bill de Blasio warned residents to stay off the roads and prepare for something worse than the 2006 storm that dropped 26.9 inches of snow. The National Weather Service calls the storm "crippling and potentially historic."

site_title: US pledges US$4b for India's 'untapped potential'
summary: US President Barack Obama pledged $4 billion in investments and loans to India, seeking to tap into the country's "untapped potential" in business and strategic partnerships. The pledge came after a day of meetings with Prime Minister Narendra Modi, including a Republic Day parade and discussions on nuclear trade and defense ties. Despite fragile trade ties, with India accounting for only 2% of US imports, Obama emphasized the need for increased cooperation and investment. Modi vowed to simplify business regulations and make India an attractive place to invest, with the goal of becoming one of the top 50 most business-friendly countries.

site_title: Shifting the focus from product to customer
summary: Marketing myopia occurs when companies prioritize products over customer needs, leading to decline and extinction. Industries such as camera-making, calculator-making, and watchmaking face risks due to technological shifts and changing customer preferences. Companies like Texas Instruments and Apple are adapting by developing alternative technologies and focusing on customer needs. To avoid decline, companies must adopt a customer-centric approach, investing in alternative technologies and strategies to sustain demand.

site_title: Keppel Corp, KepLand dominate trading
summary: Keppel Corp's bid to take over and delist its property arm Keppel Land boosted trading volume to 1.4 billion units, but the Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 12.98 points to 3,398.52, likely in response to Greece's election results. Keppel Corp rose S$0.06 to S$8.16, while KepLand ended S$0.90 or 25% higher at S$4.55. Analysts have mixed views on the move, with some predicting near-term weakness and others maintaining a "buy" rating due to upside potential and dividend yield.

site_title: Greece delivers first rumblings of potential 2015 earthquakes
summary: Greece's Syriza party, led by Alexis Tsipras, has won the most seats in the country's election, potentially ending decades of two-party rule. The party's success highlights the growing strength of populist parties across Europe, with similar movements emerging in countries such as Spain, Estonia, Finland, and the UK. Syriza's electoral success reopens the possibility of a Greek exit from the eurozone, known as Grexit, although many market participants are more sanguine about the prospect. A Grexit would have significant economic fallout for Europe, with estimates suggesting a contraction in eurozone GDP of at least 1.5%.

site_title: Cheaper oil, ECB stimulus hopes boost German business sentiment
summary: Germany's business confidence rose for the third consecutive month, boosted by cheaper oil and anticipation of European Central Bank (ECB) stimulus. The Ifo institute's business climate index increased to 106.7 in January, with executives expressing satisfaction with their current situation and optimism about the business outlook. This marks a positive start to the year for the German economy.

site_title: Abu Dhabi property price rise stalls amid oil rout
summary: Abu Dhabi property prices remained flat in the fourth quarter of 2014, marking the first period without price increases since 2013, according to a JLL report. Despite a 25% annual rise in residential prices from 2013, the market stabilized due to a decline in oil prices and weaker investor sentiment. Rental rates rose 4% in the fourth quarter, but JLL predicts single-digit annual growth in 2015 due to a slowdown in government spending. The report suggests that rental growth will continue due to a shortage of high-quality housing.

site_title: Obama needs to push harder on trade
summary: US President Barack Obama urged lawmakers to grant him trade promotion authority to conclude and pass the Trans-Pacific Partnership and Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership agreements. The proposed deals aim to strengthen the American economy and benefit the middle class, but face opposition from Democrats and labor unions. Obama must now advocate more aggressively for his policies to gain congressional support, as Republican leaders have insisted on Democratic backing in exchange for granting him the authority.

site_title: Printed retail catalogues make a comeback in the US
summary: US retailers are reviving printed retail catalogues, despite the rise of online shopping. JC Penney's announcement to revive its home goods catalogue is part of a strategy to reach existing customers, while others like Anthropologie and Patagonia focus on creating immersive experiences through high-quality visuals and storytelling. The resurgence in direct mail may be driven by a better understanding of catalogues' power to drive sales, with 90 million Americans making purchases from catalogues annually, and nearly 60% of them being women.

site_title: Investment banks seize on higher risk appetites of super rich
summary: Investment banks are shifting their focus to catering to the growing ranks of the super rich, as family offices seek more creative ways to earn returns amidst low interest rates and high fees at funds. Traditional investment banks are hiring staff and reorganizing teams to target wealthy clans, from Chinese multi-millionaires to old-world dynasties in Europe and the US. This move is expected to bring in lucrative relationships and easier deals for investment banks, with UBS and other banks already seeing significant growth in family office revenues.

site_title: Emirates considering airfare cuts in light of cheaper oil
summary: Emirates, the Dubai-based airline, is considering cutting its fuel surcharge in light of cheaper oil prices. The airline's president, Tim Clark, stated that the 60% drop in oil prices would be a "huge boost" to 2014 earnings, potentially offsetting disruptions at its home airport and a decline in business with Russia. Emirates is studying the impact of lower oil prices and is likely to introduce new prices in April, taking into account the fuel surcharge and other factors.

site_title: New investments show huge scale of technology giants' ambitions
summary: Tech giants are making significant investments in various industries, including satellites, semiconductors, and cloud computing. Qualcomm, Google, and Amazon have invested billions in companies like SpaceX, Annapurna Labs, and Microsoft's Azure. Experts argue that these investments are driven by the need for faster and more powerful data processing, which will revolutionize industries like computing, mobility, and data analysis. While some may view these investments as signs of a bubble, others see them as necessary steps to adapt to a rapidly changing industrial landscape.

site_title: China's online population nears 650m
summary: China's online population has reached nearly 650 million, according to the China Internet Network Information Center. This represents a 30 million increase from 2013, with the country already holding the world's largest online population. The figure includes those who have used the internet at least once in the last six months. The ruling Communist Party maintains tight controls over the internet, blocking sensitive websites and censoring user-generated content.

site_title: Southern Capital gains 81.15% control of UE E&C
summary: Southern Capital gains 81.15% control of UE E&C, short of its 90% target, raising uncertainty about the company's future as a listed entity. The private equity firm secured the majority stake before its offer deadline, leaving the shares potentially illiquid. This move may impact the company's ownership structure and its relation to the Singapore stock market.

site_title: Give Tsipras a chance to end Greece's nightmare
summary: Alexis Tsipras, the leader of Greece's Syriza coalition, is set to become prime minister, promising to challenge the austerity policies that have prevailed since 2010. The policies, imposed by the troika (IMF, ECB, and European Commission), were based on a flawed economic fantasy that assumed austerity would not significantly impact growth and employment. In reality, Greece experienced a severe economic and human crisis, with unemployment soaring to 28% and youth unemployment reaching 60%. The Greek government did impose significant spending cuts, but debt troubles worsened due to reduced revenues and a rising debt-to-GDP ratio. Tsipras' election offers a chance for Greece to end its economic nightmare, but it remains to be seen whether his plans are radical enough to produce a strong recovery.

site_title: Responsible taxation - the impact on Singapore's hub status
summary: Singapore's hub status as a competitive location for foreign investors may be under pressure due to the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (Beps) project by the OECD. The project aims to prevent multinational corporations from shifting profits to low-tax locations with minimal physical activity, potentially increasing taxes on global basis. While Singapore has representation at the OECD and is consulting stakeholders, it's advised to remain cautious and not take proactive unilateral steps that could impact its competitive position. The government can continue to promote other activities, such as offshore clearing houses and global gold trading hubs, to maintain its edge over competitors.

images.alt_text: Singapore-headquartered groups that invest overseas need to pay closer attention to reactions to Base Erosion and Profit Shifting in countries where they invest.

site_title: ECF platform: 'Is S'pore ready to value startups?'
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Clearbridge Accelerator have launched an equity crowdfunding (ECF) platform, sparking debate about whether the city-state is ready to value startups. Experts say the platform will bridge the gap between traditional investors and tech companies, but caution that investors need to understand how these companies should be valued. Limiting the platform to accredited investors may protect retail investors, but attracting and educating them is a challenge. The government is working on a regulatory framework to address potential fraud risks.

site_title: Investors continue pulling out of China ETFs in spite of rally
summary: Overseas investors are pulling money out of China exchange-traded funds (ETFs) despite a rally in China's debt-fuelled market. Since January 2015, the total fund assets of two popular ETFs in Hong Kong have fallen, according to data from Bloomberg. This trend continues as China's debt issues persist, raising concerns about the market's stability.

site_title: Japanese firms' pivot from China towards Asean continues: Jetro
summary: Japanese firms operating in Asia are shifting their focus towards Asean countries, with 60% of firms indicating plans to expand, compared to 50% in 2013. However, rising wage and administration costs in countries like China, Indonesia, and Cambodia are causing concerns, leading to increased local procurement and cost-cutting measures. Economists expect the policy of "re-onshoring" to gain traction, with the weakening yen and rising costs abroad contributing to the shift.

site_title: Japan sees light at the end of the tunnel for its trade deficit
summary: Japan's trade deficit reached a record 12.8 trillion yen in 2014, surpassing the previous annual record of 11.5 trillion yen. The deficit was largely driven by surging energy imports and sluggish exports. However, a pick-up in exports during December raised hopes that the trade imbalance may begin to turn around in 2015. The dramatic fall in oil prices and improvement in exports signal an improvement ahead in the trade balance, with some analysts predicting a return to a trade surplus in 2015.

site_title: British lawmakers demand national moratorium on fracking
summary: British lawmakers demand a national moratorium on fracking due to concerns over public health, air quality, and water supplies. An Environmental Audit Committee inquiry found the extraction process poses uncertain risks, contradicting Britain's pledge to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 80% by 2050. The committee recommended banning fracking in protected areas and a moratorium on the industry to resolve environmental risks. The decision comes ahead of a vote on the Infrastructure Bill, which aims to boost the shale gas industry.

site_title: Developer sentiment worsens further
summary: Singapore property developers' sentiment worsened in Q4 2014, with the NUS-Redas Real Estate Sentiment Index falling to 3.4 from 3.7 in Q3. The residential sector remained bleak, with 65.6% expecting excessive supply and 70.3% projecting a 5-10% decline in property prices in 2015. Developers also expected a 15-20% decline in new sales volumes. The office sector remained resilient, with a positive current balance of 38%.

site_title: Markets bank on Greek pragmatism
summary: Greece's new anti-austerity coalition government, led by Prime Minister-elect Alexis Tsipras, has won 149 seats in the Athens Parliament, giving them a majority of 41%. The coalition aims to renegotiate the country's debt with creditors and implement a welfare package to help the impoverished populace. Markets have largely shrugged off the likely brinkmanship, with the euro recovering against the US dollar, but analysts warn of potential logjams in negotiations and a risk of another euro crisis. Tsipras must balance economic reform demands from creditors with Syriza's hard-left faction, and some caution that anti-euro and anti-austerity populist parties could scuttle eurozone unity.

site_title: Reignited: privatisation chatter on other firms
summary: KEPPEL Corp's offer to take Keppel Land private has sparked interest in potential privatization targets among Singapore's listed property developers. Analysts caution that betting on the next target is a gamble. Other firms under consideration include Wheelock Properties, GuocoLand, Wing Tai Holdings, Ho Bee Land, Hiap Hoe, Sim Lian Group, and United Industrial Corporation. The market is watching these developments closely, with investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty, driving the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Creating a good PDPA compliance framework
summary: Singaporean private organisations must comply with the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) by appointing a data protection officer, tracking and discarding irrelevant personal data, securing it, managing archives, controlling data access privileges, and ensuring outsourced data is treated with equal stringent controls. Internal auditors can provide advice and independent reviews to help organisations create a good compliance framework and mitigate risks. Compliance failure can result in severe punishment, emphasizing the importance of implementing robust controls to protect personal data.

site_title: Local food firms take to R&D
summary: Singapore's food industry is witnessing a surge in innovation, driven by local companies and institutions collaborating with educational institutions to meet evolving consumer demands. SMEs such as Poli Medical and Freshen Group have invested in R&D, with Poli Medical automating manual bottling processes and Freshen Group developing traditional soups in retort pouch formats. The Food Innovation Resource Centre (FIRC) and Centre for Functional Food & Human Nutrition (CFFHN) provide resources and expertise for SMEs to develop functional food products. The industry is expected to focus on functional foods to cater to the growing demand for healthier options, with CFFHN working with SMEs to validate the functionality of their products.

site_title: Safety worries cloud promise of experimental cancer drugs
summary: Experimental cancer drugs, CAR T cells and bispecific antibodies, are proving effective in treating blood cancers, with some trials eliminating all traces of the disease in 40-90% of patients. However, top oncology researchers are concerned about potential side effects, including the build-up of toxic debris and damage to healthy tissue, which could block regulatory approval. The high cost of these treatments, estimated to be $300,000-$500,000 per patient, may also pose challenges for insurers. Researchers are working to mitigate these risks through anti-inflammation medications, but the potential for off-target toxicity remains a major concern.

site_title: Haitong International keen to hire retrenched HK bankers, analysts
summary: Haitong International Securities Group, a Chinese brokerage, is seeking to hire retrenched Hong Kong bankers and analysts. The company, which saw a 50% profit increase last year, is looking to expand its investment banking and research capabilities. Haitong's CEO, Lin Yong, stated that he is open to hiring up to 100 workers, but only if they meet the company's requirements. This move comes as stricter capital rules prompt some competitors to retrench. Haitong aims to advise on large initial public offerings in Hong Kong and increase its staff to 150.

site_title: German gov't expects about 1.5% growth this year and next: source
summary: The German government has revised its economic growth forecast, expecting a 1.5% expansion in 2015 and 2016, compared to a previous prediction of 1.3% for 2015. Economists attribute this increase to lower oil prices and a weak euro, benefiting major exporter Germany.

site_title: Chinese consumers turn to pricey Japanese rice
summary: Chinese consumers are increasingly turning to pricey Japanese rice due to concerns over local rice's safety, particularly pollution from industrialization. Despite Japan's limited rice exports, Chinese consumers are willing to pay luxury-good prices for Japanese rice, with some importing it directly from individuals online. Chinese producers are also promoting their rice as a safer alternative, but some may be using seeds grown in polluted areas. This trend illustrates Chinese consumers' dwindling confidence in the country's own agricultural produce.

site_title: Stronger Swiss franc hurting landlords
summary: A stronger Swiss franc is expected to lead to higher office vacancies and lower rents in Switzerland, according to analysts. The decision by the Swiss National Bank to end its currency cap has driven up the franc, making Swiss exports more expensive and increasing rental costs for foreign companies. Despite this, investors such as Swiss Life and Pensimo Management AG continue to buy office properties, driven by low interest rates and the desire for stable returns. Analysts predict a rise in vacancies over the next two years, with some companies, such as Google, re-evaluating their expansion plans due to the increased costs.

site_title: The hidden perils of benchmarking
summary: Benchmarking, a widely practiced business strategy, can be flawed due to its inability to replicate internal interactions and context-specific factors that contribute to success. Companies often copy best practices from others, only to find they don't work in their own environment. Benchmarking can also lead to wasted resources and pressure on organizations, as it assumes the world is standing still and that individual processes can improve the overall value proposition. A more effective approach is to focus on continuous improvement and creating unique value propositions, rather than simply imitating others.

site_title: KepLand soars on privatisation bid; KepCorp edges up amid mixed views
summary: Keppel Corp's bid to take its real estate subsidiary Keppel Land private has sparked a surge in Keppel Land shares, which jumped 25% to a four-year high. The offer price of S$4.60, exceeding the base offer price of S$4.38, has led analysts to raise their target prices and expect acceptance levels to reach 90%. However, some analysts warned of near-term weakness due to the rich price offered and potential synergies not immediately apparent. Keppel Corp's shares edged up 0.7% to S$8.16, with some analysts applying steep conglomerate discount rates due to the bid.

site_title: Modi pledges 'predictable, competitive' tax regime
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi promised US executives a "predictable and competitive" tax regime, aiming to improve the country's business climate. He vowed to lessen the burden of tax rules, address concerns about intellectual property, and guide foreign businesses on their projects. Modi's election win last May was based on a pledge to overhaul India's economy, and he acknowledged the previous government's excesses. The new tax regime is expected to nurture innovation and protect intellectual property, transforming India from a reputation of being hostile to business.

site_title: Birdman buoyed in Oscars bellwether
summary: Birdman won the top prize at the 21st Screen Actors Guild Awards, boosting its Oscars hopes. The dark comedy, about a washed-up superhero movie star, took the SAG equivalent of the Oscars Best Picture award. Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu's film also won the Producers Guild of America award, a significant Oscars bellwether. Eddie Redmayne won Best Actor for his portrayal of Stephen Hawking, and Julianne Moore won Best Actress for her portrayal of a woman suffering from Alzheimer's in Still Alice.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close higher
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.29%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index jumping 1.40% to a new record close, and Paris's CAC 40 climbing 0.74%. The gains followed the election of an anti-austerity party in Greece, with investors shrugging off concerns. The rally was also driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares, while US-EU trade talks were in focus.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel Corporation maintained a "Hold" rating for Frasers Centrepoint Trust, targeting a price of S$8.60. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower after US President Trump imposed fresh tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow considered increasing fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case.

site_title: S&P expects Petronas to remain resilient
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) warns that Asia-Pacific oil and gas players, including Malaysia's Petronas, may face downgrades if oil prices don't recover quickly. The agency expects a rebound in oil prices from 2016, with Brent crude averaging $65 a barrel in 2016 and rising to $80 in 2017. This warning comes as the financial flexibility of some players has already been reduced. S&P anticipates a resilient Petronas, but notes that other Asia-Pacific players may be downgraded if they fail to adapt to the changing environment.

images.alt_text: Oil players with a greater weighting on gas, and national oil companies such as Petronas (or Petroliam National Bhd) ought to prove fairly resilient

site_title: Malaysia Airlines website hacked by Lizard Squad
summary: Malaysia Airlines' website was hacked by the Lizard Squad, a group known for online gaming service hacking and denial-of-service attacks. The hackers leaked flight bookings, including passenger data, after the airline assured users their data was secure. The airline confirmed its domain name system was compromised, but claimed user data remained secure. The Lizard Squad posted screenshots of bookings on social media, contradicting MAS' claims. The airline has resolved the issue with its service provider and is expected to recover within 22 hours.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: More women appear at WEF in their own right
summary: More women are participating in the World Economic Forum's panels and sessions, breaking a previous trend of men dominating the event. Patricia Villela Marino, a Brazilian delegate, attended 40 panels, showcasing her expertise in social policy and law. Marino's presence highlights a shift towards greater female representation at the forum, which was previously dominated by male delegates. This change suggests a growing effort to promote women's participation in global economic discussions.

images.alt_text: Women make up a larger number of younger leaders at the WEF than ever before: Fifty-four per cent of the forum's Global Shapers community of 50 leaders between 20 and 30 years old were female, for instance.

site_title: Indonesian anti-graft deputy offers to resign
summary: Indonesia's anti-graft deputy, Bambang Widjojanto, submitted his resignation letter after being named a police suspect in a false testimony case. The move worsens tensions between the Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) and the police, which has raised concerns among investors. Widjojanto denied the allegations, claiming his case was a set-up. The head of the KPK, Abraham Samad, has refused to approve the resignation, citing the constitution and law. The dispute has put pressure on President Joko Widodo, who has struggled to halt rising tensions between the two rival law enforcement agencies.

images.alt_text: Mr Bambang's (above) resignation letter must now be approved by the head of the agency, Abraham Samad, who said on Saturday he would refuse such a request

site_title: Crowdfunding revives quake-hit Japan companies avoiding red tape
summary: Japan companies affected by the 2011 earthquake and tsunami are using crowdfunding to revive their businesses, bypassing government red tape. Three years after the disaster, Michihiro Kono's soy sauce factory has recovered to 70% of its pre-disaster sales, thanks to crowdfunding investments. The crowdfunding platform, Crowd Bank, has raised over 2.4 billion yen, while Maneo Market has tripled its funds to 4.8 billion yen. Companies like Yagisawa Shouten and a sweets shop owner, Masayuki Kimura, have benefited from the platform, raising funds to rebuild and hire employees.

site_title: Deutsche staff reel from 'Duesselgate' of restructuring
summary: Deutsche Bank faces a turning point after "Duesselgate", a term coined from a speech by co-CEO Juergen Fitschen questioning the bank's universal strategy. The bank's restructuring efforts may involve selling its retail unit, Postbank, to simplify its model, raise capital, and cut costs. Deutsche's poor performance in 2014, including high fines, low profitability, and low capital levels, has raised concerns about its future. The bank's new strategy is expected to be revealed by the end of June, and it may post its second quarterly loss.

images.alt_text: 2015 for Deutsche Bank will be a brutal year of cost cuts, restructuring and expensive penalties.

site_title: Update: Oil prices slip after smooth Saudi transition
summary: Oil prices slipped on Monday after Saudi Arabia's new King Salman reassured investors about the stability of the transition and potential policy changes. Brent crude fell 24 cents to US$48.55 per barrel, while West Texas Intermediate crude fell 2 cents to US$45.57 a barrel. Analysts attributed the decline to overreactions following Opec's secretary-general's comments, and noted that Saudi Arabia's retention of Ali al-Naimi as oil minister aimed to calm the market. Prices are expected to recover in the second half of the year as US oil production declines.

site_title: Drugmakers race to bring new cholesterol drugs to US market
summary: Regeneron Pharmaceuticals and Sanofi are racing to bring their jointly developed cholesterol-lowering drug, alirocumab, to the US market, with an FDA decision due by July 24. The companies are trying to beat Amgen's competing drug, evolocumab, which is scheduled for an FDA ruling by August 27. Alirocumab has shown a 40-60% reduction in LDL cholesterol in studies and is projected to generate over $2 billion in sales annually. The companies have used a special voucher to expedite the review process, potentially giving them a head start in the market.

site_title: Traders delay Russian gas imports as they expect cheap future deliveries
summary: Europe is accelerating gas withdrawals from storage sites, taking 44% more gas than last year since October 1. Russian gas imports to Europe and Turkey slid 29% last month, a quarter lower than November. This decrease is attributed to lower oil prices, leading traders to expect cheaper future deliveries. The European Union's gas inventories are being depleted as the heating season progresses, with many countries relying on imports to meet their energy needs.

site_title: How to hire people who really are what they say they are
summary: The article discusses the issue of fake degrees and universities in Asia-Pacific, particularly in China, which has over 100 phony institutions offering fake diplomas. Many young people in the region are desperate for education and job opportunities, making them vulnerable to these scams. The consequences of hiring someone with a fake degree can be severe, damaging the employer's reputation and potentially leading to financial losses. The article highlights the need for employers to verify academic credentials and be cautious of unscrupulous individuals and institutions offering fake degrees.

site_title: Obama announces US$4b in India investment and lending deals
summary: US President Barack Obama announced $4 billion in government-backed investments and lending deals to India, aiming to scale up a trade relationship with "untapped potential". The deals include $1 billion in exports of 'Made-in-America' products, $1 billion in lending to small- and medium-sized enterprises, and $2 billion for renewable energy.

site_title: SAP asks Microsoft, Apple to share hacker-fighting intelligence
summary: SAP is proposing a collaboration with major tech companies, including Microsoft and Apple, to share intelligence on vulnerabilities in open-source software. The initiative aims to improve the security of widely used open-source code, which has been found to be vulnerable to attacks such as Heartbleed and Shellshock. SAP's chief technology officer for security plans to present the proposal to companies in March, with the goal of creating a shared database of security analysis to help identify and fix weaknesses in open-source code.

site_title: Tiger Airways leaps on Q3 profit
summary: Tiger Airways, a Singapore-based budget carrier, reported a net profit of S$2.19 million for the three months ended Dec 31, 2014, reversing a loss of S$118.5m from the same period last year. This resulted in a 23.1% gain in its shares, closing at 32 cents. The airline's strong performance was the most heavily traded stock by volume on Monday, with 113.9 million shares changing hands.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: CME starts gold futures in HK
summary: CME Group Inc launched physically delivered kilobar gold futures in Hong Kong, joining other exchanges in establishing new price benchmarks in the region. The contract is tied to Hong Kong's 99.99% purity gold and will be delivered to vaults in the special administrative region. The move aims to capitalize on Asia's significant gold consumption, with almost two-thirds of gold jewelry, bars, and coins being consumed in the region in 2013. The launch is part of a broader shift in the gold market, with the London gold fix getting overhauled and central banks in Europe, Japan, and China taking steps to spur their economies.

site_title: Qatar Petroleum to absorb investment unit in sign of consolidation
summary: Qatar Petroleum (QP) will absorb its investment unit, Qatar Petroleum International (QPI), effective March 2015. This move is seen as a consolidation effort by the state-owned oil and gas giant amid the decline of oil prices. QPI, formed in 2007, will transition its employees, assets, and projects into the new QP organization. The integration aims to streamline the industry and strengthen QP's presence globally.

site_title: OUE C-Reit beats its DPU forecasts for Q4, FY2014
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) exceeded its distribution per unit (DPU) forecasts for the fourth quarter and full year of 2014, with a DPU of 1.44 and 5.27 cents respectively. The Reit's occupancy improved to 98% and gross rental income grew by 12% year-over-year, driven by positive office rental reversions of 14.9% at OUE Bayfront and 6% at Lippo Plaza. The Reit manager now expects to meet its forecast amount available for distribution for fiscal 2015.

images.alt_text: About 25 per cent of OUE C-Reit's leases by net lettable area due in 2015 have already been committed as at Dec 31, 2014, says Ms Tan

site_title: CapitaMalls Malaysia Trust buys Petaling Jaya property
summary: CapitaMalls Malaysia Trust (CMMT) has agreed to buy Tropicana City Mall and office tower in Petaling Jaya, Selangor, for RM540 million. The deal, worth RM565 million, includes a 4-storey retail mall with 448,000 sq ft of net lettable area and an office tower with 101,000 sq ft. The mall has an 89.2% occupancy rate and is easily accessible from Kuala Lumpur. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the third quarter of 2015, expanding CMMT's market presence and portfolio in the Klang Valley.

site_title: India wins Obama's backing for US$160b solar energy push
summary: India's ambitious solar energy program has gained significant backing from US President Barack Obama, who pledged to provide financial support for the US$160 billion initiative. The program aims to install 100 gigawatts of solar power by 2022, comparable to the US's current capacity, and would require significant funding to overcome regulatory hurdles. Despite challenges, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's drive has attracted international interest, with several companies planning to invest in the country's solar market. The program is seen as a crucial step towards reducing India's reliance on fossil fuels and meeting its climate change commitments.

site_title: Developers feel worse about Singapore property outlook
summary: Developers in Singapore expect worsening property market conditions, with the residential outlook remaining gloomy, according to a survey by Redas. The NUS-Redas Real Estate Sentiment Index fell to 3.4 in the fourth quarter, indicating deteriorating conditions. Experts attribute the decline to poor performance in the residential sector, with no "feel-good" factors expected to lift market sentiment. This marks a continuation of weakening market sentiment, which has been ongoing.

site_title: China Yuanbang shares down 14.7% after chairman quits
summary: China Yuanbang Property Holdings Ltd shares fell 14.7% in Singapore trading after its chairman, Chen Jianfeng, resigned amid a Chinese government investigation. Chen was taken into custody for private matters unrelated to the company. The move follows China's anti-corruption campaign led by President Xi Jinping. The company's CEO, Zhou Xiaoxiong, continues to manage daily operations, and it has not received any legal documents related to the investigation.

site_title: WikiLeaks accuses Google of handing over emails to US
summary: WikiLeaks accuses Google of handing over emails of its senior staff to the US Department of Justice without notifying them for nearly three years, in a serious violation of privacy and journalistic rights. The emails and data of staff members were obtained on warrants for alleged espionage, theft, and conspiracy. Google claims it followed the law and notified the staff after receiving the warrants, but WikiLeaks disputes this. This incident is part of a broader US investigation into WikiLeaks, which has targeted the site since 2010.

site_title: Samsung's US$63b cash pile augurs tech takeovers
summary: Samsung Electronics Co has a $63 billion cash reserve, which analysts suggest it should use for tech takeovers. The company has denied reports of a potential $7.5 billion acquisition of BlackBerry Ltd, but a takeover could provide Samsung with the necessary software to link its devices online. Other potential targets include Atmel Corp and Freescale Semiconductor Ltd, whose chips enable device communication. Samsung's acquisition of these companies could help the US$190 billion conglomerate establish a more connected home ecosystem.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat after Greek elections
summary: US stocks opened flat on Monday after a decisive Greek election victory by the Syriza party, sparking concern over eurozone instability. Despite this, the possibility of Greece leaving the bloc was considered remote. The Dow Jones fell 12.71 points, the S&P 500 lost 2.23 points, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 7.05 points. The market reaction was largely driven by a lack of concern about Greece's potential exit from the eurozone.

site_title: UBS says Asia's rich show less love for Aussie
summary: Asia's wealthy clients are losing interest in the Australian dollar due to record-low yields and declining interest rates. According to UBS, many ultra-high-net-worth individuals in the region are shifting their focus away from the Aussie dollar as the yield premium over the US has decreased from 130 basis points to 84. The trend was first observed two years ago, when clients were more interested in Australian assets and the dollar.

site_title: Local stocks: Is the glass half full or half empty?
summary: Singapore's stock market has seen a surprise buyout offer from Keppel Corp for Keppel Land, boosting interest in property counters. However, the market's health is debated, with some viewing it as a sign of a healthy corporate activity market, while others argue that it indicates a lack of competition and undervalued stocks leading to regular privatisation exercises. New 100-share board lots have made high-priced stocks more affordable to retail investors, but anecdotal evidence suggests that institutions are driving trades rather than retail players. The market's performance, including a 6.2% rise in the Straits Times Index last year, is also debated, with some arguing that it reflects a lagging market.

site_title: Opec's Badri expects some oil price rebound soon
summary: Opec Secretary-General Abdullah al-Badri expects oil prices to rebound soon, reaching a floor of around $45-$55 per barrel. He believes prices may have reached their lowest point and will see a rebound in the near future. Saudi Arabia's new king, Salman, has retained veteran oil minister Ali al-Naimi, signaling a stable energy policy. This move aims to calm a jittery energy market following the death of King Abdullah.

site_title: S&P sends early warning shot to Greece's Syriza
summary: Standard and Poor's (S&P) has sent an early warning shot to Greece's new government, led by Syriza, that it could downgrade its sovereign credit rating even before its next planned review date in mid-March if things go badly. S&P Senior Director Frank Gill warned that Greece's uncertainty over its debt and potential showdown with the eurozone and International Monetary Fund could jeopardize its recovery. The agency's concerns come as Greece faces significant debt payments and fiscal performance is deteriorating.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust Q4 distributable income misses forecast by 1.6%
summary: Viva Industrial Trust reported Q4 distributable income of S$10.3 million, missing its forecast by 1.6%. Despite this, net property income was 8.6% higher than estimated due to higher gross rental collections. For the year 2014, distributable income was 0.8% below estimates. The trust attributed weaker business optimism in Singapore, which may affect demand for industrial space in 2015.

site_title: Iron ore hits 5-/12 yr low as China mills cut output
summary: Iron ore prices hit a 5-1/2 year low of $63.30 a tonne as Chinese steel mills cut output due to cooling demand and losses. Mills reduced production to curb oversupply, forcing prices down by nearly a third last year. Analysts expect further price drops this year due to growing iron ore supplies. China's imports of iron ore rose 13.87% in 2014 to a record high, with Australian shipments accounting for 58.8% of the total.

site_title: Global gas prices to sink further in coming months
summary: Global liquefied natural gas (LNG) prices are expected to drop further in the first half of 2015, reaching record lows. A weak crude market, new supply from mega-projects, and mild temperatures worldwide are contributing to the decline. Asian gas prices are expected to attract European buyers as their price premium disappears, while falling long-term oil-linked LNG contract prices will keep spot prices competitive. New LNG supply is set to expand global capacity by 10% this year, leading to excess production capacity until 2023, with spot prices potentially falling to US$6 per million British thermal units (mmBtu).

images.alt_text: Asian liquefied natural gas prices, already at four-year lows, face further steep losses in the first half of 2015 as the full force of a weak crude market works through into gas contracts and new supply comes on stream.

site_title: Standard Chartered said to hire consultant in search for new CEO
summary: Standard Chartered has hired executive search firm Egon Zehnder to find a successor to CEO Peter Sands, who faces pressure from largest shareholders to step down. Sands, 53, has been under pressure due to slowing economic growth in Asia and rising costs for bad loans. The bank's largest shareholders, Aberdeen Asset Management and Temasek Holdings, have been pushing for a succession plan, with investors preferring a candidate from outside the firm. A new CEO may be announced in the coming weeks or when the bank reports annual earnings in March.

site_title: France PM heading to China to talk business, climate
summary: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls will visit China this week to boost commercial ties and seek Beijing's support in climate talks. The three-day trip will include meetings with Chinese leaders and the signing of 15 agreements, including nuclear power cooperation. France hopes to press China's cooperation on climate talks ahead of the UN Climate Change Conference in Paris at the end of the year, where a universal agreement is expected. The visit comes as France and China celebrate 50 years of diplomatic relations.

site_title: Big brands face struggle to contain own label advance in Europe
summary: Big brands in Europe are struggling to contain the growth of their own label products, which have surged in recent years as consumers seek cheaper alternatives. Despite efforts to cut prices, own label sales are slowing down, with a 0.1 percentage point loss of market share in 2014. Supermarkets are responding by promoting branded products, but consumers expect them to offer a range of brands and competitive pricing. Experts predict private labels will continue to grow, driven by discounters and e-commerce, and will account for half of the European market by 2025.

site_title: Oil prices fall on market relief over Saudi policy
summary: Oil prices declined on Monday, with US crude falling close to a nearly six-year low, as Saudi Arabia's new King Salman moved to assuage fears of an unstable transition and any policy change in the world's largest oil exporter. Brent crude fell 86 cents to $47.93 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell 62 cents to $44.97 a barrel. The news calmed energy markets, with oil prices expected to revisit their January 13 low of $45.19 per barrel in the next four weeks.

site_title: ECB QE should work, unlikely to extend beyond Sept 2016: traders
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) quantitative easing program is expected to be sufficient to bring inflation back to target, with 11 of 19 traders polled saying it would achieve this goal. The program, which involves purchasing nearly trillion euros in sovereign bonds, is unlikely to be extended beyond September 2016, with nine traders saying it won't be prolonged. The ECB's goal is to purchase around 50 billion euros worth of bonds per month.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank's quantitative easing programme will be enough to bring inflation back to target, a slim majority of eurozone money market traders polled by Reuters said.

site_title: IMF set for lively debate this year on adding yuan to SDR basket
summary: China is expected to push for the inclusion of the yuan in the International Monetary Fund's Special Drawing Rights (SDR) basket in a review later this year, with US officials saying they will wait for an IMF paper before taking a view. The yuan has made significant strides since Beijing's last push, with offshore trading surging and China meeting conditions for inclusion. However, concerns remain about the yuan's "freely usable" status, with US officials and some experts citing restrictions on asset management and currency exchange.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Monday, closing at 1,796.44 after a 6.64-point drop. The index saw 1.88 billion lots traded, with 559 losers and 312 gainers.

site_title: Thailand's investment applications nearly double in 2014
summary: Thailand's investment agency reported nearly doubling of total investment applications in 2014, with a combined value of 2.19 trillion baht (US$67.2 billion). Most applications were submitted in December, with nearly two-thirds of them. The surge in applications came after the BOI announced new policies in December, offering tax exemptions and incentives for value-added sectors.
