The agency received 3,469 project applications in 2014, a 54% increase from 2013. The main sectors for investment were the service and public utilities sector, followed by chemical products and papers.

site_title: Nico founders sell controlling stake to private investor at discount
summary: Nico Steel Holdings' founding family sold a controlling 28.38% stake to private investor Dov Rauschwerger's company, Parot Tovot, for S$3.42 million. The sale price was significantly lower than Nico's closing share price of 11.5 Singapore cents. This sale reduces DSAG's stake to 34.01% and follows a widening net loss to US$473,000 in the half-year ended Aug 31, 2014. Nico aims to tap into Rauschwerger's contacts to streamline and diversify its businesses and return more value to shareholders.

site_title: Economists up forecast for 2015 Brazil inflation to 6.99%
summary: Economists forecast Brazil's 2015 inflation rate to reach 6.99%, exceeding the official target of 4.5% with a two percentage point tolerance margin. The median estimate for economic growth this year dropped to 0.13%, down from 0.38% previously.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end lower
summary: Singapore shares ended lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index slipping 12.98 points to 3,398.52. Trading volume was 1.41 billion shares valued at S$1.48 billion, with 262 losers outnumbering 204 gainers. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: L'Oreal heiress trial opens with suicide revelation
summary: The trial of 10 people accused of exploiting France's richest woman, Liliane Bettencourt, began in Bordeaux, with one of the accused, Alain Thurin, attempting to take his own life on the eve of his appearance. The trial centers around Bettencourt's growing mental fragility and alleged manipulation by those around her, including former nurse Alain Thurin, butler Pascal Bonnefoy, and businessman Patrice de Maistre, who is accused of encouraging her to commit tax evasion and take advantage of her wealth.

site_title: China's overseas property investment to reach US$20b in 2015: study
summary: Chinese investors plan to spend US$20 billion on offshore property in 2015, a 21% increase from 2014, according to Jones Lang LaSalle Inc. This surge is driven by the easing of restrictions and internationalization of domestic real estate developers and insurers. Big Chinese insurers, such as Ping An and Anbang, are major buyers in global markets, while property developers like Dalian Wanda Group Co are also investing abroad to ensure long-term returns. Europe remains the most popular destination for Chinese overseas property investment, with London being the top city.

images.alt_text: Chinese investors are set to fork out US$20 billion on offshore property this year, up 21 per cent on 2014 as more domestic real estate developers and insurers internationalise their holdings, Jones Lang LaSalle Inc said on Monday.

site_title: Inflation may turn from friend to foe for Russia's grocers
summary: Russia's grocers may face challenges as inflation surges to over 13%, affecting consumer spending and real disposable incomes. Despite initial sales growth, retailers' margins could be hit due to price rises and supplier demands. Analysts predict a decline in sales growth in the first quarter and lower profits. Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev has proposed price caps, while low-price grocer Magnit saw like-for-like sales jump 17% despite a 5% decline in hypermarket sales.

site_title: Southeast Asia stocks: Most weaker; Indonesia retreats from record high
summary: Southeast Asian stock markets declined on Monday, with Indonesia's benchmark retreating from a record high due to profit-taking. Thai Airways shares fell 5.1% amid concerns about its finances, while Thailand's military-led government approved a restructuring plan. Singapore and Malaysia also ended lower, following global markets' cautious tone after Greece's Syriza party promised to roll back austerity measures.

images.alt_text: Jakarta's composite index closed down 1.2 per cent at 5,260.02 from Friday's record closing high of 5,323.89.

site_title: OUE C-Reit to pay out 1.44 Singapore cents for Q4
summary: OUE Commercial Reit achieved a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.44 Singapore cents for Q4 2014, beating its forecast by 5.1%. This translates to an annualised distribution yield of 7% based on its closing price on Dec 31, 2014. The company exceeded its forecast for the full year, posting a DPU of 5.27 cents.

images.alt_text: Buoyed by better-than-expected occupancy and rental reversions, OUE Commercial Reit achieved a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.44 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2014, beating its own forecast by 5.1 per cent.

site_title: Biggest private fund in Finland says QE kills price signals
summary: Finland's largest private investor, Varma Mutual Pension Insurance Co, says the European Central Bank's quantitative easing program is undermining bond pricing. CEO Risto Murto stated that market signals have "plummeted" and the role of market forces will be small in the near future. The ECB plans to spend $1.2 trillion buying assets, including government bonds, to combat deflation. European bond yields remain low, and the program may delay US monetary tightening due to a weaker euro.

site_title: China to cut retail price of gasoline and diesel
summary: China will cut retail prices for gasoline by 365 yuan (US$58) per tonne and diesel by 350 yuan (US$56) per tonne, effective Tuesday, amid falling world oil prices. This is the latest in a series of cuts that started in July 2014. The National Development and Reform Commission can adjust price ceilings for fuel on a bi-weekly basis, linked to the global price of crude oil.

site_title: German press warns of false hopes from Greek poll
summary: German media warns Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras that his Syriza party's electoral victory will not give him leverage in talks with creditors, citing the eurozone bailout packages and economic reforms championed by Germany. The victory, which gave Syriza 149 seats in the 300-seat Greek parliament, has raised concerns about Greece's massive debt and the need for more foreign money. German newspapers warn Tsipras of a "treaty is a treaty" and that Europe has upheld its end of the deal, with the EU providing over $225 billion to Greece since 2010.

site_title: IMF's Lagarde rules out special treatment for Greece
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde rules out special treatment for Greece, stating that the country must respect euro zone rules and complete key reforms. Lagarde emphasized that Greece's debt is not an exception and that the country must implement in-depth reforms, not just austerity measures.

site_title: Lenovo brings Motorola back to China as Moto X phone released
summary: Lenovo reintroduced the Motorola brand in China, unveiling the Moto X smartphone and four other devices to regain market share lost to Xiaomi Corp. The Moto X is priced at 3,299 yuan (US$527), while the Moto G will cost 1,299 yuan. Lenovo aims to replace Xiaomi in the No 3 spot with Motorola and sell over 100 million units, leveraging the Motorola name and history to move up the value chain with Chinese consumers.

site_title: US 30-year yields near record low as Greece spurs safety bid
summary: US Treasury 30-year bond yields are near a record low as Greece's Prime Minister-elect Alexis Tsipras prepares to form a coalition to end austerity measures, potentially sparking conflict with European peers. Ten-year yields rose, while the average yield among major bond markets remained stable at 0.79%, reflecting slowing global growth and inflation prospects. The US 30-year yield was at 2.37%, down from 1.01% at the start of the year, as investors seek safety amid economic concerns.

site_title: Ocwen calls investor claims "baseless"
summary: Ocwen Financial Group denied claims from investors, including BlackRock and Metlife, that it failed to meet its agreements to collect payments on US$82 billion worth of home loans. The company reached a US$2.5 million settlement with the California Department of Business Oversight, averting a potential license suspension. Ocwen's shares rose 47% in premarket trading. The investors alleged the company used conflicted servicing practices, failed to properly account for trust cash flows, and enriched its affiliates, resulting in over US$1 billion in losses for the trusts. Ocwen maintained that the investor group's demands were "baseless" and not in the best interests of the trusts.

site_title: Update: Euro steadies despite Greek worries
summary: The euro steadied at US$1.1224 after falling to an 11-year low of US$1.1098 following Greece's election results, which may lead to a collision course with international lenders. The European Central Bank's announcement of outright money-printing last week is seen as a positive factor for European markets. Analysts predict the euro may test US$1.10, where large options lie, but some expect Tsipras to work with the European Union and other lenders, limiting the damage.

site_title: Indonesia launches one-stop service for investment licences
summary: Indonesia has launched a one-stop service for investment licences, aiming to simplify the process for investors and boost economic growth. The move, made by President Joko Widodo, follows a campaign pledge to make the country more business-friendly. The new service, run by the Indonesia Investment Coordinating Board, will replace the need for investors to apply to various ministries, reducing processing time to 2-1/2 years for some licenses, and two years for others. This aims to increase Indonesia's economic growth to 5.6-5.8 per cent next year and 7 per cent on average during Widodo's five-year tenure.

site_title: Swiss offices get riskier as franc hurts landlords
summary: Swiss Life Holding AG purchased a Geneva office building for 535 million Swiss francs, setting a record. However, the Swiss National Bank's unexpected removal of the currency cap led to increased vacancy rates and falling rents. Despite rising vacancy rates, investors continue to buy properties due to the lack of high-yielding alternatives in Switzerland, which has one of the world's lowest interest rates. Experts predict further vacancies in the next two years, driven by a "decoupling" between the commercial real estate market and occupier market.

site_title: China Yuanbang declines after chairman held in custody quits
summary: China Yuanbang Property Holdings Ltd shares plummeted 12% in Singapore trading after chairman Chen Jianfeng resigned and was taken into custody by Chinese authorities. The company cited private matters, but the move follows an anti-corruption campaign led by Chinese President Xi Jinping. The shares have declined 24% this year, amid concerns over litigation risks in the Chinese real estate industry. The company's CEO continues to manage daily operations, but the move raises concerns about the company's stability.

site_title: ETF investors flee China market despite rally
summary: Overseas investors are pulling money out of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) tracking the Chinese market despite its recent rally. The total assets of two popular ETFs, iShares FTSE A50 China Index ETF and CSOP FTSE China A50 ETF, fell by HK$13.5 billion and 3.4 billion yuan, respectively, as of January 23. This trend suggests investors are cautious about the Chinese market's long-term prospects, despite short-term gains.

images.alt_text: Overseas investors keep pulling money out of exchange-traded funds (ETF) tracking the Chinese market even as it rallies on.

site_title: Gold drops most this year as investors sell after Greek election
summary: Gold prices fell the most this year, declining 0.9% to $1,283 an ounce, amid speculation that Greece's anti-austerity party won't leave the currency bloc. The European Central Bank's planned stimulus increase and Greek Prime Minister-elect Alexis Tsipras' pledge to keep Greece within the single currency area reduced investor uncertainty. This led to profit-taking, causing gold to drop to its biggest decline since December 31. Meanwhile, silver, platinum, and palladium also declined, with investors adding gold-backed exchange-traded products at the highest level since November.

images.alt_text: Gold fell the most this year amid speculation an anti-austerity party's victory in Greek elections won't result in the country leaving the currency bloc.

site_title: German business morale rises for third straight month in Jan
summary: German business morale rose to its highest level in six months in January, increasing for a third consecutive month, according to a survey by Ifo. The business climate index climbed to 106.7 from 105.5 in December, surpassing the Reuters consensus forecast of 106.3. This marks the highest reading since July, suggesting a strong start for Europe's largest economy in 2015.

site_title: Falling oil prices, floating storage boost Asian premiums
summary: Asian buyers are paying higher premiums for crude oil due to tumbling prices and the possibility of storing excess cargoes on tankers. Oil producers' profits have slumped by 60% since June, but stronger Asian demand is bringing relief. Refining margins have risen, and Asian buyers are willing to pay more for crude relative to Brent and Dubai benchmarks. Some oil traders are soaking up cheap supplies to put into storage, but a large rise in inventories could delay a price recovery.

site_title: As oil slides, Singapore oilfield service firms struggle to refinance debt
summary: Singapore oilfield service firms Ezra Holdings Ltd and Swiber Holdings Ltd face challenges refinancing debt due to the slump in crude prices. Their bonds are trading below par, indicating concerns around refinancing, with Ezra's S$200 million bond due in September and Swiber's S$85 million bond due in June. The companies plan to use a mix of internal cash flow, asset sales, and market funds to address maturing debt. Investors are wary, with two lenders refusing to increase their commitment to Ezra's existing loan.

images.alt_text: Two Singapore oilfield service firms are finding it tough to refinance debt maturing later this year as the slump in crude prices has made investors and lenders hesitant, banking sources said.

site_title: Greece's Syriza to form government with right-wing party
summary: Greece's leftwing Syriza party has formed a coalition government with the right-wing Independent Greeks party. The agreement, announced by Independent Greeks leader Panos Kammenos, comes after talks with Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras. The unlikely alliance is driven by a shared opposition to the EU/IMF bailout program. Kammenos stated that the Independent Greeks will give a vote of confidence to Tsipras and participate in the government, which will be sworn in by the president. This marks an unusual tie-up between parties on opposite ends of the political spectrum.

site_title: Russian dating site Topface hacked for 20 million user names
summary: Russian dating site Topface has been hacked, compromising 20 million user names and e-mail addresses. The breach, discovered by Easy Solutions Inc., has been offered for sale on a cybercrime forum. Topface's CEO, Dmitry Filatov, claims the site has no access to users' passwords and secure information, but hackers can use stolen credentials to access sensitive data. The breach is considered a tier-one breach, with 50% of compromised users from Russia and 40% from the EU.

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange Fund 2014 investment income HK$43.6b
summary: Hong Kong's Exchange Fund posted a HK$43.6 billion investment gain in 2014, down from HK$81.2 billion in the same period in 2013. The fund's return was 1.4%, compared to 2.7% in 2013, due to market volatility and global economic uncertainty. HKMA chief Norman Chan attributed the decline, stating that 2015 will be even more challenging. The decline marks a significant drop from the previous year's gain, highlighting the impact of global economic conditions on the Hong Kong economy.

site_title: Palm oil drops to weakest in 5 weeks as demand wanes
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures dropped to their lowest in nearly five weeks, falling for a third session, as demand from major buyers waned. Prices rose to a six-month high of RM2,394 in December due to monsoon flooding, but concerns about the devastation have cooled, offset by waning export demand and the rout in crude oil. Despite potential further output drops, market players believe waning demand and oil price decline will mitigate the impact, suggesting a slowdown in the palm industry's slump.

images.alt_text: Malaysian palm oil futures fell for a third session on Monday, dropping to their lowest in nearly five weeks as poor demand from major buyers sparked concern that palm's use in food and fuel industries may continue to slump in coming months.

site_title: Hot stock: Singtel shares surge above S$4
summary: Singtel shares surged to a high of S$4.03, exceeding the S$4 mark, after a brand identity refresh unveiled last week. The telco's shares rose steadily since the opening at S$3.99.

site_title: Euro hits 11-year low on Greece fears, equities muted
summary: The euro dropped to an 11-year low against the US dollar on Monday, reaching $1.1088, amid fears that Greece's anti-austerity party may leave the eurozone after winning the country's election. The eurozone's bailout package for Greece is now in doubt, and oil prices resumed their downward trend. Asian equities largely recovered from early losses, with some markets ending in positive territory. The possibility of Greece defaulting on its debt repayments is a concern for markets, with some analysts predicting further selling pressure.

site_title: Aer Lingus says considering new bid from BA owner
summary: Aer Lingus is considering a revised takeover bid from International Consolidated Airlines Group (IAG), owner of British Airways, after a third bid of 2.55 euros per share was made. The bid includes an all-cash offer and a cash dividend. The airline's board must approve the bid, and commitments from Ryanair and the Irish government are also required. The revised bid is conditional on these factors.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open lower on Greek election result
summary: European stocks fell on Monday after Greece's anti-austerity party Syriza won the country's elections, casting doubt on its international bailout and potentially leading to a eurozone exit. The FTSE 100, DAX 30, and CAC 40 indices all dropped, with London's FTSE 100 falling 0.57% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 losing 0.53%. The Greek party's victory puts Greece on a collision course with the EU and international creditors, sparking fears of a potential default and eurozone departure.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore Q4 GDP seen revised upwards on better-than-expected Dec factory output
summary: Singapore's Q4 2014 GDP growth is expected to be revised upwards due to better-than-expected December factory output, which contracted less than expected at 1.9% year-on-year. Economists predict upward revisions, with Bank of America Merrill Lynch and Citi expecting Q4 growth at 2% and 1.6% respectively. The revised GDP growth could be 1.6% year-on-year and 1.8% quarter-on-quarter, with 2014 full-year growth at 2.9% year-on-year.

site_title: Deputy of Indonesia's anti-graft body to resign: agency official
summary: Indonesia's Deputy Chief of the Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) Bambang Widjojanto will submit his resignation letter on Monday, following his detention as a suspect in a false testimony case. The move comes amid strained relations between the KPK and the police. Widjojanto had previously stated he was considering resignation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares gain for 5th day despite eurozone concerns
summary: Hong Kong shares gained for the fifth consecutive day, despite concerns over the eurozone's potential instability following Greece's anti-austerity party win in the general election. Analysts say investor sentiment remains cautious but not negative, with the Shanghai Composite Index contributing to the gains. The market's risk-off mood is limited to specific stocks affected by the election, easing pressure overall.

site_title: Kia Motors shares skid to over four-year low on poor earnings
summary: Kia Motors shares plummeted to a four-year low on Monday after the South Korean automaker reported disappointing fourth-quarter profit. The stock ended down 5.7% at 46,550 won (US$43) per share, with brokerages downgrading target share prices. This is the lowest intraday level since November 2010. The company's poor earnings have led to a broader market trend of almost flat trading on Monday.

site_title: EU open to Greek debt extension, not forgiveness
summary: The European Union is open to extending Greece's debt repayment deadline, but not forgiving the debt. Euro zone finance ministers are considering an extension of the current bailout program, which expires on February 28, to give the new government time to negotiate economic policy with international lenders. However, officials warn that a debt restructuring would send the wrong message to other euro zone members and could lead to a loss of confidence in the single currency.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 0.25% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.25% lower on Monday as Greece's anti-austerity party Syriza won the general election, raising fears of a potential eurozone exit. The Nikkei 225 index fell 43.23 points to 17,468.52, while the Topix index slipped 0.08% to 1,402.08. The market reaction was largely driven by concerns over the impact of a Greek exit on the global economy.

site_title: Swiss sight deposits surge after SNB abandons franc cap
summary: Switzerland's central bank, the Swiss National Bank (SNB), saw a surge in sight deposits, reaching 365.486 billion Swiss francs last week, after abandoning its three-year-old cap on the franc. This indicates the SNB may be intervening to keep the franc down. The SNB has also imposed a negative interest rate of -0.75% on some cash deposits, aiming to discourage new flows into Swiss francs. The move comes after the franc soared against the euro following the SNB's decision to scrap the cap in January.

site_title: Malaysia seen keeping policy rate unchanged on economic risks
summary: Malaysia's central bank is expected to keep its key interest rate at 3.25% due to economic risks from a slump in oil prices and a weakened currency. Economists predict the central bank will stand pat for the rest of 2015 unless the economy improves in the second half of the year. The country's ringgit has depreciated by 6.3% against the dollar in 2014, ranking as the worst performer among emerging Asian markets.

site_title: More China car dealers quit last year after losses, group says
summary: More Chinese auto dealerships quit their sales networks last year due to deteriorating profitability, according to a trade group's survey. The China Auto Dealers Chamber of Commerce found that Audi dealerships were the most satisfied, while Acura dealerships were the least. The decline in profitability threatens the auto industry's survival and affects consumers. Dealerships are seeking financial support and lower sales targets from manufacturers due to rapid expansion and restrictions. Volkswagen has reached an agreement with its imported model dealers, setting reasonable sales targets to ensure a financially sound distribution network.

site_title: Update: Euro hits 11-year low as Greek leftists sweep to power
summary: The euro hit an 11-year low of $1.1098 against the US dollar following Greece's Syriza party's victory in a snap election, potentially leading to a high-stakes standoff with European lenders over austerity measures. Syriza leader Alexis Tsipras will lead the first euro zone government that could challenge the "Troika" comprising the European Central Bank, International Monetary Fund, and European Commission. The euro also fell against the yen and sterling, with analysts anticipating a nuanced long-term impact as Tsipras is expected to work with international lenders.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end flat, risk appetite subdued on Greek vote; won firmer
summary: South Korean shares closed nearly unchanged on Monday, with investors curbing riskier bets following an election victory by Greece's anti-austerity Syriza party, rekindling euro zone instability worries. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) ended 0.02% lower at 1,935.68 points. The won strengthened against the dollar, rising 3.1 cents to 1,080.8, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid risk-off sentiments.

site_title: Singapore consumers more optimistic about 2015 outlook
summary: Singapore consumers are more optimistic about the 2015 outlook, with a 60.9 index points score, up 13.5 points from the previous year. This improvement is seen across all five indicators of consumer confidence, including employment, economy, regular income, stock market, and quality of life. The largest improvements were in quality of life (+19.3 points) and stock market movements (+15.5 points). This indicates increased confidence in the local economy amidst global uncertainty.

images.alt_text: CONSUMERS in Singapore are feeling more buoyant about the local economic outlook compared to a year ago, amid continued uncertainty in the global economy, according to the MasterCard Index of Consumer Confidence.

site_title: Thailand to borrow US$1.2b to help farmers get jobs
summary: Thailand's finance ministry plans to borrow $1.61 billion to provide temporary work for farmers during the dry season, aiming to alleviate economic problems and boost the economy. The military government, led by a coup in May, prioritizes solving farmers' issues, having already paid rice farmers arrears under a controversial scheme. The short-term measure is part of the ministry's package to help farmers find jobs and address economic woes.

site_title: Standard Chartered seeking successor for CEO Sands, FT says
summary: Standard Chartered Plc is seeking a successor for CEO Peter Sands amid pressure from large shareholders, with a potential replacement likely to be in place by the end of this year. Sands, who has been CEO since 2006, has overseen a decline in earnings and shares, prompting Aberdeen Asset Management and Temasek Holdings to push for his departure. The bank is expected to announce a new leadership plan in the coming months, with Sands' successor expected to be in place by year's end.

site_title: Mideast stocks: Saudi succession, positive Q4 results may lift Gulf
summary: Saudi Arabia's swift transition to King Salman may boost the kingdom's stock market, driven by potential populist policies such as state sector wage increases and increased consumer spending. Analysts differ on the likelihood of such measures, with some expecting lavish stimulus despite low oil prices and budget deficits. Other Gulf markets, including Abu Dhabi Commercial Bank and Qatar Electricity and Water Co, may also benefit from positive earnings reports. The global economic background is slightly negative due to renewed instability in Europe following the Greek election.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's swift transition of power may boost the kingdom's stock market on Monday, although analysts' views differ on potential economic policy adjustments; positive earnings reports may support other Gulf markets.

site_title: Broker's take: Nomura maintains 'reduce' rating on Keppel Corp
summary: Nomura maintains its "reduce" rating for Keppel Corp, citing weak new orders and potential earnings downgrades due to a global oversupply of jackup rigs. The rating is also due to concerns over the company's ability to privatize its subsidiary Keppel Land, which is seen as a negative catalyst. However, Nomura analysts note that the privatization offer is reasonable and accretive to shareholders, and signals a longer-term view of the property business. The target price remains at S$7.95.

site_title: North Korea's Kim Jong Un relies on improbable pair of women amid purges
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un relies on two influential women, wife Ri Sol Ju and younger sister Kim Yo Jong, to maintain power amid purges. Ri Sol Ju, known for her Western style, commands a following among the wives of North Korean elite, while Kim Yo Jong holds a senior position in the ruling Workers' Party and serves as an adviser to her brother. Their overlapping influence creates potential rivalry, as family ties are not strong enough to protect against Kim's penchant for purges.

site_title: Hot stock: Tiger Airways gains ground on profitable Q3 FY2015 results
summary: Tiger Airways reported profitable Q3 FY2015 results, with a net profit of S$2.19 million, up from a net loss of $118.54 million in the same quarter last year. Revenue climbed 5.9% year-on-year to S$182.26 million, while operating profit increased to S$4.1 million. The airline has been focusing on turning around its operations, cutting costs and hedging fuel needs, and has secured a rights issue to raise nearly S$230 million.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
SHARES in Tiger Airways gained five Singapore cents to trade at 31 cents Monday morning as the budget carrier unveiled profitable third-quarter results.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asia
summary: Oil prices in Asia declined after Greece's Syriza party won the general elections, dealing a blow to the euro and making dollar-priced oil more expensive. US benchmark WTI fell 2.7% and Brent crude tumbled 1.9% in early trading. Prices rebounded later, but analysts expect oil to remain range-bound. The victory by Syriza, which opposes austerity measures, has sparked fears Greece could exit the eurozone, further depressing oil prices.

site_title: Singapore factory output falls 1.9% y-o-y in Dec, drop is smaller than expected
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector contracted 1.9% in December, a smaller drop than expected. This is the second consecutive month of decline, with production in the electronics cluster falling 2.4% and other sectors experiencing declines in output. Despite this, overall manufacturing output rose 2.6% in 2014. The Singapore Economic Development Board reported a 1.8% month-on-month expansion in industrial production, excluding biomedical manufacturing, and a 1.5% increase on a seasonally-adjusted basis.

site_title: China's Postal Bank said to plan US$1 billion pre-IPO stake sale
summary: Postal Savings Bank of China Co., the state-owned lender with the most outlets in China, plans to raise at least $1 billion from investors before a planned initial public offering this year. The bank aims to boost capital strength as part of a government mandate to focus on lending to rural areas and small businesses, amid President Xi Jinping's efforts to introduce more market discipline to state-owned enterprises. Investment banks are pitching for roles on the pre-IPO share sale.

site_title: Japan's Marubeni halves profit outlook on oil price slide
summary: Japanese trading house Marubeni Corp has halved its net profit projection for the current business year to 110 billion yen (US$935 million) due to falls in oil, copper, and coal prices. The company also expects a goodwill impairment loss of 50 billion yen related to its US-based grain merchant unit. This decrease is attributed to the decline in oil prices, which has impacted the company's resource assets.

images.alt_text: Japanese trading house Marubeni Corp on Monday halved its net profit projection for this business year, booking losses on resource assets due to falls in oil, copper and coal prices.

site_title: Update: Anti-austerity Syriza storms to historic Greek victory
summary: Greece's radical left party Syriza won a historic victory in the country's parliamentary election, securing 149 seats and becoming the first anti-austerity party to take power in Europe. Syriza's leader Alexis Tsipras vowed to renegotiate Greece's €240 billion bailout with the EU and IMF, promising a "just, mutually beneficial and viable solution." The outcome puts Greece on a collision course with the EU and international creditors, with the possibility of a "Grexit" sparking renewed fears of a default on debt repayments.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.23% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.23% in early trading on Monday, following the European Central Bank's bond-buying scheme. The Hang Seng Index increased by 56.74 points to 24,907.19. This move overshadowed the victory of the anti-austerity party in Greek elections, which saw a rally in European shares.

site_title: Malaysia Air website hacked with phrase 'ISIS will prevail'
summary: Malaysia Airlines' website was hacked by a group known as the "Lizard Squad" on January 26, 2015. The hackers left a message referencing Islamic State (ISIS) and claimed to be from the "Cyber Caliphate". The website was temporarily redirected to a page bearing an image of a tuxedo-wearing lizard and an apparent reference to the airline's missing flight MH370. The hack was later resolved, with Malaysia Airlines stating that its web servers were intact and user data remained secure.

site_title: China developer Kaisa's bonds up on buyout reports
summary: China property company Kaisa Group's bond price rose on optimism that a rival developer, Sunac China Holdings, may acquire a stake in the firm. Kaisa failed to make a $26 million interest payment and is in a grace period until February 9. A buyout report suggests Sunac carried out due diligence on Kaisa over the weekend, potentially allowing bondholders to repurchase their bonds at a higher price under a "change of control" clause. This could prevent a default and potentially offer better treatment for bondholders, but some analysts are cautious about the enforceability of these claims.

site_title: Quick takes: Analysts react to Keppel Corp's privatisation bid for Keppel Land
summary: Keppel Corp's bid to privatize its real estate subsidiary Keppel Land has sparked mixed reactions from analysts. Maybank Kim Eng Research maintained a "hold" rating, citing limited synergies, while Nomura reduced its rating to "reduce" due to concerns over weak new orders and potential downgrades in earnings. However, OCBC Investment Research maintained its "buy" call, citing upside potential and a 19% dividend yield, despite a 10% conglomerate discount. Keppel Land's shares rose 11 cents to S$4.55, while Keppel Corp's shares gained 11 cents to S$8.21.

site_title: Oil slides as Saudi Arabia seen holding firm amid supply glut
summary: Oil prices plummeted to nearly six-year lows as Saudi Arabia's new king, King Salman, pledged to maintain production levels amid a global supply glut. The US stockpiled 383.5 million barrels of crude in December, the highest level since 1930, and oil futures dropped 2.7% in New York. The global glut, fueled by US production at a record pace, may persist, with analysts warning that crude production needs to slow down to decelerate stockpiling.

site_title: China's online population nears 650 million: govt
summary: China's online population has reached nearly 650 million, according to the China Internet Network Information Center, exceeding the 648 million users reported at the end of 2014. This represents a 30 million increase from 2013, solidifying China's position as the world's largest online population.

site_title: Tsipras moves to form anti-austerity Greek government after crushing victory
summary: Greek leftwing leader Alexis Tsipras will form an anti-austerity government after his Syriza party won 149 seats in the 300-seat parliament, two short of an absolute majority. Tsipras will meet with other parties to form a government, aiming to reverse years of austerity and renegotiate Greece's huge debts with international lenders. The victory marks a comprehensive rejection of the EU and IMF's bailout deal, and could encourage other anti-austerity forces in Europe.

images.alt_text: Greek leftwing leader Alexis Tsipras will move on Monday to build a stable government that can take on international lenders and reverse years of painful austerity following a crushing election victory by his Syriza party.

site_title: Chinese stocks in Hong Kong drop for first time in five days
summary: Chinese stocks in Hong Kong dropped for the first time in five days, with the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index falling 0.5% and the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.2%. Financial and commodity companies led the decline, while internet security software companies surged after the government announced plans to spend more on national security. This was the first decline in the five-day streak, with other indexes including the CSI 300 Index and the Bloomberg China-US Equity Index also experiencing gains.

site_title: Samsung Electronics to be main chip supplier for next iPhone
summary: Samsung Electronics will supply 75% of the processors for Apple's next iPhone, according to a report by Maeil Business Newspaper. The chips will be made in Samsung's factory in Austin, Texas. The exact contract value and other supplier details were not disclosed. Samsung declined to comment on the market speculation, while Apple was unavailable for immediate comment.

site_title: Gold climbs toward highest level since August after Greek vote
summary: Gold prices rose to a five-month high as Greece's anti-austerity party Syriza won the election, raising concerns of a potential exit from the euro area. The metal climbed 0.4% to $1,297.21 an ounce, while silver and platinum also increased. The victory is seen as a boost to gold demand as investors seek a haven from uncertainty, with gold rising 9.5% this year. The European Central Bank's expansion of stimulus also contributed to the price increase.

site_title: SoftBank to sell US$3.8b bond to retail investors
summary: SoftBank Corp plans to sell a 450 billion yen (S$5.11 billion) unsecured subordinated bond to retail investors, mainly for investment and loan repayment. The proceeds will be used to support various investment opportunities, including a US$10 billion investment in India's online retail market. The company's finance manager stated that having sufficient funds will enable SoftBank to capitalize on any unexpected investment opportunities.

site_title: Australia: Markets closed on Monday
summary: Australia's financial markets are closed on Monday for a public holiday. In contrast, global markets continued to trend upward. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while Asia's markets were driven by mining and healthcare sectors. In the US, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions. eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million in new funding, valuing the company over US$1 billion.

site_title: China: Shares mixed in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares were mixed in morning trade on Monday, with the Shanghai Composite Index falling 0.28% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rising 0.73%. Investors avoided heavyweight financials and instead focused on small firms. The benchmark indices closed at 3,342.35 and 1,525.36, respectively.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks flat; construction, energy decline
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index fell 4 points to 9467.73, flat compared to Friday's 1% gain, amid uncertainty from Greece's election results. Electronics stocks rose 0.12%, while semiconductors and construction ones declined 0.14% and 0.6%, respectively. Oil, gas, and electricity companies dropped 1%, but transportation stocks rose 1%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$31.245 to the US dollar.

site_title: Euro briefly sinks to 11-year low vs dollar after Greek vote
summary: The euro briefly sank to an 11-year low of $1.1184 against the dollar after Greece's anti-austerity party Syriza won the general election, casting doubt on the country's international bailout and potential eurozone exit. The victory has sparked fears of a "Grexit" and has led to a decline in the euro against the dollar and other currencies. Syriza's leader Alexis Tsipras vowed to renegotiate the terms of Greece's $269 billion bailout, while some analysts believe the country will remain in the eurozone.

site_title: WE Holdings plans rights issue, buys Philippine firm
summary: WE Holdings plans a renounceable non-underwritten rights issue of up to 4.2 billion warrants at S$0.001 per warrant, potentially raising S$16.7 million. The proceeds will be used to enhance working capital and financial flexibility. This move aims to capitalize on growth and acquisition opportunities.

site_title: Davos participants unsure if America can power world economy
summary: Participants at the Davos conference expressed concerns that the US economy, which is poised to outpace global growth, may not be enough to power the world economy due to slowing growth in Europe and China. The dollar's rise, driven by the US recovery, threatens to pinch exporters and slow inflation. Experts warn that the malaise in Europe and parts of Asia may undermine the US's strength, and investors are looking for alternative investment opportunities. The International Monetary Fund has reduced its global growth forecast to 3.5% in 2015, citing a multi-speed global economy.

site_title: Broker's take: Nomura maintains 'buy' on Keppel Land on privatisation offer
summary: Nomura maintains its "buy" call on Keppel Land shares after Keppel Corporation launched a two-tier price offer to take the company private at S$4.38/S$4.60 per share. The offer is in line with Nomura's target price of S$4.43 per share. Analysts recommend shareholders take up the offer, citing developers likely to perform better than Reits in 2015 and Keppel Land's similarity to CapitaLand in terms of China property exposure.

site_title: Egypt awards US$2.2b LNG tender to four foreign firms-state gas board
summary: Egypt's state gas board awarded a $2.2 billion tender to four foreign firms to import 75 cargoes of liquefied natural gas (LNG) over two years, as the country seeks new energy sources due to declining production and increasing consumption. The four companies will supply four cargoes a month, with the country relying heavily on gas for power generation. A floating storage and regasification unit is expected to be operational by March, allowing for LNG imports once the terminal is operational.

site_title: Hot stocks: KepLand resumes trading, up 24% on Keppel Corp privatisation offer
summary: Keppel Corporation and its subsidiary Keppel Land resumed trading after a trading halt, with shares rising 24% for KepLand and 1.3% for Keppel Corporation. The move follows the group's announcement of a privatization offer for KepLand, valuing the company at S$6.8 billion. The offer price is S$4.38, with a potential increase to S$4.60 per share if the acceptance levels exceed 90% and a compulsory acquisition.

site_title: Seoul: Shares flat as Greek election results dampen mood; won firmer
summary: South Korean shares were nearly flat on Monday due to Greece's Syriza party victory, which dampened investor mood. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) decreased 0.01% to 1,935.88 points. This follows a 2.5% rally last week, driven by the European Central Bank's bond-buying stimulus. The win by Syriza has raised concerns about European economic problems, affecting investor sentiment.

site_title: Tiger Airways reverses loss to post S$2.2m profit for Q3 FY2015
summary: Tiger Airways Holdings reported a net profit of S$2.19 million for its third quarter ended Dec 31, 2014, reversing a net loss of S$118.5 million a year ago. Revenue increased 6% to S$182.26 million, driven by stronger yield, higher load factor, and lower capacity. The company attributed its improved financial performance to a S$227.4 million rights issue, which strengthened its balance sheet and positioned it for turnaround plans. Despite macro-economic uncertainties and intense competition, Tiger Airways remains vigilant.

images.alt_text: TIGER Airways Holdings on Monday posted a net profit of S$2.19 million for its third quarter ended Dec 31, 2014 (Q3 FY2015), reversing a net loss of S$118.5 million a year ago.

site_title: Japan exports rise more than forecast, paring record deficit
summary: Japan's exports rose 12.9% in December, exceeding forecasts and narrowing a record annual trade deficit caused by energy purchases and surge in imports. The annual deficit widened to 12.8 trillion yen, but stronger exports are expected to support the economy. Exports to the US, EU, and Asia increased, with shipments to China rising 4.3%. The drop in oil prices may lead to a return to a trade surplus in 2015, according to JPMorgan Chase. This positive economic trend may support growth in the year starting April.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 2.96 points to 1800.49. The market saw 36.54 million lots traded worth RM13.06 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 78 to 76.

site_title: Japan's 2014 LNG imports rise 1.2% to record high
summary: Japan's liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports rose 1.2% to a record 88.51 million tonnes in 2014, driven by increased use of LNG following the shutdown of nuclear plants after the Fukushima disaster. LNG imports are expected to fall to 85 million tonnes in 2015 as some nuclear reactors resume operations. Meanwhile, thermal coal imports rose 0.1% to a record, and crude oil imports fell 5.5% to their lowest since 1988. Japan paid a record 7.85 trillion yen (US$66.67 billion) for LNG last year, up 11.2% from a year earlier.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, Keppel Land, Tiger Airways, WE Holdings, SGX
summary: Keppel Corp and Keppel Land resumed trading on Monday after a trading halt, with KepLand up 24% on a privatisation offer by Keppel Corp. Tiger Airways reported a net profit of $2.19 million for its third quarter, reversing a net loss the previous year. WE Holdings proposed a rights issue to raise up to $16.7 million, while Singapore Exchange (SGX) partnered with Clearbridge Accelerator to develop an equity crowdfunding platform for entrepreneurs and SMEs.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened higher on Tuesday, up 20.56 points to 3,419.08. The rally marks a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data. Gainers outnumbered losers 99 to 49, with volume reaching 72.0 million shares worth S$120.5 million.

site_title: Canada to unveil new security legislation after 2014 attacks: PM
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Stephen Harper announced plans to introduce new security legislation aimed at enhancing police powers and preventing terrorism. The legislation, set to be introduced next Friday, will allow for preventative detention, interrogating suspects before charges are laid, and crack down on hate speech. Harper stated the measures will not infringe on constitutionally protected rights to free speech, association, and religion. Experts note that existing laws already provide law enforcement agencies with wide-ranging powers, raising concerns that the new legislation may be unnecessary.

site_title: Ascott to manage three more properties in Beijing, Hong Kong
summary: Ascott, a serviced residence business unit of CapitaLand, has secured contracts to manage three properties in Beijing and Hong Kong, with over 300 units. The properties, including Citadines Fangshan Beijing and Hotel Pravo Hong Kong, are expected to open in 2018 and March 2015, respectively. This expansion reinforces Ascott's leadership position in China, with over 12,900 units in 72 properties across 23 cities. The move is driven by high demand for accommodation from Fortune 500 companies and major Chinese corporations in gateway cities like Beijing and Hong Kong.

site_title: Galeries Lafayette owner raises Carrefour stake to 9.5%: paper
summary: The Moulin family, owners of Galeries Lafayette, has raised its stake in Carrefour to 9.5%, becoming the second-largest shareholder after a consortium of Groupe Arnault and Colony Capital. This comes after the family acquired 6.1% of Carrefour last April for approximately 1.28 billion euros.

site_title: Kuroda remarks open possibilities for shift in BOJ stimulus
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda hinted that the central bank may need to explore unconventional monetary stimulus options, including regional-government bonds, to achieve its inflation target of 2%. Kuroda's comments come as the BOJ faces criticism for its asset-purchasing strategy, which has driven down yields on national government bonds. Economists expect the BOJ to step up easing by October, but some warn that oil price declines may limit the impact of monetary policy on inflation.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC maintains 'buy' call on Keppel Corp
summary: OCBC Investment Research maintains its "buy" call on Keppel Corp, setting a fair value of S$9.14. The company's Q4 FY2014 results showed a 9.1% year-on-year rise in revenue and a 6.1% rise in net profit. Keppel Corp recently launched an offer to take its subsidiary Keppel Land private, which may lead to near-term weakness in the stock price. Despite this, the analysts expect a 19% upside potential, maintaining their "buy" rating.

site_title: Blackstone to sell prime Sydney property to Dalian Wanda for US$327m
summary: US private equity firm Blackstone Group has agreed to sell its prime Sydney office building, Gold Fields House, to China's Dalian Wanda Group for approximately US$327 million. Blackstone acquired the property as part of its purchase of Australian property group Valad in 2011. Dalian Wanda plans to build a 5-star hotel, luxury residential, and retail developments at the location, creating a new Sydney landmark. This deal marks Wanda's expansion overseas and diversification away from a weak domestic real estate market, following investments in London and Madrid hotels and properties.

site_title: Par policies could yield lower bonuses with new risk-based capital framework
summary: Singaporean life insurance policyholders of participating (par) products may see bonus restructuring or a cut in bonus rates under the proposed changes to the existing risk-based capital framework (RBC 2). The framework is expected to substantially raise life insurers' overall capital charges due to increased equity and credit risk charges. To mitigate the squeeze on their finances, insurers may restructure par policy bonuses or reduce bonus rates, with terminal bonuses being more likely to be cut due to their immediate impact. Insurers may also consider ending sales of current whole life policies and releasing a new series with lower reversionary bonus rates.

site_title: Airlines scrap 1,400 US flights as storm threatens Northeast
summary: Airlines scrapped over 1,400 US flights ahead of a blizzard that may dump 3 feet of snow on the Northeast. JetBlue and Shuttle America canceled flights, with FlightAware predicting thousands of cancellations across the region. Airlines have already canceled 1,013 flights on Monday, with the number expected to rise significantly over the next two days. The blizzard's impact on travel is expected to be severe, with the National Weather Service warning of hazardous conditions.

images.alt_text: Airlines scrapped more than 1,400 US flights ahead of a blizzard that the National Weather Service said may dump as much as 3 feet of snow on northern New Jersey, New York City and parts of southern New England.

site_title: UK parliament group calls for shale gas fracking moratorium
summary: A UK parliament group has called for a moratorium on shale gas fracking, citing concerns over climate change targets and environmental risks. The proposal comes as the British government aims to reduce its dependence on gas imports and stem a decline in North Sea energy resources. Members of the Environmental Audit Committee believe a moratorium is necessary to resolve uncertainty surrounding environmental risks and align with the country's climate change obligations.

site_title: New York braces for monster snowstorm
summary: A fast-moving winter storm is expected to hit the US northeast, bringing up to three feet of snow to New York and potentially causing regional chaos. Authorities have issued blizzard warnings and advised residents to stay home. The storm is expected to affect areas from New Jersey to Massachusetts, with possible flight cancellations, delays, and airport closures. The National Weather Service has described the storm as a "possibly historic" nor'easter, with heavy snowfall and strong winds. Residents are advised to take precautions and prepare for extreme weather.

site_title: World leaders pay respects on Saudi day of mourning
summary: Saudi Arabia is holding a day of mourning for the late King Abdullah, with foreign leaders paying their respects to King Salman. The day of mourning comes as the kingdom continues to mourn Abdullah's death, with many Saudis visiting local government headquarters to express condolences. King Salman, a half-brother of Abdullah, has declared the day a nationwide holiday to provide comfort to citizens. The visit of foreign leaders reflects Saudi Arabia's significant influence as the world's leading oil exporter and a key player in the region.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 1.08% after Greek vote
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 1.08% at open on Monday following Greece's anti-austerity party Syriza's victory in general elections. The euro hit an 11-year low against the dollar at US$1.1169. Syriza's win poses a challenge to Greece's international bailout program and raises fears of a possible eurozone exit. Meanwhile, Japan's trade deficit expanded to a record US$109 billion last year, but lower oil prices may narrow the trade balance. US stocks closed lower on Friday, ending a four-day winning streak.

site_title: Property cash crunch worsens as trusts pull funds: China Credit
summary: China's property cash crunch worsens as investment trusts pull funds due to Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd.'s missed payments and concerns over developers' cash supply. Property-related products issuance declined 62% to 38.5 billion yuan in Q4, with builders facing a record 241 billion yuan in trust repayments in 2015. Default risks at developers may rise, with smaller developers vulnerable due to high debt loads and limited funding channels. This may lead to a credit crunch, as investors become wary of shadow banking and property developers' leverage ratios remain high.

site_title: SGX, VC firm to launch equity crowdfunding platform for SMEs, entrepreneurs
summary: SGX and venture capital firm Clearbridge Accelerator (CBA) are launching an equity crowdfunding (ECF) platform for entrepreneurs and SMEs to raise capital. The platform will be open to accredited investors and will focus on growth-stage firms in Asia. The joint venture aims to address a funding crunch for startups and provide fresh investment options for traditional investors. Key details include the platform's initial focus on Series A and B funding, and ongoing development of the platform's mechanics, including a strategic equity partnership and investor demand creation.

site_title: Fines, reforms force Deutsche Bank to face tough strategy choices
summary: Deutsche Bank faces significant challenges after a speech by co-CEO Juergen Fitschen sparked "Duesselgate", questioning the bank's universal strategy. Fines, regulations, and low profitability have led to a turning point, with potential cost cuts, restructuring, and penalties. The bank may consider selling half of its Postbank retail unit, simplifying its model and raising capital, but this could cut ties with the German economy. Deutsche still struggles with high costs, low profitability, and low capital levels, and its plan to remain a universal bank is becoming increasingly expensive.

site_title: Obama spearheads personal medicine push
summary: President Barack Obama will propose hundreds of millions of dollars for a precision medicine initiative in his upcoming budget. The effort aims to develop medical treatments tailored to individual patients' genetic characteristics. The proposal will support biomedical research and the regulation of diagnostic tests by the Food and Drug Administration. Lawmakers from both parties are expected to support the initiative, which has the potential to transform the healthcare system by providing more effective treatments and saving money.

site_title: DeClout acquires shares in unit Corous360 for S$7.36m
summary: DeClout Ltd, an infocomm company, has acquired 520,000 new ordinary shares of its subsidiary Corous360 for S$7.36 million, increasing its stake to 100%. The shares were allocated as part of Corous360's payment for its acquisition of Netipay Pte Ltd.

site_title: European politics at tipping point as frustrations grow
summary: European politics are at a tipping point as frustrations over income disparities, record unemployment, and immigration grow. Elections in Greece, Ireland, Britain, and Spain are expected to reflect these sentiments, with polls showing widespread dissatisfaction. Disaffection with the ruling elite and a sense of being left behind in a globalized world are complaints across the spectrum. The Greek economy has shrunk by a quarter, and joblessness exceeds 25%, while Spain has the highest jobless rate in Europe. The euro has declined 14% against the dollar, and borrowing costs for Greece are rising again.

site_title: How likely is it that par products' bonus rates will be affected?
summary: Singapore insurers' ability to fund future non-guaranteed benefits, including bonuses, is uncertain amid the impending risk-based capital framework (RBC 2). A comparison of insurers' allowance for non-guaranteed benefits to their total assets shows varying levels of reserves. Prudential, for example, had a S$6.27 billion buffer, while AXA Life had the least at 7%. Insurers may be forced to restructure or cut bonus rates if their reserve buffers are insufficient, but some, like Prudential, have maintained a proportion of allowance buffer at one-third of their total assets. The RBC 2 may lead to greater volatility in terminal bonuses and a shift towards non-par products.

site_title: Hoax call put through to British prime minister
summary: A hoax caller pretending to be GCHQ director Robert Hannigan was put through to British Prime Minister David Cameron on Sunday, prompting a review of security procedures. The caller, claiming to be Hannigan, had previously been given his mobile phone number, leading to a second hoax call to GCHQ. Both calls ended when the hoax was revealed, with no sensitive information disclosed. The government is reviewing procedures to ensure lessons are learned from the incidents.

site_title: Functional, with down to earth prices
summary: Syun, a Japanese restaurant at Resorts World Sentosa, boasts friendly service but lacks distinctive dishes, making it a functional but unremarkable dining experience. Chef Hal Yamashita's input to the menu is minimal, and prices are down-to-earth, with a priciest set menu of S$120. Standout dishes include a raw wagyu and uni combination, and a sashimi selection, but others, like grilled cod and char-broiled wagyu, are unremarkable. Overall, Syun is a middle-of-the-road option for those seeking a casual Japanese meal.

site_title: In-flight catalogue SkyMall may soon close shop
summary: SkyMall, a popular in-flight shopping catalogue, may be closing due to decreased usage with the rise of electronic devices and in-flight Wi-Fi. The catalogue, started in 1990, featured unique and often humorous products, such as a doggy DNA test kit and a giant fake rock. Its parent company, Xhibit, has filed for bankruptcy protection, citing the shift in consumer behavior. The catalogue's demise marks the end of an aviation tradition that was once a staple for passengers.

site_title: The bull case for oil
summary: Global crude markets are oversupplied, but the quantum of oversupply is relatively small, with a modest 0.75 million barrels per day surplus. Despite this, oil prices have plummeted, with some companies laying down rigs and reducing 2015 spending plans. The industry is expected to cut capital expenditure by 7% relative to prior budgets, with major oil companies announcing a 4% reduction. US shale plays are particularly vulnerable, with most companies already in the red zone at current prices. The industry is expected to remove capital from conventional production, including maintenance and modification work, and widespread redundancies are anticipated.

site_title: Well tests during shale boom come under a cloud
summary: US shale oil and gas developers are under scrutiny for the reliability of one-day performance tests, which can boost company shares but don't accurately predict future potential. A study by Drillinginfo found that the tests' short time frame and methods used to boost initial output can mislead investors. The practice, which has helped finance drillers during the US$100-a-barrel oil era, may become a liability as investors seek more transparency and accurate data. Industry experts and companies are shifting towards longer-term testing and more transparent reporting to address the issue.

images.alt_text: A few producers have stopped touting 24-hour tests, saying that the results are poorly understood and figure too prominently in trading and speculation about company prospects, leading to overly sharp changes in share prices.

site_title: F&N inks extension of licence agreements with Nestlé
summary: F&N (Fraser and Neave Limited) has signed 11-year licence agreements with Nestlé to manufacture and distribute Carnation, Bear Brand, and other dairy products in Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, and Brunei. The agreements extend existing licences granted in 2007 and take effect on July 1, 2015. F&N plans to invest 300 million baht (S$12 million) in a new filling and packaging line in Thailand to manufacture Carnation evaporated milk. The company now holds a 66% market share in Malaysia's condensed milk segment and leads in Thailand's condensed milk and sterilised milk segments.

site_title: New mobile app launched for municipal feedback
summary: Singapore's Municipal Services Office (MSO) has launched a new mobile app, OneService, to facilitate public feedback on municipal issues. The app, available for download on both Apple and Google Play, allows users to report issues such as cleanliness, water supply, and trees, with the option to attach photos and geo-tag locations. The app will automatically route feedback to relevant government agencies, enabling faster and more effective action. The app's launch follows a review of municipal services, which identified areas for improvement, particularly in complex issues requiring multiple agencies.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Explaining "comply or explain"
summary: The "comply or explain" approach in corporate governance, used by Singapore's Code of Corporate Governance, has been criticized for unclear rules. However, this approach allows companies to avoid burdensome and costly requirements, setting goals for non-compliant companies to learn and improve. It enables innovation and internalization of principles through self-reflection and dialogue with stakeholders, including regulators, shareholders, and industry watchers. Effective implementation relies on mutual trust among stakeholders, with regulators, shareholders, and industry watchers monitoring compliance and enforcing action when necessary.

site_title: Directors' trading activity up; buybacks decline
summary: Singaporean company directors made 52 transactions worth S$18.3 million in the Jan 19-23 week, with 16 companies recording purchases worth S$12.5 million. Buybacks declined, with 16 companies posting 58 repurchases worth S$24.4 million. Ho Bee Land recorded its first buyback since January 2014, while Global Palm Resources bought back for the first time since July 2014. Other companies, including Hong Fok Corporation, China Environment, CH Offshore, and Sarine Technologies, also made significant purchases or repurchases.

site_title: Keppel Corp, Keppel Land shares resume trading
summary: Keppel Corp announced an offer to take Keppel Land (KepLand) private using a two-tier price approach. KepLand shares resumed trading on Monday morning, up 24% following the announcement. Keppel Corp owns 54.6% of KepLand. The offer aims to acquire the remaining shares Keppel Corp does not own, marking a significant move in the group's strategy.

images.alt_text: SHARES of Keppel Corporation and Keppel Land (KepLand) will resume trading on Monday morning, after the group announced a trading halt last Wednesday.

site_title: Central bankers form defensive alliance in face of mounting criticism
summary: Central bankers have formed a defensive alliance in response to mounting criticism, with the European Central Bank launching monetary easing and Bank of England governor Mark Carney defending inflation targeting. However, analysts warn that markets may deliver a harsh verdict, exposing central bankers to criticism and market reaction. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe may distance himself from BOJ policies, and former BOJ officials have launched attacks on governor Haruhiko Kuroda's policies. The ECB's asset-buying program has also sparked controversy, with some critics accusing central banks of weakening national currencies.

site_title: Shanghai stampede showed "critical neglect": mayor
summary: Shanghai's New Year's Eve stampede that killed 36 people was attributed to "critical neglect" by the city's mayor, Yang Xiong. The incident occurred due to severe overcrowding and inadequate safety measures in the historic waterfront area. Eleven officials, mostly from Huangpu district, have been punished, but no criminal charges have been announced. The mayor defended the investigation report, which downgraded the incident to "an incident" rather than an "accident". Families of the deceased have criticized the compensation of 800,000 yuan each, calling for greater government accountability.

site_title: Crude price collapse leaves Freeport to rue oil & gas acquisitions
summary: Freeport-McMoRan Inc, the world's largest publicly traded copper miner, is struggling after a $9 billion debt-fueled purchase of oil and natural gas producers in 2012. The collapse in oil and gas prices has left the company with $19 billion in debt and a 38% decline in its shares since the acquisition. Freeport is reviewing its 2015 capital budget and may cut more than 20% of its spending due to the decline in commodity prices, with cuts in both mining and energy spending.

site_title: Taking heart
summary: A public art exhibition "Art for Autism: Diversity Exhibition" will be launched by PATHLIGHT School, featuring 17 student artists with autism. Proceeds from the sale of artworks will benefit the Autism Resource Centre. Ultramarathoner Lim Nghee Huat is raising S$150,000 for Habitat for Humanity Singapore through his ultramarathon efforts. SilkAir has partnered with Child's Dream Foundation to support education and health initiatives in the Mekong Sub-Region, offering discounted tickets and cargo allowance.

images.alt_text: Close to 50 beneficiaries from St John's Home for Elderly Persons and St Andrew's Cathedral Home for the Aged embarking on an hour-long Duck Tour on Thursday, visiting landmarks including The Esplanade and Asian Civilisations Museum. This was part of Hong Leong Foundation's annual charity event, which includes cash giveaways of about S$580,000 to more than 5,000 recipients.

site_title: Obama defends US counterterrorism strategy in Yemen
summary: US President Barack Obama defended the country's drone-based counterterrorism strategy in Yemen against al Qaeda militants, stating it was the best option despite the recent collapse of the US-backed government and the takeover by Iran-aligned Houthi rebels. Obama said the US would continue to target high-value targets and maintain pressure to keep the American people safe. White House officials defended the strategy, emphasizing the need for support to allies rather than deploying large numbers of troops, while a Republican senator criticized the approach, calling for more boots on the ground.

images.alt_text: US President Barack Obama on Sunday defended his administration's drone-based counterterrorism strategy against al Qaeda militants in Yemen, saying the alternative would be to deploy US troops, which was not sustainable.

site_title: Glued to TV, Cubans cheer talks with US like a sporting event
summary: US and Cuban diplomats met to restore diplomatic ties after five decades, with Havana residents following developments with excitement. Despite officials stating profound differences remain, both sides expressed optimism about the talks, with some residents hailing the move as a "opening" or "la apertura". US officials pressed for respect of freedom of speech, assembly, and dissent, while Cuba accused the US of rights violations. Diplomats agreed on some areas, but crucial differences remain, and a date for the next round of talks has not been set.

site_title: Greek leftist leader Tsipras claims victory over austerity
summary: Greek leftist leader Alexis Tsipras' Syriza party has won a snap election, securing 149 seats in the 300-seat parliament with 36.1% of the vote. Tsipras promises to renegotiate Greece's 240 billion euro bailout deal, raising the possibility of a major conflict with euro zone partners. He vows to cooperate with fellow euro zone leaders for a "fair and mutually beneficial solution" but prioritizes Greek interests. Tsipras faces enormous problems, including a struggling economy and tough negotiations with European partners, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel.

images.alt_text: Greek leftist leader Alexis Tsipras promised on Sunday that five years of austerity,"humiliation and suffering" imposed by international creditors were over after his Syriza party swept to victory in a snap election on Sunday.

site_title: After Ebola, WHO to set up contingency fund, develop "surge capacity"
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has agreed to create a contingency fund and emergency workforce to respond quickly to global health crises, following criticism of its delayed response to the Ebola epidemic. The fund, which will start with $100 million, aims to strengthen crisis management and streamline procedures for recruiting frontline workers. The WHO has also adopted major reforms, including a resolution to increase its workforce to 1,500 for emergencies. The moves come after the Ebola outbreak, which reported 21,724 cases and 8,641 deaths in nine countries, and comes as the outbreak is ebbing in West Africa.

site_title: China families lukewarm about easing of one-child policy
summary: China's partial relaxation of the one-child policy, introduced in 2013, has not led to an increase in fertility rates. Many families, including those in urban areas, are choosing to stick with one child due to practical and economic reasons, as well as decades of government propaganda. Analysts predict a looming demographic crisis, including low fertility rates, a rapidly aging population, and a shrinking labor force, which could threaten the legitimacy of Communist Party rule. China's fertility rate of 1.4 children per woman is below the global average, and experts warn of a substantial decline in the supply of young labor and an escalating financial burden on the elderly.

site_title: Starbucks brews new success in mobile transition
summary: Starbucks has achieved unusual success in mobile payments, with 16% of total transactions coming from smartphones. The company's mobile payment platform is integrated with its My Starbucks Rewards programme, which added nearly 900,000 new members in December. CEO Howard Schultz calls the programme a key business driver, generating long-term loyalty. Starbucks plans to expand mobile shopping capabilities, aiming to cut wait times at the counter. The company's mobile transformation is expected to provide valuable data on loyal customers, enabling targeted marketing and promotions.

site_title: Busting graft: Tone from the top is key
summary: CEOs must lead by example to build and sustain a graft-free corporate culture. Setting a zero-tolerance policy for corruption and demonstrating integrity is crucial. Companies must communicate this message openly and regularly, and hold leaders and employees accountable for upholding the code of conduct. Regular training, compliance awareness, and a strong tone from the top are essential. Implementing robust prevention, detection, and reaction systems, and creating a culture of accountability can also help prevent corruption. Effective governance, transparent operations, and recognition of good behavior are key to sustaining a graft-free society.

site_title: Getting personal: Obama's visit to India off to a warm, welcoming start
summary: US President Barack Obama's visit to India began on a warm note as Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi broke protocol to greet him at the airport with a bear hug. The two leaders are expected to strengthen their relationship, with agreements on civilian nuclear trade, climate change, taxation, and defence cooperation. Obama will be the first US president to attend India's Republic Day parade and host a radio show with Modi. The visit aims to take relations to a higher level and address issues such as Pakistan and regional security.

site_title: Delivery van-booking apps seen having good prospects in Asia
summary: Delivery van-booking apps, such as GoGoVan and EasyVan, are expected to have good prospects in Asia due to the absence of proficient logistics infrastructure and the growth of e-commerce. Despite a small market in Singapore, where only two major players operate, the apps believe there is significant demand for such services in other Asian cities, particularly in the Philippines, Indonesia, and Malaysia, where transportation networks are underdeveloped. Funding from global investors, such as Uber, has also fueled the growth of these apps, with GoGoVan valued at nearly $100 million.

site_title: India-Singapore relations going strong
summary: India and Singapore will celebrate the 50th anniversary of their bilateral diplomatic relations this year, marking a significant milestone in their close relationship. The two countries have strengthened ties through high-level exchanges, economic cooperation, and cultural programs. Plans include cultural exchange programs, reciprocal visits, and festivals in both countries. India and Singapore have a strong economic partnership, with bilateral trade growing significantly since the signing of the Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA) in 2005. The golden anniversary will be used to reflect on the progress of the bilateral relationship and assess achievements, with opportunities for cooperation in manufacturing, tourism, and infrastructure development.

site_title: Euro tumbles on Greek vote results, approaches 11-year low
summary: The euro has weakened to an 11-year low versus the US dollar, falling to around $1.1140, after Greece's Syriza party won a snap election, raising concerns over a potential debt write-off and end to austerity measures. The euro slipped below a 16-month low, and the US dollar rose to 117.50 yen, knocking the Australian and New Zealand dollars to multi-year lows. Market participants expect the euro to continue its decline if Syriza secures an outright majority, potentially testing the $1.10 level.

images.alt_text: The euro weakened on Monday, approaching an 11-year low versus the US dollar after projections showed Greece's Syriza party had won a snap election, raising the risk that the country may demand a debt write-off and end austerity measures.

site_title: Young economist stands out with maverick rate call
summary: A 29-year-old economist, Thomas Costerg, predicted the Bank of Canada would cut interest rates by 50 basis points in March, but the central bank only cut rates by a quarter percentage point. Costerg's forecast was met with surprise, as most veteran market watchers predicted no rate move for the full year. He attributed his accurate prediction to analyzing sharp oil price drops, deteriorating economic data, and a Bank of Canada policymaker's speech. Costerg has since revised his forecast to a 25 basis point cut in March and maintains a call for a 25 basis point cut in April.

site_title: McDonald's tests new concepts as sales fall
summary: McDonald's reported its worst financial performance in a decade, with a 7% decline in revenue and a 21% drop in earnings. The company attributed the decline to tough competition and changing consumer tastes, but also cited events beyond its control such as food safety scandals and global economic factors. McDonald's is testing new concepts, including kiosks and a hybrid sandwich shop, and has simplified its menu and reduced promotions. Analysts say it will take time for these changes to pay off, and the company has reduced its capital investments to $2 billion, the least in over five years.

site_title: At Home Group moves in just as JC Penney moves out
summary: At Home Group Inc has acquired over 40 shuttered JC Penney stores in the US, taking advantage of the retail chain's closures to expand its warehouse-based home decor business. At Home had already researched JC Penney's locations and expressed interest in buying some of them within hours of the announcement. The company plans to add 20 new locations this year and boost its store count by 20% annually for the foreseeable future, with CEO Lee Bird aiming for hundreds of stores across the US. At Home's big-box approach contrasts with the trend of smaller store formats and online shopping.

site_title: Green debt issuance booming, but are the bonds really green?
summary: Green bond issuance is booming, with annual growth of 50% or more, reaching $36.6 billion in 2014. However, investors are concerned about the lack of enforceable standards for "green" bonds, which can be labeled by any debt issuer. This has led to bogus proposals, such as a Canadian tar sands processor and a US transport agency, attempting to sell debt as green bonds despite environmental concerns. The Green Bond Principles, a voluntary guide, aim to address this issue, but do not declare certain industries or technologies ineligible.

site_title: Euro plunges to 11-year low amid stimulus bid
summary: The euro plummeted to an 11-year low of US$1.1204 on Friday, following Mario Draghi's announcement of a 1.1 trillion euro stimulus plan, exceeding forecasts. The currency dropped 3.1% against the US dollar, its largest weekly loss since 2011, and slid 2.9% against the yen. Other currencies also fell, with Canada's dollar dropping 3.5% and Denmark's kroner tumbling 3.3%. The European Central Bank's actions sparked a global market reaction, with the Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index rising 1.9%.

site_title: Shares of Box up 66% at US$23.23 in trading debut
summary: Box Inc. made its trading debut, with shares rising 66% to US$23.23 in its initial public offering, valuing the company at US$2.7 billion. The IPO raised US$175 million, with 50% of the proceeds going towards sales and marketing, product development, and expansion. Despite fierce competition, Box aims to carve out a niche in the cloud-storage market, which is forecast to grow 23% annually to US$2.3 billion by 2018.
