Founder Aaron Levie maintains control of the company, which has improved its financials, including a 70% revenue jump to US$57 million in the latest quarter.

site_title: Services of VPN providers suffer further disruptions in China
summary: VPN services in China experienced disruptions last week, with Astrill, StrongVPN, and Golden Frog reporting issues. Chinese state media justified the disruptions, citing network governance for safety. The Great Firewall, a sophisticated internet censorship system, has been upgraded for "cyberspace sovereignty." VPNs allow users to bypass blocked websites and apps, including those operated by Google, Facebook, and Twitter. Disruptions have become increasingly common, affecting individuals and companies using VPNs for business.

site_title: In brief
summary: CSC Holdings has warned of a net loss for its financial third quarter ended Dec 31, 2014, based on preliminary unaudited consolidated financial results. The company will disclose further details when it announces its results.

site_title: WHO chief accepts criticism over Ebola response
summary: World Health Organization (WHO) chief Margaret Chan admitted the agency was caught off guard by the Ebola epidemic, warning that complacency should not be tolerated. Despite turning the corner, progress can be undone, and a lesson should be learned to avoid similar mistakes in the future.

site_title: Regional banks better at meeting emerging markets' retail demand
summary: Regional banks are better positioned to meet emerging markets' retail demand as international banks withdraw from some countries, according to a report by EY. Global institutions are refocusing on core business lines such as wealth management and high-value investment banking, leaving regional banks to capture trade flows and retail banking demand in emerging markets. This shift is expected to benefit regional banks, which are more agile and adaptable to local market needs.

images.alt_text: HSBC and Citigroup - which, like Standard Chartered, are heavily exposed to Asia - have exited businesses in Asia.

site_title: Graft-buster Joko losing steam
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo's graft-busting efforts are in doubt amid a feud between the Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) and the national police. The police released KPK deputy chair Bambang Widjojanto on a perjury charge, sparking thousands to protest in support of the agency. The KPK's investigation into police chief nominee Budi Gunawan has raised concerns about Jokowi's commitment to anti-corruption efforts, with many seeing the police overreach as a sign of political meddling. The standoff risks crippling the KPK, which has jailed nearly 400 people in its 11-year history.

site_title: Fond farewell to the Music Man
summary: Iskandar Ismail, a renowned Singaporean musician and composer, passed away in November 2014 due to cancer. A free concert was held in his memory at the Esplanade Concert Hall, featuring top entertainers such as Dick Lee and Selena Tan, who had worked with Iskandar on musical projects. The event, organized by his friends, was a simple yet moving tribute to his legacy, with performances by child performers from the ChildAid charity concert, which Iskandar had directed from 2006 until his death.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: FOMC, Greek polls take over from ECB meeting
summary: The US Federal Reserve meeting is expected to keep interest rates depressed, while the European Central Bank's (ECB) quantitative easing (QE) package, worth one trillion euros, aims to kick-start the eurozone out of recession. Greek elections may impact the eurozone, with the Syriza party favoring exiting the eurozone. Experts caution that QE can be a double-edged sword, and structural adjustments are needed to improve the euro area's economic outlook. The US central bank is unlikely to shock markets with a rate hike, but US stocks dropped on Friday, potentially due to "buy in anticipation, sell on news."

site_title: A strong dollar not a 'good news' for all
summary: The US dollar is gaining strength, up 15% against other major currencies since July, driven by robust economic growth and low inflation. This trend is expected to continue as long as the US economy outperforms the rest of the world. However, the stronger dollar poses challenges for US companies with high overseas exposure, as it puts pressure on sales and profit margins. The dollar's rise also makes US stocks more attractive to foreign investors, potentially boosting consumer spending and economic growth.

site_title: All eyes on Fed's take on oil, forex market upheavals
summary: US stocks are expected to test record highs this week if the Federal Reserve reassures investors that its policy plans remain unchanged despite market upheavals. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing program has led to a decline in oil prices and a strengthening euro, causing volatility in the markets. Economists expect the Fed to leave its statement unchanged, which could drive the dollar up and hurt some US stock-market sectors. The impact of the stronger dollar on US corporations is expected to be offset by cheaper gasoline, but investors are advised to remain cautious.

site_title: Goldman's commodity outlook buckles under deflation threat
summary: Goldman Sachs cut forecasts for metals and mined raw materials, including copper, gold, and iron ore, due to deflation and cost pressure. The bank predicts a 10-20% decline in prices over the next three years. Lower energy costs, a stronger US dollar, and oversupply are contributing factors. The bank is more bullish on palladium, nickel, and zinc. Gold is expected to decline from the third quarter of 2015, while copper and iron ore prices are forecast to fall due to weak demand and oversupply.

site_title: Uber, Lyft vehicles must have commercial plates: California
summary: California's Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) has stated that ride-sharing drivers for companies like Uber and Lyft must possess a commercial license plate to operate in the state, or face a citation. This requirement is based on an 80-year-old law, but Uber disputes this, citing a recent law signed by Governor Jerry Brown that allows personal registration. The decision may increase costs for drivers and hinder the growth of the ride-sharing industry, with lawmakers and advocacy groups expressing concerns about the impact on the economy and personal choice.

site_title: Extra hiring for holiday season deliveries backfires on UPS
summary: UPS hired 95,000 workers and spent $675 million to improve its delivery service for the 2014 holiday season, but the efforts resulted in idle workers and trucks on less busy days, leading to a drop in productivity and increased expenses. This dragged down UPS's preliminary earnings, which fell short of forecasts, causing the company's stock to decline 9.9% and sending its earnings growth expectations for 2015 to "slightly below" its previous target. The company aims to balance volume swings with online shopping and e-commerce growth.

site_title: Vietnam architect builds low-cost, high-tech home
summary: Vietnamese architect Vo Trong Nghia has designed a low-cost, high-tech home made from bamboo and coconut leaves that can withstand typhoons, flooding, and earthquakes. The S-House 2, which costs less than $4,000, features a steel internal structure and can be built by five people in three hours. The design aims to provide affordable, sustainable housing for communities vulnerable to climate change, and Nghia plans to refine the design to create a flat-pack home. The project has the potential to provide resort-quality accommodation for low-income residents, and NGOs have already approached Nghia for support in disaster-prone areas.

site_title: Crisis intensifies for Japan govt as one of two IS hostages 'slaughtered'
summary: Japan's hostage crisis worsened with the release of an online video showing freelance journalist Kenji Goto holding a photo of decapitated hostage Haruna Yukawa, pleading for his own life and freedom. The Islamic State demanded Japan pay a $200 million ransom or release an Iranian woman on death row for a deadly hotel bombing in 2005. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe condemned the killing and demanded Goto's release, while US, French, and Australian leaders also condemned the brutal murder. The crisis is ongoing, with Japan seeking to establish communication with the Islamic State through local tribes and religious leaders.

site_title: Birdman takes lead as Oscar favourite with Producers Award
summary: Birdman has taken the lead in the Oscar best picture race after winning the Producers Guild of America award for outstanding producer of a motion picture. The film, directed by Alejandro Inarritu and starring Michael Keaton, beat out other notable films including Boyhood and The Grand Budapest Hotel. This win has a history of predicting the Academy Award for best picture, with PGA winners going on to win the Oscar for the past seven years. Birdman now ties with The Grand Budapest Hotel for the most Oscar nominations with nine each.

site_title: E-cigarettes in checked airline bags a fire danger, warns FAA
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has issued a voluntary safety alert warning airlines about the fire risk from e-cigarettes in checked luggage. Two recent incidents, including a fire at Boston's Logan Airport, have prompted the agency to advise against storing e-cigarettes in checked bags due to the risk of overheating and causing fires. The alert follows a similar warning from the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO).

site_title: Japan vows to 'never give up' search for IS hostages
summary: Japan has vowed to "never give up" its search for two Japanese hostages held captive by Islamic State militants after the deadline to pay their ransom expired. Freelance journalist Kenji Goto and self-employed contractor Haruna Yukawa were last seen in a video threatening to kill them if the $200 million ransom was not paid. Despite efforts to secure a channel of communication, Japan remains uncertain about the hostages' fate and is under pressure from Britain and the US not to pay the ransom.

site_title: Expedia buys Travelocity for US$280 million
summary: Expedia has acquired rival Travelocity in a US$280 million all-cash deal, merging two of the largest online travel operators. The acquisition strengthens Expedia's ability to innovate and deliver the best travel experiences, following a 2013 agreement in which Expedia powered Travelocity's US and Canadian websites. The move comes amid increased competition in the travel sector, with Expedia operating other travel sites such as Hotels.com and Carrentals.com.

site_title: Snubbed by US and Europe, Kremlin looks to Asia at Davos
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's government showcased its efforts to maintain economic ties at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, despite Western sanctions and a damaged relationship with Europe and the US. The Kremlin highlighted its pursuit of Asia, particularly China, as an alternative, with Chinese businesses flooding into Russia. However, Russian businessmen expressed concerns about the economic situation, with one describing it as "somewhere between 1993 and 1995" in terms of complexity. The conflict in Ukraine remains a major issue, with the West maintaining sanctions and calling for a peaceful resolution.

site_title: London home-value gains slow in Q4 as market cools
summary: London home values increased 14.7% in December from a year earlier, but the annualized rate slowed to 5% in Q4 due to high prices and mortgage lending restrictions. The slowdown is attributed to "mortgage affordability tests" and loan to income caps, which constrained buyer spending. UK home price growth has plateaued and will slow in 2015, according to Hometrack. Demand for UK mortgages fell the most since 2008 in the fourth quarter, as lending criteria became more stringent.

site_title: Spain economy in a virtuous circle; recovery still under threat: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has raised its growth forecast for Spain's economy to 2% for 2015, citing a "virtuous circle" of increased productivity and competitiveness. Spain's economy has emerged from a devastating crisis and is now growing faster than its neighbors. However, high unemployment and the rise of populist parties remain major threats to the recovery. The IMF warns that Spain's jobless rate of 23.7% remains too high and is contributing to the rise of parties with anti-euro or populist positions.

images.alt_text: Mr Guindos says his conservative government may raise its 2 per cent growth forecast for this year

site_title: Sorting out the science from the smoke in e-cigarette research
summary: Researchers have found that e-cigarettes may help smokers quit, with some studies showing significant reductions in cigarette consumption and no adverse effects. However, conflicts of interest and methodological issues are common due to industry funding and a lack of rigorous testing. A Cochrane Review found that e-cigs may help smokers quit, but the evidence is thin and data poor. Pharmaceutical companies, including GlaxoSmithKline, have chosen not to sponsor e-cig trials, leaving e-cig companies to fund their own research. The industry is also being scrutinized for bias, with some critics arguing that activists may have been prejudiced against e-cigarettes due to their past battles with the tobacco industry.

images.alt_text: Researchers have counted 7,764 varieties of "vape". That adds up to one of many challenges in working out how safe e-cigs are, and whether they help smokers quit.

site_title: Oil falls to lowest since March 2009 as Saudis signal continuity
summary: Oil prices fell to their lowest in almost six years, reaching a 6-year low of $45.59 a barrel, as Saudi Arabia signaled that the death of King Abdullah would not lead to a change in the country's oil strategy. The kingdom's oil minister, Ali Al-Naimi, stated that Saudi Arabia will maintain its production levels to defend its market share, and other producers would fill the gap if production were to be cut. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) has already maintained production levels at 30 million barrels a day to combat a glut in the market.

site_title: Brent closes up, US crude down after Saudi king dies
summary: Saudi Arabia's new king Salman is expected to maintain OPEC's policy of keeping oil output steady, supporting market share. Brent crude rose 27 US cents to $48.79 a barrel, while US crude fell 72 US cents to $45.59 a barrel. Reports of a partial shutdown at BP's refinery in Indiana weighed on US crude, while a recovering US housing market may indicate a bullish trend. However, a worsening supply glut and high oil inventory levels continue to concern traders.

site_title: Indonesia search team to float AirAsia fuselage
summary: Indonesian search teams have begun floating the AirAsia Flight 8501 fuselage from the Java Sea, where it crashed on December 28, killing 162 people. The operation comes after divers entered the main section of the Airbus A320-200 for the first time. The team has retrieved 69 bodies and hopes to lift the fuselage to inspect the inside and recover more bodies. The jet's black boxes were recovered last week, and investigators are analyzing them, citing abnormal climb and stall before the plane plunged into the sea.

site_title: Firms increasingly tapping digital technology to engage customers: Tata unit
summary: Digital technologies are increasingly being used by companies to engage customers, with 70% of global corporations investing in digital initiatives to stay competitive. A report by Tata Consultancy Services found that 80% of surveyed companies have plans to change their business models, products, and services to cater to the digital consumer economy. The adoption of digital technologies is widespread, but differentiation comes from companies combining these five forces (cloud, mobility, big data, social media, and artificial intelligence) to create differential competitive advantages.

images.alt_text: Mr Ramaswamy says 79 per cent of Asia-Pacific firms in the TCS survey expect to connect with their customers via mobile apps

site_title: Elon Musk's SpaceX settles lawsuit against Air Force
summary: SpaceX, a company founded by Elon Musk, has settled a lawsuit against the US Air Force after accusing the military of improperly awarding a contract to launch military satellites to United Launch Alliance. The Air Force agreed to expand competitive opportunities for launch services, allowing SpaceX to move forward with the certification process. The multibillion-dollar contract is worth 36 rockets and is part of the Pentagon's plan to spend almost $70 billion on the program by 2030.

site_title: Ford takes US$800m charge on currency woes
summary: Ford Motor Co has taken a US$800 million charge related to its Venezuelan operations due to the country's volatile currency, reducing fourth-quarter net profit by US$700 million. The move comes as companies scramble to shield their bottom lines from the bolivar's fluctuating value. Ford's 2014 full-year pre-tax profit remains unchanged at about US$6 billion. The accounting change affects Ford's Venezuelan operations but does not impact its ownership or cash balance, which stood at US$500 million at the end of 2014.

site_title: Preservative MI comes under greater scrutiny
summary: A popular mouthwash, Colgate Total Lasting White, contains the preservative methylisothiazolinone (MI), which can cause allergic reactions and skin irritations. Experts say MI is unusual in mouthwashes, and its use is increasing in other products despite concerns about its safety. The American Contact Dermatitis Society named MI its "allergen of the year" in 2013, citing a lack of awareness among patients and doctors. Companies are exploring alternatives to MI, but reformulating products can be complicated and expensive.

site_title: Ad-citing times for 'retargeter' Criteo
summary: Criteo, a retargeting firm, is expanding its business in Southeast Asia, with 17 offices globally and campaigns in over 130 countries. Managing Director Yuko Saito notes that 98% of e-commerce site visitors leave without a purchase, making retargeting effective in bringing back users. Criteo's revenue has grown 23 times in Southeast Asia since 2013, with Singapore being a significant market. The company plans to intensify its retargeting efforts by following users across devices, and expects mobile devices to make up 40% of e-commerce transactions globally by 2017.

site_title: Europe watches as Greeks choose reform path or election defiance
summary: Greek voters head to the polls on Sunday, deciding whether to stick with economic reform or challenge creditors and set a precedent for Europe. Prime Minister Antonis Samaras's New Democracy faces opposition leader Alexis Tsipras's Coalition of the Radical Left, Syriza, which seeks a debt writedown and budget constraints. European governments closely watch the outcome, with polls suggesting Tsipras's message of change resonates with voters. A high proportion of undecided voters could give Syriza a wider victory than polls suggest, sparking concerns about Greece's bailout and potential euro area expulsion.

site_title: Bank of England's Carney says will look beyond oil price drop
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney played down the risk of deflation in Britain, saying it's best to look beyond falling oil prices. With British wages growing, Carney stated that the BoE will still need to gradually increase interest rates over the next three years to prevent inflation from overshooting its 2% target. Oil prices have halved since mid-last year, pushing British inflation to a 14-year low of 0.5%.

site_title: Top investors put pressure on Standard Chartered boss to resign: report
summary: Standard Chartered's two largest investors, Temasek and Aberdeen Asset Management, have urged the bank's chairman, John Peace, to find a replacement for CEO Peter Sands within months. Sands, who has been CEO since 2006, is under pressure due to falling profits and costs. The investors have made it known that Sands must leave by the end of the year, and if Peace does not act, they would ask him to step down. The bank has recently announced a 16% decline in third-quarter profits and plans to axe 4,000 jobs.

site_title: US seeks reversal of landmark insider trading ruling
summary: US federal prosecutors have asked a US appeals court to reconsider a landmark ruling that limited their ability to pursue insider trading cases, potentially jeopardizing several convictions. The ruling, made by the 2nd US Circuit Court of Appeals, requires prosecutors to prove that a trader knew a source of a tip received a benefit in exchange for the information. The decision has resulted in the reversal of two insider trading convictions and has sparked concerns about the effective enforcement of securities laws. Prosecutors have asked for a rehearing, citing the decision's potential to limit their ability to pursue cases.

site_title: Ukip member defects to Cameron's Conservative Party
summary: UKIP member Amjad Bashir, a senior MEP, defected to the Conservative Party, leaving the anti-EU UKIP party reeling. UKIP responded by suspending Bashir for "extremely serious" offenses. This move comes after UKIP was previously dismissed by David Cameron as "fruitcakes, loonies and closet racists" in 2006. Bashir's defection marks a significant blow to UKIP's credibility, highlighting internal divisions within the party.

site_title: Brazil scientists find coffee protein with painkilling effect
summary: Brazilian scientists at the state University of Brasilia and Embrapa discovered a protein in coffee with effects similar to pain reliever morphine. The protein, with "analgesic and mildly tranquillising" qualities, was found to have a longer-lasting effect on laboratory mice than morphine. This discovery has "biotechnological potential" for the health foods industry and could help alleviate stress in animals bound for slaughterhouses.

images.alt_text: In 2004, Embrapa managed to sequence coffee's functional genome, a major step towards efforts to combine coffee genes with a view to improving grain quality.

site_title: Australia and China open skies in landmark air agreement
summary: Australia and China have signed a landmark air agreement, allowing for increased flights between the two countries. The pact, which follows a historic free trade agreement, lets carriers add 4,000 seats weekly to current caps between major cities, with an additional 7,000 seats phased in over two years. This move aims to capitalize on China's growing tourism market and emerging economy, with 200 million Chinese travelers expected by 2020. The agreement also paves the way for new routes and expanded traffic rights by October 2016.

site_title: German economy starts 2015 with pick-up exceeding forecasts
summary: Germany's economy started 2015 with a stronger-than-forecast pick-up, with a manufacturing and services Purchasing Managers Index advancing to 52.6. Employment increased, and services led the growth, while manufacturing slipped. The improvement suggests Germany's private sector began the year positively, but output growth remained below levels seen at the beginning of last year.

site_title: Critics pounce on Obama's plan to cut the tax benefits of 529 college savings plans
summary: President Barack Obama proposed cutting tax benefits for 529 college savings plans, allowing families to withdraw tax-free funds for college expenses. Critics argue this will discourage families from saving, particularly middle-class Americans, and drive them to take on more debt. The plan aims to redirect $50 billion in tax credits to middle-class families. Supporters of 529 plans claim the administration distorts the reality of who invests in these plans, stating that 70% of account holders earn less than $150,000. The proposal could shape future higher education policy and affect financial aid for students.

site_title: ECB stimulus spurs best week for emerging stocks in 10 months
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) stimulus plan has boosted emerging markets, with the MSCI Emerging Markets Index rising 0.8% to a 3.5% weekly gain, its best in 10 months. Russian shares jumped 7% after Saudi King Abdullah's death, while Brent crude rose 0.6% due to the succession plans being expected to be smooth. Stocks from Taiwan to Hong Kong also climbed, with technology shares leading gains, as investors reacted to the ECB's plan to buy €60 billion of bonds a month through September 2016.

site_title: Yingluck banned from politics, faces criminal charges
summary: Thai authorities banned ousted Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra from politics for five years and initiated criminal charges for negligence related to a rice-buying plan, which could result in up to 10 years in jail. The charges stem from a scheme that paid farmers above market prices for rice, costing Thailand billions of dollars. The move follows a separate impeachment case at the National Legislative Assembly, where Yingluck was voted guilty and faces a five-year ban from politics.

site_title: Japan condemns apparent IS execution, demands hostage release
summary: Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe condemned the apparent execution of Japanese journalist Haruna Yukawa by Islamic State, calling for the immediate release of fellow captive Kenji Goto. A video surfaced claiming Yukawa's death, and the US confirmed his killing, but Japan has not confirmed the authenticity of the recording. Abe demands Goto's release, saying Japan will use all diplomatic channels to secure his freedom. The US and Japan condemn the brutal murder, with the US calling it an "outrageous and unacceptable act of violence."

site_title: Starbucks' choice of Johnson underscores its tech evolution
summary: Starbucks has named Kevin R. Johnson, former CEO of Juniper Network, as its new Chief Operating Officer, effective March 1. The move reflects the company's increasing reliance on technology and mobile payments, with 16% of US store transactions now coming from mobile devices. Johnson brings deep technology and supply-chain expertise to the role, and his appointment was seen as a strategic move to drive future growth. The company's shares rose 6.6% following the announcement, driven by strong quarterly results and Johnson's addition.

site_title: New Saudi king seeks to reassure on succession and policy
summary: Saudi King Salman has taken the throne after the sudden death of King Abdullah, pledging continuity in energy and foreign policies. Salman has appointed his nephew Mohammed bin Nayef, 55, as Deputy Crown Prince, and his youngest half-brother Muqrin, 69, as Crown Prince, effectively settling the succession. The move aims to quell speculation about palace rifts amid regional turmoil and a plunge in oil prices. Salman has vowed to maintain the same approach to ruling as his predecessors, calling for unity among Arab states, and has appointed his own son, Mohammed bin Salman, as Defence Minister and head of the royal court.

site_title: Microsoft's HoloLens hits all the right spots with holograms
summary: Microsoft's HoloLens goggles have received positive reviews for their augmented reality holograms, praised as "magical" and "unbelievable". The technology differs from Oculus Rift and Google Glass, offering a unique immersive experience. The glasses, unveiled to the press last week, have hit a sweet spot between these headsets, with users describing them as a step in a different direction. This marks a rare instance of praise for a Microsoft creation, highlighting the potential of HoloLens in the world of augmented reality.

site_title: Ex-analyst basks in Xiaomi's glow
summary: Ex-analyst Richard Ji, a former Morgan Stanley technology industry analyst, is basking in the success of Xiaomi Inc after his fund invested in the company's $1.1 billion fundraising. Ji co-founded All-Stars Investment Ltd in Hong Kong last April, where he spotted Xiaomi as a "category killer" startup with disruptive potential. His fund was the largest investor in Xiaomi's recent funding round.

images.alt_text: NUMBERS MAN: Mr Ji's fund was the biggest investor in leading Xiaomi's US$1.1 billion fundraising last month

site_title: Gold gains favour as oil tumbles
summary: Gold prices are surging as oil tumbles, with gold futures climbing 9.9% in January, the best start since 1974. Investors are seeking a hedge against deflation and currency volatility, driven by low oil prices and potential economic instability. The World Bank has cut its 2015 global growth forecast, and central banks are increasing stimulus measures, boosting gold's appeal. Analysts predict gold will rise to $1,420 by the end of 2016, while some forecast a decline to $1,000 by December.

site_title: Oil jumps as Saudi king's death feeds market uncertainty
summary: Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah died, prompting a rise in oil prices as investors sought uncertainty. The new king, Salman, vowed to maintain existing energy and foreign policies, reassuring markets. Oil prices rose to $49.80 a barrel, with Brent crude easing to $49.25. The US shale boom and rising oil inventories have driven price volatility. King Salman's reign may help stabilize oil markets, but Saudi Arabia faces long-term domestic challenges and regional turmoil.

site_title: Gold falls to pare three-week rally as Goldman cuts forecasts
summary: Gold futures fell 0.6% to $1,292.60 after Goldman Sachs cut forecasts, citing low inflation and higher US interest rates, which will drag down prices in 2015. The bank now expects gold to average $1,089 an ounce in 2016 and $1,050 in 2017, down from previous forecasts of $1,200. The decline in gold prices eroded its appeal as an alternative asset, following a 9.2% gain in January as stagnant economies challenged policymakers to find new ways to boost growth.

site_title: Prices of private homes down 4% in 2014
summary: Singapore's private home prices declined 4% in 2014, marking the first annual fall since the global financial crisis in 2008. Landed homes fell 5.3%, while non-landed private homes slipped 3.5%. The decline is attributed to government-engineered cooling measures, including strict financing curbs. Consultants expect a further 5-8% drop in prices this year, with Knight Frank projecting a 4-6% decrease. The market is also facing challenges from rising interest rates, increased new home completions, and a weak leasing market.

site_title: Whisky and bourbon to bring cheer to global spirits market
summary: Whisky and bourbon are expected to drive the global spirits market, with consumption rising 8.8% and 19.3% respectively by end-2018, surpassing other types of alcohol. White spirits, such as vodka, will see a slower expansion of 0.5%. Global wine consumption is forecast to grow 3.7% by 2018, with the US leading the growth, surpassing France, the world's top wine producer.

site_title: More, new space planned for startups
summary: Singapore is planning to expand its LaunchPad for startups with the construction of a second facility, Second LaunchPad, and three new blocks at the existing JTC LaunchPad @ one-north. The new blocks will provide an additional 12,000 square meters of space and house 250 more startups. The expansion aims to support the growing entrepreneurial community in Singapore, which has seen a steady increase in startup activity and employment.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: New Singtel tagline sparks grammar apocalypse
summary: Singtel's new tagline "Let's make everyday better" has caused a grammatical apocalypse, altering laws of physics and sparking a chain reaction. The UN has declared a state of emergency for the English language, citing a violation of the Geneva Convention. The slogan's forcefield has warped grammar rules at a molecular level, causing widespread chaos, including malapropisms, dangling participles, and subjects and verbs in disagreement. The rebranding exercise has thrown international bodies into upheaval, with many questioning the telco's intentions.

images.alt_text: BLINDSIDED: 'We are forced to declare the slogan as an act of aggression against the English language,' says the UN's director-general of Lingual Peacekeeping

site_title: Worldwide bond market rally sputters after ECB boosts stimulus
summary: The worldwide bond market rally has slowed due to the European Central Bank's (ECB) efforts to strengthen the economy. The ECB announced an asset-purchase program worth €1.1 trillion, boosting bond prices and yields. The US 10-year yield remained unchanged at 1.85%, while Japan's 10-year yield dropped to 0.25%. European bonds rallied, with German 10-year yields headed for a seventh weekly decline. The ECB's decision is expected to benefit Treasuries, supported by higher US yields and a strong dollar.

site_title: Chan Chun Sing joins NTUC, expected to take role as labour chief
summary: Chan Chun Sing, Singapore's Minister for Social and Family Development, has joined the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) as a part-time member, expected to become the next labour chief within a year. He was formally introduced by NTUC Secretary-General Lim Swee Say and will be appointed a deputy secretary-general. Chan, who will leave his current role in April, aims to understand workers' concerns and issues through meetings with union leaders, following a request by the NTUC's central committee to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong for a succession plan.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
WE-FIE! Mr Chan (centre among those in green shirts) with members of the labour movement yesterday.

site_title: December existing home sales rise amid higher prices
summary: US existing home sales rose 2.4% in December to a 5.04 million annual rate, exceeding expectations, despite higher prices limiting sales to first-time buyers. Home prices increased, while inventories fell.

site_title: US: Stocks retreat as earnings results offset ECB stimulus plan
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, trimming the first weekly gain of 2015, as weaker-than-forecast earnings results from companies like United Parcel Service (UPS), Bank of New York Mellon, and Kimberly-Clark offset confidence in the European Central Bank's (ECB) stimulus plan. The Standard & Poor's 500 index lost 0.6% to 2,051.82, while the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 141.38 points, or 0.8%, to 17,672.60. The Stoxx Europe 600 index rallied 1.7% after the ECB expanded its stimulus plan, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 0.2%.

site_title: DreamWorks to cut movie production, fire 500 staff
summary: DreamWorks Animation plans to cut its movie production and lay off 500 employees, approximately 19% of its staff, due to box-office misfires and failed merger attempts. The studio will reduce its annual film releases from three to one, with a goal of releasing two films per year starting next year. The moves aim to ensure "consistent and profitable delivery" of films.

site_title: CapitaMall shares rise to 1 1/2-year high
summary: CapitaMall Trust, Singapore's largest listed mall owner, reported steady results and its trading counter rose to a 1 1/2-year high of S$2.25 a unit. Despite warning of headwinds in Europe and China, CEO Wilson Tan sees SG50 celebrations as a counter to external economy. The Reit's results are a positive note amidst global economic concerns.

site_title: Microsoft agrees to buy revolution analytics to boost cloud
summary: Microsoft has agreed to buy Revolution Analytics, a startup that makes tools to analyze large pools of data, to boost its cloud services business. The deal, terms of which were not disclosed, aims to help Microsoft compete with companies like Google and Amazon in cloud computing. Revolution Analytics' R programming language, used by statisticians and scientists, will be integrated into Microsoft products, including Azure. The acquisition is driven by the growing need for data analysis software to handle increasing volumes of data.

images.alt_text: Microsoft agreed to buy startup Revolution Analytics, which makes tools to sift through data, to help the company build up its cloud-services business.

site_title: Spoilt for choice in Kallang
summary: Aperia, a mixed-use development in Singapore, has opened with a variety of eateries and F&B outlets, including 24-hour Tim Ho Wan, Juang Dong Ji steamboat restaurant, and Olivo with low-salt menu options. Other new additions include Nature Cafe, a vegetarian restaurant, Banh Mi Baguette & Pho, a fast food joint serving Vietnamese dishes, and HAHA Sushi, which prides itself on using fresh, imported fish. The development aims to cater to the office crowd and residents in the Kallang and Boon Keng areas.

site_title: Greek reforms in balance as voters ponder left-wing turn
summary: Greece is set to hold a general election on Sunday that could potentially sweep the left-wing Syriza party to power, leading to a possible exit from the eurozone. Syriza, which has a steady lead in opinion polls, wants to redraft the EU-IMF bailout and erase over 50% of Greece's debt, diverting funds for economic recovery instead. The party's leader Alexis Tsipras has vowed to negotiate with creditors, but EU officials have expressed concerns about the consequences of such a move, which could lead to economic instability and a potential repeat ballot.

site_title: Bankers see QE plan squeezing profitability
summary: The European Central Bank's quantitative easing plan, aiming to buy at least 1.1 trillion euros, may squeeze bank profitability, particularly deposit-taking and flow-franchise businesses, as the spread between funding costs and loan interest rates narrows. Bankers acknowledge the plan's need to revitalize the euro area and head off deflation, but also express concerns about the impact on their business. Despite this, European stocks rose for a seventh day amid optimism over the plan's potential to spur economic growth.

site_title: Audi powerhouse
summary: The Audi S8 has received a major update with a cleaner twin-turbo V8 engine, improved fuel economy, and enhanced features. The 4.0-litre V8 engine now achieves 9.6 litres per km, a 5.9% decrease, and emits 5.1% lower emissions. The engine remains unchanged in terms of power and torque, but the transmission and all-wheel-drive system have been refined. The S8's agility and responsiveness have also been improved, thanks to the sport differential and exclusive wheelbase. The updated model starts at S$120,000 and is available exclusively in the S8 trim.

site_title: Keppel Corp moves to take KepLand private
summary: Keppel Corp has launched a two-tier offer to take its subsidiary Keppel Land private, valuing the real estate company at S$6.8 billion. The base offer price is S$4.38 per share, with a potential raise to S$4.60 per share if acceptance levels exceed 90%. Analysts see the move as positive for Keppel Land shareholders but less clear-cut for Keppel Corp investors, who are questioning the motivation behind the acquisition. The deal aims to allocate capital more efficiently and achieve better risk-adjusted returns, but some analysts worry about a potential dilution of Keppel Corp's exposure to the rig-building business.

site_title: Restoring trust in the financial sector
summary: The global financial industry continues to grapple with issues of ethics and culture six years after the 2008 Global Financial Crisis. Despite regulatory efforts to tighten governance standards and curb excessive risk-taking, cases of misconduct, including financial malfeasance, mis-selling, and dishonesty, persist. Weaknesses in governance, risk management, and operational controls are cited as contributing factors, but deeper issues of trust, ethics, and culture must be addressed. To build a culture of trust and strong values, regulators, the industry, and firms must work together, with a focus on getting the culture right through shared values, attitudes, and norms that guide actions.

images.alt_text: UPHOLDING STANDARDS: MAS takes an intensive supervisory approach to risk governance and culture in financial institutions.

site_title: Box hits Wall Street with a bang after IPO
summary: Cloud storage startup Box made a successful Wall Street debut, with its shares jumping 66% to close at $23.23 after an initial public offering (IPO) raising $175 million. The company now has a market value of $2.7 billion and 32 million users, including 275,000 companies. Box plans to use at least half of the capital for sales and marketing and developing new products, but has not ruled out acquisitions. Despite its growing losses, investors appear unconcerned, and the company must compete against big players like Microsoft and Amazon.com in the cloud storage market.

images.alt_text: Cloud storage startup Box soared in its Wall Street debut Friday after a public share offering, pushing its market value to US$2.7 billion.

site_title: Cagamas eyes new investors for its first non-ringgit sukuk in 2015
summary: Malaysia's state-backed mortgage lender, Cagamas Bhd, plans to target new investors in the Middle East and Europe for its first foreign-currency sukuk in 2015. The company aims to diversify its investors and engage with sovereign wealth funds. Despite lower oil and gas revenues, Cagamas' fundamentals remain strong, and the company seeks to promote home ownership through its issuance of bonds and sukuk. The move is seen as a step towards setting price benchmarks for local bond issuers in emerging markets.

site_title: Out with golf range, in with hip new hangout
summary: Parkland Green, a four-hectare hangout area in East Coast Park, Singapore, has opened with 11 tenants, including casual dining joints, a convenience store, and sports-centric outlets. The space offers a lawn for picnics and children to play. F&B outlets, such as Pick Me Up Cafe and Patro's Sports Bar & Restaurant, offer a range of cuisines, including healthy options and sports-themed food. Full Pint Microbrewery and Atmosphere Bistro round out the offerings. The area is popular, especially on weekends, and is managed by the National Parks Board to better serve park visitors.

site_title: Ford setting up research & innovation hub in Silicon Valley
summary: Ford Motor Co. is establishing a research and innovation hub in Silicon Valley, employing 125 people by the end of the year. The center, located in Palo Alto, will be dedicated to automotive research and marks Ford's presence in Northern California's innovative culture. CEO Mark Fields emphasized the need for Ford to be part of the technology industry to stay competitive.

images.alt_text: MR FIELDS: 'As we think about coming here to Silicon Valley, we want to be viewed as part of the ecosystem here.'

site_title: New foodie hotspots
summary: Singapore's Punggol Settlement, a two-storey building with 12 F&B outlets, has become a popular destination for foodies. Since its opening last year, the development has attracted big crowds, especially on weekends, with its good mix of different cuisines and sea views. Notable eateries include Ponggol Seafood, White Restaurant, and Horizon Bistronomy, offering seafood, Chinese, and French fusion cuisine. The settlement's success is attributed to its convenient location and ample parking space, making it an ideal spot for diners and food enthusiasts.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: MAS to step up oversight of financial sector compensation
summary: MAS managing director Ravi Menon announced plans to step up oversight of financial sector compensation and risk practices in Singapore, urging the industry to build a culture of responsibility and ethics to regain public trust. MAS will conduct more detailed supervision of firms' compensation and risk practices, while also encouraging the industry to hold firms accountable to standards on behavior and conduct regular surveys to detect blind spots.

site_title: STI up as ECB stimulus rubs off on region
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.2% to 3,411.5 on Friday, driven by the European Central Bank's larger-than-expected bond-buying stimulus programme, which sparked a rally in regional markets. US stocks, Japan's Nikkei 225, Hong Kong's Hang Seng, and South Korea's Kospi also increased. The STI gained 110.8 points or 3.4% for the week, its best performance so far this year. Gainers led by Jardine stocks, property, and banking stocks drove the gains, with Ascott Residence Trust and CapitaLand rising 4% and 3.4% respectively.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Encourage people to save more with a voluntary CPF scheme
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) is calling for a boost in Central Provident Fund (CPF) rates and flexibility in withdrawals, citing challenges such as rising property prices, low interest rates, and an ageing population. A proposed voluntary CPF scheme would offer one percent more interest on the first $120,000 of savings, aiming to encourage more people to save for retirement and personal needs. The NTUC suggests that a voluntary scheme could help address financial security concerns for the younger generation, particularly the lower-income bracket.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust Q1 DPU up 10%
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust reported a 10% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.75 Singapore cents for its Q1, driven by the addition of Changi City Point and higher contribution from Causeway Point. Gross revenue rose 18.3% to S$47.2 million, and net property income increased 16.2% to a record S$32.9 million. The trust's gearing level remained low at 29.3%. The declared DPU will be paid out on Feb 27, with FCT expecting "sustainable" performance.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: China factory activity shrinks again in Jan
summary: China's manufacturing growth stalled for the second month in January, with the HSBC/Markit Flash Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 49.8. This is below the 50-point mark separating contraction from growth. The slowdown adds to concerns about growing deflationary pressures in the economy.

images.alt_text: SLOWING DOWN: The HSBC/ Markit Flash Manufacturing PMI hovered at 49.8 in January, slightly up from December's 49.6.

site_title: Fuel cost savings at US carriers to hit billions
summary: US airlines forecast enormous fuel savings of billions in 2015 due to a 57% drop in global oil prices. Southwest Airlines estimates a $1.7 billion savings, while Delta Air Lines and United Airlines predict similar cost reductions. The carriers plan to use fuel savings to pay down debt and return cash to shareholders, with no indication of passing savings on to customers. Industry consolidation has reduced competitive pressures, allowing airlines to avoid fare discounts. Share prices rose across the industry, with Southwest's stock surging over 8%.

site_title: ECB pump unlikely to move US
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) decision to stimulate growth in the eurozone is unlikely to have a significant impact on the US economy, as the stronger euro will undercut the competitiveness of US exports. However, the move is welcome news for US investors and tourists, as it may lead to increased demand for American products and cheaper travel to Europe. The added liquidity in global markets is expected to benefit US stocks, with many analysts predicting a rally in the coming months.

site_title: BOJ may need to consider fresh options
summary: Japan's Bank of Japan (BOJ) may need to consider fresh options to address deflation risks if further stimulus is needed, according to Governor Haruhiko Kuroda. Kuroda stated that the central bank has no shortage of tools to address deflation and can adjust monetary policy if necessary. Despite the BOJ's unprecedented asset-purchase program, inflation remains below the 2% target, and policymakers are concerned about the slowdown in inflation in coming months. Kuroda expressed confidence in the success of his strategy, but acknowledged the need for adjustments to achieve the inflation target.

site_title: Jokowi calls for calm after arrest of country's top graft buster
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged calm after the arrest of Bambang Widjojanto, deputy chief of the Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK), amid allegations of interfering in a legal case. Hundreds of activists protested outside the KPK headquarters, calling for the president to speak out. Widjojanto faces seven years in prison if found guilty. The arrest comes after a high-ranking police general was accused of corruption, leading to the postponement of his appointment as police chief. The president urged both parties to act objectively, avoiding "friction" in their duties.

site_title: Village revival
summary: Changi Village, a former fishing village, is experiencing a transformation with the influx of modern eateries and trendy cafes. The area, known for its nasi lemak, has seen a surge in new establishments, including Chock Full of Beans, The Finest Tea Shop, Queen's Garden, and Bunny & Pony. The opening of these cafes has drawn foot traffic and attracted a new crowd, with some owners expressing concerns that the area may lose its rustic charm. Despite this, many are embracing the change, with some owners welcoming the increased business and others seeing the potential for the area to become a popular destination.

site_title: Commodity prices set to slide: World Bank
summary: The World Bank forecasts that commodity prices, including oil, precious metals, and food commodities, will decline across the board in 2015 due to a "perfect storm" in oil markets and weakening global economic activity. Oil prices are expected to average US$53 a barrel, 45% lower than last year, while precious metals prices are predicted to decline by 3%. The decline is attributed to factors such as growth in unconventional oil production, decline in demand, and appreciation of the US dollar.

site_title: Prices of Q4 resale HDB flats down 1.5%, volume up 2.7%
summary: Resale prices of Housing & Development Board (HDB) flats in Singapore fell 1.5% in Q4 2014, down 6% for the year, due to tighter Mortgage Servicing Ratio requirements and reduced maximum loan terms. Resale transactions rose 2.7% to 4,635 cases in Q4, but the full-year volume fell 4.3% to 17,318. Experts predict a slight recovery in resale transactions in 2015, but prices may fall by up to 4% in the first six months.

site_title: The strong draw of property
summary: Keppel Land, a Singapore-based property developer, attributes benefits to its China, Vietnam, and Indonesia portfolios due to external factors. At its postponed results briefing, the company cited favorable conditions, including government support, growing demand, and infrastructure development. This is expected to positively impact its properties in these markets.

site_title: Keppel adding more bricks to rigs
summary: Keppel, a Singaporean conglomerate, made a massive S$500 million takeover bid for Straits Steamship in 1983, aiming to diversify and achieve long-term growth. However, the acquisition proved costly, with a high debt burden and declining business performance, ultimately leading to a turnaround that included asset writedowns and layoffs. This failure led to a significant change in the company's name to Keppel Corp, with a renewed focus on long-term stability.

site_title: New year, new wardrobe
summary: Style specialists at Shopthemag advise incorporating traditional elements into modern outfits through accessories. The online boutique is launching a series of chinois-meets-rock-chick necklaces and brooches, blending traditional and modern styles. These accessories can add a touch of tradition to a dress without looking dated.

site_title: Architectural delight
summary: Park + Associates, a Singapore-based architecture firm, found success in theme park design after working on Universal Studios Singapore in 2008. The firm, founded by Lim Koon Park, initially produced shop drawings for 18 attractions but eventually developed its expertise in theme park design, leading to jobs at Shanghai Disneyland and other projects. Park + Associates' design philosophy is centered on creating a delightful experience, drawing inspiration from sensory experiences rather than visual ones. The firm's own office, renovated from a former school library, is a testament to this approach, featuring high ceilings and barrel vaults.

site_title: Lowdown on high blood pressure
summary: A recent guideline from the Eighth Joint National Committee (JNC 8) recommends that adults with high blood pressure aim for a blood pressure reading of less than 150/90 mm Hg, particularly for those over 60 years old. For those under 60, the target is less than 140/90 mm Hg. Lowering blood pressure can reduce the risk of stroke and heart disease, but excessively low blood pressure can have negative effects. The choice of medication also matters, with four classes of drugs recommended as initial choices: thiazide-type diuretics, calcium channel blockers, angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors, and angiotensin receptor blockers.

site_title: Divers reach AirAsia plane fuselage
summary: Indonesian divers have reached the fuselage of the AirAsia plane that crashed on December 28, 2014, with 162 people on board. Four more bodies were recovered near the wreckage, bringing the total to 63. The divers encountered difficulties accessing the main body of the Airbus A320-200 due to debris and cables. Officials hope most victims are inside the fuselage and plan further assessments to determine how to retrieve the bodies. The jet's black boxes were recovered earlier, and investigators are analyzing them, citing an abnormal climb before stalling and crashing into the Java Sea.

site_title: How China's 'new normal' affects investors
summary: China's "new normal" of slower growth, driven by domestic demand, has significant implications for investors. The country's reliance on credit-fueled investment is being replaced, leading to a shift away from export-driven growth and foreign investment. Foreign direct investment into China slowed to 1.7% growth last year, while outward investment surged 14.1%. Rising wages erode competitiveness, prompting manufacturers to shift production to other low-cost countries. China's exports and imports are growing slower, and its processing trade is declining. The "triple transition" aims to reduce credit-driven investment, promote market forces, and address excess capacity, but the risk of below-trend growth and debt defaults remains.

site_title: Classy chinoiserie
summary: Chinese New Year decorating trends focus on modern, understated touches, rather than kitschy embellishments. Experts suggest incorporating contemporary pieces with traditional elements, such as bamboo and copper, and using auspicious colors like gold and red subtly throughout the space. For a classy look, serve traditional Chinese dishes with simple, rustic plating and add decorative elements like bamboo, bonsai plants, and personalized pieces. Key design trends include minimalism, geometric shapes, and interchangeable furniture pieces, allowing for flexibility and adaptability throughout the year.

site_title: Germany's Schaeuble says to use "all room for manoeuvre" on investments
summary: Germany's Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble announced that the country will utilize all available room in its budget to boost public investments. He stated that Germany will increase its investment rate in the coming years. This decision aims to utilize fiscal policy to achieve the goal.

site_title: Shoe chain Office nears £300m London listing: sources
summary: British shoe chain Office is set to list its shares in London, potentially valuing the company at around £300 million. The private equity-backed retailer, which operates 153 sites in the UK and Ireland, has selected JPMorgan Chase & Co and Jefferies Group to lead its listing. This follows Jimmy Choo's successful IPO in October, which valued the company at £546 million. The listing is expected to take place in the coming months, pending market conditions, and will join other fashion brands listed on the London Stock Exchange.

site_title: Inflation hit poorest households most in H2 2014
summary: Inflation hit Singapore's poorest households most in the second half of 2014, with their consumer prices rising 1% due to higher food prices. The bottom 20% of households, which spend a larger share on food, felt the effects most. In contrast, the middle 60% and richest 20% saw inflation rise 0.6% and remain unchanged, respectively. The moderation in car prices and lower energy costs partially offset the increases in food, education, and healthcare costs.

site_title: Draghi's last throw of the dice
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has launched a massive quantitative easing (QE) program, purchasing €60 billion of eurozone bonds per month until at least September 2016. The 1.1 trillion euro program aims to stimulate inflation and economic growth, but its effectiveness is uncertain due to factors such as late entry into the QE market, limited impact on corporate lending, and ongoing deflation. ECB President Mario Draghi has emphasized the need for structural reforms and investment to complement monetary policy, and the program's impact on inflation and risk sharing between countries remains to be seen.

site_title: Business briefing
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has received approval from the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) as a registered Foreign Board of Trade (FBOT), providing legal certainty to US customers with direct access to SGX's derivatives offerings. K1 Ventures posted a net profit of S$30.96 million for the second quarter, up 81% from the previous year. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue below target and operating loss similar to the first half.

site_title: Global bank watchdog to review rule on zero-risk weighting for sovereign debt
summary: Global banking supervisors are reviewing a rule allowing banks to hold little or no capital against sovereign debt, a move criticized during the eurozone debt crisis. The "zero-risk weighting" rule, set by the Basel Committee, was criticized for allowing banks to hold low capital against debt that sank to junk status in some cases. The review aims to assess the impact of the rule and consider policy options to address concerns about a two-tier debt market emerging. The review is part of Basel's work program to assess the combined impact of its new rules since the financial crisis.

site_title: S'pore prices dip again on base effects
summary: Singapore's headline inflation stayed in negative territory in December, edging up to -0.2% from November's -0.3%. Economists expect this 'disinflation' to continue, citing the impact of high oil prices in 2014 and lower energy costs. Despite the fall in consumer prices, core inflation remained stable at 1.5%, driven by sticky food and services inflation. Experts predict MAS will maintain its current policy stance, with a few economists speculating a possible easing of exchange-rate policy in April.

images.alt_text: Just as economists expected, Singapore's headline inflation stayed in negative territory in December, edging up slightly to -0.2 per cent from November's -0.3 per cent.

site_title: Russia faces US$40b battle to stave off banking crisis
summary: Russia may need to spend over $40 billion this year to prevent a banking crisis, as a growing recession threatens the sector. Russian banks face deteriorating loan quality, increased risk management costs, and rising funding costs, with analysts predicting a contraction in the number of banks and a potential wave of insolvencies. The government has pledged support of $19 billion, but experts say this is insufficient, and additional capital injections could further strain the country's international reserves and budget.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat on soft earnings
summary: US stocks opened flat on Friday, despite a four-session winning streak, due to weak corporate earnings. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.07%, the S&P 500 lost 0.06%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.06%. This follows a previous record close for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq. The market remains uncertain amid tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Masking the face of masculinity with peel
summary: Men are increasingly opting for facial peels to address various skin problems, such as ingrown hairs, brown spots, and fine lines. Dermatologists and skin-care professionals report a rise in male clients seeking peels due to their fast results and non-invasive nature. Men tend to prefer gentler peels, like glycolic acid, and are attracted to products that offer a "quick fix" and painless treatment. The trend is also seen as a gateway to other cosmetic procedures, with men often seeking skin tightening treatments after experiencing positive results from peels.

site_title: Loans to Chinese property developers up 23% in 2014
summary: Chinese banks increased lending to property developers by 23% in 2014, with developers taking 5.63 trillion yuan (US$904 billion) in loans, up 22.6% from the previous year. This move is seen as policy support by the government to boost the housing market, which accounts for 15% of China's economy. Despite a slowdown in mortgage lending to home buyers, the expansion in overall real estate loans suggests the government's efforts to support the sector.

site_title: Swiss watch industry in shock
summary: The Swiss watch industry is reeling from the sudden scrapping of the franc's currency cap by the country's central bank, causing the Swiss franc to surge 30% and making exports such as watches more expensive. This has led to concerns over reduced sales and profits, with the sector already facing challenges from slowed sales in China and Russia, and increased competition from smartwatches. Swiss companies, including Swatch Group and Richemont, have seen their shares plummet, and some smaller watchmakers are struggling to survive. Industry executives predict a 3-5% price increase to offset falling margins, but the impact of the currency upheaval remains uncertain.

site_title: Eurozone economy picks up in January but growth still weak
summary: The Eurozone economy showed a modest pick-up in January, with business activity rising to a five-month high, according to a key survey. The Composite Purchasing Managers Output Index (PMI) reached 52.2 points, up from 51.4 in December. While this is a positive start to 2015, growth remains weak, and analysts warn of the risk of deflation, which could tip the economy back into recession. The European Central Bank announced a 1 trillion euro economic stimulus package to support growth.

site_title: Hutchison to buy Telefonica unit O2 for £10.25b
summary: Hutchison Whampoa Ltd, owned by Asia's richest man Li Ka-shing, has agreed to buy Telefonica's British mobile unit O2 for up to £10.25 billion, making it the top mobile operator in the country. The acquisition will be Hutchison's biggest ever takeover and revamp its European telecoms business. The deal will strengthen Hutchison's position in the UK market, where it already operates the Three Mobile network.

images.alt_text: CONSOLIDATION: The proposed O2 deal comes just two weeks after Hong Kong tycoon Mr Li undertook a major overhaul of his businesses, which will be split into two listed companies.

site_title: Apple's CEO gets US$9.22m in pay as stock price surges
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook received a compensation package valued at US$9.22 million in 2014, more than double his pay in 2013. The surge in stock price, which reached a record high of US$119.75 in November, contributed to the increase. Cook's package includes a salary of US$1.75 million and non-equity incentive compensation of US$6.7 million. The company's market capitalization surpassed US$700 billion, a milestone reached by no other US company.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ascott Residence Trust (ART) reported Q4 2014 distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.16 Singapore cents, a 13% increase on a normalised basis. The trust plans to refurbish its Makati property, potentially boosting average daily rental rates (ADR) in the medium term, but may face near-term occupancy challenges. Meanwhile, Suntec Reit's office segment outperformed its retail segment, with a 100% committed occupancy rate and average rental rates of S$8.92 psf pm. This led the broker to lower its FY2015 DPU forecast for Suntec Reit by 5.9%.

site_title: US crude falls to weekly low following refinery disruption
summary: US crude oil fell to $45.35, its lowest since the middle of last week, after a refinery unit at BP's Whiting, Indiana, refinery was shut down. The 413,500 barrel-per-day distillation unit halted production on Thursday night, contributing to the price drop. Global Brent crude rose 30 cents to $48.81. The refinery shutdown led to a decrease in US crude oil prices, with a 49-cent drop to $45.83.

site_title: Sliding oil prices raise Malaysia's default risk
summary: Malaysia's default risk is on the rise, with the cost of protecting sovereign debt against non-payment increasing 21.5 basis points to 127.5. The country's Prime Minister Najib Razak has widened the fiscal deficit target to 3.2% and cut the growth forecast to 4.5%, citing the impact of oil prices falling below $50 a barrel. The government's reliance on oil and the potential for a current-account deficit are concerns, with Fitch Ratings predicting a possible downgrade of Malaysia's A-grade rating.

images.alt_text: RELIANCE ON OIL: The government derived 29 per cent of its RM225 billion revenue in 2014 from crude, including a RM29 billion dividend from state energy company Petroliam Nasional Bhd, or Petronas.

site_title: US factory activity expands at lower rate, new orders weigh
summary: The US manufacturing sector expanded in January, but at a slower pace, matching the lowest reading in a year. The Markit US Manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index fell to 53.7, beating economists' expectations of 54.0. This marks the first time the index has fallen below 54 since January 2014, when severe weather impacted economic activity. The expansion, while slower, still signals a positive trend in the sector.

site_title: US economic activity gauge points to near-term strength
summary: US economic activity gauge increased 0.5% in December, indicating near-term economic strength. This surpasses forecast of a 0.4% rise. The Leading Economic Index, released by the Conference Board, showed a majority of its components rose, suggesting a solid expansionary path for the US economy. Employment and income gains are helping to maintain momentum despite industrial production weakness.

site_title: Boss of UK hedge fund Weavering jailed for 13 years for fraud
summary: The boss of UK hedge fund Weavering, Magnus Peterson, was sentenced to 13 years in jail for fraud. He was found guilty of eight counts, including fraud, forgery, and false accounting, related to a scheme that cost investors $536 million. Peterson was acquitted on seven other charges after a 12-week trial. The conviction marks a significant outcome for the Serious Fraud Office in its efforts to hold individuals accountable for financial crimes.

site_title: Funding levels fire up transatlantic bank issuance
summary: US banks are issuing euro-denominated bonds in Europe to meet future regulatory requirements, with Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan, and Citigroup selling a combined 4.8 billion euros in the first week of 2015. The low cost of funding and attractive yields in Europe have encouraged US banks to consider euro funding, with pricing for JP Morgan's dual-tranche euro deal being 20bp inside dollars. The issuance is also driven by the FSB's total loss-absorbing capital (TLAC) proposal, which could require US banks to issue debt at the holding company level to meet new requirements.

site_title: Swiss stability proves bad bet for some European homeowners
summary: A surge in the value of the Swiss franc has left thousands of European homeowners struggling with mortgage payments, with many seeing their monthly instalments increase by hundreds of euros. Over 60,000 Croatians, 500,000 in Poland, and hundreds of thousands in other Central and Eastern European countries have taken out loans denominated in Swiss francs, which have become a liability due to the currency's appreciation. Governments are investigating the lending practices of European banks and considering measures to alleviate the burden on borrowers, including forcing conversions of the loans.

site_title: Schaeuble sees euro-area 'moral hazard' risk in ECB bond-buying
summary: German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble expressed concerns that the European Central Bank's bond-buying program may create a "moral hazard" by deterring euro-region governments from implementing structural reforms. This could lead to a lack of action to restore competitiveness, as governments may believe they don't need to take responsibility for reforms. Schaeuble's comments were made during a World Economic Forum panel in Davos, Switzerland.

site_title: Global tourism M&A doubles as online agencies squeeze incumbents
summary: Global tourism mergers and acquisitions (M&A) more than doubled in value in 2014, reaching $64.4 billion, as low borrowing costs and growing competition fueled the busiest year in seven for deals in the industry. Online travel agencies and web-based services are threatening the earnings of hotels and tour operators, pushing them to become bigger and go digital. The pace of dealmaking may not slow, with companies like Accor SA and Kuoni Reisen Holding AG planning to spend billions to improve their digital presence and compete with online travel agencies.

site_title: New year, new picks
summary: The PGA Merchandise Show in Orlando, Florida, marked the 62nd edition of the annual event, featuring over 1,000 exhibitors showcasing the latest golf products. New releases include Nike's Vapor Flex and Vapor Speed drivers, Callaway's XR Driver and Fairway Woods, Puma's Titantour and Titanlite footwear, FootJoy's Performance Golf Apparel Spring 15 Collection, and TaylorMade's R15 Driver. The products are set to be available for sale in the South-east Asian region, with prices ranging from S$169 to S$950.

site_title: Luxury class
summary: The Mercedes-Benz S400L, the long-wheelbase sedan of the S-Class, is the latest luxury offering from the German manufacturer. The sixth-generation model boasts smoother, flowing lines and a wider cabin with a 14mm increase in rear kneeroom. The interior features a pillowy headrest, generous legroom, and soft leather. The car is powered by a 3.0-litre V6 turbocharged engine and features advanced safety innovations. With a starting price of S$97,000, the S400L offers a luxurious driving experience with impressive performance and refined handling.

site_title: Davos bosses fret over threats to Internet free trade
summary: Business leaders at the World Economic Forum in Davos are concerned about the potential break-up of the Internet, which could disrupt global free trade. Regulatory pressures, different national regimes, and fragmentation of the web are cited as threats. The forum aims to discuss ways to maintain an open, cross-border web. Experts, such as Vittorio Colao of Vodafone, warn that the temptation for fragmentation is real, citing network traffic as a potential casualty. The issue highlights the challenges of balancing national regulations with the need for a unified, global online environment.

site_title: US existing home sales rise in December
summary: US existing home sales rose 2.4% in December to an annual rate of 5.04 million units, according to the National Association of Realtors. This marks a hopeful sign for the housing market recovery in 2015, surpassing economists' forecast of a 5.06-million-unit pace. The slight increase in sales indicates a potential pick-up in the housing market as it enters the new year.

site_title: Carney says ECB action helps 'preserve prosperity in Europe'
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney welcomed the European Central Bank's 60 billion euro bond-buying programme, saying it would preserve medium-term prosperity in Europe. The programme aims to stimulate the struggling eurozone economy and prevent deflation. Carney emphasized the importance of maintaining inflation in the right spot to prevent a price spiral.

site_title: New heir to Saudi throne is relatively liberal outsider
summary: Saudi Arabia's new Crown Prince Muqrin, 69, represents a break from tradition in the ruling family due to his foreign education and lowly maternal birth. A relative progressive, he has vowed to continue King Salman's economic and social reforms, but his hawkish views on Iran may limit his influence. Born to a Yemeni woman, Muqrin has no full siblings in the ruling dynasty and is seen as an outsider by some relatives. Despite his progressive stance, he has also been quoted as warning of a "Shi'ite crescent" becoming a "full moon," indicating a more conservative view on Iran.

site_title: China Taisan to replace products with quality issues
summary: China Taisan Technology Group Holdings agreed to replace or discount 6,270 tonnes of products with quality issues, affecting approximately 6,573 tonnes delivered in the 2014 financial year. The firm began manufacturing replacement products in November 2014 and aims to complete the "one-to-one goods exchange exercise" by April 2015.

site_title: Hollande: ECB stimulus should not stop us reforming
summary: French President Francois Hollande stated that the European Central Bank's bond-buying program should not be used as an excuse for eurozone countries to avoid implementing reforms. He emphasized that despite the ECB's efforts to stimulate growth, countries still need to take action to address structural issues.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank's massive bond-buying programme should not be used as an excuse for eurozone countries not enacting far-reaching reforms, France's president said on Friday.

site_title: Gold slips 1.2% as dollar climbs on ECB move
summary: Gold prices fell 1.2% on Friday as the dollar rose, driven by the European Central Bank's plan to inject 1 trillion euros into the euro zone economy. The metal had surged 1% above $1,300 an ounce on Thursday after the ECB announcement, but pared gains amid a stronger dollar making dollar-denominated assets more expensive for foreign investors. The euro hit an 11-year low against the dollar, contributing to the decline in gold prices.

site_title: Low pay, few jobs cost women in poor countries US$9t a year: charity
summary: Women in poor countries lose US$9 trillion a year due to low pay and employment, equivalent to the combined GDP of Britain, France, and Germany. Women spend up to 10 times more hours on unpaid care work, and are often employed in exploitative forms of labor such as domestic work and factory work for low wages. ActionAid cites the World Bank in its report highlighting the economic burden on women in developing countries.

site_title: China ministry denies civil servant wages raised significantly
summary: China's Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security has denied reports that civil servants' wages were significantly raised in October, contradicting a government document that showed a 31% wage hike. The ministry's spokesman, Li Zhong, stated that the information is not true and that there is still a process ahead to determine future wage hikes. The move aims to combat corruption and boost consumption, as low pay for civil servants is a major driver of corruption.

images.alt_text: China on Friday said it had not significantly raised civil servants' wages, denying state media reports and a government document that the wages were raised in October.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. In financial news, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss in the second half of the year. London's Heathrow Airport is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee of Trafigura in a graft case. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while MAS and PBOC announced cooperation in green and transition finance. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS executive, is set to become OCBC's new CEO.

site_title: UBS to pay US$2.9b in contingent bonuses over five years
summary: UBS Group AG has announced a five-year extension to a $2.9 billion bonus plan for top employees, with the bank paying out around $500 million annually in deferred contingent capital. The plan aims to align compensation incentives with the bank's capital strength and will boost its additional Tier 1 capital. The securities can be wiped out if the bank's capital ratio falls below a predefined threshold, a move to limit incentives to take risks. This is part of UBS' efforts to underpin its finances and comply with regulatory requirements.

images.alt_text: UBS Group AG on Friday announced a five- year, US$2.9 billion extension to a bonus plan that rewards top employees with securities that can be wiped out if the bank hits tough times.

site_title: India central bank relaxes overseas loan recast rules
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), has relaxed rules for companies and banks to restructure and reschedule existing overseas borrowings. The move aims to help Indian firms restructure their debt after the economy's sharp slowdown. The RBI now allows an increase in the total cost of borrowing offshore and changes in drawdown and repayment schedules. This move is expected to provide relief to companies facing difficulties in restructuring their overseas borrowings.

site_title: Oil market upheaval looms over Saudi succession
summary: Saudi Arabia faces a major challenge as the absolute monarchy seeks to reassert its leadership in the oil market following King Abdullah's death. The kingdom, which has built up production capacity and huge financial reserves, is facing a battle for market share against North American shale oil producers. Experts expect Riyadh to fight fiercely to remain dominant, but the future is highly unpredictable due to fundamental market changes and the rise of high-efficiency producers. The kingdom's reliance on oil provides 90% of public revenues, and its ability to maintain output in the face of a global supply glut will be crucial.

site_title: Divers find more bodies, reach AirAsia fuselage
summary: Indonesian divers reached the fuselage of the crashed AirAsia plane on January 23, 2015, after four more bodies were recovered from the Java Sea. The plane, with 162 people on board, crashed on December 28 in stormy weather. Rescuers have found 63 bodies so far, including six recovered on Thursday, and are planning a more thorough assessment of the wreckage to determine how to retrieve the bodies. The jet's black boxes were recovered last week, and investigators are analysing them, with officials hoping most victims are inside the fuselage.

site_title: Bankers in Davos see ECB's QE plan squeezing profitability
