summary: Bankers at the World Economic Forum in Davos express concerns that the European Central Bank's (ECB) quantitative easing (QE) plan, which involves buying at least 1.1 trillion euros in assets, may squeeze profitability. The plan aims to put more cash into circulation and stave off deflation, but will likely narrow the net interest margin, reducing banks' profit margins. While some bankers acknowledge the need for QE to revive European growth, they also warn of the challenges it poses to their businesses, particularly deposit-taking and flow-franchise businesses.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda welcomes ECB easing, relaxed about expected Fed hikes
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed confidence in his efforts to beat deflation, despite diverging monetary policies in the US and Europe. He welcomed the ECB's bond-buying program, noting the euro's relatively stable value against the yen. Kuroda also viewed the expected US interest rate hike as a positive, citing strong US growth as a boon to the world economy. He believes the diverging policies won't complicate his efforts, citing the euro's long-term weakening.

site_title: Euro tumbles below US$1.12, lowest since Sept 2003
summary: The euro plummeted to a 12-year low of US$1.1115, its lowest level since September 2003, amid investor concerns about the European Central Bank's plan to inject over a trillion euros into the economy. The euro also fell 2% against the yen, reaching a 16-month low. The move comes ahead of a snap election in Greece and raises concerns about the region's economic stability.

site_title: K1 Ventures Q2 net profit surges to S$30.9m
summary: K1 Ventures reported a net profit of S$30.9 million for Q2 2015, up from S$561,000 in the same period a year ago. Revenue increased to S$51.5 million, more than doubling from S$2.8 million. The company declared an interim dividend of 1.5 Singapore cents per share, a first for the same period. The counter closed unchanged at 18.8 Singapore cents.

site_title: Goldman's commodity outlook buckles under threat of deflation
summary: Goldman Sachs has cut its commodity forecasts due to deflationary pressures, citing cheaper energy and a stronger US dollar. The bank reduced forecasts for metals such as copper, gold, and iron ore by 10-20% over the next three years. Oil prices have led the collapse in commodities, with Brent crude falling 60% since June last year. Goldman is bullish on palladium, nickel, and zinc, while expecting gold to decline from the third quarter of 2015. The bank also expects copper to fall, with prices tumbling 23% in the last 12 months.

site_title: UBS says did not suffer trading losses after SNB move
summary: UBS reported it did not incur trading losses following the Swiss National Bank's decision to scrap its currency cap, confirming it would return cash to shareholders. The bank's trading businesses did not experience negative revenues, and it will return 0.25 Swiss francs per share to shareholders. UBS also reaffirmed its aim to return at least half of its profits to shareholders if it maintains a 13.7% core capital ratio. The bank's capital return is part of a change in legal structure, which will allow it to qualify for a capital rebate under Switzerland's too-big-to-fail requirements.

site_title: Chan Chun Sing "suitable" minister to strengthen labour movement leadership: NTUC
summary: Singapore's NTUC has unanimously agreed that Social and Family Development Minister Chan Chun Sing is "suitable" to join its leadership ranks. The central committee wrote to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, stating Chan's ability to strengthen labour leadership and link the labour movement to the government. Lee supported the NTUC's choice and agreed to release Chan to serve in the labour movement part-time immediately and full-time from April 1.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Canada's Oanda enters race for Alpari UK: website
summary: Toronto-based Oanda has made a bid for Alpari UK, a fellow online foreign exchange broker, following Alpari's administration due to losses caused by the removal of the Swiss franc cap. Another broker, IronFX, has also made a bid for Alpari, with administrators aiming to sell the broker by the end of next week. Oanda's bid was reported by industry website Forex Magnates, citing two sources close to the matter, but a spokesman for Oanda declined to comment.

site_title: In China, VPN internet access tools suffer further disruptions
summary: China's VPN internet access tools have faced further disruptions, with popular providers Astrill, StrongVPN, and Golden Frog experiencing more sophisticated attacks. The Chinese government justifies these moves as part of its efforts to maintain control over its highly sophisticated internet censorship system, known as the Great Firewall. The disruptions are part of a technological arms race between VPN providers and the Chinese government, with Golden Frog's president describing the recent attacks as "more sophisticated than what we've seen in the past."

site_title: Update: Oil jumps as Saudi king's death feeds market uncertainty
summary: Oil prices rose after Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah bin Abdulaziz died, adding uncertainty to the market. King Salman, the new king, named Muqrin as heir and Mohammed bin Nayef as Deputy Crown Prince, aiming to prevent a succession crisis. Oil policy is expected to remain unchanged, with Saudi Arabia maintaining a steady output to protect its market share. Brent crude futures rose to $49.42 a barrel, while US WTI crude futures rose to $46.60 a barrel, up 90 cents and 29 cents respectively.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust DPU up 10% in Q1
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 10% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.75 Singapore cents in its Q1 results, driven by the addition of Changi City Point and higher contribution from Causeway Point. Gross revenue rose 18.3% and net property income increased 16.2%. The trust's units closed unchanged at S$2.02 before results were announced. The DPU will be paid out on Feb 27.

site_title: New Saudi king seeks to reassure on succession and policy
summary: Saudi King Salman has pledged to maintain existing energy and foreign policies after taking the throne following the death of King Abdullah. Salman appointed his 69-year-old half-brother Muqrin as Crown Prince and his 55-year-old nephew Mohammed bin Nayef as Deputy Crown Prince, settling the succession and quelling speculation about palace rifts. This move aims to maintain stability during a time of regional turmoil, and Salman's policies are expected to remain unchanged.

site_title: Rise in euro forgeries in second half of 2014: ECB
summary: The European Central Bank reported a 44% increase in the number of counterfeit euro banknotes withdrawn from circulation in the second half of 2014, with 507,000 fake notes removed from circulation. This represents a significant rise from the second half of 2013, but the overall number of genuine euro banknotes in circulation remains high, exceeding 16 billion. The ECB attributed the increase to the growing sophistication of counterfeiting methods.

site_title: UK 2014 car production rises to highest since 2007
summary: British car production rose to its highest level since 2007, reaching 1.528 million cars in 2014, a 1.2% increase. Strong domestic demand drove the growth, while exports fell due to a weaker eurozone recovery. SMMT Chief Executive Mike Hawes attributed the investment of over £7 billion in UK production facilities in the past two years, resulting in new models beginning production, with more expected in 2015.

site_title: New Saudi Deputy Crown Prince marks generational shift
summary: Saudi Arabia's King Salman appointed Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, a close ally of the US, as the country's first king from the third generation of its ruling dynasty. The 55-year-old prince, a grandson of Saudi Arabia's first monarch, is seen as a key figure in the kingdom's future succession and is believed to be more receptive to ideas of reform. Despite his conservative background, Prince Mohammed has followed his father's example of keeping close ties with conservatives and is considered a hawk on Iran.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's Interior Minister, Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, a close friend of the United States and a scourge of Islamist militants, will be the country's first king from the third generation of its ruling dynasty.

site_title: New Saudi king seen sticking with oil production policy
summary: Saudi Arabia's new King Salman is likely to maintain the country's oil production policy, sticking with the current levels to preserve market share despite depressed prices. The oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, who has driven decision-making since 1995, is expected to retain his position, according to analysts. The kingdom's refusal to cut production has contributed to the worst oil price slump since the 2008 global credit crisis, but the new king has confirmed that the country will maintain its policies.

site_title: China Alibaba founder Jack Ma shows global ambitions
summary: Alibaba founder Jack Ma expressed ambitions to turn his company into a global e-commerce platform serving 2 billion customers. The company, which listed on the New York Stock Exchange last year, already holds over 90% of the Chinese market for consumer-to-consumer transactions through its Taobao platform, with over 800 million product listings and 500 million registered users.

site_title: F&N seals licensing agreements with Nestle
summary: F&N, a Malaysian company, has signed 11-year licensing agreements with Nestle to manufacture and distribute several brands, including Carnation, Bear Brand, and Ideal Milk, in ASEAN countries. The agreements extend existing licenses granted by Nestle in 2007 and will take effect from July 1, 2015. The licenses are renewable for an additional 10 years until January 31, 2037.

images.alt_text: FRASER and Neave, Limited (F&N), through its listed subsidiary Fraser & Neave Holdings Bhd in Malaysia, has signed several agreements with Nestle to manufacture and distribute Carnation, Bear Brand, Bear Brand Gold, Ideal Milk and Milkmaid in Asean, including Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia and Brunei.

site_title: China facing 'unprecedented' security risks, says Party
summary: China's ruling Communist Party has warned of "unprecedented national security risks" amid strained relations with Asian neighbors and the US. The Politburo cited territorial disputes in the East and South China Seas, as well as cybersecurity threats, as key concerns. Violence in China's Xinjiang region has intensified, with at least 200 people killed in clashes, and Beijing has launched a severe crackdown in response. The party has also warned of external terrorist threats, but lacks concrete evidence linking them to organized extremist groups.

site_title: Li Ka-shing's Hutchison Whampoa confirms in talks to buy Britain's O2 for S$20.5 billion
summary: Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-Shing's Hutchison Whampoa is in "exclusive negotiations" to buy Britain's O2 for up to £10.25 billion (S$20.58 billion). The deal would create Britain's largest mobile phone group. Hutchison confirmed talks with Spanish company Telefonica, with a deferred payment of up to £1 billion. The deal is subject to due diligence and regulatory approvals.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-Shing's Hutchison Whampoa said on Friday it is in "exclusive negotiations" to buy mobile phone giant O2 for up to £10.25 billion (S$20.58 billion), in a deal that would create Britain's biggest mobile phone group.

site_title: Sony applies to delay earnings release over cyberattack
summary: Sony is seeking permission from Japanese regulators to delay the release of its earnings due to a cyberattack on its US-based Sony Pictures Entertainment subsidiary. The attack, linked to the North Korea satire "The Interview", compromised a large amount of data and prevented the company from compiling its financial statements in time. The delay is necessary to ensure the accuracy and security of the financial reports.

site_title: Emerging stocks set for biggest weekly rise in 10 months as ECB fuels rally
summary: Emerging stocks are poised for their biggest weekly gain in 10 months, driven by the European Central Bank's trillion-euro stimulus pledge, which has fueled a rally across global markets. The MSCI's emerging equities index rose over 1% after the ECB announced its bond-buying scheme, with Asian bourses such as Hong Kong, Taiwan, and South Korea also experiencing gains. However, some analysts note that the stimulus may not end weeks of outflows from emerging market funds and that longer-term risks to the trade remain.

images.alt_text: Emerging equities were headed on Friday for their biggest weekly gain in 10 months, while bonds and currencies rallied across the board, thanks to the European Central Bank's trillion-euro stimulus pledge.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 41.21 points to 3,411.50. The index rose for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data. Gainers outnumbered losers 324-167, with 1.80 billion shares valued at S$1.57 billion traded.

site_title: Southeast Asia stocks: Indonesian, Philippine shares hit record closing highs
summary: Southeast Asian stocks reached record highs on Friday, with Indonesian and Philippine shares leading the way. The Jakarta composite index rose 1.35% to an all-time closing high, while the Philippine main index climbed 1.8% to its third record closing high this year. Foreign investors poured in billions of dollars, boosting large-cap stocks and the Thai stock market. The European Central Bank's bond-buying program sparked the rally, sending Southeast Asia's best performer, the Thai benchmark SET index, 2.4% higher on the day.

images.alt_text: Indonesian and Philippine shares hit record closing highs on Friday amid foreign inflows after the European Central Bank unveiled its bond-buying programme, while a late rally in banking shares boosted the Thai stock market.

site_title: Asia's richest man starts 2015 with about US$45b in deals
summary: Asia's richest man, Li Ka-shing, is starting 2015 with a flurry of deals worth over $45 billion, surpassing his net worth to $30 billion. He is reorganizing his business empire, including a potential $15 billion acquisition of UK wireless carrier O2 and a $1 billion purchase of a British rail business. The moves come as he prepares to hand over the reins to his eldest son, Victor Li, and focus on long-term cash flow.

site_title: India's move towards better fiscal management key for rating agencies: S&P
summary: India's fiscal management is crucial for rating agencies as the current fiscal deficit number alone may not accurately reflect the country's fiscal consolidation. Takahira Ogawa, a director at Standard and Poor's, stated that the current government is aware of the quality of fiscal consolidation. This move towards better fiscal management could impact India's credit rating, with S&P closely monitoring the country's progress.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 21.33 points to close at 1,803.08 on Friday, driven by a 2.61 billion lots valued at RM3.13 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 535 to 365. The market's gain follows a 5-day rally in Singapore and comes despite uncertainty over US trade policies and a split Federal Reserve view.

site_title: Hong Kong drops from top 30 most-livable cities, survey says
summary: Hong Kong has dropped from the top 30 most-livable cities due to poor air quality and social unrest caused by the Occupy Central movement. The city fell 16 spots to 33rd place in the survey, while Singapore topped the list for the 16th consecutive year. Despite remaining highly ranked, Hong Kong's air quality and socio-political score worsened due to the recent unrest and restrictions.

site_title: UK retail sales show surprise gain in December on food, fuel
summary: UK retail sales unexpectedly rose 0.4% in December, driven by increased spending on food and fuel due to falling oil prices. This was the strongest growth in over a decade, and sales volumes rose 4.3% year-over-year. The boost was attributed to consumers taking advantage of low oil prices, which offset the impact of Black Friday sales in November. The data suggests a strong economic recovery in Britain, with consumer spending expected to remain a key driver.

site_title: Oil climbs as Saudi King's death spurs speculation over policy
summary: Oil prices rose after the death of Saudi King Abdullah, with futures climbing 3.1% in New York and 2.6% in London. The kingdom's largest crude exporter will maintain its oil-production quota, but uncertainty surrounding new leadership may lead to policy changes. Crude stockpiles in the US rose, and the US is now the world's biggest oil consumer. Analysts expect a potential shift in Saudi oil policy, but the global glut may temper price volatility.

site_title: ECB's Visco sees buying of Greek bonds in QE programme by June
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) governing council member Ignazio Visco stated that Greek sovereign bonds can be purchased starting in June as part of the ECB's government bond-buying programme, due to limitations in issues. The programme is set to start in March and is open-ended to address potential difficulties.

site_title: Chinese factory gauge recovers lost ground on stimulus
summary: China's manufacturing gauge recovered in January, exceeding expectations with a preliminary Purchasing Managers' Index of 49.8, up from 49.6 in December. The reading indicates stabilization of the world's second-largest economy, which saw a 7.4% GDP growth in 2014, its slowest pace in 24 years. The improved data may alleviate concerns of a deeper downturn, suggesting stimulus measures have helped.

site_title: Goldman joins banks cutting iron ore outlook on global glut
summary: Global banks, including Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, and UBS, have cut their iron ore price forecasts for 2015 and 2016 due to a global glut, citing rising seaborne supplies and weaker demand growth from China. Goldman Sachs now estimates the average price of iron ore to be $66 per metric ton this year, down from $80. The bank predicts that the industry will face a "painful war of attrition" as less competitive mines shut, and that the global seaborne surplus will expand to 260 million tons by 2018.

site_title: Evaporating inflation and growth put pressure on central banks
summary: Businesses across Asia and Europe cut prices at the start of 2015, driven by evaporating inflation and growth, prompting central banks to consider easing monetary policies. The European Central Bank printed money to revive the eurozone economy, while China's factory growth stalled for the second month, leading to expectations of fresh stimulus measures. Global growth is expected to be slow, with emerging economies, including South Korea and Thailand, also facing challenges, while Japan remains a lone bright spot. Central banks, including the Bank of Korea and Bank of Japan, are likely to cut interest rates to stimulate growth.

images.alt_text: Businesses across Asia and Europe have slashed prices at the start of the year to drum up trade, surveys showed on Friday, a day after the European Central Bank voted to print money in a bid to revive inflation.

site_title: Eurozone starts 2015 better than thought as firms slash prices: PMIs
summary: The eurozone economy started 2015 with a stronger-than-expected growth, according to Markit's Eurozone Composite Flash Purchasing Managers' Index, which rose to a five-month high of 52.2. Despite this, firms across the continent cut prices at the fastest rate in nearly five years, with the prices index dropping to 46.9. The European Central Bank's quantitative easing plan aims to revive inflation, and a 0.2% first-quarter growth is predicted. However, demand for manufactured goods remains low, casting a shadow over the outlook for February.

site_title: Moscovici says ECB's bond-buying plan in 'interests of all eurozone'
summary: European Union economics chief Pierre Moscovici has welcomed the European Central Bank's new government bond-buying programme, stating it is in the "interests of all eurozone". Moscovici believes the programme, which involves pumping hundreds of billions of euros into the economy, will prevent deflation. He also emphasized the need for structural reforms in eurozone countries, saying it is "absolutely necessary" despite the programme.

site_title: Japan govt upgrades view of industrial production in January
summary: Japan's government upgraded its view of industrial production for January, citing manufacturers' bullish forecasts for increased production. The economy is in a moderate recovery, with private consumption and some areas showing weakness. The government expects lower oil prices to help Japan's economy grow, as they lower fuel costs and increase purchasing power. The overall economic assessment remains unchanged for the third straight month, and the housing market is stabilizing. The upgrade comes despite lingering concerns about a global economic slowdown and the Bank of Japan's decision to keep quantitative easing unchanged.

site_title: Europe: Shares extend rally on ECB boost
summary: European shares rose for the seventh consecutive session, with the FTSEurofirst 300 index up 0.8% at 1,464.69 points, a seven-year high. The European Central Bank's decision to buy government bonds boosted investor sentiment. Cyclical stocks such as carmakers BMW and PSA Peugeot Citroen saw significant gains. Renault Nissan Chief Executive Carlos Ghosn upgraded his European car market growth forecast to at least 2% in 2015.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end at 4-month high after ECB stimulus
summary: Hong Kong shares reached a 4-month high on Friday, closing at 24,850.45, after the European Central Bank launched a stimulus program to support the euro zone economy. The ECB will purchase 60 billion euros of sovereign debt per month from March to September 2016. The Hang Seng index and China Enterprises Index gained 1.3% and 1.8% respectively, extending a global rally.

site_title: Tokyo stocks rise 1.05% after ECB stimulus move
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.05% on Friday, following a rally in European and US markets after the European Central Bank announced a bigger-than-expected stimulus programme. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 17,511.75, while the Topix index climbed 0.99% to 1,403.22. The ECB's asset-purchase plan was seen as a positive move by investors, with a senior strategist citing the higher-than-expected value of the plan.

site_title: China's use of yuan for cross-border business growing
summary: China's use of its yuan currency for cross-border transactions increased to 9.95 trillion yuan (US$1.63 trillion) in 2014, accounting for 20% of total cross-border payments and receipts. The People's Bank of China aims to promote the yuan's international use, despite controlling its value and capital flows. Analysts predict the yuan may rival the US dollar in the future. China has established yuan clearing arrangements with 10 countries and signed agreements with 28 central banks to promote its currency's global role.

site_title: ECB's quantitative easing program is open-ended: Visco
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) quantitative easing program, set to run until September 2016, will remain open-ended if inflation targets aren't met, said ECB Governor Ignazio Visco. The program aims to combat deflation by flooding the region with liquidity. Visco stated that the exchange rate is not a target for monetary policy, but rather an important channel for portfolio rebalancing. The euro fell to its lowest level in over 11 years following the decision.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank's asset-purchase program will continue past September 2016 if it hasn't met its inflation objectives by then, Governing Council member Ignazio Visco said.

site_title: ECB easing may lift Chinese exports, squeeze yuan: China central bank official
summary: The European Central Bank's quantitative easing program may boost China's exports and put downward pressure on the yuan, according to a Chinese central bank official. This could also lead to a depreciation of the yuan and a strengthening of the US dollar. The official, Vice Governor Pan Gongsheng, stated that China's monetary policy will not replace the use of a reserve requirement ratio, but will instead utilize a medium-term lending facility to inject liquidity into the financial system.

site_title: Winklevoss twins aim to take Bitcoin mainstream with a regulated exchange: NYT
summary: The Winklevoss twins, Cameron and Tyler, are launching Gemini, the first regulated Bitcoin exchange in the US, dubbed the "Nasdaq of Bitcoin". They've hired engineers from top hedge funds, enlisted a bank, and engaged regulators to open the exchange in the coming months. The twins have been seeking regulatory approval for a bitcoin exchange-traded fund, and their move aims to bring Bitcoin into the mainstream.

site_title: Update: Thai assembly finds former PM guilty of negligence
summary: Thailand's military-appointed legislature found former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra guilty of negligence, carrying a five-year ban from politics. The verdict, requiring a three-fifths majority, was reached with 190 votes in favor of impeachment. Yingluck was ousted from office for abuse of power days before a military coup in May.

site_title: German private sector expands faster in January: PMI
summary: Germany's private sector expanded faster in January, with the Markit PMI rising to 52.6 from 52.0 in December, above the 50 line for growth. The manufacturing sector index dropped to 51.0, while the services sector index rose to 52.7. This growth was attributed to weaker growth in Asia and neighboring countries, but still suggests Germany might sustain its macro-economic growth and potentially match its 2014 growth performance of 1.5%. The European Central Bank's bond-buying program may also provide additional growth support for the German economy.

site_title: China's urban unemployment at 4.1% at end 2014
summary: China's urban unemployment rate remained stable at 4.1% at the end of 2014, despite a 24-year low in economic growth. The rate, which does not account for the 298 million migrant labor force, was little changed from the previous year. The Chinese government has devised a new jobless rate through surveys, which stood at 5.1% in 2014, indicating the true unemployment figure may be higher. Premier Li Keqiang expects the economy to face headwinds in 2015, amid a housing slump and downturn in investment and manufacturing.

images.alt_text: China's labour market was stable last year even as its economic growth plumbed a 24-year low, with the urban unemployment rate little changed at 4.1 percent at the end of December, the government said on Friday.

site_title: Southeast Asia needs regional aviation regulators: AirAsia chief
summary: Southeast Asia needs a regional aviation regulator to streamline safety standards and aircrew training, according to AirAsia's CEO Tony Fernandes. The region's patchy airline safety record, highlighted by the Indonesia AirAsia crash, has sparked calls for common standards and standardization. Asean, which aims to establish a single aviation market by 2015, has yet to adopt uniform technical and safety procedures. Fernandes advocates for a single Asean regulator for air traffic, safety standards, and pilot training to enhance the region's aviation industry and improve mobility of the workforce.

images.alt_text: Southeast Asia needs regional aviation regulators to streamline a fragmented safety framework and ensure common standards for aircrew training in the booming industry, AirAsia's group chief executive officer said.

site_title: New Saudi king seen sticking with oil output policy
summary: Saudi Arabia's new King Salman is likely to maintain the country's oil output policy, sticking with the production levels set by his predecessor King Abdullah to preserve market share despite depressing prices. King Salman, 79, is expected to retain oil minister Ali al-Naimi, who has driven decision-making since 1995, and has said he wants to devote more time to his other job. This approach has contributed to the worst oil price slump since 2008, with prices falling 48% in 2014.

site_title: Singapore's headline inflation edges up slightly to -0.2% in December
summary: Singapore's headline inflation remained in negative territory at -0.2% in December, from -0.3% in November, mainly due to base effects from fluctuations in car COE premiums. Core inflation, excluding accommodation and private road transport, remained stable at 1.5%. Economists forecast a lower-than-expected inflation in 2015, with headline inflation expected at 0.5-1.5% and core inflation at 2-3%. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry cautioned that sustained low global oil prices could lead to lower-than-expected inflation.

site_title: Update: Keppel Corp launches bid for rest of Keppel Land
summary: Keppel Corporation has launched a voluntary unconditional cash offer for all remaining shares of its real estate subsidiary, Keppel Land, which currently owns 54.6% of the company.

site_title: No 'significant' change in Saudi oil policy after king's death: IEA
summary: Saudi Arabia's oil policy is unlikely to undergo significant changes following the death of King Abdullah, according to Fatih Birol, chief economist of the International Energy Agency. Birol expressed hope that Saudi Arabia will continue to be a stabilisation factor in the oil markets. He noted the importance of Saudi Arabia's contribution to oil market stability, particularly during uncertain times. Birol's comments were made at the World Economic Forum in Davos, where he emphasized the expectation of minimal changes in Saudi Arabia's oil policy.

site_title: Keppel Corp launches voluntary cash offer for rest of Keppel Land
summary: Keppel Corp has launched a voluntary cash offer for the remaining shares of Keppel Land, with a base price of S$4.38 to S$4.60 per share. The move comes after Keppel Land reached a one-year high of S$3.65. Trading for both companies was halted on Wednesday, pending the announcement, and their scheduled results briefings were postponed. The offer is expected to resume trading on Monday.

site_title: Update: Euro hits fresh 11-year low after ECB launches QE, seen staying weak
summary: The euro reached an 11-year low against the US dollar, trading at around $1.1315, after the European Central Bank launched a $1 trillion quantitative easing program to support the eurozone economy. The program, which will run until September 2016, could keep pressure on the euro, with traders predicting a prolonged period of consolidation and potential further decline. The euro also fell to a seven-year low against sterling, while the dollar rose to an 11-year high against a basket of currencies, amid uncertainty over Greek elections and potential economic implications.

site_title: No cancellation or withdrawal of rig orders: Keppel Corp
summary: Keppel Corp's CEO Loh Chin Hua stated that the company has not seen any withdrawal or cancellation of rig orders despite headwinds in the global oil and gas industry. The company has not received requests to re-negotiate payments, but there have been requests to delay delivery of two projects. CEO Chow Yew Yuen believes oil prices will move towards an equilibrium, rather than remaining at current levels, and does not foresee a significant impact on the company's rig orders.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

While there are headwinds in the global oil and gas industry, marine conglomerate Keppel Corp has not seen any withdrawal or cancellation of rig orders, chief executive officer Loh Chin Hua said on Friday.

site_title: Top Indonesian anti-graft official arrested: police
summary: Indonesia's deputy chief of the Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK), Bambang Widjojanto, was arrested on Friday over allegations of interfering in a legal case. The arrest, which sparked protests, comes amid a government crackdown on corruption under President Joko Widodo. Widjojanto could face seven years in prison if found guilty. The arrest is seen as retaliation for the KPK's investigation into a high-ranking police general, who was postponed from becoming police chief due to the investigation. The incident has drawn criticism that the police are trying to hinder anti-corruption efforts.

site_title: Casino operator Galaxy to invest at least US$7b more in Macau resort
summary: Galaxy Entertainment Group, a casino operator, plans to invest at least HK$100 billion (S$17.30 billion) in its Macau integrated resort, more than doubling its investment. The company aims to diversify its focus from gaming to entertainment and cultural offerings, in line with China's push for Macau to diversify its economy. Galaxy will invest HK$55 billion in the third and fourth phases of its Galaxy Macau integrated resort, leveraging its largest land bank to bring in more attractions.

site_title: Philippine central bank says to keep financial volatility in check
summary: The Philippine central bank, BSP, plans to maintain financial stability and monitor inflation risks, with Governor Amando Tetangco stating there's no reason to change monetary policy. Deputy Governor Diwa Guinigundo emphasized the bank's readiness to use tools to safeguard price stability. The central bank will continue to closely watch the balance of risks on inflation outlook.

site_title: Keppel Corp, Keppel Land to resume trading on Monday: KepCorp CEO
summary: Keppel Corp and Keppel Land will resume trading on Monday, lifting a trading halt due to a voluntary unconditional cash offer for all remaining shares of Keppel Land. The offer price ranges from S$4.38 to S$4.60 per share, valuing Keppel Land at S$6.8 billion to S$7.1 billion. KepCorp CEO Loh Chin Hua apologized for the halt, stating that the company wants to ensure all relevant information is out.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Keppel Corporation (KepCorp) and Keppel Land will lift the trading halts on their shares on Monday, KepCorp chief executive officer Loh Chin Hua said on Friday.

site_title: Uber to restart cab service in India's Delhi: spokesman
summary: Uber has applied for a radio taxi license in India's Delhi, restarting operations after being banned following allegations of a driver raping a female passenger. To improve passenger safety, Uber will introduce additional safety measures, including stricter driver checks, an in-app emergency button, and a dedicated incident response team. The company aims to regain trust with the public and restore its presence in the Indian market.

site_title: KepLand privatisation not predicated on short-term recovery of property sector: KepCorp CEO
summary: KepCorp's planned takeover of its 54.6% subsidiary Keppel Land is not driven by short-term expectations of the property sector recovery, according to KepCorp CEO Loh Chin Hua. The move is considered "sound and well-timed" and will be immediately accretive to shareholders. Loh stated that the decision was deliberate and not based on the assumption that the property market would recover quickly, but rather seen as a strategic move for KepCorp in the long term.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Ousted Thai PM Yingluck to face criminal charge in Supreme Court
summary: Thailand's former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra will face a criminal charge in the Supreme Court for negligence over a rice subsidy scheme. The charge carries a maximum of 10 years in jail. This comes as the military-appointed legislature is set to vote on an impeachment case against Yingluck for failing to exercise sufficient oversight over the scheme. The Attorney General's Office announced the indictment on the same day, hours before the impeachment vote.

site_title: China says US tyre duty ruling has 'multiple flaws'
summary: China has criticized a US ruling that imposed heavy duties on Chinese tyres, calling it "flawed" and urging Washington to handle the case "prudently". The US Commerce Department's preliminary judgement, which is due for a final decision in June, levies anti-dumping duties of 19.17-87.99% on car and light-truck tyres made in China. China claims the ruling has "multiple flaws" and will likely appeal.

site_title: Indonesia: Stock index hits record high on ECB stimulus boost
summary: Indonesia's stock index reached a record high of 5,312.37, rising over 1% in early trading on January 23, 2015, after the European Central Bank launched a 1 trillion euro stimulus plan to revive the European economy. The ECB's move supported blue-chip companies such as Astra International and Unilever Indonesia, making it the first time the main stock index crossed the 5,300 mark.

site_title: Indonesia to form infrastructure bank to attract private investment: ministry
summary: Indonesia's finance ministry plans to transform state-owned financing firm PT Sarana Multi Infrastruktur (SMI) into an infrastructure bank with $1.63 billion in funding, aiming to boost infrastructure development with private backing. The move is part of President Joko Widodo's campaign to lift economic growth. The new infrastructure bank would have a capital of $2.05 billion and aim to increase lending by 19.2 trillion rupiah this year, helping to overcome liquidity mismatch issues in conventional banking. The plan is expected to be completed by 2017.

site_title: Asian economies to grow at lacklustre pace in 2015
summary: Emerging Asian economies are expected to grow at a lacklustre pace in 2015 due to China's slowdown and weak global demand. China's growth rate is predicted to slow to 7.0% in 2015, restrained by weak lending and a housing slump. This may lead to monetary policy easing in cooling inflation. The outlook also affects regional trade partners, making the growth trajectory uncertain.

site_title: Australian dollar drops to 5.5-year low after ECB move
summary: The Australian dollar plummeted to a 5.5-year low of 79.95 US cents after the European Central Bank announced a massive bond-buying stimulus program, causing a global rally in the US dollar. Analysts attribute the decline to softening commodity prices, rising expectations of interest rate cuts, and the ECB's quantitative easing operation. The Reserve Bank of Australia's next meeting on February 3 may see further rate cuts, adding to the downward pressure on the Australian dollar.

site_title: China's bad debt ratio rises to five-year high in 2014
summary: China's bad debt ratio reached a five-year high of 1.6% at the end of 2014, according to government data. This is the highest level since the 2009 global financial crisis and indicates growing financial pressures as China's economy cools. The non-performing loan ratio increased from 1.16% at the end of September to 1.64% in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: The bad debt ratio of Chinese banks climbed to 1.6 per cent as of the end of 2014, government data showed on Friday, a level not seen since the global financial crisis and underscoring building financial pressures as China's economy cools.

site_title: Malaysia's default risk heads for longest rising streak in a year
summary: Malaysia's default risk is expected to rise for the third consecutive month, with the cost of protecting sovereign debt against non-payment increasing 21.5 basis points to 127.5 basis points. Prime Minister Najib Razak attributed the rise to falling oil prices, which he said would lead to a widening fiscal deficit and a lower growth forecast. Fitch Ratings has expressed concerns over Malaysia's reliance on oil and predicted a downgrade to its A- grade, citing the risk of a further widening in sovereign and CDS spreads.

site_title: 10 missing in boat crash off South Korea: coast guard
summary: A Chinese fishing boat collided with an unidentified cargo ship off South Korea's Jeju island, resulting in the sinking of the 138-tonne Chinese boat. Ten crew members are missing, while three others were rescued. A joint search operation involving South Korean and Chinese rescue boats is underway, approximately 160 kilometers off Jeju. The collision occurred as the Chinese fishing boat was anchoring due to rough seas.

images.alt_text: Ten crew members are missing after a Chinese fishing boat collided with an unidentified cargo ship off South Korea's southern island of Jeju, coast guards said Friday.

site_title: Singapore households see 0.4% inflation in H2 2014
summary: Singapore households experienced a 0.4% inflation rate in the second half of 2014, lower than the 1.7% rise in the preceding six months. Excluding imputed rentals, the consumer price index (CPI) increased by 0.7%. Inflation varied across income groups, with the bottom 20% of households worst affected, experiencing a 1% rise, while the richest fifth saw no change. Higher food prices and costlier medical treatment fees contributed to inflation, offset by lower car and petrol prices.

site_title: Seoul: Shares climb to 4-week high on ECB stimulus; won firmer
summary: South Korean shares reached a four-week high on Friday after the European Central Bank (ECB) launched a massive bond-buying stimulus program to boost the euro zone's economy. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rose 0.7% to 1,934.22 points. The ECB's move was seen as a positive signal for global markets, with the won also strengthening against the euro.

site_title: Euro ticks up in Asia after plunging on ECB stimulus
summary: The euro edged higher in Asia after plummeting to an 11-year low due to the European Central Bank's (ECB) launch of a 60 billion euro monthly bond-buying program. The single currency rose to $1.1366, but remained under pressure. Analysts predict further weakness as the ECB's move diverges from the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy. The euro's modest gain was attributed to the Asian market's reaction, with the euro buying 134.66 yen and 0.9882 Swiss francs.

site_title: Hong Kong's Li Ka-shing to buy Britain's O2: reports
summary: Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing's Hutchison Whampoa is set to buy UK mobile phone giant O2 for over £10 billion, creating Britain's largest mobile phone group. The deal comes after Li announced a major revamp of his business empire, which also includes the purchase of Eversholt Rail Group for £2.5 billion. The move is seen as part of Li's efforts to streamline his vast business empire and pave the way for his retirement, with speculation of a handover to his son Victor.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-Shing's Hutchison Whampoa is set to buy UK mobile phone giant O2, reports said Friday, the latest in a spree of overseas acquisitions by the billionaire.

site_title: South Korea's Park names new prime minister at third attempt
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye nominated 64-year-old Lee Wan-koo as prime minister for the third time, aiming to improve government administration and make a fresh start. This comes amid low public support ratings and challenges in engaging North Korea in dialogue. Lee, a Saenuri Party member and parliamentary floor leader, has a background in politics and public service, having served as a provincial police commissioner and provincial governor. His nomination aims to address the country's economic slowdown and improve governance.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise on ECB stimulus
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 1% on Friday, following the European Central Bank's announcement of massive monetary stimulus. The ECB plans to inject over 1 trillion euros into the European economy by September 2016 to combat deflation. The Taiwan dollar strengthened against the US dollar and Euro, while electronics and semiconductors led gains. Only the transportation sector fell, down 0.3%.

site_title: China factories stall for second month in January, prices fall: HSBC Flash PMI
summary: China's manufacturing growth stalled for the second consecutive month in January, with the HSBC/Markit Flash PMI at 49.8. Companies cut input prices to 39.9, a level not seen since March 2009, but reduced prices for the sixth straight month. This deflationary trend raises concerns for China, which aims to avoid Japan's 20-year-long deflationary cycle.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rally 1.37% in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.37% in early trade on January 23, 2015, after the European Central Bank unveiled a bigger-than-expected bond-buying scheme to boost the eurozone economy. The benchmark Hang Seng Index jumped 335.34 points to 24,857.97. This move is seen as a positive signal for global markets, with investors optimistic about the potential economic recovery.

site_title: New Singtel tagline sends English into state of emergency
summary: The United Nations has declared a state of emergency for the English language after Singtel's new tagline "Let's make everyday better" was deemed a formal violation of the Geneva Convention. The change, which replaced the uppercase "T" with a lowercase one, has caused widespread grammatical errors and altered the laws of physics, resulting in chaos and disruptions worldwide, including schools cancelling English classes and books rewriting themselves with spelling errors. The UN director-general has stated that the slogan has "ripped a hole through the space-time continuum" and is "an act of aggression against the English language."

site_title: Draghi corners Tsipras by tying QE access to good Greek behaviour
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has set limits on accessing its quantitative easing program, excluding Greece for at least six months due to its stalled review of the current bailout and concerns over its debt strategy. President Mario Draghi said Greece will be ineligible until July, unless it reaches an agreement with creditors. The move aims to pressure Syriza, which is leading in polls, to adopt more fiscal discipline and persuade the ECB to write down Greek debt holdings.

site_title: China's yuan weakens on PBOC guidance after new round of European QE
summary: China's yuan weakened 0.2% to 6.1342 per dollar on Friday, the biggest single-day drop in 10 months, following the European Central Bank's announcement of a fresh round of quantitative easing. The PBOC had previously tolerated the yuan's decline, but strong global central bank moves may prompt a proactive policy shift. The yuan's offshore rate fell 0.08% to 6.2223 per dollar, while one-year non-deliverable forwards contracts traded 3% below the midpoint.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 10-week high, ECB stimulus buoys demand
summary: Australian shares rose 1.4% to a 10-week high on Friday, driven by the European Central Bank's stimulus package and speculation of a domestic interest rate cut. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5492.2. Energy stocks surged amid hopes of reduced global supply tensions in Saudi Arabia, while a surprise interest rate cut in Canada fueled speculation of a potential Reserve Bank of Australia cut. The ECB's bond-buying drive is expected to pump hundreds of billions into the euro zone economy, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: Asia: Stocks surge on ECB move, oil rallies on Saudi king death
summary: Asian equity markets surged on Friday after the European Central Bank announced a cash injection to boost the eurozone economy. The euro plummeted to 11-year lows against the dollar, fueling buying in US and European stocks. Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, and Tokyo all saw gains, with Hong Kong adding 1.41%, Shanghai 0.69%, and Tokyo 0.84%. The ECB's move also led to a rally in oil prices after the death of Saudi Arabia's monarch.

site_title: China central bank to maintain prudent monetary policy, defuse risks
summary: China's central bank has decided to maintain prudent monetary policy to promote healthy economic growth while defusing financial risks. This move comes after Chinese economic growth hit a 24-year low, raising concerns about the need for further policy efforts to avoid a sharper downturn.

images.alt_text: China's central bank said on Friday it will maintain prudent monetary policy through timely fine-tuning.

site_title: Oil jumps after Saudi king's death amid huge market shifts
summary: Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah died, and his brother Salman became king, adding uncertainty to energy markets. Oil prices surged, with US benchmark WTI crude futures rising 2% to $47.76 a barrel and international benchmark Brent futures opening 1.5% higher at $49.10 per barrel. The death of the king, who was the architect of keeping oil production high, has led to market shifts, with oil prices more than halving since June last year due to soaring supplies and slowing demand.

site_title: Eastern Holdings' suit against Riway Singapore dismissed, counter-claim allowed
summary: Eastern Holdings' subsidiary Hoy Fatt's lawsuit against Riway Singapore was dismissed by the High Court on January 20. The court ruled that Riway Singapore had validly rescinded the option to purchase a six-storey building. This decision concludes the lawsuit, which began in 2013.

site_title: China: Shares higher in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares rose 0.57% in morning trade, driven by anticipation of preliminary January manufacturing data. The Shanghai Composite Index increased to 3,362.42, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.13% to 1,532.23. The gains followed a strong 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, which are also awaiting GDP data.

site_title: Ringgit climbs a second day on ECB stimulus, rally in oil price
summary: Malaysia's ringgit rose for a second day, appreciating 0.3% to 3.5915 a dollar, amid speculation of European Central Bank (ECB) stimulus and stabilizing oil prices. The ECB plans to purchase 60 billion euros of bonds monthly, boosting demand for higher-yielding assets. Oil prices, including Brent crude, have also shown signs of recovery, with a 1.8% rally on Friday. This is attributed to the ECB's stimulus and Malaysia's revision of energy cost projections, leading to a trimmed weekly loss of 0.9% for the ringgit.

site_title: HDB resale prices fall 1.5% q-o-q in Q4 2014, but transactions up 2.7%
summary: HDB resale prices fell 1.5% in Q4 2014, but transactions rose 2.7% to 4,635 cases, a 4.3% decrease in full-year transactions. Resale prices for the year fell 6.0%, while subletting approvals increased 16.2%. HDB will offer 16,900 BTO flats in 2015, including new areas.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaMall Trust, Reits, Keppel Corporation, Keppel Land
summary: Singapore's largest mall owner, CapitaMall Trust, reported a 5.1% increase in Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.86 cents, while Ascott Residence Trust surged 62% to 2.16 Singapore cents. Several other Reits released Q4 financial results, including a 1.4% rise in DPU for Ascendas Reit and a 20% rise for Frasers Commercial Trust. Keppel Corporation is expected to release its results on Friday, with trading halted pending the announcement.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Singaporean shares opened higher on Friday, with the Straits Times Index rising 20.04 points to 3,390.33. The rally marks the 5th consecutive day of gains. Volume reached 74.8 million shares worth S$75 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 115 to 42.

site_title: Brazil could auction off airports to current holders, minister says
summary: Brazil's Civil Aviation Minister Eliseu Padilha suggests auctioning off airport licenses to private investors, potentially scrapping a rule that restricts current license holders from participating. The move aims to boost competition and improve the country's aging infrastructure, a key priority for President Dilma Rousseff. The plan could involve 11 airports, with officials seeking to determine the number of license holders needed to ensure competition. The veto on current license holders could be reviewed to gauge the feasibility of the plan.

images.alt_text: Brazil may auction licenses to improve and operate as many as 11 airports to private investors as part of a broader plan to revamp privatization rules in the industry, Civil Aviation Minister Eliseu Padilha said on Thursday.

site_title: Internet will 'disappear', Google boss tells Davos
summary: Google's Eric Schmidt predicted that the Internet will "disappear" into the background due to its pervasive presence in daily life, with sensors and devices interacting with users constantly. He envisioned a highly personalized, interactive world where technology is seamlessly integrated into every aspect of life. This prediction was made during a panel discussion at the World Economic Forum in Davos, where Google, Facebook, Microsoft, and Vodafone leaders addressed concerns about technological advancement and job loss.

site_title: Sri Lanka softens its stance on China port city deal
summary: Sri Lanka's new government, led by Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, has softened its stance on a $1.5 billion port city deal with China, potentially allowing for renegotiation. The government had previously threatened to scrap the project, but now says it will reassess the deal, focusing on environmental impact, feasibility studies, and tax concessions. Construction on the project, launched by Chinese President Xi Jinping last year, will continue, but the government's change in stance may slow progress.

site_title: South Korea Q4 GDP growth slows to 0.4% q-o-q vs 0.9% in Q3
summary: South Korea's economic growth slowed to 0.4% in Q4 2014, down from 0.9% in Q3, with construction spending plummeting 9.2% in the October-December period. This marked the worst pace in almost six years, matching the median forecast of 16 analysts. The economy grew 2.7% on an annual basis, slower than the 3.2% increase in the third quarter. The decline in construction investment was the sharpest since 1998.

site_title: Singapore private home prices fall 1.1% q-o-q in Q4, down 4% for full-year 2014 (Amended)
summary: Singapore's private home prices fell 1.1% quarter-on-quarter in Q4 2014, marking the fifth straight quarter of price decline. This brings the full-year drop to 4%, reversing the 1.1% climb in 2013. The decline is attributed to a decrease in demand and slower sales growth, reversing the 1.1% climb in prices in 2013, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA).

site_title: China says Microsoft Outlook hacking allegations "groundless"
summary: China's cyberspace regulator has denied allegations that it hacked into Microsoft Outlook, calling the accusations "groundless slander". The claim was made by online censorship watchdog GreatFire.Org, which said Chinese users of the email service were subject to a hacking attack. The regulator's spokesman, Jiang Jun, stated that the accusation aimed to "incite dissatisfaction and smear China's cyberspace management system". This comes as China continues to operate its sophisticated online censorship mechanism, known as the Great Firewall, to eliminate dissent and challenges to the ruling Communist Party.

images.alt_text: Allegations that Chinese authorities hacked into Microsoft Corp's Outlook email service are "groundless slander", the official Xinhua news agency quoted Beijing's cyberspace regulator as saying late on Thursday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 1.11% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.11% on Friday following the European Central Bank's announcement of a larger-than-expected stimulus program, injecting over $1.15 trillion into the stagnant eurozone economy. European stocks rallied, and US indices added 1.5% or more, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.48%. The euro rebounded against the dollar, while the yen strengthened against both currencies. The stimulus move boosted investor confidence, with stocks extending their rally ahead of US-EU trade talks and a potential split in the Federal Reserve's views.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close higher after ECB move
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed higher on Friday after the European Central Bank announced a trillion-euro bond-buying programme to combat deflation and stimulate growth in the eurozone. Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 1.32%, the CAC 40 in Paris increased 1.52%, and London's FTSE 100 index rose 1.02%. The ECB move was seen as a positive step to boost the economy.

site_title: Oil drop a 'great opportunity' but don't rush in now: Icahn
summary: Billionaire investor Carl Icahn expects oil prices to fall further before recovering on increased demand. He considers the current oil drop a "great opportunity," but advises against rushing in now. Icahn's long-term investment approach has previously paid off, such as betting on the euro's decline against the dollar. Crude prices have dropped over half since June, and the energy sector has fallen 23% during the same period, prompting many investors to sell energy stocks.

site_title: Japan factories start 2015 on strong note, flash Jan PMI rises to 52.1
summary: Japan's manufacturing sector started 2015 on a strong note, with the Markit/JMMA flash Japan Manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) rising to 52.1 in January from 52.0 in December. The index remained above the 50 threshold, indicating expansion for the eighth consecutive month. New orders and export orders also rose, driven by a rebounding economy after a mild recession. Economists expect growth in consumer spending, exports, and capital expenditure to drive growth this year, with a decline in oil prices expected to further boost the economy.

images.alt_text: Japanese manufacturers began the new year on a strong note as domestic and overseas orders picked up, a survey showed on Friday, suggesting the economy is shrugging off a slump in consumer spending last year that triggered a recession.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.72 points to 1792.47 on Friday, with gains outnumbering losses 182 to 39. The market opened higher on the day, with a trading volume of 54.82 million lots worth RM24.06 million.

site_title: Apple's Cook gets US$9.22m in pay as stock reaches high
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook received a compensation package valued at US$9.22 million for the fiscal year that ended in September, more than double his pay in 2013. The company's stock reached a record high, and Cook's compensation includes a salary of US$1.75 million and non-equity incentive compensation of US$6.7 million. This comes after the company unveiled new products, including larger-screen iPhones and a mobile-payment system, which contributed to its record-breaking market capitalization of over US$700 billion.

site_title: Ukraine troops cede prized airport to pro-Russia rebels
summary: Ukraine's military has abandoned the Donetsk airport, a key symbolic prize in the nine-month war, after six Ukrainian troops were killed and 20 captured by pro-Russian rebels. The airport, rebuilt at a cost of $1 billion, was a symbol of Ukraine's post-Soviet emergence as a democratic state but became a battleground after the presidential election of pro-Western leader Petro Poroshenko. The rebels intend to send some of the detained soldiers to Russia for questioning, and the US has branded the conflict a "Russian occupation plan."

site_title: Euro dives to 11-year low after aggressive ECB stimulus
summary: The euro plummeted to an 11-year low of US$1.1316 after the European Central Bank (ECB) launched a massive bond-buying program to stimulate the eurozone economy. The ECB will inject over 1 trillion euros into the economy through at least September 2016, with 60 billion euros of stimulus purchased per month. The move aims to combat ultra-low inflation and prevent a deflationary spiral. Despite expectations of a moderate stimulus, the ECB's aggressive action has left investors surprised, potentially putting pressure on the euro.

site_title: Saudi King Abdullah dies, new ruler is Salman
summary: Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah died, with his brother Salman becoming the new ruler. Salman has appointed Muqrin as his crown prince and heir. Abdullah, who ruled since 2006, had been regent for a decade before that.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah (pictured) has died, state television reported early on Friday and his brother Salman became king, it said in a statement attributed to Salman.

site_title: City buzz
summary: A 20-year veteran of the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical "CATS", Jo-Anne Robinson has had a remarkable career. The article highlights various lifestyle topics, including a new mod-Indian cuisine restaurant, a charity event to engage volunteers, a zero-waste initiative, and a partnership to promote financial literacy for women. Additionally, it touches on the concept of corporate purpose, a documentary series about retailers, and design solutions for unusual home layouts.

site_title: Ford goes Silicon Valley with new research centre
summary: Ford opened a new research centre in Silicon Valley, aiming to advance connected vehicles, autonomous driving, and big data technologies. The centre, headed by Dragos Maciuca, will have 125 researchers and engineers, and is expected to be one of the largest automotive manufacturer research centres in the US by the end of the year. The move is part of Ford's efforts to make these new technologies accessible to everyone, not just luxury customers. The centre will collaborate with technology leaders outside the automotive industry to create and apply innovative mobility solutions.

site_title: CapitaMall Trust Q4 DPU up 5.1% to 2.86 cents
summary: CapitaMall Trust reported a 5.1% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.86 cents, driven by a 2.2% revenue growth to S$165.2 million. Net property income fell 4.1% due to higher operating expenses. Occupancies remained high at 98.8%. The company's joint ventures saw significant revenue and net property income growth, driven by the start of Westgate's operations. Net asset value per unit rose to S$1.81, resulting in a price-to-book ratio of 1.22 times.

site_title: Harper backs Bank of Canada rate cut; no fiscal stimulus planned
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper expressed confidence in the Bank of Canada's decision to cut interest rates, citing the threat of economic growth and inflation targets from the oil price plunge. Harper stated the government would balance the budget in 2015/16, despite billions in lost government revenue from the 60% decline in oil prices since June. Harper downplayed the need for fiscal stimulus measures, citing the economy's growth and the Bank of Canada's prediction of some growth this year.

site_title: Fed's solo act gets tougher with ECB, others in stimulus mode
summary: The Federal Reserve's plans to raise interest rates are becoming more challenging due to the actions of other central banks, including the European Central Bank, which recently cut rates and increased stimulus. The ECB's move has deepened the divide between the Fed and other central banks, heightening risks and uncertainty surrounding the Fed's plans. The Fed will face increased downward pressure on market rates and a potential flood of money from investors seeking safe-haven assets, making it harder for the Fed to proceed with its plans to end crisis-era policies.

site_title: Oil price drop 'threatens 23,000 jobs in Canada'
summary: Canada's oil sector and supporting industries face significant job losses due to a fast-falling oil price, with 23,000 jobs potentially at risk. The Canadian Association of Oilwell Drilling Contractors projects a 46% drop in active wells from 370 to 203 in 2015, resulting in 3,400 oil sector jobs and 19,500 indirect jobs lost. The forecast is based on an oil price of US$55 a barrel.

site_title: 4,000 property agents drop out, over 50 agencies throw in towel
summary: Around 4,000 property agents have dropped out of the industry in Singapore over the past year, with over 50 agencies closing shop, amidst sagging property sales. Despite this, 3,006 new agents joined the industry in January.

images.alt_text: Buffeted by sagging property sales, close to 4,000 real estate agents have dropped out of the industry while over 50 agencies have closed shop over the past year.

site_title: US housing construction at highest since recession
summary: US housing construction is expected to reach its highest level since the recession in 2009, with 1.15 million starts forecasted for 2015, a 15% increase from last year. Low mortgage rates, a strong labor market, and easing credit standards are driving the growth. This is expected to boost economic growth, potentially adding 1 percentage point to the 2.6-3% forecast, and bolster the Federal Reserve's confidence in the economic outlook. Stronger housing could also offset a deteriorating trade balance and less investment in energy, making it a pivotal factor in growth this year and next.

site_title: SGX plans to trade Chinese equity-index options
summary: SGX plans to start trading Chinese equity-index options, with approval pending from the China Securities Regulatory Commission. This move aims to hedge risks in China's volatile stock market. Volume on China A50 futures traded in Singapore surged 183% in the last quarter. The Singapore bourse reported its first quarterly profit growth since 2013, driven by derivatives and options trading, which accounted for 39% of revenue. The introduction of options on the FTSE China A50 Index is seen as a way to expand the bourse's offerings and attract investors.

site_title: US: Stocks soar 1.5% after ECB embarks on bond purchases
summary: US stocks surged 1.5% on Thursday after the European Central Bank announced a $69 billion monthly bond-buying program to boost the eurozone economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite all rose, with bank and tech stocks leading the gains. The move sent the euro down 2% against the dollar and boosted stocks across Europe. The ECB's actions are expected to increase liquidity in the economy, potentially benefiting stocks or bonds.

site_title: Microsoft to give away Windows 10, unveils hologram glasses
summary: Microsoft will give away its upcoming Windows 10 operating system as a free upgrade to users of the most recent versions of Windows and Windows Phone, aiming to retain customers in the mobile era. The company will also release hologram glasses, HoloLens, which allows users to see three-dimensional renderings of computer-generated images. This move is part of Microsoft's cloud-centric strategy, expected to generate significant revenue from services like Office over the Internet. The free upgrade is seen as a calculated gamble, with limited revenue impact initially, but potentially leading to major opportunities.

images.alt_text: The Microsoft HoloLens allows users to see three-dimensional renderings of computer-generated images. The device, which will be available around the same time as Windows 10 this autumn, is wireless and looks like a visor.

site_title: Google reaches for sky-high Internet connections
summary: Google has invested $1 billion in SpaceX, a private rocket company, to develop high-altitude satellites for global Internet connectivity. The move aims to spread the Internet to underserved areas worldwide, increasing control over the experience and potential revenue for Google. Similar efforts by Facebook, OneWeb, and Planet Labs also focus on satellite-based Internet services, driven by declining satellite costs and increasing demand for bandwidth. This initiative reflects Google's strategy to bypass Internet service providers and reach consumers directly, ultimately boosting ad revenue.

site_title: JTC rolls out new and improved industrial price, rental indices
summary: JTC Corporation has introduced new industrial price and rental indices in Singapore, providing more granular data to help businesses make informed decisions. The indices offer expanded data coverage and improved methodology, in response to increased lobbying from stakeholders. The move aims to better reflect the industrial landscape and provide more detailed rental data. This enhancement is expected to support businesses and policymakers in their decision-making processes.

site_title: HK financiers challenge China in newspaper ad
summary: A group of pro-democracy financiers in Hong Kong, HK Finance Monitor 2047, has taken out a quarter-page ad in the Wall Street Journal challenging China to respect the city's autonomy and introduce free elections. The ad lists 10 requests to the Chinese Communist Party, including establishing universal suffrage and defending freedoms. The campaign comes after months of rallies for fully free leadership elections, which ended in December. The group, consisting of 70 finance workers, aims to stand together to fight for true democracy in Hong Kong.

site_title: Opec head forecasts oil will rebound rather than fall to US$20
summary: Opec's secretary-general, Abdalla El-Badri, forecasts oil prices will rebound rather than decline to US$20 per barrel due to a lack of merit in the current supply and demand imbalance. Producers outside Opec should prioritize reducing output amid a surplus, which has pushed crude below US$50 per barrel. Iraq, Opec's fastest-growing supplier, aims to boost output to compensate for revenue losses due to the price slump.

site_title: Bankers say big is beautiful, safe and economic
summary: Europe's bankers defended the big bank model at the World Economic Forum in Davos, citing the mounting cost of regulation and the potential risks of splitting firms. JPMorgan's Jamie Dimon and HSBC's Douglas Flint stated that breaking up banks would be bad for financial prestige and that there is no better model. Despite pressure from regulators and investors, many bankers believe that the universal banking model is still viable, with Deutsche Bank considering splitting off its retail division and Barclays' boss Antony Jenkins stating the model is dead.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan, the biggest US bank by assets, has faced growing pressure to consider a break-up, and similar questions are being put to less profitable European rivals such as Deutsche Bank, Barclays and Credit Suisse.

site_title: Barclays execs named by New York A-G in amended dark pool complaint
summary: New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman has amended a complaint against Barclays, naming several executives for misrepresenting how algorithms in its dark pool worked and how client orders were routed to customers. The complaint, filed in the New York Supreme Court, alleges false representations made by Barclays executives. This marks the first time individuals at the bank have been named in the complaint.

site_title: eBay to shed 2,400 jobs ahead of PayPal IPO
summary: eBay is cutting 2,400 jobs, about 7% of its workforce, as it restructures ahead of spinning off its PayPal finance unit. The job cuts will be across three divisions: Marketplaces, Enterprise, and PayPal. eBay's fourth-quarter profit rose 10% to $936 million, and the company expects to spin off PayPal in the second half of the year. The restructuring aims to simplify the organization, reduce complexity, and create competitive cost structures. eBay's CEO, John Donahoe, said the move is necessary to position the company for success.

site_title: KepCorp, KepLand results briefings today
summary: KepCorp and its real estate subsidiary Keppel Land are holding results briefings for the media and analysts on Friday. The briefings were postponed from earlier in the week, sparking speculation about potential privatization of Keppel Land or asset swaps between the property firm and its parent company. The postponement was unusual, as the full-year results were announced on schedule for both companies. The briefings will take place at 2pm for Keppel Corporation and 5pm for Keppel Land.

site_title: Shedding light on a British WWII warrior in tweed
summary: The Imitation Game tells the story of Alan Turing, a British WWII code-breaker who contributed to the Allied victory despite being a socially awkward genius. Turing, played by Benedict Cumberbatch, works with a team to decode German messages using the Enigma device. His determination and genius lead to a breakthrough, but Turing's personal life is marred by prosecution for homosexuality in post-war Britain. The film sheds light on Turing's pioneering work in computer science and his tragic fate, earning a posthumous pardon in 2013. Turing's contributions to the war effort remain a testament to his service to nation.

site_title: KL budget revision may still fall short of compensating for oil price plunge
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak has unveiled a revised budget in response to the 50% decline in oil prices, scaling down economic growth projections to 4.5-5.5% and reducing the fiscal deficit target to 3.2% of GDP. However, economists question the realism of these numbers, citing a lower oil price forecast and potential headwinds such as a 6% goods and services tax and a weakening ringgit. The International Monetary Fund has also lowered its global growth forecast, and some economists estimate a higher fiscal deficit. The revised budget includes measures to boost consumption, but may not be enough to cushion the blow from the oil price plunge.

site_title: Illegal short-term rentals in NY under scrutiny as complaints surge
summary: Complaints about illegal short-term rentals in New York City surged 62% last year, reaching 1,150, prompting regulators to target apartment owners using websites like Airbnb. The complaints led to 900 inspections and 600 violations, with many safety procedures lacking. Despite Airbnb's claims that problems are rare, Attorney General Eric Schneiderman estimates 72% of reservations in NYC are illegal. Regulators aim to identify and address the issue, focusing on large commercial operators rather than individual hosts.

site_title: More news from the art world
summary: Singapore Art Week has announced several art developments, including a partnership between UOB and the National Gallery Singapore to showcase 8,000 modern South-east Asian art works. Local artist Ho Tzu Nyen won the Asia Pacific Breweries Foundation Signature Art Prize for his multi-sensory installation "Pythagoras". The new Singapore Pinacotheque de Paris will open in May with an exhibition on the myth of Cleopatra, while emerging artist Sookoon Ang will be mentored by Indian artist Jitish Kallat in a Lohia Mentorship series.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: M'sia banks on private consumption to boost economy
summary: Malaysia's economy is relying on private consumption to boost growth, with the government planning to extend shopping hours and increase mega sales to stimulate domestic demand. Despite weaker seasonal sales, the country saw robust vehicle sales in December, with 55,313 units sold, a 2.1% month-on-month increase. The move aims to counter the impact of plummeting oil prices and weaker global growth, with growth projected at 4.5-5.5% this year.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q4 distribution per unit up at 2.577 cents
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 11% increase in distribution income for Q4 FY14 to S$64.56 million, driven by the completion of Suntec City Phase 2 and improved contributions from existing properties. Distribution per unit rose to 2.577 cents, while gross revenue and net property income also increased. The Reit's office and retail portfolios remain fully leased, with 91.3% and 99.6% committed occupancy, respectively. The Reit's assets under management stood at S$8.8 billion as of Dec 31, 2014.

site_title: China banks see loophole in leasing firms
summary: China's major banks have increased lending to financial leasing companies to meet new capital adequacy rules under Basel III regulations. This move allows them to cut provisions for loans to these companies, which are considered safe borrowers, from 25% to 100%. Leasing companies buy assets like ships and heavy machinery, then lease them to firms that would have borrowed directly from banks. Despite this, leasing companies are not afraid to lend to companies in volatile sectors, such as the shipping industry, which has been struggling since 2008.

site_title: Japan predicted to see powerful economic uptrend this year
summary: Japan is predicted to see a powerful economic uptrend in 2015, with the country likely to achieve its 2% target inflation rate by early next year, according to Etsuro Honda, special adviser to Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The country's Abenomics policy package, which includes monetary easing, fiscal stimulus, and growth strategy, aims to lift Japan out of two decades of deflation by 2020. Despite some improvements, the growth strategy will take time to yield results, and companies are advised to explore long-term investment opportunities in sectors such as hospitality and real estate.

site_title: KepLand, StarHub, CDL, CapitaLand win kudos for sustainability policies (Amended)
summary: Four Singapore companies, Keppel Land, StarHub, City Developments (CDL), and CapitaLand, have made it to the Global 100 Most Sustainable Corporations list, recognizing their commitment to corporate sustainability. Keppel Land moved up to fourth position, retaining its top ranking in Asia and real estate worldwide. StarHub improved its ranking to 24th, while CDL moved up to 34th spot. CapitaLand fell to 84th position. The companies attribute their success to their sustainability policies and commitment to the environment.

site_title: Unilever sends frightening message on deteriorating global growth
summary: Unilever reports its 2014 sales improvement was the weakest in over a decade, with a 2.9% increase in underlying sales. The company expects no significant improvement in market conditions in 2015, citing weak emerging markets, a modest pick-up in North America, and a market contraction in Europe. Global food prices have dropped by a fifth since 2011, and consumers are curbing their spending, restricting market expansion to 3%. This grim outlook raises concerns for retailers, particularly in Europe.

site_title: Wilsonian Moment in US foreign relations
summary: US President Barack Obama's support for popular demands for democracy in the Middle East during the Arab Spring shares similarities with President Woodrow Wilson's advocacy for independence in colonized countries in 1919, dubbed the "Wilsonian Moment." Wilson's rhetoric radicalized freedom movements in Korea, China, Vietnam, India, and Egypt, inspiring similar protests during the Arab Spring. However, unlike Wilson, Obama's efforts led to the collapse of dictators in Egypt and other countries, while China's nationalist movement eventually achieved greater autonomy. The Wilsonian Moment marked a turning point in US foreign relations, announcing an eventual end to colonial empires, and its legacy continues to influence US presidents' approaches to promoting democracy abroad.

site_title: US banks stop selling account data to payday lenders
summary: US banks have stopped selling account data to payday lenders, a move aimed at curbing abusive practices. Early Warning Services, owned by major banks, has discontinued service to lenders that use the data to select borrowers. The decision reflects regulators' efforts to address concerns over high-interest loans that can ensnare borrowers in debt cycles.
