Hundreds of banks use Early Warning to prevent fraud, but the move may hurt payday lenders already facing mounting regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: Ascendas Reit Q3 DPU up at 3.59¢
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a 3.59¢ DPU for its Q3 2014, slightly higher than the previous year. Gross revenue rose 11.2% to S$171.7 million, driven by rental income from Hyflux Innovation Centre and higher occupancies.

site_title: Ascott trust unit price up as Q4 DPU surges
summary: Ascott Residence Trust reported a 62% year-on-year surge in fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.16 cents, driven by a 15% increase in semi-annual distribution. Full-year DPU dipped 2% to 8.2 cents. The Reit expects steady growth from acquisitions and renovations of existing properties, with hopes for a busy 2015. Ascott acquired 1,800 apartment units in 2014, with revenue rising 13% to S$357 million. Occupancy rates are maintained at 80% and the Reit does not expect business to be affected by potential changes in short-term rental rules.

site_title: Show of strength
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several art exhibitions are taking place in Singapore during Art Week. The Prudential Singapore Eye exhibition at the ArtScience Museum features 17 artists, including Kumari Nahappan and Lee Wen, and includes a coffee-table book with 62 artists. The History of Java exhibition at Fost Gallery explores the myth and history of Sir Stamford Raffles in Java through charcoal drawings. The installation "John Scripps, Or The Butcher And The Surgeon" at Golden Mile Tower blends fact and fiction to recreate a hotel room where a murder took place. Other exhibitions include "Along The Golden Mile" and "Impress: New Works".

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Angela Chong's 3D Tic Tac Toe, a multi-player game using fibre optics, LED light engines, coated steel structure with 4 player stands.
Gerald Leow's The Decline of the Western Civilisation (detail).
Donna Ong's And We Were Like Those Who Dreamed.
Jimmy Ong's charcoal work titled Rampogan Macan. The exhibition also includes installation and video works.
This installation looks like the scene of a 1995 murder in River View Hotel, but a closer look at the keyhole and mirror opens up criminal dioramas.
Darren Soh's Along The Golden Mile attempts to capture the rich blend of architectural styles found within the Beach Road and Jalan Sultan area
Victor's decollage work Imprint By Subtraction is one of the highlights of the STPI exhibition

site_title: Musical boost for Singa-Pop
summary: Local musicians Olivia Ong, Hanjin Tan, and indie acts Hanging Up The Moon and Pleasantry are set to perform at upcoming festivals, marking a promising year for Singapore's music scene. Olivia Ong, a 29-year-old Mandopop idol, is returning to Singapore for her biggest-ever solo show after spending a decade abroad. Hanjin Tan, a 38-year-old songwriter-producer, will also perform two intimate shows in Singapore after achieving success in Hong Kong. The indie bands Hanging Up The Moon and Pleasantry will perform at St Jerome's Laneway Festival and The Gathering, respectively, gaining exposure to a larger audience.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

A multilingual songbird who has recorded in English, Mandarin and Japanese, Ong says "working with the musicians in this concert has helped me realise the amount of opportunities and talent we now have here"
Hanjin is now one of the region's most sought-after songwriter- producers.
Hanging Up The Moon will perform on Saturday before a sold-out crowd of 13,000 at this year's St Jerome's Laneway Festival.
Pleasantry is all set to perform alongside a list of established overseas names, including Belle and Sebastian, at a new music fest, The Gathering.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: DBS Group Research maintains a "hold" rating on the Singapore Exchange, lifting its target price to S$7.30 due to Q2 FY2015 earnings in line and a surge in derivatives activities. OCBC Investment Research upgrades Soilbuild Business Space Reit to "buy" with a target price of S$0.93, driven by its strong Q4 2014 results and attractive distribution yield of 8.2%.

site_title: Otis gets a lift from recovering Spanish economy
summary: Spanish elevator company Zardoya Otis sees higher sales in 2015 due to the recovery of the Spanish economy, with new residential building projects starting to pick up in cities like Madrid and Barcelona. The company expects to sell more elevators in Spain, driven by increased investment in building refurbishment and modern elevator equipment. Despite a seven-year slump in the real estate market, Spain's unique housing policy and high demand for apartments are expected to drive growth in the sector. However, a patchy recovery is anticipated, with home sales of new homes decreasing 21% in November.

site_title: Boeing unions seek to put conditions on tax credits
summary: Boeing's two largest labor unions are working on legislative bills to put conditions on $8.7 billion in tax credits given to the company and the state aerospace industry in 2013. The tax credits were a condition of Boeing's decision to locate production of its 777X jetliner in Washington state. Altering the tax credits could change the business case for that decision. The unions are seeking to ensure that the tax credits are tied to specific labor and environmental conditions.

site_title: Obama's visit to India more than just symbolic
summary: US President Barack Obama's visit to India is more than a symbolic gesture, despite being his last visit as a lameduck president. The trip aims to boost diplomatic momentum, create a sense of momentum for the US-India relationship, and generate powerful images that can influence public opinion and elite attitudes. The visit includes business deals, military agreements, and a visit to the Taj Mahal, which can overshadow simple policy considerations. The trip's impact on the US-India relationship will be significant, even if its immediate effects are minimal.

site_title: Marriott wants to lure millennials with cheaper, ultraslim rooms
summary: Marriott is launching a new line of stylish microhotels under the Moxy flag, targeting millennials with cheaper, ultraslim rooms. The hotels will feature trendy bars and space-efficient rooms with amenities such as free WiFi, luxurious power showers, and art pieces. Locations include New York, San Francisco, and Seattle, offering a European hostel-like experience. This move aims to attract younger guests who prefer more affordable and stylish accommodations, differentiating Marriott from traditional hotel rooms.

site_title: Ultra-wealthy investors' three top concerns in 2015
summary: Ultra-wealthy investors face three key concerns in 2015: diversifying away from concentrated holdings, managing cash holdings at historic low interest rates, and coping with predicted US interest rate rises. To address these concerns, investors can use various strategies, such as offsetting core holdings with less correlated investments or actively hedging positions. Real asset investments, like real estate and farmland, offer higher returns and long-term certainty, particularly when tied to underlying themes like population growth.

site_title: Shenzhen govt seen wooing developers to invest in Kaisa
summary: The Shenzhen government is in talks with Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd, a Chinese developer, to orchestrate investments after the company failed to make a US$23 million coupon payment on its US$500 million dollar bonds. Kaisa's projects were blocked, and key executives quit, amid allegations of links to a former security chief. The government aims to prevent the sale of stakes at a discount. Kaisa has already faced lawsuits over its assets, including a frozen 540 million yuan deposit.

site_title: Six bodies recovered near jet fuselage
summary: Six bodies were recovered near the main section of the AirAsia plane that crashed into the Java Sea on December 28, bringing the total to 59 recovered bodies. The bodies were found among debris, with some still strapped into their seats, not far from the jet's main section. Despite efforts to reach the fuselage, search teams were unable to recover it due to strong underwater currents and limited visibility. The jet's black boxes were recovered last week, and investigators are analyzing them. The cause of the crash remains unknown, with radar data showing the plane had climbed faster than normal before stalling.

site_title: Apple buys data analysis company
summary: Apple has acquired Semetric, a data analysis company that tracks online music consumption, in a move that may hint at Apple's ambitions to revamp iTunes and Beats Music. Semetric, known for its Musicmetric service, provides data on streaming services and social media chatter to clients like record companies and talent agents. The acquisition, which was confirmed by a person briefed on the deal, is Apple's latest investment in streaming music and data, following its purchase of Beats last year.

site_title: Africa's oil boom put on hold as prices spur explorer caution
summary: Africa's oil and gas boom is in jeopardy due to the global drop in oil prices, prompting explorers to reconsider the high costs of exploration on the continent. Despite billions of dollars invested in promising oilfields, the dash for resources is stalling. The caution is fueled by the high costs of exploration, which is leading to a decrease in investment and potential delays in the development of these fields. This shift could have significant implications for the African economy and the global energy market.

site_title: Emirates vows to buy 100 more A380s if Airbus agrees to upgrade the jets
summary: Emirates has vowed to buy 100 more A380s if Airbus agrees to upgrade the jets with a new engine, worth over $43 billion. The upgrade, dubbed Neo, would reduce seat-mile costs by 10-13% and appeal to customers. Emirates president Tim Clark urged other carriers to re-evaluate the A380 as a solution to capacity constraints at airports in the next 3-7 years. Airbus is under pressure to commit to the Neo upgrade, as sales slow and the company focuses on boosting A350 production.

site_title: China's 'new normal' masks old anxieties
summary: China's "new normal" concept, used by Premier Li Keqiang and others to describe the country's slowdown, disguises the fact that the situation is far from normal. The 7.4% expansion in 2014 was the slowest rate in 24 years, and describing it as normal suggests the miss is deliberate and targets are less binding. The term is also a political statement, allowing Xi Jinping to criticize his predecessors' economic policies without openly doing so. However, the concept's sustainability is uncertain, with fixed asset investment and housing under construction showing signs of decline.

images.alt_text: Economists, business leaders and most lately Premier Li Keqiang have used the phrase "new normal" to explain China's slowdown.

site_title: Procter & Gamble unveils management shake-up
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has announced a management shake-up, effective February 1. David Taylor, group president for global health and grooming, will take over the company's global beauty unit, responsible for 40% of revenue. Deb Henretta, who will oversee global online business, will step down. The changes suggest Henretta may no longer be in the running for CEO, with Taylor's expanded role seen as a step towards the top position. P&G is undergoing a corporate restructuring, including the potential divestment of up to 100 brands.

site_title: Leave no one behind in pursuit of global sustainable development
summary: The United Nations will launch the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in 2015, replacing the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) that expire in 2015. The SDGs aim to eradicate poverty, dignify people, and save the planet by 2030. To achieve success, the narrative must be transformed to focus on ownership, enfranchisement, and empowerment among individuals, political blocs, mega-city based BRIC countries, and global faith traditions. These demographics must work together to achieve scale and impact through technology, institutionalization, and greater regional integration.

site_title: Ryanair eyes feeder role for long-haul routes
summary: Ryanair's CEO Michael O'Leary stated that legacy airlines such as British Airways, Air France-KLM, and Lufthansa may use low-cost carriers like Ryanair to feed passengers onto their long-haul routes, as it is too expensive for them to compete on intra-European flights. Ryanair plans to expand into larger airports, potentially flying into London Heathrow, and is open to connecting with US or Gulf airline flights. The airline has also ruled out selling its 29.9% stake in Aer Lingus, but would consider any offer.

site_title: No upside for 2013 Burgundies despite tight supply
summary: The 2013 Burgundy wine vintage is experiencing steady or declining prices, despite tight supplies due to cold, wet weather and yields below average for the fourth consecutive year. Demand remains strong in the US, UK, and Japan, but prices for 2012 wines are easing. Experts describe 2013 as a "very good vintage" but not consistent across the board, with some regions producing quality wines. Prices for 2013 Burgundies are being kept stable, with the prospect of reducing them for the 2014 vintage, which is expected to have a larger crop and softer prices.

site_title: Del Monte Pacific defers US$360m preference share offering
summary: Del Monte Pacific has postponed a US$360 million preference share offering due to weak global market conditions. The company cited a lack of investor demand, citing the oil price crash and sell-down in high-yield bonds. It plans to extend its bridge loan and monitor the markets before resuming the offering. The company aims to reduce its gearing levels through equity raising and debt paydown from cashflows, following its US$1.7 billion acquisition of Del Monte Foods.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust DPU up 20% in Q1
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust reported a 22% year-over-year growth in distributable income to S$16.7 million in Q1, driven by higher contributions from Alexandra Technopark and higher occupancy rates. The Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) increased by 20% to 2.46 cents. Gross revenue rose 23.3% and net property income (NPI) increased 15% to S$25.4 million. The Reit's CEO attributed the growth to the increased contribution from Alexandra Technopark, which will boost future growth in NPI and DPU.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Swiss chocolate maker says strong franc could hurt results
summary: Swiss chocolate maker Barry Callebaut warned that the strong Swiss franc could negatively impact its results, despite sales revenue rising 15.1% in the first quarter. The company's reporting currency is the Swiss franc, which could lead to currency translation impacts. Global sales volumes lagged estimates, and sales of cocoa bean by-products fell 1.8%. Barry Callebaut confirmed its mid-term targets but noted the currency impact, which could affect its earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) per tonne.

site_title: Kinder Morgan to buy rival pipeline firm for US$3b
summary: Kinder Morgan, the world's largest pipeline company, agreed to buy Hiland Partners for about $3 billion to gain a foothold in the Bakken shale formation. The deal, valued at $3 billion including debt, is Kinder Morgan's latest move to dominate US gas shipping. The company reported a 63% decline in fourth-quarter net income due to writing down oil and natural gas properties. Shares fell 2.4% after the announcement.

site_title: Gucci accessories chief is named creative director in bid to boost sales
summary: Kering has promoted Alessandro Michele, Gucci's head of accessories, to creative director in an effort to boost sales. Michele replaces Frida Giannini, who was asked to leave, and will have total creative responsibility for all Gucci collections and brand image. The move aims to inject new ideas into the brand, focusing on accessories, particularly leather goods, which have emerged as a fast-growing category in luxury. Analysts believe Michele's appointment signals a gamble on the Gucci brand and accessories, betting that the brand's power and Gucci's accessories can drive sales.

site_title: Industrial capital values, rents dip in Q4; occupancy at 90.9%
summary: Industrial property prices and rentals in Singapore decreased by 0.1% and 0.6% respectively in Q4 2014, while occupancy rates remained steady at 90.9%. The decline in prices was largely due to the low base in the previous year, and the impact of growing industrial space supply. Rentals fell 2% year-over-year, while tender prices for large Industrial Government Land Sales sites moderated. However, demand for small IGLS plots remained strong, and some 2.6 million square feet of industrial space is expected to come onstream this year.

site_title: Keppel Corp's Q4 profit up 6.1% at S$725.9m on higher revenue
summary: Keppel Corp posted a 6.1% increase in Q4 net profit to S$725.9 million, driven by a 9.1% rise in revenue to S$3.93 billion. The company also declared a final cash dividend of 36 Singapore cents per share, raising the year's payout to 48 cents per share. Despite lower oil prices and a softer property market, Keppel's results demonstrate its resilience.

site_title: Euro inches higher ahead of ECB decision
summary: The euro rose above 11-year lows ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting, where it is expected to launch massive stimulus. Traders believe the euro will continue to fall but are selling into rallies, making the currency's gains volatile. The Swiss franc surged 20% following the Swiss National Bank's removal of its cap, while emerging currencies like the Taiwanese dollar and Indonesian rupiah strengthened due to expectations of ECB stimulus.

images.alt_text: The euro held more than one US cent above 11-year lows on Thursday, ahead of a European Central Bank (ECB) policy meeting expected to launch the outright money-printing the bank has steadfastly avoided since 2008.

site_title: US court says JPMorgan must live with US$1.5b paperwork error
summary: A federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled that JPMorgan Chase & Co must live with a $1.5 billion paperwork error that unsecured a loan to General Motors in 2008. The mistake, made by JPMorgan's law firm, included a lien that secured the loan, which was later terminated. The court found that JPMorgan effectively authorized the termination of the security interest despite not intending to, and the decision reverses a previous ruling by US Bankruptcy Judge Robert Gerber. JPMorgan is reviewing the decision and its options.

site_title: Vossloh boss to bid 447m euros for German trainmaker
summary: Vossloh AG chairman Heinz Hermann Thiele plans to bid 447 million euros (S$690 million) for the remaining 70% stake in German trainmaker Vossloh, offering 48-49 euros per share through his KB Holding GmbH. This bid aims to acquire the remaining 30% stake owned by other investors.

site_title: SME body calls for framework to certify student employees
summary: The Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (Asme) in Singapore is calling for a framework to certify student employees who work in SMEs, allowing them to translate these certifications into university credits. This move aims to support SMEs in finding local talent and increase productivity. The Asme's Business Sentiment Survey found that 68.2% of SMEs are considering overseas expansion, with Indonesia being the most popular choice. The government is also urged to provide practical measures to support SMEs, including increased support for market penetration, grant availability, and low-cost industrial spaces.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

The Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (Asme) is calling on the government to develop a structured framework or curriculum to allow small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to provide certification to students who were employed within their organisations.

site_title: Catching the unsuspecting shopper
summary: A pop-up art gallery, K+, has opened at Scotts Square in Singapore, aiming to show that shopping and art can coexist. Curated by Kinetic, a design and advertising agency, the gallery features local artist Cheok Keng Lye's artwork, which can be purchased. The mobile gallery's flexibility allows for tailored shows and brands according to the venue, enhancing the experience for visitors. This is the first in a series of seven exhibitions, showcasing artists from Singapore, Japan, and Hong Kong.

site_title: Creating likenesses out of steel mesh
summary: Former Singapore Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew's likeness is featured in Art Stage Singapore, inspiring works by Korean artist Park Seung Mo. Park created five steel mesh portraits, including one of Mr. Lee, using a subtractive method and a gadget to achieve three-dimensional shapes. The artwork, priced at S$29,000, will donate part of the proceeds to the Sing50 Fund. Other artists, including Gao Qiang and Nan Qi, have also created works featuring Mr. Lee, highlighting his significant influence on the art world. Park's artwork showcases the versatility of steel mesh as a medium.

site_title: US: Shares boosted by ECB stimulus plan
summary: The European Central Bank's larger-than-expected stimulus plan boosted US shares in opening trade on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 62.42 points (0.36%) to 17,616.70, the S&P 500 gaining 6.07 (0.30%) to 2,038.19, and the Nasdaq Composite rising 10.72 (0.23%) to 4,668.14.

site_title: Opportunities galore for Singapore firms to tap Israeli technologies
summary: Singapore firms have numerous opportunities to tap into Israeli technologies, driven by the country's excellent reputation in the Israeli market and strong ties between the two nations. In 2014, Israeli startups witnessed record exits and raised nearly $1 billion in financing rounds, making them a hot commodity globally. The quick turnaround from founding to acquisition for Israeli tech startups is also notable, averaging just 3.8 years. With its innovative and disruptive technologies, Israel is an attractive option for Singaporean corporations seeking to access cutting-edge solutions, such as big data analytics, cyber protection, and automation technology.

site_title: Case building for RBA chief to relent, cut interest rate
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has kept its benchmark interest rate at a record low for 17 months, the longest period on hold in almost two decades. Economists are urging the central bank to cut interest rates again, citing a shift from a mining investment boom to bust. The prolonged low interest rate period has led to concerns about the economy's future growth.

images.alt_text: Mr Stevens has been reluctant to reduce the overnight cash rate target from 2.5 per cent

site_title: Eurozone consumer confidence rises to -8.5 in Jan
summary: Eurozone consumer confidence rose 2.4 points to -8.5 in January, according to the European Commission. This marks a slight improvement from the previous month. Consumer confidence in the 28-nation European Union also increased by 1.7 points to -5.8.

site_title: Yahoo could become takeover target without stake in Alibaba
summary: Yahoo! Inc could become a takeover target without its stake in Alibaba Group Holding if it spins off its remaining shares, making it a more manageable acquisition size. Analysts predict SoftBank Corp or private-equity firms may be interested in buying Yahoo, which would leave shareholders with a US$5-8 billion US internet advertising and search business. Marissa Mayer is expected to provide an update on her plans next week, with options including a tax-free spinoff or a cash-rich split, both of which could make Yahoo a more appealing target for potential buyers.

site_title: Allocations likely for middle class: economist
summary: Singapore's 2015 Budget is likely to target the middle class with increased social spending, alongside expectations of a "jubilee" Budget to celebrate SG50 celebrations and a possible election. The budget may include handouts, tax rebates, and expanded workfare, with a focus on healthcare and supporting smaller firms. The government may also unveil details of the Silver Support Scheme to supplement retirement savings for the elderly.

site_title: Opec's Badri says oil won't fall to US$20: Bloomberg
summary: Opec Secretary-General Abdullah al-Badri stated that oil prices won't fall to US$20 or US$25 per barrel, instead predicting they will remain stable. This comes after Opec decided not to cut its own output at a November meeting, contributing to a 60% decline in oil prices since June.

images.alt_text: Oil prices will not fall to US$20 or US$25 a barrel, Opec Secretary-General Abdullah al-Badri said in an interview with Bloomberg.

site_title: ECB commits to trillion-euro QE
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has committed to a trillion-euro quantitative easing program, purchasing 60 billion euros of bonds each month from March to September 2016. The move aims to strengthen demand, credit growth, and stimulate inflation to reach the 2% target. ECB President Mario Draghi said the measures will be effective and raise inflation expectations, while also providing banks with more money to lend to the private sector. The program will begin in March and is seen as a significant expansion of the ECB's previous asset purchase programs.

site_title: IMF welcomes ECB bond-buying, calls for more actions
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) welcomed the European Central Bank's (ECB) decision to buy 60 billion euros in government bonds, expected to boost the eurozone economy. IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde said the move should reinforce the ECB's accommodative policies, lowering borrowing costs and raising inflation expectations. However, Lagarde emphasized the need for comprehensive policy actions, including structural reforms, to support potential growth and ensure broad political support for demand management policies.

site_title: Merkel says ECB moves should not obscure need to reform
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel stated that the European Central Bank's efforts to boost growth should not overshadow the need for economic reforms by European politicians. Merkel emphasized that policymakers must take decisive action to address structural issues, rather than relying on measures to "buy time." This message came during her speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

site_title: Japanese IS hostages: approaching deadline raises tension levels
summary: Tension mounts as Japan approaches a 72-hour deadline to pay a $200 ransom to Islamic State (IS) for the release of two Japanese hostages, Haruna Yukawa and Kenji Goto. Despite efforts by the Japanese government to secure negotiating channels, IS militants have threatened to kill the pair unless the ransom is paid. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga has confirmed the hostages' safety is uncertain, and the government is exploring every possibility to save their lives. The crisis could become a major embarrassment for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, who recently pledged $200 million in aid to anti-IS efforts.

site_title: Merkel warns Europe not to stray from reform path after ECB move
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel warned European leaders not to ease off on economic reforms after the European Central Bank's announcement of a bond-buying program to bolster the euro area. Merkel praised reform progress in Italy and France, but emphasized the need for more decisive action by governments. The ECB's quantitative easing program aims to bring about a sustained reversal of the downtrend in inflation, with monthly purchases of 60 billion euros. Merkel said the euro crisis has not been overcome and Europe lacks sufficient competitiveness.

site_title: Spot on target over sniper loneliness
summary: American Sniper, a film directed by Clint Eastwood, tells the story of Chris Kyle, a Navy SEAL sharpshooter who served four tours in Iraq, earning a record number of kills and a reputation as a hero. Eastwood's film is a character study that blends war and domestic drama, exploring Kyle's intense combat, personal life, and the sad irony of his legend. Kyle's deadly skill with a rifle even earned him a bounty from Iraqi insurgents. The film is a tribute to Kyle's larger-than-life story and his unwavering patriotism.

site_title: Bill Gross invested more than $700 mln in Janus bond fund
summary: Bill Gross, a prominent bond fund manager, has invested over $700 million of his own money into the Janus Global Unconstrained Bond Fund. This move aims to align his interests with those of clients. Janus Capital's CEO, Dick Weil, stated that Gross believes in "eating his own cooking" and investing alongside clients. Following this investment, Janus shares rose 5.6% to $17.19 during morning trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

site_title: Ageing Japanese prove rich pickings for investment fraud
summary: Japan's aging population is vulnerable to investment fraud, with over 90% of victims being people over 60, according to the National Police Agency. The number of reported cases jumped from 112 in 2010 to 1,875 in 2013, with losses totaling 17.9 billion yen. The government's campaign to encourage investment among retirees has increased the risk of scams, with lawyers estimating that undetected cases may exceed 100,000 annually. Police are running awareness campaigns to combat the issue, but experts warn that the growing number of elderly in the population will make it a rising challenge for authorities.

site_title: Central banks focus on flagging inflation
summary: Central banks worldwide are focusing on combating slowing inflation, with key decisions made at the Bank of Canada and Bank of Japan. The Bank of Canada cut its main interest rate for the first time since 2009, while the Bank of Japan expanded a lending program. These moves are attributed to the 56% decline in oil prices since June, which is expected to drag down inflation. The decisions signal that central banks are still supportive of stimulative policies, despite the risk of defeat in their battle against inflation.

site_title: Oil majors seek to claw back costs from service firms
summary: Global oil majors, including BP, Royal Dutch Shell, and Chevron, are demanding cheaper and better services from engineering and service companies or taking work in-house to address cost overruns. The move comes after oil majors lost hundreds of billions of dollars on cost overruns in the last five years. With oil prices now half that of the previous five years, the urgency to address costs and delays rises, with some companies, such as Schlumberger and Halliburton, having already cut thousands of jobs. The oil majors aim to renegotiate contracts, implement common standards, and move work in-house to deliver projects on time and on budget.

site_title: ECB agrees landmark sovereign bond-buy plan
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) agreed on a landmark sovereign bond-buy plan, pumping 60 billion euros a month into the eurozone economy from March to September 2026. The plan aims to boost the flagging economy, where inflation has turned negative and is below the central bank's target of 2%. Countries under a bailout program, such as Greece, will be included but with additional criteria.

site_title: Oil pares gains after ECB bond buying decision
summary: Oil prices pared gains after the European Central Bank announced it would buy 60 billion euros of government bonds monthly until September 2016 to support the eurozone economy. The move is expected to push the dollar to new highs, increasing demand for the dollar-priced commodity and putting downward pressure on oil prices. As a result, Brent crude futures traded at $49.67 a barrel, down from a high of $50.45 earlier in the session. The strong dollar is also denting demand for commodities due to their high cost for holders of other currencies.

site_title: UK factories see hit to exports in coming months: CBI
summary: British factories anticipate the weakest export orders since 2012 in the next three months, according to the Confederation of British Industry. Export order volumes are expected to show a balance of +1, down from +9 in the previous survey. The CBI's director of economics, Rain Newton-Smith, attributed this to the eurozone's struggles with deflation. Meanwhile, the European Central Bank is set to announce bond-buying measures to combat deflation.

site_title: Morgan Stanley CEO says ECB's decision is positive for markets
summary: Morgan Stanley CEO James Gorman says the European Central Bank's decision to expand its asset-purchase program is positive for markets, citing a necessary step to stimulate the economy. The ECB will buy 60 billion euros per month until September 2016, reducing the cost of long-term loans to banks. Gorman expects investors to see appreciation in European markets, but notes the euro may fall. The move follows a similar step taken by the Federal Reserve six years ago to combat deflation and stagnation.

site_title: Merkel says "not there yet" on lifting of Russia sanctions
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel stated that Europe cannot lift economic sanctions against Russia until Moscow changes its course, particularly regarding Ukraine. Merkel criticized Russia's annexation of Crimea as a violation of European post-war values, including border acceptance and territorial integrity. She emphasized that economic sanctions were necessary, but can be lifted if the reasons for their introduction are removed, and that "we are not there yet."

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Angela Merkel accused Russia on Thursday of violating Europe's peaceful post-war order with its interventions in Ukraine and said Europe could not consider lifting economic sanctions against Moscow until it changed course.

site_title: ECB says now up to governments to act after QE
summary: European Central Bank chief Mario Draghi stated that it's now up to governments to act and prevent deflation in the eurozone after the ECB rolled out a massive bond purchase programme. Draghi emphasized that monetary policy can create growth, but investment is necessary for growth to pick up.

site_title: Gold prices rebound after ECB announces more stimulus measures
summary: The European Central Bank announced additional stimulus measures, including buying 60 billion euros of assets a month through September 2016, boosting demand for gold as a store of value. This move led to a rebound in gold prices. The ECB's expansion of stimulus measures was seen as a positive sign for the economy, supporting gold's role as a safe-haven asset. The news lifted gold futures, providing a boost to investors seeking value in the metal.

site_title: Euro weakens, shares rise, bond yields fall after ECB launches QE
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) launched a 60 billion euro monthly bond purchase program, causing the euro to fall to US$1.1511, while bond yields in Italy, Spain, and Portugal declined. European shares rose, with the FTSEurofirst 300 index gaining 0.8% and hitting a seven-year high. Italian stocks, such as Unicredit and BMPS, also surged.

site_title: ECB says further policy measures to come as rates left unchanged
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) kept interest rates unchanged at record lows, citing no need to alter policy measures. ECB President Mario Draghi will announce further policy measures, including a possible quantitative-easing program exceeding $1.2 trillion, at a media briefing later. This marks a critical juncture for the currency and European unity, as the ECB arrives at this point three months after the Federal Reserve ended its own quantitative easing program.

site_title: ECB's Draghi says inflation could stay below zero in coming months
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that eurozone consumer prices could stay below zero in the coming months, citing a significant drop in oil prices. This marks the first time eurozone consumer prices have fallen in over five years. Draghi also expressed concern that consumers' inflation expectations may be unhinged due to this development. The ECB's comments come amid a slowdown in China's GDP growth, which is putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: China's economy not headed for 'hard landing': Li
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang addressed concerns over the country's economic growth, stating that the economy is not headed for a sharp slowdown. Despite posting the weakest growth in nearly a quarter of a decade, Li emphasized the need for structural reforms to deliver "quality growth" rather than high top-line figures. China's economy grew 7.4% in 2014, slower than the previous year, but Li vowed to push on with reforms, citing the creation of 13 million new jobs. The International Monetary Fund projects slower growth this year, but Li believes efforts to shift the economy towards consumption will make growth more sustainable.

images.alt_text: Mr Li vowed to push on with structural reforms which would deliver "quality growth" rather than just a high top-line figure.

site_title: Air France reveals job cut plans to staff: sources
summary: Air France has revealed a new job-cutting plan to staff, focusing on voluntary redundancies, following the airline's struggles with competition from low-cost carriers and state-backed airlines. The plan, part of a "salary moderation" initiative, does not provide specific figures. Air France has already reduced 8,000 jobs in the past three years. The airline will present additional cost-cutting measures to its unions on February 5.

site_title: India's Tata Motors targets younger drivers with new Bolt model
summary: Tata Motors, India's top automaker, is targeting younger drivers with its new Bolt hatchback model to regain market share. The company has hired over 1,200 people to promote the car to individual customers, shifting its focus away from fleet sales. The Bolt competes with Maruti's Ritz and Honda's Brio at a base price of 444,993 rupees. Tata's sales dropped 37% in the June 2014 quarter, and the company plans to introduce two new cars in India each year until 2020 to boost sales.

site_title: ECB's Draghi says large majority in favour of QE
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that a large majority on the bank's Governing Council is in favor of launching a broad quantitative easing plan, with members unanimously agreeing it's a monetary policy tool. The council also agreed on risk-sharing terms, with 20% and 80% on a no-risk-sharing basis. This move comes despite some countries, including Germany, being hesitant to buy government debt, citing concerns over feckless spending and slow economic reforms.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi said on Thursday there was a large majority on the bank's Governing Council in favour of launching a broad quantitative easing plan.

site_title: Malaysia risk tops Mexico's to approach Indonesia
summary: Malaysia's default risk has surged to 135.5, the highest in 19 months, due to Prime Minister Najib Razak's warning that sliding oil prices will lead to a fiscal deficit and growth target miss. The country's reliance on oil, with 29% of its revenue coming from crude, has raised concerns among investors. Fitch Ratings has warned of a downgrade to Malaysia's A- grade, and the yield on its 10-year government bond has fallen to 3.967%. The government has revised its economic outlook, cutting its growth forecast to 4.5% from 5%, and is facing pressure to implement budget consolidation measures.

site_title: Euro-priced gold hits highest since April 2013
summary: The European Central Bank launched a government bond-buying program, injecting hundreds of billions of euros into the eurozone economy, causing gold prices to surge. Euro-priced gold reached its highest level in 21 months, rising 1.9% to 1,134.27 euros an ounce, with a year-to-date gain of 15.7%. The single currency dropped to US$1.1511, while spot gold rose 10% for the year. The move was seen as a response to the sagging eurozone economy.

site_title: ECB action should not divert Europe from reforms: Merkel
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel stated that any European Central Bank (ECB) action should not divert attention from reforms to bolster the economy. Merkel emphasized that European politicians must enact a framework for recovery, despite the ECB's potential decision to introduce a bond-buying program. The ECB held its key interest rates unchanged, but is expected to announce new monetary policy measures later. Merkel's comments come as the eurozone struggles, with the German central bank opposing the bond-buying scheme, which might give some countries less incentive to reform.

site_title: Yahoo at US$8b without Alibaba may lure buyers
summary: Yahoo! Inc may be a takeover candidate for SoftBank Corp or private-equity firms after spinning off its remaining stake in Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, potentially valuing the US company at $5-8 billion. If Yahoo sells its Alibaba shares, it will be left with a smaller business worth about $5-8 billion. SoftBank could buy Yahoo to increase its Yahoo Japan stake, while private-equity firms may be attracted to the cash generated by Yahoo's operations. Alibaba could also consider acquiring Yahoo to gain exposure to the American technology market.

site_title: Eurogroup chief urges ECB to 'remain accommodative'
summary: Eurogroup chief Jeroen Dijsselbloem urged the European Central Bank to maintain accommodative monetary policy to stimulate the eurozone economy. He emphasized that the ECB's actions do not excuse individual governments from implementing reforms to make their economies more competitive, particularly in France and Italy. Dijsselbloem stated that while the ECB can provide more time and alleviate pressure, it cannot fix Europe's competitiveness issues.

site_title: AirAsia to help analyse flight recorders to uncover crash cause
summary: AirAsia officials will analyze the flight recorders of the doomed Flight QZ8501 to help Indonesian investigators determine the cause of the crash. The Airbus A320 likely entered a stall after an unusually steep ascent, and initial reports suggest no evidence of terrorism. The company hopes to recover more bodies from the ocean and issue an initial report on the loss of 162 lives by next week. AirAsia made an administrative error by flying without a permit, but officials argue that some approvals were in place, leading to a single "bit of administrative issue."

site_title: Huawei forgave 4,000 workers for corruption, falsifying results
summary: Huawei's founder, Ren Zhengfei, revealed that the company forgave over 4,000 workers involved in corruption and falsifying business results. He emphasized the need for better internal policing as Huawei experiences rapid growth, projecting a 20% increase in sales to $56 billion this year. Ren also stated that the company aims to achieve consistency between accounts and business in the next five years, despite past challenges with corruption.

site_title: Qatar Air to add italy flights following Etihad's Alitalia stake
summary: Qatar Airways plans to increase flights to Italy by 30% over the next five months, adding wide-body aircraft to Rome, Milan, and Venice. The move intensifies competition with local Gulf carriers, including Abu Dhabi's Etihad Airways, which has acquired a 49% stake in Alitalia. Qatar currently operates 35 flights a week to Italy, while Etihad will offer direct services to Rome, Milan, and Bologna. The expansion aims to drive traffic on to long-haul routes.

site_title: Ascendas Reit posts higher Q3 DPU of 3.59 cents
summary: Ascendas Reit reported a Q3 DPU of 3.59 cents, exceeding the 3.54 cents paid out in the previous year. Gross revenue rose 11.2% to S$171.7 million due to higher occupancy and rental income from Hyflux Innovation Centre and Aperia. Positive rental reversion and incentive payments also contributed to the higher gross revenue.

site_title: BoE says UK insurers well capitalised ahead of new EU rules
summary: The Bank of England's Paul Fisher stated that UK insurers are well-capitalized ahead of the introduction of EU's Solvency II rules in 2016, which aim to maintain insurer stability. He emphasized that the UK regulator will not use the new rules to raise capital requirements across the board, instead focusing on ensuring the industry's stability. The regulator also plans to allow for business model innovation and won't restrict firms' ability to adapt to the new regulatory regime.

images.alt_text: European Union rules from 2016 to keep insurance companies stable will not be an excuse for regulators to ramp up capital requirements for insurers in Britain, a senior Bank of England official said on Thursday.

site_title: Postponed Keppel briefings now set for Jan 23
summary: Keppel Corporation and Keppel Land briefings, initially postponed, have been rescheduled for January 23. The briefings, which were halted due to the release of full-year earnings, will be held at 2pm and 5pm, respectively. The postponement sparked market speculation, with analysts considering potential privatization of Keppel Land or asset swaps between the property firm and its parent company.

site_title: Oil trades close to $50 in London before ECB, Opec sees rebound
summary: Oil prices rose to nearly $50 a barrel in London ahead of the European Central Bank's meeting, with Brent futures gaining 1.9% to $49.95. The ECB is expected to consider a $58 billion monthly quantitative-easing plan, which is seen as bullish for oil prices. OPEC's secretary-general stated that oil prices will rebound rather than decline to $20 a barrel. The ECB's intentions are expected to guide market sentiment, with some analysts predicting that crude prices can go either way once the ECB's plans are clear.

images.alt_text: Oil traded close to US$50 a barrel in London amid speculation that the European Central Bank will commit to a quantitative-easing program.

site_title: India finance minister commits to strict fiscal roadmap
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley has reaffirmed the government's commitment to slashing the fiscal deficit to 3% of GDP within two years. Despite advisors' advice to boost infrastructure spending, Jaitley will maintain the deficit target. The government aims to reduce subsidies and allocate more funds for infrastructure, reflecting a shift in economic thinking. India's economy is recovering from its longest slowdown since the 1980s, but demand and investment remain weak. Jaitley vows to return the economy to 8-9% growth without raising taxes.

site_title: China conducts first reverse repos in a year as outflows pick up
summary: China's central bank conducted its first reverse repos in a year to address a seasonal cash squeeze exacerbated by capital outflows, injecting 50 billion yuan (US$8.05 billion) into the financial system. The move aims to smooth out liquidity before the Lunar New Year holiday. The People's Bank of China has reduced its benchmark rates in November to revive an economy expanding at its slowest pace in over two decades, but has signaled less dovish intentions, unlike other major economies.

site_title: Africa oil boom on hold as prices spur explorer caution
summary: Africa's oil and gas boom is facing a slowdown due to the global drop in crude prices, pushing drillers to reconsider the high costs of exploration on the continent. With oil prices below $50 a barrel, analysts expect a more concentrated pullout in 2015, with drilling costs increasing the industry's susceptibility to lower oil prices. Companies such as Tullow Oil and Ophir Energy have already cut their exploration budgets, and governments need to adapt their terms to reflect lower prices to revive the momentum of Africa's oil and gas industry.

site_title: India: Shares surge to record high for 3rd straight day
summary: Indian shares surged to record highs for the third straight day, gaining 0.41% to reach 29,006.02 points, as investors awaited the European Central Bank's potential quantitative easing. The broader NSE index also closed up 0.37% at 8,761.40 points. This marks the sixth consecutive session of gains, driven by firm regional trends.

site_title: SMEs expect higher labour costs; Asme offers recommendations for Budget 2015
summary: Singapore's small and medium enterprises (SMEs) expect higher manpower costs in the next six months, with 82.3% citing it as a top contributing factor to increased operational costs. The Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (Asme) suggests revising the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme to encourage companies to focus on process redesign and software development. Additionally, Asme recommends introducing certification programs for SMEs to work with higher education institutions to enhance productivity and growth.

site_title: "Dama" queens: China investigates "auntie demolition team"
summary: Chinese police are investigating reports of "auntie demolition teams" in Shangqiu, Henan province, where middle-aged women were paid 200 yuan each to demolish homes for a new development. The women, known as "dama" in China, harassed residents and destroyed property. The incident has sparked anger about forced demolitions, which are a common cause of unrest in China. The case is being investigated by the public security department, with no final result announced yet. This is the latest in a series of similar incidents in Henan province.

site_title: Gold declines for second day as ECB easing seen curbing demand
summary: Gold declined for a second day, falling 0.5% to $1,286.73 an ounce, amid speculation that the European Central Bank's economic stimulus will curb demand for haven assets. The ECB plans to purchase $58 billion in assets each month through 2016, potentially calming markets. Gold has risen 8.8% this year on signs of a global economic slowdown. Analysts say the ECB's policy could restore calm, but investors slowed purchases of gold-backed exchange-traded products.

images.alt_text: Gold declined for a second day on speculation economic stimulus by the European Central Bank will lessen demand for haven assets.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust's Q1 distributable income up 22%
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust reported a 22% increase in distributable income to S$16.7 million in Q1 2015, driven by the first full quarter of contribution from Alexandra Technopark. The Reit's distribution per unit rose 20% to 2.46 Singapore cents. Gross revenue and net property income also increased by 23.3% and 15%, respectively. The Reit's units rose 2 cents to S$1.46, and the declared DPU will be paid on Feb 27.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Treasuries advance as ECB bond-buying plan well-anticipated
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) announced plans to buy 60 billion euros (US$69 billion) of private and public securities a month through September 2016 to boost economic growth and avoid deflation. This move was well-anticipated and led to a rally in Treasuries, with benchmark 10-year yields dropping. The announcement was seen as a response to the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike later this year, making US securities more attractive. The move was also influenced by falling yields around the world, making Treasuries more attractive on a relative basis.

images.alt_text: Treasuries gained on speculation investors had anticipated plans by the European Central Bank for expanded bond-buying to bolster economic growth and avoid deflation.

site_title: China luxury market shrank in 2014: consultancy
summary: China's luxury market shrank by one percent in 2014, falling to 115 billion yuan (US$18.5 billion), according to Bain & Company. The decline is attributed to a national anti-corruption campaign, slowing economic growth, and changing consumer tastes. Luxury goods sales declined in high-end watches, menswear, and leather goods. The anti-corruption campaign has curtailed extravagant gift-giving and other excesses, while slowing economic growth has exacerbated the issue. The market is becoming more diverse, with the daigou market increasing to 55-75 billion yuan.

site_title: Swiss Re says infrastructure investment, insurers good match
summary: Swiss Re CEO Michel Lies proposes creating a special infrastructure asset class to allow insurers to invest in projects like roads and bridges, matching the industry's investment potential with infrastructure needs. Insurers seek alternative investments due to low interest rates eroding fixed-income earnings. Meanwhile, European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker seeks private-sector support for his 315 billion-euro investment plan.

site_title: UK December public finances suffer from EU budget hit
summary: The UK's public finances suffered in December due to a large European Union budget contribution. Borrowing rose to £13.1 billion, largely influenced by £2.9 billion in payments to the EU. Despite a strong increase in income tax receipts, the government's deficit reduction targets may be difficult to achieve. The Conservative-led coalition's plans to run an outright budget surplus by 2015 may be scaled back, with some economists predicting a 6% reduction in borrowing.

site_title: Suntec Reit reports DPU of 2.577 cents for Q4
summary: Suntec Reit reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.577 Singapore cents for Q4 2014, up 0.6% from the previous year, driven by the opening of Phase 2 of Suntec City mall and an office property acquisition in Sydney. The company's distributable income grew 9.1% to S$230.3 million for FY 2014, with a DPU of 9.4 cents, up 0.8% from the previous year.

site_title: Swiss central bank says franc move was 'best option'
summary: The Swiss National Bank announced it would stop its three-year effort to hold down the value of the Swiss franc, leading to a 30% surge in the currency's value. If it had continued, Switzerland would have had to spend over $100 billion this month alone. The move sent shockwaves through global markets and bankrupted several foreign exchange traders. The decision was deemed the "best option" by the central bank official, citing the significant costs of maintaining the franc's value.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended higher on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 11.66 points to close at 1,781.75. A total of 2.58 billion lots worth RM2.87 billion were traded, with 664 gainers and 253 losers.

site_title: Declining UK mortgages will hurt home sales, Countrywide says
summary: Countrywide Plc, a UK property broker, warns that declining mortgage approvals and uncertainty ahead of the national election in May will lead to "sluggishness" in the UK housing market in the first half. This decline in mortgage approvals and cautious buying in London will hurt home sales, with a significant deceleration of market growth observed in 2014. The Bank of England's restrictions on mortgage lending also contributed to the decline, with demand for mortgages falling "significantly" in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank reserves fall US$4.8b in first two weeks of January
summary: Malaysia's central bank reserves fell US$4.8 billion in the first two weeks of January, from US$116.0 billion to US$111.2 billion, due to a steep decline in oil and gas export earnings. The reserves, equivalent to 1.1 times the country's short-term external debt, are sufficient for over eight months of retained imports. The Prime Minister revised the country's budget to address investors' concerns, recasting economic targets in line with lower oil prices. The ringgit closed at 3.6000 to the dollar, stronger than a six-year low.

site_title: Keppel Corporation's Q4 profit rises 6.1% to S$725.9m
summary: Keppel Corporation reported a 6.1% increase in Q4 net profit to S$725.9 million, driven by a 9.1% rise in revenue to S$3.93 billion. The company's full-year net profit rose 2.1% to S$1.88 billion. The offshore and marine business contributed 10% to the increase in net profit, driven by better operating results and higher interest income. Keppel also declared a final cash dividend of 36 Singapore cents per share, up from 30 cents in 2013.

site_title: Malaysia's Tenaga Nasional Q1 net profit rises 34.3%
summary: Malaysia's Tenaga Nasional Bhd, the country's largest power firm, reported a 34.3% increase in its Q1 net profit to RM2.35 billion (US$652.8 million) due to higher charges and electricity sales. Revenue rose 15% to RM11 billion. The company also announced plans to buy US$181 million of shares in port operator Integrax Bhd, securing coal supply for its power plants. Despite this, the company's directors expressed caution over the financial year 2015 due to global economic conditions and exchange volatility.

site_title: Registered real estate salespersons at lowest since 2012
summary: The number of registered real estate salespersons in Singapore decreased to 30,830 as of Jan 1, 2015, down from 31,783 and 31,040 over the past year and two years, respectively. New entrants numbered 3,006, while 3,959 salespersons did not renew their registration. This marks the lowest number since 2012, when 30,577 salespersons were registered.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2015 likely to target middle class: economist
summary: Singapore's 2015 budget is expected to target the middle class with handouts, tax rebates, and expanded workfare, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch economist Chua Hak Bin. This comes ahead of the 50th anniversary of Singapore's independence and the upcoming 2017 elections. The budget is also expected to allocate more funds towards social spending, particularly in healthcare, and enhance the Productivity & Innovation Credit scheme for smaller firms. The move aims to address concerns about slowing growth, labor market pressures, and rising interest rates.

site_title: Spain's unemployment rate inches up in fourth quarter
summary: Spain's unemployment rate rose to 23.7% in the fourth quarter of 2014, up slightly from 23.67% in the previous quarter. The number of people out of work grew by 30,100, but 65,100 jobs were added, resulting in a total workforce increase of nearly 100,000. The rate remains a major drag on the country's economic recovery, with 5.4 million people out of work, and analysts expect employment creation to slow in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Spain's unemployment rate edged up slightly in the fourth quarter of 2014 to 23.7 per cent as the number of people out of work grew although more than 65,000 new jobs were added.

site_title: Europe: Shares up for 6th day ahead of ECB decision
summary: European shares rose for a sixth consecutive day ahead of the European Central Bank's (ECB) decision on a sovereign bond-buying program. Market expectations are high for the ECB to unveil a large-scale quantitative easing (QE) program, potentially worth €50 billion per month from March. Investors are optimistic about the program's size and duration, driving gains in single stocks such as Remy Cointreau.

site_title: China's state firms profit growth slows in 2014
summary: China's state-owned firms reported a 3.4% annual growth in profits in 2014, down from 5.9% in 2013. Combined profits reached 2.48 trillion yuan, with a slowdown in profit growth mirroring China's economic slowdown. The country's GDP grew at 7.4% in 2014, the weakest in 24 years, and central bank interest rates were cut in November to support the economy. State firms' total assets rose 12.1% to 102.1 trillion yuan, while liabilities increased 12.2% to 66.56 trillion yuan, amid a decline in coal, chemical, and petrochemical sectors.

site_title: Oil holds below US$48 as US crude stockpiles seen boosting glut
summary: Oil prices fell below $48 a barrel as US crude stockpiles are expected to increase, boosting the global glut. The US crude inventory likely rose to 390.5 million barrels in the week ended January 16, according to a Bloomberg survey. Oil producers outside OPEC should be the first to reduce output, according to Opec's Secretary-General, Abdalla El-Badri. Despite predictions of a potential price drop to $20 a barrel, El-Badri believes prices will rebound rather than extend declines.

site_title: BoE's Miles says UK a long way from falling into deflation trap
summary: The Bank of England's David Miles says the UK's low inflation rate of 0.5% in December does not pose a risk of deflation and does not necessitate a resumption of government bond purchases. The decline in inflation is attributed to global commodity prices and sterling's strengthening, rather than domestic deflationary forces. Miles believes the current low inflation rate is boosting household disposable income and easing debt burdens, making interest rate hikes unnecessary at this time.

images.alt_text: The sharp fall in British inflation does not raise the risk of damaging deflation and the Bank of England does not need to resume buying government bonds in response, a policymaker at the central bank said on Thursday.

site_title: Indonesian divers recover bodies from near crashed AirAsia jet fuselage
summary: Indonesian divers have recovered six bodies from the near-crashed AirAsia jet fuselage in the Java Sea. The bodies were found near the wreckage, but divers were unable to enter the plane due to poor visibility. The recovery of the bodies is expected to continue, with plans to attach giant air bags to lift the fuselage to the surface by Friday. The cause of the crash, which killed all 162 people on board, remains unknown, with investigators ruling out foul play and citing radar data showing the plane climbed faster than normal before stalling.

site_title: China air quality dire but improving: Greenpeace
summary: China's air quality has seen a marginal improvement, with 71 of 74 cities monitored by the ministry of environmental protection experiencing a year-on-year decrease in PM2.5 levels. However, pollution remains above national and international standards, with the country's most polluted city, Xingtai, still averaging 131.4 micrograms per cubic metre. Despite this, the decline in pollution is attributed to factors such as car use restrictions, factory closures, and public holidays. Environmental activists are calling for further action to reduce pollution, citing the estimated 350,000 to 500,000 premature deaths annually due to outdoor air pollution in China.

site_title: Palm drops to 3-week low
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures plummeted to a three-week low, falling 1.2% to RM2,245 (US$624) per tonne, amid weak crude oil prices and poor demand. Tight supplies of palm oil due to flooding provided some support, but the drop was largely driven by the decline in crude oil prices, which have more than halved since June.

images.alt_text: Malaysian palm oil futures dropped to their lowest level in three weeks on Thursday as the ringgit ticked up and crude oil prices continued to languish, but tight supplies of palm after flooding provided some support.

site_title: China island building 'threat to all Asean': Philippines
summary: China's land reclamation in the disputed South China Sea is a threat to all Asean nations, according to the Philippines' foreign minister. China is reclaiming land around isolated reefs to turn them into islands, which could hold fortified positions or airstrips. This action impacts freedom to navigate the strategic mineral-rich waters, affecting global trade. The Philippines and Vietnam have accused China of aggressive actions, while other Asean members have been reluctant to criticize the regional giant. The Philippines will raise the issue at an upcoming Asean foreign ministers' meeting, seeking a code of conduct to reduce tensions.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on hopes of Europe stimulus package
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to close at 5,419.9, driven by hopes of a European stimulus package and rebounding oil and copper prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 26.5 points, while New Zealand's NZX 50 index fell 0.5%.

site_title: Keppel Land, StarHub, CDL and CapitaLand stay among world's most sustainable firms (Amended)
summary: Four Singapore companies, Keppel Land, StarHub, City Developments (CDL), and CapitaLand, have been named among the world's most sustainable corporations by the Global 100 Most Sustainable Corporations list. Keppel Land jumped to 4th place, becoming Asia's most sustainable firm and top-ranked real estate company globally. StarHub improved its ranking to 24th, while CDL moved up to 34th and CapitaLand fell to 84th. The list is compiled by Corporate Knights and recognizes the top standard in corporate sustainability.

images.alt_text: Four Singapore companies have continued to feature among the 100 most sustainable corporations of the world.

site_title: Ousted Thai PM slams impeachment vote
summary: Thai ousted PM Yingluck Shinawatra attacked the impeachment proceedings ahead of a vote that could ban her from politics for five years. The impeachment is over her administration's rice subsidy programme, which cost billions and inspired protests that toppled her government. A successful vote would bring a five-year ban and risk enraging her supporters. Experts say the move is an attempt by the royalist elite to nullify the Shinawatra's influence, following two coups and the removal of three premiers by the kingdom's interventionist courts.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares rose 15.83 points to 3,370.29 on Thursday, with 1.65 billion shares traded at S$1.29 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 295 to 146. The Straits Times Index has been on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Despite US tariff uncertainty, investors remained positive, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Shenzhen government said to seek investors to buy Kaisa stakes
summary: Shenzhen's government is in talks with property developers to orchestrate investments in Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd. amid the company's financial struggles, including a missed US$23 million coupon payment and blocked projects. Kaisa's chairman and executives have quit, and it's being probed over alleged links to a former security chief. Deposits have been frozen, and investors in a Kaisa trust will be repaid their principal plus interest. The government aims to avoid selling stakes at a discount.

site_title: BOJ says inflation to slow further due to oil slump, soft demand
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) expects Japan's inflation to slow further due to declining oil prices and a continued impact from a sales tax hike. The central bank revised its assessment on factory output, maintaining optimism about a moderate recovery. Despite cutting its inflation forecast to 1.0% for the year, Governor Haruhiko Kuroda believes inflation will eventually accelerate as wages rise and oil prices fall. Consumer inflation is expected to slow for the time being, with core inflation at 0.7% in the year to November.

site_title: ECB to decide on bond-buying plan for reviving eurozone economy
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to announce a plan to buy government bonds to revive the eurozone economy and combat deflation. The proposed 50 billion euro (US$58 billion) monthly bond-buying program, which could total up to 600 billion euros, is expected to be unveiled on Thursday. The move aims to boost inflation, which has turned negative, and generate a "portfolio effect" that could influence other asset markets. The decision comes despite opposition from Germany's Bundesbank and concerns that the policy could undermine economic reforms.

site_title: Japanese bonds set for biggest drop since May 2013
summary: Japanese 10-year government bonds are set for their largest drop since May 2013 due to investor selling ahead of the European Central Bank's (ECB) monetary policy announcement. The yield on the benchmark 10-year bond climbed 7 basis points to 0.315% as demand at a 20-year debt auction fell to its weakest since November. The Bank of Japan (BoJ) retained its plan to increase the monetary base at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen, sparking concerns the ECB may disappoint the market with its announcement.

site_title: China will remove rare earth export taxes in May
summary: China will remove rare earth export taxes in May, further easing export curbs after a WTO ruling deemed the tariff and quota system discriminatory. The 15-25% tariffs will be retained until May 2, as China abolishes the quota system following a similar move in March last year. This move is seen as a response to the WTO ruling, allowing China to increase rare earth exports.

site_title: Silver poised for bull market as economic woes boost demand
summary: Silver is poised for a bull market as economic woes boost demand, with holdings in exchange-traded products backed by the metal posting three straight weekly gains. Speculation of slowing global economic growth and deflation has led investors to return to precious metals, with silver prices rising 20% from their recent low and nearing a bull market definition. Central bank stimulus measures and rate cuts are expected to boost silver demand, with forecasts of growth in consumption and a tighter physical market providing support to prices, potentially reaching $20 by the end of the year.

site_title: Seoul: Shares flat, won a shade lower as investors await ECB outcome
summary: South Korean shares closed nearly flat on Thursday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) ticking down 0.02% to 1,920.82 points. The won fell by a whisker to 1,084.9 to the dollar. The subdued market activity is attributed to investors awaiting the European Central Bank's (ECB) policy decision later in the day.

site_title: Australian authorities call for tenders for potential MH370 recovery
summary: Australian authorities have called for tenders to potentially recover the wreckage of missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, which disappeared in 2014. The search, led by the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB), has focused on a 60,000-sq-km area of the Indian Ocean. If found, the recovery operation is likely to cost millions of dollars and be technically challenging. Expressions of interest are due by February 18, and a final decision will be made jointly by the Australian, Malaysian, and Chinese governments.

site_title: Banks bet speculators to be shamed as Denmark weakens krone
summary: Denmark's central bank is expected to cut its benchmark deposit rate to minus 0.3% on Thursday to defend the krone against speculation, following a similar move by the Swiss National Bank last week. The rate cut is aimed at putting an end to speculation that Denmark will abandon its peg to the euro. The move is seen as a response to the European Central Bank's plan to buy 50 billion euros of bonds, which could further strengthen the euro and weaken the krone.

site_title: Japanese economy will show a powerful upward trend in 2015: PM adviser
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic adviser, Etsuro Honda, predicts a powerful upward trend in Japan's economy in 2015, driven by rising inflation expectations under the Bank of Japan's monetary stimulus. The Bank of Japan maintained its pledge to increase base money at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen. Honda's comments come after the Bank of Japan kept monetary policy steady, with no change to its pledge to increase base money. This suggests a positive outlook for Japan's economy in 2015.

site_title: Brokers keep 'neutral' on SGX, saying positives priced in
summary: Brokerages maintain a "neutral" stance on Singapore Exchange (SGX) following its 16% net profit growth in the second fiscal quarter, driven by strong derivatives revenue. Analysts say the stock's performance has priced in revenue growth from China A50 contracts. Despite positive outlooks and momentum, the positives are considered to be already factored into the stock's price, with target prices ranging from S$7.40 to S$8.08. As a result, SGX fell six cents to S$7.84.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end up 0.28% in see-saw trade
summary: Tokyo stocks closed up 0.28% on Thursday, following a see-saw trade as investors await the European Central Bank's monetary policy meeting. The Nikkei 225 index rose 48.54 points to 17,329.02, while the Topix index edged down 0.08% to 1,389.43. The move comes ahead of the ECB's meeting, with investors closely watching for any changes to monetary policy.

site_title: Virgin Australia cuts fuel surcharges for Australia-US flights
summary: Virgin Australia is cutting fuel surcharges from flights to the US, reducing airfares by up to A$50 on four daily flights to Los Angeles. The move follows declining oil prices and the Australian dollar's low value. The airline will bundle fuel surcharges into base fares. This decision comes after the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission launched an investigation into airlines' fuel surcharge representations. Virgin Australia's move is likely to put pressure on rival Qantas, which said it will monitor the use of surcharges but maintains its competitive fares.

site_title: South Korea regulator seeks criminal charges against Uber
summary: South Korea's telecom watchdog, the Korea Communications Commission, has reported Uber to prosecutors for violating communications rules. The move comes after prosecutors indicted Uber's American founder and CEO Travis Kalanick and its Korean partner MK Korea for operating an illegal cab service. Uber Korea is accused of failing to report its business and receive official permission before providing location tracking services. This is the latest development in South Korea's ongoing battle against Uber.

site_title: Update: Asia: Shares near 8-week highs as markets brace for ECB action
summary: Asian shares near eight-week highs as investors expect the European Central Bank to unveil a bond-buying program to revive the euro zone economy. The euro is expected to open flat, with European bourses forecast to rise 0.3-0.1%. The Canadian dollar plunged to a nearly six-year low after the Bank of Canada cut its overnight rate, while US crude dipped on expectations of a stronger dollar. Market analysts expect limited room for the euro to fall, despite some predicting a short squeeze unless the ECB announces more significant measures.

site_title: Ringgit halts three-day decline after crude rallies overnight
summary: Malaysia's ringgit halted a three-day decline after an overnight oil price rally, with Brent crude climbing 2.2% to around $45-$50 a barrel. This easing of concerns about the country's fiscal position helped the currency strengthen 0.1% to 3.6155 a dollar. Prime Minister Najib Razak revised Malaysia's budget and growth forecasts last week after cutting oil price assumptions, and inflation slowed to 2.7% in December.

site_title: Gates group to expand its global philanthropy
summary: Bill and Melinda Gates outlined their vision for a 15-year future, aiming to cut child mortality in half, eradicate polio and other diseases, and make Africa self-sufficient in food production. The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation has committed to new goals in agriculture, technology, and education, with a focus on making individuals involved in efforts to improve lives in poor countries. The foundation also launched a new campaign, Global Citizen, to bring together those who want a voice in addressing global inequalities and holding governments accountable.

site_title: JTC launches improved industrial property price and rental indices
summary: JTC Corporation has released revised industrial property price and rental indices, providing more comprehensive data on the Singapore market. The new indices cover single-user factories and business parks island-wide, and include sub-indices based on property attributes such as type, planning region, and land-use zoning. This expanded coverage aims to provide a more accurate representation of the market, with improved methodology that groups properties with similar attributes and uses fixed weights to prevent drastic fluctuations. The revised indices will help support the Ministry of Trade and Industry's efforts to provide more detailed data on rents for various space types.

images.alt_text: JTC Corporation on Thursday released revised industrial property price and rental indices when it announced its fourth-quarter industrial statistics.

site_title: South Korea central bank watchful of financial mkt volatility, global rate moves
summary: South Korea's central bank governor Lee Ju-yeol is closely monitoring financial market volatility sparked by global rate cuts. The European Central Bank's policy decision on Thursday is expected to impact investors, with the Bank of Korea keeping a close eye on markets. Despite recent rate cuts, the economy is expected to recover, with growth forecasted at 3.4%. The central bank remains prepared to wait before altering rates again, with some economists predicting another rate cut, possibly in the second quarter.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on hopes of Europe stimulus, resources gain reprieve
summary: Australian shares rose for a second session, up 33.9 points or 0.6% to 5427.3, driven by hopes of an EU stimulus package and a rebound in oil and copper prices. The Reserve Bank of Australia may cut interest rates later in 2015, following a shock rate cut in Canada. Key sectors, including mining and energy, also gained, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto rising 3% and 2.3% respectively.

site_title: Google to sell wireless service in deals with Sprint, T-Mobile: The Information
summary: Google is set to launch a wireless service, codenamed "Nova", and will sell mobile phone plans directly to customers through deals with Sprint and T-Mobile. The project, expected to launch later this year, will allow Google to manage calls and mobile data over a cellular network. The service will be available in markets where Google sells Google Fiber Internet service, but details on pricing and device manufacturers are unclear. Google, T-Mobile, and Sprint have not commented on the matter.

images.alt_text: Google is preparing to sell mobile phone plans directly to customers and manage their calls and mobile data over a cellular network, The Information reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly higher ahead of ECB meeting
summary: Asian markets rose ahead of the European Central Bank's policy meeting, with Hong Kong, Sydney, and Seoul gaining 0.52%, 0.59%, and 0.34% respectively. Tokyo fell 0.10% as investors await potential quantitative easing (QE) measures to combat weakening inflation. The euro edged up marginally, rebounding from recent losses, as traders expect the ECB to unveil a QE programme worth between 500-800 billion euros.

site_title: Divers find bodies belted in seats near AirAsia QZ8501 fuselage
summary: Indonesian divers have found 58 bodies, including 5 more, near the main section of the AirAsia plane that crashed into the Java Sea on December 28, killing 162 people. The bodies were found still belted into their seats, and divers are hopeful of reaching the fuselage. The crash occurred during stormy weather while flying from Surabaya to Singapore. The recovery efforts are ongoing, with 58 bodies already recovered and more expected to be found.
