summary: US-based online travel agent Orbitz Worldwide Inc is exploring a sale, with private equity funds and internet companies showing interest. The company, which operates Orbitz.com and Cheaptickets.com, aims to gain scale in the competitive online travel market. Google and Priceline Group, a major competitor, have bolstered investments in travel to capture a bigger share of the market. Orbitz jumped 15% in stock value after news of the potential sale, with a market value of around $1.1 billion.

site_title: Opec's Al-Badri says oil prices will rebound
summary: Opec Secretary-General Abdullah al-Badri stated that oil prices will rebound and return to normal soon, following a 50% decline since June. This comes after a bearish outlook from US President Trump on tariffs, which led to a drop in oil prices. Al-Badri's comments were made at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, amid concerns about the global energy market.

site_title: The future of innovation lies in customer experience
summary: Innovation is shifting from product-centric to customer experience-driven, as converging technologies blur industry boundaries and active consumers drive value creation. With digitization, features and functions of traditional industries are combined, making products more versatile. However, this can lead to customer overwhelm, and value is co-created through personalized interaction, not just product features. Examples of co-creation include language learning apps and airline experiences, where the individual's interaction with the system creates unique value. This new approach to innovation prioritizes customer experience, leading to loyalty, retention, and recommendations, marking the beginning of the "age of the customer."

site_title: Europe: FTSE hits six-week high on strong energy stocks
summary: Britain's top share index, the FTSE 100, reached a six-week high on Wednesday, driven by gains in energy stocks following a rise in oil. The benchmark index rose 0.9% to 6,677.81 points, its fifth consecutive gain. Pearson, an education and media group, also contributed to the rise after predicting a return to growth in 2015.

site_title: Canadian dollar at almost 6-year low as BOC cuts interest rates
summary: The Canadian dollar hit an almost 6-year low after the Bank of Canada unexpectedly cut interest rates to 0.75% from 1%, citing a slump in crude oil and a global glut. Economists had predicted an increase in interest rates, but the central bank took pre-emptive steps to stabilize the economy. The currency fell against 31 major peers, with crude oil tumbling over 50% since June. The move was seen as a response to the economic forecasts being revised downward.

site_title: Gold declines from five-month high after ECB stimulus reports
summary: Gold prices fell 0.6% to $1,288.04 after the European Central Bank announced plans to purchase 50 billion euros in assets per month through 2016, potentially reducing stimulus. The proposal, discussed by the ECB's Governing Council starting Wednesday, will be finalized Thursday. Despite gold reaching a five-month high, some market participants expressed disappointment with the amount of stimulus, citing uncertainty and a need for more details.

site_title: Netflix shares up on talk of profit stream after rollout
summary: Netflix shares rose 16% after the company announced it will reach profitability in all 200 countries with broadband Internet service within two years, driven by international subscriber growth. The company expects to add 2.25 million international customers this quarter, reaching 18.3 million users worldwide. Netflix plans to borrow at least $1 billion to support its programming efforts, which include 320 hours of original content this year. The company's CEO, Reed Hastings, expressed confidence in the company's ability to compete with Amazon and other rivals, despite concerns over licensing issues in China and widening international losses.

site_title: ECB said to propose QE of 50 billion euros a month through 2016
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has proposed a 50 billion euro monthly quantitative easing plan through 2016 to combat deflation and boost the euro-area economy. The proposal, set to be discussed by the ECB's Governing Council, could still change significantly. Purchases are expected to begin in March 2015, aiming to inject 1.1 trillion euros into the economy. The move reflects ECB President Mario Draghi's efforts to stimulate growth and put the economy back on track.

site_title: After defiant speech, Obama heads to Republican heartland
summary: President Barack Obama delivered a defiant State of the Union speech to the Republican-led US Congress, stating the economy has effectively recovered from years of stagnation. Following the speech, Obama embarked on a two-day trip to Idaho and Kansas to promote his plans for lifting up the middle class, citing the "shadow of crisis has passed." With his tone more confident, Obama aimed to push his message without restraints of facing voters again.

site_title: OECD urges ECB to launch unlimited bond-buying
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) should launch unlimited bond-buying to raise inflation and revive the economy, according to OECD Secretary-General Angel Gurria. He urged ECB President Mario Draghi to take bold action, without capping the amount, to achieve the desired inflation rate. This comes as the ECB is set to make a crucial decision on quantitative easing, a monetary policy tool to boost economic growth. Gurria's comments come as the global economy faces challenges, including slowing GDP growth in China and a shrinking UK economy.

site_title: Swiss shockwaves hit Seoul as Kexim shelves issue
summary: Switzerland's decision to scrap its currency peg has sent shockwaves through Asia's franc-bond market. The Export-Import Bank of Korea, South Korea's largest issuer of offshore bonds, plans to shelve a sale of franc notes due to the Swiss National Bank's move. The cost of swapping francs into US dollars has risen to a two-year high, discouraging other issuers. This move may have significant implications for Asia's franc-bond market, as other issuers may be hesitant to participate in the market due to the increased costs.

site_title: Late buying accounts for bulk of STI gain
summary: The Straits Times Index rose 20.44 points or 0.6% to 3,354.46 on Wednesday, driven by late buying ahead of the European Central Bank's expected quantitative easing announcement. The late push, which added 13 points to the index, involved broad-based buying of the Jardine stable, Singapore Airlines, and three banks. No individual stock benefited from the late buying, and the advance-decline score was 248-183, suggesting a mixed session.

site_title: IEA economist sees upward pressure on oil prices by year-end
summary: IEA economist Fatih Birol expects oil prices to face upward pressure by year-end due to a 50% drop in crude prices since last June, which may eventually curb production. Opec Secretary General Abdullah al-Badri disagrees, stating that producers should not cut production despite the price fall.

site_title: Boeing exec sees strong demand for 737 MAX, confident on 777
summary: Boeing's top sales official, John Wojick, expressed confidence in demand for the 737 MAX and 777 models despite the recent oil price slump. Strong demand for air travel, fueled by lower oil prices, is offsetting hesitation from some airlines to upgrade to new models. The global sales & marketing senior vice president stated that modern fuel-saving jets, longer service life, and high prices for current models are driving continued demand. This optimism comes as participants in an aircraft finance gathering in Dublin predicted strong demand for modern fuel-efficient narrowbody jets.

site_title: US mortgage applications rise in latest week: MBA
summary: US mortgage applications surged 14.2% last week, reaching a 17-month high, as mortgage rates dropped to 3.8%, the lowest level since May 2013. Refinancing applications jumped 22.3% to 2,746.1, while home purchase demand dipped 2.5%. The data, from the Mortgage Bankers Association, indicates a second consecutive week of high activity.

site_title: EU privacy watchdogs to review air passenger data stance
summary: EU data protection regulators will review their stance on sharing airline passenger data as part of efforts to tighten security and thwart terror attacks. The move comes after EU President Donald Tusk urged lawmakers to drop their resistance to the EU Passenger Name Record system. Regulators had previously opposed the system, citing privacy concerns, but may consider safeguards and guarantees to address these concerns. The review is seen as a response to deadly Islamist attacks in France and efforts to improve security without undermining personal liberties.

site_title: Slower, more sustainable growth good for China: central banker
summary: China's central banker, Zhou Xiaochoan, says slower growth is good for the country's economy as it allows for more sustainable and stable growth. China's growth slowed to 7.4% in the final quarter of 2014, the lowest rate in 20 years. Zhou believes sacrificing a little lower growth rate is worth it for structural reforms, including transitioning to renewable energy sources, to make the economy more sustainable. He notes that pursuing high growth rates would postpone necessary structural reforms.

images.alt_text: Somewhat slower growth will allow a reformed Chinese economy to become more stable and should be good news, the head of China's central bank said on Wednesday.

site_title: Oil slump may force firms to quit mature Norwegian fields early: directorate
summary: Norway's oil directorate head Bente Nyland warns that low oil prices may force companies to abandon mature fields early, shortening their lifetime and accelerating a fall in crude production after 2020. If prices stay low, firms may delay future projects, further reducing production. Norway's oil industry is cutting spending, delaying or cancelling projects, and laying off workers due to the low oil price, which has fallen 60% over the past seven months. The country's oil output has been declining since 2000, and decisions to delay recovery efforts are difficult to reverse.

images.alt_text: The low oil price could force firms to abandon Norway's mature fields early, leaving recoverable deposits in the ground and shortening the lifetime of some projects, the head of the country's oil directorate said on Wednesday.

site_title: S&P to pay US$77m to settle US SEC, state charges over ratings
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) will pay US$77 million to settle civil charges with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) and state attorneys general over alleged "fraudulent misconduct" in rating commercial mortgage-backed securities. The payment includes US$58 million to the SEC and US$19 million to the attorneys general of New York and Massachusetts. Former S&P executive Barbara Duka is also facing charges and plans to contest them in an SEC administrative court.

site_title: US single-family housing starts highest since early 2008
summary: US single-family housing starts rose 7.2% in December to 728,000 units, the highest level since March 2008, and permits surged 4.5% to their highest level since January 2008. The increase offset a 0.8% fall in multi-family home starts, lifting overall housing starts 4.4% to 1.09 million units. This hopeful sign for the sluggish housing market recovery comes as wage growth is expected to pick up and the 30-year mortgage rate has decreased.

site_title: Distressed oil rig bonds soar over 20% yield mark
summary: Mexico's oil rig operators, including Grupo R's Offshore Drilling Holding SA and Oro Negro Drilling Pte Ltd, are facing financial distress due to the collapse in oil prices. Their bonds have soared over 20% in yield, with Offshore Drilling's notes due 2020 losing 28% in value this month alone. The companies are under pressure from state-owned oil producer Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex) to cut costs, as the government seeks to save $3 billion this year. The industry's struggles undermine President Enrique Pena Nieto's bid to attract foreign investment and reverse Mexico's decade-long decline in oil output.

site_title: Singapore IDA throws down data gauntlet
summary: The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) has opened a venture capital office in San Francisco, challenging the tech community to use open government datasets to develop innovative solutions. IDA is part of Singapore's Smart Nation initiative, which aims to leverage data to improve the country's infrastructure and services. The move signals a shift towards utilizing open data for innovation, with over 8,000 datasets available for analysis. The challenge aims to foster collaboration and drive growth in the tech industry, positioning Singapore as a hub for data-driven innovation.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

The Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) is making a big push for its venture capital arm, opening a new office right smack in the hotbed for technology startups in San Francisco's South of Market (SoMa) district.

site_title: Oil export losses to reach US$300 billion in Middle East
summary: The International Monetary Fund predicts oil export losses in the Middle East and Central Asia will reach US$300 billion this year due to a 50% decline in petroleum prices. Countries heavily reliant on oil exports, such as Qatar, Iraq, Libya, and Saudi Arabia, will be hit hardest. The IMF cuts its global economic growth forecast to 3.5% for 2015, significantly lowering projections for oil exporters like Russia, Nigeria, and Saudi Arabia. Nearly all Middle Eastern and Central Asian exporting countries are expected to run fiscal deficits this year.

site_title: Kuwait to splash US$100b on oil projects
summary: Kuwait plans to spend approximately US$100 billion over the next five years on oil projects to modernize the sector. The country aims to increase its crude production capacity to 4.0 million barrels per day by 2020 and maintain it until 2030. The investment plans come as oil prices have declined significantly since June, accounting for around 94% of Kuwait's public revenues. The government is focusing on upstream projects to maintain excess capacity, with a goal of raising production to 3.5 million bpd by the end of 2015.

site_title: Cuba and US open historic talks in Havana
summary: US and Cuba officials opened historic talks in Havana on Wednesday to end decades of Cold War-era animosity and reestablish diplomatic relations. The talks, led by US Assistant Secretary of State Roberta Jacobson and Cuban Foreign Ministry official Josefina Vidal, focus on migration issues and the reopening of mutual embassies, closed since 1961. US President Barack Obama urged Congress to end the decades-long embargo against Cuba, while Cuban officials expressed hopes for civilized relations despite their differing political concepts.

images.alt_text: The United States and Cuba opened two days of historic talks in Havana on Wednesday to end decades of Cold War-era animosity and reestablish diplomatic relations.

site_title: Bank of Canada makes shock rate cut due to oil, slashes forecast
summary: The Bank of Canada unexpectedly cut its benchmark rate to 0.75% from 1% to counter the effects of cheaper oil on economic growth and inflation. The central bank slashed its 2015 growth outlook to 2.1% and forecast lower inflation, citing a vulnerable housing market and household imbalances. The move aims to provide "insurance" against financial stability risks and prevent a potential housing price crash. The economy is expected to grow only 1.5% in the first half of 2015, down from 2.4% previously predicted.

site_title: China's property market no longer 'red hot but deep cold'
summary: China's property market, once "red hot but deep cold", is experiencing a slump, with prices falling in the second half of 2014. Experts say the sector is moving from growth to stagnation, with developers shifting focus to consumption and finding new ways to rent out space. China's central bank has eased mortgage policies and cut interest rates, but analysts predict investments will shift from property to stocks, with the central bank maintaining a stable monetary policy. The slowdown in the property market is seen as a cyclical adjustment, potentially fueling fears of slowing economic growth.

site_title: Europe's leaders under fire from davos attendees as US hailed
summary: Europe's leaders face criticism for failing to boost growth in the region, with US leaders hailed for turning around their economy. The International Monetary Fund forecasts US growth of 3.6% this year, three times faster than the euro area. The European Central Bank is expected to announce a bond-buying program to combat deflation, but critics argue it has "continuously bought time" for European policymakers to address underlying issues, making it hard to rule the single currency a success.

site_title: Oxley terminates main contract for construction of Devonshire Residences
summary: OXLEY Holdings Limited has terminated its main contract for the construction of Devonshire Residences, effective January 6, due to the main contractor, Admin Construction Pte Ltd, being placed under creditors' voluntary winding up. The company has appointed another contractor to complete the project, which is not expected to impact its earnings per share or net tangible assets per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Volvo names new US chief as sales decline
summary: Volvo Cars named Lex Kerssemakers, 55, as senior vice president of the Americas and president and CEO of Volvo Cars of North America, aiming to reverse declining US sales. Kerssemakers will report to CEO Hakan Samuelsson and vows to drive Volvo's ambition to reach US sales of over 100,000 vehicles "in the medium term." Volvo faces stiff competition from German luxury brands and faces an uphill battle in the US market, where sales fell 8% last year to 56,000.

images.alt_text: Volvo Cars on Wednesday named a new head of North America as the Swedish auto brand tries to reverse lagging sales in a growing US market.

site_title: China tells local governments to use unspent money
summary: China's cabinet instructed local governments to reallocate unspent funds from fiscal 2012 and before to new budgets. The move follows a 24-year low in China's economic growth last year, driven by slowing investment and cooling sectors. This is the latest effort by China to adjust public budgets to boost the economy, following previous reworkings. However, the exact amount to be reallocated remains unclear.

site_title: Fragrance subsidiary buys property in Australia for A$1.45m
summary: Fragrance Group's subsidiary, Fragrance Hobart, acquired a property in Hobart, Tasmania for A$1.45 million. The 525 square-meter freehold property is adjacent to another property owned by Fragrance Hobart and is zoned for central commercial and administrative use. The acquisition was made with internal funds and is not expected to impact the company's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the 2015 financial year.

site_title: Thai junta to spend US$7.5b on water projects in 2015-16: minister
summary: Thailand's military government plans to invest US$7.5 billion in urgent water management projects over the next two years, aiming to resolve drought-related problems and tackle economic issues. The projects, part of a new 10-year water management plan, will be funded from the annual budget and borrowing, with US$3.75 billion allocated for this year and the remaining US$3.75 billion for next year. The government scrapped a previous 350-billion baht water plan initiated by the previous administration.

site_title: ISDN buys 49 per cent stake in Indonesian hydropower energy business
summary: ISDN Holdings has agreed to buy a 49% stake in Indonesian hydropower business PT Izmi Power Mandiri for 3.854 billion Indonesian rupiah (S$411,434). The stake purchase includes a power purchase agreement to build an 8MW mini-hydroelectric power plant, expected to generate 52GWh of electricity annually and produce US$3.4 million in revenue. The deal was announced on January 21, 2015.

site_title: Keppel Land's Q4, full-year earnings fall on lower fair value gain
summary: Keppel Land reported a 21.6% drop in net profit to S$444.52 million for Q4 2014, mainly due to a lower fair value gain on investment properties. Sales increased 39.5% to S$705.38 million, driven by divestment and new revenue streams. Full-year earnings dropped 15.1% to S$752.49 million, while revenue rose 2.5% to S$1.50 billion.

site_title: US: Stocks fall after IBM weakness, ahead of ECB meeting
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 60.91 points, or 0.35%, to 17,454.32. The decline came after IBM's disappointing outlook and ahead of an ECB meeting that could result in new stimulus. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the S&P 500 down 4.63 points, or 0.23%, to 2,017.92, and the Nasdaq Composite down 12.58 points, or 0.27%, to 4,642.26.

site_title: Investment bank fees soar to seven-year high, led by JP Morgan
summary: Investment banking fees surged to a seven-year high of $90.1 billion in 2014, driven by deals in North Asia and Southern Europe. JP Morgan led the rankings with $6.3 billion in fees, followed by Bank of America Corp and Goldman Sachs. Fees for deals in North Asia and Southern Europe jumped 28% and 29% respectively, with North America generating $47 billion in fees. Despite potential slowdowns in China and global geopolitical tensions, bankers expect fees to climb, citing increased demand for complex transactions and higher client acceptance of fees.

site_title: Oman oil minister criticises Opec policy on prices, market share
summary: Oman's oil minister, Mohammad bin Hamad al-Rumhy, criticized Opec's production policy, saying it creates market volatility without benefiting oil producers, particularly Oman, which is suffering from low energy prices. Oman's first direct public criticism of Opec comes as the country faces a projected $6.5 billion deficit due to the oil price slide. Al-Rumhy questioned the importance of market share over revenue, warning that Opec's policy may temporarily force high-cost producers out, only for them to return, making the policy useless.

site_title: German population grew in 2014 driven by immigration: data
summary: Germany's population grew by 470,000 in 2014, driven by immigration, reaching 81.1 million, the highest positive migration balance since the 1990s. This marks the fourth consecutive year of population growth, largely due to low birth rates and an aging population.

site_title: Europe missed chance to fix economy: ex Bundesbank chief
summary: Former Bundesbank chief Axel Weber says Europe squandered three years of opportunity to carry out economic reforms, warning the ECB against overcompensating for governments' inaction. Despite the ECB's unconventional measures, growth remains sluggish, unemployment high, and the eurozone risks deflation. Weber urges European policymakers to implement reforms under international scrutiny, rather than relying on the ECB's actions, and to avoid creating an incentive for governments to do less.

site_title: iPhone 6 hands Apple record share of Samsung's home market
summary: Apple captured a record 33% market share in South Korea in November, surpassing Samsung's 46% share, according to a Counterpoint report. The gains are attributed to the sales of the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus, which likely came at the expense of Samsung's Galaxy Note 4 phablet. Analysts expect Samsung to continue losing share in the global market, with Apple extending its lead in the premium segment and upstarts like Xiaomi making inroads into the low-end market.

site_title: France, Europe in anti-terror shakeup after Paris attacks
summary: French and European leaders are unveiling anti-terror measures in response to the Paris attacks that killed 17 people. Four men have been charged with providing equipment and support to one of the gunmen. The measures include boosting security and intelligence services, increasing funding for police and troops, and implementing stricter laws against radicalization. The European Commission will also discuss changes to the Schengen free travel area and intelligence cooperation. Meanwhile, President Barack Obama vowed to hunt down terrorists and dismantle their networks in his State of the Nation address.

site_title: Swiss government says programme to support economy "not appropriate"
summary: The Swiss government has stated that launching an economic support program is not appropriate at this time, as the country is not approaching a recession. The Swiss National Bank's decision to scrap its currency cap has led to a surge in the franc, but officials are reassuring the public that the economy will not be destabilized. This decision comes amid concerns that the SNB's move could impact Switzerland's export-driven economy, particularly in relation to the European Central Bank's potential bond-buying program. The economy minister emphasized that a discussion of an economic support program would only occur if the country were facing economic downturn.

site_title: AirAsia jet's alarms 'screaming' before crash: investigator
summary: An investigator in Indonesia's National Transportation Safety Committee stated that the warning alarms on AirAsia flight QZ8501 were "screaming" as the pilots tried to stabilize the plane before it crashed into the Java Sea on December 28. The plane had climbed abnormally fast, exceeding normal speeds, and the pilots' voices were drowned out by the alarm noise. The two black boxes were recovered last week, and investigators are focusing on human or aircraft error, ruling out terrorism. A preliminary report is expected to be completed next week, with the full report to be released to the media later.

site_title: China's e-commerce transactions hit US$2t in 2014: government
summary: China's e-commerce transactions reached US$2.09 trillion in 2014, growing 25% year-over-year, according to the government. Online retail sales alone were 2.8 trillion yuan, up 49.7% from the previous year. Authorities aim to make e-commerce a new growth driver for the country's economy, which slowed to 7.4% growth in 2014. This growth is attributed to consumers seeking cheaper products and overseas goods, and online shopping platforms like Alibaba, which saw record sales on Singles Day.

site_title: Hong Kong opens fresh public consultations on financial failures
summary: Hong Kong's government opened a second public consultation on sweeping new powers to protect taxpayers from financial firm collapses. The proposals aim to end "too big to fail" and increase financial regulators' powers. The reforms, in line with G20 recommendations, could change insolvency laws and empower governments to let failing firms go bust while maintaining critical functions. The consultation, open until April 20, is crucial for Hong Kong to maintain its status as a global financial center, with 38 of the world's largest and most systemically important firms operating in the city.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint unit sells stake in Beijing property firm
summary: Frasers Centrepoint's indirect subsidiary, Sinomax International, sold its entire stake in Beijing Sin Hua Yan Real Estate Development Co Ltd for 357.4 million yuan (S$76.6 million). The sale involves a retail mall cum office building, Crosspoint, with a net lettable area of 156,336 square feet in Beijing. The divestment aligns with Frasers Centrepoint's strategy of streamlining non-core businesses to focus on main activities.

site_title: Record new LNG supplies to pull prices down further, boost demand: Bernstein
summary: New liquefied natural gas (LNG) supplies are expected to boost demand, putting downward pressure on prices that have halved over the past year. Over 60 million tonnes of new LNG production will start up in 2015 and 2016, lifting capacity by 20% to 345 million tonnes a year. Analysts predict LNG prices will remain low this year due to new projects in Australia and Japan, despite public resistance to nuclear power restarts. Demand is expected to increase by 9.8% in 2015, and prices may rise in the longer term as demand continues to rise.

images.alt_text: The next two years will see the biggest ever additions made to liquefied natural gas (LNG) supplies, almost all in Asia, putting further pressure on prices that have halved over the past year.

site_title: Sabana Reit's Q4 DPU down 18.7%
summary: Sabana Reit's Q4 DPU dropped 18.7% to 1.78 Singapore cents, with distributable income falling 14.8% to S$12.9 million and net property income down 8.6% to S$18.2 million. This marked a 21.9% decline in full-year DPU. The trust's units remained unchanged at S$0.925.

site_title: China labour activists say facing unprecedented intimidation
summary: China's labour activists face unprecedented intimidation as the country's economic slowdown fuels industrial unrest. The number of strikes doubled to 1,378 in 2014, with a record-breaking strike at Adidas and Nike supplier Yue Yuen. Labour activists, including Zeng Feiyang and Zhang Zhiru, report police intimidation, including overnight arrests and threats from landlords. The government is pressuring NGOs to stop receiving foreign funding, instead encouraging workers to turn to the state-sponsored All-China Federation of Trade Unions. Despite the risks, activists remain undeterred, with Zeng saying he would not regret his work if he were imprisoned.

site_title: West trying to throttle Russia's economy, overthrow Putin: Kremlin
summary: Western countries are trying to isolate and weaken Russia's economy and President Vladimir Putin through the Ukraine conflict, according to Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov. Despite "illegal sanctions," Russia's economic situation is under control, Peskov said. Russia is providing humanitarian aid and supplies, but cannot resolve the conflict in Ukraine as the West demands. Peskov urged Kiev to start talking to its own regions, and suggested that a meeting of leaders could be held in Astana if concrete results are achieved. The Kremlin sees the events in Ukraine as a test of international diplomacy.

site_title: China money rate increases as banks build up cash before holiday
summary: China's money-market rate increased by 27 basis points to 4% due to speculation banks will hoard funds before the Chinese New Year holidays. The People's Bank of China is rolling over $43.4 billion in loans and offering alternative funding methods, potentially tightening liquidity ahead of the holidays. Experts warn of a potential tightening of funds, citing the PBOC's decision to avoid open-market operations.

site_title: Ex-AG Walter Woon joins RHTLaw Taylor Wessing; Robson Lee to join Gibson Dunn
summary: Former Singaporean Attorney-General Walter Woon has joined RHTLaw Taylor Wessing as non-executive chairman and senior consultant, bringing his extensive experience in law, politics, and diplomacy to the firm. He will provide strategic counsel and leadership to the management and board. Meanwhile, Robson Lee has joined Gibson Dunn & Crutcher as a partner in the Singapore office, focusing on mergers and acquisitions and capital markets transactions.

site_title: UBS's Weber says euro inflation won't return to target level for "years"
summary: UBS Chairman Axel Weber stated that eurozone inflation won't return to the ECB's target level of 2% for years due to persistently low inflation. Weber also expressed doubt about a significant pickup in European growth in the near future. This assessment comes despite potential measures from ECB President Mario Draghi.

site_title: Fortune Reit's Q4 distributable income up 8.3%
summary: Fortune Reit reported an 8.3% increase in Q4 distributable income to HK$197.2 million, a 10.50 Hong Kong cent DPU, up 8% from last year. Net property income rose 6.7% to HK$293.5 million, driven by an 8.4% increase in total revenue to HK$425.7 million.

site_title: Singapore Exchange Q2 profit up 15.5%, highest in one year
summary: Singapore Exchange Ltd reported a 15.5% increase in Q2 net profit to S$86.6 million, the highest in over a year, driven by a 46% rise in derivatives revenue to a record S$76.4 million. Trading volumes rose 52% to 40 million contracts, contributing to the growth. The exchange attributed the improvement to accelerated capital investments in derivatives and fixed income businesses, aiming to boost trading volume.

images.alt_text: Singapore Exchange Ltd (SGX) , which has rolled out a slew of measures to boost trading volume, said its quarterly net profit rose 15.5 per cent to the highest in more than one year, helped by record derivatives business.

site_title: China says its gender imbalance "most serious" in the world
summary: China's health authorities described the country's gender imbalance among newborns as "the most serious and prolonged" in the world, directly linked to its one-child policy. The strict policy has led to a traditional bias for sons, resulting in 118 boys born for every 100 girls. The government has stepped up supervision on foetal sex determination, which is banned, and acknowledged that women are transferring blood samples overseas to determine baby genders for profit. This has exacerbated the imbalance, raising concerns about social stability and economic growth.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher, with the Straits Times Index gaining 20.44 points to 3,354.46. A total of 2 billion shares valued at S$1.11 billion were traded, with 248 gains and 183 losses. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains, ahead of upcoming GDP data.

site_title: Europe: Shares extend rally
summary: European shares rose for the fifth consecutive session, driven by expectations of a European Central Bank quantitative easing program to boost the economy. The FTSEurofirst 300 index gained 0.2% to 1,425.94 points. ASML NV rose 4.6% after better-than-expected fourth-quarter results. The rally comes as investors focus on US-EU trade talks and despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: SGX's Q2 net profit up 16%
summary: SGX posted a 16% increase in net profit for its second fiscal quarter, reaching S$86.6 million, driven by strong derivatives growth. This contrasts with a 2% decline in the first half. The market operator will declare a dividend of four Singapore cents per share.

site_title: ECB action could hurt banks' margins: Deutsche Bank co-CEO
summary: The European Central Bank's expected bond buying stimulus program could significantly impact banks in Europe, potentially destroying margins. Deutsche Bank's co-CEO, Anshu Jain, stated that quantitative easing will bring stability but also very low interest rates, which will be a huge challenge for banks. Markets expect the ECB to announce around 750 billion euros in QE, with 500 billion seen as slightly disappointing and one trillion viewed as bullish. Banks will need to adjust their business models to adapt to the new environment, which could last until European growth turns around.

images.alt_text: The European Central Bank's expected launch of a bond buying stimulus programme on Thursday will have a profound effect on banks in Europe and could destroy margins, the co-head of Deutsche Bank said.

site_title: UK households' optimism over finances highest on record: Markit
summary: UK households' optimism about their finances reached a record high in January, with a measure of financial well-being increasing to its highest level since the survey began six years ago. Inflation tumbled, reducing expectations of higher interest rates, and only 32% of respondents anticipated an increase in the first half of 2015. This boost in optimism is attributed to low inflation and decreased expectations of interest rate hikes, indicating a positive outlook for UK households' financial prospects.

site_title: Obama says 'shadow of crisis has passed'
summary: President Barack Obama declared in his State of the Union address that the US has turned a page on years of war and economic hardship, calling for a new chapter in US history with a fairer economy for the middle class. He proposed tax hikes for the rich to fund middle-class breaks, including a minimum wage increase and equal pay for women. Republicans quickly criticized the speech as more about politics than leadership, with several senators stating that the economy still struggles with stagnant wages and lost jobs.

site_title: SNB was right to scrap Swiss franc cap: UBS's Weber
summary: Axel Weber, UBS chairman, supports the SNB's decision to scrap the Swiss franc cap, stating it was a temporary measure that the Swiss economy could withstand. Weber criticizes European politicians for not reforming their economies during the ECB's bond-buying program and advises caution, as excessive measures would remove incentives for reform.

site_title: PTC agrees to raise public bus and train fares by 2.8%, but 1.1 million commuters expected not to see any changes
summary: The Public Transport Council (PTC) agreed to raise public bus and train fares by 2.8% in April 2015. However, 1.1 million commuters will not see any changes due to frozen senior citizen fares and existing travel concession passes. The fare increase will generate S$48.5 million in additional revenue, with S$13.5 million allocated to the Public Transport Fund for transport vouchers for the needy.

site_title: UK earnings outpace inflation again, unemployment falls to 5.8%
summary: The UK economy saw average weekly earnings rise 1.7% in November, outpacing inflation, giving Prime Minister David Cameron a boost ahead of May's national elections. This marks the third consecutive month of earnings growth surpassing inflation, a trend that has continued for three months. Unemployment fell to 5.8%, providing further positive economic indicators.

site_title: Brent crude oil rises above US$48.50, but outlook remains weak
summary: Brent crude oil prices rose above $48.50 on Wednesday, but analysts predict weak prices for the next six months due to oversupply. The International Monetary Fund cut its 2015 global economic forecast, and Iran hinted at potential price drops to $25 a barrel. Despite stabilization, analysts expect a large stock build and a stronger dollar to hinder upward price improvements. Lower oil prices have led to decreased inflation in many countries, creating room for policy easing in key economies.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 19.98 points to close at 1,770.09, driven by gains in the stock market. On Wednesday, 2.16 billion lots valued at RM2.45 billion were traded, with 559 gains and 287 losses. The index's performance was largely unaffected by global market trends, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Oil inches above US$48, outlook remains weak
summary: Oil prices edged above US$48 a barrel on Wednesday, but traders and analysts expect further weakness due to oversupply and potential inventory rises. The International Monetary Fund cut its 2015 global economic forecast, and OPEC member Iran hinted at further price drops. Brent rose 61 US cents to US$48.60 a barrel, while US crude added 41 US cents to US$46.88. Industry forecasts indicate a surplus in 2015, prompting investment cuts and a potential rise in inventories.

images.alt_text: Oil edged above US$48 a barrel on Wednesday, consolidating after a drop in the previous session, although traders and analysts said oversupply and the prospect of inventory rises made further weakness likely.

site_title: Obama says US, not China, must write trade rules
summary: President Barack Obama stated in his State of the Union address that the US, not China, should write trade rules for Asia, emphasizing the need for "strong new trade deals" that protect American workers. He urged Congress to grant him trade promotion authority to negotiate these deals, warning that China's dominance could disadvantage US workers and businesses. Obama acknowledged past trade deals had not always met expectations, but emphasized the importance of fair trade agreements.

images.alt_text: President Barack Obama said on Tuesday the United States and not China must write trade rules for Asia and called on Congress to give the White House a freer hand to close trade deals.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 0.49%
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 0.49% lower on Wednesday, as the yen rose and the Bank of Japan withheld fresh easing measures. The Nikkei 225 index fell 85.82 points to 17,280.48, while the Topix index lost 0.50% to 1,390.61.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust Q3 DPU up 11.5%
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust reported a 11.5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) for its fiscal third quarter, driven by a 10.7% rise in net property income to S$54.7 million. DPU for the period ended Dec 31, 2014, was 2.08 Singapore cents, up from 1.865 Singapore cents in the same period last year. The gains in gross revenue outpaced property operating expenses.

site_title: Samsung drops Qualcomm processors in next Galaxy S: report
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd will not use Qualcomm Inc's processors for the next Galaxy S smartphone, citing overheating issues with the Snapdragon 810 chip during testing. The South Korean company will instead use its own Exynos processors, which could boost sales for its struggling foundry business. This decision may also enhance Samsung's credentials as a chip designer and manufacturer, potentially attracting more orders from companies like Apple Inc. The move is seen as a blow to Qualcomm's prospects for 2015, which had already guided for weaker-than-usual annual revenue growth.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd will not use Qualcomm Inc's processors for the next version of the South Korean technology giant's flagship Galaxy S smartphone, Bloomberg reported on Wednesday, citing unidentified sources.

site_title: Tier PIC scheme for sustainability and efficacy: KPMG
summary: KPMG suggests the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme in Singapore be tiered into two phases. The first three-year phase would focus on higher cash payouts and flexibility for productivity-driven activities, while the next five years would concentrate on innovation and internationalisation, including intellectual property registration and market feasibility studies. This tiered approach aims to boost the scheme's efficacy and sustainability.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares post biggest rise in 3 weeks
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.7% on Wednesday, their largest gain in three weeks, following a 7.7% drop in mainland Chinese indexes on Monday. Investor confidence returned as China is expected to implement stimulus measures to boost economic growth. The Shanghai Composite Index posted its biggest one-day rise in over five years, with Chinese investment flowing into Hong Kong through a mutual market access pilot program. Strategists attribute the rally to a focus on fundamentals rather than liquidity, with investors betting on easing policies from China.

site_title: Seoul: Won bolsters gains after BOJ holds policy; shares edge up
summary: The South Korean won rose against the dollar after the Bank of Japan maintained its policy stance, prompting speculators to cover their short positions. The won was quoted at 1,083.4 to the dollar, while South Korean shares edged up 0.15% to 1,921.23 points, driven by growing expectations of European Central Bank stimulus measures.

site_title: Bank of England dissenters drop call for higher rates: minutes
summary: The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee voted unanimously to keep interest rates on hold in January, marking the first time since July, due to tumbling inflation. External members Martin Weale and Ian McCafferty dropped their call for higher rates, citing a potential risk of below-target inflation. British inflation fell to 0.5% in January, its lowest level in 14 years, below the BoE's 2% target.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England voted unanimously to keep rates on hold in January for the first time since July, after two policymakers dropped their call for higher rates in the face of tumbling inflation.

site_title: Indonesia will not make public preliminary AirAsia crash report
summary: Indonesia will not release a preliminary report on the AirAsia passenger jet crash that killed 162 people last month. The report, expected to be submitted to the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) next week, is a requirement under ICAO regulations. Chairman of the National Transportation Safety Committee, Tatang Kurniadi, declined to comment on the report's contents. The decision not to make the report public has raised concerns about transparency in the investigation.

site_title: COE premiums mostly higher in latest round of bidding
summary: COE premiums largely increased in the latest round of bidding, with cars above 1,600 cc or 130 bhp seeing the largest jump to S$76,889. In contrast, COE for cars up to 1,600 cc and 130 bhp decreased to S$65,001. The premium for motorcycles edged up to S$4,889, while goods vehicles and buses saw a marginal increase to S$55,012. The open category also saw a significant rise to S$76,790.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Swedish 5-yr inflation expectations unchanged in January: TNS Prospera
summary: Sweden's long-term inflation expectations remained unchanged at 1.7% in January, according to a TNS Prospera survey commissioned by the central bank. Short-term expectations decreased slightly. The Riksbank, Sweden's central bank, targets 2% inflation, which it has consistently undershot.

site_title: Four under investigation after Paris attack: prosecutor
summary: Four men, aged 22-28, have been placed under formal investigation and detained in connection with the Paris attack that killed 17 victims. The investigation, led by Paris prosecutor Francois Molins, aims to find possible accomplices, particularly abroad, and will involve international cooperation with Turkey, Spain, and Belgium. The four suspects have been in police custody since Friday.

site_title: Total CEO sees oil staying at low levels in H1 2015: French TV
summary: Total CEO Patrick Pouyanne predicts oil prices will remain low throughout the first half of 2015, citing factors such as global demand and producer country behavior. The price of oil has dropped 60% since June, currently trading at around $47 a barrel. Pouyanne believes a sustained low oil price is beneficial for the economy, but notes that prices may rise again if demand for oil products increases.

site_title: China: Shares close up 4.74% as rebound continues
summary: Chinese shares surged 4.74% on Wednesday, marking the largest gain since October 2009, driven by buying in heavyweight financial stocks. The Shanghai Composite Index jumped 150.56 points to 3,323.61 on 473.8 billion yuan in turnover. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 2.40%, fueled by a rebound from the biggest decline in over six years.

site_title: Malaysia's Dec inflation eases to 2.7% y-o-y, below forecasts
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate eased to 2.7% in December, below forecasted 2.8%, as domestic food prices rose despite falling fuel prices. The increase was attributed to the worst flood in decades. This marks a decrease from November's 3% inflation rate.

site_title: Australia: Shares post biggest one-day gain in 2015; NZ stocks set record high
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares experienced significant gains on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 1.6% and New Zealand's NZX 50 index setting a record high. The gains were driven by hopes of stimulus from central banks to bolster uneven global growth, with miners leading the increase. The Australian benchmark is still down 0.3% for the month, while the New Zealand index surpassed its previous record high.

site_title: Toyota still world's top automaker with 10.23m vehicles sold in 2014
summary: Toyota maintained its position as the world's top automaker in 2014, selling 10.23 million vehicles worldwide, surpassing General Motors and Volkswagen. However, the company expects a decline in sales this year to 10.15 million vehicles, potentially allowing Volkswagen to overtake it. Toyota's fiscal year profit forecast was boosted by strong results in North America, but concerns about the Chinese economy and its own safety issues, including a Takata air bag crisis, may impact its future prospects.

site_title: Oil prices have reached 'bottom': Iraqi minister
summary: Oil prices have reached their "bottom" after a nearly 60% decline since June, according to Iraqi Oil Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi. The prices are unlikely to fall further, and analysts expect them to rebound due to a supply glut and weakening global demand. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 44 cents to $46.91, while Brent North Sea crude added 44 cents to $48.42. The low prices may reduce surplus production and support prices, with BHP Billiton cutting back on its US shale oil rigs by 40%.

site_title: China to clamp down on firms evading fuel oil consumption tax: document
summary: China plans to clamp down on companies evading fuel oil consumption taxes by blending bitumen into heavy fuel oil and heavy crude, then declaring it as bitumen. An estimated 270,000 to 540,000 tonnes of this mixture are imported monthly, avoiding 1.2 yuan per liter tax. A committee comprising nine ministries will tackle the issue starting January. This practice has been ongoing since at least 2014.

site_title: An impasse in Paris, a gamble in Athens: how Greece returned to crisis
summary: Greece's standoff with creditors in Paris has led to a political impasse, potentially altering the country's economic course. After four years of austerity measures, Greece sought an early bailout exit but negotiations collapsed. The resulting uncertainty has led to elections next week, where a far-left party, Syriza, is expected to win, further worrying investors and creditors. This outcome could mark Greece as the eurozone's weakest link, exacerbating regional economic instability.

site_title: Toyota flags sales fall in 2015 as emerging markets, Japan stall
summary: Toyota expects a 1% decline in global vehicle sales to 10.15 million in 2015 due to stagnant demand in emerging markets like China and Indonesia, as well as in Japan. The company anticipates a 0.4% rise in parent-only sales to 9.18 million vehicles, with a 2% increase overseas and a 7% fall in Japan. This marks a reversal from the 3% growth in 2014.

site_title: Australian wine exports rebound as China chooses cheaper tipples
summary: Australian wine exports to China rebounded by 8% in 2014, reaching 40 million litres valued at A$224 million, after a 16% decline in 2013. The surge was driven by sales of lower-priced wines, while Asia accounted for 90% of Australia's ultra-premium wine exports. Overall, Australian wine exports rose 1.9% in volume and value to 700 million litres or A$1.82 billion, driven by strong demand for premium wines in North America, Europe, and Asia.

site_title: China revises 2013 economic growth rates
summary: China has revised its 2013 economic growth rates, with the full-year rate remaining at 7.7%. Quarterly growth rates for 2014 were also revised. This is part of the country's annual review of its gross domestic product data, which typically occurs after the full-year growth report is released. The revisions were made after a new economic census, which increased the 2013 GDP by 3.4% or $305 billion. This change does not affect China's 2014 economic growth rate, which was 7.4%.

images.alt_text: China has revised quarterly economic growth rates for 2013, though the full year rate of 7.7 per cent was unaltered, the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) said on Wednesday, releasing its regular review of the data series.

site_title: Yen rises despite Bank of Japan cutting inflation outlook
summary: The Japanese yen rose against the dollar and euro on Wednesday after the Bank of Japan cut its inflation outlook and decided against fresh easing measures. The yen rose to 117.79 yen per dollar, down from 118.40 yen before the decision. Despite the cut in inflation projections, the BoJ boosted its growth forecasts, citing a rebounding economy. Investors are now waiting for the European Central Bank's policy meeting on Thursday, which may impact the euro and dollar. The US Federal Reserve is expected to start raising interest rates in the middle of the year or earlier.

site_title: China: Stocks recover further from plunge, led by finance and property shares
summary: China's stock market rebounded on Wednesday, with the CSI300 index rising 2.3% and the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 2.2%. Finance and real estate shares led the recovery, following a 7.7% drop on Monday due to concerns about margin trading. The regulator denied intentionally suppressing the rally, and market sentiment is seen as having settled. Broker profits surged 119% in 2014, and China's stock market is expected to continue mirroring Hong Kong's performance.

site_title: Luxury Manhattan condos pile up as foreigners lose buying power
summary: Foreigners are losing buying power in Manhattan as the strengthening US dollar impacts their purchasing power. New luxury condominiums are flooding the market, but sales are struggling due to reduced demand from international buyers. Real estate agent Lisa Gustin listed a four-bedroom Tribeca loft for $7.45 million, but had to cut the price by $550,000 after failing to secure a sale. This trend is expected to continue in cities like New York, Miami, and Los Angeles, where new high-priced condos are being released just as international buyers are losing purchasing power.

site_title: Gold prices top US$1,300 an ounce for first time in five months
summary: Gold prices surpassed US$1,300 an ounce for the first time in five months, driven by speculation that slowing global growth will prompt central banks to boost stimulus, sparking haven demand. This marks the first monthly gain in exchange-traded products backed by the metal since July. Money managers have increased their net-bullish position to the largest since August, indicating investors are returning to the metal amid concerns about US growth and foreign economies.

site_title: URA seeks feedback on short-term private home rentals
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched a public survey to gather feedback on short-term private home rentals. The review, which does not include Housing Board flats, aims to address the rise of websites like Airbnb that offer cheaper alternatives to hotels. The survey will run until February 23 and can be submitted online. The move is expected to heat up competition in the hospitality industry, but the URA has not yet announced any plans to regulate short-term rentals. The review is part of the URA's ongoing assessment of the short-term rental market in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The public survey that regulator Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) said it will launch in its review of short-term private home rentals is now live. The current review does not include Housing Board flats.

site_title: Chinese billionaire Wang to buy stake in Atletico Madrid
summary: Chinese billionaire Wang Jianlin is buying a 20% stake in Atletico Madrid through Dalian Wanda Group for 45 million euros. This marks the first investment by a Chinese company in a top European soccer club. The deal aims to boost Wanda's brand recognition and reduce risks in China's competitive commercial real estate market. In return, Wanda and Atletico will invest 15 million euros in a training center and soccer schools in Madrid and China.

site_title: Goldex CEO caught on bus in US$970m Colombia laundering case
summary: Colombia's Attorney General's office says the CEO of CI Goldex SA, John Hernandez, was captured on a bus, ending a manhunt. He is accused of being at the center of a US$970 million money-laundering scheme, the largest in the country's history. The alleged scheme involves Colombian cocaine traffickers, Marxist guerrillas, and others who launder around US$10 billion annually, equivalent to 3% of the country's GDP.

site_title: Oil prices rebound in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices rebounded in Asian trade on Wednesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising 34 US cents to $46.81 and Brent North Sea crude adding 26 US cents to $48.25. The rebound is attributed to profit-taking trade following a slide to near six-year lows, but analysts expect prices to remain low due to weakening global demand and a supply glut. The International Monetary Fund's forecast of 3.5% global economic growth this year is also cited as a factor. Oil prices have lost over half their value since June last year.

site_title: BOJ maintains stimulus, cuts inflation forecast
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its massive monetary stimulus and expanded a loan programme to encourage banks to boost lending, aiming to achieve its 2% inflation target. The central bank raised its economic growth forecast but cut its core consumer inflation projection to 1.0% due to a collapse in global oil prices. The BOJ will continue to increase base money at an annual pace of 80 trillion yen and extended its loan programmes until March 2026.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan maintained its massive monetary stimulus on Wednesday and expanded a loan programme aimed at encouraging banks to boost lending, signalling its resolve to achieve its ambitious 2 per cent inflation target.

site_title: Europe car sales speed up after six years of decline
summary: Europe's car sales rose by 5.7% in 2014, ending a six-year decline, but analysts warn the sector remains sluggish due to economic concerns. The European Automobile Manufacturer's Association notes current volumes are lower than pre-crisis levels, and sales growth is expected to be limited to 1-3% this year. A recovery to pre-crisis levels is likely still years away, with analysts predicting the market won't approach those levels until the end of the decade.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, rising 2.45 points to 1752.90. Gainers outnumbered losers 78 to 35, with volume reaching 34.16 million lots worth RM11.62 million.

site_title: Nomura to hire bankers abroad after cutting Asia equity jobs
summary: Nomura Holdings plans to hire 20 senior investment bankers in the US and Asia to boost its mergers and acquisitions business, despite cutting 12 Asia equities jobs in Hong Kong. The move aims to reclaim its status as Japan's top M&A adviser and work on global takeovers involving Japanese companies. The bankers will cover industries such as hotels, real estate, and healthcare, and will be based in Tokyo and other key locations. The hiring plans are part of Nomura's efforts to expand overseas and improve its profitability.

site_title: JGBs edge down as market awaits BOJ decision
summary: Japanese government bond prices eased on Wednesday in anticipation of the Bank of Japan's policy meeting, where investors expect a cut in core consumer inflation forecast to below 1.5%. The BOJ is expected to maintain its asset buying program, although a surprise increase cannot be ruled out. The 20-year JGB yield rose 1 basis point to 0.875%, while the 5-year JGB yield increased 0.5 basis point to 0.005%. The market awaits the outcome of the policy meeting, which may influence the market's reaction to Thursday's 20-year JGB auction.

site_title: Keppel Land and Keppel Corp postpone post-results analyst and media briefing
summary: Keppel Land and Keppel Corp have postponed their post-results analyst and media briefing, citing more details to be provided shortly. The companies will release fourth-quarter and full-year results as scheduled, with Keppel Land on Wednesday and Keppel Corp on Thursday. Analysts had speculated on the possibility of a special dividend or a pick-up in the China market, but no further details have been provided.

site_title: NTUC calls on government to pursue investments with risk-free interest rates
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has urged the government to pursue investments with risk-free interest rates to boost workers' total savings and retirement benefits. NTUC recommended increasing the CPF Ordinary wage ceiling, raising the average gross monthly wage for low-wage workers, and providing incentives for self-employed individuals to contribute to the CPF savings. The organization also suggested introducing a 10-year Minimum Sum Schedule with corresponding CPF Life monthly payouts and allowing for voluntary top-ups subject to a cap.

site_title: Australia: Shares rally on ECB hopes, NZ stocks hit record high
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares rallied on Wednesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 1.3% and the NZX-50 index reaching a fresh record high. Gains were driven by hopes for central bank stimulus and weaker oil prices, which boosted consumer sentiment. Key sectors, including miners, banks, and energy companies, also saw significant gains, with Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton leading the charge.

site_title: Obama calls for simplifying tax filing for small businesses
summary: US President Barack Obama called for simplifying tax filing for small businesses in his State of the Union address, aiming to reduce costs for owners. He suggested allowing businesses to file based on their actual bank statements instead of hiring accountants. Additionally, Obama proposed new bipartisan fast-track legislation to speed trade agreements through Congress.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore share prices opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 4.93 points to 3,338.95. Volume reached 72.8 million shares valued at S$70.5 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 71 to 58.

site_title: Mining giant BHP cuts US shale oil rigs by 40% amid sliding price
summary: BHP Billiton, the world's largest miner, is reducing its US shale oil rigs by 40% due to sliding oil prices. The company will cut the number of rigs from 26 to 16 by the end of June. Despite the reduction, BHP expects shale volumes to grow by approximately 50% during the financial year. CEO Andrew Mackenzie attributed the move to lower prices, stating that the company has "moved quickly" to respond to the change.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open down 0.33%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.33% lower on Wednesday, following a 2.07% gain the previous day due to a weakening yen. Investors await the European Central Bank's monetary policy meeting and the Bank of Japan's policy meeting. Sharp fell 3.08% after reports of planned LCD panel production cuts due to slowing sales. The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed flat on Tuesday.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up, boosted by tech shares, overseas markets
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.5% on Wednesday, driven by gains in technology shares and overseas markets. The main TAIEX index reached 9301.72, following a 0.85% increase on Tuesday. Domestic shares tracked firmness in overseas markets, with the electronics sub-index up 0.7% and the semiconductor sub-index 1.4% higher. The news comes after Taiwan's export orders hit a record high last year, led by demand for technology goods.

site_title: Singapore IDA offers US$200m in funds to tech startups
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) has launched a US$200 million fund to support tech startups, particularly those interested in expanding into Asia. The IDA's investment arm, Infocomm Investments Pte Ltd, aims to foster new technology talents and support the country's Smart Nation initiative. The fund will focus on innovative solutions to analyze Singapore's 8,000 open government data sets, with curated ideas potentially being scaled globally to tackle urban challenges.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall on global growth worry, ECB in focus
summary: South Korean shares fell on Wednesday due to concerns over global growth and sliding oil prices. The market is anticipating the European Central Bank's (ECB) policy meeting, where more stimulus measures are expected. Analysts believe the ECB's previous steps towards buying government bonds may lead to more decisive action, but past meetings have been marked by disappointment. The market sentiment remains cautious ahead of the ECB's announcement.

site_title: South Korea Jan 1-20 exports down sharply, fall 9.0% y-o-y
summary: South Korea's exports declined 9.0% in the first 20 days of January compared to the same period last year, reaching $24.671 billion. Imports also dropped 10.6% to $25.940 billion during the same period. This marks a rocky start to the year for the fourth-largest economy in Asia.

site_title: IBM profit forecast, fourth-quarter revenue below estimates
summary: IBM reported a new 2015 profit target and quarterly revenue below analysts' estimates, falling 1.6% to $154.48 in extended trading. The company's annual revenue fell to $93 billion in 2014, and it forecast 2015 operating earnings of $15.75-$16.50 per share, missing the average estimate of $16.53. IBM's fourth-quarter revenue fell 12% to $24.11 billion, with net income declining to $5.48 billion or $5.51 per share.

site_title: Obama urges Congress to give women equal pay
summary: US President Barack Obama urged Congress to pass a law guaranteeing equal pay for women, stating it's crucial for boosting family incomes. He called for better pay, childcare support, paid sick and maternity leave, and overtime wages to help working-class families. The proposal comes after data shows men earn nearly 18% more than women for the same jobs, and the US is the only advanced country without guaranteed paid sick leave or paid maternity leave. Obama emphasized the need for "middle-class economics" to strengthen household incomes and pull Americans from poverty.

site_title: Obama calls on Congress to back bipartisan infrastructure plan
summary: President Barack Obama called on Congress to pass a bipartisan infrastructure plan, which could create over 30 times as many jobs per year as the Keystone XL pipeline. In his State of the Union address, Obama prioritized modernizing US infrastructure, including ports, bridges, and internet connections. He rejected "offensive" stereotypes of Muslims and addressed anti-Semitism globally. This move contrasts with Republicans' focus on the Keystone XL pipeline, and Obama's proposal aims to address the country's infrastructure needs.

site_title: Obama chooses income equality as next battleground
summary: US President Barack Obama emphasized income equality as his next priority in his State of the Union address, following a resounding defeat for his Democratic Party in Congressional elections. Despite the economy's recovery, the average American has not seen a rebound in wages since the 2008 crisis. Obama vowed to address the issue, which has seen the wealthy become wealthier while the middle class struggles. This shift in focus comes two months after the Congressional elections, which highlighted growing income inequality concerns among voters.

site_title: China: Shares up in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares rose 0.58% in morning trade on Wednesday, with the Shanghai Composite Index increasing to 3,191.45 and the Shenzhen Composite Index rising to 1,482.75. This uptrend was driven by bargain hunters seeking heavyweight financial plays that fell earlier in the week.

site_title: Tycoon Li Ka-shing's Cheung Kong Infrastructure to sell US$593m shares
summary: Cheung Kong Infrastructure Holdings Ltd, controlled by tycoon Li Ka-shing, plans to raise HK$4.6 billion (US$593 million) through a share sale. The company, which recently acquired Eversholt Rail for US$3.8 billion, will sell 80 million new shares at HK$58 each. The funds raised will be used for general funding purposes. This is part of Li Ka-shing's plan to diversify his business empire and boost its value, as he announced earlier this month to restructure his businesses into two camps.

site_title: Obama asks Congress for power to set trade pacts
summary: President Barack Obama asked Congress to grant him trade promotion authority to negotiate and finalize the Trans-Pacific Partnership and Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership trade pacts. He argues that this will boost the economy and protect American workers from China's efforts to dominate trade in the Asian region. The authority would allow the White House to negotiate complete trade deals without Congress's power to amend them, and then submit them for ratification. This move aims to level the playing field and capitalize on 95% of the world's customers.

site_title: Cambridge Industrial Trust refinances debt; S$55m 3.5% notes 1.4 times subscribed
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust, a real estate investment trust, has refinanced S$50 million of 4.75% debt maturing in March 2015 with S$55 million of 3.5% debt maturing in November 2018. The issue was 1.4 times subscribed, part of its S$500 million multicurrency medium term note programme. This move reduces the Reit's interest rate exposure, with 90% of debt fixed for 2.5 years, and brings its all-in cost of debt to 3.55% per annum.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel stocks, CCT, MIT, Rex, Blumont
summary: Keppel Land and parent Keppel Corp announced trading halts on Wednesday morning amid speculation of a special dividend or China market pick-up. Keppel T&T recommended a bumper dividend payout after its results showed a surge in net profit due to the disposal of data centre properties. CapitaCommercial Trust (CCT) reported a 2.9% increase in DPU to 2.15 cents, while Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) increased its DPU by 6.4% to 2.67 cents. Rex International found two commercially viable wells in Trinidad & Tobago but expects a significantly bigger loss for its financial year.

site_title: US demands IS release of Japanese hostages
summary: The US has demanded the immediate release of two Japanese hostages threatened with death by Islamic State militants. State Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki condemned the threat and expressed support for Japan, stating that the US Secretary of State, John Kerry, would speak with his Japanese counterpart later in the day.

site_title: Rex International to record 'significantly bigger' loss for 2014 from impairment
summary: Rex International will record a "significantly bigger" loss for 2014 due to an impairment of Fram Exploration, a Norwegian company with US oil rights. The impairment decision is attributed to falling oil prices and difficulty in securing investments. Rex will subscribe to half of Fram's latest fund-raising round, increasing its stake to 30.3%. The company has also completed three wells in Trinidad & Tobago, with two found commercially viable at below budgeted costs.

images.alt_text: Oil exploration and production firm Rex International said it will record a "significantly bigger loss" for its financial year ended 2014, results which will be announced by March 1.

site_title: Facebook clamps down on fake news stories
summary: Facebook has introduced an option to flag fake news stories as "purposefully fake or deceitful news" to reduce their distribution. However, the company will not remove the stories from its website. Instead, the algorithm will take into account hoax reports, reducing the visibility of posts linked to fake news in the News Feed. This move aims to curb the spread of hoaxes without suppressing free speech.

site_title: CapitaCommercial Trust reports Q4 DPU of 2.15 cents; yield now 4.6%
summary: CapitaCommercial Trust reported a Q4 DPU of 2.15 cents, up 2.9% from the same period last year, and a full-year DPU of 8.46 cents, up 3.9%. The yield is 4.6%. Net property income rose 3% to S$50.6 million, and distributable income increased 5.7% to S$63.6 million. The Reit's first development project, CapitaGreen, secured leases for 69.3% of its net lettable area as of end-2014.

site_title: China stock surge to boost SGX profit on derivatives demand
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is expected to report its first quarterly profit growth in over a year, driven by a surge in derivatives trading, particularly in China A-50 futures contracts. Derivatives volume reached an all-time high in the three months ended December, with trading of FTSE China A-50 futures contracts jumping 183% from the previous year. SGX's net income is predicted to be S$87 million, up from S$75 million a year ago. This growth is attributed to efforts to attract investors across a broader range of asset classes, as cash equity market volumes stagnate.

site_title: Bodies of 3 employees of Sembcorp Marine unit to be repatriated from China this week
summary: Three employees of Jurong Marine Services, who died when a tugboat they were on sank in the Yangtze River, China, are expected to be repatriated to Singapore and Batam this week. The employees, aged 53, 41, and 27, were on board to witness the sea trial of the tugboat. The incident occurred during the sea trial, resulting in the deaths of 22 people, including the three Jurong Marine Services employees. Investigations by Chinese maritime authorities are ongoing, and Sembcorp Marine has offered support to the bereaved families and employees affected by the incident.

site_title: Oil prices edge up in early trading but outlook remains weak
summary: Oil prices rose slightly in early Asian trading on January 21, 2015, after falling 5% the previous day due to the International Monetary Fund's reduced 2015 global economic forecast and Iran's hint at price drops to $25 a barrel. Despite this, analysts believe the outlook remains weak due to oversupply. Traders are waiting for benchmark Brent crude to drop to $48 a barrel to buy, indicating prices may stabilize.

images.alt_text: Oil prices edged up in early Asian trading on Wednesday in a further sign that prices are receiving support around current levels, but analysts said the outlook for the next six months remained weak due to oversupply.

site_title: Netflix cheers market with talk of profit after global rollout
summary: Netflix reported a 15% surge in shares after announcing plans to reach profitability in all 200 countries with broadband Internet within two years. The company expects to generate material global profits from 2017 onwards. Fourth-quarter revenue rose 26% to $1.48 billion, with international subscriber growth outpacing US growth for the third straight quarter. Netflix added 18.3 million international subscribers and 39.1 million worldwide subscribers, with forecasts of 1.8 million new US customers this quarter. The company plans to spend $9.5 billion on programming and borrow at least $1 billion to support its efforts.

site_title: Indonesia's Telkom cancels plan to buy New Zealand's 2 Degrees
summary: Indonesia's Telkom cancels plan to acquire New Zealand's 2 Degrees Mobile Ltd due to a disagreement on price. The planned acquisition, which would have given Telkom a stake of 25-30%, was announced in November 2014. Telkom is now focusing on partnership opportunities in Asia and the Middle East this year.

site_title: Sony's 'The Interview' surpasses US$40m in digital sales
summary: Sony's comedy film "The Interview" has sold over 5.8 million digital downloads, generating more than $40 million in revenue. The film's digital release was made available after the studio shelved a theatrical release due to threats of violence from hackers. The film's success marks a significant milestone for Sony's online and pay television release, despite the initial threats. President Barack Obama called the decision to scrap the theatrical release a "mistake."

site_title: Australia consumer sentiment picks up in January
summary: Australia's consumer sentiment index rose 2.4% in January, following a 5.7% drop in December, as petrol prices fell to six-year lows and employment data showed a 6.1% unemployment rate. The index for buying major household items surged 13.6%, while the outlook for the next 12 months improved by 1.2%. However, the index for economic conditions over the next 12 months eased 0.7% and the outlook for the next five years fell 1.6%. Westpac chief economist Bill Evans suggests the Reserve Bank of Australia may cut interest rates next month.

site_title: Google aboard as Musk's SpaceX gets US$1b in funding
summary: SpaceX has secured a US$1 billion investment from Google and Fidelity, with Google owning 10% of the company. The funding is aimed at helping SpaceX build a satellite Internet network, with founder Elon Musk's plan to deliver the Internet globally. Details on plans for the funds are not provided. This investment follows SpaceX's private space exploration efforts and marks a significant milestone in the company's expansion.

site_title: City of Paris aims to sue Fox News: mayor
summary: Paris mayor Anne Hidalgo announced plans to sue Fox News for "insulting" the city's image after the US cable network portrayed some neighborhoods as no-go-zones following deadly attacks in January 2015. Hidalgo stated that the city's honor had been prejudiced. Fox News apologized for the portrayal, but representatives did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

site_title: Deutsche Bank ranks top in fixed income: Greenwich Associates
summary: Deutsche Bank has ranked top in the global fixed income market for the fifth year in a row, according to a survey by Greenwich Associates. The German bank increased its market share to 10.1% in 2014, ahead of Citigroup (9.6%) and Barclays (9.4%). The survey attributed gains to growth in government bonds, investment-grade corporate bonds, and the US market for clients.

site_title: UniCredit not eying acquisitions after cooperative bank move
summary: Italy's UniCredit bank CEO Federico Ghizzoni stated the bank is not interested in making acquisitions following the Italian government's move to reform cooperative banks. The government approved a decree requiring cooperative banks to change governance rules and become joint stock companies within 18 months. UniCredit also reached an agreement to sell its debt collector unit UCCMB, with an announcement expected shortly. The bank had entered exclusive talks with US investment firm Fortress Investment Group and Italian real estate group Prelios last October, but talks are taking longer than expected.

images.alt_text: Italy's biggest bank UniCredit is not interested in making acquisitions even after the latest move by the Italian government to reform the country's cooperative banks, the lender's CEO Federico Ghizzoni said on Tuesday.

site_title: Alibaba, Tencent spend billions in race to be China's one-stop online shop
summary: Chinese internet giants Alibaba and Tencent have spent over $8 billion last year backing similar ventures, racing to create one-stop online shops to win the loyalty of China's vast population. The companies, including search engine provider Baidu, are investing heavily in services such as group-buying and taxi-hailing apps to stay relevant and attract users. The competition is fueled by the realization that the platform with the most users will have the biggest returns, with Alibaba and Tencent often backing similar ventures to outdo each other.

site_title: Fewer CEOs see better global economy this year
