This growth reflects the currency's increasing global profile, with offshore trading volumes soaring 350% on Thomson Reuters platforms. The yuan's rising dominance is also driven by the Renminbi Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor scheme, which has seen rapid growth, with the size of the scheme more than tripling to 870 billion yuan at the end of 2014. China aims to turn the yuan into a global currency to reduce its reliance on the US dollar.

site_title: Demand for home loans jumps in eurozone
summary: Demand for home loans in the eurozone surged in 2014, with one in four banks reporting a rise in home loan demand, according to a European Central Bank survey. The trend is expected to continue, fueled by consumers' optimism about rising house prices and banks' loosening lending standards. Strong demand was seen in the Netherlands, Germany, and Italy, with prices rising by almost a quarter in Germany's most prosperous cities. Critics warn that cheap money and record-low borrowing costs could fuel a property bubble, with some experts cautioning that prices may soon brake.

site_title: Daimler cuts Swiss Mercedes, Smart Car prices 18% on SNB move
summary: Daimler AG is cutting the prices of Mercedes-Benz and Smart cars in Switzerland by 18% due to the Swiss National Bank's decision to abandon a minimum exchange rate policy, causing the Swiss franc to surge versus the euro. The move aims to counter deflationary pressure in the country. The "currency rebate" will be applied to the list price of affected models, effectively reducing prices by 18%. This is the latest example of the impact of currency fluctuations on the automotive industry.

site_title: Malaysia trims economic sails in wake of oil price rout
summary: Malaysia has trimmed its 2015 growth forecast to 4.5-5.5% due to the sharp fall in oil prices, which has hit the country's economic plans. The government has also reduced its fiscal deficit target to 3.2% of GDP. Prime Minister Najib Razak announced measures to promote trade, tourism, and investment to keep the economy moving forward, including reducing business costs and allocating funds for recovery efforts. Analysts say the country should weather the storm due to its thriving manufacturing sector and less dependence on energy.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 26.32 points to 3,334.02. Over 1.23 billion shares, valued at S$949.7 million, were traded. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day rally.

site_title: Sim Lian places top bid for executive condominium site in Anchorvale Crescent
summary: Sim Lian Land has placed the top bid of S$157.80 million for a 1.75-hectare executive condominium site in Anchorvale Crescent, Singapore. The site, near the Cheng Lim LRT Station, is estimated to generate around 525 homes. The initial buyer eligibility and resale conditions are fully lifted 10 years after project completion. Allgreen Properties and Victoria Realty also submitted bids, with prices at S$143.89 million and S$126.80 million respectively.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: TAG Heuer discards 'Swiss Made' label to take on Apple watch
summary: TAG Heuer is abandoning its "Swiss Made" label to develop smartwatches in partnership with Silicon Valley companies, as Switzerland lacks the necessary technological expertise. According to Jean-Claude Biver, head of LVMH's timepiece unit, the brand will no longer manufacture watches exclusively in Switzerland. This move marks a significant shift for TAG Heuer, which will now work with partners to produce smartwatches, entering uncharted territory for the brand.

site_title: S&P warns prolonged oil slump may derail Malaysia's fiscal plan
summary: Malaysia's fiscal consolidation plan may be disrupted by a prolonged oil slump, according to Standard & Poor's. The credit rating agency warns that lower oil and gas revenues could affect overall economic growth, contradicting the government's revised 4.5-5.5% economic growth forecast. The ringgit currency hit a six-year low as the government reduced its budget and widened its fiscal deficit target, reflecting the impact of plunging oil prices.

site_title: German ZEW investor confidence gains as ECB stimulus approaches
summary: German investor confidence surged to 48.4 in January, the highest level in 11 months, ahead of the European Central Bank's potential quantitative easing. The ZEW Center for European Economic Research reported the increase, despite economists forecasting a 40-point rise. The ECB's bond-purchase program, expected to be announced on January 22, is seen as a boost to the German economy, with investors optimistic about exporters' prospects due to a weaker euro and strong equity market. The reading comes as the euro area faces deflation and the Bundesbank has expressed concerns about adding stimulus.

site_title: Rolexes fly off Singapore shelves as Swiss franc surges
summary: Rolexes and other Swiss luxury watches are flying off shelves in Singapore as the Swiss franc surges 20% against the euro and US dollar since Thursday. The franc's strengthening is due to the Swiss central bank's decision to abandon the minimum rate of 1.20 francs against the European common currency. Enthusiasts and investors are buying fine timepieces before retailers adjust their price tags, with some retailers reporting sold-out stocks. The franc's surge is expected to have a significant impact on the luxury watch industry.

images.alt_text: Rolexes and other Swiss luxury watches are flying off the shelves in Singapore after the Swiss franc surged against other currencies, retailers said on Tuesday.

site_title: Higher rents, lower operating costs boost Mapletree Industrial Trust's Q3 DPU
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust reported a 6.4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.67 Singapore cents for its Q3 2014, beating the previous year's payout. Gross revenue rose 3.3% to S$78.13 million, driven by higher rental rates and revenue from completed projects. Lower property operating expenses contributed to a 5.4% increase in net property income to S$57.98 million. The trust's average portfolio passing rent rose to S$1.83 per square foot, while occupancy fell to 90.8% due to tenant relocation.

site_title: China's Tencent shuts down 133 WeChat accounts for 'distorting history': Xinhua
summary: Tencent Holdings, China's largest social networking firm, shut down 133 WeChat accounts for 'distorting history', citing a government internet authority. The censored accounts spread fabricated information and disrupted online order, violating laws and regulations. China's Cyberspace Administration of China has been enforcing strict internet censorship and has closed 1.8 million accounts since an anti-pornography campaign. This move is part of China's efforts to promote a clean and controlled internet, reflecting its vision to influence global online content.

site_title: New S&P criteria draw line between sukuk issuers, sponsors
summary: Standard & Poor's has updated its criteria for Islamic bonds to distinguish between sukuk issuers and sponsors. The new criteria require sukuk to be rated on a par with the sponsor's senior unsecured rating if they provide contractual commitments to make payments. This may lead to withdrawals of ratings for fewer than 5% of rated sukuk. Global sukuk issuance is expected to exceed $100 billion this year, driven by positive economic outlooks in the Gulf region and Malaysia. The market is also expected to benefit from new sovereign issuers and Basel III banking standards, but may be affected by episodes of turbulence, including a potential drop in oil prices.

site_title: Chinese regulator sets up department to supervise trust firms
summary: China's banking regulator has established a new department to supervise trust firms, a move aimed at strengthening on-site inspection and risk supervision. The regulatory framework also sets up departments to oversee city commercial banks and credit cooperatives. This follows China's December rules governing the management of its US$2.1 trillion trust industry to reduce financial risk in shadow banking. The move is part of efforts to increase control over the shadow-banking sector, which has raised concerns about financial stability.

site_title: AirAsia crash probe focuses on human error, plane damage
summary: AirAsia Flight QZ8501 crashed in the Java Sea on December 28, killing 162 people. Investigators have ruled out terrorism and are considering human error or plane damage as causes. The cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder have been recovered, and 53 bodies have been found. Indonesia's National Transportation Safety Committee (NTSC) is analyzing the data and will release a preliminary report on January 28. Investigators are examining the possibility of plane damage and human factors, with bad weather also being considered a contributing factor.

images.alt_text: Investigators examining the cockpit voice recorder of a crashed AirAsia jet said on Tuesday they were considering whether human error or problems with the plane caused the accident, after ruling out terrorism.

site_title: Asset sale boosts Keppel T&T Q4 profit to S$198.4 million; declares special dividend
summary: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation (Keppel T&T) reported a Q4 net profit of S$198.4 million, a 1113% increase from the previous year, driven by gains from the disposal of data centre properties. Revenue rose 57.6% to S$70.9 million. The company declared a special cash dividend of 11.5 Singapore cents and a final cash dividend of 3.5 Singapore cents for the year.

site_title: Fitch says may downgrade Malaysia rating in upcoming review
summary: Fitch, a credit ratings agency, plans to review Malaysia's rating in the first half of 2015 and may downgrade the sovereign due to a revised fiscal deficit target. The agency cites dependence on commodities as a key credit weakness, as well as vulnerability to commodity price movements. Prime Minister Najib Razak revised the budget to reflect falling oil prices and a weakened ringgit. The review is prompted by the government's aim to achieve a balanced budget by 2020.

site_title: China raises wages for government workers at least 31%: document
summary: China has raised the wages of government workers by at least 31%, with basic salaries nearly tripling for some civil servants, as part of efforts to combat corruption and boost consumption. The increase, effective from October 1, 2014, is aimed at improving efficiency and accountability. The move follows a broader effort to reform compensation levels, with subsidies and performance bonuses frozen. Despite the increase, government worker salaries remain low, with ordinary workers earning around $82 per month. The move is seen as a step towards improving the quality of life for the average Chinese.

site_title: China's Alibaba makes first investment in Israeli firm
summary: Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba has made its first investment in an Israeli company, Visualead, a provider of QR code technology. The deal allows Alibaba to use Visualead's technology across its platforms, while Visualead will use the funding to develop its next-generation technology. This marks Alibaba's first investment in an Israeli company and follows its recent strategic cooperation agreement with AdChina, China's leading digital marketing platform.

site_title: Year of disasters sinks trust in business and governments
summary: A year of global disasters, including air crashes, data hacks, and the Ebola outbreak, has eroded trust in governments and businesses, according to a survey. The Edelman Trust Barometer found that trust in governments, business, media, and NGOs is below 50% in two-thirds of countries. The US, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy, Russia, and Turkey are among the countries with low trust. Business leaders, particularly CEOs, are also losing credibility, with trust falling for the third consecutive year. The survey attributes the decline to the unpredictable nature of recent events.

site_title: Hong Kong exchange chief said expects Shenzhen link this year
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEx) expects to extend its Shanghai trading link to the Shenzhen Stock Exchange this year, according to HKEx chief Charles Li. The addition would allow Chinese investors to trade Hong Kong shares via the Shenzhen Stock Exchange, and foreign investors to deal in Shenzhen shares via the Hong Kong exchange. Li hopes the expansion will happen in 2015, and the exchange is exploring ways to extend the scheme to other products, including index futures on the Shanghai-Hong Kong link.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up 2.07%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 2.07% on Tuesday, driven by a weakening yen that lifted exporters. The Nikkei 225 index gained 352.01 points to 17,366.30, while the Topix index climbed 1.84% to 1,397.63. The move followed European markets' rise on expectations of a European Central Bank stimulus.

site_title: Thai cabinet approves larger budget deficit for next fiscal year
summary: Thailand's military government approved a 56% increase in the budget deficit for the next fiscal year, projecting a 390 billion baht ($12 billion) deficit. Expenditure is expected to increase 5.6% to 2.72 trillion baht, with 544 billion baht allocated for investment. The junta aims to revive the economy after a coup ended months of political unrest and weak exports. The move is seen as a response to the country's economic challenges and a push for infrastructure projects to support Southeast Asia's second-largest economy.

site_title: In victory for Joko, Indonesia parliament backs direct regional vote
summary: Indonesia's parliament approved direct regional vote elections for governors and mayors in a unanimous decision, overturning a September measure that had given legislative assemblies the power to choose regional leaders. The move is seen as a victory for President Joko Widodo, who had opposed the legislation. The reversal comes after opposition parties, including former President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono's Democratic Party, threatened to leave the opposition if they did not support the reversal. The decision aims to restore direct elections, which were introduced in 2005 and have been criticized for being costly and corrupt.

site_title: Samsung in discussions with BlackBerry to expand partnership
summary: Samsung denies interest in acquiring BlackBerry, instead stating it's in talks to use the Canadian smartphone maker's technology in Samsung devices. The partnership would focus on business-to-business strategic partnerships, competing with IBM and Apple's alliance. Samsung's co-CEO Shin Jong Kyun says the goal is to "work with BlackBerry and develop this partnership, not acquire the company." The move aims to provide Samsung with new revenue sources as its smartphone business faces pressure.

site_title: Japan says will not give in to 'terrorism' after IS kidnapping
summary: The Japanese government has stated it will not give in to "terrorism" after a video emerged threatening to kill two Japanese if a $200 million ransom is paid. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's Middle East tour will be altered, with part of it canceled, but a summit with Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas will proceed. The government's stance on combating terrorism remains unchanged.

site_title: Southeast Asia stocks: Malaysia's index off high, Singapore outperforms
summary: Malaysia's stock index fell 0.2% on Tuesday after the government revised its economic policy, widening its fiscal deficit target to 3.2% of GDP for 2015. In contrast, Singapore's benchmark outperformed regional peers, with a 0.4% gain, driven by selective buying ahead of GDP data. The Kuala Lumpur composite index had earlier reached a near three-week high on Monday.

site_title: Singapore's GIC to invest US$165m in Indian bank permit winner Bandhan
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC is investing US$165.5 million in Indian bank Bandhan Financial Services. The investment, valued at 10.2 billion rupees, is part of a total equity investment of 16 billion rupees. Existing investor IFC will also increase its stake after the latest investment.

site_title: Twitter buys India mobile phone startup ZipDial
summary: Twitter has acquired Indian mobile marketing firm ZipDial for $30-$40 million. The deal aims to expand Twitter's presence in India, a rapidly growing mobile market. ZipDial provides phone numbers for marketing campaigns, and Twitter will take over the staff and offices of the firm. The acquisition is part of Twitter's efforts to improve the user experience for Indians with mobile devices, with plans to elevate the existing platform to a global scale.

site_title: Oil prices dip on weak China GDP data
summary: Oil prices dropped on Tuesday as China's economic growth for 2014 fell short of the government's target, with the world's second-largest economy growing 7.4% last year, its weakest annual expansion in 24 years. This led to concerns about slowing demand and oversupply in energy markets. Brent crude fell to $48.46 per barrel, down 38 cents from Monday's settlement, while US crude fell to $47.26 per barrel. Analysts attributed the price drop to the pause in the US dollar's appreciation and a potential improvement in industrial production in the long run.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise early as China data reassures
summary: European shares rose 0.5% in early trade, tracking a rally in Asian shares after China's economic growth slowed less than expected, reaching 7.4% in 2014. The data was seen as a relief for investors, who had feared a sharper slowdown. Meanwhile, Unilever shares fell 1.7% after posting lower-than-expected sales growth. The FTSEurofirst 300 index is near a seven-year high, just shy of 1,417.33 points.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices declined in Asia, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate falling to $47.43 and Brent crude to $48.78, amid weak global demand and oversupply. Analysts attribute the drop to increased US production, slow worldwide demand, and Saudi Arabia's decision not to act as OPEC's swing producer. Moody's lowered its price assumptions for Brent crude to $55-$65 per barrel and WTI to $52-$62 per barrel for 2015-2016, citing poor economic prospects, including a 3.5% global growth forecast for 2015 and 3.7% for 2016.

site_title: Parliament: Spike in HDB's net deficit for FY2013/14 expected due to ramp up: Khaw Boon Wan
summary: National Development Minister Khaw Boon Wan attributed the spike in Housing and Development Board's (HDB) net deficit for FY2013/14 to the ramp-up in flat-building and upgrading programmes. The net deficit rose to S$1.97 billion, a significant increase from S$443 million in FY2011/12. Khaw stated that the deficit is a result of government policies to provide affordable public housing and quality living environments for Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Rolex to raise watch prices in Japan after Swiss franc soars
summary: Rolex is increasing prices of its watches in Japan by 8% starting February 1 due to the Swiss franc's surge against the yen, caused by the removal of a currency peg. The price hike affects the steel Submariner Date with a black bezel, now priced at 810,000 yen (US$6,800). Patek Philippe is considering a similar price increase, ranging from 4% to 5%. The move is a response to the 17% increase in the franc's value against the yen since the Swiss National Bank's decision.

site_title: China workers decline as demographic time bomb ticks
summary: China's working-age population decreased to 915.8 million in 2014, down 3.7 million from 2013, due to its one-child policy. The population aged 60 and over rose by 10 million, reaching 15.5% of the total population. Projections show that one in four Chinese will be 60 or older by 2030. The sex ratio in 2014 was 105 men to 100 women, and the migrant population swelled to 253 million, sparking concerns over social stability and inequality.

site_title: Downside protection from STI's dividend yield: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse expects the Straits Times Index (STI) to experience single-digit percentage returns in the year ahead due to its attractive dividend yield of 3.7% and cheap valuation. The index's board lot size reduction is expected to boost market liquidity, benefiting higher-priced blue chips. Existing tax concessions for Reits are likely to be extended, and a partial relaxation of residential property purchase curbs could provide a sentiment boost to the market. This could drive a re-rating of property developer stocks, currently trading at a low price to book ratio.

site_title: External search for directors linked to higher ROEs: NUS Business School
summary: A study by the National University of Singapore Business School found that Singapore-listed companies that engage external search firms for board director appointments have an average return on equity (ROE) of 8.2%, compared to 5.5% for companies that do not disclose such information. The study, which analyzed data from over 600 companies, suggests that having a systematic approach to appointing directors is crucial for good corporate governance. However, it remains unclear whether the higher ROEs are caused by the use of external search firms or other factors.

site_title: China's 2014 steel output grows at slowest rate since 1981
summary: China's steel production grew at its slowest rate since 1981 in 2014, reaching a record 822.7 million tonnes, a 0.9% increase from the previous year. The country's economy, the world's second-largest, grew 7.4% in 2014, undershooting the government's target. Efforts to curb production and pollution appear to be working, but analysts warn of possible upward revisions to the data and forecast a small rise in steel production in 2015.

site_title: Chinese billionaire hires former Infiniti executive to make cars
summary: Chinese billionaire Jia Yueting has hired former Infiniti executive Allen Lu to head Leshi's expansion into electric vehicles. Lu will oversee the company's vehicle business in China, aiming to produce Web-enabled cars with indigenous intellectual property. Leshi plans to sell the vehicles globally, joining a growing list of Chinese billionaires, including Elon Musk, Wanxiang Group's Lu Guanqiu, and Foxconn Technology Group's Terry Gou, who also plan to manufacture electric vehicles in China. The move aims to support China's efforts to reduce air pollution and reliance on imported energy.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat, China GDP relief helps trim early losses
summary: Australia's sharemarket ended flat on Tuesday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing down 0.03% at 5,307.70. Early losses were trimmed after data showed China's economic growth was not as weak as feared. Gains in big four banks offset losses in energy stocks, which were pressured by weak oil prices.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise, eyes on China data
summary: Asia markets rose on Tuesday, with Tokyo and Hong Kong shares jumping 1.02% and 0.25% respectively, while Seoul added 0.49%. The euro retreated after a minor rally on Monday due to speculation about a potential European Central Bank stimulus package and Greece's upcoming election. China's economic growth data for 2014 is set to be released today, and analysts expect the ECB to announce a bond-buying scheme. US markets were closed for a national holiday.

site_title: China: Stocks rebound from biggest drop in six years on GDP data
summary: China's benchmark stock index rose 1.8% to 3,173.05, rebounding from its biggest loss in six years, after GDP data showed the nation's economy grew faster than estimated at 7.3% in the three months ended December. Industrial and consumer companies led the rally, with CSR Corp and China CNR Corp soaring 10% each. PetroChina Co rebounded 3.4% after a 9.2% drop on Monday, while Citic Securities Co and Haitong Securities Co extended their losses. The Shanghai gauge slid 7.7% on Monday due to margin-lending regulation.

site_title: Rolls-Royce delivers locally made Trent 1000 engine for Singapore-based Scoot (Amended)
summary: Singapore-based budget carrier Scoot has taken delivery of a locally made Trent 1000 engine for its Boeing 787 aircraft, manufactured by Rolls-Royce at the company's Seletar facility. The engine is part of 20 aircraft that Scoot will receive early next month. The partnership aims to save fuel and reduce costs for the airline, offering lower airfares to customers. This marks a significant milestone for Singapore's aerospace industry, which supports the entire life-cycle of an aircraft. Rolls-Royce has previously powered Boeing 787 test flights and deliveries since 2009.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares gain on China's market rebound and relief over GDP data
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.9% on Tuesday after mainland China's market rebounded, with regulators denying attempts to suppress the rally. China's fourth quarter growth data was also met with relief, despite being the slowest in 24 years. The Hang Seng index gained 0.9% to 23,951.16 points, while the China Enterprises Index rose 2.3%. Investors were also attracted to stocks such as Bank of China, ICBC, and Yat Sing Holding Ltd, which saw significant gains.

site_title: Ringgit leads in emerging market losses; Najib revises fiscal deficit target upwards
summary: Malaysia's ringgit fell 1.2% to its lowest level since 2009, leading emerging markets in losses, amid a revised fiscal deficit target of 3.2% of GDP and lower economic growth forecast of 4.5-5.5%. Prime Minister Najib Razak attributed the decline to market reaction to the higher deficit and lower GDP growth. He assured that the government will take proactive measures to support the economy, but warned that a balance must remain in excess of the current-account surplus.

site_title: Citic warns of up to US$1.8b impairment on Australia iron ore mine
summary: Citic Ltd warned of a potential US$1.4-1.8 billion impairment on its Australian Sino Iron mining project due to falling global iron ore prices. The impairment is attributed to the company's inexperience and contractor Metallurgical Corp of China's mistakes in building the project outside China. Construction of the final production lines will continue, with a target to operate all six lines by the end of 2016. The company's 2014 profits are expected to be lower due to the impairment.

site_title: No loud sound, explosion heard in crashed AirAsia QZ8501 voice recorder
summary: Indonesian authorities have ruled out terrorism as the cause of the crash of AirAsia QZ8501, a plane that disappeared on December 28 with 162 people on board. The cockpit-voice recorder found no loud sound or explosion, and investigators are decoding the flight-data recorder and piecing together debris to understand the cause of the crash. The pilot had sought permission to change course due to clouds, but air traffic controllers responded two minutes later without a reply. An initial report on the loss of the airliner will be issued by next week, with investigators focusing on administrative errors and technical issues.

site_title: Yuan firms after slightly better-than-expected Chinese growth data
summary: China's yuan firmed slightly after the government reported better-than-expected economic growth for the fourth quarter and full-year 2014, at 7.3% and 7.7% respectively. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.1226 per dollar, 0.08% stronger than the previous close. This modest boost was attributed to the steady growth, despite its weakest pace since the global financial crisis.

site_title: China says housing market showing some positive signs
summary: China's housing market showed positive signs in 2014, with property investment growth cooling to 10.5% from a year earlier, according to the Chinese statistics bureau. Despite falling housing prices and a large inventory of unsold homes, policy support contributed to the improvement. Revenues from housing fell 6.3% in 2014, marking a slight decrease from the previous year. This marks a turning point for China's cooling housing sector, which had been a major drag on the economy last year.

site_title: Japan's Amari: want to hear BOJ's view on impact of falling oil prices
summary: Japanese Economics Minister Akira Amari expressed interest in hearing the Bank of Japan's views on the impact of falling oil prices on consumer prices and inflation goals. With oil prices plummeting by over half since June 2014, the BOJ faces the challenge of maintaining its 2% inflation target amid deflationary pressures. The BOJ's two-day meeting ends on Wednesday, with the possibility of policy changes, including asset purchases under its quantitative and qualitative easing program, being considered to address the inflation target.

site_title: SBF-led SME Committee reveals Fair Tenancy Framework
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has unveiled the Fair Tenancy Framework, developed by the SME Committee's Rental Practices Working Group. The framework includes rental data transparency, education and awareness, and a preferred dispute resolution channel. No specific details on implementation or timeline are mentioned in the article.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Japan's Itochu and Thailand's CP Group to invest US$10 billion in Citic Group
summary: Japan's Itochu Corp and Thailand's CP Group will jointly invest US$10.36 billion in Citic Group, China's oldest and biggest financial conglomerate, as part of a strategic partnership. Citic has been trying to broaden its investor base, having completed a restructuring in August by injecting US$36 billion worth of assets. The investment is part of China's efforts to reform state-owned enterprises.

site_title: China's industrial output, retail sales up in Dec: govt
summary: China's industrial output rose 7.9% year-on-year in December, while retail sales increased 11.9%. Fixed asset investment expanded 15.7% on-year for 2014. These indicators suggest the economy is performing well, but China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Seoul: Shares augment gains on China growth data; won slips
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.81% on Tuesday, driven by better-than-expected Chinese economic growth and anticipation of additional stimulus measures from the European Central Bank. Samsung Electronics and Korea Electric Power Corp surged, with Samsung considering a stock split and KEPCO posting expected profits. The won slipped against the dollar, while March futures on three-year treasury bonds fell 1 basis point.

site_title: China 2014 property investment growth slows to 10.5% y-o-y
summary: China's real estate investment growth slowed to 10.5% in 2014, down from 11.9% in the first 11 months of 2014, as the housing sector dragged on economic growth. Property sales revenue dropped 6.3% annually. New home prices fell 4.3% year-on-year in 68 major cities, and the world's second-largest economy grew 7.4% in 2014, undershooting the 7.5% target, marking the weakest expansion in 24 years.

site_title: China's CITIC Sec denies media allegations of insider trading
summary: China's CITIC Securities has denied allegations of insider trading, stating that its largest shareholder, CITIC Limited, sold shares in the broker "in the normal course of business" and only learned of a regulatory ban at the same time as the public. The broker was barred from opening new accounts for three months following an investigation into margin trading rules. Shares in CITIC Securities fell 10% on Monday after the ban was announced.

site_title: China 2014 retail sales rose around 12 %, says commerce ministry
summary: China's retail sales rose 12% in 2014 to 26.6 trillion yuan, according to the Commerce Ministry. Economists expect economic growth to slow to 7.2% in the fourth quarter, the weakest since 2009. Retail sales are expected to grow 11.7% in December, flat from November. The data follows a slowdown in China's economic growth, with the country's statistics agency set to release official 2014 economic data on Tuesday.

site_title: Singaporeans expect retirement savings to last 13 years: HSBC
summary: Singaporeans expect their retirement savings to last approximately 13 years, according to a HSBC report. This assumes a retirement age of 60 and a life expectancy of 83. The minimum household income for a comfortable retirement is S$54,000 per year, yet over two-thirds of retirees live on less than S$48,000. This highlights concerns about the sustainability of retirement savings in the country.

site_title: China's survey-based jobless rate at 5.1% in 2014
summary: China's survey-based jobless rate stood at 5.1% in 2014, according to the Chinese statistics bureau. Despite a 7.3% GDP growth rate in the fourth quarter, many economists believe the official employment readings underestimate the number of jobless. This has led to concerns that the true unemployment rate may be higher. The data comes as China's economy faces pressure from slowing growth, with policymakers under scrutiny.

images.alt_text: One of China's official measures of its unemployment rate, also known as the survey-based unemployment rate, stood at 5.1 per cent in 2014, the Chinese statistics bureau said on Tuesday.

site_title: IMF cuts global growth outlook, calls for accommodative policy
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) lowered its global economic growth forecast for 2015 and 2016 to 3.5% and 3.7%, respectively, citing lingering crisis legacies and lower potential growth in many countries. The IMF advised advanced economies to maintain accommodative monetary policies to avoid deflation and recommended pursuing structural reforms to support growth. Emerging economies, including the US, were also affected, with projections cut back, while oil exporters like Russia and Nigeria saw their outlook worsen.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund lowered its forecast for global economic growth in 2015, and called on Tuesday for governments and central banks to pursue accommodative monetary policies and structural reforms to support growth.

site_title: IMF welcomes slower growth as China rebalances economy
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has welcomed China's decision to rebalance its economy, which is reflected in the country's slowdown in growth. China's economy grew 7.3% in the fourth quarter, near a six-year low. IMF Chief Economist Olivier Blanchard stated that the slowdown is a welcomed move, indicating a rebalancing of the world's second-largest economy. This decision is seen as a positive development, as it reduces pressure on policymakers to maintain high growth rates.

images.alt_text: The slowdown in China's economy reflects a welcomed decision by the Chinese government to re-balance the world's second-largest economy, the chief economist of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) said on Tuesday.

site_title: Credit Suisse sues Rei Agro in Singapore over alleged loan fraud
summary: Credit Suisse sued REI Agro Ltd. in Singapore, claiming the Indian rice producer conspired to obtain a $115.5 million loan for non-existent trades. The lawsuit alleges breaches of loan terms, including failure to provide audited accounts and a $20 million payment. REI Agro's founders deny involvement in fraud, stating the trades were genuine. The case is set for a hearing on January 26, with Credit Suisse seeking at least $80 million in damages.

site_title: China: Stocks rebound after regulator comment, GDP
summary: Chinese stocks rebounded after a regulator denied speculation it intentionally suppressed the market's rally, following a day of their biggest tumble since the global financial crisis. The market also took comfort from better-than-expected fourth-quarter growth data, but analysts say capital flows remain the key focus for investors. The GDP data had a marginal impact on stocks, and the market's focus will likely remain on capital flows rather than economic fundamentals.

site_title: China's GDP growth slows to 7.4% in 2014: govt
summary: China's GDP growth slowed to 7.4% in 2014, the lowest since 1990. The result was below the government's target of 7.5% and the median forecast of 7.3%. Despite this, the National Bureau of Statistics reported stable progress and improved quality in the economy. Industrial production, retail sales, and fixed asset investment showed growth, but the country faces challenges and difficulties in its economic development. The "new normal" of slowing expansion is being discussed by authorities.

site_title: Australia: Shares trim losses after China data, NZ subdued
summary: Australian shares trimmed losses after China's fourth-quarter economic growth held steady at 7.3%, beating forecasts for 7.2%. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.1% to 5,302.7. China's growth for 2014 slowed to 7.4%, below the government's target of 7.5%. Stocks, including BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto, rose after reporting strong iron ore output. New Zealand shares were generally flat, with NZ Refining and Oceana Gold posting gains.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.25% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.25% higher on Tuesday, rebounding from a previous day's sell-off. The benchmark Hang Seng Index rose 59.97 points to 23,798.46. The gains come as traders brush off new US President Trump's threats, with stocks in the US and Europe also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: China: Stocks open little changed after Monday's plunge
summary: China's stocks opened little changed on Tuesday, following a 7.7% drop on Monday, their largest one-day decline since the 2008 financial crisis. The CSI300 index fell 0.55% and the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.06%. China's regulators punished industry heavyweights for illegal operations in margin trading and tightened supervision of entrusted loans. Market talk that regulators intentionally suppressed a stock rally "is not consistent with facts," said a CSRC spokesman.

site_title: Malaysia central bank chief says interest rate highly accommodative
summary: Malaysia's central bank chief, Zeti Akhtar Aziz, stated that the country's policy interest rate of 3.25% is "highly accommodative" to support significant credit growth. This comes after the Prime Minister lowered economic growth forecasts for 2015 and increased the government's fiscal deficit target due to the decline in global crude prices. The central bank's accommodative monetary policy aims to counter the impact of the fall in oil and gas earnings on the economy.

images.alt_text: Malaysia'a central bank chief said on Tuesday that the country's policy interest rate of 3.25 per cent is still "highly accommodative".

site_title: Tokyo plans US$385m for hydrogen facilities for 2020 games
summary: Tokyo plans to spend 45.2 billion yen (approximately $514 million) on fuel-cell vehicle subsidies and hydrogen stations for the 2020 Olympics, aiming to have 100,000 hydrogen passenger vehicles, 100 hydrogen buses, and 80 refueling stations by 2025. The plan is part of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's strategy to reduce Japan's reliance on nuclear power following the Fukushima Daiichi disaster in 2011. The city is in negotiations with Toyota and Honda to deploy 6,000 hydrogen cars by 2020, with subsidies of up to 1 million yen per buyer.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 0.90 points to 1754.21. The trading volume was 40.75 million lots worth RM10.92 million, with 80 gainers outnumbering 60 losers.

site_title: Hong Kong, Sydney housing affordability worsens as New Zealand improves
summary: Housing affordability in Hong Kong and Sydney worsened in 2014, with median home prices 17 and 9.8 times median household incomes, respectively. Vancouver remained the most unaffordable market at 10.6 times income. New Zealand saw the biggest improvement in affordability, with prices at 5.2 times incomes. The survey ranked US cities as the most affordable, with Detroit and Rochester leading the list.

site_title: China regulator denies market talk stock rally was suppressed
summary: China's China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has denied speculation that regulators intentionally suppressed a stock rally by taking actions that led to Monday's 7.7% drop in share prices. The CSRC claims the actions, including punishing industry heavyweights for illegal operations and tightening supervision of entrusted loans, were not intended to clip the market. The plunge wiped out $315 billion of market value, but mainland stocks opened little changed on Tuesday, with some analysts suggesting the moves may pave the way for further monetary easing.

site_title: Malaysia increases 2015 fiscal deficit target to 3.2%
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak announced a revised fiscal deficit target of 3.2% for 2015, up from the original 3.0%, due to a sharp fall in oil and gas earnings. The revised budget assumes a global oil price of $55 a barrel. Najib stated that Malaysia is not facing an economic crisis, but the government needed to adjust to changing circumstances. The move aims to address the impact of lower oil prices on the country's economy.

site_title: Panama Canal widening will go over budget: administrator
summary: The Panama Canal widening project, initially forecast to cost $5.25 billion, is now expected to exceed budget due to $2.39 billion in overruns by the consortium, Grupo Unidos por el Canal. The project, already a year behind schedule, will now be completed in early 2016. The expansion aims to enable the canal to handle modern mega-freighters, but even after completion, it will only be able to handle ships carrying up to 12,000 containers, limiting its capacity.

site_title: Oil markets open cautiously ahead of China GDP data
summary: Oil markets opened cautiously ahead of China's GDP data, with Brent crude futures trading at $48.90 per barrel and US crude at $47.60 per barrel. China's economy grew at 7.2% in the fourth quarter, a 24-year low, stoking concerns about energy demand and oversupply. The price difference between oil for immediate delivery and for barrels to be supplied later, known as contango, has steepened, making it difficult for producers to find buyers for their crude. This has led to refiners prioritizing economically viable options and storing excess crude.

site_title: Stocks to watch: China Everbright Water, M1, MLT, K-Reit, KIT
summary: Stocks to watch on Tuesday include China Everbright Water, which is issuing new shares, and M1, which reported a 9.9% increase in fourth-quarter profit. M1's record net profit for 2014 caps a year of strong earnings.

site_title: Samsung Electronics considering stock split: exec
summary: Samsung Electronics is considering a stock split, a move to make its shares easier to buy and potentially attract more retail investors. The company's profits have been declining, and it has launched a $2 billion share buy-back program and promised a 50% increase in its 2014 year-end dividend. A stock split could make the shares more volatile and invite greater investor scrutiny, but analysts say Samsung may be hesitant due to the potential inheritance tax burden and generational change in leadership.

site_title: Australia raises terror threat level against police to 'high'
summary: Australia has raised the terrorism threat level against its police officers to "high" due to intelligence and discussions with international partners. The decision comes after a 16-hour siege in a central Sydney cafe in December, where two hostages and a gunman with radical Islamist sympathies died. A police statement did not cite any specific or imminent threats, but the move is seen as a precautionary measure to protect officers. The exact reason for the threat level increase is not specified.

site_title: IMF chief Lagarde warns Greece: 'A debt is a debt'
summary: IMF chief Christine Lagarde warned Greece that renegotiating its debt would have "consequences" ahead of Greek elections, where an anti-austerity party is tipped to win. Lagarde stated that a debt is a contract and that defaulting or restructuring terms would have negative effects. Alexis Tsipras, the head of the Syriza coalition, has called for debt renegotiation and partial cancellation of Greece's enormous public debt, citing a 1953 London Conference that cancelled German debt after World War II.

site_title: Malaysia's E&O buys third property in London for US$86m
summary: Malaysia's Eastern & Oriental Bhd (E&O) has acquired two vintage office buildings in London, Landmark House and Thames Tower, for US$86 million. This marks the company's third purchase in London, following Princes House in 2012 and ESCA House last year. E&O aims to strengthen its overseas growth engine and establish its brand internationally, aligning with its corporate strategy.

site_title: Twitter and Tumblr leaders ditch smartphones to combat addiction
summary: Executives from Twitter, Tumblr, and other tech companies have taken a break from their smartphones to combat addiction and data overload. Arianna Huffington, editor-in-chief of the Huffington Post, and Deutsche Telekom's CEO Timotheus Hoettges, have reported switching off their phones to find time to think and relax. The executives acknowledge the increasing impact of smartphones and social media on how we think and relate to the world, but believe that occasional breaks are necessary to remain wise. They argue that technology itself is not the problem, but rather the over-reliance on it.

site_title: South Korea 2014 tax revenue seen 11.1t won below budget plan
summary: South Korea's tax revenue for 2014 is expected to fall short of the government's budget plan by 11.1 trillion won (US$10.29 billion), according to the Ministry of Finance and Strategy. The estimated revenue is around 205.4 trillion won. The final revenue number will be released in February. This news comes after the central bank reported that fourth-quarter growth was negatively impacted by weak state spending.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 6.56 points to 3,314.26 on Tuesday, driven by a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Gainers outnumbered losers 83 to 41, with a total of 39.4 million shares traded at S$68.1 million.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE share prices opened lower on Friday with the Straits Times Index down 13.31 points to 3,325.53.

site_title: Analysts point out opportunities in Asia and Europe amid turbulent start to new year
summary: Analysts are identifying opportunities in Asian and European stocks amid turbulent markets. Raymond Chan, Allianz Global Investors' chief investment officer, highlights China's insurance and green energy sectors, as well as Taiwan's robotics and automation sector. He also predicts India will outperform China in two years, citing its growing economy. Meanwhile, European mining and healthcare stocks are seeing gains, while US stocks continue to edge towards fresh records despite trade uncertainty.

images.alt_text: A few weeks into a dramatic new year for financial markets that saw oil and copper plunges, Greece exit fears, a China correction, a Swiss franc surge and deflation worries, analysts are pointing out opportunities in Asian and European stocks.

site_title: TAG Heuer casts aside 'Swiss Made' label to take on Apple watch
summary: TAG Heuer, a Swiss luxury watch brand, plans to develop its own smartwatch, marking its first foray into producing timepieces outside of Switzerland. The brand will partner with Silicon Valley companies to produce the watch, as Switzerland lacks the necessary technological expertise. TAG Heuer aims to differentiate its smartwatch through unique applications and tie-ups with sports it sponsors, while maintaining Swiss craftsmanship in watch design and dial production. The move comes as the Swiss watch industry faces challenges from the Apple Watch and a surge in the Swiss franc, making Swiss-made timepieces more expensive abroad.

site_title: Globe's hot spots are quickly forgotten by oil traders
summary: Oil traders are overlooking rising geopolitical risks, including the Islamic State's goal of a Middle East caliphate, Libya's chaos, pro-Russian separatists in Ukraine, and North Korea's conflict with Hollywood. Despite current prices at $50 a barrel, analysts like Michael McCarthy warn that investors are underestimating the risk of a disruption in oil production, potentially leading to a sharp price increase. As prices remain low, some experts fear investors are setting themselves up for a surprise, highlighting the need for caution in the market.

site_title: Global uncertainty weighs on Japan business mood: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's business confidence slumped for the second consecutive month, with manufacturers' mood falling to 9 and service companies' sentiment index dipping to 20, according to a Reuters poll. The decline is attributed to global uncertainty, particularly falling crude oil prices and concerns over economic downturns in Europe, China, and other emerging markets. Despite this, manufacturers expect a rebound to 13 in April. The Bank of Japan's inflation forecast for the fiscal year may be revised downward to 1.5% or lower due to the impact of falling oil prices.

site_title: China Everbright Water places out 120.7m new shares at S$0.94 each
summary: China Everbright Water Limited is issuing 120.7 million new shares at S$0.94 each to raise S$113.4 million. The shares are being subscribed by International Finance Corporation (IFC) and Dalvey Asset Holding (DAH), representing 4.9% of the firm's existing share capital. The money will be used for growth and expansion purposes. This follows the firm's debut on the Singapore Exchange mainboard last month, where it is 78% owned by China Everbright International, a state-owned company linked to China's Everbright Group.

site_title: Merkel downplays impact of ECB bond move, ally warns against it
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel downplayed the potential impact of the European Central Bank's decision to buy euro zone government bonds, saying it was not a "week of destiny" for the euro. Merkel acknowledged the euro crisis is not fully overcome, but emphasized the ECB's independence in making its decision. Her ally, Norbert Barthle, warned that excessive liquidity could distort markets, while the Bundesbank opposes the policy, fearing it could create liabilities for German taxpayers. The ECB is expected to announce the decision on Thursday, amid concerns about deflation and the Greek elections this week.

site_title: Brazil seeks additional US$7.7b with first round of tax hikes
summary: Brazil announced tax hikes to raise US$7.7 billion in revenue this year, aiming to balance budget accounts and boost investor confidence. The measures include fuel, import, and consumer loan tax increases, which may boost inflation. Finance Minister Joaquim Levy said the goal is to improve confidence and encourage investment in Brazil, but economists warn the measures could put the economy into a slump. The tax hikes will take effect early on February 1.

images.alt_text: Brazilian Finance Minister Joaquim Levy delivers a news conference in Brasilia on Jan 19, 2015.

site_title: Huge anti-Charlie Hebdo rally in Chechnya as global protests rumble on
summary: A massive rally in Chechnya, Russia, drew hundreds of thousands of people protesting Charlie Hebdo's cartoons of the Prophet Mohammed. The event, organized by Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov, aimed to show loyalty to Russian President Vladimir Putin and condemned the magazine's publication of the cartoons. Global protests, including in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Iran, and Gaza, also took place, with demonstrators burning French flags and threatening attacks against France. The international community, including France's President Francois Hollande, defended freedom of speech, while human rights activists questioned the state-sponsored rallies' legitimacy.

site_title: Tesco puts pressure on rivals with price cuts, improved customer service
summary: Tesco, the UK's largest grocer, has implemented price cuts and customer service improvements to regain market share. The company, led by Dave Lewis, has already seen positive signs from customers, with January price cuts averaging 25% on 380 branded products. Tesco aims to narrow the gap with discounters like Aldi and Lidl by offering a wider range of products and better service. The move is expected to increase pressure on Tesco's rivals, including Sainsbury, Asda, and Morrison, in a tough market.

site_title: Only 13% of Singapore employees will get a pay increase of 6% or more: Hays
summary: Singapore employees can expect most pay increases, but only 13% will receive a 6% or higher increase, according to Hays' 2015 Asia Salary Guide. 59% of employers gave staff a 3-6% increase, while 22% gave less than 3%. The median gross monthly income in Singapore is S$3,250 excluding CPF contributions, with 54% of employers planning a 3-6% salary increase in the next review.

images.alt_text: Recruiting and human resources firm Hays said on Tuesday morning that Singapore salaries remain steady despite steady hiring demand.

site_title: Australian state bonds in high demand as bank regulator tightens rules
summary: Australia's state government bonds are experiencing high demand due to stricter liquid capital rules for banks. The reduced supply of new debt and increasing demand have led to a potential yield compression of 20 basis points between sovereign and state 10-year bonds, a decade-low. Fund managers believe state debt will be in high demand as local banks seek compliant assets. The high demand is attributed to the need for banks to hold more government paper, rather than private bonds, to meet the regulator's requirements.

images.alt_text: ICBC Australia has a A$10 billion balance sheet. "So naturally, semi-government (state) bond spreads will compress as, at the same time, the amount of issuance is also being reduced," he added.

site_title: DreamWorks Animation plans 'substantial' layoffs: LA Times
summary: DreamWorks Animation plans a "substantial" number of layoffs, citing two sources familiar with the matter, to cut operating costs. The move is expected to significantly reduce the studio's workforce, potentially exceeding the 350 layoffs in 2003. The layoffs will impact animators, story-board artists, and support staff at the studio's Glendale and Redwood City facilities, employing about 2,200 workers. A spokesman for DreamWorks Animation declined to comment on the report, which comes after the studio appointed new co-presidents and its Chief Creative Officer stepped down.

site_title: US to seek end to travel curbs, set up embassy in Cuba talks
summary: The US will urge Cuba to lift travel restrictions and establish US and Cuban embassies in talks in Havana, starting January 21-23. US diplomat Roberta Jacobson will lead the talks, which aim to restore diplomatic ties and normalize relations. The US seeks to end the 54-year-old trade embargo and increase access for US diplomatic personnel and shipments. Cuba has released 53 political prisoners and the US has eased trade and investment restrictions. The outcome depends on mutual consent and Cuba's tolerance for engagement, with human rights and dissident groups to be met with.

site_title: Google sticks to EU only application of 'right to be forgotten'
summary: Google is only removing search results from European websites when individuals invoke their "right to be forgotten", contrary to EU regulators' guidelines that suggest results should be scrubbed globally. The company's Chief Legal Officer, David Drummond, stated that Google's approach remains unchanged since November, but will review it when a report is published in January. Google has received over 200,000 removal requests from across Europe, affecting over 700,000 URLs, and will consider the report and regulators' input to arrive at an approach.

site_title: China toughens controls on illegal guns and explosives: Xinhua
summary: China has launched a nationwide campaign to crack down on illegal guns and explosives ahead of the Lunar New Year festival and the annual parliament session. The campaign, set to run through March, aims to "eliminate public security risks linked to guns and explosives." This follows a 3.6% decrease in gun-related crime and a 15% decrease in explosive-related crime in 2014, according to the Ministry of Public Security.

images.alt_text: China's police are cracking down on illegal guns and explosives ahead of the Lunar New Year festival and the annual session of parliament, state-run Xinhua news agency reported on Tuesday.

site_title: NZ business confidence lifts in Q4, backs rates on hold: survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence rebounded in the fourth quarter, reaching a two-year high, with 23% of firms expecting improved general business conditions. The New Zealand Institute of Economic Research's survey found steady growth and low inflation pressures, supporting the view that the Reserve Bank of New Zealand may keep interest rates on hold for most of the year. The survey also showed a robust level of optimism, activity, and hiring, with capacity utilisation at 91.9%.

site_title: ILO chief laments failure to tackle inequality at Davos
summary: ILO Director-General Guy Ryder expressed disappointment at the Davos meeting, stating that world leaders acknowledge inequality but fail to take concrete actions to address it. Ryder said there's a disconnect between the issue's acknowledgment and proposed policies to reduce inequality. He cited the need for governments to support collective bargaining, minimum wages, and tax policies to ensure workers share in employers' successes. Ryder warned that growing inequality contributes to social problems, potential unrest, and economic waste, and can hinder growth and social mobility.

images.alt_text: World leaders meeting in Davos this week are likely to agree that inequality is a problem but unlikely to do anything about it, the head of the International Labour Organization said.

site_title: Investors to get taste of new China via Shenzhen trading link
summary: Foreign investors will soon be able to directly trade stocks in Shenzhen, China's second-largest exchange, via a new trading link. The move is seen as a key step in China's capital account opening, which could attract billions of dollars from foreign funds. However, high valuations and extreme volatility in Shenzhen's market may limit early inflows. The Shenzhen stock market, home to smaller, newer companies, poses challenges for foreign investors due to its volatility and corporate governance issues. An announcement on the start date for Shenzhen is expected in the first half of this year.

site_title: EU agrees to stick to Russia sanctions policy
summary: EU foreign ministers agree to maintain sanctions against Russia until it fully implements Ukraine peace accords, despite a warning from the EU's diplomatic chief that the situation in Ukraine has worsened. The ministers reaffirmed their commitment to "keep sanctions pressure on Russia" and rejected a proposal to review the EU's Russia policy, including sanctions. The decision comes as a fresh round of fighting erupts in eastern Ukraine.

images.alt_text: EU foreign ministers agreed on Monday there would be no change in the bloc's Russia policy, including sanctions, as the union's diplomatic chief warned the Ukraine situation had got "much worse" in recent weeks.

site_title: More QE won't help world economy, says ex-BoE governor King
summary: Former Bank of England governor Mervyn King stated that additional quantitative easing (QE) won't help the world economy return to strong growth, despite six years of monetary stimulus. King expressed concern about persistent weak global demand and questioned the effectiveness of QE in solving the issue. This contradicts the European Central Bank's decision to consider a massive bond-buying program, which will be made in the coming days.

site_title: Global economy will 'muddle through' 2015: Allianz
summary: Allianz Global Investors' global chief investment officer Andreas Utermann expects the global economy to "muddle through" in 2015, citing supportive monetary policy and liquidity in financial markets. The world is still in a state of "financial repression," with central banks printing money to keep interest rates low. Utermann recommends actively-managed investing, as passive investing is unlikely to meet investors' liabilities in a low interest rate environment. Equity performance will increasingly come from dividends, with attractive yields globally.

site_title: Economists say Canada won't raise rates for another year due to oil rout
summary: Canada's central bank is expected to keep interest rates unchanged for another year due to the country's economic growth concerns triggered by the plunging oil prices. Economists predict the Bank of Canada will maintain its benchmark interest rate at 1% until 2016, citing the significant impact of the oil slump on exports, investment, and housing markets. The median forecast in a Bloomberg survey shows a yield on Canadian government bonds due in two years at 1.45%, down from a previous projection of 1.8%.

site_title: Merkel: ECB action no substitute for economic reform
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel warned that the European Central Bank's (ECB) quantitative easing (QE) action is no substitute for economic reforms in the euro zone. Merkel urged the ECB to avoid giving the impression that QE can replace needed reforms, saying it could sponsor spendthrift countries and avoid necessary market changes. The ECB is expected to announce a QE program on Thursday, with Merkel's government seeking safeguards to ensure Germany is not left on the hook for losses.

images.alt_text: Germany's chancellor made a rare public intervention in the debate about money printing by the European Central Bank on Monday, warning it was no substitute for economic reforms in the euro zone.

site_title: WEF meets at potential historical crossroads
summary: The 2015 World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, kicked off with a focus on a "new global context" for decision-making, amid a period of unprecedented global instability. The past few years have seen a surge in political revolutions, protests, and uprisings in emerging markets, as well as in developed countries, driven by factors such as economic downturn, austerity measures, and social media. Despite potential economic recovery, the legacy of the financial crisis, including high youth unemployment, will likely continue to fuel unrest, particularly in countries with pre-existing socio-economic discontent.

site_title: UN warns of growing inequality and joblessness
summary: The UN warns of growing global inequality and joblessness, predicting 11 million new unemployed people by 2020 and 212 million jobless by 2019. The International Labour Organisation (ILO) attributes the crisis to slower economic growth and the 2008 financial crisis, which has created a 61 million job gap worldwide. The report highlights the need for 280 million new jobs by 2019 to close the gap, with the youth unemployment rate at 13% globally. Extreme poverty remains a significant issue, affecting one in 10 workers earning less than $1.50 a day.

site_title: Bank losses from SNB surprise seen mounting
summary: The Swiss National Bank's decision to end the cap on the Swiss franc has led to billions of dollars in losses for major banks, including Citigroup, Deutsche Bank, and Barclays. These losses, still being tallied, will have ripple effects throughout the financial system. According to Mark Williams, an expert in risk management, the losses will range from large banks to currency speculators, impacting the global economy. The financial implications are expected to be significant, with billions of dollars at stake.

images.alt_text: Citigroup, Deutsche Bank and Barclays are said to have suffered US$400m of cumulative losses after the SNB scrapped a three-year-old policy of capping its currency against the euro.

site_title: In Israel, Japan PM talks business with tough line on peace
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe held talks with Israeli officials in Jerusalem, focusing on economic cooperation and a tough stance on peace. Abe reaffirmed Tokyo's commitment to brokering peace in the region and strengthened bilateral ties. This visit, the first by a Japanese premier since 2006, aims to bolster the economic relationship, particularly in the spheres of trade and investment.

site_title: Marks & Spencer's strategy may be testing shareholders' patience
summary: Marks & Spencer, the UK retailer, has posted 14 consecutive quarterly declines in clothing, footwear, and homeware sales, testing shareholders' patience. Despite efforts by Dutchman Marc Bolland to revamp the business, including improving quality and using natural fibers, sales have yet to increase. However, margins are improving, giving investors hope for higher payouts. The company's shares have risen 26% under Bolland's tenure, but a disappointing Christmas has reignited concerns about the need for a fresh direction. An update on April 2 could prove decisive for Bolland's tenure.

site_title: Go-ahead for Johor projects could open way for petro-hub
summary: Malaysia has approved reclamation works for two mega developments in the Johor Straits, paving the way for a potential 3,485-acre integrated petroleum and petrochemical hub. The project, led by Benalec Holdings Bhd, has a stake in the joint venture and is expected to be undertaken if the petroleum hub gets the green light. Chinese developers, such as Country Garden and Guangzhou R&F, have also received approvals for luxury housing projects in the area, with reclamation work commencing in mid-April.

site_title: China grid investment will boost copper consumption this year: state research firm
summary: China's state power grid plans to invest 420 billion yuan (S$90 billion) in 2015, a 24% increase from last year, boosting copper consumption in the power sector by around 9% this year. The power sector accounted for nearly half of last year's refined copper consumption. Analysts expect copper consumption to rise 8.7% to 4.62 million tonnes, easing worries over China's copper demand and lifting prices, which have been weighed down by concerns. The investment is part of China's environmental push to shift power generation inland away from the coast and towards renewables.

site_title: Gold slips from four-month high, haven appeal lends support
summary: Gold prices eased from four-month highs on Monday after investors cashed in some gains, but remained supported by market volatility. The metal rose to $1,281.50 last week after a market rout following Switzerland's abandonment of a franc cap, boosting its appeal as a haven from risk. Gold prices are expected to remain volatile this week as the euro zone faces a critical week.

site_title: China probes state television producer amid corruption investigation
summary: Chinese authorities are investigating Luo Fanghua, an executive at state television producer China Central Television (CCTV), amid a corruption probe targeting senior producers, executives, and journalists. The investigation follows the detention of popular news anchor Rui Chenggang and other CCTV staff, as well as a demotion of a former presidential aide's brother-in-law. The crackdown on corruption in the media is part of a broader effort by the Chinese government to curb perceived extravagance among top officials and their families. Several high-ranking officials have been detained or sacked in recent months.

site_title: Amazon doubles down on entertainment with 'indie' movie bet
summary: Amazon is doubling down on entertainment by producing around 12 indie movies a year for theatrical release, with the option to stream them on Prime Video within two months. The company is investing $5-25 million in each film, targeting a niche audience with modest budgets. This move aims to bolster Amazon's digital media ambitions, following its recent TV series acquisition and Golden Globe win. While the business is uncertain, Amazon's strategy is seen as a threat to traditional big-screen movie theaters, with the goal of reducing the window between theatrical releases and streaming availability.

site_title: No need for more BOJ easing this year, says Abenomics' architect
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) does not need to ease monetary policy further this year unless hit by a severe external shock, according to Kozo Yamamoto, architect of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policies. Yamamoto cited a sales tax hike and drop in oil prices as factors that may prevent the BOJ from meeting its 2% inflation target this fiscal year. Instead, the BOJ may hold off on additional stimulus, allowing its previous easing program to take effect by summer, and may expand its existing loan programs to boost lending and extend deadlines.

site_title: Did Google Glass lack a proper vision?
summary: Google announced it will stop selling its Google Glass smart glasses and will no longer develop the product in its research division, Google X. The Explorer programme, which allowed software developers and gadget nerds to buy test versions of the product, has been discontinued. The move signals a humbling retreat for Glass, which struggled to gain clarity on its purpose and was met with skepticism from consumers and lawmakers. The product will still be available to certified partners and for commercial trials, but its future development will be overseen by Tony Fadell, who helped design Apple's iPod and Nest thermostat.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure FY14 earnings down 10.4%
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a 10.4% drop in earnings for FY14, with net profit at S$12.7 million and earnings per unit (EPU) at 2.02 Singapore cents. Revenue declined 2.5% to S$65.5 million due to lower NEWater production and power tariff, but was partially offset by higher waste-to-energy plant output and O&M tariffs. Trust expenses increased 31% to S$1.85 million, and the net asset value per unit decreased to S$0.94.

site_title: China's push into services risks long-term growth stagnation
summary: China's push to shift its economy from investment-intensive manufacturing to the services sector is raising concerns that it may risk long-term growth stagnation. Officials hope to replicate the US model, but economists warn that forcing a rapid transition could lead to job losses and lower productivity. China's productivity growth has gone into reverse since the global financial crisis, and many laid-off factory workers are being retrained for lower-paying service jobs. The central government's efforts in the province of Hebei, which has shut down factories to incubate services, are seen as a potential example of the risks involved.

site_title: Seoul holds firm on GDP forecast that conflicts central bank's outlook
summary: South Korea's Finance Ministry is sticking to its GDP growth forecast of 3.8% for 2015, despite the Bank of Korea cutting its estimate to 3.4%. The ministry's Vice-Finance Minister Joo Hyung Hwan cited differences in opinion on the impact of government policies, including fiscal stimulus and relaxed lending rules, as the reason for the divergence. The government's forecast contrasts with analysts' expectations and reflects concerns about US interest rate increases, the Japanese yen, and the European slowdown.

site_title: Ornate malls mushroom in Iran to attract elite
summary: In Iran, a record 400 shopping malls are being built across the country, with 65 in Tehran alone, as developers cater to the growing demand for luxury and consumerism. Despite economic sanctions and low oil prices, the malls are a testament to a past era of prosperity, with many built by institutions affiliated with the Revolutionary Guards Corps and police. The malls offer a Western-style shopping experience, complete with international brands and amenities, and are seen as a reflection of the growing influence of urban, middle-class Iranians who aspire to Western lifestyles.

site_title: Inflation expectations lowest in 3 years
summary: Singapore's inflation expectations have fallen to their lowest levels in three years, with consumers polled in December expecting an overall inflation rate of 3.53% in 2015. This is lower than previous expectations and below historical averages, but still higher than the official forecast of 0.5-1.5%. The drop in expectations is attributed to sliding oil prices and shaky global growth. The latest survey also found lower expectations for core inflation, which excludes accommodation and private transport costs, at 3.61%.

site_title: Euro still struggling near 11-year low
summary: The euro edged up against the US dollar, but remains near an 11-year low, trading at US$1.1585. Investors await the European Central Bank's policy meeting, where a large-scale quantitative easing programme is expected, sparking speculation about ECB action. The Swiss National Bank's removal of the franc's cap on the euro sparked volatility, while Greece's snap election could further undermine the eurozone's credibility. Other currencies, such as the yen and ringgit, were affected by global market uncertainty.

site_title: Xiaomi to buy 3% of software firm Kingsoft
summary: Xiaomi Inc has agreed to buy approximately 3% of software firm Kingsoft Corp Ltd from Tencent Holdings Ltd for HK$527 million (S$90.5 million), expected to close on Jan 30. Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun, who is also Kingsoft's chairman, will see his voting rights increase to 29.9%. This deal marks Xiaomi's expansion into media and content, with plans to invest in Internet TV content and potentially acquire more from overseas. Partnering with Xiaomi will benefit Kingsoft and promote its business.

site_title: Measurement firm to track US video viewers across many devices
summary: ComScore, a measurement firm, is introducing a new metric to track video audiences across multiple devices, including computers, mobile phones, and streaming devices. The new metric is expected to increase digital viewership for television networks by 8-30%. The move aims to provide a more accurate count of video audiences and counter Nielsen's dominance in traditional television ratings. ComScore's CEO, Serge Matta, stated that proper measurement is crucial for platforms to increase usage and attract advertising.

site_title: Moscow draws flak for poor handling of economy
summary: Russia's government is facing criticism for its handling of the country's economic crisis, with experts warning that the authorities lack clear policies to deal with the crisis. The economy is expected to contract by 5% in 2015, with inflation predicted to reach 17% by spring. Despite efforts to provide assistance to pensioners and large families, the government has failed to announce concrete measures to address the crisis. Analysts blame infighting between hawkish and liberal clans in the Kremlin for the lack of direction, and the appointment of a new economist to oversee the rouble's fate is seen as a stopgap measure.

site_title: Too early to judge impact of smaller board size
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) introduced a smaller board lot size of 100 shares, reducing from 1,000, in an effort to make high-priced stocks more affordable for small investors. On the first day of trading, volume was lower than expected, but SGX reported appreciable demand for high-priced counters. Critics argue that high broking fees remain a barrier for retail players, with some stocks costing S$25 for 100 units. Despite this, the move is seen as a step in the right direction, but other fundamental issues need to be addressed to attract retail investors back into the market.

site_title: Extensive powers for administrators with MediShield Life Scheme Bill
summary: The MediShield Life Scheme Bill grants extensive powers to administrators, allowing them to access financial and medical information to check eligibility for premium subsidies and identify individuals with serious pre-existing medical conditions. Those who choose not to share this information must apply manually, and unauthorized access can result in fines and imprisonment. The government will spend almost S$4 billion over five years on premium subsidies and other support. Penalties for defaulters, including employers and banks, will be imposed, and a MediShield Life Council will be set up to review and make recommendations on the scheme's administration.

images.alt_text: Singaporeans and permanent residents are one step closer to having a universal health coverage.

site_title: Govt moves to ban alcohol sale, public drinking after 10.30pm
summary: Singapore is moving forward with a bill that proposes a nationwide ban on the sale and public consumption of alcohol between 10:30pm and 7am. Event organizers can apply for exemptions for specific events, and individuals can continue to consume liquor at home or in licensed premises during the restricted hours. The government aims to minimize "displacement problems" and enhance public order, citing examples from cities like Australia, the US, and the UK. Designated areas in Little India and Geylang will be subject to stricter regulations, with enhanced penalties for liquor-related offenses.

images.alt_text: A bill introduced in parliament on Monday proposed a nation-wide ban on the sale and public consumption of alcohol between 10.30pm and 7am.

site_title: Indie movie studio goes for low-cost digital marketing
summary: An indie movie studio, American Film Co., is adopting low-cost digital marketing techniques to promote its film, Against the Sun. The studio is offering discounted prices to customers who buy the movie online, using contemporary online sales tactics. This move aims to increase sales and reach a wider audience, marking a shift towards more aggressive digital marketing strategies in the film industry.

site_title: Genting Singapore and SATS lead share buybacks to four-week high of $33.3m
summary: Genting Singapore and SATS led a surge in share buybacks in Singapore, reaching a four-week high of S$33.3 million in the second week of January 2015. 41.22 million shares were repurchased by 15 companies, with Genting Singapore buying 10.2 million shares for S$10.34 million. Analysts suggest that the buybacks may be due to undervalued shares, particularly for Genting Singapore, which has seen a 32.2% decline in its value since last year.

site_title: Why Singapore needs a new IPO story
summary: Singapore's share of initial public offerings (IPOs) in South-east Asia has declined from 45% in 2004-2009 to 37% over the last five years. Despite efforts to boost the market, companies are increasingly turning to neighboring countries for equity capital. Singapore's reliance on international listings, such as Formula One, is limited, and domestic liquidity from pension and sovereign funds has improved in neighboring countries like the Philippines, making it harder for Singapore to attract companies. The city-state needs a new IPO story to revitalize its financial center.

site_title: Chinese funds linked to copper dive shorting commodities: sources
