summary: Chinese hedge funds, such as Shanghai Chaos Investment Co and Zhejiang Dunhe Investment Co, have been linked to a significant sell-off in copper, with benchmark prices falling to 5 1/2 year lows near $5,350 a tonne. The funds are believed to have used an aggressive short-selling strategy, targeting copper and other commodities. This move is seen as a demonstration of the growing influence of Chinese funds in global commodity markets, leveraging their home-ground advantage in copper and other commodities.

site_title: Germans perceive deflation for first time since 2009: study
summary: Germans perceive deflation for the first time since 2009, despite a slight rise in the cost of living in December, according to a survey by UniCredit. Annual consumer prices rose 0.1% in December, a five-year low, while consumers thought prices had dropped 1.2%. Economists believe this perception could boost private consumption, and with record employment and rising wages, creates favorable conditions for consumption to remain the main growth driver this year.

site_title: Local fish farm to net global market
summary: Barramundi Asia, a Singapore-based fish farm, aims to become the world's largest barramundi supplier while maintaining environmental sustainability. The company has 500 tonnes of barramundi fish and plans to expand globally, with a second farm site in Singapore and potential operations in countries near the equator. Barramundi Asia's farm-to-fork model, which includes processing and cold chain management, sets it apart from competitors. The company has secured EU certification and is expanding its operations, with plans to become a major supplier of premium Australian barramundi.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam
Barramundi Asia's Joep Kleine Staarman and Commonwealth Capital's Andrew Kwan hamming it up with their prize fish.

site_title: Obama's US$110b bank tax would hurt economy, says top lobbying group
summary: US President Barack Obama's proposed $110 billion tax on financial companies could hinder economic growth and reduce lending, according to the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association. The 7-basis-point fee on large banks, investment firms, and insurers would raise about twice as much money as a previous proposal. Industry leaders argue that the tax is unnecessary and could lead to unintended consequences, while the bill faces uncertain prospects in Congress due to Republican opposition. The proposal is part of a package aimed at expanding tax breaks for lower- and middle-income families.

site_title: Nomura Securities to raise entry-level wages; Daiwa may increase all salaries by 2%
summary: Nomura Securities and Daiwa Securities are raising entry-level wages, with Nomura increasing pay by 2.3% and Daiwa considering a 2% hike. This move follows Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's call for companies to boost pay to boost the economy. The wage hikes aim to help lift consumer spending and counter declining real wages. Despite this, employees still face a 3 percentage point increase in the sales tax and 4.3% year-on-year decline in inflation-adjusted real wages.

site_title: Burgundy vintages drove wine auction sales in 2014
summary: Burgundy vintages dominated wine auction sales in 2014, with the Domaine de la Romanee-Conti estate driving demand, according to US houses Acker Merrall & Condit and Zachy's Wine Auctions Inc. Burgundy led Bordeaux by 41% to 32% in market share at Acker, while at Zachy's, Burgundy rose 8 percentage points to 41% as Bordeaux fell 5 points to 42%. This shift reflects buoyant demand for top-name producers in Burgundy and a three-year slide in Bordeaux prices due to Chinese appetite subsiding.

site_title: China issues draft rules restricting entrusted lending
summary: China's banking regulator has issued draft rules to tighten supervision of entrusted lending, a type of shadow banking product used to speculate on stocks. The move aims to curb excessive leverage and risks associated with the product, which has grown rapidly to over $214 billion by the end of 2014. The rules restrict funds from being used for entrusted loans, particularly those linked to bank lending and funds raised from other investors. The public has until February 16 to suggest amendments to the rules.

site_title: Under-fire Uber tries to mend fences with Europe
summary: Uber's CEO, Travis Kalanick, aims to mend fences with Europe, seeking to work with politicians to find ways for the ride-hailing service to operate legally across the European Union. Despite resistance from taxi associations and politicians, Kalanick claims Uber can create 50,000 new jobs and generate tax revenue. He rebutted claims of unfair competition, stating current transportation rules were devised to protect existing taxi associations. Uber operates in almost 270 cities worldwide, valued at $40 billion, and expects to spend more time in Europe in 2015.

site_title: Euro back in crisis mode as Davos awaits ECB then Greece ballot
summary: The euro-area economy is facing renewed concerns as investors and policymakers head to the World Economic Forum's annual meeting in Davos. Greece's upcoming election may lead to a renegotiation of austerity, potentially sparking a euro exit. Meanwhile, the European Central Bank (ECB) is trying to craft a consensus for full-blown quantitative easing, but is being hindered by resistance from Germany. The threat of deflation and Greece's high unemployment rate are exacerbating the crisis, with some predicting a financial crisis. The ECB is considering buying government bonds for the first time, but faces opposition from Germany.

images.alt_text: Even if Greece stays in the eurozone if Syriza wins the polls, rejection of the traditional political class could still spread.

site_title: Obama to lose either way in oil pipeline row
summary: US President Barack Obama is set to veto the Keystone oil pipeline bill, despite the Republican-controlled Congress likely overriding the veto. The pipeline, which would transport Canadian oil to the US Gulf Coast, has sparked intense debate over environmental concerns and economic benefits. Opponents argue the pipeline would contribute to global warming and harm local ecosystems, while supporters claim it would create jobs and strengthen economic ties with Canada. The outcome is seen as a symbolic victory for Republicans, who are eager to showcase their legislative prowess.

site_title: Moody's more upbeat on global airline industry as fuel costs fall
summary: Moody's upgraded its outlook on the global airline industry to "positive" due to declining fuel costs, which are expected to boost financial performance. US carriers will see the largest increases in profit margins, while airlines in developing markets and Europe will face challenges due to high capacity growth and weakening currencies. Despite a projected 5-6% rise in passenger demand, yields are forecast to be flat to 2% in 2015 and one to 3% in 2016, as declining fuel prices and capacity growth in the Asia-Pacific region limit growth.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Economists expecting quantitative easing by ECB this week: survey
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi is expected to announce a 550 billion-euro bond-purchase program, known as quantitative easing, this week to combat deflation in the euro area. The program, which will expand the ECB's balance sheet to 3 trillion euros, aims to reinvigorate the moribund economy. Economists predict that the program will be "pervasive, risk-transferring, and long-lasting," with a focus on government bonds and sovereign debt. The move is seen as a bold step to steer the euro area away from deflation, following a 93% survey of economists who predict QE will be announced.

site_title: Throwing out your IT equipment too soon?
summary: A global survey by Forrester Consulting found that SMEs are not maximizing their returns on IT investments, with 76% of decision-makers concerned about reducing costs. The survey revealed that businesses often default to vendor influence, leading to unnecessary upgrades and maintenance contracts, resulting in significant capital and operational expenditure savings being missed. Key takeaways include: businesses should maximize the use of existing assets, not refresh infrastructure unnecessarily, and consider third-party maintenance solutions to reduce costs.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore's REITs are expected to benefit from a continued flattening of the yield curve, with most having hedged interest rate risk. However, residential mortgage loans may be negatively impacted by rising interest rates, posing a downside risk to developers. Analysts, including OCBC Investment Research, upgraded First Reit to a "buy" due to its solid defensive attributes and lower risks, with a target price of S$1.40. The upgrade comes despite low DPU growth, with the company's balance sheet remaining healthy.

site_title: HK-Shanghai stock link needs time: regulator
summary: Hong Kong's Hong Kong-Shanghai stock link, which connects the two markets, will take time to grow as international investors become familiar with China's securities rules. Chairman Xiao Gang of the China Securities Regulatory Commission stated that it will require both sides to work together to improve the mechanism. This comes amid pressure from foreign banks and asset managers to address regulatory and technical issues that have kept many investors away. The link aims to increase trading and investment between the two markets, but progress has been slow.

site_title: PSA handled 65.4m TEUs of containers globally in 2014
summary: PSA International handled 65.44 million TEUs of containers globally in 2014, a 5.8% increase from the previous year. The Singapore terminals contributed 33.55 million TEUs, with a 4.1% year-on-year increase, while terminals outside Singapore saw a 7.8% increase. The group's CEO attributed the growth to a modest global trade growth and the introduction of mega vessels.

site_title: Curb on loans a double blow for Citic Sec, Haitong Sec
summary: China's top brokerages, Citic Securities and Haitong Securities, face a double blow as regulators curb loans to equity traders, reducing potential earnings and limiting margin trading. The move, aimed at slowing down the country's fast-growing equity market, has led to a 10% drop in shares of the two brokerages. Margin trading, which accounts for about 3.5% of the nation's market capitalization, has surged over 10-fold in the past two years, with Citic Securities and Haitong Securities among the top holdings.

images.alt_text: The total amount of shares purchased on margin in China has surged more than 10-fold in the past two years to a record 1.1t yuan.

site_title: Oil markets may be in for pain felt by miners
summary: Oil producers may face prolonged pain as global supply surges, with US crude output reaching a 30-year high and OPEC maintaining production targets. Despite tumbling prices, coal and iron ore exporters continue to increase supply, boosting global gluts and jeopardizing profits. Analysts predict that oil prices will remain low until 2016, with US shale drillers potentially being less exposed to price drops than anticipated. The prolonged supply surplus may force oil producers to endure weak prices for the next two to three years, with the goal of forcing competitors to shut down.

site_title: Lenders turn to big data to know customers
summary: Startups are using big data to create new lending models, focusing on behavioral signals such as capitalization, online reading habits, and social network connections to assess creditworthiness. These data-driven lenders aim to provide more accurate assessments, broaden the lending market, and reduce borrowing costs. However, regulators are concerned about potential biases and discrimination, as the technology is still unproven. The new models have the potential to help millions of Americans, particularly those with thin credit files, such as immigrants and recent college graduates.

site_title: Consumer-protection laws being reviewed
summary: Singapore's government is reviewing its consumer protection laws to address unfair trading practices and errant retailers. The review aims to enhance enforcement and prevent retailers from side-stepping restrictions by forming new companies. The review will consider setting up a new agency, studying best practices from other countries, and conducting further consultations. The review is expected to be completed by mid-2015, balancing the interests of consumers and businesses.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: China shipyards brace for leaner times as oil slump sours rig-building spree
summary: China's shipyards, which had built up a large market share in the oil rig industry due to low financing costs and discounts, are now facing a slowdown as crude prices decline. Chinese yards, such as China Merchants Heavy Industry, Dalian Shipbuilding, and Shanghai Waigaoqiao, have lured orders away from regional peers, but many of these rigs remain unsold. The industry's exposure to a prolonged oil market slump is a concern, with some predicting price cuts and cancellations, potentially delaying new construction even if oil prices recover.

images.alt_text: China became the world's biggest offshore drilling rig builder after rapid expansion led by the likes of state-backed yards China Merchants Heavy Industry, Dalian Shipbuilding and Shanghai Waigaoqiao.

site_title: Subaru puts China production on hold as car demand wanes
summary: Subaru has put its efforts to start car production in China on hold due to declining demand growth, with sales in the country not guaranteeing profitability. The company's executive vice-president stated that even with government approval, production would not commence. Subaru joins other Japanese automakers in showing decreased interest in China's massive auto market, where sales growth slowed to 6.9% last year. This decision comes as China's economy is forecast to expand at the slowest pace since 1990 this year.

site_title: Acquisitions lift MapletreeLog Q3 DPU
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust reported a 2.7% increase in total amount distributable to unitholders to S$46.19 million for its third quarter ended December 2014, driven by a 6.2% rise in gross revenue to S$82.92 million. The increase was largely due to the contribution from six acquired assets in China, Singapore, Malaysia, and South Korea. The trust's distribution per unit (DPU) rose to 1.87 Singapore cents, a slight increase from the previous year.

site_title: Why Oscar nominations matter
summary: The Motion Picture Academy's failure to nominate the black director and lead actor of Selma, a Martin Luther King Jr biopic, has sparked debate about its significance. Despite not being the most egregious example of racism, the snub lands on the list of indignities visited upon African-Americans. The incident raises questions about the impact of Oscar nominations on representation and diversity in the film industry.

site_title: China's graft-busters target state-owned firms ahead of ambitious reform
summary: China's anti-corruption watchdog has stepped up inspections of state-owned firms, focusing on 53 strategic conglomerates where top executives hold deputy government minister ranks. Inspectors are targeting business leaders and politicians, including a top spy chief caught in the dragnet. The Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (CCDI) aims to prosecute officials for suspected corruption, coinciding with the imminent rollout of ambitious new guidelines to overhaul the country's inefficient state sector. Chinese President Xi Jinping has vowed to curb corruption, warning that it threatens the Communist Party's legitimacy.

site_title: Rental revision not 10%; no renovation cost deal
summary: A rental revision of 3.75% was reported, contrary to a 10% increase stated in a Bloomberg article. The revision was confirmed by a landlord, who also disputed claims of sharing renovation costs. The correct information aims to provide accurate insight into the softening of Singapore residential rents.

site_title: Fall in oil prices will benefit S'pore: Hng Kiang
summary: Trade and Industry Minister Lim Hng Kiang said Singapore, a net importer of oil, will benefit from the fall in global oil prices, reducing electricity tariffs and fuel costs. Lower oil prices will directly benefit businesses and consumers, but any competitive advantage will be temporary. The government will focus on boosting productivity and innovation to enhance long-term competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Singapore market bored lots despite 100-share trading
summary: Singapore's stock market saw muted trading volumes on the first day of reduced minimum board lot sizes, with total trading volume reaching 1.2 billion shares, 59% of the 2014 average. Turnover was also down, but 4% higher than the previous year's Martin Luther King Day holiday. Despite efforts to make blue-chip stocks more accessible, market analysts attributed the lackluster performance to "overarching market factors" and poor investor engagement, with some brokers citing minimum brokerage fees as a possible deterrent.

site_title: Australia inflation gauge slows sharply in December as petrol prices plunge
summary: A private inflation gauge in Australia slowed to its lowest pace in two-and-a-half years in December, largely due to a sharp decline in petrol prices. The TD Securities-Melbourne Institute's consumer price measure remained unchanged in December from November, suggesting room for another interest rate cut to support the economy. This development could indicate the Reserve Bank of Australia may lower interest rates further to stimulate economic growth.

site_title: KL to announce policy tweaks amid oil slide
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak will announce policy changes, including budget revisions, on Tuesday to address the impact of reduced oil and gas earnings due to global crude price slump. The government aims to maintain a 3% fiscal deficit target, using savings from fuel subsidies and a consumer tax, despite a forecasted 4% deficit risk. Analysts expect Najib to reaffirm commitment to reducing the fiscal deficit and may hint at a reduced growth forecast.

site_title: Bus, MRT fares may fall at next price review
summary: Singapore's next public transport fare review, set to take place at the end of 2015, may see bus and MRT fares reduced due to the drop in energy prices in 2014. Transport Minister Lui Tuck Yew mentioned a potential reduction of "in the region of negative one per cent". This is based on the current available data, which shows a decline in the benchmark Brent oil price from $115 to $50 per barrel since June 2014. The fare review formula is pegged to changes in the core consumer price index, wage index, and energy index, reflecting the operating cost structure of public transport operators.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
The reduction, which could be "in the region of negative one per cent", is due to the drop in energy prices in 2014, said Mr Lui

site_title: Swiss firm files patent suit against Nespresso
summary: Swiss firm Ethical Coffee Company has filed a patent suit against Nestle, the maker of Nespresso coffee machines, in a Paris court. Ethical Coffee claims Nestle's new Pixie range uses a "harpoon" device to jam competitors' capsules, violating its patent. The company has suffered losses of at least 150 million euros since 2010. Nestle denies patent infringement and plans to fight the case in court. This is the second patent dispute between the two companies, following a 2012 trade tribunal ruling in favor of Ethical Coffee.

site_title: M1 rings in record full-year net profit S$175.8m
summary: M1 Singapore reported a record full-year net profit of S$175.8 million, a 9.7% increase from the previous year. This surpasses the previous record set in 2007. The telco's fourth-quarter profit increased by 9.9% to S$44.5 million, driven by a 6.8% rise in operating revenue to S$1.08 billion.

site_title: Irish taxpayers tell rescued banks that it's payback time
summary: Ireland is seeking to recover billions of euros in bailout funds from rescued banks, including Allied Irish Banks (AIB), as part of a strategy to push debt below the euro region's average. The government hired Goldman Sachs to advise on recouping AIB's 21 billion-euro bailout, which could help Ireland's debt fall to 74% of GDP by 2020. AIB has returned to profit and is expected to post a one billion-euro profit in 2015, with the government planning to sell down its 99.8% stake in the bank.

site_title: Malaysia needs to get to the bottom of its domestic water challenges
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak is launching a budget review and expert panel to address the country's domestic water challenges following devastating floods in January. The floods, the worst since 1972, have caused RM2 billion in damage and are expected to shave 0.5 to 0.8 percentage point off Malaysia's GDP growth. The panel will examine the causes of the floods, including land clearing and tree logging, and propose preventive measures to avoid future disasters. The issue highlights the need for water security, damming of rivers, and sustainable pricing of water for agriculture and industries.

site_title: Chinese property loans come under selling pressure
summary: Chinese property loans are facing selling pressure amid speculation of government crackdowns on corrupt developers. Investors are shunning loans from builders such as Shimao Property Holdings, Country Garden Holdings, and Evergrande Real Estate Group due to concerns about impending stress and potential targets for anti-graft probes. This has led to a decline in the value of Chinese high-yield dollar notes, with a 5.67% loss this year, and a weakening of dollar-denominated bonds. Moody's Investors Service warns that asset quality metrics may deteriorate in the next 12-18 months due to slower economic growth.

site_title: HR managers must adapt to meet challenges of regional integration
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is set to implement the Asean Economic Community (AEC) in 2015, aiming to transform the region into a single market for production, distribution, and investment. To meet this challenge, HR managers must adapt to changing workforce and employment patterns. A recent survey by the American Chamber of Commerce found that 58% of respondents believe Asean markets have become more important for their companies' worldwide revenue, highlighting the need for businesses and HR managers to understand the region's changing landscape.

site_title: MPs show support for collective unions for PMEs
summary: Singapore's Parliament has shown support for collective unions for Professionals, Managers, and Executives (PMEs), with the proposed 2014 Industrial Relations (Amendment) Bill aiming to strengthen the tripartite partnership. PMEs now make up over 30% of the workforce, with the proportion expected to increase as Singaporeans become better educated. The bill proposes extending collective union representation for executives and expanding limited representation for re-employment matters, with certain executives excluded from collective union representation.

site_title: UK's Aviva says may cut 1,500 jobs on Friends Life takeover
summary: UK's Aviva may cut 1,500 jobs following its planned $9 billion acquisition of rival Friends Life, with redundancies to be kept to a minimum by utilizing vacancies and natural turnover. The deal, which includes a prospectus for shareholder vote on March 26, is expected to be finalized by April 13 if approved. Aviva's total workforce is approximately 31,500.

site_title: BMW sees cheap gas making electric cars a harder sell for now
summary: BMW expects electric cars to become harder to sell due to cheap gas, with sales potentially dipping in countries like the US. The company's head of sales and marketing, Ian Robertson, notes that consumers are turning towards bigger models with conventional motors. Despite this short-term shift, BMW remains committed to its strategy of offering plug-in hybrid versions of its models, with plans to introduce a plug-in hybrid X5 sport-utility vehicle. Robertson emphasizes that the company's goal is to comply with tightening emissions regulations.

site_title: UAE says falling oil prices will not impact clean energy
summary: The UAE has downplayed concerns that falling oil prices will impact the development of renewable energy projects, citing the growth of investments in clean energy and the increase in production capacity of wind turbines and solar energy panels. Minister of State Sultan al-Jaber stated that renewable energy has shifted from an expensive alternative to a competitive technology, driven by declining costs and rising technology efficiency. The UAE aims to seize the opportunity of falling oil prices to cut fuel subsidies and promote clean energy.

site_title: Keppel Reit's Q4 DPU down
summary: Keppel Reit's Q4 DPU fell to 1.51 Singapore cents, down from 1.97 cents a year ago, due to the divestment of its Prudential Tower stake and delayed contribution from MBFC Tower 3. Despite this, the Reit's full-year net property income rose 9.5% to S$151.44 million, driven by better performance from Ocean Financial Centre and a 50% stake in Melbourne's 8 Exhibition Street. The Reit expects MBFC Tower 3's full contribution to offset the loss from Prudential Tower.

images.alt_text: Keppel Reit's divestment of its stake in Prudential Tower led its fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to fall to 1.51 Singapore cents for the period ended December 2014, down from 1.97 cents a year ago.

site_title: By 2016, 1% to own half of world's wealth: Oxfam
summary: Oxfam reports that by 2016, the world's wealth will be owned by just 1% of the population, with the top tier holding 50% of the global wealth. This represents a significant increase from 44% in 2009, as global inequality soars. The richest 80 individuals have the same wealth as the poorest 50% of the population, with the average wealth of top one-per-centers reaching $2.7 million per adult. Oxfam urges action to tackle rising inequality at the World Economic Forum meeting in Davos, calling for a crackdown on tax dodging and progress on climate change.

site_title: STI manages 7pt rebound in low volume
summary: The Straits Times Index rebounded 7.02 points to 3,307.70 on its first day of trading in 100-share lots, following a 38-point drop the previous week. Weak oil prices and currency turmoil were cited as main market worries. Despite a 340% year-on-year increase in A50 futures volume, UBS Securities downgraded Singapore Exchange to "sell" with a target price of S$7.05. Meanwhile, Singapore Airlines rose after a "overweight" call from JP Morgan, while Nomura warned of market complacency in yield products like Reits.

site_title: US won't intervene in oil market amid price declines on supply
summary: The US will not intervene in the oil market amid falling crude prices, according to US State Department's energy envoy Amos Hochstein. Oil prices have dropped 53% in the past year due to growing US, Russian, and OPEC production overwhelming demand. Hochstein stated that the global market will decide the outcome, and cheaper oil prices won't stop the development of alternative energy sources, which can continue to grow globally.

site_title: Commodities trader Noble winding down cocoa ops: sources
summary: Noble Group, a Hong Kong-based commodities trading house, is winding down its cocoa operations, with sources expecting a liquidation by June at the latest. The move follows the departure of Paul Davis, a veteran cocoa trader who resigned as global head of cocoa in October 2014. Noble declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Facts don't matter to those who reject government's role
summary: The US experienced its warmest year on record in 2014, debunking claims of climate change denial. However, this fact has little impact on the "debate" over climate policy, as evidence is irrelevant to those who reject government intervention. Similarly, issues such as tax cuts and universal health insurance continue to be shaped by dogmatic views, with facts often ignored in favor of ideological agendas. The underlying reason for this dogmatism appears to be a rejection of government's role in serving the public interest, driven by a desire to limit government power and protect traditional hierarchies.

site_title: Private home resales up 8.4% in H2 from H1
summary: Resale private home transactions in Singapore rose 8.4% in the second half of 2014 to 2,528 units, while new sales by developers and subsales declined 36% and 9.4% respectively. This is attributed to sellers offering bigger discounts to move their properties. Resales are expected to continue outperforming new sales, with ownership in the resale market being more fragmented and buyers willing to negotiate prices. Private home purchases by Singaporeans, PRs, and foreigners also declined, with companies making a significant increase in purchases, possibly due to developers setting up vehicles to mop up unsold units.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Nationality-wise, DTZ found that the number of purchases by Indonesians slumped 58 per cent to 392 last year, from 941 in 2013.

site_title: "Grexit" risk may be underestimated, Greek officials say
summary: Greek officials and economists express skepticism about the idea that a Greek eurozone exit, or "Grexit," could be handled without significant damage to the rest of the bloc. Despite efforts to downplay the risk, experts warn that a Greek exit could have unpredictable consequences, including contagion via financial markets, and undermine the eurozone's cohesion. The European Commission and IMF also caution that a Greek exit would have consequences, including debt restructuring and a loss of confidence in the euro.

images.alt_text: The idea that a Greek eurozone exit could be handled without much damage to the rest of the bloc is met with disbelief in Greek government circles.

site_title: Thai junta says wider budget gap no burden for future govt
summary: Thailand's military-led government plans to increase the budget deficit to 390 billion baht (S$16 billion) for the next fiscal year, with spending projected at 2.72 trillion baht. The junta aims to avoid burdening a future administration with large debts, saying the deficit is not high, even at 3% of GDP. The government plans to focus on infrastructure projects to boost growth, including water management and rail infrastructure, to lift the economy after a weak 2014 full-year growth of 0.8%.

site_title: Uber adjusts business model to comply with South Korea rules
summary: Uber adjusts its business model in South Korea to comply with local regulations. The company will direct users to Seven Call Taxi in Incheon, a partnership that follows the indictment of CEO Travis Kalanick by South Korean prosecutors. This move comes after Uber's services were suspended or banned in several countries, including India, Germany, and Spain, amid legal challenges. By partnering with licensed cabs, Uber aims to comply with South Korea's laws that prohibit unlicensed taxis.

site_title: Polish central bank chief sees need for extra measures in face of franc surge
summary: Poland's central bank chief Marek Belka has stated that the surge in the Swiss franc against the Polish zloty necessitates extraordinary measures, including modifying banks' liquidity policies. The franc's sharp increase, triggered by Switzerland's interest rate cut, poses a risk to Polish banks with high franc-denominated debt. Belka's comments follow a similar warning made earlier, emphasizing the need for banks to adjust their financing policies due to the new exchange rate.

site_title: Singapore's anti-graft laws: 5 possible areas for reform
summary: Singapore's 55-year-old anti-corruption laws need review to keep pace with global developments, particularly in light of its slide in Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index. The government plans to boost the Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau by 20% and establish a central corruption reporting centre. Proposed reforms include: 1) lowering corporate liability thresholds, 2) introducing a compliance defence, 3) expanding extraterritorial effect, 4) strengthening whistleblower protection, and 5) implementing a private-sector outreach programme to address corruption challenges. These reforms aim to restore Singapore's leading reputation for non-corruptibility and maintain its image globally.

site_title: Paint tycoon tops Singapore billionaire list
summary: Goh Cheng Liang, founder of Nippon Paint South East Asia Group, has become Singapore's richest person with an estimated US$8.2 billion fortune, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. He co-founded the company in 1955 and has expanded it into 15 Asian countries. The company's paints are sold in stores across Asia and adorn prominent landmarks, with Nippon Paint becoming Asia's largest paintmaker and estimated fourth-largest globally. Goh's wealth has funded the Goh Foundation and his family's business empire continues to grow under the leadership of his son, Goh Hup Jin.

site_title: After Gmail blocked in China, Microsoft's Outlook hacked, says GreatFire
summary: China's hacking attack on Microsoft's Outlook email service, targeting users with SMTP and IMAP protocols, occurred just weeks after Google's Gmail was blocked in the country. GreatFire.org, an online censorship watchdog, says China's Cyberspace Administration of China (CAC) is likely responsible for the "man-in-the-middle" attack. This move further restricts communication methods that China cannot monitor, amid increased disruption of foreign online services in China.

site_title: Oil's plunge to siphon Gulf petrodollars from global markets
summary: Oil prices have plummeted 60% over the past seven months, threatening the financial stability of Gulf Arab sovereign wealth funds. These funds, worth around $2.43 trillion, rely heavily on oil revenues to invest in global markets. With projected deficits of up to $60 billion, governments may liquidate fund assets to cover budget deficits, potentially halting net inflows of fresh petrodollars. However, funds are expected to remain active in long-term investments, focusing on infrastructure and real estate in emerging economies, and may even reverse flows of petrodollars.

site_title: Oil price slide expected to boost earnings for many euro firms
summary: Eurozone firms are expected to see a 25% boost in earnings for the fourth quarter of 2014 and a 10% increase throughout 2015 due to lower oil prices and a weakening euro. The benefits of cheaper commodities, lower input costs, and export-boosting currency moves are expected to lift earnings for travel and tourism companies, retailers, and non-energy sectors. However, the oil and gas sector is expected to experience a significant decline in earnings momentum, with analysts focusing on the short-term negative impact of the drop in oil prices.

site_title: Currency wars unlikely to break out in region: StanChart economist
summary: Asian economies are vulnerable to currency wars, but senior analysts from Standard Chartered Bank say they are unlikely to break out in the region. Despite the euro and yen being driven down in value, countries such as Japan and most Asian nations have not engaged in competitive devaluation, which could hurt trade. Analysts believe that countries are wary of devaluation, as it may not benefit them in the long run. Instead, they expect the US to hike interest rates in a few months, potentially leading to more currency weakness, but this is seen as a natural response.

site_title: US: Markets closed
summary: US markets are closed on Monday for Martin Luther King Jr Day. Trading resumes on Tuesday. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while Popiah king Sam Goi made a mandatory offer for the rest of PSC at S$0.40 a share. Asia stocks continue to rise despite US President Trump's new threats, with mining and healthcare stocks propelling shares upward. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Denmark cuts certificate of deposit rate by 0.15% points
summary: Denmark's central bank reduced its certificate of deposit rate by 0.15 percentage points to minus 0.20% on January 19, 2015, following the Swiss National Bank's decision to scrap the franc's cap against the euro. This move comes as the Danish crown strengthened against the euro, which is pegged to the euro.

site_title: SNB upending mortgages unnerves bank bondholders
summary: The Swiss National Bank's (SNB) decision to drop its currency cap sent the Swiss franc surging, causing yields on Eurobonds for Polish banks to jump to five- and nine-month highs. Polish banks, which hold $35 billion in mortgages denominated in the currency, face increased risk of non-performing loans. While the banks have adequate capital to withstand a drop in the franc's value, analysts warn that borrowers' solvency may be at risk if the zloty stays close to 5 against the franc.

site_title: China considers easing controls on foreign investment
summary: China is considering relaxing controls on foreign investment by introducing a "negative list" that would only regulate sectors where activity is restricted. Foreign investors in other areas would be treated equally to domestic counterparts, with no approval requirement for most investments. This move aims to cut red tape and boost a slowing economy, following previous rule changes that opened up areas such as real estate and oil refining to foreign investment. China's foreign direct investment reached a record $119.6 billion last year, despite a two-year low in growth.

site_title: Goldcorp to buy Probe Mines for about US$440 million
summary: Goldcorp Inc agreed to buy Probe Mines Ltd for approximately US$439 million, valuing the company at C$526 million, in a bid to gain control of the promising Borden Gold project in northern Ontario. The deal is expected to close in March and values Probe shares at C$5, a 49% premium to Friday's closing price. Goldcorp aims to secure a low-cost, high-quality gold production opportunity, and the acquisition is seen as a strategic move to expand its existing districts.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise on expected ECB stimulus move
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose on Monday, driven by expectations of the European Central Bank's (ECB) stimulus move, including a possible quantitative easing program. The ECB's policy meeting on Thursday is expected to announce fresh stimulus measures, boosting investor confidence. The euro recovered against the dollar, and stocks in companies reliant on exports benefited from a weaker currency. Meanwhile, a snap election in Greece on Sunday has raised concerns about the potential impact on the eurozone.

site_title: Swedish banks say rate fall making borrowers complacent
summary: Swedish banks have expressed concern that falling interest rates have made borrowers complacent about household debt costs. In the mortgage market, 60% of clients at Svenska Handelsbanken AB take short-term adjustable loans despite long-term rates hitting historic lows. This complacency is a concern for lenders, who fear that borrowers may not be adequately prepared for potential future rate hikes. The situation highlights the need for borrowers to carefully consider their loan options and be prepared for potential increases in interest rates.

site_title: Euro back in crisis mode as Davos awaits ECB, Greece ballot
summary: The euro-area economy is facing concerns as investors and policymakers attend the World Economic Forum in Davos. Greece's upcoming election may lead to renegotiation of austerity measures, potentially sparking a euro exit. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi is trying to craft a consensus for quantitative easing to combat deflation, but faces resistance from Germany and other governments. The euro has reached its lowest level in over a decade, and the Swiss National Bank's surprise decision to scrap its currency cap has added to market turmoil. A Greek exit could have significant financial implications, and elections in Portugal and Spain are also raising concerns.

site_title: Investors pile into eurozone debt as focus turns to QE details
summary: Investors are piling into eurozone debt ahead of the European Central Bank's (ECB) announcement of a sovereign bond-buying scheme, known as quantitative easing (QE). Implied borrowing costs for many countries have fallen to record lows, with Italian and Spanish yields reaching historic lows. The ECB may leave the burden of risk for purchases with national central banks, and set limits on how much debt can be bought from each country. Investors are bracing for a potential announcement on Thursday, with some warning of a further default in Greece if junk-rated debt is excluded.

site_title: Sterling eases from 7-yr high vs euro with ECB action seen likely
summary: Sterling dropped from a 7-year high against the euro, recovering slightly ahead of the European Central Bank's decision on quantitative easing. Analysts expect the ECB to launch quantitative easing to stimulate the eurozone economy, pricing the euro accordingly. The euro rose 0.3% against sterling to 76.64 pence, while the pound fell slightly to US$1.5150. The Bank of England's minutes and UK labor market data will be released on Wednesday, potentially influencing sterling's value. Analysts expect interest rate expectations to remain low, with some speculating a possible shift in BoE policy.

images.alt_text: Sterling fell from a seven-year high against the euro on Monday, as the single currency recovered some poise ahead of Thursday's European Central Bank decision on whether and how to launch quantitative easing.

site_title: Markets expect decade of below-target inflation even as ECB readies QE
summary: European markets expect a decade of below-target inflation, despite the European Central Bank's (ECB) planned quantitative easing (QE) program. Market-implied inflation expectations have fallen 60 basis points in the past six months, with the eurozone's five-year, five-year breakeven forward contract trading at record lows around 1.50%. The ECB aims to boost inflation to its 2% target, but investors doubt the effectiveness of QE, citing the failure of central banks to hit their targets over the past four-five years.

site_title: China to promote reform as economy faces difficulties, Li says
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang emphasized the need for structural reforms and public services amid economic difficulties. The country is expected to experience significant downward pressure this year, with the economy growing at its slowest quarterly pace since 2009. Li also announced plans to deepen medical-care system reforms and add doctors in rural areas. The government aims to promote economic restructuring through these reforms.

images.alt_text: China's Premier Li Keqiang said the government needs to push ahead with reforms and provide more public services amid challenges to the economy.

site_title: London luxury homebuilders seen paying less affordable home tax
summary: London luxury homebuilders are expected to pay significantly less in affordable home tax after the UK government introduced a policy allowing them to only pay levies on expanded space, not the entire conversion. The policy change, announced in November, will reduce contributions from developers converting disused offices into apartments. This move is seen as a boost to regeneration and could provide more homes, with the Westminster borough council anticipating a drop in levies. The policy change aims to encourage the redevelopment of vacant office buildings into apartments.

site_title: Global regulators mull swaps rules reprieve
summary: Global regulators are considering an extension of the December 2015 deadline for introducing new capital requirements for swaps transactions, giving the international banking industry more time to implement post-crisis rules that could add $800 billion to the global financial industry's cost. This reprieve comes after strong resistance from the industry, which has expressed concerns about the feasibility of implementing the new rules within the current timeline. Regulators hope to reach an agreement on a new timeline in the coming weeks.

site_title: BoE says badly run banks face hefty capital surcharge
summary: The Bank of England's Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) plans to require badly run banks to hold substantially more capital until internal risks are under control. Poor governance and risk controls have led to misconduct and hefty fines, prompting regulators to consider extra capital requirements. Banks with weak risk management and governance would need to hold 10-40% extra capital, with a plan to address failings and a potential removal of the requirement once issues are resolved. The changes reflect EU bank capital requirements and will be phased in from January 2016.

images.alt_text: Badly run banks in Britain will be forced to hold substantially more capital until they can show that internal risks are under control, the Bank of England said on Monday.

site_title: 3 days out, Bundesbank striving to put limits on ECB money-printing
summary: Germany's Bundesbank is pushing to limit the European Central Bank's (ECB) money-printing plan, aiming to soften or delay key decisions ahead of a Thursday announcement. The Bundesbank is concerned that the ECB's bond-buying program could leave it responsible for losses. To mitigate this, the Bundesbank is seeking to shift the risk to national central banks, rather than the ECB, for buying euro zone member states' bonds.

site_title: BlackRock sees 15% Aussie drop on mining rout
summary: BlackRock predicts the Australian dollar could drop 15% to 70 US cents due to a decline in resource export prices, which could also lead to a narrower gap between the Aussie and US 10-year bond yields. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to keep interest rates unchanged at 2.5% in 2015, with a cut more likely than an increase. Despite weak consumer confidence and a slump in mining exports, BlackRock sees positive signs in employment numbers and a decline in the exchange rate, which may influence the RBA's decision.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust net profit down 10.4% at S$12.7 million
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported a 10.4% decrease in net profit to S$12.7 million for the full financial year 2014, due to lower production of NEWater, lower power tariffs, and higher trust expenses. Revenue fell 2.5% to S$65.5 million, while distribution per unit remained steady at 7.82 Singapore cents. KIT's underlying asset performance is expected to remain stable, but Ulu Pandan Trust's cash earnings may fluctuate due to variable power revenue changes.

site_title: Oil price plunge drags down Russian economy: EBRD bank
summary: Russia's economy is expected to shrink 4.8% in 2015 due to a sharp fall in oil prices, which have plummeted 60% since June, and the ongoing Ukraine crisis. The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) revised its forecast, downgrading its previous prediction of a 0.2% contraction. The Ukrainian economy is also expected to shrink 5.0% this year, with Western sanctions and capital outflows exacerbating the crisis. The EBRD notes that some emerging nations will benefit from the low oil prices, but overall growth in its investment zone is expected to contract 0.3% in 2015.

site_title: Uber says it can create 50,000 jobs in Europe
summary: Uber CEO Travis Kalanick announced that the company can create up to 50,000 jobs in Europe this year through a "new partnership" with European cities. This follows the creation of 7,500 full-time-equivalent jobs in San Francisco, 13,750 in New York, 10,000 in London, and 3,750 in Paris. Uber aims to establish a partnership with EU cities, promote progressive regulation, and provide economic benefits to cities and their economies. The company has faced criticism from regulators and taxi operators due to concerns over competition and safety.

site_title: UK lawmaker wants senior bankers vetted under new rules
summary: UK lawmaker Andrew Tyrie warns that introducing a new senior persons regime for bankers without vetting existing senior staff could repeat past failures. The regime aims to hold major decisions accountable to a named individual, but grandfathering existing staff could increase the risk of a "box-ticking, back-covering culture". Tyrie urges regulators to apply checks to all staff, saying no key banker should be automatically enrolled. The Treasury has not set a start date for the new regime, which has sparked frustration among lawmakers that few bankers have been held accountable for the 2007-09 financial crisis.

site_title: Europe's startups find US tough to crack in quest for cash
summary: European startups are struggling to gain traction in the US market, where they face tougher competition and higher barriers to entry. Despite the allure of access to a larger pool of investors, many European startups have retreated from the US in recent years. In 2013, US startups raised seven times more money than their European counterparts, and the gap may have widened last year. European governments have tried to boost innovation and attract technology companies, but the US ecosystem remains a significant challenge for European startups.

site_title: Hollande says France needs Charlie-Hebdo spirit to fix economy
summary: French President Francois Hollande urged the nation to tap into the unity shown after terrorist attacks to revive the economy. Following the attacks that killed 17 people, Hollande led a march of 3.7 million and emphasized the need for economic strength. His approval rating jumped 21 points to 40% due to his handling of the terrorist threat. Hollande plans to lower oil prices and a weaker euro to boost households and companies, aiming for a 1% GDP expansion this year.

site_title: China's Tencent apologises for "civil rights" blunder
summary: China's Tencent apologized for a technical error that allowed US flags to appear on WeChat screens in China, a move intended to commemorate Martin Luther King Jr Day. The animation was meant to be available only in the US, but a glitch allowed users worldwide to see the flags. Tencent said it would try harder to achieve internationalization, acknowledging that its path is "not easy." The incident sparked outrage among Chinese internet users, who criticized the company for its human rights record and the perceived lack of sensitivity to China's censorship policies.

site_title: Air India to cut costs by US$226.6 million
summary: State-owned carrier Air India plans to cut annual costs by 14 billion rupees (US$226.6 million) in an effort to improve its finances. The airline will identify surplus staff, slash overtime and expenses, and cut flights not meeting fuel costs. Staff travel and hospitality have been restricted, and wage increases for local staff will not be entertained. This move comes after the government ordered the airline to reduce losses, which have not been reported since 2007. Air India aims to increase its reputation after recent technical glitches and improve its market share.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch up early
summary: European shares rose 0.1% in early trading, following last week's gains, as investors anticipate a potential bond buying program by the European Central Bank to support the euro zone economy. Julius Baer shares led the gains, rising 2.7% after the Swiss National Bank abandoned its franc cap. The FTSEurofirst 300 index stood at 1,408.40 points.

site_title: Indonesia says no evidence so far of terrorism in AirAsia crash
summary: Indonesian investigators have found no evidence of terrorism in the AirAsia crash that killed 162 people on December 28, 2014. Cockpit voice recordings show no threats or signs of foul play, and investigators have transcribed only half of the recording. The investigation suggests bad weather was likely a contributing factor, and an explosion before the crash is unlikely. The National Transportation Safety Committee (NTSC) hopes to finish a preliminary report on the crash early next week.

site_title: M1's Q4 net profit up 9.9%
summary: M1's Q4 net profit rose 9.9% to S$44.5 million, driven by a 24.3% increase in operating revenue to S$346.4 million. For the full year, net profit increased 9.7% to S$175.8 million and operating revenue rose 6.8% to S$1.08 billion. The company declared a final cash dividend of 11.9 cents per share.

site_title: China hopeful of further cooperation with Sri Lanka, despite project reviews
summary: China expressed hope for continued cooperation with Sri Lanka despite a pledge to review Chinese infrastructure projects awarded under the previous administration. The move comes after a Sri Lankan minister announced plans to use independent audit firms to assess costs, a step likely to please Indian and Western powers concerned about Beijing's access. This development may impact China's Belt and Road Initiative projects in Sri Lanka.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 7.02 points to 3,307.7. Trading volume reached 897.2 million shares valued at S$897.2 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 193-239.

site_title: Chinese banks buy the most yuan in seven years in December
summary: Chinese banks bought a record $19 billion in yuan in December, the most in seven years, amid concerns of capital outflows as China's economy slows. This follows a decline in foreign exchange reserves and a slowdown in foreign direct investment in 2014. Analysts attribute the capital outflow to "hot money" exiting China due to market jitters and the yuan's recent weakness. China's GDP growth is expected to cool to 7.2% in the fourth quarter, putting pressure on policymakers to address the economic slowdown.

site_title: Southeast Asia stocks: Malaysia up on policy hopes, Indonesia cement shares fall
summary: Malaysia's stock index rose 0.6% to a two-week high on Monday, driven by hopes of policy changes, including budget revisions, expected to help adjust to reduced oil and gas earnings. Indonesian cement shares fell after the government announced a price cut of 3,000 rupiah per bag. Regional markets were lifted by expectations of global monetary easing and a possible delay in US interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Most Southeast Asian stock markets were flat to higher on Monday, with Malaysian index hitting a two-week high a day before the government's announcement of policy changes, but Indonesian cement shares fell after a cut in cement prices.

site_title: Morgan Stanley sees developing nations cutting dollar debt sales
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts developing nations will reduce dollar debt sales and increase local-currency bond offerings in 2015 due to rising US borrowing costs. Foreign-currency debt issuance is forecast to drop 25% to $72 billion, while domestic-currency sales are expected to rise 2.9% to $712 billion. This comes as investors demand a 393 basis point extra yield for developing-country dollar debt over Treasuries, up from 124 basis points since June.

site_title: European shares hit seven-year high, all eyes on ECB
summary: European shares reached a seven-year high on Monday, driven by anticipation of the European Central Bank's potential bond-buying program. Swiss blue chips led the gains, with the SMI index up 3.2%. Julius Baer surged 5.3% after the bank reported no losses following the Swiss National Bank's decision to scrap the franc cap. The move is expected to support the eurozone economy and lift investor sentiment.

images.alt_text: European shares hit a seven-year high on Monday, lifted by growing expectations that the European Central Bank is about to embark on a bond-buying programme to support the eurozone economy.

site_title: Oil prices slip on record Iraq output
summary: Iraq announced record oil production of 4 million barrels per day in December, with plans to increase exports from the northern city of Kirkuk and the Kurdistan region. This led to a drop in Brent crude oil prices below $50 a barrel. The global economic outlook has darkened, further contributing to the decline in oil prices.

site_title: Thailand to launch first special economic zone in northern Tak province
summary: Thailand plans to launch its first special economic zone in northern Tak province, aiming to boost trade and attract investors. The zone, located 260 miles north of Bangkok, is part of the military government's efforts to revive the economy. The construction cost is estimated at 10.54 billion baht over two years, with the area of Mae Sot, a major trade hub, being a priority. Thai firms, including Charoen Pokphand Group, have expressed interest in setting up in the zone, which is expected to lift growth and boost border trade with neighboring countries.

site_title: Former Swiss banker found guilty in WikiLeaks trial, avoids jail
summary: A former Swiss banker, Rudolf Elmer, has been found guilty of breaching Swiss banking secrecy laws by handing over data about offshore clients to WikiLeaks. He was ordered to pay costs and given a suspended fine, avoiding jail time. Elmer was found guilty of forging a letter and found not guilty of breaching secrecy laws in two other cases.

images.alt_text: A former Julius Baer banker was found guilty on Monday of breaching Swiss banking secrecy laws by handing over data about offshore clients to WikiLeaks, but will avoid jail time.

site_title: LNG to snap 4-year run as sub-$10 price seen amid oil's drop
summary: Liquefied natural gas (LNG) prices in Asia are expected to average below $10 per million British thermal unit (BTU) in 2015, marking a four-year low, due to growing supply and falling oil prices. Benchmark crude prices have dropped 50% last year, exacerbating a global glut, and are expected to remain below $80 through late 2020. As a result, spot LNG prices are likely to stay at $9 to $11, with a risk to the downside, and long-term prices will be single-digit.

site_title: Bank losses from SNB shock seen mounting as ripples spread
summary: The Swiss National Bank's decision to end the franc's three-year cap on the euro and franc led to significant losses for major banks, including Citigroup ($150M), Deutsche Bank ($150M), and Barclays ($100M), with total losses potentially in the billions. Hedge funds and currency speculators also suffered losses, with some, like FXCM, receiving cash infusions to stay afloat. The move has created ripple effects throughout the financial system, with potential long-term consequences for Swiss banks, asset managers, and the broader economy.

site_title: Swiss franc surge may hit Polish banks: Moody's
summary: Moody's warns that a surge in the Swiss franc may negatively affect Polish banks, citing increased costs for borrowers and liquidity needs due to collateral requirements. The banks most vulnerable to this devaluation are Bank BPH, Bank Millennium, mBank, and Getin Noble, with higher concentrations of Swiss franc mortgage loans. A sustained devaluation of the Polish currency relative to the Swiss franc would be credit negative for these banks.

site_title: Malaysia December inflation seen easing to 2.8% year-on-year
summary: Malaysia's annual inflation rate is expected to ease to 2.8% in December, down from November's 3.0%, as falling fuel prices offset higher food costs from severe floods. Despite oil price declines, crop prices surged due to the worst flood in decades. The easing inflation rate is a positive sign for the economy, which has been impacted by the floods.

site_title: Keppel Reit fourth quarter distribution per unit (DPU) drops to 1.51 Singapore cents
summary: Keppel Reit reported a 24.2% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.51 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2014, due to the absence of Prudential Tower's contribution. Net property income eased 8.3% to S$34.25 million. The trust's net asset value per unit stood at S$1.41, and its stock price ended two cents higher at S$1.23.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.74 points to close at 1,753.31, with 507 gainers and 302 losers. The index saw significant trading volume of 1.92 billion lots valued at RM1.91 billion.

site_title: Richest one per cent will own more than the rest by 2016: Oxfam
summary: Oxfam reports that by 2016, the richest one percent of the world's population will own more than the rest, with their share of wealth projected to exceed 50 percent. This trend, driven by rising inequality, could hinder efforts to combat poverty. According to Oxfam, the top tier's share of wealth increased from 44 percent in 2009 to 48 percent in 2014. The charity's executive director, Winnie Byanyima, attributes the growing gap to an "explosion in inequality" that is holding back poverty reduction efforts.

site_title: Stocks of developers face greater risks than Reits when Sibor spikes: OSK-DMG
summary: SIBOR's recent spike to 0.64% is expected to benefit Reits more than developer stocks, as most Reits have hedged interest rates to fixed rates. A 50 basis point increase in Sibor could hit Reits' distribution per unit by 1-3%, but may dampen private home sales, posing a downside risk to developers. Meanwhile, the low Singapore 10-year government yields are expected to remain stable, with risk-free rates falling below 2%.

site_title: Parliament: Singapore will benefit from lower oil prices
summary: Singapore will benefit from lower oil prices due to its status as a net importer of oil. Minister for Trade and Industry Lim Hng Kiang stated that the economy will gain from cheaper raw materials, but the petrochemical sector's net gain will be limited due to falling prices of petrochemical products.

site_title: China mulls "green" sector asset-backed securities: regulator
summary: China's banking regulator is considering the launch of asset-backed securities (ABS) based on loans to "green" industries, aiming to increase liquidity without expanding the money supply. The move follows China's expansion of asset securitization on an unprecedented scale. A registration system for ABS was introduced in November, simplifying the process. No launch date has been set, but the development is seen as part of China's efforts to promote green finance.

site_title: Germany continues to repatriate gold: Bundesbank
summary: Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, has stepped up the repatriation of its gold reserves from overseas storage, transferring 120 tonnes in 2014, including 35 tonnes from Paris and 85 tonnes from New York. Germany's gold reserves now total 3,384.2 tonnes, the second-largest in the world after the US. The repatriation effort, initiated in 2013, aims to bring back 674 tonnes by 2020 and store half of its gold in its own vaults, amid historical concerns over storing gold abroad during the Cold War.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust's Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) slightly higher at 1.87 cents
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust reported a Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.87 Singapore cents, slightly higher than the 1.84 cents paid out in the same period last year. The trust's total amount distributable to unitholders increased 2.7% to S$46.19 million, driven by a 6.2% rise in gross revenue to S$82.92 million. Net property income rose 3.1% to S$69.48 million, despite a 2.7% increase in the Japanese yen's depreciation. The distribution will be paid on February 27.

site_title: Swiss sight deposits jump in week of SNB move to scrap cap
summary: Switzerland's central bank, the Swiss National Bank (SNB), scrapped its three-year-old cap on the franc, causing the currency to surge against the euro. Sight deposits, used to provide commercial banks with cash, jumped 10.6 billion francs to 339.6 billion francs last week, the largest weekly increase since July 2013. The move suggests the SNB may have intervened to defend the cap before its removal. The franc's value soared after the announcement, indicating the bank's actions may have been a response to market pressure.

site_title: China's push into services risks long-term growth stagnation
summary: China's efforts to shift its economy from investment-intensive manufacturing to the services sector may risk long-term growth stagnation, experts warn. The country's slowest annual economic growth in decades is partly due to a rapidly expanding service sector, which officials hope will offset losses in inefficient industries. However, many believe that not all services jobs are created equal, and that low-end cultural services don't pay well, potentially leading to stagnant wages and economic growth.

site_title: Pricing standoff holds off issuance in Sing dollars
summary: A pricing standoff between investors and issuers in Singapore's bond markets is hindering new issue sales, with only two deals completed so far this year. The gap in pricing expectations is too wide, causing investors to be selective and hesitant to take on new high-yield names. Potential issuers, including Fragrance Group and ICBC Singapore, have been hearing from investors and checking market conditions, but none have emerged with a deal yet. The standoff is attributed to the selloff in the secondary markets since early December, when oil prices crashed, and investors are still out of the money on oil-related high-yield credits.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall after anti-speculation moves batter China indexes
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted, their worst day in nearly five weeks, after mainland Chinese indexes fell by their largest percentage in over six and a half years. Regulators cracked down on margin trading, which has fueled speculation, and concerns about Europe also weighed on investors. The mainland's financial stocks tumbled, dragging down Hong Kong's indexes. Analysts say the selling mood was already present due to concerns about Europe, and the mainland's tumble provided another reason for the correction.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close 0.89% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.89% on Monday, following a positive lead from Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index climbed 150.13 points to 17,014.29, driven by higher oil prices and investor hopes for European Central Bank stimulus. This comes as US shares rebounded from a five-day losing streak, snapping an oversold market.

site_title: Oil prices edge lower in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices edged lower in Asian trade, easing 37 cents to US$48.32 for US West Texas Intermediate and 37 cents to US$49.80 for Brent crude. Despite a rally last week, concerns over weak demand and a global supply glut continue to weigh on prices, with analysts predicting range-bound trading until fundamentals change. The market is awaiting the June Opec meeting, which could determine whether the cartel lowers output and addresses global oversupply, with prices potentially falling to around US$40 before an upturn.

site_title: Value in European stocks: Henderson Global Investors
summary: European stocks are considered a "happy hunting ground" for value investors, with a significant gap in valuations between US and European stocks. According to Nick Sheridan, a manager at Henderson Global Investors, Europe and Japan are the cheapest developed markets on an inflation-adjusted price-earnings measure. Sheridan is overweight on Italy and Spain, but underweight on France due to high social and employment costs. The European Central Bank is expected to announce a quantitative easing package to boost the economy, which could help boost demand for credit and stimulate growth.

site_title: Lenovo parent Legend Holdings plans up to US$3b H2 2015 HK IPO: IFR
summary: Legend Holdings Corp, parent of Lenovo Group Ltd, plans an up to US$3 billion initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong in the second half of 2015, according to people familiar with the matter. China International Capital Corp and UBS AG are working with Legend on the planned IPO. No immediate comment was available from Legend Holdings.

images.alt_text: Legend Holdings Corp, the parent of the world's biggest maker of personal computers, Lenovo Group Ltd, plans an up to US$3 billion initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong in the second half of 2015, IFR reported on Monday, citing people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Singapore JTC awards tender for industrial site at Tuas South St 9 but not Tanjong Penjuru
summary: JTC Corporation awarded a tender for an 8,369 sqm industrial site at Tuas South Street 9 to Asiaone Logistics & Warehousing Pte Ltd for S$7.04 million. The site has a 20-year 7-month tenure and a gross plot ratio of up to 1.0. The tender was launched in October and closed in December, with four bids received. Two bids for an industrial site at Tanjong Penjuru were not accepted due to low prices.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Moody's upgrades outlook for global airlines to positive from stable
summary: Moody's has upgraded its outlook for the global airline industry to "positive" from "stable", driven by sharp declines in fuel costs. The agency projects adjusted operating profit margins of 12-14% for this year and 11.5-13.5% for next year. US carriers are expected to see the largest increases, with stronger performance relative to airlines in competitive developing markets and Europe.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Technology to give a fillip to productivity in developed countries: StanChart
summary: A report from Standard Chartered suggests technology can boost productivity in developed countries, despite fears of job losses due to automation. The report states that while repetitive jobs may be replaced by machines, human skills such as problem-solving, communication, and adaptability will be more important. Experts who rely on knowledge and experience will face challenges, but those with skills that complement AI will remain in demand. The report concludes that the fear of high unemployment caused by technology is misplaced, and that technology can actually create new job opportunities.

site_title: Indonesia's November loan growth slows to 11.9% y-o-y
summary: Indonesia's loan growth in November slowed to 11.9% year-over-year, down from 12.6% in October, according to the financial services authority. The country's central bank estimated loan growth at 11-12% in 2014 and 15-17% this year amid better economic conditions. The broad money supply (M2) rose 12.7% year-over-year in November.

site_title: Parliament: MediShield Life Scheme Bill tabled
summary: Singapore's Parliament tabled the MediShield Life Scheme Bill, providing for universal health coverage and administration. The Bill sets out coverage and benefits, establishes a MediShield Life Council, and allows deduction of Medisave monies for premium payments. Those with pre-existing medical conditions will pay 30% higher premiums for 10 years, and individuals can choose to access financial or medical information for premium subsidies. The Bill also imposes penalties for accessing unauthorized information and sets out recovery of premiums from defaulters. The scheme aims to provide lifelong protection against large hospital bills.

site_title: Korean Air chairman's daughter denies "nut rage" charges
summary: Heather Cho, daughter of Korean Air Lines chairman Cho Sun-oo, has denied conspiring with airline executives to force flight attendants to lie about her outburst over nuts being served in a bag instead of a dish. Cho, a former executive and head of in-flight service, appeared in court in Seoul after her arrest on December 30. She faces charges related to the incident at John F Kennedy airport in New York, which led to her resignation in 2013. Cho maintains her innocence and is set to face trial.

site_title: Australia: Shares pare gains but end higher
summary: Australian shares closed 0.2% higher on Monday, paring earlier gains, amid concerns over economic data from China. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 9.86 points to 5,309.10, despite consumer staples and telecom stocks falling. Woolworths and Wesfarmers declined 1% and 0.3%, respectively, while Telstra fell 0.8%. The benchmark posted its biggest weekly drop since June 2013.

site_title: Indonesia to inject funds into infrastructure-related firms
summary: Indonesia plans to inject 7 trillion rupiah (US$555.42 million) into state-controlled firms PT Aneka Tambang Tbk, PT Krakatau Steel Tbk, PT Waskita Karya Tbk, and PT Adhi Karya Tbk to boost infrastructure development. The funds will support the government's goal of injecting 48 trillion rupiah into 35 state-owned firms to increase their role in driving development in priority sectors. The state enterprises will sell new shares to raise funds, and dividend payouts will range from 5 to 40% of profits. The plans require parliamentary approval.

site_title: Japanese companies doing more firing than hiring: report
summary: Japan's labour market shows a trend of more companies firing employees than hiring, with 1.4% of workers losing jobs annually. Those laid off often face long periods of joblessness, with 48% finding new employment within 12 months, and suffering a 20% cut to income. Even four years after displacement, earnings are 15% lower. OECD report criticizes Japan's rigid job market, citing the need for "flexicurity" to balance flexibility with security for workers. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe aims to improve the economy by cutting red tape and increasing flexibility.

images.alt_text: More than half of Japanese who are laid off will still be out of work a year later, an international report said on Monday, adding firms must be more flexible if Japan's economy is to improve.

site_title: Parliament: Singapore economy to benefit from lower global oil prices, says Lim Hng Kiang
summary: Singapore's economy is expected to benefit from lower global oil prices, said Trade and Industry Minister Lim Hng Kiang in Parliament. Lower oil prices will translate into lower electricity tariffs and fuel costs, benefiting businesses and consumers. With global oil prices declining from $115 to around $50 per barrel, businesses will see improved margins, while consumers will benefit from lower spending on electricity and oil-related items. This could lead to increased purchasing power and stimulate consumption, further boosting the economy.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: China to prioritise natural gas for home use, public transport
summary: China will prioritize natural gas for residential use and public transport in 2015 due to rapid growth in consumer demand, resulting in shortages. Despite increased domestic output and imports, insufficient storage capacity and weak demand management contribute to the issue. The country aims to conserve supplies by limiting new gas-fired power plant construction. China's gas demand growth is expected to slow down this year due to slower economic growth and higher gas prices.

site_title: China issues draft rules restricting entrusted lending
summary: China's banking regulator has issued draft rules to tighten supervision of entrusted lending, a shadow banking product used to speculate on stocks. The move aims to curb excessive leverage and risk in the financial sector. Entrusted loans, which allow firms to lend to each other while banks act as intermediaries, pose a risk to banks due to their revolving nature. The draft rules restrict funds from being used for entrusted loans, including bank lending to companies and funds raised from other investors. The public has until February 16 to suggest amendments to the rules.

site_title: China shares end down 7.7%, biggest fall in six years
summary: China's shares plummeted 7.7% on Monday, the largest one-day decline in six years, following regulators' punishment of several brokerages for margin trading rule violations. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 260.15 points to 3,116.35 on turnover of 409.9 billion yuan. This decline surpasses the previous record of 7.73% set in 2008.

site_title: Gold trades near highest level since September before ECB meets
summary: Gold prices rose near a four-month high before the European Central Bank's meeting, driven by increased demand for the metal as a safe-haven asset amid market uncertainty. The metal traded at $1,275.09 an ounce, its highest level since September 2. This followed a surge in gold holdings in the largest exchange-traded product, the SPDR Gold Trust, which rose 1.9% to 730.89 metric tons, its largest gain since May 2010. The ECB's potential introduction of new stimulus measures is expected to further boost gold prices.

site_title: Broker's Take: Nomura's five property surprises for 2015; Reits could drop 10%
summary: Nomura analyst Sai Min Chow has predicted five property surprises for 2015, including Reits potentially falling 10% due to rising mortgage rates and a decline in office rents. He also expects the 10-year Singapore government bond yield to rise above 2.5% by end-2015 and hotel room rates to fall 5% due to increased supply. Additionally, tax incentives for Reits may not be extended beyond March. Chow prefers several non-consensus Reits, including CapitaLand and City Developments, for 2015.

site_title: Tokyo Olympics top sponsors to pay at least US$128m: report
summary: Tokyo Olympics top sponsors will pay a minimum of 15 billion yen (approximately $170 million) for the "Gold Sponsor" title, which includes the right to use the Games logo and slogans in advertisements until the end of 2020. Seven companies, including Asahi, NTT Docomo, and Toyota, are expected to bid for the top spot. The total sponsorship revenue aims to reach 150 billion yen, with three sponsorship ranks: Gold Partner ($170 million), Official Partner (6 billion yen), and Official Supporters (1-3 billion yen). The first sponsor will be decided as early as this month.

site_title: Shanghai widens lead over Singapore as world's busiest box port
summary: Shanghai has widened its lead over Singapore as the world's busiest container port for a fifth consecutive year, processing approximately 35.2 million 20-foot containers in 2014. This surpasses Singapore's 33.9 million containers, a gap that has increased from around one million boxes a year ago. China's dominance in the global container-shipping market continues, with Shanghai and other Chinese ports expanding their operations.

site_title: Euro weakens in Asia on ECB stimulus speculation
summary: The euro weakened in Asia on Monday as investors anticipate the European Central Bank's potential introduction of quantitative easing (QE) to boost the struggling eurozone economy. The euro slipped to US$1.1559 and 135.31 yen, down from US$1.1566 and 135.87 yen on Friday. The ECB's meeting on Thursday is expected to see the introduction of sovereign bond purchases, which could lead to increased cash circulation and weaken demand for the single currency.

images.alt_text: The euro struggled in Asia Monday on growing expectations that the European Central Bank will pull the trigger on a massive bond-buying scheme to buoy the struggling eurozone economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
