summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.49 points to 1745.50, driven by a higher volume of 45.72 million lots worth RM17.72 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 152 to 38.

site_title: Oil prices dip on gloomy Chinese, European outlook
summary: Oil prices fell in early Asian trade on Monday, dropping 34 cents to $49.83 per barrel for Brent crude and 41 cents to $48.28 per barrel for US crude. The decline is attributed to gloomy Chinese economic data and expectations of a European Central Bank bond-buying campaign, which is expected to further weaken the euro and put downward pressure on oil prices. This marks the fourth consecutive drop in oil prices, which have fallen by more than half since last June due to increased global production and slowing demand.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.63% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.63% lower on Monday, following a plunge in Shanghai. The Hang Seng Index fell 189.49 points to 23,914.03, overshadowing a Wall Street rally. Investors are awaiting Chinese growth data release later in the week.

site_title: Singapore's inflation expectations at lowest levels in 3 years: SMU survey
summary: Singapore's inflation expectations have reached their lowest levels in three years, according to a survey by the Singapore Management University. Consumers expect overall inflation to be 3.53% this year, down from 3.73% in September. Core inflation expectations have also dropped to 3.61%, the lowest since the survey started in 2011. This reflects consumers' awareness of global economic conditions and their responses to price changes and official communications. The survey results will be released on January 23, coinciding with Singapore's inflation rate for December.

site_title: Banks battle speculation Denmark's euro peg at risk
summary: Banks in Scandinavia are working to reassure offshore investors that Denmark will not abandon its euro peg, following Switzerland's surprise decision to exit its three-year-old euro cap. Despite speculation, Denmark's economy minister and economists say the peg remains "secure" and backed by the European Central Bank. Denmark's benchmark deposit rate has been cut to minus 0.05%, and its currency reserves are near pre-crisis levels. The Danish central bank has not commented on potential rate cuts, but experts predict easing monetary policy in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Banks in Scandinavia are joining the Danish government in trying to persuade offshore investors that the Nordic country isn't about to copy Switzerland and drop its euro peg.

site_title: Australia: Shares shine after a week of losses
summary: Australian shares rose 1.2% on Monday, snapping a 5-day losing streak, after Macquarie Group upgraded its earnings forecast and new vehicle sales posted their largest monthly gain of the year. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 61.06 points to 5,360.30 points. Investors are cautious ahead of China's GDP data and the ECB meeting, but relieved by a bounce in US markets last week. Energy and mining stocks also gained, with Rio Tinto and BHP Billiton reporting positive production data.

site_title: China Environment replies to SGX query on price spike
summary: China Environment, a waste gas treatment systems manufacturer, responded to a Singapore Exchange (SGX) query on a price spike of 18.7% on Friday. The company stated it was unaware of unannounced information, but substantial shareholders acquired 3 million shares at an average price of 24.5-23.8 cents each. The shares were used to fund working capital, including raw materials and operating expenses.

site_title: Asia markets mostly up, euro struggles ahead of ECB meeting
summary: Asian markets mostly rose Monday, driven by a Wall Street rally and oil price gains. However, Shanghai plummeted 5.9% after Chinese regulators suspended three brokerages for rule violations. The euro struggled ahead of the European Central Bank's meeting, expected to unveil a bond-buying scheme. Asian markets ended the day with gains: Tokyo (0.52%), Sydney (0.90%), Seoul (0.92%), and Singapore (0.24%).

site_title: Seoul: Shares up as energy counters rally on oil rebound; won slips
summary: South Korean shares rose nearly 1% on Monday, led by gains in commodity-linked sectors and oil prices rebounding from a seven-week skid. The KOSPI index climbed 0.96% to 1,906.17 points. Foreign investors bought 27.2 billion won of KOSPI shares, snapping a five-day selling streak. Energy counters, including Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering and SK Innovation, outperformed, while casino operators and Samsung Techwin shares also rose. The won slipped against the dollar, trading at 1,080.1 to the dollar.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index rising 20.67 points to 3,321.35. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day gain. Gainers outnumbered losers 111 to 39. The index has been boosted by a mandatory offer for PSC shares and positive investor sentiment despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE share prices opened lower on Friday with the Straits Times Index down 13.31 points to 3,325.53.

site_title: Russian government takes flak as it fails to stem economic crisis
summary: Russian authorities are facing criticism for their handling of the country's economic crisis, which is expected to contract by 5% in 2015. Despite predictions of a 17% inflation rate by spring, the government has failed to announce clear policies to address the issue. Experts and business leaders, including Sberbank's Herman Gref, have called for a "radical" shift in direction, but so far, Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev has promised increased assistance to pensioners and large families without specifying concrete measures. The Kremlin's infighting and lack of direction are seen as major factors contributing to the crisis.

site_title: UK's Cameron defends free speech "right to cause offence"
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron defended the concept of free speech, stating there's a "right to cause offence about someone's religion" in a free society. He drew a distinction from Pope Francis, who said provoking others by insulting their faith is wrong. Cameron emphasized that while he might find offense to comments about Jesus, he doesn't have the right to "wreak vengeance" on those who offend him. His comments came during a visit to Washington for talks with President Barack Obama.

site_title: Japan December consumer mood improves, govt upgrades view
summary: Japanese consumer confidence improved in December for the first time in five months, according to a Cabinet Office survey. The sentiment index for general households rose to 38.8, up from 37.7 in November. The government has upgraded its view on the consumer confidence index, citing signs that the declining trend may be ending. This marks the first improvement in consumer mood since July 2019.

site_title: Nippon Paint helps make Goh Cheng Liang Singapore's richest
summary: Nippon Paint's 2014 repainting of the Raffles Hotel in Singapore required 2,500 litres of paint, a small fraction of the company's annual production. This project has contributed to the success of its founder, Goh Cheng Liang, who has become Singapore's richest person with an estimated US$8.2 billion fortune, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. Goh, who owns 39% of the company, has maintained a 50-year partnership with Osaka-based Nippon Paint Holdings Co.

site_title: China: Shares fall over 5% at open as brokerages tumble on margin trading crackdown
summary: China's stock indices fell over 5% at open on Monday, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 6.3% and the CSI300 index down 6.1%. The decline came after the securities regulator punished top brokerages for illegal margin trading activities. The crackdown led to a sharp fall in financial stocks, contributing to the overall market downturn.

site_title: Hot stocks: Keppel Land, Resources Prima
summary: Keppel Land and Resources Prima are among the top-traded stocks on Monday. Keppel Land announced an agreement to buy a 4.6-hectare site in West Jakarta for S$40.2 million, with its shares rising 3.4% to S$3.62. Resources Prima saw its shares jump 6% to 10.7 cents after a share price plunge last week. The company maintained its confidence in long-term growth prospects despite the volatility.

site_title: Fox News apologises for 'totally Muslim' remarks
summary: Fox News apologized for claiming "totally Muslim" no-go zones in Europe, following backlash over comments made by security analyst Steven Emerson. Emerson stated non-Muslims "don't go in" to areas in Birmingham, drawing mockery from Prime Minister David Cameron and European officials. Fox News aired a lengthy apology, acknowledging "regrettable errors" but also noting that areas in Europe, like the US, have high-crime zones where visitors enter with caution.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Centurion, Resources Prima
summary: Centurion Corporation is exploring injecting worker dormitory assets into a real estate investment trust (Reit) to be listed on the Singapore Exchange. Meanwhile, Indonesian coal miner Resources Prima remains confident in its long-term growth prospects despite a competitive environment and cautious sentiment, following a recent share price plunge.

site_title: Malaysia to unveil policy changes on Tuesday as oil earnings slide
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak will announce policy changes on Tuesday to address the impact of reduced oil and gas earnings due to a slump in global crude prices. The changes include likely budget revisions and are aimed at reducing the country's debt to GDP ratio. Analysts expect the government to reduce its growth forecast from 5-6% to around 4% due to the decline in oil prices. The announcement comes after the Malaysian ringgit emerged as Asia's worst-performing currency in 2014.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Najib Razak will announce policy changes, including likely budget revisions, on Tuesday to help Malaysia adjust to the impact of reduced oil and gas earnings due to the slump in global crude prices.

site_title: Jardine Matheson tops trading by value as smaller board lots trading starts
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings topped trading by value at the Singapore Exchange, with 197,000 shares traded at a total value of US$12.6 million within the first hour of trading. The stock rose 50 US cents to US$63, following a change in board lot size from 400 shares to 100 shares, reducing the minimum trading amount to US$6,300.

site_title: Cheaper oil to boost British economy: report
summary: A report by the EY ITEM Club predicts British economic growth of 2.9% in 2015, higher than the government's prediction of 2.4%, due to lower oil prices and flat inflation. Lower oil prices will boost consumer spending, and the Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates at 0.5% until spring 2016. The report also forecasts 3.5% wage growth and a 3.7% rise in real disposable income, contributing to increased household consumption.

site_title: Sharp set to fall back into the red: Nikkei
summary: Sharp Corp, Japan's electronics giant, is set to post a net loss in the current financial year due to fierce price competition and an extraordinary charge. The company is considering revising its earnings estimates, citing tough competition in liquid crystal display panels and foreign exchange market fluctuations. Sharp's operating profit is expected to be around 50 billion yen, half of its earlier forecast. Shares have dropped 7% to 234 yen, a two-year low.

site_title: Australia's new vehicle sales jump 3% in December
summary: Australia's new vehicle sales rose 3% in December, with 94,903 units sold, the largest monthly gain of the year. Sales of passenger vehicles increased 2.8%, while sports utility vehicles gained 1.2% and other vehicles climbed 6.5%. This marks a reversal from the 0.5% decline in November. Despite a 1.0% decline in December 2013, the increase is a positive note for the automotive industry in Australia.

site_title: Oxfam says richest 1% to own more than rest by 2016
summary: Oxfam reports that by 2016, the richest 1% of the global population will own more than the remaining 99%, with the richest 1% holding 50% of the world's wealth. The average wealth per adult in this group will be $2.7 million, while the remaining 80% will have an average wealth of $3,851. Oxfam urges governments to tackle tax evasion, improve public services, and introduce living minimum wages to address global inequality. The issue will be discussed at the Davos World Economic Forum, where world leaders will gather to address rising inequality and other global crises.

images.alt_text: Wealth accumulated by the richest one per cent will exceed that of the other 99 per cent in 2016, the Oxfam charity said Monday, ahead of the annual meeting of the world's most powerful at Davos, Switzerland.

site_title: China's Xiaomi to buy stake in software firm Kingsoft from Tencent
summary: China's Xiaomi has agreed to buy a 3% stake in software firm Kingsoft from Tencent for HK$527 million (US$67.99 million). The deal, expected to close on January 30, will increase Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun's voting rights in Kingsoft to 29.9%. The partnership aims to promote Kingsoft's business and invest in media and content. This move is part of Xiaomi's expansion into home appliances and television, with a reserved US$1 billion for Internet TV content.

site_title: South Korean government holding firm on growth forecast as BOK cuts
summary: South Korea's government has reaffirmed its growth forecast for 2015 at 3.8% despite the Bank of Korea's revised estimate of 3.4%. The government attributes the difference to varying opinions on the impact of policies, including fiscal stimulus and relaxed lending rules. Expansionary policies are expected to remain in place this year, with a focus on speeding up a stimulus package and allocating a record budget. The Korean economy is seen as poised for its strongest performance in four years, with risks including US interest rate increases and a slowdown in Europe.

images.alt_text: South Korea's Finance Ministry plans to stick with its growth forecast for this year, putting it at odds with the central bank on the outlook for Asia's fourth-largest economy.

site_title: Resources Prima, hit by share price plunge, says it's confident over business
summary: Resources Prima, an Indonesian coal miner listed on the Singapore Exchange, has seen its share price plummet 44.8% due to market volatility. Despite this, the company's senior management remains confident in its long-term growth prospects. Coal production volumes have risen, with sales volumes also increasing, and the company expects to maintain a cost advantage due to its owned facilities. Resources Prima's business model remains strong, with a diversified income stream, and operations continue as usual. The company expects to receive approval for a permit that could increase its coal reserves.

site_title: Yemen province to halt oil flow unless official freed
summary: Yemen's Shabwa province governor Ahmed Ali Belhaj warned that oil companies will halt production unless Shi'ite militiamen free President Abdrabuh Mansur Hadi's chief of staff Ahmed Awad bin Mubarak, who was kidnapped by the Huthi militias. Production at Shabwa's oil fields and the Belhaf gas terminal will stop unless Mubarak is released by midnight. The move is a bid to press for amendments to Yemen's constitution, which the Huthis oppose.

site_title: Abu Dhabi fund offers US$57m loans for clean energy
summary: An Abu Dhabi fund announced it will provide US$57 million in concessional loans for clean energy projects in five developing countries, aiming to bring reliable and sustainable power to over 280,000 people in Argentina, Cuba, Iran, Mauritania, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines.

site_title: South Korea Dec producer prices fall by fastest in 19 mths y-o-y
summary: South Korea's producer prices fell 2.0% in December, the largest annual decline in 19 months, due to a global selloff in commodities and weak domestic demand. Coal and oil products led the drop, plummeting 28.8% from a year earlier. The Bank of Korea, in line with expectations, held its policy interest rate steady and slashed this year's inflation forecast by half a percentage point. This decline is the fifth consecutive month of decrease in producer prices.

images.alt_text: A South Korean national flag, left, and a Bank of Korea flag fly outside the central bank's headquarters in Seoul, South Korea, on Jan. 15, 2015.

site_title: Britain's financial sector reports fastest growth since 1996 in Q4: CBI
summary: Britain's financial sector reported its fastest growth since 1996 in the fourth quarter, with a +57 business volume index, according to the Confederation of British Industry. This contrasts with official data showing a 3.2% decline in financial services output. Forecasts from Ernst & Young suggest the economy will grow by 2.9% this year, driven by falling oil prices. The sector continues to cut jobs, with skills shortages in areas like compliance, but the outlook is improving, with conditions expected to pick up in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Britain's financial sector reported the biggest upsurge in business in nearly 20 years in the final three months of last year, the Confederation of British Industry said on Monday.

site_title: Euro stays on edge as crucial ECB meeting looms
summary: The euro remains volatile ahead of the European Central Bank's (ECB) January 22 meeting, where a large-scale sovereign bond-buying program is expected. The euro has flirted with 11-year lows, trading at US$1.1561 and near a three-month low against the yen. Investors await details on the plan's design and credibility, with some predicting a 1 trillion euro quantitative easing program. The Swiss National Bank's recent policy U-turn has intensified pressure on the euro, which remains near record lows against the Australian and New Zealand dollars.

images.alt_text: The euro flirted with 11-year lows early on Monday as investors braced for the European Central Bank to take its boldest steps yet to combat deflation and revive the euro zone economy.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 0.81%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.81% higher on Monday following a rally on Wall Street, driven by oil price rebounds. The Nikkei 225 index rose 136.62 points to 17,000.78. Investors are awaiting the European Central Bank's policy meeting later this week, expecting fresh stimulus. The Swiss National Bank's decision to abandon the euro's minimum rate of 1.20 francs also contributed to the market's optimism.

site_title: Eurostar to resume service after weekend of 'Chunnel' disruptions
summary: Eurostar will resume full service Monday after a weekend of disruptions caused by a lorry fire and electrical issues in the Channel Tunnel. Although the tunnel won't be fully repaired, parts will be operational, allowing for a normal service. However, delays of up to 30 minutes may occur due to reduced capacity. Eurostar's CEO Nicolas Petrovic stated that the entire tunnel will not be repaired tomorrow.

site_title: Bank losses from SNB surprise seen mounting as ripples spread
summary: The Swiss National Bank's decision to end the cap on the Swiss franc led to significant losses for major banks and financial institutions, including Citigroup ($150 million), Deutsche Bank ($150 million), and Barclays ($100 million). Hedge funds and currency speculators also suffered substantial losses, with one hedge fund closing its largest fund after losing virtually all its money. The ripple effects of the decision are expected to spread throughout the financial system, impacting banks, brokers, and the Swiss economy in the long term.

images.alt_text: The Deutsche Bank AG headquarters stands in front of commercial and residential property in Frankfurt, Germany, on Monday, on Mar 24, 2014.

site_title: China's shipyards brace for leaner times as oil slump sours rig building spree
summary: China's shipyards, which previously benefited from a surge in oil rig building due to low oil prices, now face a downturn as producers slash new project spending. Chinese yards, which dominated the global jackup rig market, have lured orders away from regional peers with financing terms and discounts, but many have yet to be chartered. With a near 40% share of the global market, Chinese yards are exposed to a slowdown, with some fearing cancellations and price cuts that could persist longer than the oil market's slump.

site_title: Don't forget the internal threats
summary: Internal fraud poses a significant threat to organisations, with most likely to be hit by internal fraud than cyber attacks. High-profile cases in Singapore, including the Barings Futures Singapore collapse and misappropriations by insiders, highlight the dangers of misplaced trust, forgery of documents, and lack of supervisory controls. To mitigate this risk, Audit Committees (ACs) should work closely with internal auditors to implement effective internal controls, including the COSO framework, and ensure measures such as mandatory block leave, whistle-blowing policies, and periodic duty rotation are enforced.

site_title: Unknown variables to feed volatility
summary: Volatility in financial markets continues, with risk returning after the US Federal Reserve ended its QE money printing. Markets are struggling to cope with unknowns such as crashing oil prices and a surging Swiss franc, leading to heightened uncertainty. Despite a brief Wall Street bounce, volatility is expected to remain high in the coming weeks. The Straits Times Index lost 38 points last week and is likely to regain some ground, but the underlying market concerns persist. Investors face an uncertain environment with many unknown variables.

site_title: World economy will muddle through 2015: Allianz
summary: Allianz Global Investors' global chief investment officer Andreas Utermann predicts the world economy will "muddle through" 2015, similar to 2014. The global economy is not in great shape, but it won't go into recession. Central banks are printing money to keep interest rates low, supporting risky assets. Despite the Swiss National Bank's surprise move to abandon the euro cap, Allianz will remain fully invested. Economists expect a slowdown in China's GDP growth, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: The global economy will muddle through 2015 in a year much like 2014, said Allianz Global Investors' global chief investment officer Andreas Utermann.

site_title: Argentina to keep currency restrictions: central bank chief
summary: Argentina's Central Bank President Alejandro Vanoli stated that the country will not lift its currency restrictions, which were introduced in 2012 to prevent capital flight and protect foreign reserves. The restrictions, which limit access to foreign currency, are expected to remain in place to strengthen currency markets stability. Vanoli ruled out short-term measures, aiming to find mechanisms to manage capital that are not pro-cyclical. The decision aims to maintain control over the country's economy amidst a rise in foreign reserves over the past few months.

site_title: UOB suit: former agents' sons, daughter, nephew also named
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) is suing a Lippo Group subsidiary and seven individuals, including former real estate agents and their relatives, over alleged conspiracy to mislead the bank into offering inflated housing loans for 38 Sentosa condo units between 2011 and 2013. The defendants, including Goh Buck Lim and Aurellia Adrianus Ho, denied the allegations, claiming they had no knowledge of the matters. The bank claims that the defendants misled them into granting loans exceeding the maximum permissible amount, with 37 out of 38 units defaulting.

site_title: China's graft-busters target state-owned firms ahead of reform
summary: China's anti-corruption watchdog has intensified inspections of state-owned firms, targeting 53 strategic conglomerates where top executives hold deputy government minister ranks. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to implement its most ambitious government industry reform in nearly two decades. Chinese President Xi Jinping has vowed to crack down on corruption, with officials and business leaders being targeted. The inspections aim to curb corruption and promote "mixed ownership" by separating business from politics, with the goal of creating a more efficient state sector.

site_title: Pakistanis protesting at Charlie Hebdo burn French flags
summary: Thousands of Pakistanis protested in major cities, including Lahore, Karachi, and Islamabad, against Charlie Hebdo's printing of cartoons of the Prophet Mohammed. Workers from various parties burnt effigies of French President Francois Hollande and cartoonists, as well as French flags. The protests were largely peaceful, with over 2,000 people marching in Karachi. The demonstrations were organized by religious and secular parties, with the Jamaat-e-Islami party rallying at the mausoleum of Mohammad Ali Jinnah, the nation's founding father.

site_title: Hong Kong's embattled leader falls short on housing promises
summary: Hong Kong's leader, Leung Chun-ying, has failed to meet his promise to make housing more affordable, with home prices and public housing waiting lists increasing by a third since 2012. Despite introducing measures to curb the property market, the city's red-hot real estate market continues to thrive, with over 200,000 people living in inadequate housing. The government has pledged to build 480,000 flats in the next decade, but critics argue that the policies mainly benefit developers, and Leung's five-year term may not be enough to address the city's housing crisis.

site_title: For sale: former missile silo in New Mexico desert
summary: A former missile silo in New Mexico is up for sale for $295,000. The 10-storey, 10-hectare site was built in the 1960s to house an Atlas-F missile and can withstand a nuclear blast. The silo has been in disrepair since its decommissioning and has become a hangout for teenagers and vandals. Potential buyers have proposed various uses, including a secure farm, archive, or doomsday bunker. The site's infrastructure remains sturdy, but it requires significant work, including repairs to a fuel container.

site_title: US insurers step up discount war against Big Pharma
summary: US insurers are intensifying their efforts to extract steep price discounts from pharmaceutical companies, even for new and expensive medications. The move has expanded to niche fields, such as cancer treatment, where drugmakers previously charged high prices. Insurers like Express Scripts are seeking discounts from companies like Amgen and Regeneron, forcing them to reevaluate their pricing strategies. Industry experts predict that pharmaceutical companies will have to become more selective and focus on diseases with limited treatments to remain competitive, as the pressure from insurers is becoming more real and actionable.

images.alt_text: Large drugmakers are focusing their research on diseases that do not have adequate treatments and finding ways to differentiate their products from competitors in terms of effectiveness and convenience.

site_title: Junket operator closes some VIP rooms in Macau
summary: A Macau junket operator, David Group, is closing three of its VIP rooms due to China's anti-graft drive reducing customer traffic in the territory. The company, which serves high-end casino customers, is expanding into other Asian countries with easier transit visas, such as Manila, Vietnam, and South Korea. The move is part of a reorganization prompted by an industry downturn, with the company expecting the casino industry to recover in the fourth quarter. David Group plans to enter the Australian market by the end of the year and expand to Europe later.

images.alt_text: David Group, a Macau junket operator that serves higher-spending casino customers, is closing some rooms in the city and expanding into other Asian countries as China's anti-graft drive reduces customer traffic in the territory.

site_title: California overtakes Brazil as world's 7th largest economy amid diverse businesses
summary: California has surpassed Brazil as the world's 7th largest economy, driven by diverse businesses, rising employment, home values, and personal and corporate income. The state's GDP grew almost every measure in 2014, while Brazil's declined by 1%. California-based companies have provided investors with a 119% return since 2011, compared to 96% for the S&P 500. The state's economy has sustained momentum since 2013, with an average annual growth of 4.1%. Despite challenges, California's job growth outpaced the nation's, and its non-farm employment reached an all-time high.

site_title: Firms need better data for improved analysis: study
summary: A survey found that only 59% of leading companies in Singapore have 30-day cashflow visibility, and 19% have 60-day visibility, slightly better than the regional average. This highlights the need for improved data analysis to make informed business decisions.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Demand for hedging dollar debt picks up as yuan volatility increases
summary: Chinese companies with dollar debt are increasing their currency hedging costs as the yuan's volatility rises. The yuan unexpectedly weakened 2.4% against the dollar in 2014, leaving companies with US dollar debt or payables carrying losses. To mitigate this risk, companies are borrowing in yuan or using derivatives to lock in stable funding costs on dollar debt. The cost of hedging is high, with one-year forward contracts hovering at record highs, and some companies are taking a wait-and-see approach due to uncertainty about the yuan's future value.

site_title: Easy money, budget reform, more investment are keys to eurozone growth: French finance minister
summary: French Finance Minister Michel Sapin suggests that the eurozone can achieve growth through a more expansionary monetary policy, balanced budget reform, and increased investment. He acknowledges that growth and inflation are currently "too low" but believes this is a temporary situation. Sapin's comments come as the eurozone faces economic challenges, with growth and inflation rates below expectations. His proposed approach aims to boost growth and stimulate investment, potentially leading to a recovery in the eurozone economy.

site_title: 1MDB needs a new script
summary: Malaysia's state-backed fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) is under fire for its questionable investment moves. To placate critics, 1MDB's new CEO Arul Kanda must follow basic rules, including holding annual account reviews and providing transparency. The fund's actions have drawn comparisons to its sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional, which has turned over a new leaf after years of secrecy. 1MDB's struggles include a debt of RM40 billion, a debt rollover, and a significant operating loss, prompting calls for a new strategy and increased transparency to restore credibility.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: China's 2014 growth likely to hit 24-year low: economists
summary: China's 2014 GDP growth is projected to be the weakest in 24 years, expanding 7.3% according to a median forecast, down from 7.7% in 2013. This would be the worst full-year result since 1990. Economists predict further deceleration in 2015, with a median forecast of 7.0% growth. China's leaders have proclaimed a "new normal" of slower expansion, emphasizing economic reforms, including restructuring and financial reforms.

images.alt_text: For this year, the economists in the AFP survey see growth slowing further to a median 7.0%, as Chinese leaders proclaim a "new normal" of slower expansion and emphasise economic reforms.

site_title: Japanese working on dementia care products
summary: SoftBank Mobile is developing a humanoid robot called Pepper, designed to serve people with dementia by recognizing their emotions. The robot aims to act as a conversation partner and provide support for daily life, such as reminding patients to take medication. Pepper is set to retail for $2,235 in February and is being tested at a nursing home in Tokyo. The development of robots like Pepper is seen as a solution to Japan's rising dementia population, with SoftBank hoping to provide a higher-quality service by reducing the workload of nursing care staff.

site_title: Oil price slump puts at risk clean energy push
summary: A 60% drop in oil prices since June poses a significant threat to the development of renewable energy sources, according to experts at the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA) conference in Abu Dhabi. The trend could hinder efforts to shift to clean energy, as falling oil prices may shift the balance among various energy sources. Despite this, total world investments in renewable energies reached $264 billion in 2014, with IRENA aiming to promote sustainable use of all forms of renewable energy.

site_title: Chastened Uber CEO seeks fresh start for ride services in Europe
summary: Uber CEO Travis Kalanick promised to create 50,000 new jobs in Europe this year if cities agree to help his firm operate. Kalanick, speaking at the DLD conference in Munich, Germany, said Uber wants to establish a new partnership with EU cities. The company has faced criticism and court injunctions in several European cities for violating taxi licensing rules. Uber has expanded rapidly into over 250 cities worldwide and offers various local transportation options. Kalanick's conciliatory tone marks a shift for the company, which has been embroiled in controversy since its founding in 2010.

images.alt_text: The chief executive of controversial online ride-sharing company Uber stuck a newly conciliatory tone on Sunday, promising to create 50,000 new jobs this year across Europe in cities that are willing to reach deals to help his firm operate.

site_title: ECB ready with QE measures to battle deflation
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is poised to announce a quantitative easing (QE) program to combat deflation in the eurozone, with analysts expecting a sovereign bond purchase program to be unveiled at its policy meeting on January 22. The move comes after area-wide inflation turned negative in December, with the ECB having few other options to counter the risk of deflation. Despite criticism from the German Bundesbank, many economists believe QE can work and boost the economy, with some predicting a program worth at least €500 billion.

site_title: Manhunts, death threats as Europe on high terror alert
summary: Europe is on high alert as a suspected mastermind of a jihadist cell in Belgium remains at large. Abdelhamid Abaaoud is considered the brains behind the cell that plotted to kill Belgian police. Tensions are heightened with authorities blocking anti-Islamist rallies in Germany and France, and a French court preventing a rally by anti-Islamist groups in Paris. Meanwhile, EU foreign ministers will meet in Brussels to discuss ways to boost cooperation to combat terrorism. The meeting comes after a series of attacks in Europe, including the Charlie Hebdo magazine attack that left 17 people dead.

images.alt_text: Anti-Pegida demonstrators perform a broom-dance to protest against a rally by the mounting right-wing populist movement Pegida (Patriotic Europeans Against the Islamisation of the Occident) in Dresden, eastern Germany on Jan 5, 2015.

site_title: Superyachts bring new life to sleepy old French shipbuilding port
summary: La Ciotat, a French port, is experiencing a resurgence in its economy thanks to its growing superyacht repair industry. The town, once a major shipbuilding center, has seen a significant increase in yacht maintenance and refitting, with 220 yachts lifted onto the docks last year. The port's modernization, including an underwater elevator and a new crane, has attracted major companies like Monaco Marine and Compositeworks, creating jobs and boosting local revenue. The industry's growth has helped the town recover from years of decline, with many locals now employed in the sector, and the city's mayor crediting the shipyards for saving the city's economy.

site_title: Argentina's 'King of Soy' abdicates in favour of biotechnology
summary: Argentina's 'King of Soy' company, Los Grobo, has abdicated its title due to unprofitable farming conditions. High inflation, trade restrictions, and taxes have led to a significant reduction in farmed areas. The company now favors biotechnology as the future of farming, citing the industry's potential for higher profitability. Gustavo Grobocopatel, company president, stated that farming in Argentina has become "subsistence farming" due to the economic challenges.

site_title: Soya bean market turns focus from supply to demand
summary: The US soya bean market is shifting its focus from supplies to demand due to a record pace of exports, with China canceling its first large US soya bean export sale of the season. The US Department of Agriculture's January final crop production summary highlighted the importance of exports in determining the size of the US soya bean stockpile. As shipments to China increase from South America, US exporters will tap other markets, including Europe and Japan, to offload the record US crop, which is expected to remain competitive due to low prices and ocean freight costs.

site_title: Alibaba opens China consumer door to US retailers
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd plans to expand its US business by offering American retailers new ways to sell to China's growing middle class. The company is using Alipay, its dominant Chinese electronic payment system, to connect US retailers with Chinese consumers. Alibaba is also working with US startups and retail services providers to handle Chinese sales, payment, and shipping. The company aims to raise awareness among US businesses of its global business-to-business wholesale platform, Alibaba.com, and reduce counterfeit goods. Alibaba's efforts are part of a conservative strategy to gain goodwill and prepare for long-term growth in the US market.

site_title: Amazon's tax deal with Luxembourg may have broken rules
summary: The European Union's antitrust office has released a preliminary finding that Amazon's tax deal with Luxembourg may have enabled the company to underpay its taxes for a decade or more, potentially breaking EU competition rules. This is part of a wider investigation into multinational companies, including Apple and Starbucks, that have sharply cut their tax bills. The EU will now conduct a full investigation before making a final decision on the matter.

site_title: Passengers behind airline investors in gaining from oil slump
summary: US airline investors are expected to reap significant benefits from the decline in fuel costs, which contributed to record profits for the industry in 2014. Despite falling fuel prices, airlines are unlikely to reduce ticket prices, instead using the savings to reward shareholders and pay off debt. Analysts predict that airlines will prioritize debt reduction and share buybacks over passing on the savings to consumers, with some expecting fares to only decrease in areas with increased competition.

site_title: BOJ facing perilous policy decision over inflation target
summary: The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) Policy Board is set to decide on a policy adjustment amid severe turbulence in global financial markets, including the European Central Bank's (ECB) potential quantitative easing program. The BOJ faces a dilemma, with options limited and a risk of undermining credibility if it fails to meet its 2% inflation target. A decision to extend the deadline or implement further easing could signal competitive devaluation, while inaction could be seen as a sign of giving up on the target. The outcome will have significant implications for the Japanese economy and markets.

site_title: Dubai's real estate markets peaking: JLL
summary: Dubai's residential real estate and hotel markets are peaking due to lower oil prices, according to a report by JLL. Despite this, strong government spending and the emirate's diversified economy are expected to prevent a sharp pull-back. In 2014, the residential market saw a 15% increase in rents and a 20% rise in selling prices, but activity cooled in the fourth quarter. A peak is expected, but a significant downturn is not anticipated.

site_title: Bjork to play New York classical halls for new album
summary: Icelandic singer Bjork plans a series of intimate concerts at New York classical halls in March to promote her new album, Vulnicura, released in March. The album, which explores nature themes, will be her first in four years. Bjork will also perform at the Governors Ball festival in June. The concerts will take place at Carnegie Hall and New York City Center. Bjork, 50, has collaborated with producer Arca for the album.

site_title: Dealing with smaller board lot sizes
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reduced its minimum trading unit, also known as a standard board lot, from 1,000 shares to 100 shares. This change aims to increase accessibility for retail investors to certain high-priced stocks, particularly local banks, and allows for lower initial investment for testing stock-picking ideas. The adjustment is seen as a positive move for investors looking to diversify and practice their skills without committing significant funds.

site_title: Taking heart
summary: Casio Singapore is launching the "Casio Cares" Initiative, lending graphing calculators to students from low-income families. The initiative aims to provide equal access to academic tools for students regardless of financial background. Additionally, charity events will be held in January, including an art, book, and CD auction and a volunteer experience event, to support HIV-positive and AIDS victims in Myanmar and other social causes.

site_title: Swiss lose battle in currency war that could spread
summary: Switzerland's central bank abandoned the franc's exchange rate floor, ending its foray into the global currency war. This move left markets shell-shocked, but the currency war is far from over. Analysts expect major shifts in monetary policy to continue, with other countries taking the front lines. The move may have implications for the global economy, but the full impact remains to be seen.

site_title: Older job-seekers find ways to avoid bias
summary: Older job-seekers are finding ways to avoid age bias in the job market by exploring non-traditional employment options, such as non-profits, startups, and educational programs. Many employers assume older workers are looking for short-term jobs or are less productive, but research shows this is not always the case. To overcome these biases, older workers can demonstrate technology comfort, highlight transferable skills, and network through personal connections. Career coaching and exploring consulting and contract work can also be effective strategies for finding employment.

site_title: Obama's budget to target large financial institutions, wealthy
summary: US President Barack Obama plans to propose a $320 billion tax increase in his State of the Union address, targeting wealthy individuals and large financial institutions to fund new programs for lower- and middle-income families. The proposal includes raising capital gains and dividend tax rates to 28%, imposing a fee on big financial institutions, and broadening inherited money subject to taxes. The plan aims to boost taxes on the nation's wealthy households and help lower- and middle-class families, with 99% of the impact falling on the top 1% of earners.

site_title: Getty Images rides digital photography wave
summary: Getty Images has opened its repository of images for non-commercial use via an embedded tool, allowing individuals to share the company's content on social media and blogs without infringing on copyright. The move aims to provide a simple and legal way to utilize content while respecting creators' rights. With over 55 million images available, the embed capability supports HTML posting and is accessible on major social platforms. This shift is seen as an opportunity for Getty Images, which has over 1.5 million customers in 185 countries, with revenue nearing US$1 billion.

images.alt_text: Ms Shimamoto thinks that citizen photography presents a great opportunity for Getty Images.

site_title: Swiss franc reigns supreme, makes historic rally
summary: The Swiss National Bank abandoned the euro cap, driving a historic rally in the Swiss franc, which surged 21% to 99.41 centimes per euro, its strongest since the euro's 1999 debut. The yen also rallied, while the euro plummeted 2.3% to US$1.1567, its biggest weekly loss since July 2012. Oil prices fell to an almost six-year low, contributing to declines in commodity currencies like the Russian rouble and Canada's dollar. Market volatility jumped to a one-year high, with the JPMorgan Chase & Co's index of global currency volatility rising to 11.68%.

site_title: 2014 a slow year for super fast, ultra-luxury cars
summary: 2014 saw a 70% decline in registration numbers for ultra-luxury limousines and super sports cars in Singapore, with some dealers fearing this trend could continue unless policy changes or economic growth occur. The slow year may be attributed to loan and property curbs, which could make 2015 another quiet year for these high-end vehicles.

site_title: Changi Airport ranked fourth globally for on-time performance
summary: Changi Airport ranked fourth globally for on-time performance among large airports in 2014, with an average on-time performance of 85.3%. Singapore Airlines ranked in the top 10 Asia-Pacific carriers for on-time performance, coming in tenth with 83.7%. The OAG Punctuality League, based on 43.5 million flight records, attributed the challenges faced by top airports to congestion and disruptions. No Chinese airports made it to the top 20, with Beijing coming in at No 28.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Slump in industrial raw materials hits home
summary: A slump in industrial raw materials has hit home, with prices falling due to a weaker global economy, excess supplies, and the implosion of a speculative commodity bubble. Most commodity prices peaked in 2011, fueled by quantitative easing and speculative purchases by investment banks and hedge funds. As emerging markets slowed and Europe and Japan remained in recession, prices slumped, and demand from factories and consumers failed to match the glut in commodities. Copper prices have fallen by 43% since 2011, while iron ore, cotton, and rubber quotes have collapsed by over 60%. Economists disagree on the impact, with some seeing the decline as "good deflation" and others warning of job losses and bankruptcies.

site_title: CIOs' changing role: from controlling to organising
summary: CIOs' roles are shifting from controlling technology to organizing and adapting to a more employee-led approach in the digital age. With the rise of mobile devices and Internet-based programs, companies are allowing employees to experiment with new technologies, while CIOs track usage and consider it in purchasing decisions. This change requires CIOs to be more responsive, innovative, and secure, as workers have more options and choices. According to Forrester Research, 18% of US technology purchases will be initiated by employees outside of the IT group by 2015, up from 13% in 2009.

site_title: Blackstone to buy property globally this year
summary: Blackstone Group LP plans to be an active buyer of global property assets in 2015, with a focus on the US and Europe. The company is raising a global property fund expected to reach $13 billion and will continue to invest in Europe, particularly in Italy and southern countries, as the market recovers. Despite exiting high-profile US investments, Blackstone sees the US market as "somewhere in between" its 2007 peak, with prices surpassing those of 2007.

site_title: PepsiCo reaches truce with billionaire investor Nelson Peltz
summary: PepsiCo has reached a truce with billionaire investor Nelson Peltz's Trian Fund Management after nearly two years of public disagreements. The company will add William Johnson, former CEO of HJ Heinz, to its board as an emissary for Trian, likely ending a campaign to break up PepsiCo's historic beverages business. The settlement comes after Trian won public support from a California public pension fund and PepsiCo's third-quarter profit surpassed analysts' expectations, bolstering the company's business model. The truce suggests a détente between Trian and PepsiCo's chairman and CEO Indra Nooyi.

site_title: Sri Lanka's new govt to review Chinese infrastructure projects
summary: Sri Lanka's new government, led by President Maithripala Sirisena, will review Chinese infrastructure projects awarded under the previous administration, citing concerns over costs and land ownership. The review aims to show the true cost of projects and prevent over-pricing. The move is expected to please Indian and Western powers concerned about China's access in the island state. The government will consider legal action against those involved in over-priced projects, and will work on a project-by-project basis to discuss issues with China.

site_title: Oil collapses again in volatile week
summary: Oil prices plummeted to six-year lows in a volatile week, influenced by oversupply worries and a strong US dollar. The International Energy Agency (IEA) reported signs that the market may turn, while the European Central Bank's meeting next week is expected to impact commodities. Gold and silver prices rose, while copper and platinum declined, with the World Bank cutting its global economic forecasts.

site_title: BP faces maximum US$13.7b fine after spill-size decision
summary: A US judge has ruled that BP's 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill was the result of gross negligence, but not recklessness, by the company's exploration unit. The court rejected the government's estimate of 4.2 million barrels of oil spilled, instead ruling that 3.2 million barrels were dumped into the Gulf. The reduced estimate decreases the potential maximum fine from $18 billion to $13.7 billion, the largest US pollution penalty. The trial will proceed next week to determine the amount of fines, with BP facing claims from private parties, state governments, and other defendants.

images.alt_text: BP has set aside US$3.5 billion to cover the pollution fines. The London-based oil company has already spent more than US$28 billion in spill response, clean-up and claims.

site_title: Keppel Land to buy 4.6 ha site in Jakarta
summary: Keppel Land has signed a conditional agreement to acquire a 4.6-hectare site in West Jakarta, Indonesia, for 381.9 billion rupiah (S$40.2 million). The development, set to launch in phases starting 2017, will feature over 4,000 units, including studio apartments and three-bedroom units, targeting middle-income buyers. Located near shopping centers and schools, the project is part of Keppel Land's expansion plans in Indonesia, a key growth market for the company.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
Artist’'s impression of Keppel Land’s 99-year leasehold project, The Highline Residences, in Kim Tian Road.

site_title: Goldman vindicated in bet on commodities as rivals shy away
summary: Goldman Sachs has reported a strong commodities trading performance, with its rivals pulling back from the market. Despite a rough quarter in its fixed-income trading business, Goldman's commodities trading is highlighted as a bright spot by its CFO. The bank's decision to stick with commodities trading has been vindicated, with shares rising after President Trump announced fresh tariffs on Canada and other countries. This move has led to a bearish outlook for oil prices.

site_title: Shenzhen home prices rebound as rate cuts lift demand
summary: Shenzhen home prices rebounded in December, rising 1.2% from November, marking the first increase in four months. The central bank's interest rate cut boosted demand, and housing sales in major cities rebounded. Nationwide home sales may see the first annual increase in 12 months if the momentum is maintained. However, prices in other cities, such as Beijing and Guangzhou, fell, and the overall market trend is expected to stabilize, with no significant price gains in most cities.

site_title: China's new home prices fall 4.3% in Dec
summary: China's new home prices fell 4.3% in December for the fourth straight month, foreshadowing weak economic growth data expected later in the week. The slowdown in growth is expected to slow to 7.2% in the fourth quarter, the weakest since the 2009 financial crisis. Falling property prices may pressure policymakers to intervene, potentially cutting interest rates or lowering reserve requirements. Despite a 9% increase in property sales volumes in December, experts warn that the property market's oversupply fundamentals remain unchanged, and the slowdown will continue to drag on the economy in 2015.

site_title: Spotlight on Denmark after SNB's shock move on euro cap
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) removed its euro cap, causing investors to look to Denmark, which pegs the krone to the euro. Danske Bank reports receiving requests from hedge funds and offshore investors to bet on Denmark's euro peg. However, Danske advises clients to prepare for unprecedented negative interest rates. Despite this, Denmark is unlikely to abandon its euro peg.

site_title: S'pore empty homes may climb to highest since 1998
summary: Singapore's property market is experiencing a shift, with increasing apartment vacancies putting pressure on landlords and giving tenants more negotiating power. The vacancy rate rose to 7.1% in the third quarter, the highest since 2006, and is expected to rise further due to more new apartments being completed. Landlords facing mortgage difficulties are defaulting on their loans, with 159 apartments auctioned off last year, a fivefold increase from 2013. Experts predict that rents could fall another 10% this year, with some predicting the vacancy rate could reach 10% by the end of 2015.

site_title: A reasonable man who can discuss different ideas
summary: Alexis Tsipras, leader of the left-wing Syriza Party in Greece, is poised to become the country's prime minister after the upcoming election. Tsipras has softened his rhetoric, abandoning the "left-wing firebrand" image he once had, and is now emphasizing negotiation and creating a "modern European state." He has promised to restore basic services, such as electricity and food stamps, and to tackle corruption. Tsipras expects Europe, particularly Germany, to make concessions on Greece's crushing debt, and has warned that default would be in everyone's best interest.

site_title: Virtual shipyard
summary: London's Heathrow airport is considering increasing fees for its £10 billion upgrade project, amid rising costs and concerns about its financial sustainability. Meanwhile, Tesla has entered the Indian market with a launch event in Mumbai, marking the company's formal entry into the country. Additionally, FedEx has partnered with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas, and Delta Air Lines has offered an upbeat outlook on travel demand, lifting its shares.

site_title: Jokowi's political outsider sheen losing its lustre for Indonesians
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo's reputation as a clean and outsider leader is being challenged by his recent political appointments, including a police general facing corruption allegations. Widodo's administration has been criticized for its handling of issues such as airline safety and fuel subsidies, which have sparked controversy. Despite his efforts to push through ambitious social programs, Widodo's government has been marred by allegations of corruption and cronyism, casting doubt on his ability to deliver a "squeaky-clean" government. Analysts say Widodo's most pressing challenge is managing his own coalition, which has been weakened by internal divisions.

site_title: Dubai residential, hotel real estate markets peaking
summary: Dubai's residential real estate and hotel markets are peaking due to lower oil prices, but a sharp pull-back is not expected due to strong government spending and the emirate's diversified economy. The residential market surged in 2014, with rents up 15% and selling prices up 20%, but cooled in the fourth quarter. The consultancy JLL predicts the residential sector will remain subdued over the next 12 months, with a 30% drop in residential transactions and 14% fall in their value last year.

site_title: New fund to promote local music heritage
summary: A new fund, the Sing50 Fund, was launched in Singapore to preserve and promote local music heritage. The initial sum of S$348,000 will be used to buy Steinway-designed Lang Lang pianos for schools and pay for choral trainers to teach students popular Singapore songs. The fund aims to foster knowledge and passion for Singapore music, with the Sing50 mega-concert scheduled for August 7 featuring popular singers and a 1,000-member choir. The event is expected to draw 50,000 people and raise awareness and appreciation for Singapore's musical heritage.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Significant bounce may ensue in US market
summary: US stock indexes started the year with a rally, driven by expectations of a new round of quantitative easing and positive earnings reports. Investors remain cautious due to the oil bust and dollar boom, but lowered expectations may lead to surprise earnings growth. Analysts at Goldman Sachs predict a 7% year-over-year earnings growth for the S&P 500, with fourth-quarter earnings per share expected to surprise by 3%. The market's performance may indicate a significant bounce, despite ongoing uncertainty and tariff concerns.

site_title: Reforms, foreign investment key to Tunisia's success
summary: Tunisia, a rare regional success story four years after the Arab Spring, aims to deepen reforms and attract foreign investment to boost its economy. Despite political stability and a surging stock market, the country faces challenges such as a current account deficit and a weak banking sector. Investors are cautiously optimistic, with some predicting a positive outlook for the next two to three months. Tunisia has signed a two-year IMF deal and is set to form a government, with ratings agency Fitch noting positive comments about the country's potential.

site_title: When stocks are more affordable, but not cheaper
summary: Stocks can be considered affordable but not cheap based on valuation multiples and earnings prospects, not board lot sizes. A stock's true value is determined by its multiples and earnings, not its absolute share price. UOB's share price increased from S$8,200 in 2009 to S$2,000 in 2015, but its valuation multiple expanded from 6.6 to 12 times earnings. Investors should consider multiple expansion, mean reversion, and company-specific factors when evaluating a stock's affordability. A stock may be considered cheap if its price is below book value or earnings multiples, but this can change if earnings growth stalls or fundamental factors change.

site_title: The Six Million Dollar Man will soon be fact, not fiction
summary: Apple's entry into the healthcare industry with HealthKit and the Apple Watch is poised to transform medicine, but it's not the only player in this space. Advances in MEMS sensors, microfluidics, and nanobiophysics are enabling comprehensive, inexpensive diagnostics, while Artificial Intelligence-based systems will monitor patients 24/7. The convergence of electronic medical records, smartphone data, and AI will revolutionize healthcare, making it possible to diagnose diseases more accurately and prevent illnesses. Companies like Google, IBM, and start-ups are racing to develop innovative technologies, including wearable devices, genome analysis, and synthetic biology, to transform the pharmaceutical industry and extend human lifespan.

site_title: Intel US$4.21b mobile loss would have sunk most rivals
summary: Intel Corp. reported an operating loss of $4.21 billion in its mobile division for 2014, a loss that would erase profits at most rivals. The company generated negative sales in the fourth quarter, instead paying customers to use its chips to build market presence. Despite this, Intel's server business remained profitable, with an operating profit of $7.28 billion. The company plans to reduce costs at its mobile unit by $800 million in 2015 to improve profitability.

site_title: Taiwan's embattled ruling party looks to new leader to turn tide
summary: Taiwan's Beijing-friendly ruling party, the Kuomintang (KMT), is set to appoint a new leader, Eric Chu, in an effort to reverse its fortunes after its worst-ever local election defeat. The election, seen as a public backlash over warming ties with China, led to President Ma Ying-jeou's resignation. Chu, a 53-year-old former accounting professor, is expected to take the reins Monday, promising to strike a balance between building relations with China and appeasing a frustrated electorate. His appointment is seen as a temporary fix, with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) widely tipped to win the presidency in 2016.

site_title: Brazil, Netherlands outraged as Indonesia executes their citizens
summary: Brazil and the Netherlands have recalled their ambassadors from Indonesia after the country executed two of their citizens and four other foreign nationals by firing squad, in defiance of international pleas. The executions, carried out under new President Joko Widodo, were the first under his presidency and have sparked outrage from rights activists and governments worldwide. Brazil's President Dilma Roussef and the Netherlands' Foreign Minister Bert Koenders have expressed "distress and outrage" over the executions, and have called for improved relations between their countries and Indonesia.

site_title: Oil slump slashes Saudi Basic Industries Q4 profit
summary: Saudi Basic Industries Corp (SABIC), the world's largest petrochemicals group, reported a 29% decline in Q4 net income to $1.16 billion due to the slump in global oil prices, which more than halved since June. This was below analysts' forecasts of $1.47 billion. Lower oil prices hurt SABIC's earnings, but were partially offset by lower feedstock prices. The company's results are closely tied to global economic growth, as its products are used in construction, agriculture, industry, and consumer goods.

site_title: GE finances first A350 powered by rival Rolls-Royce
summary: GE finances first A350 powered by rival Rolls-Royce, a rare move that highlights the complexities of the highly concentrated aviation industry. The deal involves GE's aircraft leasing arm Gecas buying the aircraft from Qatar Airways, which is powered by Rolls-Royce engines, and then renting it back. This financing arrangement completes a series of twists in the history of Airbus's newest jet and underscores the need for diversification in the industry.

site_title: Google in talks to buy mobile-payments company Softcard
summary: Google is in talks to acquire mobile-payments company Softcard, valued below $100 million, to pair with US wireless carriers and compete with Apple's Apple Pay service. Softcard is jointly owned by AT&T, Verizon, and T-Mobile. The deal aims to enhance Google's mobile payment capabilities.

site_title: Two die of bird flu in China
summary: Two people in China's Fujian province have died from the H7N9 strain of bird flu, with 15 confirmed cases reported since the start of 2015. Another human infection was reported in the adjacent province of Jiangxi, and cases have been reported in Shanghai and Zhejiang province this winter. The deaths bring the total number of H7N9-related fatalities in China to at least 10.

site_title: More buys than sells among directors
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Among directors, there were more buys than sells in Singapore from January 12 to 16, with 39 purchases worth $9.3 million and 2 disposals worth $5.06 million. Notable buys included SingHaiyi Group's first buyback since 2002 and insider buys in KOP Limited, Sapphire Corporation, and IEV Holdings. Ezra Holdings saw a significant buyback by independent director Ngo Get Ping, who increased his holdings by 96%. Meanwhile, fund managers sold shares in Petra Foods, KrisEnergy, and Raffles Medical Group. The buying activity was largely driven by a sharp drop in the share prices of these companies.

site_title: CEOs' Budget wish-list
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The article discusses various news topics, including the upcoming 2015 Singapore Budget, set for February 23. In a separate section, CEOs share their budget wish-lists, but the article does not provide specific details. Other news includes Malaysia seizing assets worth RM3 billion, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and the UK economy shrinking for the second month. Additionally, the article covers economic news from around the world, including South Korea's trade talks and Malaysia's industrial production rising 0.3% in May.

images.alt_text: Adam Judd

site_title: US airfares seen staying high
summary: US airline profits reached record levels in 2014 due to falling fuel bills, with investors set to reap the benefits. However, consumers are unlikely to see lower ticket prices, with airlines instead choosing to reward shareholders. Analysts say there's "no reason" to trim prices as demand for travel remains high and planes are sold out. The industry is expected to continue to thrive, with airlines using the windfall to boost profits.

site_title: Twitter hackers take over accounts of New York Post, UPI
summary: Hackers took over Twitter accounts of the New York Post and United Press International, posting fake messages, including false reports of a US-China war and a Bank of America CEO's statement about savings accounts. The tweets were later deleted, with the Post stating its account was briefly hacked. This incident is part of a trend of media organizations having their Twitter feeds hacked in recent years, with the Pentagon's Central Command also falling victim to a hacking incident this week.

site_title: Barclays loses tens of millions over Swiss franc move
summary: British bank Barclays has lost "tens of millions" of dollars after Switzerland's central bank scrapped its currency ceiling against the euro, a move that led to a sharp rise in the franc. Deutsche Bank also reportedly lost around $150 million. The move led to a decline in Swiss shares and triggered insolvency at currency broker Alpari UK. The Swiss central bank's decision has sparked criticism at home and abroad, with shares in other foreign-exchange brokers also being affected.

site_title: At Singapore printers' request, Economist pulls Charlie cartoon
summary: The Economist has removed a picture of the Charlie Hebdo magazine cover from its Singapore-printed edition due to objections from the printers, citing concerns over potential backlash. The magazine had featured a cartoon of the Prophet Mohammad, which some Muslims deemed offensive and provocative. The decision comes after Islamist gunmen killed 12 people at Charlie Hebdo's Paris office in January.

site_title: Middle class decline looms over final years of Obama presidency
summary: US President Barack Obama's final two years in office are marked by a decline of the middle class, a key promise he made since taking office in 2009. Despite stabilizing the economy and adding jobs, middle-class families have seen decreased earnings and lower net worth. A Reuters analysis shows that jobs have been added at the top and bottom of the wage scale, but shed in the middle. Obama's administration is expected to propose measures to address the issue, but the trend suggests entrenched economic inequality may define his legacy.

images.alt_text: The revival of middle-class jobs has been one of Mr Obama's mantras since he took office in 2009 fighting the worst economic crisis in generations.

site_title: Bangladesh shuts down messaging services to quell violence
summary: Bangladesh's telecom authorities shut down Viber and Tango messaging services to quell violence in the country, where protests against the government have turned increasingly violent, resulting in at least 25 deaths. The shutdown aims to prevent protesters from exchanging information. The protests, led by the Bangladesh Nationalist Party, have disrupted transport services and shipments, affecting the country's biggest export, garments. The government has deployed thousands of police and paramilitaries to crack down on protesters, while international bodies, including the US, Britain, and EU, have expressed concern over the crisis.

site_title: Global woes pose main threat to US economy: Federal Reserve official
summary: A top Federal Reserve official, John Williams, stated that global weakness poses the main threat to the US economy's robust growth, potentially delaying interest rate increases until late 2015. Despite mixed economic data, including a 2.5-3% forecast for US growth, Williams expressed no urgency to raise interest rates, citing a need to avoid getting behind the curve. Consumer prices declined in December, and inflation remains below the Fed's 2% goal, leading to a patient approach to monetary policy.

site_title: Brazil, Netherlands recall Indonesia ambassadors after executions
summary: Brazil and the Netherlands have recalled their ambassadors in Indonesia after the country executed six prisoners for drug offenses, including a Brazilian and a Dutch citizen. The executions, carried out by firing squad, were the first under President Joko Widodo. The Netherlands condemned the execution of its citizen, Ang Kiem Soei, as a "cruel and inhuman punishment." The executions have strained bilateral relations between Brazil and Indonesia, with Brazil describing the use of the death penalty as "affecting severely the relationship of our countries."

site_title: Ex-Sri Lanka leader's brother accused of killing editor
summary: Sri Lankan authorities are investigating a claim that former defence secretary Gotabhaya Rajapakse ordered the assassination of Lasantha Wickrematunga, a high-profile newspaper editor, in 2009. The allegations, made by ex-public relations minister Mervyn Silva, claim Rajapakse ran a "death squad" and was responsible for Wickrematunga's murder, as well as three other killings. The case was previously unsolved, but the new complaint reopens it amid widespread allegations of corruption and human rights abuses during Rajapakse's administration.

site_title: Facebook hiring spree hints at ambitions in virtual reality and beyond
summary: Facebook is hiring over 1,200 new employees, a 14% increase, as the company expands into new areas such as virtual reality with Oculus Rift and satellite technology. The company aims to grow its workforce to support its business and users, with roles including managers, software engineers, and sales people. Facebook's ambitious investments are driven by CEO Mark Zuckerberg's vision for the company's future, with analysts predicting the company's annual revenue could reach $30 billion in a few years. The hiring spree is seen as a key factor in Facebook's ability to remain competitive in the tech industry.

site_title: Switzerland: Stock exchange closes down 5.96% on soaring franc
summary: Switzerland's stock exchange closed down 5.96% on Friday, following the central bank's decision to scrap its three-year bid to hold down the value of the franc. The main SMI index fell to 7,899.59 points. This move was a surprise to markets, leading to a significant drop in stocks.

site_title: Fitch lowers Greece credit outlook to 'negative'
summary: Fitch lowers Greece's credit outlook to 'negative' due to rising political uncertainty, citing potential delay in reopening market access and a possible renegotiation of its bailout with the "troika". The agency keeps the country's credit rating unchanged at 'B', indicating highly speculative. A snap general election on January 25 has increased uncertainty, with a Syriza victory raising concerns over financing difficulties and a return to recession. Fitch forecasts 0.5% GDP growth in 2014 and 1.5% in 2015.

site_title: Original spin on high-style dining
summary: Executive chef Johnston Teo's debut restaurant, Sorrel, offers an original take on "approachable fine dining" in Singapore. The restaurant, which combines techniques from Tippling Club and Jaan, features a cryptic menu with surprising yet coherent flavor combinations. Standout dishes include pan-seared scallop and foie gras, a seared octopus tentacle, and a roast langoustine. While some courses are slightly over-ambitious, the restaurant's attention to detail and originality shine through. With prices ranging from $45 to $118, Sorrel is poised to be one of the brightest sparks in Singapore's F&B scene this year.

site_title: US tells Bangladesh to do more on factory safety
summary: The US has told Bangladesh it needs to improve worker safety and rights in its apparel sector before trade benefits can be restored. Nearly two years after a factory collapse killed 1,100 workers, the US Trade Representative said over 2,000 factories have been inspected, but "further progress is needed" to address concerns. The US is urging the Bangladesh government to accelerate efforts to ensure worker rights and address reports of harassment against labor activists. The country's special trade benefits were removed in 2013 after the Rana Plaza disaster.

site_title: Moody's cuts Russia debt rating one notch
summary: Moody's has cut Russia's credit rating to Baa3, one step above junk level, citing a severe oil price shock and restricted international market access due to sanctions. The agency forecasts a 5.5% contraction in Russia's economy this year and a 3.0% contraction in 2016, leading to virtually zero real growth over the next decade. Moody's also warned of a risk of politically motivated actions raising risks to creditors due to current geopolitical tensions, and is embarking on another review that could lead to further rating cuts.

site_title: Pope says Mass for huge Manila crowd
summary: Pope Francis celebrated a massive open-air Mass in Manila, Philippines, attended by an estimated 4-6 million people, the largest crowd in the city. The event, held on the feast of the infant Jesus, saw the Pope appeal to the world to "learn how to cry" over the plight of poor, hungry, homeless, and abused children. In his homily, he urged Filipinos to shun social structures perpetuating poverty and corruption, and criticized the government's population control efforts. The Pope's visit marked the end of his week-long trip to Asia.

site_title: Infrastructure sales to drive Aussie bonds
summary: Australia's plan to privatize A$130 billion worth of state assets is expected to boost its A$388 billion corporate bond market and reduce the central bank's concern over lenders' reliance on mortgages. Investment bankers target big Asian and Canadian investors, positioning the asset sales as a major driver for the market this year.

site_title: Indonesia executes six drug convicts, including foreigners
summary: Indonesia executed six people convicted of drug offenses, including five foreigners, on Sunday, marking the country's first executions under President Joko Widodo. The executed individuals were from Brazil, the Netherlands, Vietnam, Malawi, and Nigeria. The move was widely condemned by Amnesty International as "seriously regressive". The executions took place by firing squad, with two women among those executed.

site_title: Keppel Land signs agreement to acquire 4.6 ha site in Indonesia for 381.9 billion rupiah
summary: Keppel Land signs a conditional agreement to acquire a 4.6 hectare site in West Jakarta, Indonesia, for 381.9 billion Indonesian Rupiah (S$40.2 million). The company plans to develop a high-rise condominium with ancillary shophouses and shop units, launching it in phases starting 2017. The development will feature over 4,000 apartment units targeting middle-income buyers. Keppel Land aims to strengthen its presence in Indonesia's growing real estate market, driven by the country's steady economic growth and demand for affordable homes.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Swiss franc surge rocks currency brokers, burns banks
summary: A surprise surge in the Swiss franc left currency brokers and banks worldwide reeling, with at least two brokers declaring insolvency and others warning of heavy losses. The Swiss central bank scrapped its bid to stop the franc from strengthening, causing a 30% surge in minutes, later settling at a 15% gain against the euro.

site_title: Taiwan man dies after Internet gaming binge: report
summary: A 32-year-old Taiwanese man died after a three-day gaming binge at an internet cafe in Kaohsiung city. He was found slumped and not breathing, and was pronounced dead at the hospital with cardiac failure. This is the second such case this year, following the death of a 38-year-old man at an internet cafe in New Taipei City in January. Other patrons continued playing despite cordoning off the table for investigators, and the cause of death was attributed to prolonged computer gaming.

site_title: Argentina inflation hits 23.9%, second after Venezuela
summary: Argentina's inflation reached 23.9% in 2014, the second highest in South America after Venezuela, according to official statistics. The figure is lower than opposition estimates of 38.5%. Argentina's economy has slowed down, marked by its second debt default in 13 years, amid concerns about inflation and economic stability.

site_title: Greece arrests four over 'terror' plot
summary: Greece has arrested four individuals in connection with a foiled Islamist "terrorist" plot. The suspected mastermind, Abdelhamid Abaaoud, a 27-year-old Belgian of Moroccan descent, is believed to be among those detained. Belgian troops have been deployed to patrol the streets following the dismantling of an alleged terrorist cell in Belgium. The Greek authorities are working with the Belgian authorities to formally identify the suspects, requiring digital fingerprints and DNA samples to be sent. The plot's details and the extent of the arrests are currently being confirmed.

images.alt_text: Belgium deployed troops to patrol its streets after smashing an Islamist "terrorist" cell that allegedly planned to kill police officers, as Greece arrested four people in connection with the foiled plot.

site_title: ECB poised to pull QE trigger on deflation
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is poised to announce a quantitative easing (QE) program to combat deflation in the eurozone, with analysts predicting a sovereign bond purchase program. The ECB has been struggling to combat negative inflation, which fell 0.2% in December, and has few options left. While some critics, such as the German Bundesbank, oppose QE, others, including economists at Berenberg and UniCredit, believe it could help stimulate growth. The ECB is expected to make a decision on January 22, with some predicting a program of at least €500 billion in government debt.
