summary: AF Global, a joint venture firm of Aspial Corporation and Fragrance Group, has increased its stake in LCD Global Investments to 29.9% through a series of transactions. AF Global had previously made a voluntary conditional cash offer for LCD Global at 33 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: US cities in architectural arms race to the sky
summary: US cities are engaging in an architectural arms race to create iconic structures, with projects such as a 100-story observation tower, a 1,000-foot hairpin-shaped tower, and a 690-foot Ferris wheel. Cities like Miami, Camden, and Phoenix are competing to become world-class destinations, with some investing taxpayer funds to make their projects a reality. The trend is driven by urban renewal, rising real estate values, and an influx of residents, with many hoping to attract tourists and boost local economies.

site_title: Rehiring change: SIA to work with MOM
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will work with the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) to rehire pilots past retirement age by providing assistance to find alternative employment. SIA aims to cease offering re-employment contracts for captains. This move is part of the airline's rehiring change plan.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani
About 90 of SIA's 2,100 pilots will be hit by the move not to rehire those aged 62 and up

site_title: Softbank, others invest 70 billion yen in taxi hailing app
summary: SoftBank and other firms, including Alibaba, have invested approximately 70 billion yen (S$795 million) in Kuaidi Dache, a Chinese taxi hailing app. The investment will be used to expand services and market share. SoftBank's vice chairman, Nikesh Arora, stated that Kuaidi is a leading player in the Chinese mobile taxi booking industry, expected to see further growth. The investment comes as China's transport ministry regulates the sector, and analysts see rides-on-demand as a key link in domestic logistics.

images.alt_text: An advertisement of Kuaidi Dache is seen on the exterior of a building in Beijing. It is one of two local apps that together control around 90 per cent of the China online taxi hailing market.

site_title: Singapore retail sales leap 6.5% in November, thanks to car sales
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 6.5% in November 2014, driven by a surge in car sales, but month-on-month momentum weakened for a second straight month. Excluding motor vehicle sales, retail sales would have fallen 0.4% in November. The food and beverage sector saw a 2% year-on-year increase, but month-on-month momentum was maintained. Experts note that a potential rise in real incomes in 2015 may boost spending, but factors such as modest tourist spending and property market slowdown could temper this effect.

site_title: Fitch sees Singapore home prices dipping 3% each in 2015, 2016
summary: Fitch Ratings predicts Singapore home prices will decline by 3% annually from 2015 to 2016, with mortgage rates increasing to around 2% due to abundant liquidity. Delinquency rates for local banks are expected to rise by 0.3 percentage points, but remain "comfortably low" due to Singapore's strong labor market and debt burdens. Fitch attributes the property market's resilience to strict lending standards and macro-prudential policies aimed at cooling the market.

images.alt_text: FITCH Ratings on Thursday said that Singapore property prices will likely continue to fall in 2015-2016 by around 3 per cent per annum for both public and private homes, which are highly correlated with each other.

site_title: Forays to the south of Burgundy country
summary: A wine tasting in the Cote d'Beaune region of Burgundy, France, featured several fine domaines with star vintages. Domaine Comtes Lafon's Meursault 1er Cru Charmes 2001 was described as a charmer with a shimmering golden color, elegant palate, and long finish. Domaine Leflaive's Chevalier Montrachet Grand Cru 2001 was also praised for its rich, smooth, and lingering finish. Other notable wines included Baron Thenard's Montrachet Grand Cru 1999 and Marquis d'Angerville's Volnay Premier Cru Clos des Ducs 1999. The tasting highlighted the quality and diversity of wines in the Cote d'Beaune region.

site_title: Swiss franc surge sends shock waves through global markets
summary: A surprise surge in the Swiss franc against the euro, triggered by the Swiss National Bank's decision to stop supporting the euro at 1.20, sent shockwaves through global markets. The move, seen as an indicator of larger-than-expected European Central Bank monetary easing, led to extreme volatility, with the euro plummeting 30% and the US dollar falling 20%. The Swiss franc's jump also boosted gold and sterling, while negatively impacting Swiss exports and imports. The move is expected to lead to higher quantitative easing, which could impact global markets and economies.

site_title: Uniqlo pledges to improve factory conditions in China
summary: Uniqlo, the Japanese clothing giant, has pledged to improve working conditions at its Chinese suppliers following claims of unsafe and mistreated workers. A report by Students and Scholars Against Corporate Misbehaviour (Sacom) alleged that two suppliers were forcing employees to work long hours for low pay in unsanitary conditions. Uniqlo's parent company, Fast Retailing, has instructed the suppliers to reduce working hours and improve conditions, and will conduct its own independent inspection and engage in dialogue with Sacom to seek further clarification.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Singapore banks are expected to benefit from rising interest rates, but analysts also note that higher credit costs will partially offset this gain. OCBC is preferred due to its lower price-to-book value ratio and potential revenue synergies from Wing Hang Bank. DBS is seen as the most geared to rising interest rates, but its expectations may be excessive. Analysts maintain an "overweight" stance on OCBC, followed by DBS and UOB.

site_title: Private consumption drove German growth of 1.5% in 2014
summary: Germany's economy expanded by 1.5% in 2014, driven by private consumption and trade, marking its best performance in three years. Private consumption added 0.6 percentage points to growth, while foreign trade contributed 0.4 percentage points despite sluggishness in Europe. The government is relying on domestic demand to fuel a recovery, with record-low unemployment and rising wages boosting household spending. Economists expect the economy to gradually pick up speed in 2015, with a possible revision of its forecast to 1.5% growth.

site_title: Beijing creates capital fund to aid start-ups
summary: China establishes a 40 billion yuan (S$8.6 billion) government venture capital fund to support start-ups in emerging industries, aiming to foster innovation and promote the country's economy to evolve towards the medium and high ends. The fund will be financed by government capital and state corporates, with private partners invited to participate. This move is part of China's strategy to let market forces play a decisive role in the economy, following the introduction of new rules last month allowing insurance companies to invest in venture capital funds.

site_title: Malaysian property prices likely to stay put, even amid softer economy
summary: Malaysian property prices are expected to remain stable this year despite a softer economy, with some analysts predicting a 2-4% increase ahead of the implementation of a 6% goods and services tax. Strong unbilled sales from previous years and robust revenues remain, but tightened lending guidelines and a deteriorating ringgit may limit property sales. Analysts prefer Klang Valley developers due to their suitable landbanks and demographics, and most buyers are wary of committing during economic headwinds.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate-led group close to buying AXA Tower
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings is close to buying AXA Tower in Singapore for approximately S$1.18 billion, translating to S$1,750 psf based on the existing net lettable area. The 50-storey office building is on a site with a 66.5-year balance lease term and is around 90% occupied. The purchase price reflects a net yield of 4% and the consortium plans to reposition the 29,177 sq ft retail space and potentially develop additional office space on the site.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: JPMorgan ATMs become harder to find after retail retreat
summary: JPMorgan Chase reduced its automated teller machines by 12% last quarter, exiting from some retail locations due to declining customer usage. The bank scaled back its relationship with Cardtronics, resulting in exits from Walgreens and CVS pharmacies, Hess and Speedway convenience stores. Despite this, active mobile customers rose 4% in the fourth quarter. The move is part of CEO Jamie Dimon's cost-cutting efforts to simplify the business and adapt to declining physical banking usage.

site_title: Vale's dividend at risk of slump, say analysts
summary: Vale SA, a Rio de Janeiro-based mining company, is expected to cut its annual dividend by almost half, down 47% from last year, due to plummeting iron ore prices. This would be the lowest level since 2007. The company will pay US$2.2 billion in dividends this year, down from US$4.2 billion in 2014. Analysts predict a minimum dividend payment target announcement later this month, which could jeopardize Vale's status as the most generous major mining company.

site_title: Ananda Krishnan in discussions to make key investment in 1MDB
summary: Malaysian billionaire Ananda Krishnan is in talks with state firm 1MDB to invest 5% in its US$3 billion listing of power assets, a major boost for the cash-strapped company. Krishnan's investment could be used to repay a US$12 billion debt pile and fund expansion. The IPO is likely to take place in the second quarter of 2015, with proceeds potentially covering a US$2 billion bridge loan owed to local lenders. Krishnan's investment could inspire confidence among other potential IPO investors and help 1MDB cut its debt.

site_title: Png Kim Chiang to take over as SIA Engineering CEO
summary: SIA Engineering Company's CEO, William Tan, 62, will step down in April and be replaced by Png Kim Chiang, 56, who currently holds the position of executive vice-president (operations). Under Tan's leadership, the company has emerged as a leading player in the Asia-Pacific for aircraft maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) services, despite the challenges faced by the aviation industry. Png, who has 40 years of experience in the aerospace industry, will take over on April 1.

site_title: Emerging-market investors in for another rocky year, says IIF
summary: Emerging-market investors are expected to face another challenging year, according to the Institute of International Finance (IIF). The report predicts that total EM capital inflows will decline by $25 billion to $1.06 trillion in 2015, driven by the US Federal Reserve's potential tightening of monetary policy and slower EM growth. The IIF also notes that countries such as China, India, and Indonesia are likely to maintain high levels of inflows, while others, including Russia and Turkey, may suffer more significant falls.

site_title: From chichi outings to grunge fare
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

Singapore Art Week features over 100 events, including the Prudential Singapore Eye exhibition at Marina Bay Sands, showcasing 17 contemporary artists, and the APB Foundation Signature Art Prize at the Singapore Art Museum. Other highlights include Artwalk Little India, Aliwal Urban Art Festival, and Art After Dark @ Gillman Barracks. The festival also includes performances, talks, and exhibitions at various locations, including the Singapore Art Museum and Aliwal Arts Centre. Events run from January 17 to June 28, offering a diverse range of art experiences for visitors.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Tickets for SEA Games opening and closing ceremonies go on sale
summary: Tickets for the SEA Games opening and closing ceremonies in Singapore went on sale to pre-registered fans on Thursday, with general public sales starting on January 22. The opening ceremony tickets range from S$12 to S$60, while the closing ceremony tickets range from S$12 to S$40, with various concessions available. The event, which will feature 7,000 athletes from 11 Asean nations, is being held to celebrate Singapore's 50th anniversary and will take place from June 5 to 16 at the National Stadium.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
The 55,000-seater National Stadium at the Sports Hub Line will be the venue for the opening and closing ceremonies of the SEA Games, a highlight among Singapore's jubilee events.

site_title: Stanchart's platform 'fully operational'
summary: Standard Chartered Bank's Online Securities Trading platform is fully operational, allowing retail clients to access cash equities across 13 stock market exchanges with no minimum brokerage. Existing cash equity holdings remain unaffected. Regional Head of Wealth, Chung Shaw Bee, confirmed this in a statement.

site_title: BlackBerry's patent portfolio is a treasure trove
summary: BlackBerry's patent portfolio, comprising 44,000 patents, is attracting potential buyers like Samsung due to its security features and basic wireless technologies. The company's patents could help Samsung expand into lucrative government contracts and corporate customers, while also potentially lowering licensing costs for the company in disputes with Apple. BlackBerry has built its portfolio through acquisitions, including a 2011 deal for 6,000 patents from Nortel Networks Corp. The company's patents have been the subject of previous deals, with Google buying Motorola's mobile-devices business in 2012 for $9.8 billion to secure patents.

site_title: Disney after dark hides plenty of surprises
summary: Disney's adaptation of Stephen Sondheim's Into The Woods brings magic and surprises to the big screen. Led by Meryl Streep, Emily Blunt, and James Corden, the ensemble cast delivers delightful performances. The film follows a baker and his wife as they navigate fairy tale characters to lift a witch's curse, but takes a darker turn in the second half. Despite some tweaks to the original story, the adaptation balances naughty and nice, showcasing Disney's potential for "Disney after dark" content. The film's performances and direction earn a rating of B.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Cloud of paper 'pigments'
summary: Singaporean artist Suzann Victor created an abstract series of works during her residency at the Singapore Tyler Print Institute, pushing the boundaries of traditional printmaking. She used paper pulp as a "paint" on acrylic and polycarbonate surfaces, treating paper as a painterly pigment. The works, titled "We Cloud," challenge traditional ideas of print-making and blur the lines between artist, medium, and subject. Victor's unconventional approach resulted in a unique aesthetic, exploring the sensuality and potential of paper as a medium.

site_title: Traders buy ahead of expected US bounce
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 12.68 points to 3,338.84 after two days of losses, with banks OCBC and UOB leading the gains. Jardine Group's Hongkong Land also contributed to the rise. The recovery was partly driven by an overnight rebound in oil prices, easing pressure on offshore oil and marine stocks. Analysts, including Morgan Stanley and S&P, expect lacklustre returns in 2015 due to slower growth and a strengthening USD, with Thailand having the most downside risk and Singapore being the most attractive market.

site_title: HK Lessons for enhancement of SGX enforcement powers
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is seeking to enhance its enforcement powers to tackle corporate governance issues. The exchange believes its current range of enforcement powers is inadequate and has used public reprimands sparingly. In contrast, Hong Kong's Stock Exchange of Hong Kong (SEHK) has a more robust system, with a Listing Committee that employs a dual approach to enforcement. A recent study on the impact of public reprimands in Hong Kong found that reprimanded issuers experienced significant negative market reaction and higher board turnover, while reprimanded directors lost their directorship in the issuer. To improve enforcement, SGX should consider calibrating reprimands according to the severity of the breach and the culpability, and establish a proper nominating process for committees.

site_title: December wholesale prices down the most in three years on plunge in oil prices
summary: US wholesale prices declined 0.3% in December, the largest drop in three years, due to a 6.6% plunge in energy costs. The decline, driven by lower oil prices, suggests inflation remains under control. Federal Reserve officials remain patient in raising interest rates, citing the energy story as the dominant driver of headline inflation. Core producer prices rose 0.3% in December, beating forecasts, and energy costs have fallen 6.6% since November 2009.

site_title: China banks issue fewer loans in Dec despite surprise rate cut
summary: China's banks issued 697.3 billion yuan in loans in December, lower than expected despite a surprise interest rate cut in November. The weaker-than-expected data suggests that Beijing's traditional reliance on credit to spark the economy is losing its effectiveness, posing a challenge to policymakers. The shadow banking system is also growing, with total social financing increasing to 1.69 trillion yuan in December. Economists predict a further slowdown in 2015, with growth likely slowing to 7.2% in the fourth quarter, undershooting the official 7.5% target.

site_title: Productivity must rise in line with higher wages: NTUC
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) in Singapore has stated that as the tight labour market increases pressure on companies to pay higher wages, productivity must also improve to sustain wage increases in the long term. The union will continue to advocate for broad-based real wage increases, particularly through the adoption of the progressive wage model.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Why drugs cost so much in US
summary: US drug manufacturers blame high prices on complexity, regulations, and profit margins. However, a simpler explanation lies in the US system, where insurers must cover expensive drugs, and companies offer them at attractive prices to European healthcare systems that can say no. This approach has resulted in US prices being 50% higher than in Europe. By allowing insurers and government programs to exclude expensive drugs, manufacturers may lower prices, or countries like Germany and France can set prices comparable to those in the US.

site_title: Birdman takes off with A-lister mojo
summary: Birdman, directed by Alejandro G. Inarritu, follows Riggan Thomson (Michael Keaton), a washed-up Hollywood star, as he attempts to revive his career on Broadway. Riggan's play, an adaptation of a Raymond Carver short story, is his final attempt to reclaim relevance. However, backstage shenanigans, a talented new cast member, and a caustic critic threaten to derail the production. The film's technical wizardry and impressive cast performances make it a standout, earning it a rating of A-.

site_title: US online video tutorial service Lynda.com in big round of financing
summary: Lynda.com, an online video tutorial service, has raised $186 million in financing led by TPG Capital, marking the largest ed-tech financing deal in the past six years. The company, founded in 1995, offers 5,700 courses in professional skills training and has 5.4 million individual and enterprise customers. Lynda.com generated $150 million in revenue in 2014 and has been profitable since 1997. The company plans to use the capital to acquire firms, expand internationally, and improve its product experience.

site_title: First Reit's DPU rises 3.6% in Q4 FY2014
summary: First Reit, Singapore's first healthcare real estate investment trust, reported a 3.6% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.04 Singapore cents in Q4 FY14. Gross revenue grew 4.6% to S$23.9 million, driven by contributions from acquired hospital properties and increased turnover from Indonesia and Singapore properties. Full-year DPU grew 7% to 8.05 cents. The trust's CEO, Ronnie Tan, expects Indonesia to remain its key market due to its growing GDP.

site_title: Soaring Swiss franc stirs panic among Polish mortgage holders
summary: A surge in the Swiss franc's value has sparked panic among Polish mortgage holders, with monthly payments expected to jump by 70-95 euros for those with loans in the currency. Around 700,000 Polish households hold mortgage loans in Swiss francs, which now trade nearly 20% higher against the Polish zloty. Analysts predict the fallout will be "much smaller" than in the past, but some homeowners, like Piotr Andrzejewski, fear their monthly payments will become unaffordable.

site_title: Conflict trumps economy as top risk to world in WEF survey
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) has identified conflict as the top risk to the world in the coming decade, surpassing economic concerns. This is the first time the organization has highlighted conflict as the primary threat, reflecting an increasingly volatile global landscape. Experts cited the pro-Russian uprising in Ukraine, the rise of the Islamic State, and other geopolitical flashpoints as major concerns. The survey, which analyzed 28 global risks, also ranked water crises and infectious diseases as top dangers in terms of their potential impact.

site_title: Australia to start probing petrol stations
summary: Australia's Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) will investigate petrol stations for possible price fixing after lawmaker accused some of failing to pass on oil price falls to consumers. The probe targets firms like Chevron, BP, and Vitol, which dominate the service station industry, and may impact large retailers like Woolworths and Coles. The ACCC will produce eight reports a year on petrol pricing, up from one, and will use its powers to gather information on the gap between regional and city prices, which has tripled since July last year.

site_title: BOJ faces major dilemma over inflation target
summary: BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda faces a dilemma in achieving the bank's 2% annual consumer price inflation target as it appears to recede further due to plunging oil prices. The central bank is expected to lower its forecast next week, and Kuroda may need to step up monetary easing or risk credibility. A flexible approach could lead to a rapid yen appreciation and collapse in Japanese equity prices. The BOJ's real priority is securing the "re-onshoring" of Japanese production and boosting exports, but this could take around five years or more.

site_title: Budget 2015: a chance to recalibrate policies and targets
summary: The upcoming Singapore Budget 2015 presents a chance for the government to recalibrate its economic restructuring policies and targets. Productivity growth has been dismal, declining from 2.2% in 2011 to -0.5% in 2014, due to unattainable initial targets. The government has allocated significant grants to incentivize companies to be more productive, but sectors like construction, food-and-beverage, and retail may require more time to see productivity gains. The government should consider a broader definition of productivity and provide incentives for business model restructuring, land optimization, and innovation.

images.alt_text: The upcoming Budget 2015 presents the Singapore government with a suitable and timely opportunity to recalibrate its approach to economic restructuring and particularly its push for greater productivity.

site_title: Sng Ngoi May to retire from SPH
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) announced the retirement of Sng Ngoi May, 69, as executive vice-president of retail property management, effective February 1. May will become an adviser to SPH in the same role and step down as chairman of the Orchard Road Business Association (ORBA), which she led for over eight years. Mark Shaw, current ORBA vice-chairman, will take over as chairman. May's contributions to SPH and ORBA include securing numerous awards and contributing to the success of SPH's three shopping malls.

site_title: Poor new-home sales in December sum up placid 2014 market
summary: Singapore's new-home sales plummeted to 230 units in December, the lowest since 2009, amid a three-party stalemate between buyers, developers, and authorities. Developers held back launches and scaled marketing efforts, while buyers waited for better price offers. Year-on-year, December's sales were on par with 2013, and the full-year tally was half that of 2013. Analysts expect developer sales to pick up in 2015, but prices are forecast to drop 5-8% after a 4% decline in 2014. Authorities may lift cooling measures only after prices correct by 15% or more.

site_title: Pending deals seen unaffected by Swiss franc leap
summary: Swiss National Bank's decision to scrap a cap on the Swiss franc has had a minimal impact on pending deals involving Swiss companies Sika and Holcim, with companies having bought insurance to protect against exchange rate moves. Some analysts see an opportunity in the stronger currency, while others believe volatility will dampen deal-making in the longer term. Companies such as Saint-Gobain and Holcim remain committed to their deals despite the market fluctuations.

site_title: Sayer dusts off the ditties
summary: Chart-topping singer-songwriter Leo Sayer is set to release a new album, Restless Years, after a successful comeback trail. Since moving to Australia, Sayer has been playing 80 shows a year and is about to kick off a tour in Singapore. He attributes his career revival to the popularity of reality singing competitions, which has led to a desire for "the real thing" – classic hits performed by legends like Sayer. With decades of experience, Sayer is confident in his ability to captivate audiences, despite the physical demands of touring.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: A chance to put Sri Lanka in order
summary: Sri Lanka's President Mahinda Rajapaksa's sudden defeat in a snap election has created a fresh opportunity for the country to put its politics, ethnic relations, economy, and foreign policy in order. However, the new government faces significant challenges, including a divided opposition, public institutions still dominated by Rajapaksa loyalists, and a high level of corruption. The new government's 100-day program aims to address these issues through constitutional and political reform, but critics argue that its economic policies are populist and economically nonsensical. A radical economic overhaul and reorientation of foreign policy towards the West and India are also necessary to ensure Sri Lanka's long-term prosperity.

images.alt_text: Supporters holding up images of Mr Sirisena as they celebrate in the streets of Colombo last week. The new government is extremely diverse and could easily fall apart.

site_title: #JeSuisCharlie creator seeks to copyright slogan to 'protect message'
summary: French graphic designer Joachim Roncin, creator of the #JeSuisCharlie slogan, is seeking to copyright the phrase to protect its message from commercialization. Roncin's lawyer says he will use his copyright to control the use of the slogan and preserve its original meaning. This move comes as the slogan has been widely adopted globally since the 2015 jihadist attack on Charlie Hebdo magazine.

images.alt_text: The Frenchman who coined the #JeSuisCharlie slogan that was adopted globally in the wake of a jihadist attack on the Charlie Hebdo magazine, is trying to copyright the phrase to stop its commercialisation, his lawyer told AFP Thursday.

site_title: Stress and social media: it's complicated
summary: Researchers found that social media can increase stress due to the "cost of caring" - being aware of problems in friends' and family members' lives. However, frequent internet and social media users do not have higher levels of stress than the general population. Women who use social media frequently report lower stress levels, but are also more aware of stressful events in others' lives. Facebook was found to be a significant source of stress, particularly among women, due to its high level of awareness of close and distant acquaintances' stressful events.

site_title: US mortgage rates fall for second week to hold at 20-month low
summary: US mortgage rates fell to 3.66% for a second week, the lowest level in over a year and a half. The average 30-year fixed mortgage rate declined from 3.73%, while the 15-year rate dropped to 2.98%. Loan demand surged 49% after the holidays, boosting the housing market, which is in a "slow and steady progression." Experts say the low rates are beneficial for activity levels, with companies like Lennar Corp reporting a 50% increase in fiscal fourth-quarter profit.

site_title: Disinflation, eurozone and China pose threat to global growth: Reuters poll
summary: Global economic growth is expected to be modest this year, with the world economy forecast to grow 3.5% in 2015 and 3.8% in 2016. The eurozone and China pose a threat to global growth, with economists citing weak inflation and disinflationary trends. The European Central Bank is likely to print money through government bond purchases, but its impact may be limited due to low euro bond yields and a weaker currency. The US economy is expected to experience higher growth, but the global economy is "running on a single engine."

site_title: First BoE hike pushed back to Q4, but close call: Reuters poll
summary: The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates from a record low this year, but the timing is uncertain. A Reuters poll found 20 economists expect no change before October, while 19 predict an increase. This contrasts with a previous poll in December, which suggested a third-quarter rise. The decision is influenced by low inflation, currently at a 14-year low, and the BoE's desire to avoid pressure to hike rates. The exact timing of the interest rate hike remains unclear.

site_title: Qatar 2015 budget likely to be based on $45 oil: industry source
summary: Qatar's state budget for the fiscal year starting in April is likely to be based on an average oil price of $45 per barrel, down from $65 in the current year's budget, according to an industry source. This conservative assumption aims to keep growth on track, despite a recent plunge in oil prices. Qatar's natural gas export revenues are weakly correlated with oil, and the country's long-term contracts are expected to cover any deficit for another three to four years. The finance ministry has not commented on the budget.

site_title: Ascott's global expansion continues apace
summary: Ascott, a serviced residence business unit of CapitaLand, continues its global expansion with plans to open over 20 properties in 2015, targeting 40,000 apartment units by the end of the year. The company aims to expand in key cities in Asia, Europe, and the Gulf region, and has secured franchises in Vientiane and Bali, as well as formed alliances in China and Australia. Ascott's CEO, Lee Chee Koon, stated that the company will continue to build its scale and explore new markets, with its first international branded serviced residences opening in Malaysia, Thailand, and Vietnam.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Somerset Central TD Hai Phong City - the first international branded serviced residence in the city.

site_title: Xiaomi challenges iPhone 6 Plus with new flagship Mi Note
summary: Xiaomi unveiled the Mi Note, its flagship smartphone, in Beijing, challenging Apple's iPhone 6 Plus with a lower price point of 2,299 yuan (S$493) for a 16GB model. The company, valued at $45 billion, aims to disrupt the market with its innovative features and strategy to connect devices with home appliances. Xiaomi's CEO Lei Jun played down comparisons with Apple, saying the company will have tens of thousands of patents in 10 years. The move marks a significant challenge to Apple and Samsung Electronics as Xiaomi rises to become the world's No 3 smartphone maker.

site_title: Citigroup plans to exit hedge fund administration, prepaid cards
summary: Citigroup plans to exit hedge fund administration and prepaid card services, transferring these operations to its Citi Holdings unit in the first quarter of 2015. The bank will also discontinue some transfer agency operations and wealth-management administration. The move aims to focus on core businesses and reduce costs.

site_title: Consumer comfort in US increases to highest since July 2007
summary: US consumer confidence reached its highest level since July 2007, increasing to 45.4 in the period ended January 11, driven by steady job gains, declining gasoline prices, and a measure of households' views of the economy at its strongest in over seven years. This improvement is expected to boost consumer spending, as wage growth and low gas prices provide relief to cash-strapped households. A gauge of the buying climate also rose to its highest level since April 2007.

site_title: HSBC set to pass Lloyds as Europe's biggest issuer of CoCo bonds
summary: HSBC Holdings is expected to surpass Lloyds Banking Group as Europe's biggest issuer of Contingent Convertible (CoCo) bonds, with new issues this year bringing its total close to $10 billion. The UK, led by HSBC, has seen significant issuance of CoCo bonds since 2013, with the UK accounting for over 10% of the $50 billion expected to be sold in Europe this year. HSBC's additional Tier 1 bonds offer a 7.18% coupon, compared to 3.32% on senior debt, and are seen as a way for banks to meet new capital rules without putting taxpayers at risk.

site_title: ECB will almost certainly conduct QE in Jan or March: Reuters poll
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to conduct quantitative easing (QE) in January or March, according to a Reuters poll of over 50 economists. The move is aimed at preventing deflation and stabilizing the economy, which has seen negative inflation for the first time since 2009. The ECB's balance sheet is expected to expand by one trillion euros by the end of next year, with economists predicting a 90% chance of QE. The decision comes as the eurozone faces challenges, including a potential showdown with international lenders over Greece's debt.

site_title: Bombardier to suspend business jet program, cut 1,000 jobs
summary: Bombardier Inc suspended its Learjet 85 aircraft program and laid off approximately 1,000 employees due to weak demand for business jets. The move reflects continued weakness in the light aircraft category since the economic downturn. The company expects a pretax charge of about US$1.4 billion for the fourth quarter, mainly for the impairment of development costs.

site_title: Global gold demand may rise 15% in 2015 on Asia, ETP buys: HSBC
summary: Global gold demand is expected to rise 15% in 2015, driven by increased demand in Asia, particularly China and India. Analysts at HSBC Securities predict 4,127 tonnes of gold demand this year, a rebound from a 15% drop in 2014. Rising Asian demand may help gold prices recover after testing new lows, with prices expected to average US$1,234 an ounce this year. Assets in gold-backed ETPs are also expected to expand 50 tonnes, and central banks are forecast to add 400 tonnes this year.

site_title: GKE Corporation appoints new CFO
summary: GKE Corporation appoints Ben Teo as its new chief financial officer, replacing Clarence Tan who steps down on February 28. Teo's previous roles include freelance financial consultant, CFO of Chasen Holdings and Koon Holdings, and financial controller of GKE International. The appointment marks a change in leadership for the Singapore-based logistics provider.

site_title: Oil rallies a second day in New York to trade near US$50 a barrel
summary: Oil prices surged a second day in New York, reaching near US$50 a barrel for the first time in over a week. West Texas Intermediate futures gained 5.8% before paring their rally, while OPEC predicted US supply growth will slow due to reduced drilling activity. Despite this, US production reached a record 9.19 million barrels a day last week. Brent crude also rose, trading below WTI for the first time since 2013, as Saudi Arabia's strategy to curb US shale output growth appears to be working.

site_title: Europe thrown into turmoil as Swiss let franc soar
summary: Switzerland's decision to lift its 1.20 euro cap on the franc sent the currency soaring, jumping by almost 30% in a few minutes. The franc traded as high as 0.8052 francs per euro, causing global markets to tumble, including Europe's shares and bond yields. This move has created market turmoil and uncertainty, with investors having shattered hopes of a calming of recent market volatility.

site_title: Indonesia's interest rate remains unchanged
summary: Indonesia's central bank kept its main interest rate unchanged at 7.75% for a second straight month, as declining oil prices ease pressure to cool inflation. The decision comes amid a persistent decline in oil prices and President Joko Widodo's overhaul of the country's fuel subsidy system. Policymakers expect the price pressures to be temporary and anticipate the economy will expand around 4.9% in the fourth quarter. The rupiah strengthened 0.5% against the US dollar following the decision.

site_title: Swiss banks hammered as earnings face hit from currency surge
summary: Swiss banks UBS and Credit Suisse saw their shares slump by as much as 15% on Thursday due to a massive strengthening of the Swiss franc, which raised concerns about hit to reported earnings. The Swiss National Bank's decision to scrap a three-year-old cap on the franc and cut interest rates further exacerbated the issue. Analysts estimate a 7-10% negative impact on forward earnings, with Credit Suisse potentially taking a 15% hit and UBS a 14% hit, primarily due to higher costs and lower reported earnings.

site_title: Aspial may spin-off property business in Australia, Malaysia for listing
summary: Aspial Corporation, a Singapore-based company, is planning to spin off its Australian and Malaysian property business for listing on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board. The proposed spin-off, in its preliminary stages, requires regulatory approvals and market conditions. Aspial has appointed Canaccord Genuity Singapore as sponsor and issue manager for the spin-off. The move aims to separate the company's property business from its jewellery retail and financial services operations.

site_title: Update: Switzerland scraps euro rate cap, shocking markets
summary: Switzerland's central bank announced the end of a three-year bid to hold down the value of its currency against the euro, citing that the currency was no longer massively overvalued and the economy had adjusted. The decision sent stocks plummeting and the franc soaring 29% against the euro. The Swiss franc also strengthened significantly against the dollar, causing widespread market panic and concerns about the impact on exports and earnings. The central bank shifted its strategy, introducing negative interest rates and ending the minimum exchange rate floor.

site_title: France says spending cuts keep 2014 deficit on target
summary: France managed to cut state spending in 2014, meeting its public deficit target for the year, according to Finance Minister Michel Sapin. This achievement comes despite the country's repeated fiscal slippages and a higher-than-expected 4.4% public deficit-to-GDP ratio. The move is seen as a positive step for Paris, which is under scrutiny from the European Commission over fiscal issues.

site_title: UBS, Credit Suisse plunge after SNB abandons cap on swiss franc
summary: Switzerland's central bank unexpectedly abandoned its franc-euro ceiling, causing UBS, Credit Suisse, and Julius Baer shares to plummet. The franc surged, with UBS shares falling 16% and Credit Suisse shares trading 11% lower. Analysts predict the stronger franc could shave 7-10% off earnings and improve leverage ratios. The move reverses a three-year-old policy aimed at protecting the country's economy from investors.

site_title: Jubilee Industries in bid to acquire WE Components
summary: CATALIST-LISTED Jubilee Industries Holdings has entered into a supplemental agreement for its proposed acquisition of WE Components, a distributor and trader of electronic equipment, for US$5.617 million. The acquisition aims to expand Jubilee Industries' presence in the electronics industry. The parties will mutually agree on the consideration amount and manner of completion following the acquisition's completion. This is Jubilee Industries' second supplemental agreement for the acquisition, indicating ongoing negotiations.

site_title: Eurozone exports rise in November: Eurostat
summary: The eurozone trade surplus narrowed to 20.0 billion euros in November, down from 23.6 billion euros the previous month. Eurozone exports rose 0.2% month-on-month to 162.6 billion euros, while imports remained flat. Despite a slight increase in exports, it may not be enough to counter expectations of an unprecedented bond-buying program by the European Central Bank to fight deflation. The EU's overall trade balance rose 0.9% month-on-month, with Germany posting the EU's biggest trade surplus.

site_title: Franc surges to record versus euro as SNB move raises floodgate
summary: Switzerland's franc surged to its strongest level on record against the euro after the Swiss National Bank removed a 1.20-per-euro cap, allowing a flood of foreign investment into the nation. The franc strengthened at least 15% against 16 major peers, driven by speculation of the European Central Bank's potential quantitative-easing program. The move was seen as a response to expected European Central Bank action, with analysts noting the SNB aims to prepare for potential future market pressures. The franc's surge is expected to continue as investors take advantage of the new market dynamics.

site_title: Swiss stocks plunge as 'crazy' central bank move upends markets
summary: Swiss stocks plummeted 9.5% to a record low after the Swiss National Bank abandoned its 3-year-old minimum exchange rate cap, sending the Swiss franc soaring against the euro and triggering wild market swings. The move, seen as a shock, hurt exporters and small- and mid-size companies, with Holcim and Swatch Group falling 21% and 16% respectively. Economists predict the European Central Bank may announce fresh stimulus, which could lead to a hit for Swiss companies.

images.alt_text: Stocks in Switzerland fell the most on record after the country's central bank gave up its minimum exchange rate - a shock move that sent the Swiss franc soaring against the euro and triggered wild swings in equity markets.

site_title: US: Wall St drops after Swiss move; banks tumble
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday after the Swiss National Bank scrapped its euro cap on the franc, sparking concerns about global economic stability. The move led to a decline in US-dollar denominated stocks, including UBS, Credit Suisse, and Novartis, which rose in Swiss trading. The US market erased small gains at the open, with trading remaining volatile. The decision by the Swiss bank to discontinue the cap introduced in 2011 to combat recession and deflation threats added to market uncertainty.

site_title: Indonesia c.bank holds benchmark rate steady at 7.75%
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, held its benchmark interest rate at 7.75% as expected, aiming to keep inflation at its target and maintain a healthy current account deficit. This decision follows a 25 basis point rate hike in November and a 30% fuel price hike. Annual inflation in December was 8.36%, exceeding the bank's forecast of 7.7-8.1%. The bank targets inflation to return to its normal range of 3-5% by 2015 and 2016.

site_title: Opec to see market share drop even as oil slump slows shale boom
summary: Opec reported a forecast of 28.78 million barrels per day (bpd) in oil demand for 2015, down 140,000 bpd from the previous estimate, marking the lowest demand since 2004. The slowdown in US oil output, attributed to the decline of the shale boom, is expected to continue, with Opec lowering its forecast of total US oil supply in 2015 by 100,000 bpd.

site_title: Oil price plunge could leave helicopters sputtering
summary: Tumbling oil prices are affecting the helicopter industry, with off-shore oil drilling and production accounting for 40% of annual sales. This segment relies on helicopter makers such as Sikorsky, AgustaWestland, and Airbus Helicopters. Lower oil prices could lead to reduced demand for helicopters, potentially impacting their sales and operations.

site_title: BlackRock's quarterly earnings beat Wall Street estimates
summary: BlackRock Inc., the world's largest money manager, reported a higher-than-expected fourth-quarter profit of US$813 million, or US$4.77 per share, with assets under management increasing 8% to US$4.65 trillion. The company beat analysts' average estimate of US$4.68 per share. Net inflows for the quarter totaled US$87.8 billion, with US$23 billion and US$20.7 billion going to the active retail and institutional businesses, respectively.

site_title: Wholesale prices in US fall by most in three years on fuel
summary: US wholesale prices fell 0.3% in December, the largest drop in three years, driven by a plunge in energy costs. This decline has kept inflation in check, prompting the Federal Reserve to remain patient on raising interest rates. Despite a 1.1% rise in wholesale prices over the past 12 months, weak price growth has convinced officials to wait for a rate increase since 2006. The sustained drop in energy prices has also limited the impact on businesses and consumers, with inflation showing little sign of bubbling up.

site_title: Singapore home prices to fall 3% per annum in 2015-2016: Fitch Ratings
summary: Fitch Ratings predicts Singapore property prices will fall 3% per annum in 2015-2016, with mortgage rates increasing slightly to around 2%. Abundant liquidity and low funding costs are expected to limit downside risks to house prices.

site_title: AF Global raises stake in LCD Global Investments to 29.9%
summary: AF Global, a joint venture firm, raised its stake in LCD Global Investments to 29.9% after a voluntary conditional cash offer at 33 Singapore cents a share. This is just 0.1% short of the general offer trigger. Aspial Corporation and Fragrance Group teamed up to gain control from JTrust Asia, which acquired a 29.5% stake last September. The stock price jumped 11.67% to close at S$0.335 on the same day.

site_title: Cost to hedge against price swings in Swiss franc, euro soars
summary: The Swiss National Bank's decision to abandon its three-year-old currency cap on the Swiss franc led to a significant spike in volatility, with one-month implied volatility reaching 24.675%, its highest since 2011. The franc surged up to 30% against the euro, its highest jump since the euro's launch in 1999. This move has major implications for investors looking to hedge against price swings, with costs increasing to their highest in over three years.

site_title: Jobless claims in US unexpectedly climb to four-month high
summary: US jobless claims unexpectedly rose to a four-month high of 316,000 in the week ended January 10, surpassing economists' median forecast of 290,000. The increase is attributed to companies letting go of seasonal workers following the holidays. Despite this, the unemployment rate among people eligible for benefits declined to 1.8% and payrolls climbed by 252,000 workers in December, the lowest level since June 2008. The labor market is expected to continue improving in 2015, with many economists projecting better job growth than the previous year.

images.alt_text: More Americans unexpectedly filed applications for unemployment benefits last week, indicating companies let go of seasonal workers following the holidays.

site_title: Olam issues US$50 million in private placement of 5-year notes
summary: Olam International has issued US$50 million in private placement of 5-year senior notes at a fixed coupon of 4% per cent, with maturity on January 22, 2020. The net proceeds will be used to fund its ordinary course of business. This issuance falls under Olam's US$5 billion Euro Medium Term Note Programme established on July 6, 2012.

site_title: Denmark may cut rates after Swiss drop franc cap: analysts
summary: Denmark's central bank may cut its deposit rate to stop the crown appreciating after the Swiss National Bank scrapped the franc's cap against the euro, risking an unwanted strengthening of the Danish crown. Analysts expect Denmark's key policy rate to be cut to -0.05% to prevent the crown from rising further. The Danish central bank aims to keep the crown within a narrow band of 7.29252 to 7.62824 per euro, currently trading at its strongest level since June 2012. A rate cut is expected within the next three months.

site_title: Eurozone periphery faces downgrades if deflation persists: Fitch
summary: Fitch warns that the eurozone's debt-strained countries face credit rating downgrades if deflation persists for a long period. The agency's chief credit officer, Eileen Fahey, stated that high levels of debt-to-GDP in peripheral countries will worsen under such conditions. This could lead to material ratings impact, indicating a negative outlook for the region.

site_title: Swatch Group CEO says SNB action is a tsunami for Switzerland
summary: Swatch Group CEO Nick Hayek described the Swiss National Bank's decision to discontinue the minimum exchange rate on the Swiss franc as a "tsunami" for Switzerland and its economy. This move is expected to negatively impact the country's export industry and tourism, as well as companies with international operations, such as Swiss watchmakers. Shares in Swatch Group and Richemont fell 15% and 14% respectively, underperforming the 9% drop in the Swiss market index.

site_title: India makes surprise interest rate cut, more expected
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), cut interest rates by 25 basis points to 7.75% in a surprise move to boost the flagging economy. The move is attributed to falling local food and global oil prices, which have brought inflation under control. RBI governor Raghuram Rajan signaled further rate reductions could come, citing the government's commitment to contain the fiscal deficit. The decision is expected to increase lending and help kickstart the economy, which has been struggling through its worst slowdown since the 1980s.

site_title: SNB move fuels speculation Danes may be next as krone gains
summary: The Swiss National Bank's decision to abandon its euro cap has fueled speculation that Denmark may follow suit, with investors questioning whether the Danish central bank can support its currency regime. The Danish krone has strengthened to its strongest level since December 25, while the Swiss franc has risen 29% against the euro. Economists predict the Danish central bank may respond with a rate cut to avoid too much krone appreciation versus the euro, although Governor Lars Rohde has warned that Danish rates are already under pressure. The move comes just ahead of the European Central Bank's quantitative easing announcement.

site_title: Swiss, German, UK shares slide as SNB scraps exchange-rate cap
summary: Switzerland's Swiss National Bank unexpectedly ended its three-year-old minimum exchange rate policy, allowing the Swiss franc to surge to a record against the euro. The move led to a 12% decline in the Swiss Market Index and a 0.6% fall in the UK's FTSE 100 Index, as well as losses in Germany's DAX Index. The franc's strength prompted investors to sell Swiss shares, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index briefly rising 4% before paring gains. US stock-index futures also fell 0.6% after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Stocks in Switzerland, Germany and the UK slid as the Swiss National Bank unexpectedly announced the end of its minimum exchange rate.

site_title: Rate cut a start but we need more, says Indian business
summary: Indian businesses have expressed disappointment with the Reserve Bank of India's 25 basis point interest rate cut, stating it's a start but not enough to fuel a recovery. The economy has grown at less than 5% over the past two years, with businesses facing high lending rates, above those in developed nations and emerging markets. To induce investments, businesses are demanding a full percentage point reduction in the next six months, citing high debt costs and a need for significant reforms, including regulation and land acquisition improvements.

site_title: Update: Divers hunt for victims in crashed AirAsia jet's main body
summary: Indonesian divers searched the main body of the crashed AirAsia jet, located by a navy ship on Wednesday, in hopes of recovering victims. Flight QZ8501, carrying 162 people, went down on December 28 in stormy weather. The plane was on a short trip from Surabaya to Singapore. The search, hampered by bad weather, finally yielded the fuselage at the bottom of the Java Sea.

site_title: Q&M Dental completes acquisition of New Dental Centre
summary: Q&M Dental Group has completed the acquisition of New Dental Centre for a total cash consideration of S$1. The company also sold two specialist centres to other clinics, as part of its strategy. This move marks Q&M's expansion into the dental services market.

site_title: Citigroup quarterly earnings down 86% on huge legal costs
summary: Citigroup reported a 86% drop in fourth-quarter earnings to $350 million due to a $3.5 billion charge for legal and repositioning costs. The bank has faced costly government settlements and private litigation over interest rate and foreign exchange trades. This charge is a result of the bank's efforts to reposition itself and address regulatory issues. The earnings drop is a significant decline from the $2.5 billion reported in the same quarter last year.

images.alt_text: Citigroup on Thursday reported an 86 per cent drop in fourth-quarter earnings due to a US$3.5 billion charge for legal and repositioning costs.

site_title: Sterling hits six-year high against weakened euro
summary: Sterling hits a six-year high against the euro, driven by expectations of the European Central Bank's imminent bond buying and the UK's stronger economic prospects. The pound is also supported by the UK's subdued inflation and slowing growth, contrasting with the eurozone's threat of deflation. This move is seen as a positive for the UK economy, which shrunk for the second month, dealing a fresh blow to Prime Minister Starmer.

images.alt_text: Sterling hit a six-year high against a struggling euro on Thursday on growing expectations the European Central Bank will embark soon on outright government bond buying.

site_title: SIA Engineering's William Tan to retire; Png Kim Chiang named new CEO
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) CEO William Tan, 62, will retire on April 1, handing over to Png Kim Chiang, current executive vice president of operations. Tan led the company since 2001, navigating challenges such as 9/11, SARS, and the 2008 global financial downturn. Under his leadership, SIAEC emerged as a leading Asia-Pacific player in aircraft maintenance and repair services.

site_title: Indonesia revises 2015 current account deficit outlook to 3% of GDP
summary: Indonesia's central bank has revised its forecast for the country's current account deficit to 3% of GDP for 2015, up from the previous 2.8% estimate. The revised forecast also shows a 3% current account deficit for 2014. The central bank maintained interest rates steady in its first policy meeting for the year. This revision is likely due to a stronger-than-expected rupiah and increased imports. The revised forecast may impact the country's economic growth and inflation expectations.

site_title: Moody's says India ratings upgrade to depend on fiscal consolidation
summary: Moody's Investors Service says India's ratings upgrade to depend on fiscal consolidation, citing a need for material improvement in the country's fiscal position. Analyst Atsi Sheth warns that policy action would likely take time to reflect on government finances. The current rating of "Baa3" with a "stable" outlook remains unchanged, and the Reserve Bank of India's recent rate cut has had a limited impact. Sheth emphasizes that government moves to improve the fiscal position would have a greater impact on India's credit than central bank actions.

site_title: Swiss franc surge hits emerging Europe bank sector
summary: The Swiss National Bank's decision to let the Swiss franc surge has sent shockwaves through the banking sector in central and eastern Europe, particularly Poland and Hungary, where widespread mortgages denominated in francs are becoming harder to service. Analysts predict a rise in bad loans and a policy headache for governments as citizens' purchasing power dwindles. Polish banks, such as Getin Noble Bank and mBank, are expected to be heavily impacted, with some analysts warning of potential political issues in Poland's upcoming elections.

images.alt_text: The Swiss central bank's surprise move to let the franc surge sent shock waves through the banking sector in central and eastern Europe (CEE), where widespread mortgages denominated in francs suddenly became much harder to service.

site_title: Downgrades for oil producers likely if crude doesn't recover: Fitch
summary: Fitch warns that credit rating downgrades for oil-producing countries are likely if crude prices don't recover. Analyst Ed Parker stated that further ratings actions on countries like Russia would be considered if oil prices fail to recover from current lows, accompanied by a deeper and longer recession and financial sector turmoil.

site_title: India central bank urges banks' auditors to improve monitoring
summary: India's central bank deputy governor SS Mundra urged domestic banks' audit committees to improve monitoring of potential risks, including loan assessments and asset quality. Recent inspections found recurrences of "know your customer" rule violations and discrepancies between assets and provisioning. Mundra emphasized the need for audit committees to pre-emptively address potential risks to improve the banking system's health. The central bank aims to clean up lenders and revive lending, which is still saddled with non-performing loans, now at 10.7% of total bank assets.

site_title: Update: Samsung, BlackBerry deny report they're in talks about deal
summary: Samsung Electronics Co. and BlackBerry Ltd. have denied reports that they are in talks about a potential deal, with Samsung saying the report is "groundless" and BlackBerry stating it has not engaged in discussions with Samsung. The reported price of $7.5 billion would be a 37% premium to BlackBerry's closing price on January 13, and analysts say it seems too high. The denial comes after a report suggested Samsung approached BlackBerry with an initial offer price of $13.35 to $15.49 per share to acquire the Canadian smartphone maker.

site_title: Switzerland ends euro minimum exchange rate, cuts interest rate
summary: Switzerland's central bank announced the end of a three-year minimum exchange rate of 1.20 francs per euro, allowing the Swiss franc to strengthen 29% to 0.8517 against the euro. The move aims to protect the country's export industry, which was defended by buying foreign currencies since 2011. The bank also cut interest rates by 0.5 percentage points to negative 0.75%, aiming to stimulate economic growth and reduce the currency's overvaluation.

site_title: India to make provision in budget to fill oil storage
summary: India plans to make a provision in its budget to fill its strategic oil storage reserves, taking advantage of the country's low oil prices. The country aims to hold 36.87 million barrels of oil, enough to cover 13 days of needs in case of a supply disruption. The first underground facility at Vizag is ready for commissioning, with a cost of around $354 million to fill the bigger compartment. The remaining facilities at Padur and Mangalore are expected to be ready by October 2015, providing a fiscal windfall for Finance Minister Arun Jaitley.

site_title: SapuraKencana signs Malaysia's largest Islamic loan worth US$2.3b
summary: SapuraKencana Petroleum Bhd has signed a US$2.3 billion Islamic loan with 11 lenders, marking Malaysia's largest Islamic loan. The transaction will convert part of the company's conventional borrowing into a syariah-based facility, allowing SapuraKencana to return to the Securities Commission's list of syariah-compliant securities. The deal follows SapuraKencana's conventional debt exceeding two-thirds of its total assets, prompting its removal from the list.

site_title: Drop in SIA's passenger load factor in December
summary: Singapore Airlines reported a 0.8% decrease in systemwide passenger carriage in December 2014, with a 0.7% drop in the passenger load factor to 81.8%. In contrast, SilkAir's passenger load factor increased by 0.7 percentage points to 75% due to a 7.3% capacity jump. The airline attributed the decline to a competitive and challenging operating environment, stating that capacity will be adjusted to match market demand.

site_title: Energy giant BP says to cut 300 jobs in North Sea
summary: Energy giant BP plans to cut 300 jobs in North Sea operations, shedding 200 staff and 100 contractors due to a sharp drop in oil prices. The company employs around 3,000 people in Aberdeen, Scotland, and regional president Trevor Garlick says the cuts are inevitable. British energy minister Ed Davey vows to retain jobs in the sector, while Scotland urges the government to ease the tax burden on the North Sea oil industry. Oil prices have slumped by over 50% since June, affecting the regional economy.

site_title: Silicon Valley firms in agreement over non-poaching accord
summary: Apple, Google, Intel, and Adobe agree to settle a US$415 million lawsuit alleging they colluded not to hire each other's employees. The firms offered the settlement to avoid a trial and release of incriminating emails. The 64,000 plaintiffs will accept the deal, and court papers may be filed as early as Thursday if the judge accepts the conditions. The firms had previously settled with three other companies for a total of US$344.5 million in 2013 and 2014.

site_title: Russian 2015 car sales seen falling 24% after 10% drop last year
summary: Russian car sales are forecast to plummet 24% in 2015, extending last year's 10% decline, due to high interest rates and a weak ruble. New car and light commercial vehicle sales are expected to drop to 1.89 million vehicles from 2.49 million last year. The ruble's 40% collapse last year led to slowed production and price increases by carmakers. High interest rates are also expected to hold down car sales this year.

site_title: Rajan's rate-cut message to India's Modi: Now fix the budget
summary: India's central bank governor Raghuram Rajan cut interest rates by a quarter-point, citing easing inflation, but linked future rate cuts to "high-quality fiscal consolidation" to be implemented by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government. The move aims to revive growth and ease the relationship between Rajan and Finance Minister Arun Jaitley. The government is now expected to present a budget next month with cuts in subsidies, tax revenue boosts, and infrastructure investments to meet Rajan's conditions.

site_title: Gold demand seen expanding 15% by HSBC on Asia-to-ETP buying
summary: HSBC analysts predict global gold demand will rise 15% to 4,127 metric tons in 2015, driven by increased demand in Asia. Bullion consumption in China and India is expected to recover, helping to boost gold prices. The analysts forecast gold to average US$1,234 an ounce this year, with prices trading between US$1,120 and US$1,305. Central banks are also expected to continue accumulating gold, supporting prices.

site_title: HSBC seen passing Lloyds as biggest issuer of CoCos: UK Credit
summary: HSBC is expected to surpass Lloyds as Europe's biggest issuer of Contingent Capital Bonds (CoCos) this year, with the bank planning to sell around $4 billion of additional Tier 1 notes, bringing its total to nearly $10 billion. UK banks have been actively issuing CoCos, with issuance reaching over $65 billion since 2013, and are favored by banks as a cheaper alternative to selling stock. The bonds offer investors high coupons and are seen as a way for banks to meet new capital rules without putting taxpayers at risk.

site_title: Oil prices retreat again as Iraq schedules record exports
summary: Iraq plans to boost monthly crude oil exports to a record high of 3.3 million barrels per day in February, further exacerbating the global supply glut. Oil prices retreated, with Brent crude oil down $1.48 to $47.21 a barrel, nearing six-year lows. The move is attributed to a war for output market share and a bearish market sentiment, with analysts predicting Brent prices to range between $40-$60 a barrel in the first half of the year.

site_title: Heathrow remains top European hub as Istanbul surges up rankings
summary: Heathrow remains Europe's top hub, serving 73.4 million travelers in 2014, with Paris Charles de Gaulle and Frankfurt retaining second and third places. Istanbul Ataturk jumped to fourth, driven by a 11% surge in passengers to 57 million, surpassing Madrid and Amsterdam Schiphol. Heathrow's growth lags behind European peers, with a 1.4% increase, while Istanbul's growth rate suggests it may rank third or second in 2015.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 1,745.00, up 2.99 points, with 1.93 billion lots traded, valued at RM2.3 billion. The market saw 497 gainers and 283 losers.

site_title: Swiss franc soars 29% against euro
summary: The Swiss franc surged 29% against the euro after Switzerland's central bank ended its three-year bid to artificially hold down the franc's value. The franc strengthened to 0.8517 immediately after the announcement. This move is seen as a significant shift in the country's monetary policy.

site_title: Dwindling growth options push Samsung to M&A
summary: Samsung Electronics may be considering a major acquisition, such as buying BlackBerry, due to dwindling growth options and declining profits in its mobile division. The company's earnings from its mobile business shrank last year, outsold by Apple's iPhones and Xiaomi's low-end smartphones. Samsung has offered up to $7.5 billion to acquire BlackBerry, which would create a new revenue stream and give Samsung access to advanced security features and encryption technologies. Analysts say Samsung may have no choice but to take big bets on acquisitions due to its lack of promising homegrown options.

site_title: Swiss exporters face 'tsunami' after SNB unexpectedly drops cap
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) unexpectedly dropped its cap on the Swiss franc, causing a significant surge in its value against the dollar and euro, resulting in a "tsunami" for Swiss exporters. Swiss watchmakers, such as Swatch and Richemont, and cement maker Holcim, saw their shares plummet as much as 21% and 9% respectively. The move poses a serious challenge for exporters, particularly those with high labor costs, and has led to the largest intraday decline in the Swiss Market Index since 2008.

images.alt_text: Swiss exporters including Swatch Group AG and Richemont slumped in Zurich trading after the central bank's decision to scrap its cap on the currency saw the Swiss franc jump more than 14 per cent against the dollar and euro.

site_title: Falling euro, energy costs widen eurozone surplus in November
summary: The eurozone widened its trade surplus in November to 20 billion euros, driven by a 1% increase in exports and a 2% decline in imports, largely due to a weaker euro and lower oil prices. This marks a significant improvement from the same period in 2013. Despite this positive trend, economists caution that foreign trade alone cannot revive the struggling economy, citing deflation and near-record unemployment. They also expect the European Central Bank to consider quantitative easing to stimulate growth.

site_title: Thai commercial banks to see average 7% growth in 2015 loans: central bank
summary: Thailand's commercial banks are expected to experience an average 7.0% loan growth in 2015, aligning with domestic economic growth, according to a central bank deputy governor. Loan growth for large-size banks is projected at 5-9%, while mid- and small-size banks are expected to average 10%. This growth is driven by loans to construction, property, and infrastructure, following a 5% growth rate in 2014, which was hindered by months of political unrest.

site_title: Keppel Singmarine bags S$265m contract to build ice-class vessel
summary: Keppel Singmarine has secured a S$265 million contract to build an ice-class multi-purpose vessel for New Orient Marine. The vessel, designed for operations in temperatures as low as -30 degree Celsius, will feature 'Ice Class Arc 5' notation and capabilities such as dynamic positioning and diving support functions. This is Keppel Singmarine's eighth ice-class vessel, with its orderbook currently standing at four. The contract marks a significant win for the company, which has built seven ice-class vessels for the Arctic and Caspian regions to date.

site_title: Ringgit gains most since 2013 as US data tempers Fed rate bets
summary: Malaysia's ringgit surged the most in over a year after US retail sales declined 0.9% in December, reducing expectations of a Federal Reserve interest-rate hike. This drop, combined with softer wages, led investors to pare bets on a rate hike by June. As a result, the ringgit rose 1.3% to its highest level since 2013.

site_title: Malaysia tycoon Ananda Krishnan in talks to take key stake in 1MDB US$3b IPO: sources
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB state firm is in talks with billionaire Ananda Krishnan to become a cornerstone investor in its US$3 billion IPO, with Krishnan potentially taking a 5% stake. This investment would boost 1MDB's funding and confidence among investors, who are concerned about the firm's debt pile and strategy. Krishnan, Malaysia's second-richest man, would use his investment to repay a US$562 million bridge loan, and the IPO is now likely to take place in the second quarter of this year.

site_title: Asian oil market contango boosts demand for crude, gasoline storage
summary: The Asian oil market is experiencing a contango, where near-delivery prices are higher than future months, boosting demand for crude and gasoline storage in Singapore. This has led to increased enquiries from tank farm companies and shipowners, with some deals reached for short-term storage. However, the profit from storing gasoline and gasoil is not sufficient to cover leasing costs, and other oil products, such as naphtha and fuel oil, are not yet seeing significant storage demand. The contango for Brent crude is expected to widen further as crude storage becomes more viable.

site_title: Asia-pacific crude-steady, Russia raises ESPO exports
summary: The Asia-Pacific crude market remained steady on Thursday, awaiting results of tenders for March-loading cargoes. Russia increased its ESPO crude exports to 71 cargoes in the first quarter, with 6 shipments going to Chinese buyers. Iraq plans to boost crude oil exports from southern ports in February, and South Korea's imports of Iranian crude oil fell 1.7% in December. Meanwhile, the number of oil wells drilled in the British North Sea fell to the lowest level in 15 years.

site_title: Thailand's December tourist arrivals up 11.8% year-on-year
summary: Thailand's tourist arrivals rose 11.76% in December to 2.84 million, marking the third consecutive month of growth. This follows a significant drop in June 2014, but recovery began in October with free visas for Chinese visitors. Tourism accounts for 10% of the Thai economy, with foreign arrivals increasing from 2.44 million in November. This growth is a positive sign for Thailand's economy after months of political unrest.

site_title: China's Xiaomi challenges iPhone 6 Plus with new flagship Mi Note
summary: China's Xiaomi Inc unveiled the flagship Mi Note, a large-screen phone rivaling Apple's iPhone 6 Plus, with a price tag of 2,299 yuan (S$495) compared to the iPhone's 3,500 yuan. The company, valued at $45 billion, aims to challenge Apple and Samsung as the world's No 3 smartphone maker. Xiaomi's CEO Lei Jun emphasized the phone's innovative features and seamless connectivity with home appliances, predicting a future where all devices will become smart devices.

site_title: Conflict trumps economy as top risk to world in Davos survey
summary: The World Economic Forum's annual survey of global hazards now ranks conflict as the top risk to countries and businesses in the coming decade, surpassing economic concerns. The survey, conducted by nearly 900 experts, highlights the pro-Russian separatist uprising in Ukraine, the rise of the Islamic State, and other geopolitical flashpoints as major threats. While economic concerns, such as deflation and decreased global growth, remain, they have taken a relative backseat to geopolitical risks. The survey's findings come ahead of the WEF's annual meeting in Davos, where the global elite will discuss the planet's future.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Thursday, following a recovery in Asia and after the previous day's sharp falls. London's FTSE 100 rose 1.09%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 climbed 1.19%, and Paris' CAC 40 gained 1.56%. The rebound came after deflation fears and tumbling commodity prices led to sharp declines on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Europe's main stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Thursday following a recovery in Asia and after the previous day's sharp falls.

site_title: China December bank loans post big miss, reliance on credit losing its potency
summary: China's banks issued far less credit in December than expected, despite a rate cut, as companies struggled to pay off existing debts and bad loans spiked. This weaker-than-expected loan data indicates Beijing's reliance on credit to spark the economy is losing its effectiveness, posing a challenge to policymakers. The move drives cash-starved companies into the shadow banking system, hindering the government's financial reform efforts.

site_title: Thailand to start US$12.2b railway project in September
summary: Thailand will begin constructing a US$12.2 billion railway project in September, spanning 873 km with two phases. The first phase will connect Bangkok to Saraburi and Saraburi to Rayong, while the second phase will link Saraburi to Korat province and Korat to Nong Khai. The project is expected to be completed within two and a half years, with 12-15 private companies interested in funding the project.

site_title: Gold holds below 12-week high as Asian shares climb
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,228.27 an ounce, below a 12-week high, as Asian equities rose and the dollar regained ground. The decline came despite disappointing US retail sales data, which typically boosts demand for safe-haven metals. Analysts expect gold prices to average $1,234 for the year, with some predicting a test of $1,215-20 in the coming days. The dollar's strength is seen as a ceiling for gold rallies, with lower US yields and concerns over global economic growth and deflation also weighing on the metal.

site_title: Productivity in Singapore must improve as firms pay higher wages in tight market: NTUC
summary: Singapore's labor market is expected to remain tight in 2015, with foreign manpower quotas shrinking, leading to pressure on companies to pay higher wages to retain talent. However, productivity must improve to ensure sustainable wage increases. NTUC forecasts a 4.1% basic wage increase in 2014, down from 4.63% in 2013. The union also flagged concerns over negative productivity growth, which could lead to wage stagnation. With 2,212 unionised workers retrenched in 2014, NTUC calls for alignment and collaboration with tripartite partners to raise productivity and income growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China widens definition of loan-to-deposit ratio
summary: China's central bank has expanded the definition of its loan-to-deposit ratio to include interbank deposits and lending for the first time, allowing banks to lend up to 75% of deposits. This change may boost the economy but could also curb the benefits of the wider definition of deposits. Analysts were surprised by the inclusion of loans from non-banking financial institutions, which could have a limited impact. The move is part of the government's efforts to support growth without a broad stimulus program, and banks' shares gained as a result.

site_title: Brokers' Take: OCBC keeps 'sell' call on Tiger Airways
summary: OCBC Investment Research maintained its "sell" call on Tiger Airways, citing it's too early to see material impact from its alliance with Scoot. The research note believes material impact could come until at least H2 FY2016. Despite this, the alliance is seen as positive for Tiger Airways' turnaround strategy. The airline's shares were trading at 25.5 Singapore cents apiece, down half a cent, following the announcement. OCBC left its fair value estimate for Tiger Airways at 18 Singapore cents a share.

site_title: BP to announce North Sea job cuts: BBC
summary: BP is expected to announce job cuts in its North Sea operations on Thursday, following a global restructuring plan announced in December. The British oil major employs nearly 4,000 people in the North Sea and a further 11,000 in the UK. The job cuts are part of BP's efforts to adapt to steep falls in oil prices.

images.alt_text: BP is expected to announce job cuts in its North Sea operations on Thursday, the BBC reported.

site_title: Seoul: Won trims losses, bonds slide after BOK keeps rates on hold; shares flat
summary: South Korea's central bank held interest rates steady, easing expectations of a rate cut. The won trimmed losses, closing at 1,083.3 to the dollar, while bond prices fell 24 basis points. Shares closed nearly unchanged, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rising 0.03%. The Bank of Korea cut economic growth and inflation forecasts, but maintained its confidence in a sustained recovery, reducing speculation of an imminent rate cut.

site_title: Fed saw consumer spending rise amid concern on cheaper oil
summary: The Federal Reserve's Beige Book report shows most US regions experienced "modest" or "moderate" economic growth driven by gains in consumer spending, despite oil prices plunging by over half since June. Retail sales rose 3.2% in December, with auto sales showing moderate to strong growth. Several districts expect faster growth over the coming months, while wage pressures were largely limited to specialized technical skills. The report provides anecdotal evidence for Fed officials as they consider raising interest rates for the first time since 2006.
