images.alt_text: Federal Reserve survey showed most regions saw "modest" or "moderate" economic growth driven by gains in consumer spending, while the energy-rich Dallas district slowed as oil prices plunged.

site_title: H&M December sales stronger than expected
summary: H&M reported stronger-than-expected December sales, with a 15% year-over-year increase, beating analyst expectations of a 13% increase. This marks the ninth consecutive month the company has met or exceeded sales forecasts, driven by a recovering US economy. The strong sales performance extends into the new fiscal year, with the company set to unveil detailed earnings for 2013/2014 on January 28.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close up on mainland policy prospect
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 1.0% to 24,350.91 points, following a surge on the Shanghai index, which experienced its biggest rise since January 5, driven by prospects of policy stimulus to support economic growth. The mutual market access pilot programme between Hong Kong and Shanghai saw Chinese investment flow in at 0.57 billion yuan (US$92.08 million). Stocks such as Bank Of China, China Construction Bank, and Hutchison Harbour Ring Ltd also saw significant gains.

site_title: Sydney siege declared terrorist act for insurance claims
summary: A fatal Sydney cafe siege in December was officially declared a terrorist incident, allowing businesses to make insurance claims. Iranian-born gunman Man Haron Monis, who had a history of extremism, took 17 hostages before being killed by police after 16 hours.

site_title: 'Reborn' Charlie Hebdo buries its dead
summary: Charlie Hebdo magazine, which was attacked and killed 12 people, has sold out of its "survivors' issue" and a print run of 5 million copies, sparking controversy over its depiction of the Prophet Mohammed. The magazine's editor, Stéphane Charbonnier, was killed in the attack. French President François Hollande declared Charlie Hebdo "reborn" and vowed to protect freedom of speech. The magazine's new edition, which features a cartoon of the Prophet with a tear in his eye, has sparked protests in some parts of the Muslim world.

site_title: China's Chengdu plans new US$11 billion airport to ease congestion
summary: China's Chengdu has received approval to build a new US$11.2 billion airport, expected to handle 40 million passengers annually by 2025, addressing congestion issues at the city's existing Shuangliu International Airport. This investment follows Beijing's recent US$14 billion airport construction project. The new airport will be the third major airport in China, after Beijing and Shanghai, aiming to alleviate delays and growing passenger frustration caused by congestion at major airports.

site_title: China having negative impact on global democracy, says Nathan
summary: China's pursuit of economic and security interests is negatively impacting global democracy, according to Andrew Nathan, a leading China scholar. Nathan notes China's success in co-opting its middle class and building modern infrastructure, which other authoritarian regimes are emulating. China's economic growth has also led to concerns it will "remake the world in its authoritarian image." Nathan, a professor of political science at Columbia University, is co-chair of the board of Human Rights in China and a member of the Advisory Committee of Human Rights Watch.

site_title: Singapore is Asia's third most expensive market for construction: report
summary: Singapore is Asia's third most expensive market for construction, according to the International Construction Cost Report, despite seeing significant cost reductions over the past year. The country dropped five places on the global ranking. Hong Kong is the most expensive market in Asia, followed by Macau. The report attributes the changes to currency fluctuations, commodity prices, and increasing demand in recovering economies.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Oil prices rally loses steam in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia on Thursday after a brief rally, with US benchmark WTI dropping 52 cents to $47.96 and Brent crude falling 62 cents to $48.07. The decline followed a surge in US commercial crude stocks to 5.4 million barrels, signaling weak demand. Analysts attribute the market's weakness to softer demand and an oversupply, with major producers maintaining production levels. The market may experience further volatility, with some analysts predicting a potential surge in prices.

site_title: Singapore's retail sales up 6.5% in November on robust car sales
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 6.5% in November, driven by a significant 50.2% increase in car sales. Excluding motor vehicle sales, retail sales would have decreased 0.4%. The total retail sales value for November reached S$3.2 billion, higher than the S$3.0 billion in 2013.

site_title: Australia investigating service stations for possible failure to pass on oil plunge
summary: Australia's Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) is investigating petrol stations for possible price fixing after accusing some of failing to pass on the huge oil price drop to consumers. The probe will target major players like Chevron and BP, and may impact large retailers like Woolworths and Coles. The ACCC has found the gap between regional and city petrol prices has tripled since July, with prices in regional areas lagging behind those in cities.

site_title: Congestion expected after Toyota green car orders soar
summary: Toyota has received over 1,500 orders for its hydrogen fuel-cell car, the Mirai, since its launch in mid-December, exceeding its initial 400 unit sales forecast for the year. The orders are mostly from government offices and corporate fleets, with a significant wait time expected for early buyers due to high demand. The Mirai has a 6.7 million yen price tag and can travel 650 kilometers without refuelling, with Toyota planning to sell more than 3,000 units in the US by 2017 and up to 100 in Europe annually.

site_title: French officials to visit India to rescue stalled Rafale jet deal
summary: A French delegation will visit India to try to salvage the stalled Rafale fighter jet deal, which has hit a snag over the local assembly of the planes. India wants France's Dassault Aviation to take full responsibility for production at a state-run facility in Bangalore. France will help with delivery schedules, but cannot guarantee production at a facility it has no control over. The deal, worth 126 jets, is one of the world's biggest defense agreements. The visit aims to resolve the issue and save the deal.

site_title: Sanctions-hit Russia in risky bet on Ukraine talks
summary: Russia, facing economic woes due to Western sanctions and falling oil prices, is engaging in a risky gamble in Ukraine talks, analysts say. Despite economic strain, Russia holds trump cards, including a potential longer-than-expected ability to withstand sanctions. Russia may be betting on Ukraine's financial crisis to weaken the West's resolve, while also leveraging its leverage on a US$3 billion loan to Ukraine. A short-term solution, such as self-governing zones in eastern Ukraine, may be the best hope for a peaceful resolution.

site_title: China: Stocks end sharply up on policy stimulus bets
summary: China's stocks surged 2.9% and 3.5% on the CSI300 and Shanghai Composite Index, respectively, as investors bet on policy stimulus following disappointing bank loan data. Analysts predicted the government would loosen policy, citing stabilized investor sentiment. The central bank's surprise interest rate cut was also seen as a factor. The rally is the largest daily increase since January 5.

images.alt_text: China stocks surged on Thursday with the Shanghai index experiencing its biggest daily rise since Jan 5, as investors bet on an increased chance of policy stimulus after disappointing bank loan data.

site_title: E-mail loses favour as Sony embarrassment changes worker habits
summary: Frontier Communications CEO Maggie Wilderotter advises employees to pick up the phone instead of sending emails for sensitive discussions due to recent hacking incidents, including the Sony breach in November. Companies are retraining workers to delete emails frequently, change passwords, and avoid sharing sensitive information via email. This shift is prompting employees to revert to phone calls and face-to-face meetings, promoting a sense of self-discipline and tightening security policies.

images.alt_text: Frontier Communications CEO Maggie Wilderotter had some advice for her top 10 executives last week as they discussed ways to prevent hacks like the one that exposed Sony Corp's e-mail secrets: Pick up the phone.

site_title: Update: Singapore's Ezra puts on hold US IPO plan for subsea unit
summary: Ezra Holdings Ltd, a Singapore-listed oilfield service company, has put on hold its plan to list its subsea services unit in the US due to unfavorable market conditions. The company cited a decline in crude oil prices and a drop in enterprise value-to-EBITDA ratios of comparable companies from 7-8 times to 3-4 times, prompting investors to sell shares of oil and gas companies. The move comes as the FT ST Oil & Gas index has lost 29% in the past six months.

site_title: Search firms define best practices to support gender diversity in board appointments
summary: Singapore's Diversity Action Committee (DAC) has partnered five executive search firms to define best practices for recruiting board directors, focusing on gender diversity. The firms should ensure 20-25% of candidates presented are women and encourage clients to interview at least one qualified female candidate. This initiative aims to rectify the under-representation of women on boards, following the recommendations of the Diversity Task Force, which examined the state of gender diversity on boards in Singapore.

site_title: Caesars Entertainment's operating unit files for bankruptcy
summary: Caesars Entertainment's operating unit filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy to cut $10 billion of debt. The company has the support of senior noteholders, reducing debt from $18.4 billion to $8.6 billion. This plan aims to restructure the unit's financial obligations and emerge from bankruptcy.

images.alt_text: The operating unit of Caesars Entertainment Corp, the largest US casino company, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy on Thursday to implement its plan to cut US$10 billion of debt.

site_title: LTA awards S$17m noise barrier installation contract to CKT Thomas
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) of Singapore has awarded a S$17 million contract to CKT Thomas to install 3.5km of noise barriers at nine locations, including tracks in Clementi and Eunos, to reduce railway noise levels by five to 10 decibels. The works are expected to be completed in mid-2017, with the entire 20km noise barrier programme targeted for completion by 2019.

site_title: Australia: Shares pare loses on better jobs data
summary: Australian shares pared losses and pulled back from lows on Thursday after robust jobs data and gains in energy-related shares. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 0.4% to 5,331.4, sustaining a weak start to the year. Despite the decline, the index came off lows led by gains in consumer staples and healthcare sectors. New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index also fell 0.12%. The benchmark is down 1.5% so far this month, marking the worst weekly performance since June 2013.

site_title: Uniqlo pledges to improve factory conditions in China
summary: Japanese clothing giant Uniqlo has pledged to improve working conditions at its Chinese suppliers and monitor factories following a study by Students and Scholars Against Corporate Misbehaviour (SACOM) that found unsafe and mistreated workers. Uniqlo's parent company, Fast Retailing, said it would cooperate with SACOM and check progress within a month. The company has instructed suppliers to reduce working hours, improve conditions, and change management styles. However, a Fast Retailing probe found some discrepancies with SACOM's findings, and the company has limited power to boost wages at the factories.

site_title: Europe: Shares track commodity bounce; Beiersdorf leads after sales
summary: European shares rebounded on Thursday, driven by a 2% rise in oil & gas companies and a 1.5% gain in basic resources companies, following a late Brent crude recovery and copper's climb to its highest level since 2009. Strong results from retailers H&M and Beiersdorf also contributed to the bounce. Despite volatility, investors are reassessing global growth prospects amid a slowdown in areas such as the euro zone and China.

images.alt_text: European shares rebounded on Thursday, boosted by a bounce in mining and oil companies, as well as by strong results at retailer H&M and Nivea cream-maker Beiersdorf.

site_title: India makes surprise interest rate cut to 7.75%
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) cut interest rates by 25 basis points to 7.75% in a surprise move, its first since March 2013, to boost the struggling economy. The decision aims to control inflation, which eased in recent months, and provide support to the economy. The RBI also kept the cash reserve ratio at 4.0% and reduced the reverse repo rate to 6.75%. The move is expected to increase lending and help kickstart the economy, which has been in a slowdown since the 1980s.

site_title: Divers hunt for victims in crashed AirAsia jet's main body
summary: Indonesian divers have begun searching the main body of the AirAsia jet that crashed on December 28, 162 people on board, in the Java Sea. The fuselage, believed to be the resting place of most victims, was located by a Singaporean ship on Wednesday. 50 bodies have been recovered so far, and divers hope to retrieve more victims. The crash occurred during a stormy flight from Surabaya to Singapore, and investigators are analyzing data from the flight data recorder and cockpit voice recorder to determine the cause.

site_title: Japan carrier Skymark hit by collapsed investment deal report
summary: Japan's budget airline Skymark saw its shares drop 7.95% after a report said talks about a capital injection deal with All Nippon Airways (ANA) had collapsed. The airline denied the report, stating it had not requested a capital injection and was instead exploring code-sharing agreements with ANA and Japan Airlines. Skymark has been struggling due to intense competition and a failed Airbus deal for A380 jets. The airline plans to try to climb out of the red on its own, despite efforts to secure investments.

site_title: Stable ratings continue for Asia-Pac structured finance tranches in Q4 2014: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings reported that 222 Asia-Pacific structured finance tranches were affirmed in Q4 2014, with no downgrades. Two Australian tranches were upgraded, while steady economic performance in India, Korea, and Singapore contributed to affirmations. Most long-term ratings in the region have stable outlooks, except for four Indian auto loan tranches and seven in Australia and Japan.

site_title: Singapore developers sold 230 private homes in December, against 423 in Nov '14
summary: Singapore developers sold 230 private homes in December, down from 423 in November 2014. This is in line with the 259 units sold in December 2013. Including executive condos, developers sold 406 units, down from 1,278 in November. The slower sales are attributed to fewer EC launches in December compared to November.

site_title: Broker's take: Nomura maintains 'buy' on SingTel
summary: Nomura maintains a "buy" call on SingTel, citing its steady business and management approach, despite unexciting financial performance. The telco's total return since 2010 stands at 53% with a 4-8% dividend yield. Key areas for improvement include Australian performance and regaining traction in the fixed segment through the National Broadband Network. SingTel's associates are expected to remain volatile, while Singapore is forecasted to remain steady.

site_title: Australia unemployment falls but still near decade-long highs
summary: Australia's unemployment rate fell to 6.1% in December, a slight decrease from the previous month, but remained near a decade-long high. The job market added 37,400 positions, with full-time jobs increasing by 41,600, while part-time roles eased by 4,100. Despite the better-than-expected figures, economists are cautious due to recent data adjustments and growing expectations of a Reserve Bank of Australia interest rate cut to boost the economy amid a shift away from mining-driven growth.

site_title: Singapore's Protection from Harassment Act 2014 now in force
summary: Singapore's Protection from Harassment Act 2014 has come into effect, strengthening harassment laws in the country. The Act considers harassment an offence, both online and offline, and applies to cases committed outside Singapore under certain conditions. Victims can now seek civil or criminal protection, with penalties ranging from fines to imprisonment for repeat offenders. The law provides a range of responses, including Protection Orders and monetary damages, and sets out specific penalties for convictions, including fines and imprisonment. The Act aims to enhance victim protection and deter harassment.

site_title: Facebook founder in Colombia to promote affordable Internet
summary: Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg visited Colombia to promote "Internet.org", a project to boost web availability in developing countries. The initiative, launched with Samsung and Nokia, aims to improve web access and reduce mobile phone costs. Zuckerberg stated that giving people connectivity tools is crucial for creating communication and promoting peace. The project's goal is to connect two-thirds of the world's unconnected population, with the first step being to improve internet access in Colombia.

site_title: China: Shares down in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares declined in morning trade on January 15, 2015, following overnight losses on Wall Street. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.19% to 3,216.22, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged down 0.03% to 1,445.48. The decline was attributed to global market trends.

site_title: Seoul: Won pares gains, bonds slide after BOK holds rates; shares lower
summary: The Bank of Korea held its policy base rate steady for a third consecutive month, as expected, but disappointed investors who had anticipated a rate cut. The won pared losses and treasury bonds fell, while South Korean shares edged lower. Investors remained cautious due to weak US economic data and falling commodity prices, rekindling concerns over global economic growth. A net outflow of foreign capital occurred for the fourth consecutive session, with brokerages underperforming.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.24% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.24% higher on Thursday, edging up 56.75 points to 24,169.35, despite a fourth consecutive day of losses on Wall Street. This marks a slight improvement in the market's performance, which had been impacted by global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore contractor to change plea in Navy bribery scheme
summary: A Singapore-based naval contractor, Leonard Glenn Francis, is changing his plea in a US Navy bribery scheme. Francis, nicknamed "Fat Leonard," is accused of bribing US Navy commanders with cash, gifts, and prostitutes to influence where ships docked. His company, Glenn Defense Marine, had contracts worth hundreds of millions of dollars. Three US Navy officials and two of Francis's employees have already pleaded guilty. Francis's change of plea is scheduled for tomorrow in federal court in San Diego.

site_title: Hot Stock: Keppel DC Reit most active Singapore Reit, gets outperform call from Credit Suisse
summary: Keppel DC Reit, the recently-listed pure data centre Reit, is the most actively traded Reit in Singapore, with over 8 million units changing hands. Credit Suisse has initiated coverage on the Reit with an outperform call, citing its unique exposure to the growing data centre market and favourable industry fundamentals. The Reit's yield is currently at 6.6% and analysts expect future upside from incremental acquisitions. Credit Suisse targets a price of S$1.10 per unit.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Divers search for bodies in fuselage of crashed AirAsia jet
summary: Indonesian navy divers searched for bodies in the fuselage of the crashed AirAsia jet, located 3 km from the aircraft's tail, which was recovered from the Java Sea two weeks ago. The AirAsia jet, carrying 162 people, lost contact with air traffic control on December 28 during a flight from Surabaya to Singapore. The cause of the crash remains unknown, with divers continuing the search for remains.

images.alt_text: Indonesian navy divers searched for bodies on Thursday in the fuselage of an AirAsia airliner that crashed into the sea more than two weeks ago, killing all 162 people on board.

site_title: China to create US$6.5b venture capital fund to support startups
summary: China plans to establish a US$6.5 billion government venture capital fund to support startups in emerging industries, including technology and green energy. The fund will be funded by government capital and state corporates, with private partners invited to participate. This move aims to foster innovation and support the private sector, helping China's economy evolve towards the medium and high ends. The fund's establishment is a significant step in China's efforts to promote its venture capital market, which remains small due to decades of restrictions on private sector development.

site_title: McDonald's Australian experiment is to look less like McDonald's
summary: McDonald's Australia is testing a new concept, "The Corner", a cafe-like restaurant with healthier options and table service, to compete with fast-casual chains. The company also operates a traditional McDonald's outlet with "build your own" burgers. Experts say McDonald's is adapting to changing consumer preferences, with Australia being a key test market. The company has around 930 restaurants in Australia, serving 1.7 million customers daily, and is gauging customer feedback to enhance its offerings nationwide.

site_title: China investigates Shanghai officials' lavish banquet before stampede
summary: Chinese authorities are investigating allegations that officials attended a lavish New Year's Eve banquet in Shanghai before a deadly stampede, where dozens were trampled to death. The banquet, held at a government-owned Japanese restaurant, cost an estimated $305-$628 per person. This comes as President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption crackdown gains momentum, with officials taking allegations of corruption seriously. An investigation is underway, according to the Shanghai Municipal Disciplinary Inspection Committee.

site_title: CIMB and RHB shares up, MBSB down, on bank-merger cancellation
summary: Shares of CIMB Group Holdings Bhd and RHB Capital Bhd rose 3.8% and 2.6% respectively after cancelling plans for a three-way merger with Malaysia Building Society Bhd. The merger would have created the country's largest bank by assets. CIMB's shares reached their highest point since November 20, while MBSB fell 3.2%. The cancellation comes after the banks failed to seal a "value creating transaction."

site_title: Singapore: Shares open up on Thursday
summary: Singapore share prices opened up on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index rising 5.53 points to 3,331.69. Gainers outnumbered losers 72 to 53, driven by the 0.4% gain on the STI. Investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: BlackBerry shares jump on Samsung takeover rumours
summary: BlackBerry shares surged 30% on Wednesday following reports of a potential takeover by Samsung. The Canadian smartphone maker's share price rose US$2.89 to close at US$12.60 on the Nasdaq. However, analysts remain bearish on BlackBerry, predicting significant losses despite improving hardware sales. Tech analyst Carl Simard questioned Samsung's interest in BlackBerry, citing the company's security encryption as having limited value to Samsung's consumer-oriented smartphones.

site_title: Australia employment surges in Dec, tugs jobless down
summary: Australia's employment surged 37,400 in December, exceeding forecasts and lowering the jobless rate to a four-month low of 6.1%. Full-time work rose 41,600, while the unemployment rate fell despite a rise in participation. The Australian dollar strengthened, and investors scaled back expectations for further interest rate cuts. Leading indicators suggest an improvement in labor demand, and wages growth remains slow, indicating a benign outlook for inflation.

site_title: Samsung Elec says has no plan to acquire Blackberry
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd denied a Reuters report on a potential acquisition of BlackBerry Ltd, stating that media reports of the acquisition are "groundless." Samsung reportedly offered to buy BlackBerry for up to $7.5 billion to acquire its valuable patents, but BlackBerry said it had not engaged in discussions with Samsung.

site_title: China's credit growth surges as interest-rate cut spurs lending
summary: China's broadest measure of new credit exceeded economists' estimates in December, reaching 1.69 trillion yuan (US$273 billion). The People's Bank of China attributed this surge to interest-rate cuts, which began in November. New local-currency loans were 697.3 billion yuan, and M2 money supply grew 12.2% from a year earlier. This data suggests government efforts to spur lending are starting to take effect, but experts caution that monetary policy must strike a balance between growth, risk reduction, and deleveraging.

site_title: Volatile oil dips as high US stocks underline global oversupply
summary: Crude oil prices dipped in early Asian trade on Thursday, falling 56 cents to $48.13 a barrel, after a 4.5% surge in Brent crude futures the previous day. The surge was attributed to traders covering expiring options, but the market remains bearish due to a global oversupply. US crude stockpiles rose to 5.4 million barrels, exceeding expectations, and analysts predict Brent prices will range between $40 and $60 a barrel in the first half of the year.

site_title: Taiwan's Chu to take over ruling party, seen balancing China policy
summary: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) party is set to appoint Eric Chu as its leader, a move seen as a balancing act to distance himself from China while maintaining commercial ties. Chu, 53, faces the challenge of improving the party's image and winning back domestic support. As the party's candidate for the presidency, Chu's success is crucial, with China reportedly comfortable with his leadership and seeking to build mutual trust. The move comes after a series of protests against China's influence in Taiwan, and Beijing hopes Chu can turn things around.

images.alt_text: Eric Chu will take over as leader of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) on Saturday, inheriting an unpopular party seen as favouring big business and the mainland at a time of growing scepticism about ties with Beijing.

site_title: Oil slips after rebound, dollar recovers against yen
summary: Oil prices slid in Asia after a brief rally, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate losing 32 cents to $48.16 and Brent falling 29 cents to $48.40. The dollar recovered against the yen after plummeting in New York due to disappointing US retail sales data. The US stock market also fell, with the Dow losing 1.06% and the S&P 500 shedding 0.58%. The World Bank cut its global growth forecast, citing a US recovery not enough to boost other economies, but the Federal Reserve reported modest growth in the US economy.

site_title: Road closure at Paterson Road due to oil spillage
summary: A road closure on Paterson Road in Singapore has been in effect since 3.48am on January 15, 2015, due to an oil spillage. The affected area is between Orchard Road and Orchard Boulevard, in front of Orchard Ion, towards Kim Seng Road. The cause of the spillage is not specified.

site_title: Fast Retailing vows steps against labour abuses at China plants
summary: Fast Retailing, the parent company of Uniqlo, has vowed to improve working conditions at two Chinese factories, Dongguan Tomwell Garment and Pacific Textiles, following an investigation by an advocacy group. The company will ask factories to eliminate fines, increase holidays, provide protective clothing, and monitor air quality. Fast Retailing will also establish a union at one of the factories and conduct regular audits with third-party organizations to ensure progress. This move comes as the company seeks to boost sales in China and other international markets.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 6.26 points to 1747.54. The index saw 43 million lots traded worth RM31.89 million, with 88 gainers for every 69 losers.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on global growth worries, slide in copper
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Thursday, continuing a losing streak, amid global growth concerns and a copper price drop. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 32.5 points to 5,321.1, its worst weekly performance since June 2013. Financials and resource stocks led the decline, while consumer staples and energy shares rose. The World Bank's cut to global growth forecasts for 2015 and 2016 added to investor worries.

site_title: Update: Chinese taxi app gains US$600m investment from Softbank, Alibaba
summary: SoftBank Corp and Alibaba Group Holding Ltd have invested approximately $600 million in Travice Inc, the operator of Chinese taxi hailing app Kuaidi Dache. This investment, which marks the bulk contribution from SoftBank, aims to fuel further growth for Kuaidi Dache, a leading player in China's mobile taxi booking industry. Alibaba already holds an undisclosed stake in Kuaidi, and the investment is part of SoftBank's strategy to expand in the taxi hailing app market, following significant investments in GrabTaxi and Ola last year.

site_title: US man arrested over IS-inspired plot to attack Capitol
summary: A US man, Christopher Cornell, 20, was arrested for allegedly plotting an attack on the US Capitol inspired by Islamic State jihadists. He purchased semi-automatic weapons and ammunition in Ohio, and posted messages on Twitter supporting IS militants. Cornell told an informant he planned to launch attacks targeting US officials in Washington and members of Congress, and intended to use firearms to kill employees and officials. He had been under FBI surveillance since August 2014. Cornell faces charges of attempting to kill officers and employees of the US and possession of a firearm to carry out violent acts.

site_title: China's yuan pauses after 4-day rising streak
summary: China's yuan paused after a four-day rising streak, consolidating investor positions ahead of data showing the economy's slowest pace in 24 years. The yuan rose to 6.1193 per dollar, but then weakened to 6.1957 in late morning trades, 1.25% weaker than the midpoint. Data on Thursday showed slower-than-expected bank lending in December, indicating headwinds in the property sector and bloated debt. China's GDP growth is expected to average around 7% this year, but data next week will likely show the economy expanding at its slowest pace in 24 years.

images.alt_text: China's yuan took a breather on Thursday after gaining for four consecutive days as investors consolidated positions ahead of data next week that will likely show the economy expanded at its slowest pace in 24 years.

site_title: US eyes India drone, C-130 project deals for Obama trip
summary: US Undersecretary of Defense Frank Kendall will discuss joint production of drones and equipment for transport planes with Indian officials during President Barack Obama's visit to India. The talks aim to finalize two pilot projects, one involving the RQ-11 "Raven" drone and the other involving systems for the C-130 military transport aircraft. The US seeks to develop its ties with India, which shares concerns about China's territorial claims in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 0.46%
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.46% higher on Thursday, following two days of losses, as the dollar rebounded against the yen. The Nikkei 225 index rose to 16,872.95 after a weak US retail sales report and a global economic forecast from the World Bank. The dollar bounced back from a low of 116.08 yen on Wednesday, while US oil prices surged over 5% due to bargain-hunting.

site_title: Australia dollar rallies as strong jobs data curbs rate talk
summary: The Australian dollar surged nearly one percent to US$0.8213 after strong jobs data in December, exceeding forecasts of a small gain. The data showed 37,400 new jobs created, with unemployment dipping to 6.1% from 6.2%. This led the Reserve Bank to scale back interest rate cut expectations, with bond yields rising and Australian debt futures edging lower. Market expectations for a rate cut by July also shifted, with ANZ Bank revising its forecast to two 25 basis-point cuts this year.

site_title: Facebook testing workplace version of social network
summary: Facebook is testing a workplace version of its social network, dubbed "Facebook at Work," which allows companies to use the platform for professional collaboration instead of personal networking. The pilot program, available to a few select companies, features news feeds, chats, groups, and other social media tools, but with restrictions on sharing with non-employees. The platform is hosted on Facebook's servers and companies control their own data. Facebook plans to refine the offering based on user feedback and may charge subscriptions as a cloud-based service.

site_title: Chinese taxi app gains US$600m investment from Softbank, Alibaba: source
summary: Travice Inc, a Chinese taxi-hailing application operator, has received a US$600 million investment from SoftBank, Alibaba, and others. The investment, valued at 70 billion yen, was first reported by the Nikkei business daily. This funding follows SoftBank's investments in other taxi-hailing apps, including ANI Technologies Pvt Ltd and GrabTaxi.

site_title: Sng Ngoi May retires from SPH, takes on adviser role in retail property management
summary: Sng Ngoi May, 69, retires as SPH's executive vice-president of retail property management, taking on an adviser role starting Feb 1. With 34 years of service, she previously held positions including director of Orchard 290 Ltd and chairman of the Orchard Road Business Association. SPH CEO Alan Chan praised May's dedication, saying she helped build a solid foundation for the company's property portfolio. May will continue to contribute to SPH as an adviser.

site_title: British hospital says has suspected Ebola case
summary: A woman suspected of having Ebola was being treated at Northampton General Hospital in central England, where doctors were taking precautions. This comes after a British nurse, Pauline Cafferkey, was diagnosed with Ebola in London last month while volunteering in Sierra Leone. The global Ebola death toll has reached 8,429 out of 21,296 reported cases, according to the World Health Organization. The hospital has not confirmed the woman's travel history, but is taking precautions.

site_title: South Korea central bank keeps interest rates unchanged in Jan, as expected
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, kept interest rates unchanged at 2.00% for a third consecutive month, in line with expectations. The decision was made to monitor the country's economic recovery and euro zone troubles. Analysts had predicted a rate hold, with some expecting a potential cut in the coming months. The Bank of Korea's governor, Lee Ju-yeol, is set to hold a news conference later.

images.alt_text: South Korea's central bank kept interest rates unchanged for a third straight month on Thursday, in line with expectations, as it monitors the ongoing recovery at home along with euro zone troubles and falling oil prices.

site_title: China new Dec bank lending well below forecasts but up 10% in 2014
summary: China's banks extended 697.3 billion yuan (US$112.55 billion) in new loans in December, below market expectations, despite central bank instructions to support the slowing economy. The central bank reported a 12.2% increase in the Broad M2 money supply measure, below the expected 12.5%. For the full year, new local-currency loans reached 9.78 trillion yuan, a 10% increase from 2013.

images.alt_text: Chinese banks extended 697.3 billion yuan (US$112.55 billion) in new loans in December, well below market expectations despite instructions from the central bank to lend more in the last months of 2014 to support the slowing economy.

site_title: Stocks to watch: LCD Global, SIA, Popular
summary: Several stocks made significant announcements on Thursday. LCD Global Investments resumed trading after canceling a rights issue proposal, while Singapore Airlines stopped offering re-employment to captains over 62. Scoot and Tiger Airways deepened their cooperation, and Popular Holdings' CEO attempted to take the company private with a voluntary cash offer. The Singapore Stock Exchange Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor positivity despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda says economy recovering moderately
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated the economy is recovering moderately, with the pain from a sales tax hike subsiding. The BOJ will maintain quantitative and qualitative easing to achieve and maintain 2% inflation. This stance has been steady since October last year, preventing weak demand and slumping oil prices from delaying deflation.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said on Thursday the economy is recovering moderately as a trend with the pain from a sales tax hike in April subsiding.

site_title: DBS in tie-up to set up consumer finance company in China
summary: DBS Bank has agreed to set up a consumer finance company in China, China Post Consumer Finance Company Limited, in partnership with Postal Savings Bank of China and five other Chinese corporates. DBS will invest 120 million yuan (S$25.83 million) for a 12% stake, making it the second largest shareholder. The company will be registered in Guangzhou city and aims to provide consumer finance services in China.

site_title: Deutsche Bank mulls retail float, tie with foreign banks: source
summary: Deutsche Bank is considering splitting off its retail division and listing it on the stock exchange if lawmakers approve measures to isolate risky trading activities. The bank would keep investment banking and asset management, and potentially join forces with a foreign partner to compete in Germany's consumer banking market. This move is seen as a response to regulators' potential restrictions on bank ownership. The consideration is at a theoretical stage, and the bank has not ruled out selling its Postbank-branded retail unit.

site_title: Offshore wind would boost jobs, energy more than oil: study
summary: A study by Oceana found that developing offshore wind technology in the Atlantic Ocean would produce twice the energy and job growth as drilling for oil. The report states that 20 years of offshore wind in the Atlantic could generate nearly five billion barrels of oil equivalents, compared to all economically recoverable oil and gas. Offshore wind could also lead to 91,000 more jobs than offshore drilling over the next two decades.

site_title: Japan Nov core machinery orders rise 1.3% m-o-m
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 1.3% in November from the previous month, lower than the forecasted 5.0% increase. This follows a 6.4% decline in October and a 14.6% year-over-year decline. The Cabinet Office lowered its assessment of machinery orders, indicating a stalling recovery. The data suggests capital expenditure among manufacturers could weaken, posing a risk to the economy.

site_title: Ascott continues global expansion, on track to achieve target
summary: Ascott, a serviced residence business unit of CapitaLand, plans to open over 20 properties globally this year, with locations in China, India, Indonesia, and other countries. This marks a continuation of its expansion strategy, which added 28 properties with 4,800 units to its portfolio in 2014. Ascott secured franchises in Vientiane and Bali and formed alliances in China and Australia to accelerate growth.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Spain's Catalonia to hold regional vote Sept 27 amid independence drive
summary: Catalonia, a wealthy Spanish region, will hold a regional parliament election on September 27, with the vote seen as a proxy for a referendum on independence. The election is amid a deeply divisive issue, with Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy opposing secessionist ambitions. A majority of people in Catalonia would likely vote to stay part of Spain, according to a recent poll. The vote is a few months before Spain's general election and reignites tensions over Catalonia's status within or without Spain.

site_title: UK house price growth slowest since May 2013: RICS
summary: British house prices rose at their slowest annual pace since May 2013, with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) reporting a +11 house price balance in December, down from +13 in November. The housing market has been slowing since mid-2014 due to tighter lending rules and a looming national election. This marks the slowest annual growth in house prices since May 2013.

images.alt_text: British house prices rose at their slowest annual pace since May 2013 at the end of last year, as tighter lending rules and a looming national election weighed on buyer demand, an industry body said on Thursday.

site_title: GIC, Ironbridge plan IPO of Australian car-lease firm FleetPartners
summary: Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC and Australian private equity firm Ironbridge Capital plan to list Australian car-leasing firm FleetPartners Ltd in an initial public offering (IPO) valued at approximately US$615 million. The IPO, expected as early as April, would involve selling between 50-80% of the company. FleetPartners manages over 50,000 vehicles across Australia and New Zealand, operating in a competitive industry with potential for consolidation.

site_title: Cyprus Airways name, logo up for sale
summary: The Cypriot government is selling the name and logo of national carrier Cyprus Airways, shut down last week after breaking EU state aid rules. The goal is to create jobs for 550 axed staff and increase connectivity. A precondition is that the new airline must be based in Cyprus, with no immediate investor interest. The government has pledged full compensation to all axed staff. The sale will be overseen by legal and financial advisers, and the commercial value of the airline's name and logo will depreciate over time.

site_title: US economy continues broad expansion: Fed report
summary: The US economy continued its broad expansion in recent weeks, with moderate job growth from mid-November to late December, according to the Federal Reserve's Beige Book. However, wages did not see upward pressure, with significant wage increases limited to workers with specialized technical skills. Despite the best annual job creation since 1999, the continued minimal growth in wages has raised concerns for Fed officials. The Fed's policy arm suggests the first interest rate hike could come in April, but some analysts argue it may be delayed due to soft wage gains.

images.alt_text: The US economy kept up "modest" or "moderate" growth in recent weeks, although lower oil prices were hitting the Dallas region, according to a Federal Reserve report released Wednesday.

site_title: BlackBerry may be valued as if still smartphone king
summary: Samsung Electronics Co. is reportedly valuing BlackBerry Ltd. at $7.1 billion, equivalent to 24 times its trailing 12-month earnings, in an initial takeover offer price of $13.35 to $15.49 per share. This valuation is a multiple of 1.9 on a revenue basis, the highest since 2011. BlackBerry's market share has shrunk to about 1% since its peak, prompting analyst Roger Entner to question the value of such an acquisition, stating it's "a lot of money for a company that's not going anywhere."

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics Co. may be valuing BlackBerry Ltd. like it's still the leader in smartphones.

site_title: Comedian to stand trial as France cracks down on hate speech
summary: Controversial French comedian Dieudonne was arrested and will stand trial for suggesting sympathy with one of the Paris attackers who killed 17 people in a three-day shooting spree. The arrest is part of 54 cases opened since the attacks, amid a debate on the limits of free speech. Dieudonne's lawyer says the arrest is "shocking" and that his client is a victim of government overreach. Prosecutors argue that Dieudonne's post condoned terrorism, while critics say the comedian's rights are being unfairly restricted.

site_title: Ex-SAC's Kumin said to gather US$1b for hedge fund startup
summary: Solomon Kumin, former chief operating officer of SAC Capital Advisors, is gathering US$1 billion in capital for his hedge fund firm, Folger Hill Asset Management, set to start trading in March. Kumin, 39, joined forces with Todd Rapp and Gabriel Plotkin, and plans to hire up to three money managers per year. The firm will charge 10-20% of profits to clients, with a management fee of 15-20% after raising $1 billion. Kumin left SAC after a decade, following the firm's record fine for insider trading.

images.alt_text: Solomon Kumin(right), who was chief operating officer of billionaire Steven A. Cohen's SAC Capital Advisors, is on track to gather US$1 billion (S$1.33 billion) for his hedge fund firm when it starts trading in March, according to a person familiar with the matter.

site_title: Oil surges 5% on options expiry; bounce seen fleeting
summary: Oil prices surged 5% on Wednesday, the biggest gain in two-and-a-half years, as traders covered expiring options and rebounded from a nearly six-year low. US and Brent crude rallied $2 each, with US crude reaching its strongest daily percentage gain since August 2012. The rebound is seen as a temporary correction in the seven-month slump, with some analysts cautious about a potential floor. Low prices may finally slow US oil production growth, a key factor in the market.

site_title: Britain rejects bid to force energy companies to pass on oil price drop
summary: British lawmakers rejected a Labour Party bid to force energy companies to lower prices when wholesale costs fall, with 305 votes to 228. Energy Minister Ed Davey argued that the proposals would damage competition and increase consumer bills. The move comes as a steep drop in oil prices has revived the debate about living costs, with only one energy firm, E.ON, having cut prices so far. Labour promised to bring in laws if they win the May 7 election, but the government opposed the plan, citing concerns about increased uncertainty and higher prices.

site_title: China's CRCC likely to win in new bid for Mexico train project: sources
summary: China's CRCC is likely to win a contract to build a $3.75 billion high-speed train system in Mexico, despite its original winning bid being revoked due to a political scandal. The new bidding process, with a July 14 deadline, remains the same, and CRCC is favored due to its broad financing plan, cheap technology, and political support in Mexico. The Mexican government has denied the process was designed to benefit the Chinese, but CRCC is expected to clinch the contract, potentially partnering with a less controversial Mexican builder.

site_title: BlackBerry denies Samsung takeover report
summary: BlackBerry has denied a report that Samsung is in takeover talks with the Canadian smartphone maker. Following the report, BlackBerry's shares initially jumped 30% before falling back to $10.53. The company stated it has not engaged in discussions with Samsung and is "aware of certain press reports." Analysts remain bearish on BlackBerry, setting targets of $7 to $10 for its stock, citing expected significant losses despite new product launches. Tech analyst Carl Simard questioned Samsung's interest in BlackBerry due to its security encryption, which may not add value to Samsung's consumer-oriented smartphones.

site_title: In cyberattacks such as Sony strike, Obama turns to "name and shame"
summary: The US government, under President Barack Obama, has adopted a new policy to respond to cyberattacks by "name and shaming" countries suspected of involvement. This approach involves publicly blaming the country and warning of potential consequences, such as sanctions or trade complaints. The policy shift was prompted by the destructive cyberattack on Sony Pictures Entertainment, which was blamed on North Korea. The US Justice Department is considering indictments related to the attack, and the "name and shame" campaign has sparked conversations with companies about hacking incidents.

site_title: UK company watchdog to study boards, investor advisers
summary: Britain's Financial Reporting Council (FRC) will study corporate boards to determine if they are improving business standards and providing investors with best advice on voting at annual meetings. The FRC's 2014 review found failings, with boards needing to better assess their company's culture, especially under pressure. FRC Chairman Win Bischoff emphasized the need for boards to think critically about their culture and make improvements.

site_title: US risk council to discuss reforms for designating risky firms
summary: The US Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC) will hold a public meeting on January 21 to discuss potential reforms to its process for designating financially risky firms. This comes after MetLife sued the panel over its decision to designate the insurer as a systemically important financial institution (SIFI), sparking concerns over the FSOC's flawed process. The FSOC had previously announced plans to consider changes to its process after critics, including MetLife, accused the panel of having a flawed methodology. The meeting aims to address these concerns and potentially overhaul the SIFI designation process.

images.alt_text: The US risk council will hold a public meeting next week to discuss potential reforms to its process for deciding which financial firms should be designated as systemically important.

site_title: Do not be so suspicious, China tells Taiwan over new air routes
summary: China has told Taiwan not to be so suspicious of its intentions after Taipei protested against Beijing's decision to open new domestic commercial air routes over the Taiwan Strait. The routes, set to take effect on March 5, could increase flight-safety risks, particularly around Taiwan's outlying islands. China deems Taiwan a renegade province and has not ruled out force to take it back if the island makes a move toward independence. The US supports a "one China" policy but emphasizes maintaining international aviation safety.

site_title: Rural India slowdown threatens Modi's promise of "better days"
summary: India's rural economy is experiencing a slowdown, threatening Prime Minister Narendra Modi's promise of "better days" for the country's poor. A shift in government spending and lower prices for crops are contributing to the hardship, with over 800 million people living in rural areas accounting for 35% of the economy. Tractor sales have plummeted, and consumer goods firms are also reporting weak sales. Modi's nationalist party faces a test of support in upcoming state polls, particularly in Bihar, where many rural poor live. The slowdown is also affecting Modi's plans to invest in infrastructure and skills to boost long-term growth.

site_title: Facebook launches mobile app offering free Internet in Colombia
summary: Facebook has launched a mobile app offering free internet access to Colombian users through its Internet.org service, in partnership with local mobile phone provider Tigo. The app provides access to a handful of online services, including Wikipedia, weather websites, and Facebook's social network. The goal is to boost internet usage in developing markets, with the aim of expanding the service across Latin America. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg sees the service as a way to "build prosperity" and aid in creating peace in Colombia, where 50 years of war have ended.

site_title: Samsung approaches BlackBerry about buyout: source
summary: Samsung has approached BlackBerry about a potential buyout worth up to $7.5 billion, offering $13.35 to $15.49 per share, representing a 38-60% premium over the current trading price. The deal would give Samsung access to BlackBerry's patent portfolio, which could help it compete with Apple. BlackBerry's CEO John Chen has regained some market share, but the company still faces challenges. A deal would need the approval of Fairfax Financial Holdings, a major shareholder led by Prem Watsa.

site_title: US House passes security funding bill blocking immigration actions
summary: US House Republicans passed a security funding bill blocking President Barack Obama's executive immigration initiatives, which includes provisions to block deportations of undocumented immigrants and reverse Obama's 2012 initiative to defer deportation actions against young undocumented immigrants. The bill, which provides $39.7 billion for Homeland Security, could hamper Republican efforts to boost their appeal among Hispanic voters in the 2016 presidential election. The bill faces potential veto by Obama and may not pass the Senate, where Democrats have a 54-46 majority.

site_title: Turkey blocks Charlie Hebdo websites as anger rises in Islamic world
summary: A Turkish court ordered the block of websites featuring the Charlie Hebdo front cover that depicts the Prophet Mohammed, amid growing anger in the Islamic world. The court's decision, in response to a single lawyer's petition, aims to prevent the spread of the satirical image. The image was published after a gunman attacked Charlie Hebdo's offices, killing 12 people. The move reflects the increasing tensions between the Islamic world and Western satire.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall on deflation fears
summary: Europe's major stock markets plummeted on Wednesday as deflation fears intensified, with the FTSE 100 falling 2.35% and the DAX 30 dropping 1.25%. Copper prices plummeted to a six-year low, and mining shares suffered significantly. Despite a cautious green light for quantitative easing from the European Court of Justice, the European Central Bank faces mounting pressure to act against deflation. The euro firmed against the US dollar, and oil prices remained near six-year lows.

site_title: Tigerair, Scoot deepen cooperation
summary: Scoot and Tigerair Singapore have strengthened their partnership, with the number of passengers connecting between flights doubling since August last year. The carriers now offer two routes flown in parallel and are exploring further collaboration, including seamless booking, common ground handling, and joint promotions. Scoot's CEO Campbell Wilson and Tigerair's CEO Lee Lik Hsin expressed optimism about the partnership, citing increased convenience and flight options for customers. The partnership has also led to significant early benefits, including a rise in connecting passenger volumes.

site_title: Charlie Hebdo issue offered on eBay for thousands of euros
summary: Copies of Charlie Hebdo's sold-out edition are being offered on eBay for thousands of euros, prompting criticism from a media watchdog. One vendor listed the issue at 15,000 euros, significantly higher than the cover price of three euros. The authenticity of the offers and the actual possession of the copies are unknown.

site_title: GM sees improved profit in 2015 on China, US growth
summary: General Motors forecasts improved 2015 operating profit due to growth in China and the US. The company expects modest global vehicle sales growth, which will help it post improved results in all regions. GM reaffirms its 2016 targets, including 10% profit margins in North America and a return to profitability in Europe. The company also plans to boost capital spending by 20% to $9 billion and introduce new designs, with 25% of vehicles sold in 2015 coming from new and refreshed models.

site_title: Kaisa bondholders seek advice as Moody's forecasts losses
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings, a Chinese developer, is facing a grim outlook for its offshore bond investors due to missed coupon payments and significant onshore creditor demands. Moody's has predicted substantial losses and downgraded Kaisa to "Ca" with a negative outlook. The company is seeking restructuring advice and has hired law firms to represent its bondholders. Kaisa's assets have been frozen, and its bank accounts are under review, with investors expecting substantial losses.

site_title: Charlie Hebdo flies off shelves as Al-Qaeda claims attack
summary: Charlie Hebdo published a new issue featuring a cartoon of the Prophet Mohammed with a tear in his eye, selling out across France in record time after last week's deadly attack on its cartoonists. Al-Qaeda claimed responsibility for the attack, which killed 12 people, including some of France's best-loved cartoonists. French President Francois Hollande said "Charlie Hebdo is alive and will live on," while critics, including some global Muslim leaders, have criticized the new cartoon. The issue has raised tensions, but many have taken a nuanced stance, urging calm and avoiding emotive reactions.

site_title: Google partners with auto suppliers on self-driving car
summary: Google partners with top automakers and suppliers to develop self-driving cars, aiming to bring them to market by 2020. The company is discussing partnerships with General Motors, Ford, Toyota, Daimler, and Volkswagen, and is developing and refining self-driving systems with suppliers like Continental and Robert Bosch. Google's self-driving prototype cars, built by Roush, will have a "test driver" on board but no human intervention in steering or braking. The company's goal is to extend transportation options to blind, elderly, and disabled individuals.

images.alt_text: General Motors headquarters is seen in the Renaissance Center in Detroit, Michigan.

site_title: Slowdown, US problems prompt Philips' Q4 profit warning
summary: Philips, a Dutch industrial company, has warned of a weaker-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings due to a manufacturing plant closure in Cleveland, Ohio, and a slowdown in major markets. The company expects adjusted earnings before interest, taxation, and amortization (Ebita) of 735 million euros, down from previous estimates. Philips plans to focus on its healthcare division, which accounts for 40% of sales, and is making progress in attracting external investors for its automotive components business.

site_title: US: Wall St ends down for 4th day on global growth worries
summary: US stocks fell for a fourth day, with the S&P 500 down 0.58% to 2,011.27, as a World Bank forecast fueled concerns about global economic weakness and copper prices sank. The S&P energy index rebounded late in the day, while materials and financial sectors fell over 1%. US retail sales dropped 0.8% in December, adding to investor concerns. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.06% to 17,427.09, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.48% to 4,639.32.

site_title: US sees gap between trends in car sales and regulatory demands
summary: US carmakers face a disconnect between consumer demand and government emissions regulations, with big trucks, SUVs, and luxury cars selling well despite efforts to meet the 54.5-mpg fuel economy target by 2025. Executives, including Fiat Chrysler Automobiles CEO Sergio Marchionne, say cheap petrol is driving sales of gas-guzzling vehicles, making it harder to comply with regulations. The EPA expects carmakers to shift to electric and hybrid vehicles, but some industry officials suggest the government could relax rules to allow mileage credits for advanced safety systems.

images.alt_text: A Smart Electric Drive Coupe on display at the international car show in Detroit. The US EPA expects carmakers to shift 2 per cent of their fleets to electric vehicles to comply with regulations.

site_title: Country Garden looks to cut risk with more non-dollar debt
summary: Country Garden Holdings, a Chinese property developer, plans to reduce its reliance on dollar-denominated debt by raising funds in other currencies. The company aims to issue at least 10 billion yuan (S$2.16 billion) of medium-term notes in China, which are cheaper than bank loans. This move is part of Country Garden's efforts to cut risks and access lower financing costs. The company expects 10% growth in contract sales this year, driven by a healthier property market and government policies supporting GDP growth.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Keppel DC Reit has been initiated with an "Outperform" rating by Credit Suisse Equity Research, with a target price of S$1.10 and a 21% total return. The analyst favors the company's defensive play due to its high lease expiry and rental income visibility. In contrast, Silverlake Axis has seen its share price react negatively to the potential cancellation of a mega-bank merger in Malaysia, but analysts believe it presents a good buying opportunity.

site_title: Microsoft unveils low-cost smartphones in some markets
summary: Microsoft has unveiled two low-cost smartphones, the Lumia 435 and 532, priced between 69 to 79 euros, aimed at expanding its Windows Phone operating system in Europe, Asia, and Africa. The devices feature the latest Windows Phone 8.1 operating system and Microsoft Office suite, with the 435 having a four-inch display and the 532 offering a more powerful camera and dual SIM capabilities. This move follows Google's decision to sell Android smartphones for under $100 in emerging markets, and other low-cost handsets using alternative operating systems, such as Firefox.

site_title: European jobs wanted
summary: The European Union is struggling to create jobs and opportunities for its citizens, with youth unemployment rates exceeding 20% across the continent. Despite some countries, such as Austria, Denmark, and Germany, managing to reduce unemployment rates, many still face significant challenges, including dual labour markets and limited educational opportunities for certain groups. The EU's Youth Employment Initiative, launched in 2013, has been deemed a failure, and experts warn that unless new thinking is adopted, Europe's many unemployed young people risk becoming a lost generation, with estimated annual costs of 150 billion euros in lost wages and spending.

site_title: US Secret Service dumping senior officials after security lapses
summary: The US Secret Service has removed four senior officials and another has retired amid a series of security lapses, including a 2014 breach where a knife-carrying man entered the White House. The shake-up follows the agency's failure to prevent the incident, which occurred during President Barack Obama's presidency. Acting Director Joseph Clancy announced the changes, citing the need for "fresh perspectives" and "new leadership." The moves are aimed at improving the agency's security protocols and preventing similar breaches in the future.

site_title: Suncor cuts jobs and spending as price rout rattles oil sands
summary: Suncor Energy Inc, Canada's largest oil company, is cutting 1,000 jobs and reducing its 2015 capital budget by 13% to weather the collapse in oil prices. The company will also delay several projects, including the MacKay River oil-sands project, and reduce operating expenses by $600-800 million over two years. The move is the latest blow to Canada's energy industry and economy, which is facing a revenue shortfall of $6 billion. The cuts are expected to impact contract workers, with the company stating that the job losses will primarily affect them.

site_title: Ying Li plans mixed development in Chongqing
summary: Ying Li International Real Estate signed a memorandum of understanding to develop a mixed-development property in Chongqing's Jiangjin District. The estimated initial investment is 1.8 billion yuan (S$388.2 million) and will feature a one-stop hardware and electrical mall, as well as retail shops, hotels, and residential components. The project, which has already garnered interest from over 900 prospective buyers, is expected to commence in the first quarter of this year and be completed over 2-3 years.

site_title: Brazil gets first soccer trade law as investor ban makes impact
summary: Brazil's soccer authorities have made it illegal to invest in transfer rights of players to turn a profit on future trades, aligning with a global FIFA ban set to take effect in May. The move aims to prevent teams from being pressured to sell players to realize gains for speculators. The ban has already led to a decrease in market activity, with the biggest trade taking place before the FIFA deadline. Brazilian clubs are now required to declare existing contracts and details of third-party investors.

site_title: Shell ends US$6.5b Qatar project as oil price falls
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has canceled a $6.5 billion petrochemicals project in Qatar due to low oil prices. The Al Karaana project, a joint venture with Qatar Petroleum, was set to begin in 2015 but is now deemed unfeasible. Shell cited a "high envisaged capital cost" and the current economic climate as the reasons for the cancellation.

site_title: Al-Qaeda says it's behind Paris attack, calling it 'vengeance'
summary: Al-Qaeda in Yemen has claimed responsibility for the Paris attack on Charlie Hebdo, stating it was "vengeance" for the French weekly's cartoons of the Prophet Mohammed. The group's chief, Ayman al-Zawahiri, ordered the attack. The attack killed 12 people and boosted President Francois Hollande's approval ratings, with polls showing a significant increase in his popularity. Hollande's approval ratings have gained five points, and experts predict further gains in the coming weeks, presenting him with an opportunity to change his image and turn around his mandate.

site_title: Cutting luxury listings down to size
summary: Luxury real estate broker Chris Cortazzo and Coldwell Banker Real Estate are embroiled in a California court battle over square footage measurements in luxury listings. A Hong Kong multimillionaire, Hiroshi Horiike, claims that Cortazzo and Coldwell misrepresented the size of a Malibu mansion, listing it at 15,000 sq ft when official records indicate less than 10,000 sq ft. The case has implications for California's 400,000 real estate agents and brokers, who often work for large firms like Coldwell. The Supreme Court of California is set to rule on the case this year, with Horiike seeking over $5 million in damages.

site_title: Popular Holdings' CEO moves to take company private
summary: CHOU Cheng Ngok, CEO of Singapore's bookstore chain Popular Holdings, is attempting to take the company private with a voluntary conditional cash offer from Grand Apex Holdings, jointly owned by Chou and his wife. The offer price is S$0.32 per share, a 39.1% premium, and is conditional on Grand Apex holding at least 90% of shares. The move aims to provide greater management flexibility and address difficulties in selling unsold condominium units amid a challenging market environment.

site_title: Aftermath of floods may affect Malaysian palm output
summary: Malaysia's palm oil output may decline further this month due to the aftermath of monsoon flooding, which has already affected yields. Growers in Borneo are bracing for the monsoon, while the weather office predicts better conditions in the peninsular region for the coming week. The flooding in Kelantan, Terengganu, and Pahang has been the hardest hit, but the situation is expected to improve in the coming week.

site_title: AXA Real Estate sees Japan office property prices nearing peak
summary: AXA Real Estate, the world's fifth-largest property fund, warns that Japan's office property prices are nearing their peak. Commercial real estate values have increased due to the government's efforts to end deflation and boost economic growth, prompting the company to consider selling some properties. The capitalisation rate for office buildings in Tokyo has fallen to its lowest level since August 2009, indicating rising values. AXA Real Estate may sell some properties to take advantage of recent price increases, despite concerns about the competitive market and potential for future price drops.

site_title: New edition of Charlie Hebdo flies off the shelves
summary: The first issue of Charlie Hebdo after the jihadist attack was sold out within hours, with 700,000 copies sold across France, and will eventually total 5 million. The magazine featured a satirical cover of the Prophet Mohammed with a "Je Suis Charlie" sign, sparking widespread support for free speech and satire. The event marked a show of solidarity with the victims and their families, with many Parisians joining long queues to purchase the issue.

site_title: Najib to unveil budget cuts and action plan amid oil-price slump
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak is set to announce budget cuts and an action plan to address the country's fiscal challenges amid a slump in oil prices. Economists expect him to be specific about measures to meet these challenges and be realistic about the difficulties facing Malaysia. The announcement comes as the country faces a volatile oil market, with lower prices affecting the economy.

site_title: China housing inventories seen piling up in 2015 as supply grows
summary: China's real estate market is expected to see a surge in new housing projects in 2015, with nine out of 12 listed developers planning to launch more projects to meet sales targets. Despite this, inventories are expected to remain high, and home prices may ease further. Executives cite a lack of confidence in the market and high inventories as reasons for their plans, which could add to the country's slowing economy. Nomura's economist Hua Chang Chun forecasts a slowdown in property investment growth to around 8% this year.

site_title: New York e-commerce website Etsy said to be planning US$300m IPO
summary: Etsy, a US e-commerce website specializing in handmade crafts and vintage goods, is reportedly planning a US$300 million initial public offering (IPO). The company, based in Brooklyn, aims to raise funds and may become the biggest technology IPO to emerge from New York since 1999.

site_title: "Under assault", JPMorgan's Q4 profit falls 6.6%
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co reported a 6.6% drop in quarterly profit due to increased legal costs from government probes, including a $1 billion penalty for foreign exchange market conduct. CEO Jamie Dimon stated that banks are "under assault" from multiple regulators. This comes as investigations into Libor interest rates and other areas of the bank's business continue.

site_title: LCD Global drops rights issue; offeror fixes bid price at S$0.33 a share
summary: LCD Global Investments has cancelled its planned rights issue of convertible bonds after a cash offer from Aspial Corp and Fragrance Group, which offered 33 Singapore cents per share, surpassed the proposed rights issue price. The decision was made to allow the higher offer price to be made available to shareholders, citing the intervening event as a significant factor. The move is seen as a positive for shareholders, who will now receive a higher offer price.

site_title: ECB primes financial markets for imminent QE
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is preparing to announce a programme of sovereign bond purchases, known as quantitative easing (QE), to counter the risk of deflation in the eurozone. ECB President Mario Draghi said the bank has few options to achieve its mandate of keeping inflation at 2% and has discussed the technical details of the programme. The announcement is expected at the ECB's policy-setting governing council meeting on January 22, despite criticism from the German Bundesbank that QE will take away pressure on governments to reform their economies.

site_title: Climate change? Pay heed to water
summary: Climate change has garnered significant attention, but a global water shortage poses a pressing issue. The main problem is not climate change, but rather the increasing global water shortage due to overdraft. Water management has been neglected, and water is often taken for granted, leading to inefficient use and abuse. The lack of water pricing has made utilities unviable, resulting in pollution and scarcity. The economic, social, and environmental costs of poor water management are significant, and if trends continue, the situation will worsen, affecting businesses, people, and the environment.

site_title: Khazanah's portfolio up 7.7% to RM145.6b; outlook challenging
summary: Khazanah Nasional, Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund, reported a 7.7% increase in its asset value to RM145.6 billion in 2014. Managing Director Azman Mokhtar stated the fund is in good shape for a challenging year ahead due to a weakening currency and falling oil prices. Despite this, Khazanah remains optimistic and is entering the year in "relative strength."

site_title: Apple sues Ericsson to cut royalties on phone patents
summary: Apple Inc. has sued Ericsson AB, a Swedish company, to dispute royalties on phone patents. Apple claims Ericsson is seeking excessive royalty rates, and that its patents aren't essential to the Long Term Evolution (LTE) standards. Apple argues that Ericsson wants to pay royalties based on the entire device price, which is unreasonable. Apple is seeking a federal court ruling to determine that Ericsson's patents are not essential, thus weakening the company's hold on wireless technology.

site_title: Yen up on oil fears, euro hit by stimulus talk
summary: The yen rose in Asia as investors sought safer assets amid plunging oil prices, while the euro weakened due to expectations of more European Central Bank stimulus. Oil prices fell to near six-year lows, and the US dollar slipped to 116.79 yen. The euro edged up to US$1.1791 after comments from a key ECB member suggested new stimulus measures could come soon. Investors see the yen as a safe-haven currency during uncertain times, driving its strength.

site_title: Retired TPV founder sues Deutsche Bank over US$32m loss
summary: Retired Taiwanese businessman Stanley Pan Fang-Jen sued Deutsche Bank in Singapore's High Court over a US$32 million trading loss, alleging false representations. The bank advised Pan to buy complex and high-risk structured products in 2008, which he claimed led to the loss. Deutsche Bank denied wrongdoing, describing Pan as a "speculative and aggressive investor." The bank will defend against the lawsuit, which has no merit, according to a spokesman. Pan sold his stake in TPV Technology Ltd for US$231 million in 2003.

site_title: SIA to stop offering captains re-employment past age of 62
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will stop offering re-employment contracts to captains beyond the age of 62, with those already 62 set to be released by the end of March. The move, which has caught pilots by surprise, aims to reduce the airline's pilot surplus amid tough operating conditions. About 90 pilots will be affected, with SIA offering assistance to find alternative employment. The airline has been struggling to address a surplus of pilots, with measures including voluntary leave and voluntary transfers to subsidiaries.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: SGX, ICAP to develop new Asian currency products and services
summary: SGX and ICAP will collaborate to develop new Asian currency products and services, offering customers access to SGX-listed currency derivatives via the EBS platforms, to be cleared by SGX. This initiative aims to boost the growing Asian currency market. Additionally, SGX announced Mizuho Securities USA as its first remote derivatives-clearing member, allowing US customers to trade with SGX's large Asian customer base and clear their trades on the SGX platform. The collaboration and membership are subject to regulatory approvals and are expected to be implemented in the third quarter of this year.

site_title: JTC launches cluster hub for niche semicon firms
summary: JTC Corporation has launched JTC nanoSpace@Tampines, its 11th "innovative space" targeting niche semiconductor firms. The four-storey facility, designed to support companies in advanced packaging, compound semiconductors, and micro-electro-mechanical systems, aims to reduce startup times and costs. With vibration-controlled space and shared utilities, the facility is expected to be completed in early 2017 and help boost industries' productivity and competitiveness. The move aims to avoid a repeat of the 2010-2013 period when supply lagged demand, leading to rent spikes.

images.alt_text: JTC Corporation is building industrial space ahead of demand to avoid a repeat of the problem during 2010-2013, when supply lagged demand and led rents to spike about 20 per cent per year, CEO Png Cheong Boon told media on Wednesday on the sidelines of the launch of JTC nanoSpace@Tampines.

site_title: Non-landed private home rents down 6.4% in 2014
summary: Non-landed private home rents in Singapore declined 6.4% in 2014, with a 0.8% drop in December compared to November. HDB flat rents fell 2.1% for the year, with a 0.4% drop in December. Experts expect further weakness in 2015, with rents potentially falling up to 8% for the whole year due to increased completions and tightening of foreign labor. This is attributed to increased leasing competition, with new condominiums cutting rents to attract tenants.

site_title: Same-store sales for GameStop rise 4.4% in December
summary: GameStop Corp reported a 4.4% increase in same-store sales for December, driven by strong demand for games such as Call of Duty and Grand Theft Auto. The company narrowed its full-year same-store sales forecast to 3-4% growth, citing continued sales growth into the first quarter. Shares rose 10% to $36 in extended trading after the announcement.

site_title: Temasek to turn Mandai into nature heritage precinct
summary: Temasek has partnered with the Singapore Tourism Board to transform Mandai into a nature heritage precinct, spanning 120 hectares over 10 years. The estimated S$1 billion first phase will include integrated wildlife and nature attractions, open spaces, and green public areas. The project will build on the existing wildlife attractions, such as the Singapore Zoo and Night Safari, and aims to create a world-class nature destination for recreation, education, and conservation.

site_title: Russia to convert foreign currency from wealth fund to arrest rouble's fall
summary: Russia's government plans to convert $88 billion in foreign currency from its wealth fund to roubles, injecting liquidity into the economy and supporting the national currency. The move comes as the ruble faces its worst slump since 2009, with the central bank having spent $88 billion defending it last year.
