summary: The Obama administration plans to unveil regulations to cut methane emissions from oil and gas production by up to 45% by 2025 from 2012 levels, a potent greenhouse gas. The Environmental Protection Agency will issue proposed rules targeting methane emissions. This move aims to reduce the impact of oil and gas production on the environment and combat climate change.

site_title: British Jewish people fear future in Europe: poll
summary: A survey of 2,230 British Jewish people by the Campaign Against Anti-Semitism found that 45% fear they have no long-term future in Britain and 58% in Europe. The poll comes after a series of attacks in Paris, leading France to increase security measures. A quarter of respondents considered leaving Britain in the past two years, and 2014 saw the highest number of recorded anti-Semitic incidents in London's metropolitan police. Anti-Semitic views are widespread, with 45% of those surveyed believing at least one anti-Semitic statement.

images.alt_text: Almost half of British Jewish people fear they have no long-term future in Britain or Europe, according to a survey published on Wednesday.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler seen breaking even in Europe in 2015
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) is on track to break even in Europe by 2015, according to CEO Sergio Marchionne. The company, which faced a six-year slump in car sales, is seeing a turnaround with a focus on premium vehicles for export. FCA's European operations, which posted an operating loss of 520 million euros in 2013, are expected to arrest losses in 2016 and break even in 2015. This marks a positive shift for the company, which has increasingly relied on its US operations for profit.

site_title: Cadillac unfurls most powerful car in its history
summary: Cadillac unveiled its most powerful car, the CTS-V, with 640 horsepower and a top speed of 320kmh, aiming to regain its preeminence in the luxury market. The brand, owned by General Motors, has invested $12 billion to launch a "product offensive" across several segments, seeking to disrupt the status quo and shatter the competition. Following a 6.3% decline in sales last year, Cadillac is focusing on growth in China, where sales rocketed 47% to 74,000 units in 2014. The company aims to reclaim its glory days and challenge established market leaders.

images.alt_text: Cadillac came out all guns blazing at the Detroit auto show Tuesday, unleashing the most powerful car in its storied 112-year history in an aggressive bid to return to preeminence.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.74% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.74% lower on Wednesday, driven by the yen's rise and global market declines, particularly on Wall Street where the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 fell 0.15% and 0.26% respectively. The Nikkei 225 index lost 125.89 to 16,961.82 at the start.

site_title: Ying Li signs MOU to develop mixed-use project in Chongqing
summary: Ying Li International Real Estate has signed a memorandum of understanding with Chongqing City Shangfu New Area Administrative Committee and Chongqing Hardware & Electrical Industry to develop a 1.6 million square meter mixed-use project in Chongqing's Jiangnin District. The project, featuring high-grade retail shops, hotels, residential, and a logistics distribution center, is estimated to cost around 1.8 billion renminbi and will take two to three years to complete. Ying Li will retain some premium developments as investment properties.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Nintendo hits pause button on Brazil
summary: Nintendo is pausing its operations in Brazil due to high import taxes, which force the company to distribute games at a 20% premium to the US market. The Kyoto-based firm will assess a sustainable distribution model and may return to the market in the future, citing Brazil's large population and rising wages. Nintendo's general manager in Latin America, Bill van Zyll, stated that the business environment in Brazil has persuaded the company to withdraw from the market for now, but still sees potential for growth.

site_title: Working too hard can drive you to booze: study
summary: Researchers found that working over 48 hours a week can drive individuals to consume "risky" quantities of alcohol, increasing the likelihood of higher intake by 11% overall. Those working 49-54 hours a week had a 13% higher risk of developing a "risky" drinking habit, while those working 55 hours or more had a 12% higher risk. The study, covering over 400,000 people across 12 developed economies, links long working hours to increased risk of liver and heart disease, cancer, stroke, and mental disorders.

site_title: Big drops of oil
summary: Oil prices plummeted amid a bearish outlook due to US President Trump's fresh tariffs on Canada and potential threats to other countries. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) also trimmed its oil demand forecast for the next four years. This move is attributed to the uncertainty surrounding global trade policies and the resulting decrease in oil consumption. As a result, global oil prices fell, while gold prices rose in response to the increased uncertainty and potential for trade wars.

site_title: DuPont to sell theatre after activist criticism
summary: DuPont will sell its 100-year-old theatre, the DuPont Theatre, to the Grand Opera House in Wilmington, Delaware, for an undisclosed price. The sale comes after shareholder activist Trian Fund Management criticized the asset as an example of DuPont's mismanagement. The theatre's new name will be the Playhouse on Rodney Square. The sale will not affect ticket holders for the 2014-15 season, which includes performances of Camelot and Guys and Dolls. The decision is seen as a strategic and mutually beneficial business move for DuPont and the Grand Opera House.

site_title: YuuZoo, Hong Kong's Hamon tie up to build social e-commerce network for investors
summary: YuuZoo Corporation has partnered with Hong Kong-based Hamon Private Equity to develop a social e-commerce network for investors, called YuuInvest. The network will connect users with financial specialists for investment advice. YuuZoo will receive a pre-agreed proportion of the revenue generated from the network, including e-commerce, advertising, and transaction fees. The joint venture aims to capitalize on the growing demand for social e-commerce platforms, particularly among investors.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: World Bank cuts global economic outlook despite oil price drop
summary: The World Bank lowered its global growth forecast for 2015 and 2016 due to disappointing economic prospects in the eurozone, Japan, and some emerging economies. The bank now predicts a 3% global growth rate for 2015, down from 3.4% previously, and 3.3% for 2016, below the previous forecast of 3.5%. This is attributed to challenging economic conditions, with World Bank chief economist Kaushik Basu describing the global economy as being at a "disconcerting juncture."

site_title: Charlie Hebdo survivors produce defiant edition a week after attack
summary: Charlie Hebdo, a French satirical weekly, is set to publish a defiant edition with a Prophet Mohammed cartoon on the cover one week after a jihadist attack killed 12 people at its Paris office. The magazine, known for its freedom of expression, has become a symbol of resistance against terrorism. The cartoon, designed by a survivor of the attack, depicts Mohammed crying with the caption "Je Suis Charlie" (I am Charlie). The move has sparked outrage from Islamic authorities, but French Muslim groups urge calm and avoid emotive reactions.

site_title: More buys than sells in Singapore Reits
summary: Global mutual funds were net buyers of Singapore Reits, with net purchases of S$150 million compared to net sales of S$85.7 million in the three months to Jan 7. The top five Reits saw a net buy of S$150 million, with CapitaMall Trust Management receiving the highest volume of S$56.3 million. This trend suggests fund managers are focusing on the Reits segment, potentially driven by market sentiment and growth prospects.

site_title: US oil refiners work to recover from weekend glitches, fires
summary: US oil refiners are working to recover from weekend glitches that temporarily knocked out 1 million barrels per day of processing capacity, the worst outage in years. Three refineries were affected, with one, Husky Energy's Lima, Ohio, refinery, expected to return online by the end of the week after an explosion damaged its isocracker unit. The disruptions boosted prompt gasoline and diesel prices in the New York harbor, while fueling deeper losses in US crude oil prices. Icy weather may further delay the restart of the damaged refinery.

site_title: Public's trust and keeping systems up to date key to Singapore's fight against corruption: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong pledged to keep up efforts to combat corruption, citing the country's strong anti-corruption law and well-qualified officers. The government will review the Prevention of Corruption Act and increase CPIB manpower by 20%. A new reporting centre for whistleblowers will be set up, along with a heritage gallery to educate the public about anti-corruption issues. Lee emphasized the importance of trust and maintaining a zero-tolerance policy for corruption, warning that breaches can damage public trust and the country's reputation.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: North Korea offers direct talks with US
summary: North Korea has offered to hold direct talks with the US on suspending nuclear tests in exchange for the temporary scrapping of joint military exercises in South Korea. The US State Department rejected the offer as an "implicit threat" but remains open to dialogue. The talks could pave the way for broader engagement on the Korean peninsula. North Korea's Deputy Ambassador to the UN said the offer still stands and could lead to "many things being possible" this year. The US and North Korea have no diplomatic relations, and the US is considering additional sanctions against North Korea.

site_title: Crucial year for PM Modi's efforts to kick-start growth in India
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's 2015 budget is crucial in reviving the country's growth story. The government has made progress on stalled projects and the implementation of a goods and services tax. However, Modi needs to balance reducing the budget deficit with investing in inefficient infrastructure. Indian industry is seeking measures such as lower corporate tax rates, disinvestment, and increased public expenditure to boost growth. The government plans to spend $250 billion on infrastructure projects by 2019, with most investment coming from the government and foreign investment.

site_title: Translation app starts to prove itself
summary: Google is set to announce updates to its translation app, which has been installed over 100 million times on Android phones. The app will automatically recognize popular languages and turn spoken words into written text. The technology aims to bridge language barriers, allowing people to communicate across borders. Google's Translate app has 500 million active users monthly, and the company plans to expand its capabilities to include automatic translation of web pages and street signs. Microsoft's Skype has also introduced simultaneous translation, with plans to add more languages.

site_title: No more new residential projects in 14 ha area of Geylang
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) proposes re-zoning a 14-hectare stretch of Geylang from residential to commercial/institution use. The rezoning aims to preserve the area's character, with a maximum plot ratio of 2.8. No new residential projects will be approved in this area. This decision is part of the URA's efforts to balance development and preservation, ensuring the area remains vibrant and functional for the community. The rezoning is expected to be finalized in the near future.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Riding Asia's 'Great Moderation' era in 2015
summary: Asia's "Great Moderation" era, characterized by sustained but moderately high growth, is expected to provide a prolonged period for harvesting equity returns. Focusing on the quality of growth rather than pace, the article highlights China, India, and Indonesia as top picks for policy-driven quality growth. Additionally, efficiency imperatives in a competitively driven marketplace, such as e-commerce and modern logistics, will drive market-driven quality growth. However, valuation risks and execution challenges at the government and corporate levels may impact the region's equity universe.

site_title: UK's Osborne urges ECB to do "whatever it takes" to hit price target
summary: Finance Minister George Osborne urged the European Central Bank to take all necessary steps to combat deflation, a week before the ECB's policy meeting, citing Britain's low inflation rate of 0.5% as a positive example. In contrast, the euro zone's lower inflation poses a risk of deflation, which could have negative consequences for economies. Osborne's latest intervention is seen as more forceful than previous calls, as the euro zone's weakness could impact Britain's economy ahead of its national election on May 7.

site_title: World Bank sees growth pick-up for developing countries
summary: The World Bank predicts developing countries will experience a growth pick-up in 2015, driven by falling oil prices and a stronger US economy. Developing countries' GDP growth is expected to reach 4.8% in 2015 and 5.3% in 2016. Despite a slowdown in China, the leader of emerging-market economies, structural reforms and fiscal stimulus are expected to slow its growth to 6.9% by 2017. Other emerging-market countries, such as India, Brazil, and Indonesia, are also expected to benefit from low oil prices.

images.alt_text: The World Bank on Tuesday predicted a pick-up in economic growth for developing countries, spurred by falling oil prices and despite a slight slowdown in global engine China.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as falling oil prices weigh
summary: US stocks closed modestly lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.15% to 17,613.81, as falling crude oil prices overshadowed a strong unofficial start to earnings season by Alcoa. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also fell, with the S&P 500 down 0.26% to 2,023.00. Oil prices hit nearly six-year lows, with West Texas Intermediate falling 18 cents to $45.89 a barrel. The continued selling pressure in commodities weighed on overall risk sentiment, according to analysts.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks closed modestly lower on Tuesday as worries about sliding crude oil prices overshadowed a strong unofficial start to earnings season by Alcoa.

site_title: Resale prices of private condos up 0.1% in December: SRX
summary: Resale prices of private condos in Singapore rose 0.1% in December, according to SRX Property. However, property consultants view this as a blip, citing muted demand for 2015. Transactions in suburban areas (0.5% increase) and city fringe areas (1.1% decline) were the main drivers of the price rise. Experts attribute the increase to the mass market segment due to lower debt servicing ratios and upgraders' demand. Despite this, prices are expected to fall further due to supply overhang and interest rate hikes, with the non-landed private residential price index falling 4.2% in December compared to a year ago.

site_title: Taxi fares to go up?
summary: Taxi fares in Singapore may increase to S$3.80, replacing the 25% peak-period surcharge, to boost drivers' income and retain them. The flagdown fare for ComfortDelGro's taxis, owned by the two market leaders, is expected to rise to S$3.80, with the meter adding 30 cents for every 400m travelled. This change could encourage more drivers to stay in the profession and address the industry's stagnant takings and driver shortages.

site_title: SPH posts Q1 profit of S$69.4m
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) posted a net profit of S$69.4 million for its fiscal first quarter, a 21.9% year-on-year drop, due to a 6.5% decline in total operating revenue. The newspaper and magazine business saw a 7.9% fall in revenue, while the property segment maintained a steady performance. Amid the uncertain macroeconomic environment, SPH CEO Alan Chan emphasized the need for new investments and digital initiatives to position the group for sustainable growth.

site_title: New Charlie Hebdo front page shows Prophet Mohammed holding up 'Je suis Charlie' sign
summary: The French satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo has released a new front page featuring a cartoon of Prophet Mohammed crying and holding up a "Je suis Charlie" sign, sparking both international sympathy and renewed fury among some devout Muslims. The magazine's staff, who survived a deadly attack last week, vowed to continue publishing provocative cartoons, despite death threats and a history of violence against them. The move has cemented Charlie Hebdo's status as a symbol of free speech, with millions rallying in support of the magazine and its principles.

site_title: HK leader seeks to bolster support in policy address
summary: Hong Kong leader Leung Chun-ying is set to focus on property, economy, and youth issues in his policy address, aiming to bolster support after last year's massive pro-democracy protests. The annual policy blueprint will include measures such as boosting housing supply, introducing subsidized housing schemes, and easing restrictions on foreign talent hiring. Analysts expect the address to boost Leung's approval ratings, but note that economic incentives alone may not appease the youth, who were largely driven by the protests.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.55%. NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in H2, citing a challenging market. The MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Malaysian floods support rally in palm oil prices
summary: Malaysia's palm oil prices have surged 22% since September due to severe flooding that damaged plantations, resulting in a 22% decline in output to 1.23 million tonnes in December, the lowest for that month since 2010. The floods, the worst in four decades, have exacerbated the seasonal low in year-round production, boosting the cost of vegetable oil used by major companies such as Unilever and Hershey Co. Analysts predict the rally will continue, with Macquarie Group estimating palm oil prices could reach RM2,500 in 2015.

site_title: China's 2014 trade rises only 3.4% as surplus soars
summary: China's trade grew 3.4% in 2014, missing its target by far, with a record trade surplus of $382.46 billion. Exports rose 6.1% and imports only 0.4%, due to weak commodity prices and lagging internal demand. The surplus was attributed to falling international commodity prices, which dragged down import values. China's trade surplus has raised concerns with the US, which claims structural imbalances steal jobs from US factories. Analysts expect more interest rate cuts to spur growth, but warn of a potential slowdown in the economy.

site_title: Amazon shakes up another industry with big win at Golden Globes
summary: Amazon won its first Golden Globe for best TV series for its original show "Transparent," a dark comedy about a transgender family, at the 72nd Golden Globe Awards. The show's star, Jeffrey Tambor, also won the award for best actor in the category. The win marks a significant shift in Amazon's image, as the company was previously criticized for its e-book pricing dispute with book publishers. Amazon's success in producing high-quality content is seen as a testament to its ability to disrupt the entertainment industry, and its vice-president, Roy Price, credited the company's passion for the show's success.

site_title: No early rate hikes expected as UK inflation falls to a new low
summary: UK inflation fell to a record-low 0.50% in December, sparking deflation fears and delaying interest rate hikes. Sliding oil prices, which have dropped 60% since June, contributed to the decrease. The Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates on hold until after the UK's general election in May, rather than raising them in the second quarter as previously expected. Deflation, which could undermine economic growth, is a concern, but the UK's low unemployment and rising wages are seen as mitigating factors.

site_title: Oil prices hit fresh lows since 2009
summary: Oil prices dropped to fresh lows since 2009, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate settling at $45.89 a barrel and Brent crude at $46.59 a barrel. Opec officials reaffirmed their commitment to not cut output, citing a supply glut, despite plummeting prices. This move contributed to the decline in oil prices, which had previously traded below $50 a barrel for the first time since April 2009.

site_title: IAG planning higher Aer Lingus bid: sources
summary: IAG, the parent company of British Airways, is planning to increase its offer for Aer Lingus to as much as 2.50 euros per share, up from the initial 2.40 euros, in an effort to acquire the Irish airline. The move comes after Aer Lingus rejected the initial offer, which valued the company at 1.28 billion euros. The acquisition would help IAG gain control of London Heathrow's slots and increase transatlantic flights, competing with Ryanair. IAG needs to secure deals with Ryanair and the Irish government, which controls 25% of Aer Lingus.

site_title: Indonesia taking centre stage in global sukuk race
summary: Indonesia is set to issue its fifth consecutive year of global sovereign sukuk, with sales in the past four years reaching $5 billion, ahead of Malaysia's $3.25 billion and Qatar's $2 billion. The Jakarta government plans to tap the sukuk market amid optimism over President Joko Widodo's potential reforms. Rising demand for government debt due to global market turmoil has pushed Indonesian yields to a one-month low, with the yield on 4% Syariah-compliant notes due in 2018 dropping to 3.02%.

site_title: In brief
summary: Tee International reported a 5.8% decline in Q2 profit to S$1.52 million due to lower revenue and higher administrative expenses. Zico Holdings plans a joint-venture with Stamford Law Corp to manage corporate secretarial services. King Wan Corp secured S$43.3 million in new projects, while Global Logistic Properties added six subsidiaries in China. NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, and Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss.

site_title: Two Thai property developers plan Reit IPOs
summary: Two Thai property developers, Golden Land Property Development PCL and Country Group Development PCL, plan initial public offerings of real estate investment trusts (Reits) to raise funds for expansion. Golden Land aims to list its Reit worth up to 10 billion baht, while Country Group plans to list a Reit worth more than 1.3 billion baht. The move follows the success of Bangkok Land's first Reit, which has encouraged more developers to tap investor appetite. The listings are expected to raise funds for expansion and debt repayment.

site_title: Restructuring moves open to change, says GPC chairman
summary: Singapore's restructuring initiatives, aimed at driving productivity and innovation, are open to change, said Liang Eng Hwa, chairman of the Government Parliamentary Committee for Finance, Trade and Industry. The government is considering tweaks to the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme and foreign worker quotas, with a focus on managing downside risks and supporting businesses. Panelists emphasized the need for sector- and firm-size-specific incentives and a greater focus on research and development to drive growth. The government is also exploring opportunities for Singapore to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging.

site_title: Malaysia's proposed mega bank merger may be off the table
summary: Malaysia's proposed mega bank merger between Malaysia Building Society Bhd (MBSB), CIMB Group, and RHB Capital may be scrapped due to lax loan provisioning practices at MBSB. A three-month due diligence exercise revealed a significant gap in MBSB's loan provisioning compared to potential partners, casting doubt on the feasibility of the merger. The mega bank would have been Southeast Asia's fourth-largest lender.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: ST Aerospace wins new deals worth S$310m in Q4 2014
summary: ST Aerospace secured S$310m worth of new contracts in Q4 2014, including a five-year maintenance-by-the-hour contract with a returning airline customer and heavy maintenance contracts for three Boeing 757 aircraft. The company also inked a two-year engine maintenance contract with a regional low-cost airline. In Q4 2014, ST Aerospace redelivered 238 aircraft and processed 12,145 components, with 1,927 engine washes conducted for commercial and military customers.

site_title: E-Jets E2 cabin mock-up on display in Singapore
summary: Embraer is showcasing the cabin mock-up of its E-Jets E2 family in Singapore as part of a worldwide tour. The E-Jets E2, set to enter service in 2018, aims to achieve similar costs per seat as larger aircraft while reducing trip costs. The mock-up will be displayed at Seletar Aerospace Park for two weeks before traveling to Sydney and the Paris Air Show. This marks the second generation of the E-Jets family, launched in June 2013.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Divers recover cockpit voice recorder from beneath wreckage
summary: Divers in Indonesia have recovered the cockpit voice recorder from the wreckage of the AirAsia plane that crashed into the Java Sea on December 28, 2014. The recovery comes a day after the plane's flight data recorder was found. The devices are expected to provide crucial information about the cause of the accident, helping investigators overcome the challenges of the investigation. The airline's boss vowed to overcome the "toughest times" he has known amid the tragedy.

site_title: Backlog at US West Coast ports at critical level as talks drag on
summary: The US West Coast ports are experiencing a critical backlog due to a port slowdown and eight months of unsuccessful labor talks with longshoremen. The Pacific Maritime Association stated that the congestion levels are "no longer sustainable" at the five largest ports. This has significant implications for shipping companies, potentially leading to disruptions in global supply chains.

site_title: China grapples with economic burden of cancers
summary: China is grappling with the economic burden of cancer, with incidence rates doubling over the past two decades. The country has the world's largest number of cancer cases and deaths, driven by a rapidly aging population, environmental pollution, and lifestyle changes. The financial burden on families is significant, with many struggling to afford treatment costs, including expensive drugs. The Chinese government is now looking to bolster insurance coverage for diseases like cancer, but the changes are not happening fast enough for patients like Xiao Caiyu, who was forced to close her family's business after her diagnosis.

images.alt_text: AS ONE of China's wave of entrepreneurs, Xiao Caiyu built and ran a small pork business with her husband that allowed her to squirrel away a nest egg of more than 30,000 yuan (S$6,400).

site_title: Designer Galliano is back - to rave reviews
summary: Designer John Galliano made his comeback in London for Maison Margiela, receiving rave reviews for his collection. The 54-year-old, banned from Paris fashion world in 2011 for anti-Semitic remarks, was appointed creative director in October. Critics praised the show as "sensational" and "magical," with many noting Galliano's return to his "absolute peak of perfection." The collection blended Galliano's flamboyant style with Maison Margiela's minimalist look, with attendees including fashion bigwigs and supermodel Kate Moss.

images.alt_text: John Galliano's new collection blended his flamboyant, theatrical style with Maison Margiela's more minimalist look.

site_title: 2015: The year the renminbi goes mainstream
summary: The renminbi, China's currency, has become increasingly mainstream as an international currency, with the Chinese authorities facilitating its internationalisation. In 2014, the renminbi was established as a trade currency and its progress towards global acceptance as a medium of investment accelerated. Key milestones include the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect scheme, which created an investment bridge between the two cities' stock exchanges, and the growth of offshore liquidity pool, renminbi-denominated products, and renminbi bonds. As a result, the renminbi is now the world's seventh largest payment currency in value, with over 22% of China's overseas trade settled in renminbi.

site_title: Broking fees: Don't ignore the economics of doing business
summary: A recent editorial highlighted the high brokerage fees charged by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) despite smaller lot sizes. The author argues that the fees are still too high, citing the massive trade volumes of large companies like Apple and the relatively low fees charged by smaller ETFs. The author suggests that the broking industry is not a charity, but a profit-oriented business that needs to cover costs. The editorial emphasizes the need for a fuller picture of the economics of doing business, rather than blindly aping Western standards and cherry-picking statistics.

site_title: US admits mistake in missing huge unity rally in Paris
summary: The White House acknowledged a mistake in missing a massive unity rally in Paris against terrorism, where President Barack Obama failed to attend despite 50 world leaders, including the Israeli prime minister and Palestinian president, joining the event. The US ambassador to France attended, but White House spokesman Josh Earnest said the security requirements and short planning time prevented a senior official from attending. The absence was criticized by US commentators and lawmakers, with some accusing Obama of letting down ally France.

site_title: DeClout, Acclivis to buy ISP licence holder
summary: DeClout and its subsidiary Acclivis Technologies have agreed to acquire OSINet Communication, a Singapore-based Internet Service Provider (ISP) licence holder, for S$14.2 million. The acquisition will enable Acclivis to scale up its network capabilities and acquire OSINet's technical know-how and experience. The deal is expected to enhance DeClout's cloud and data centre offerings, allowing for increased scalability, cost efficiency, and flexibility. The proposed acquisition is seen as a strategic move to expand DeClout's presence in the cloud and data centre market in Singapore.

site_title: Cheap gas makes US only place where export makes sense
summary: US plans to build new liquefied natural gas (LNG) terminals are gaining momentum due to cheap gas prices. Unlike other countries, where LNG prices are tied to crude oil, the US model charges a set fee based on capacity purchased, making it more profitable even with low oil prices. This advantage, combined with lower labor and capital costs, makes US suppliers more competitive, with some projects expected to be more viable than those in Australia.

site_title: Paris tourism launches Open for Business campaign after shootings
summary: Paris tourism launches an "Open for Business" campaign after a series of fatal shootings by militants in January 2015, reassuring visitors and agents that the city is safe. The campaign, led by the Comite Regional du Tourisme Paris Ile-de-France, includes a world tour to promote the city's attractions and address concerns. Despite the attacks, the organization expects a slight increase in visitors this year, with growth notably coming from the Middle East, South Korea, and China, and no cancellations have been reported among tour operators and travel agents worldwide.

site_title: Creditors put heat on retail SMEs to settle bills more quickly
summary: Singapore's retail SMEs are paying their bills sooner, with the average payment period decreasing from 63 days in 2013 to 42 days in 2014. The credit bureau attributes this improvement to increased pressure from creditors and suppliers, driven by higher rental costs and the need for companies to improve productivity. The "Days Turned Cash" national average increased overall, but the credit-related sector saw the largest improvement in payment speeds, settling accounts nine days faster. The percentage of severely delinquent debts also decreased, from 41% to 19%.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Noble plunges 6.82% to 10-month low
summary: Noble Group's shares plummeted 6.82% to a 10-month low of S$1.025 due to a significant sell-off, with over 70 million shares changing hands. Analysts speculate that China Investment Corporation's possible divestment, following its 9.4% stake sale in September 2014, may be the cause. The recent decline in crude oil prices, which accounts for 70% of Noble's Q3 FY2014 revenues, is also a contributing factor. Despite differing views, analysts maintain "buy" calls, with some expecting lower commodity prices to present opportunities for Noble in the medium term.

site_title: US wages set to start rising as jobs market firms: economists
summary: US workers are expected to see average hourly earnings rise 2-3% this year as the job market tightens, according to economists polled by Bloomberg. This represents a 1.7% increase in the past year. The forecast comes as workers and jobseekers become more optimistic about their job prospects.

site_title: Hard power returns in international ties
summary: The world has seen a resurgence in hard power use by major states, with the US, Russia, and China employing military force and coercion to achieve strategic goals. This shift is partly driven by the changing global balance of power and countries seeking to assert their interests. While soft power remains an effective tool, smart power - combining hard and soft power - is also being used to achieve desired outcomes. Examples include the US's portrayal of ISIS as an enemy of fellow Muslims, Russia's annexation of Crimea, and China's attempts to reassure its neighbors in the South China Sea. The long-term effectiveness of hard power depends on the military and economic strength of these countries, and soft power remains a crucial component in shaping public opinion and narratives.

site_title: No love lost with shareholders as Deutsche Bank plots new strategy
summary: Deutsche Bank's co-CEOs, Anshu Jain and Juergen Fitschen, have outlined a new strategy to address the bank's declining revenue and high litigation costs. The bank's shares have fallen 35% over the past year, the largest decline among major global investment banks. To revamp its strategy, Deutsche Bank will need to implement deeper cuts to its securities unit, and may consider selling its Postbank German consumer-banking unit. Analysts expect the bank to miss return on equity goals, and recommend investors sell Deutsche Bank shares due to its high capital requirements and low interest rates.

site_title: SEC said to be considering stricter rules for dark pools: source
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission is considering stricter rules for dark pools, which are criticized for not treating investors fairly. The proposed rules would require dark pools to disclose the types of orders available and the source of pricing data, addressing concerns over transparency and fairness. The SEC has previously fined dark pool operators for breaking market rules, and the new regulations aim to increase accountability and transparency in the industry.

site_title: More losses for gold this year: Barclays
summary: Barclays predicts gold prices will test new lows in 2015, dropping to less than $1,130 an ounce due to increasing US interest rates and economic headwinds. Analysts Suki Cooper and Kevin Norrish expect the physical market to be more supportive this year, but this won't be enough to offset the downward pressure. The prediction comes after gold posted its first back-to-back annual drop since 2000 in 2014.

site_title: Uniqlo under fire over factory conditions, pay
summary: Uniqlo, a Japanese clothing giant, is under fire for buying supplies from Chinese factories accused of putting workers at risk in unsafe conditions. A Hong Kong-based human rights group, Students and Scholars Against Corporate Misbehaviour (Sacom), accused Uniqlo of buying from suppliers with long working hours, low pay, and poor working conditions. The group cited extreme temperatures, sewage on the factory floor, and poor ventilation as hazards. Uniqlo acknowledged the investigation and opened an investigation, but said it had "different views" on some of the issues.

site_title: HK government tells conflicting stories
summary: Hong Kong Chief Secretary Carrie Lam faced criticism from student leader Joshua Wong after Lam failed to answer his question about the government's public sentiment report, which concluded that there was a "common aspiration" for universal suffrage in 2017. Wong had protested against the Aug 31 decision, which would limit public voting in the election, and felt the report's conclusion distorted facts. The report was later contradicted by a second document released by the Hong Kong authorities, which acknowledged that the community's support for universal suffrage was uncertain. The Hong Kong government's credibility has been severely damaged, with a poll showing 48% of respondents supporting a veto of the bill to implement the NPCSC decision.

site_title: Thai small investors slow to take up govt savings bonds
summary: Thailand's military government is selling 100 billion baht ($4 billion) of savings bonds to finance a budget deficit and a state rice-buying scheme. However, small investors have shown a slow initial response, limiting the market impact of the sale. The junta's reliance on the broader bond market may push up yields, affecting the sale's success. The move aims to encourage small investors to participate in the bond market, but its effectiveness remains uncertain.

site_title: Alcoa sees global aluminium use expanding 7% this year
summary: Alcoa Inc, the largest US aluminium producer, forecasts global aluminium use to grow 7% this year, driven by increased demand from automakers and the aerospace industry. Sales to US automotive customers are projected to rise 5.8%, while demand for commercial and regional jets is expected to boost aerospace sales by up to 10%. The company reported better-than-expected profit and sales, with record volume of automotive aluminium sheet shipped, and shares rose 2.4%. Alcoa's shift towards downstream operations is seen as a key factor in its growth, with the company focusing on metals engineering and manufacturing.

site_title: Amundi: Fed unlikely to tighten rate this year
summary: The US Federal Reserve is unlikely to tighten interest rates this year due to global concerns over deflation and declining oil prices. Fund manager Amundi Asset Management believes that growth is not the main driver of performance, but rather abundant liquidity and yield-seeking investments. The European Central Bank is expected to announce quantitative easing, favoring eurozone equities. Asian equities are expected to deliver a 10% return this year, driven by moderate earnings growth and lower commodity prices.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve is unlikely to tighten the interest rate this year, given global concerns over deflation, and as oil prices have declined, senior executives from fund management Amundi Asset Management said on Tuesday.

site_title: Senior Chinese lawmaker sacked after graft probe
summary: China's anti-corruption commission has sacked senior lawmaker Bai Enpei, who was under investigation for accepting bribes in "huge amounts". Bai, former party boss of Yunnan province, was also governor and party chief of Qinghai province. This move is part of President Xi Jinping's efforts to crack down on corruption, warning that it threatens the Communist Party's grip on power. The anti-corruption campaign has led to the downfall of several high-ranking officials, including Zhou Yongkang, China's disgraced domestic security tsar.

site_title: Sony CEO eyes options as pressure mounts on weak TV, mobile
summary: Sony CEO Kazuo Hirai is considering options for the company's struggling TV and mobile operations, including sales and joint ventures, amid a 230 billion yen (S$2.6 billion) net loss forecast for the business year. Despite recent cost cuts and the success of its PlayStation 4 console, Sony's electronics division has failed to turn a profit since Hirai took over in 2012. The company has already cut 15,000 jobs and suspended dividend payments, with analysts suggesting further drastic action may be needed to revitalize the business.

images.alt_text: Mr Hirai used last week's high-profile Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas to push an array of new gadgets.

site_title: Bumps seen ahead for trade in smaller board lots
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) will reduce the minimum board lot size from 1,000 shares to 100 shares on January 19, making trading more affordable for investors. However, some market observers warn that sticky fees could limit the impact, while others see the move as a step towards increasing market participation and liquidity. SGX has launched a campaign to grow its retail base, which currently accounts for 30-35% of daily turnover, aiming to boost investor participation and returns.

site_title: Japan to spend revenue from tax hike on welfare
summary: Japan's government agreed to use additional revenue from a sales tax increase to boost welfare spending in the coming fiscal year. The government expects 8 trillion yen in tax revenue and plans to spend around 5.75 trillion yen on cash handouts for families, healthcare costs, and pension system top-ups. This marks a significant increase in social-welfare spending, which is set to rise 1 trillion yen to 31.5 trillion yen. The state budget for the new fiscal year will rise to a record 96.3 trillion yen, allowing for a reduction in bond issuance.

images.alt_text: The government will spend around 1.35 trillion yen on cash handouts for families with children and to help cover health-care costs.

site_title: 10-year SGS yield falls below 2%
summary: The 10-year Singapore Government Securities (SGS) yield has fallen below 2% due to speculation that interest rate hikes will be delayed. This drop is attributed to the US Treasury yield, which has also decreased to 1.88%. Experts believe the US Federal Reserve will only hike interest rates by Q3 this year, leading to a decrease in bond prices and a rise in yields. The SGS yield decrease is seen as a positive sign for investors, with the price rising 0.8% to 108.79.

site_title: Spotify says its subscribers now number 15 million
summary: Spotify has reached 15 million subscribers, a significant growth milestone for the music streaming service. This increase comes just eight months after the company announced it had reached 10 million subscribers. With 60 million users, Spotify's paid subscription rate of around $10 a month generates substantial revenue for record companies and distributors. The service's growth has helped to shift the music industry debate towards streaming, with major labels pressuring free outlets to generate more revenue. Spotify has paid out over $2 billion in music royalties since its inception in 2008.

site_title: Sterling struggling near recent lows
summary: The British pound fell to an 18-month low against the US dollar, trading at US$1.5077, due to low inflation data showing a 0.5% annual rate in December. This bolsters expectations that the Bank of England will keep interest rates suppressed. The euro also declined, falling below US$1.1800, as investors anticipate the European Central Bank's potential bond buying program. The dollar index rose 0.3% to 92.275, while the yen recovered from its lowest level since December 17.

site_title: Short sellers wager shipbuilder misery to deepen
summary: South Korean shipbuilders, which suffered losses last year, are being heavily targeted by short sellers due to falling crude prices and decreased demand for oil rigs. Short interest in Hyundai Mipo Dockyard Co and Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine Engineering Co has more than tripled in the past year. Analysts predict that earnings may pick up in the second quarter, but say that the sector's recovery will be slow and dependent on fundamental improvement. Short interest in Hyundai Heavy Industries Co has surged to 3.5%, its highest since 2006.

site_title: 1MDB's US$2.3b Cayman fund now fully redeemed
summary: 1MDB, a Malaysian state-owned company, has fully redeemed its US$2.318 billion investment in a Cayman Islands registered fund, following a US$1.215 billion redemption earlier. The move aims to ease criticism and address financial pressures, including RM42 billion in debts and a RM2 billion payment owed to local banks. New president Arul Kanda attributed the redemption to softer economic conditions and a need to shore up domestic activities. The full redemption will provide breathing space, but 1MDB still faces significant challenges, including opaque investments and a struggling cash flow.

site_title: United Air mulls outsourcing jobs at 28 US airports
summary: United Airlines is reviewing outsourcing jobs at 28 US airports, potentially impacting 2,000 workers, including baggage handlers and gate agents. The move is part of the carrier's cost-cutting efforts to reach a $2 billion annual reduction. The company has already announced plans to outsource 630 jobs and may offer workers the option to transfer to other airports, with furloughs or layoffs possible if declined. The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers will negotiate with the airline to retain workers within the company.

site_title: Japan joins Germany in bond yield slide
summary: Japan's 10-year bond yield fell to 0.255% as global bonds surged, driven by tumbling oil costs and slowing inflation expectations. Germany's 10-year yield also matched Japan's at zero, while Australia's hit a record low of 2.603%. The Bank of America Merrill Lynch Global Broad Market Sovereign Plus Index dropped to 1.21%, a record low since 1996, and the US 10-year yield declined one basis point to 1.90%. The European Central Bank may start buying government debt soon, fueling speculation about a potential programme to combat deflation.

site_title: Finance minister warns of accidental Grexit after polls
summary: Finance Minister Gikas Hardouvelis warns that Greece could accidentally leave the euro area due to a new government's failure to reach an agreement with international creditors after the January 25 election. Hardouvelis advises the next government to negotiate an extension to the bailout before the aid expires on February 28. If led by Syriza, the party of Alexis Tsipras, Greece may seek a write-down on debt, which is unacceptable to creditors. Hardouvelis emphasizes the need for clarity to avoid negative economic consequences, suggesting that the earlier the uncertainty is clarified, the better for everyone.

site_title: Trading on oil price movements via ETFs
summary: Crude oil prices plummeted 41.4% in the last three months of 2014, reaching a 2014 peak of $108 per barrel. This decline hit energy fund investors hard, with mutual funds averaging a 20% loss. However, some energy ETFs, such as those focusing on exploration and production, did moderately better. Investors are divided on the future of oil prices, with some expecting a sustained decline and others anticipating a rebound. Analysts recommend focusing on domestic refinery operators and storage centers/pipeline operators, which are less sensitive to energy price fluctuations.

site_title: Facebook 'likes' can reveal your true personality
summary: Researchers at the University of Cambridge and Stanford University found that a computer program analyzing Facebook "likes" can be a better judge of personality than close friends and family. The study used data from 86,220 volunteers, who completed a personality questionnaire and shared their Facebook "likes." The computer predicted personality traits with high accuracy, outperforming human judges in some cases. The findings raise concerns about privacy and call for policies to control digital footprints, with lead author Wu Youyou stating that computers could become emotionally-intelligent and socially skilled machines in the future.

site_title: Airbus to equip its long-haul jets with floatable black boxes
summary: Airbus plans to equip its long-haul jets, including the A350 and A380, with ejectable black boxes that can float, making them easier to locate in air crashes at sea. The technology, approved for military aircraft, was previously used in civil aviation only for take-off and landing. The move comes after recent passenger jet crashes into the ocean, highlighting the need for improved recovery methods. Airbus aims to install the ejectable black boxes first on its A350 and A380 jets, with the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) set to vote on a recommendation to equip commercial airliners with the technology.

site_title: Eco World buys 75% stake in London residential projects worth £2.2b
summary: Eco World Investment Co, a Malaysian property company, has agreed to acquire a 75% stake in three London residential projects worth £2.2 billion. The projects, located near Battersea Power Station, Canary Wharf, and the Leamouth Peninsula, will include 2,800 homes and 250,000 square feet of commercial space. Ballymore Group, the developer, will retain a 25% stake and manage the developments. The acquisition is part of a trend of developers buying residential land in London due to a shortage of new homes, with home prices rising 18% in the year through November.

site_title: US$3 trillion inheritance expected in Asia over next 30 years: report
summary: Wealth-X and National Financial Partners Corp predict US$3 trillion in inheritance transfers to the next generation in Asia over the next 30 years, with US$110 billion expected in Singapore alone. The top five countries with the largest proportion of wealth transfers will be Malaysia, Taiwan, Japan, Hong Kong, and Singapore. Globally, US$16 trillion of UHNW wealth is expected to be transferred, with 40% coming from the US. Inheritance taxes may impact these transfers, with Japan and the US charging 50% and 40% respectively, while China charges no tax.

site_title: India needs to aim for growth without inflation: junior finance minister
summary: India's junior finance minister, Jayant Sinha, emphasized the need for non-inflationary economic growth, aiming for 7-8% growth. This comes as India's consumer price inflation accelerated to 5.0% in December, driven by higher food costs. Sinha's comments follow India's annual inflation acceleration for the first time in five months.

site_title: Noble, O&M selloff sees STI lose ground
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 3.82 points to 3,341.07 on Tuesday, weighed down by heavy selling of Noble Group and offshore and marine (O&M) stocks. Noble Group's stock plummeted 6.8% to S$1.025, while Keppel Corp's stock dropped 0.12% to S$8.17. Despite Nomura's positive outlook on the O&M sector, the market's focus remained narrow. Overseas markets, including Wall Street, provided little direction, with the S&P 500 dropping 0.8% due to weak oil prices.

images.alt_text: Volume, however, picked up and amounted to 1.4 billion units worth S$1.2 billion largely because of heavy selling of Noble Group and pressure on offshore and marine (O&M) stocks.

site_title: ADB president Nakao praises Indonesia's fuel subsidy cut
summary: ADB president Takehiko Nakao praised Indonesia's fuel subsidy cut, saying it will free up resources for infrastructure and development priorities. The move has boosted market confidence in the country's economic program. Nakao met with Indonesian President Joko Widodo to discuss further cooperation between the ADB and Indonesia.

site_title: Muslims assimilate better in the US than in Europe
summary: US Muslims are more assimilated into American society than their European counterparts, with many integrating into the country's social and cultural milieu. A study by Charles Kurzman found that Muslim-American terrorism has claimed 37 lives in the US since 9/11, a fraction of the 137 fatalities in 2013. In contrast, European countries like France and Britain have struggled with Muslim extremism and alienation. Factors contributing to this difference include the US's history of immigration, cultural diversity, and lower levels of anti-Muslim sentiment.

site_title: Oil prices down again as UAE defends production hold
summary: Crude oil prices hit their lowest in almost six years, falling 60% from June 2014 peaks, due to rising production, particularly US shale oil, and weaker-than-expected demand. Opec producers, including the UAE, defended their decision not to cut output, offering discounts to customers to defend market share. Analysts predict further falls, with Goldman Sachs cutting its Brent forecast to $50.40 a barrel from $83.75, and Deutsche Bank predicting $59.40 a barrel.

site_title: Oil price fall unjustified but set to continue: Kuwait
summary: Kuwait's Oil Minister Ali al-Omair stated that the recent sharp fall in oil prices is unjustified, attributing it to a production glut of 1.8 million barrels per day and a slowdown in global economic growth. The market may not improve before the second half of this year, according to al-Omair.

images.alt_text: Kuwait said on Tuesday that the sharp fall in world oil prices is unjustified but that the market may not improve before the second half of this year.

site_title: US: Stocks jump as Alcoa results best expectations
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, following European equity markets, as Alcoa's quarterly earnings beat expectations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 1.35% to 17,879.10, while the S&P 500 jumped 1.16% to 2,051.83 and the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 1.26% to 4,724.62. The gains were attributed to Alcoa's strong earnings, which kicked off quarterly earnings season.

site_title: Report on Forest City project gets nod from M'sian environment department
summary: Malaysia's Department of Environment (DoE) approved a detailed environmental impact assessment (DEIA) report for the Forest City Island Reclamation and Mixed Development project off southwest Johor, allowing the project to proceed. The project's land area has been scaled down by about a fifth, from 5,000 acres to 4,012.5 acres, following the approval. The DoE's decision was made public on Monday, paving the way for the project's continuation.

site_title: Former UBS trader challenges US case over Libor scheme
summary: A US lawyer has urged a New York federal judge to dismiss charges against a former UBS trader, Roger Darin, in a case related to alleged Libor rate manipulation. Darin's lawyer argued that the alleged conduct occurred overseas and had little connection to the US. The US prosecutor countered that Darin could have anticipated the impact of Libor rates on the New York markets. Darin is one of 11 individuals charged in the US as part of a global investigation into Libor and related rates.

site_title: Kaisa's ties to official under investigation being probed
summary: China's Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd is under investigation for ties to a senior official in Shenzhen, who's being probed since October. The company, which missed a US$23 million interest payment last week, had dealings with Jiang Zunyu, party chief of Longgang district. Kaisa's chairman Kwok Ying Shing resigned after the company defaulted on a HK$400 million loan, triggering a waiver from HSBC Holdings Plc. The company's immediate cash has been reduced as it seeks to restructure its debt, with its 2020 notes dropping to 30 cents on the dollar.

site_title: How investment banks can tap opportunities in 2015
summary: Investment banks in 2015 face opportunities and challenges in a highly-regulated environment. Initiatives such as Asean Exchanges create new investment opportunities, but require banks to adapt to additional regulatory requirements. Staff costs remain a significant challenge, accounting for 60% of operating expenditure. To address this, banks should consider outsourcing non-core areas and adopting digital technologies and analytics. Additionally, they must restructure governance structures and business models to meet their cost of capital and generate sufficient return on equity.

site_title: SPH, INKEF invest in social media news curation platform
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) and INKEF Capital have invested in Crowdynews, a social media curation platform for media companies. Crowdynews raised 2.5 million euros (S$3.95 million) in Series A funding to expand globally, particularly in Asia. The platform gathers and filters social media content and integrates it into news cycles, providing a "crowd perspective" on stories. With SPH's guidance, Crowdynews plans to integrate its platform onto more magazine titles and in-house units, offering new opportunities for digital revenue growth.

site_title: TCP Asia not to collaborate with Sitra in hotel project
summary: TCP Asia has dropped out of a hotel project in Timor Leste with Sitra Holdings, citing no further collaboration. Sitra had accepted a binding letter of intent from TCP in December 2014, but TCP now plans to evaluate its rights. The US$17.5 million project, led by the ZEESM Authority of Timor Leste, will proceed without TCP. The decision comes after Sitra's share price fell 5.26% following the news.

site_title: Rouble down around 5% against dollar on back of falling oil price
summary: The Russian rouble plummeted by around 5% against the dollar due to a sharp decline in global oil prices, reaching 66.38 against the ruble as of 1330 GMT on Tuesday. This marks a significant drop from the start of the year, with the currency losing around 16% against the dollar. The decline in oil prices has put pressure on Russia's economy, which has been heavily reliant on oil exports.

site_title: Making enclosed spaces on board safer for everyone
summary: The Enclosed Space Management System, launched by Videotel and Mines Rescue Marine, aims to improve safety in enclosed spaces on board ships. The system assesses, audits, and manages safety risks, providing a "living" database for crew members to contribute information and reducing the risk of safety being affected by crew changes. The system meets International Maritime Organization (IMO) and SOLAS recommendations and can be accessed ashore and on board. The system costs approximately $200 per year per ship for a licence, making it a proactive approach to reducing enclosed space-related accidents and fatalities.

site_title: Lower than expected bids at tender for Yishun mixed site
summary: A Housing and Development Board (HDB) tender for a mixed-use commercial/residential site at Yishun Ave 4 garnered a "muted" turnout from just five bidders, falling short of predicted six to 18 bidders. The top bid of S$185.09 million (S$629.24 psf ppr) from Northern Resi and Northern Retail was below the predicted floor of S$650 psf ppr. Experts attribute the low bids to the mandatory use of prefabricated prefinished volumetric construction (PPVC) technology, higher construction costs, and competition in the vicinity.

site_title: Paris's ultra-modern concert hall to open
summary: Paris's ultra-modern concert hall, La Philharmonie, is set to open on Wednesday with a gala concert. Designed by Jean Nouvel, the 386m euro venue features a 2,400-seat concert hall with curved balconies for better views and acoustics. This new home for orchestral events is a departure from the city's traditional Belle Epoque landmarks, blending modernity with Parisian charm. The opening marks a significant addition to the city's cultural landscape.

site_title: US energy job hiring to slow in H1 amid price crash: Rigzone survey
summary: US energy job hiring is expected to slow in the first half of 2015 due to tumbling oil prices, forcing oil and gas producers to cut spending. 44% of hiring managers surveyed anticipate hiring less, while 5% expect no hiring. This shift in outlook reflects the industry's adjustment to the current economy, with many firms bracing for a difficult 2015. Oil prices have fallen from $115 to $46 per barrel in the past seven months, prompting companies to pause hiring plans.

site_title: China shuts 50 websites and social media accounts
summary: China has shut 50 websites and social media accounts for violating regulations, including pornography and unlicensed online news content. The Cyberspace Administration of China made the announcement, citing a crackdown on unwanted material online. The move is seen as further limiting free speech in the one-party Communist state. Authorities targeted 17 Weixin pages, 24 websites, and 9 online columns for violating rules.

site_title: Airbus says priority for A380 is new customers
summary: Airbus expects to secure new orders for its A380 this year, despite failing to book any in 2014. The priority is to find customers for the current version, rather than waiting for upgrades. Emirates, the largest A380 customer, has expressed interest in ordering more planes if upgraded with new engines. Airbus plans to evolve the A380 in the long term, but for now, the company is focusing on finding new customers.

site_title: EU finds 'huge scepticism' over US trade deal
summary: The European Union has found "huge scepticism" among Europeans regarding a key element in the proposed EU-US trade deal, known as the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Pact (TTIP). A survey of 150,000 responses received an overwhelming number of negative comments, with 97% organized by activists. This setback is the latest challenge for the 19-month-old talks, which aim to be the world's biggest free trade deal.

site_title: King Wan gets four M&E projects worth S$43.3m
summary: King Wan Corporation has secured four new mechanical and electrical (M&E) projects in Singapore worth S$43.3 million. The projects, valued at S$209 million, will be completed by 2018. The projects include plumbing and sanitary systems installations for public housing developments and an aircon installation for an executive condominium project. This brings King Wan's order book to its current level.

site_title: Malaysia's CIMB says bank merger talks continuing, board meeting Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's CIMB Group Holdings Bhd said talks on a proposed three-way bank merger are continuing, with a board meeting set for Wednesday to discuss the deal. The $20 billion merger, involving CIMB, RHB Capital Bhd, and Malaysia Building Society Bhd, would create the country's largest bank by assets. However, sources indicate Malaysia may scrap the deal after CIMB and RHB Capital failed to agree on terms.

site_title: Changi Airports lands extension to operate Saudi airport till June
summary: Changi Airports International (CAI) has secured a seven-month extension to manage and operate the King Fahd International Airport in Dammam, Saudi Arabia, until June this year. Under CAI's management, the airport has seen significant growth, including a 65% increase in passenger traffic, 80% rise in concession space, and more than doubling of non-aeronautical revenue over the past six years. CAI's efforts have helped establish KFIA as a leading regional airport, with 36 airlines serving 65 cities, and the airport is expected to handle over 21 million passengers per year once infrastructure plans are completed.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

Efforts to improve the King Fahd International Airport include infrastructure initiatives to boost airport capacity, as well as expanding commercial and retail offerings to enhance passengers' experience

site_title: Malaysia's US$20b bank merger set to collapse: sources
summary: Malaysia's US$20 billion bank merger between CIMB Holdings and RHB Capital is set to collapse after the two firms failed to agree on new deal terms. The merger, which would have formed the country's largest bank, was part of Malaysia's plan to promote regional champions. CIMB Chairman Nazir Razak, brother of Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak, faces a major blow to his expansion efforts. The collapse could raise concerns about Malaysian bank governance, following recent bank troubles and a sharp decline in oil-related revenue.

site_title: Zico to form joint venture with Stamford Law
summary: Zico Holdings, a Singapore-based integrated professional services provider, has formed a 51-49 joint-venture company (JVC) with Stamford Law Corporation to offer corporate secretarial services. The JVC will manage corporate secretarial files, including a $2.4 million acquisition of Stamford Law's files, which were completed on January 1. The partnership aims to enhance Zico's services and expand its client base, while also reducing operational expenses. Zico's shares rose 3.13% following the announcement.

site_title: Housing in focus as Hong Kong leader seeks support in post-protest address
summary: Hong Kong leader Leung Chun-ying is set to focus on housing, the economy, and youth issues in his policy address, aiming to boost support after last year's protests. He plans to increase housing supply, including subsidized flats and limited development of country parks, to moderate prices. The government has pledged to supply 480,000 flats over 10 years, with potential additional measures. Leung's address seeks to heal divisions, maintain ties with China, and ensure the economy's steady growth, expected at 2.2% this year, while addressing concerns about democracy and youth expectations.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong leader Leung Chun-ying is expected to focus on housing, the economy and youth issues in his policy address on Wednesday, seeking to bolster support after last year's massive pro-democracy protests and widespread calls for him to quit.

site_title: Opec won't back down, UAE minister says as oil plunges
summary: OPEC, led by the UAE, has reaffirmed its decision not to cut oil production to support prices, despite a 4% drop in Brent crude to below $46 a barrel. The move is expected to lead to higher-cost producers reducing output. Iranian President Hassan Rouhani warned that countries behind the price drop will regret their decision, while OPEC's energy minister said the market needs time to adjust and a fair price range would be one that allows shale oil producers to continue operating.

site_title: Global Logistic Properties incorporates four & acquires two new indirect subsidiaries
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) incorporated four and acquired two new indirect subsidiaries, mainly involved in distribution facilities and services. The new subsidiaries include GLP Zhuzhou, Pujian Xixianxinqu, GLP Nantong NSIP, and GLP Foshan Pudan Logistic Service. GLP also acquired a 65% interest in Beijing Lihao Technology and the entire interest in Shanghai Kangjiekong Logistics Facilities. The acquisitions are not expected to impact GLP's net tangible asset value and earnings per share for the 2015 financial year.

site_title: BOJ to cut next fiscal year's CPI forecast to 1.5% or lower: sources
summary: The Bank of Japan is expected to cut its core consumer inflation forecast for the fiscal year ending in March 2016 to 1.5% or lower, putting pressure on the central bank to ease policy or acknowledge it will take more time to meet its 2% target. This comes after oil prices have fallen 60% since last June, making the cut deeper than initially projected. The move is seen as a response to the BOJ's already huge stimulus program, which may need to be expanded to meet its price target.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan is expected to cut its core consumer inflation forecast for next fiscal year - the deadline for meeting its 2 per cent target - to 1.5 per cent or lower, sources say, keeping it under pressure to expand an already huge stimulus programme.

site_title: 10-year Singapore Government Securities yield falls below 2%
summary: The 10-year Singapore Government Securities (SGS) yield has fallen below 2% as investors anticipate delayed interest rate hikes. The yield dropped to 1.99% from 2.09% on Monday, resulting in a 0.8% increase in the bond's price. This follows the US Treasury's 10-year yield, which has also declined to 1.88% from 2.17% on December 31, 2014. Experts predict the US Federal Reserve will only hike interest rates by Q3, contributing to the market's optimism.

site_title: Europe: Shares roused by rally in retailers
summary: Retail shares in Europe led the region's equities higher, with the STOXX Europe 600 Retail Index rising 2.9% on expectations of new economic stimulus measures from the European Central Bank. German retailer Metro AG and British supermarket operator Morrison advanced 4.5% on strong Christmas sales. The European oil and gas sector underperformed due to low oil prices, which are expected to boost consumer spending. Greece's benchmark index rose 3.3% ahead of a January 25 election, while Italy's borrowing costs hit new record lows on speculation of ECB plans for government bond purchases.

site_title: Shell restarts Singapore ethylene cracker: trade
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has restarted its ethylene cracker in Bukom, Singapore, after a three-month maintenance and expansion project. The project increased the unit's capacity by 20% to 960,000 tonnes per year. The cracker uses naphtha and liquefied petroleum gas to produce ethylene, a key building block for plastics. Shell declined to comment on the restart date, citing its disclosure policy. The expansion work aims to raise the unit's capacity and meet growing demand for ethylene in the market.

site_title: Charlie Hebdo to publish Mohammad cartoon on front page
summary: Charlie Hebdo plans to publish a front page with a caricature of the Prophet Mohammad on January 14, 2015, in its first edition since the Islamist attack on the satirical newspaper that killed 17 people. The paper will print up to 3 million copies, with demand surging for the edition. The cartoon, titled "Je suis Charlie," features a tearful Mohammad with a sign saying "I am Charlie" and will be accompanied by other cartoons making fun of politicians and religions. France has increased security measures, and European leaders are concerned about rising anti-immigrant sentiment.

site_title: SPH Q1 profit falls 21.9%
summary: SPH's Q1 net profit fell 21.9% to S$69.4 million, down from S$88.8 million a year ago. Operating revenue declined 6.5% to S$307.1 million, mainly due to a 7.9% drop in newspaper and magazine revenue. The property business saw revenue edge up to S$51.4 million. The company attributed the decline to muted global macroeconomic outlook, deflationary pressures, and a tight local labour market, expecting modest domestic economic growth.

site_title: Taiwan slams China flight routes plan
summary: Taiwan has strongly opposed China's plan to open four new flight routes over the Taiwan Strait, calling it "unacceptable" and a potential air defense threat. China had not consulted with Taiwan on three of the routes, which could lead to planes flying too close to existing routes. Taiwan's defense ministry stated it will monitor and intercept any unidentified aircraft, while China hopes to ease congestion on existing paths. The move has strained relations between the two sides, which have improved since 2008 but remain wary of Beijing's increasing influence.

site_title: Northern Resi, Northern Retail come up tops in Yishun Ave 4 site tender
summary: A consortium of Northern Resi and Northern Retail won the highest price of S$185.09 million for a 27,327 sqm HDB site at Yishun Avenue 4, with S$629.24 per square foot per plot ratio. This is the first GLS site to adopt prefabricated prefinished volumetric construction (PPVC) and meet prefabrication rules. The second-highest bid was S$181.6 million by KBD Ventures and Changi Properties, while Sim Lian came in third with S$168 million. The winning bid surpasses the S$617.37 psf ppr of the second-highest bidder.

site_title: Alibaba agrees to block sale of dangerous toys in US: commission
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has agreed to block the sale of up to 15 illegal or dangerous toys in the US, marking the first such agreement between the US Consumer Product Safety Commission and a foreign company. The deal, announced at the Hong Kong Toys and Games Fair, is not enforceable, but demonstrates the company's commitment to cooperation with US authorities. CPSC Chairman Elliot Kaye welcomed the partnership, stating that Alibaba is "thrilled to cross beyond our borders and work with whomever we need to."

site_title: European banks face US$52b in litigation costs: Morgan Stanley
summary: European banks, including Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays, may face significant litigation costs of US$52 billion over the next two years, mostly related to foreign exchange trading and mortgage mis-selling. US banks have already paid US$230 billion in litigation costs since 2009, with European banks paying US$104 billion so far. Regulators have fined six banks US$4.3 billion for manipulating foreign exchange markets, and analysts predict additional costs of US$7.5 billion for foreign exchange rigging and US$9.4 billion for US mortgages.

site_title: Airbus hopes cockpit recorder to help explain AirAsia crash
summary: Airbus CEO Fabrice Bregier welcomed the retrieval of the cockpit voice recorder from the sunken AirAsia A320 plane wreckage. The recorder will be sent to Jakarta for analysis to help explain the cause of the Dec 28 crash that killed 162 people. Bregier expressed hope that the investigation will bring clarity, and Airbus will support the investigation to draw lessons for the future, reaffirming air transport as the safest way to travel.

site_title: Metro reports strong Christmas sales at core units
summary: Metro AG reported sales fell 2.2% to 18.3 billion euros in the first quarter of its 2014/15 financial year, beating analyst forecasts. The company's consumer electronics business, Media-Saturn, saw a 3.8% increase in same-store sales and a 25% rise in online sales. Despite a challenging economic environment, CEO Olaf Koch stated that the group has created a "solid basis" for a slight rise in sales for the full year.

site_title: Germany achieves balanced budget one year ahead of schedule
summary: Germany has achieved a balanced federal budget one year ahead of schedule, marking the first time in nearly half a century. Robust tax revenues and low interest rates contributed to the achievement, which is a boon for Chancellor Angela Merkel's government. The feat was set in the 2013 coalition agreement and demonstrates Germany's fiscal discipline, potentially giving it more leeway to support weak euro zone growth.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as oil slump hits energy stocks
summary: European stocks fell 0.5% in early trading on Tuesday, driven by a 4.2% drop in oil prices, which led to a decline in energy stocks. The FTSEurofirst 300 index fell to 1,351.67 points. However, shares in German retailer Metro rose 3.3% after reporting a recovery in its wholesale and consumer electronics units.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 13.82 points to close at 1,748.9 on Tuesday, driven by 502 gains and 313 losses. The index saw 1.91 billion lots traded, valued at RM2.12 billion.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end lower
summary: Singapore shares ended lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index slipping 3.82 points to 3,341.07. A total of 1.39 billion shares were traded, with 164 gainers and 226 losers. This marks a reversal from the previous day's 0.4% gain.

site_title: Tee International Q2 net profit down 5.8%; lower turnover from engineering projects
summary: Tee International, a mainboard-listed engineering and property company, reported a 5.8% decline in Q2 FY2015 net profit to S$1.52 million, driven by lower turnover from engineering projects and higher administrative expenses. Revenue fell 14.2% to S$43.0 million. The company expects a challenging business environment and will focus on delivering ongoing projects on time and leveraging its existing network to secure new projects. Interim dividends were issued at 0.18 cents per share, down 0.27 cents from the previous period.

site_title: Amazon creates 6,000 new permanent jobs in Europe
summary: Amazon created 6,000 new full-time permanent jobs in Europe in 2014, bringing its total EU staff to 32,000. The jobs were created in logistics, customer service, software development, supply chain management, and design. The majority of new positions were in Germany (1,200) and Britain, with the rest spread across other EU countries. This move comes as Amazon invests in the European market, driven by booming demand.

site_title: StanChart to close Swiss private bank after sale founders
summary: Standard Chartered is closing its Swiss private bank after failing to attract a buyer, as part of its plan to shed non-core businesses and focus on Asia, Africa, and the Middle East. The bank began winding down the business a few months ago, moving most accounts to other booking centers. The Swiss unit had 70 staff, with most finding new roles or leaving. The closure is part of broader changes at Standard Chartered, which also announced plans to close its equities business and axe 4,000 jobs.

site_title: CNN wins go-ahead to test drones for news coverage
summary: CNN has reached an agreement with the US aviation regulators to test drones for news gathering in the US. The tests will take place at the Georgia Tech Research Institute and aim to establish safe and high-quality video journalism using drones. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has banned private use of drones for aerial surveillance, but allows exceptions for video production companies. The agreement is seen as a step towards safely integrating drones into the National Airspace System, with the hope of paving the way for legislation to allow their use in news coverage.

site_title: ECB ready to decide on QE by January meeting: official
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is nearing a decision on its quantitative easing (QE) program, with executive board member Benoit Coeure stating that the discussion is "very far advanced" and a decision is likely by January 22. The ECB had a discussion on technical details last week and is set to make a decision on the program, which would involve purchasing sovereign bonds to boost the eurozone economy. The move is seen as a potential solution to the region's economic woes.

site_title: India central bank likely buying dollars via state banks: traders
summary: The Indian central bank is likely buying dollars via state-run banks to prevent a further appreciation in the rupee. The partially convertible rupee traded at 62.06/07 per dollar, after briefly hitting a 10-day high of 61.0175.
