summary: The Bank of Canada's quarterly business outlook survey shows that the plunge in oil prices has significantly dampened the outlook for Canadian energy firms, despite overall business sentiment remaining positive. Companies expect sales to grow at a slightly faster pace this year, but investment intentions are lower, particularly for Western Canadian companies. Oil price developments have led to uncertainty about business outlooks, with a majority of businesses expecting lower inflation over the next two years. Business lending conditions remained nearly unchanged in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong campaigners announce major democracy rally
summary: A pro-democracy group in Hong Kong announced plans for a major street rally on February 1, with organizers expecting 50,000 to attend. The rally comes after months of protests, which ended when protest camps were cleared by police. The group, the Civil Human Rights Front, is calling for universal suffrage in Hong Kong, citing Beijing's vetting process for candidates in 2017. The rally is seen as a continuation of civil disobedience, with protesters expressing their determination to see the cause through despite police crackdowns.

site_title: Southeast Asia stocks: Thai trims gains, Bank Mandiri leads Indonesia decline
summary: Thai stocks rose 0.12% on Monday, driven by selective buying ahead of quarterly earnings reports, while most other Southeast Asian markets ended little-changed to weaker. Indonesian stocks declined, with Bank Mandiri dropping 2.7%, and the Philippine index retreated after domestic investors cashed out from recent gainers. Thai energy stocks fell due to declining oil prices, and Bank Mandiri plans to increase its capital by 9 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Oil prices sink further, dollar hit by wage data
summary: Oil prices plummeted, falling for the second consecutive day, as a weak US wage growth report led to a sell-off in New York markets. The news also negatively impacted the dollar, making it harder for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. Asian markets, including Sydney and Seoul, also declined. The drop in oil prices is attributed to bearish market sentiment, particularly due to Trump's tariff outlook.

site_title: US: Wall St opens up slightly, investors await earnings
summary: US stocks opened modestly higher on Monday, as investors awaited the start of the corporate earnings season. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 44.76 points, or 0.25%, to 17,782.13. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 rising 4.21 points, or 0.21%, to 2,049.02 and the Nasdaq Composite adding 10.50 points, or 0.22%, to 4,714.57, despite a two-week decline pushing the S&P 500 into negative territory for the year.

site_title: Indonesian state lender Mandiri to raise capital by US$715m: minister
summary: Indonesia's state-owned bank Mandiri plans to raise its capital by 9 trillion rupiah (US$714.6 million) through a rights issue and government injection, subject to parliament's approval. The bank will use the funds to pay out large dividends.

site_title: European stocks rise, buoyed by chemical and health shares
summary: European stocks rose on Monday, led by gains in healthcare shares, after Shire agreed to buy NPS Pharmaceuticals for $5.2 billion and Roche struck a deal. Chemicals shares also performed well after Citigroup upgraded several European chemicals companies, citing a weaker euro as a boost to earnings. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index rose 0.5% to 1,352.67 points, while the STOXX Europe 600 Healthcare Index advanced 0.8%.

site_title: Surbana, Jurong International named master planners for new capital of Indian state
summary: Surbana International Consultants and Jurong International have been appointed master planners for the new capital of the Indian state of Andhra Pradesh, with over 7,000 sq km of land use projected to support a population of 49.4 million. This international collaboration marks the first large-scale project between the two companies, which have previously completed over 20 projects in India. The master plan is expected to bring economic benefits to Andhra Pradesh, Singapore, and the international business community, with opportunities for Singapore companies to participate in the region's growth.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Facebook, Xiaomi discussed possible investment in the Chinese smartphone maker: sources
summary: Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg discussed a potential $1.1 billion investment in Xiaomi, China's top smartphone maker, with Xiaomi CEO Lei Jun in October 2014. The talks were informal and never formalized due to concerns over Facebook's ban in China. The discussions highlight the growing ties between US and Chinese companies as China's tech industry matures. A deal was never materialized, but the talks underscore the complexity of investing in a Chinese company with a significant political and commercial risk.

site_title: Singapore bonds beat STI in 2015 so far
summary: Singapore bonds have outperformed the Straits Times Index (STI) for the week ended Jan 9, 2015, with the Singapore Fixed Income Indices (SFI) gaining 0.66% to 120.32 points, compared to a 0.79% loss for the STI. The SFI is comprised of 62% Singapore government bonds, 16% statutory board bonds, and 22% corporate bonds, but currently has no tracking funds.

images.alt_text: A bond index created by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Reuters tracking Singapore-dollar denominated bonds continues to hit new highs, outperforming the Straits Times Index (STI) for the week ended Jan 9, 2015.

site_title: Two blue-chip companies drop UBS as corporate broking adviser: FT
summary: UBS Group AG, Switzerland's largest bank, has lost two blue-chip corporate broking clients, BAE Systems Plc and Smith & Nephew Plc. BAE confirmed it dropped UBS in favor of Morgan Stanley, while Smith & Nephew's decision was cited by the Financial Times. This loss follows a previous departure of another major client, HSBC. The reasons behind the departures are not specified.

site_title: Pressure change likely caused AirAsia jet to explode before impact: government official
summary: An AirAsia jet that crashed in Indonesia likely experienced an explosion before hitting the water, according to a government official. The explosion, caused by a significant change in air pressure, is believed to have disintegrated the left side of the plane. The finding is based on the wreckage and other investigations.

images.alt_text: The AirAsia airliner that crashed two weeks ago in Indonesia likely "experienced an explosion" before hitting the water due to a significant change in air pressure, a senior government official said on Monday.

site_title: OECD indicator signals stable growth
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has reported stable economic growth across the OECD area and the eurozone, despite signs of slowing in Germany and Italy. The OECD's monthly leading indicator showed a stable eurozone index of 100.6, while individual countries saw mixed results, with France showing a marginal improvement and Russia experiencing a notable dip. China's index ticked up to 99.3, while the US and Japan remained steady. The OECD's overall index nudged up to 100.5.

site_title: China 2014 auto sales beat 23m, but growth slows
summary: China's auto sales reached 23.49 million vehicles in 2014, exceeding the 23 million target, but growth slowed to 6.9% due to a weaker economy. This is half of the 13.7% growth in 2013. The China Association of Automobile Manufacturers (CAAM) had initially forecast 10% growth, but later reduced its target to 8.3%. The slower growth is attributed to the economic slowdown in China, affecting the world's largest car market.

site_title: US media criticize Obama for missing Paris rally
summary: US President Barack Obama faced criticism from American media for not attending a Paris solidarity rally following deadly Islamist attacks in France. The rally, which drew 1.6 million people, was led by world leaders including French President, but Obama and Vice President Joe Biden were not in attendance. The US Ambassador to France, Jane Hartley, represented the US at the event. The administration downplayed the criticism, with Secretary of State John Kerry stating that the relationship with France is not about one day or one particular moment.

site_title: Opec price war in Asia intensifies as oil falls below US$50
summary: Oil prices have fallen below $50 a barrel, the weakest since 2009, as a price war intensifies in Asia. Gulf Opec producers, led by Saudi Arabia, are competing to secure market share, with the UAE joining Kuwait and Iraq in pricing their crude below Saudi's. Goldman Sachs has cut its price forecast to just above $40, citing the need for lower prices to hold shale oil investments. To restore market balance, output cuts from Opec and non-Opec producers will be necessary, according to consultancy FGE.

site_title: Update: Divers retrieve "black box" data recorder from AirAsia wreck
summary: Indonesian navy divers successfully retrieved the black box flight data recorder from the wreckage of AirAsia Flight QZ8501, which crashed on December 28, killing all 162 people on board. The second black box, containing the cockpit voice recorder, has been located but not yet retrieved. The retrieved data recorder is being analyzed and investigators may need up to a month to complete the reading. The crash is believed to have been caused by seasonal storms, and relatives of the victims are urging authorities to prioritize finding the remaining bodies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end 0.45% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.45% to 24,026.46, driven by Cheung Kong Holdings' surge after unveiling a restructuring plan. This contrasts with mainland China, where the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.71% and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.71%.

site_title: Indonesian safety investigator disputes AirAsia explosion theory
summary: An Indonesian safety investigator has disputed the theory that the AirAsia airliner exploded before hitting water, citing a lack of data to support the claim. Investigator Santoso Sayogo stated that the wreckage showed a significant change in air pressure, suggesting the jet experienced an explosion before impact. The National Search and Rescue Agency's operations coordinator, Mr Supriyadi, had previously reported that the wreckage indicated an explosion occurred before impact. The investigation's findings contradict the initial theory, leaving the cause of the AirAsia disaster still unclear.

images.alt_text: There was no evidence to support the theory that an AirAsia airliner exploded before hitting water two weeks ago, an Indonesian transport safety investigator told Reuters on Monday.

site_title: Airbus in talks with regulator on ejectable 'black boxes'
summary: Airbus is in talks with the European Aviation Safety Agency to make ejectable flight recorders available on its A380 and A350 models, potentially becoming the first commercial planes to use the technology. This move comes after the global aviation authorities consider recommending the devices to make it easier to recover evidence in cases like the AirAsia jet crash. The technology combines both voice and data recordings and could be expanded to other Airbus models, including the A330 and A320. The goal is to improve evidence recovery in crash cases.

site_title: Schroder Investment Management Singapore gets RQFII licence
summary: Schroder Investment Management Singapore Ltd has obtained a Renminbi Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (RQFII) licence from the China Securities Regulatory Commission, allowing it to apply for a one billion yuan quota for the Schroder International Selection Fund Asian Bond Absolute Return.

site_title: Goldman Sachs slashes oil price forecasts
summary: Goldman Sachs has slashed its oil price forecasts, predicting Brent crude will stay below $50 a barrel for a longer period to curb production and end a global supply glut. Analysts led by Jeffrey Currie expect crude oil prices to drop to the high $30s a barrel before rebounding. The bank reduced its 2015 forecast for Brent to $50.40 a barrel and WTI to $47.15 per barrel, down from previous estimates. Short-term forecasts also indicate a drop to $42, $41, and $65 for Brent, WTI, and 12-month forecasts respectively.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 6.45 points to 3,344.89. Trading volumes reached 1.1 billion shares valued at S$906.1 million. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and follows a 5-day winning streak.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed at 1,735.08, up 2.64 points, driven by a trading volume of 1.36 billion lots valued at RM1.46 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 394-317.

site_title: France mobilises 10,000 troops at home after Paris shootings
summary: France has mobilized over 10,000 troops at home after 17 people were killed in attacks by Islamist militants in Paris last week, Defence Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian said. The attacks, which included a shooting at Charlie Hebdo and a hostage-taking at a Jewish deli, were carried out by a Paris-based militant Islamist cell. A massive public demonstration was held on Sunday, with over 1.2 million people marching in Paris and 2.5 million more in the provinces. The French government has also increased security measures, including deploying 4,700 police officers at Jewish schools across the country.

site_title: QE could become part of ECB's normal framework: Finnish official
summary: A senior Bank of Finland official suggests that quantitative easing could become a normal part of the eurozone's monetary policy framework if inflation expectations diverge from the ECB's target. This comes as the ECB prepares to consider bond-buying tools ahead of its January policy meeting to address falling consumer prices and deflation risks. The official hopes this measure is not necessary, but leaves the possibility open.

site_title: GIC selling US$95m stake in Indonesian property firm: IFR
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC is selling up to US$95 million worth of shares in Indonesian property firm Pakuwon Jati as part of its portfolio rebalancing activities. This sale is not a reflection on the company's performance, according to GIC. The move comes as GIC, estimated to have assets worth over US$300 billion, continues its investment strategy.

site_title: Hyundai Motor execs to sell US$1.25b stake in logistics affiliate: source
summary: Hyundai Motor Co.'s chairman and vice chairman, Chung Mong-koo and Chung Eui-sun, plan to sell a combined 4.8 million shares of Hyundai Glovis, a logistics affiliate, for approximately US$1.25 billion. This sale would help Eui-sun, the heir apparent, acquire stakes in Hyundai Motor, Kia Motors, and Hyundai Mobis without triggering antitrust regulations. After the sale, Eui-sun would hold 23.3% of Hyundai Glovis, while Mong-koo's stake would decrease to 6.7%. The shares will be offered at a discount of up to 12% of their last closing price.

site_title: China's Wanda Cinema seeks to raise US$203m in scaled-back IPO: sources
summary: China's Wanda Cinema Line Corp is seeking to raise US$203.26 million through a scaled-back initial public offering (IPO) by selling 60 million shares at 21 yuan per share. The company, controlled by billionaire Wang Jianlin, had originally planned to raise up to 2 billion yuan. The smaller fundraising is due to the China Securities Regulatory Commission's efforts to control IPO pricing and reign in insider trading. Wanda Cinema aims to use the funds to open 50 new cinemas and plans to control 20% of the global box office by 2020.

site_title: Hot stock: Cosco down after earnings guidance
summary: Cosco Corporation's shares plummeted to S$0.55 in Monday trading after the company issued an earnings guidance on Friday, revealing "significantly lower earnings" due to a decline in crude oil prices and a one-off charge for a project. The results are scheduled for release on February 16.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Obama to propose new laws to protect consumer data, privacy
summary: US President Barack Obama plans to propose three new laws to protect consumer data and privacy, including a national standard for companies to notify consumers within 30 days of a data breach, criminalizing overseas trade in stolen identities, and codifying a "Consumer Privacy Bill of Rights" into law. The proposals aim to empower consumers to control how companies use their personal data, particularly in the digital age. The White House will release a revised legislative proposal within 45 days.

site_title: France seeks security answers after Paris attacks
summary: France is addressing security concerns after a series of deadly terrorist attacks, the deadliest in the country's history. The attacks, which targeted a satirical magazine, a kosher supermarket, and police, resulted in 17 deaths. President Francois Hollande will chair a crisis meeting to discuss security measures, amid concerns about how the attackers evaded intelligence. The Kouachi brothers, who carried out the attacks, had a history of extremism and were on a US terror watch list. Millions of people across France and around the world have shown solidarity in historic rallies, with the French government vowing to remain vigilant against potential new attacks.

site_title: Vietnam outlines major bank mergers in 2015: central bank
summary: Vietnam's central bank announced plans for six to eight major bank mergers in 2015 to consolidate the country's banking sector. The moves aim to reduce bad debt and restructure the clogged banking system. Potential mergers include Vietcombank with Saigon Bank, VietinBank with OceanBank, and BIDV with Mekong Housing Bank. The goal is to create more efficient and stable banks, improving the overall financial sector.

site_title: China e-commerce competition intensifies as JD.com, Alibaba go niche
summary: JD.com, China's second-largest e-commerce player, has made a US$1.55 billion deal with online car sales portal Bitauto Holdings, expanding into the high-value market of auto sales. This move intensifies competition with Alibaba Group, as both companies target niche e-commerce markets such as tourism and homes. The deal gives JD.com a 25% stake in Bitauto and benefits from its larger audience and brand recognition, while Bitauto gains JD.com's clout in the auto sales market.

site_title: Australia job advertisements rise 1.8% in December: ANZ
summary: Australian job advertisements rose 1.8% in December to 140,521 per week, the highest in at least two years, according to ANZ. This marks a seventh consecutive month of growth, with annual growth accelerating to 11.4%. Despite this, the official unemployment rate remains 6.3%, and economists caution that new employment opportunities may not be enough to offset the loss of jobs in certain sectors.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as oil, iron slide outweighs upbeat jobs data
summary: Australian shares fell 0.8% on Monday as investors sold down resource sectors due to weak oil and iron ore prices, despite upbeat domestic employment data. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,422.7, down 42.9 points. Weak US jobs data and offshore market declines also weighed on the bourse. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark NZX 50 index rose 0.4%.

site_title: Lufthansa says falling fuel prices will boost profits
summary: Lufthansa expects a significant increase in operating profit in 2015 due to falling fuel prices, with estimated fuel costs of 5.8 billion euros, down from 6.7 billion euros in 2014. The airline attributed the drop to falling oil prices, which will be the "main driver" of its improved profit outlook. As a result, Lufthansa shares rose 1.67% to 14.30 euros on the Frankfurt stock exchange, marking a positive start to the year.

images.alt_text: German airline Lufthansa said on Monday it expects to see a sharp increase in underlying profits this year as a result of falling fuel prices.

site_title: India's growth slowdown has bottomed: finance ministry adviser
summary: India's economic growth slowdown has ended, with the country's economy expected to accelerate to a 5.5% growth rate in the fiscal year ending in March, according to finance ministry adviser Arvind Subramanian. This marks the longest period of sub-par growth since the 1980s, which saw a growth rate below 5% for two years. The positive outlook comes as Asia's third-largest economy looks to bounce back from a slowdown.

site_title: Global banks extend retreat from Asian bond markets: researcher
summary: Global banks have retreated from Asia's local currency bond markets in 2014 due to increasing capital requirements and declining revenues. This has created opportunities for local operators, with domestic banks such as KDB Daewoo Securities and ICBC expanding their presence. Large global banks like RBS and UBS have exited the market, while others like HSBC and Citi remain. The pull-back has also led to a decline in foreign holdings of domestic bonds in Malaysia and the Philippines.

site_title: Scoot ties up with Virgin Australia to expand Aussie network
summary: SCOOT has partnered with Virgin Australia to expand its Australian network. Guests can now book single-transaction tickets to 8 cities, including Adelaide, Brisbane, and Melbourne. This partnership allows for seamless travel between these cities. The expansion aims to enhance connectivity and travel options in Australia.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Credit Suisse expects MAS to ease Singapore monetary policy in April
summary: Credit Suisse predicts the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) will ease monetary policy in April due to a weaker inflation outlook and subdued GDP growth prospects. Analysts expect a reduced slope in interest rates from 2% to 0.5-1% per annum, with a neutral stance or zero pace of appreciation possible if economic activity moderates further. The labour market remains tight, limiting the extent of easing, and a higher unemployment rate could also influence policy decisions.

site_title: China: Stocks end lower ahead of new listings
summary: China stocks closed down 0.9-1.7% on Monday ahead of new listings this week, with investors selling shares to raise funds for upcoming initial public offerings. 22 new share offerings were announced, putting pressure on pricing. The CSI300 index fell 0.9% to 3,513.58, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 1.7% to 3,229.32 points. Foreign investment flowed into Shanghai from Hong Kong, with a daily quota of 13 billion yuan.

site_title: Investors look beyond the obvious for oil-price winners
summary: European businesses, particularly those in the chemicals, household goods, and logistics sectors, are expected to benefit from the slump in oil prices, which have fallen to their lowest since 2009. The cost savings could amount to 20 billion euros (US$23.63 billion) for German industry this year. Analysts also see upside for companies such as Anheuser-Busch InBev, Henkel, and Givaudan, which rely on oil-based materials. However, some logistics businesses, including road-haulage operators, may not benefit as much due to long-term contracts that reflect price swings.

site_title: Detroit auto show roars to life
summary: The North American International Auto Show in Detroit is set to open, with luxury and performance vehicles expected to dominate the event. The US auto industry has seen its best sales year in nearly a decade, thanks to low gas prices and low interest rates. Manufacturers such as Mercedes-Benz, Honda, Ford, and Cadillac are showcasing new models, including the Mercedes-Benz GLE Coupe, Honda's Acura NSX, and Ford's new GT. The luxury sector is expected to be a key focus, with analysts predicting a surge in demand.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.83% higher
summary: Hong Kong shares opened 0.83% higher on Monday, driven by US data showing the world's largest economy added more jobs than expected in December. The Hang Seng Index rose 198.64 points to 24,118.59.

site_title: VW aims to tune in to local tastes in latest US turnaround plan
summary: Volkswagen aims to regain traction in the US market by tuning into local tastes, following a year of changing US chiefs and disappointing sales. The company plans to triple its product range in the crossover segment, refresh models more quickly, and assemble a team of experts at its US plant to better cater to American preferences. This includes a new five-seat variant of the midsize SUV, set to be unveiled at the Detroit auto show, and a long-wheelbase Tiguan seven-seat SUV, potentially built in Mexico in 2017. VW's US sales target for 2018 is 547,000, missing the goal by about a third.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen's latest push to become more than a niche player in the United States builds on a truism the German carmaker has long ignored: if you want to crack the US market, tune in to American customers.

site_title: Indonesia plans to inject US$3.8b into state firms this year
summary: Indonesia plans to inject US$3.8 billion into state-owned enterprises this year, mainly in the infrastructure sector, following the government's move to slash fuel subsidies. The funds will be allocated to companies such as port operators, construction firms, railway operators, and airport operators. This move aims to give the government more fiscal flexibility and allow state-owned firms to leverage on enhanced equity to secure bigger bank loans. The funds will also enable state-owned firms to use their profits for capital expenditure instead of sharing them with the government.

site_title: China: Shares down in morning trade
summary: Chinese shares fell 0.76% in morning trade on Monday, with the Shanghai Composite Index dipping to 3,260.30 and the Shenzhen Composite Index sliding to 1,435.79. The decline was attributed to concerns over tighter liquidity sparked by imminent stock offers.

site_title: Abe says Japan can meet deficit-halving goal with FY2015/16 budget
summary: Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said the country is on track to meet its goal of halving the primary budget deficit by the next fiscal year. The government has proposed a record budget of 96.34 trillion yen, up 460 billion yen from the current year, with tax revenue reaching a 24-year high. The budget aims to revive the economy while restoring public finances, with new bond issuance expected to be trimmed by 4.39 trillion yen. Despite this, the goal of balancing the primary budget by 2020-21 remains ambitious.

site_title: Japan expects real 1.5% growth in fiscal 2015 as economy bounces back
summary: Japan's government forecasts the economy to grow 1.5% in fiscal 2015, a slight upgrade from its previous forecast, due to an expected acceleration in consumer spending. Consumer prices are expected to rise 1.4%, below the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target. The forecast guides fiscal and economic policies as the government aims to accelerate growth after a surprise recession last year. Nominal growth is expected at 2.7%, while real growth in fiscal 2014 is forecast to contract 0.5%.

site_title: India's Jaitley expects nationwide sales tax to take effect next year
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley expects the nationwide sales tax, or Goods and Services Tax (GST), to take effect next year. The GST bill needs support from two-thirds of parliament members and ratification by state legislatures. The tax is seen as a game-changer, simplifying taxes and broadening the tax base, potentially adding 2 percentage points to Asia's third-largest economy.

site_title: Japan economics minister Amari expects real wages to turn positive in FY2015/16
summary: Japanese Economics Minister Akira Amari expects real wages to turn positive in FY2015/16, marking the first time in nearly two decades of mild deflation. This comes as the economy recovers, with wage growth crucial for Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's reflationary policies. Real wages fell 4.3% year-on-year in November, the steepest decline in five years, due to wages failing to keep pace with consumer price gains, weighing on private consumption. This development is seen as a positive sign for Abe's economic stimulus plans.

site_title: High Court judge Tan Siong Thye appointed deputy AG
summary: High Court judge Tan Siong Thye has been appointed deputy Attorney-General of Singapore, assuming the role on February 2, 2015, for a three-year term. The appointment was made by the President upon the Prime Minister's advice, following a distinguished career in the Singapore Legal Service.

images.alt_text: High Court judge Tan Siong Thye has been appointed deputy Attorney-General and will assume his new role at the Attorney-General's Chambers (AGC) on Feb 2, for a period of three years.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index down 16.07 points to 3,328.82. Losers outnumbered gainers 83 to 46, and volume was 57.2 million shares worth S$74.0 million. This marks a reversal from the previous day's 0.4% gain.

site_title: As oil plummets, how much pain still looms for US energy firms?
summary: US energy firms are still reeling from the six-month decline in oil prices, with nearly a quarter of their shares' value wiped out. Despite a recent 4% gain in the broad energy S&P 1500 index, many investors are anxious that the sector may still face significant pain. Smaller firms, such as drilling and trucking companies, are particularly vulnerable, with some reporting sharp cuts in business and shipments. Analysts predict earnings for energy firms will fall 20.7% in the fourth quarter and 36.1% this quarter, with some stocks showing resilience, such as pipeline companies and integrated oil majors.

site_title: Edition eyes financial services-related business in China
summary: EDITION Ltd, a Singapore joint venture company, has entered into a non-binding MOU with an independent third party to engage in financial services-related business in China. The joint venture will hold a 51% stake, with the partner holding the remaining 49%. The MOU is subject to shareholders' approval and relevant authorities' approvals.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Monday, down 2.78 points to 1,729.66, with 78 losers outweighing 71 gainers. Volume was 23.69 million lots worth RM8.90 million.

site_title: Oil falls further in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices fell further in Asia, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropping 81 cents to $47.55 a barrel and Brent crude falling 90 cents to $49.21 a barrel. Weak demand and a supply glut continue to pressure prices, with analysts predicting further declines this week. Crude prices have lost more than half their value since mid-last year, with key producers showing no sign of cutting output. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries has also stated it will not cut production despite excessive supplies.

site_title: Nasdaq eyes running dark pools for banks: WSJ
summary: Nasdaq OMX Group has approached several big banks with a proposal to take over the operation of their "dark pools," electronic trading venues that allow investors to trade anonymously. The proposal aims to reduce costs and increase regulatory transparency, as dark pools have lost market share to broker-run alternative trading systems. Nasdaq plans to seek regulatory permission to manage dark pools on behalf of banks, using its technology, surveillance software, and regulatory expertise. This move comes amid increased regulatory scrutiny of broker-run trading platforms and the shutdown of several banks' dark pools last year.

images.alt_text: Nasdaq OMX Group has approached several big banks with a proposal to take over the operation of their so called "dark pools," and plans to seek regulatory permission to do so, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing Nasdaq chief executive Robert Greifeld.

site_title: Update: Worldwide marches in solidarity with France
summary: A global show of solidarity with France followed the Islamist attacks in Paris that killed 17 people, most at Charlie Hebdo magazine. Hundreds of thousands of people marched worldwide, including in Europe, the Middle East, and North America, chanting "Je suis Charlie" and holding pens in the air. The rallies were held in cities such as Berlin, Jerusalem, Beirut, and Montreal, with prominent figures including European leaders and Hollywood stars showing support for the victims. The marches were seen as a united stand against terrorism and in defense of freedom of expression and media.

site_title: South Korea President Park says no pre-condition to summit with North Korea's Kim
summary: South Korean President Park Geun Hye stated she is open to holding a summit meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, with no pre-condition for talks. Kim had expressed willingness to hold a high-level summit with South Korea on January 1. Park emphasized that an end to North Korea's nuclear program should be a key part of peace discussions on the Korean peninsula, but not a prerequisite for a summit meeting.

site_title: RBS set to exit Asia corporate banking operations: Bloomberg
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland Group plans to exit its Asian corporate banking operations and put most of it up for sale, according to a Bloomberg report. CEO Ross McEwan will discuss the idea in Singapore meetings. The move comes as RBS focuses on UK loans and economic recovery, with 2,000 employees in the Asia-Pacific region potentially affected. The bank has undergone restructuring to pay back taxpayer funds and return to private ownership.

site_title: South Korean president did not assume sure-thing rate cut: official
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye's comments about cooperation between policy authorities did not imply an interest rate cut, contrary to market speculation. Her aide, Choi Sang-mok, clarified that the president's statement was about general macro-economic policy decisions. The initial assumption of an interest rate cut led to a lift in bond futures prices, putting pressure on the central bank to consider a rate cut at its upcoming meeting on January 15.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Park Geun-hye was not assuming an interest rate cut as a sure thing when she talked about cooperation between policy authorities at a news conference on Monday, an aide to Ms Park said.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on weak oil, ore prices
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Monday, despite upbeat domestic employment data, as investors sold down resource sectors due to weak oil and iron ore prices. Energy majors such as Santos and Origin Energy declined 3.3% and 1.7%, respectively. Iron ore miners also fell, with Fortsecue Metals Group down 3%. In contrast, gold producers like Newcrest Mining rose 2.7% and defensive buying pushed the precious metal's spot price higher.

site_title: Former CapitaMalls executive named COO of Mapletree Comm Trust Management
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust Management has appointed Sharon Lim Hwee Li as its chief operating officer, effective January 12. Lim previously served as executive director and CEO of CapitaMalls Malaysia REIT Management from 2010 to 2014. She also held the role of country head for Malaysia at CapitaMalls Asia from 2008. Lim holds a Master of Business Administration from Murdoch University.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: New salaries in London's financial services up 18%
summary: London's financial services sector saw an average 18% salary rise for new hires in 2014, exceeding overall British wage growth. The increase reflects increased demand for staff, with 4,620 new jobs created in December, up 13% from the previous year. Recruitment firms predict continued demand for staff in 2015, with a focus on compliance roles due to heightened regulatory demands. Despite economic uncertainties, Morgan McKinley expects demand for new staff to grow, driven by business needs and regulatory requirements.

site_title: China arrests over 110 people for selling contaminated pork
summary: China has arrested over 110 people suspected of selling contaminated pork, with 1,000 tonnes of the meat confiscated. The arrests are part of a crackdown on food safety violations, with the network selling diseased pigs to markets in 11 provinces since 2008. The suspects also bribed officials to obtain quarantine certificates, with 75 prosecuted and several staff members sent to prosecutors. The move comes amid ongoing food safety concerns in China, following high-profile scandals involving tainted milk powder and donkey meat.

site_title: South Korea launches world's second-biggest carbon market
summary: South Korea has launched its second-largest carbon market, with trading starting on Monday for 525 major companies. The market aims to limit greenhouse gas emissions to 30% below current levels by 2020. Companies have been given a fixed amount of permits to cover emissions for three years, with prices reaching US$7.97 per permit. Despite initial modest volumes, analysts predict a surplus of permits and rising prices, with estimates suggesting prices could reach US$30 by 2017.

site_title: China will not take path of "Western colonists" in Africa: foreign minister
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi stated that the country will not adopt a "Western colonist" approach in Africa, promising to prioritize the continent's ecological environment and long-term interests. China is Africa's largest trade partner and has invested heavily in the region, but some critics accuse the country of imposing one-sided policies and damaging projects. Wang defended China's mediation efforts in South Sudan, saying they were driven by a responsibility to the region rather than China's own interests.

site_title: Bankers see good omens for raising cash on Europe's stock markets
summary: Bankers expect a strong start to 2015 for European stock market offerings, with around 10 initial public offerings (IPOs) and merger and acquisition (M&A) related financing deals anticipated. This follows a record-breaking 2014, where European IPOs raised $65 billion and total equity issuance hit $264 billion. However, market uncertainty, including the UK general election in May and global economic concerns, may impact investor appetite, particularly from US investors.

site_title: China stock investor confidence hits record high: official media
summary: China's investor confidence in stocks reached a record high in December, driven by a 26% increase in the blue-chip index and monetary easing steps. The People's Bank of China cut interest rates in November, supporting the market. Investor sentiment is also influenced by the pace of market reforms, with 48.2% of investors planning to increase their stock holdings. However, some analysts question the sustainability of the rally amid slowing economic growth and weakening corporate earnings. The index rose to 71.2 points, a record high, and was up 52% in 2014.

site_title: Singapore's business optimism dives to near-contractionary levels in Q1 2015: SCCB
summary: Singapore's business optimism plummeted to near-contractionary levels in Q1 2015, with the Business Optimism Index (BOI) falling to +1.11 percentage points from +10.79 in Q4 2014. Only three of six indicators remained in the expansionary region, with volume of sales and net profits entering the contractionary zone. Inventory levels moderated, while selling prices remained unchanged, and hiring sentiment remained positive. The decline marks the second-lowest BOI score in two years since 2013.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Indonesian divers retrieve AirAsia flight data recorder from sea
summary: Indonesian divers have retrieved one of the two black boxes from the wreckage of AirAsia Flight QZ8501, which crashed on December 28, killing 162 people. The flight data recorder was found under the plane's wing and is expected to be analyzed in Jakarta, potentially revealing the cause of the crash. The retrieval comes after "pings" from the black boxes' emergency locator transmitter were detected by three vessels over the weekend. The search for the remaining fuselage and cockpit voice recorder continues, with officials urging calm and promising to prioritize finding the remains of the victims.

site_title: China's Alibaba to buy US$550m stake in Indian online payment firm: sources
summary: China's Alibaba Group Holding and its unit Alipay are in talks to buy a $550 million stake in Indian online payment firm One97 Communications. The deal, expected to be announced by the end of the month, will give Alibaba and Alipay a 30-40% stake in the company. This marks Alibaba's first significant investment in India's growing online business segment. The investment is expected to be completed by the end of the month.

site_title: German paper that ran Charlie Hebdo cartoons firebombed
summary: A German tabloid, Hamburger Morgenpost, was firebombed in Hamburg, Germany, after reprinting Charlie Hebdo cartoons mocking the Prophet Mohammed in response to the Paris attack that killed 12 people. The attack occurred on the front page of the newspaper, which had a circulation of around 91,000. No one was injured in the attack, and two men were detained and questioned by police. The incident comes amid heightened tensions over the rise of an anti-Islamic movement in Germany.

site_title: TEE Land Q2 profit jumps 46% on revenue surge
summary: TEE Land's Q2 net profit rose 46% to S$2.42 million, driven by a 530% surge in revenue to S$15.12 million. For the half year, net profit doubled to S$5.11 million, while revenue rose 34% to S$21.56 million. The increase was attributed to progressive revenue recognition from the Aura 83 development and increased contributions from associates.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Alibaba, South Korea city in talks for 1t won joint investment: paper
summary: Alibaba Group is in talks with the South Korean city of Incheon for a 1 trillion won (approximately US$923 million) joint investment in a new business complex, including a shopping mall, hotel, and logistics center. The investment would be equally split between Alibaba and Incheon, but neither party has confirmed the details.

site_title: Croatia elects first woman president after tight vote
summary: Croatia's opposition challenger Kolinda Grabar-Kitarovic was elected the country's first female president with 50.4% of the vote, narrowly beating incumbent Ivo Josipovic. Grabar-Kitarovic, a former foreign minister and NATO official, aims to kickstart the ailing economy. The election, held as Croatia grapples with a deep economic crisis, saw a turnout of 58.90%. Grabar-Kitarovic's victory is seen as a key test ahead of parliamentary elections later this year, where her party is expected to make significant gains.

images.alt_text: Opposition challenger Kolinda Grabar-Kitarovic was elected Croatia's first female president on Sunday, narrowly winning a tight run-off vote with a pledge to kickstart the EU country's ailing economy.

site_title: Ezra unit wins US$110m contract from Jurong Shipyard
summary: EZRA Holdings' subsidiary London Marine Consultants won a US$110 million contract from Jurong Shipyard to supply an external turret mooring system for the Libra field's FPSO vessel. The Libra field, located in the Santos Basin, Brazil, is one of the largest deepwater oil accumulations globally, with estimated recoverable resources of 8-12 billion barrels of oil. The FPSO vessel will be converted from a Navion Norvegia shuttle tanker, owned and operated by a joint venture between Odebrecht Oil & Gas and Teekay Offshore, and chartered to Petrobras for 12 years.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: United to review hedging policy amid oil price plunge
summary: United Airlines has reduced its fuel hedge position to 22% of its 2015 fuel consumption, costing the airline $2.83 per gallon, up from $2.76 per gallon. This move comes as the airline reviews its strategy to mitigate oil market volatility. The hedge position was reduced at a cost, with the airline facing potentially billions of dollars in gains or losses from its bets on oil and jet fuel prices. United officials are discussing whether to unwind more of its existing hedges or make new ones to cover multiple years of fuel consumption.

site_title: Olam exits Australian wool business with sale of Western Wool Marketing
summary: Olam International has sold its Australian wool business, Western Wool Marketing, to Quality Wool, marking its exit from the niche market. The sale, made by Olam Australia's executive director and country head Bob Dall'Alba, aligns with the company's global strategy of focusing on growth opportunities while exiting non-core operations. Western Wool Marketing has stores in NSW and Victoria, and Quality Wool will become one of Australia's largest, independent wool companies.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: US gas prices hit lowest levels since April 2009
summary: US gas prices have fallen to their lowest level since April 2009, averaging $2.20 per gallon, down 27 cents from the previous survey. The decline is attributed to the oil price slump, with US crude futures halving since the summer due to lackluster demand and over-supplied markets. Gas prices have dropped more than $1.14 per gallon from the same period last year, with the highest price recorded in San Francisco at $2.66 per gallon and the lowest in Albuquerque, New Mexico at $1.76 per gallon.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed on Monday
summary: Japan's financial markets were closed on Monday for a public holiday, resuming trading on Tuesday. Meanwhile, OCBC Bank announced that Tan Teck Long will succeed Helen Wong as CEO, replacing her after her retirement. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Chinese banks faced challenges due to Beijing's consumer lending push. Additionally, Citigroup set a mid-2026 target for MSCI's global equity index to reach 1,150, while MUFG targets the US for its securitization business. The People's Bank of China (PBOC) is also considering a 1.5 trillion yuan stimulus package to counter US tariffs.

site_title: US carrier JetBlue targets in-flight etiquette on social media videos
summary: JetBlue has launched a series of humorous social media videos targeting in-flight etiquette, showcasing common issues such as snoring sleepers, slouching passengers, and cramped aisle spaces. The videos, part of the #FlightEtiquette campaign, aim to spark conversation and encourage passengers to think about their behavior. The airline's director of brand management, Lisa Borromeo, emphasizes that the videos are meant to be fun and not prescriptive, but rather to generate dialogue about in-flight etiquette.

site_title: India's industrial output likely recovers as Modi pushes reforms
summary: India's industrial output likely recovered 2.2% in November, bouncing back from a 4.2% contraction in October, according to a Reuters poll. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government has pushed through economic reforms to accelerate growth, but global headwinds and domestic demand remain weak. Retail inflation rose sharply in December, and analysts expect the Reserve Bank of India to cut interest rates in late February, possibly after the government presents its annual budget. Despite a robust economic outlook, the economy remains below potential, with unused industrial capacity and low capital investment.

site_title: Strong start by buyers in New Year; sellers quiet
summary: Buyers dominated the trading in the first week of the year, with 35 director purchases worth S$10.5 million, compared to one firm with two disposals worth S$5 million. The significant trades were purchases in Hyflux, Raffles Education, Global Invacom, and ST Engineering. Directors also bought shares in Avi-Tech Electronics, Heeton Holdings, and Swissco Holdings. Institutional shareholders also made purchases in Ascendas India Trust and Singapore Reinsurance Corporation.

site_title: Offer for LCD shares 'viable exit alternative' for shareholders: AF Global (Amended)
summary: AF Global, a consortium comprising Aspial Corporation and Fragrance Group, has made an offer of S$0.33 for all offer shares in LCD Global Investments. This "viable exit alternative" provides shareholders with a chance to exit their investment without risking dilution or injecting funds. The offer price is significantly higher than the previous offer of S$0.17, offering shareholders a potential return of almost double. The offer is contingent on LCD cancelling or deferring its rights issue, which will be announced before January 14.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Two blue-chip companies drop UBS as their corporate broking adviser
summary: UBS Group AG, Switzerland's largest bank, has lost two blue-chip corporate broking clients, BAE Systems and Smith & Nephew. BAE replaced UBS with Morgan Stanley, while Smith & Nephew selected Bank of America Merrill Lynch and JPMorgan Cazenove as its corporate brokers. This follows UBS' loss of Standard Chartered Plc as a corporate adviser last year. The move comes after UBS agreed to pay 774 million Swiss francs to settle a foreign exchange rate manipulation probe in November 2014.

site_title: Millions to welcome Pope on Asia trip
summary: Pope Francis is set to embark on a week-long trip to the Philippines and Sri Lanka, where he will immerse himself in Asia's fervent Catholicism and preach reconciliation in Sri Lanka amidst ethnic conflict. The trip is expected to draw millions of devotees, with up to six million people attending an open-air mass in Manila, and one million at a public mass in Colombo. The Pope's visit comes as Sri Lanka celebrates a peaceful election victory, and he will also visit areas affected by Super Typhoon Haiyan, offering a message of mercy and compassion.

site_title: Recalibration
summary: The article discusses various market trends and news, including a painful stocktaking for Jurong Aromatics, a special feature on Jurong Island as a chemicals hub, and the impact of Trump's tariffs on gold and oil prices. Additionally, it mentions Aster's potential acquisition of Exxon Singapore stations, China's move to calm solar stock price wars, and Opec's decision to trim oil demand for the next four years. Chinese tycoons are also expanding Indonesia's aluminium industry.

site_title: South Africa faces looming power blackouts, threatening economy
summary: South Africa is facing looming power blackouts due to ageing power plants and inability to meet electricity demand, threatening its economy. Eskom, which generates 95% of the country's electricity, has warned of high risk of "load shedding" until March, and analysts predict blackouts could continue for two years until new power plants come online. This could have a negative impact on the economy, with potential losses of 0.5-1% of GDP, affecting businesses and growth.

site_title: Volkswagen says December sales up 2.7% to 881,000 vehicles
summary: Volkswagen reported a 2.7% increase in global December sales to 881,000 vehicles, driven by growth in China and Europe. The company met its 2007 sales target four years early, with full-year deliveries reaching 10.14 million autos. Sales gains in China and Europe outweighed declines in the US and Latin America. VW plans to cut 5 billion euros in costs by 2017 and give more power to regional leaders to boost operations in key markets. The company aims to focus on profit after meeting its sales targets.

site_title: Cushman & Wakefield on expansion path
summary: Cushman & Wakefield, a global property consulting firm, is expanding its Singapore office, with plans to increase its headcount to over 200 by 2017, up from 150 currently. The firm attributes its success in the city-state to its people and culture, citing a focus on teamwork, honesty, and respect. Despite a slowdown in investment sales, C&W is optimistic about the Singapore office market, particularly for institutional investors returning as buyers and collective sales of industrial properties. The firm expects to see a diverse pool of occupiers, including social media, technology, and pharmaceutical firms, driving growth in the office leasing market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Bitcoin firms at CES aim to make digital currency mainstream
summary: Bitcoin companies showcased their digital currency at CES, aiming to make it mainstream. Start-ups like ChangeTip and BitPay introduced simplified ways to use bitcoin, such as micro-payments and virtual tipping. The companies have attracted significant venture capital funding and partnerships with major companies like Microsoft. Bitcoin's growth is seen as a shift in financial paradigms, with the virtual currency being used to buy goods and services from anyone accepting it.

site_title: Defeated Sri Lanka head accused of having tried to stage coup
summary: Sri Lanka's new government accused defeated President Mahinda Rajapaksa of trying to stage a coup to cling to power after losing the presidential election. A top aide to President-elect Maithripala Sirisena said Rajapaksa tried to persuade the army and police chiefs to help him stay in office with force. The new government will investigate the alleged coup and conspiracy, with Sirisena promising to establish a government of national unity and implement reforms.

site_title: French probe into kosher supermarket attacker moving forward
summary: A French probe into the 2015 kosher supermarket hostage siege in Paris has advanced, with the discovery of Amedy Coulibaly's possible hide-out and the identification of his DNA at a fatal police shooting site. Coulibaly, a repeat offender linked to extremist Islamist activity, is suspected in several attacks, including the Charlie Hebdo shooting and a car explosion. His partner, Hayat Boumeddiene, is believed to be hiding in Syria, and police are searching for her and a possible accomplice. Coulibaly claimed responsibility for the attacks in an internet video, declaring membership to the Islamic State and vowing to target the caliphate.

site_title: Charlie Hebdo to sell 'survivor's issue' outside France
summary: Charlie Hebdo, a French satirical weekly, is releasing a "survivor's issue" this week, with one million copies printed, after a massacre killed 12 staff members and the publication was on the brink of folding. The issue will be sold worldwide, with proceeds going to the families of the victims. The sudden global attention has saved Charlie Hebdo from bankruptcy, with international support and sales of the issue expected to exceed usual numbers. The publication's survival is seen as a testament to free speech and defiance against those who sought to extinguish it.

site_title: Greek crisis: All Greek to you?
summary: The article discusses the Greek debt crisis, a renewed crisis in the eurozone, and various terms and institutions involved. The European Central Bank (ECB) is trying to keep inflation below 2%, but interest rates near zero and stagnant growth limit its ability to encourage borrowing. The ECB may implement quantitative easing (QE), but its legality is being challenged by the Bundesverfassungsgericht. The European Stability Mechanism (ESM) is the permanent rescue fund for the eurozone, offering Precautionary Conditioned Credit Lines and Enhanced Conditions Credit Lines to eligible countries. The crisis has led to challenges to the legality of Outright Monetary Transactions (OMT) and bailouts, with the EU and ECB seeking to stabilize the eurozone.

site_title: Elderly to soon pay less cash upfront for medical fees
summary: Singapore's elderly will have more flexibility in using their Medisave starting April, with up to S$200 allowed for medical treatments at specialist outpatient clinics. This new scheme, Flexi-Medisave, aims to reduce cash payments for outpatient care, following increased subsidies for specialist outpatient care and vaccinations. The government encourages responsible spending of Medisave funds to ensure sufficient coverage for healthcare needs over a lifetime.

site_title: Cyprus Airways closure 'unavoidable': govt
summary: Cyprus Airways, the 68-year-old national carrier, made its last flight after EU regulators ordered Cyprus to recover illegal state aid granted to the airline. The government cited "long-standing" and "irreversible" problems, despite efforts to rescue the carrier. The airline, 93% state-owned, struggled with intense competition and posted a net loss of 55.8 million euros in 2012. The EU deemed the government's aid as a breach of competition guidelines, leading to the airline's closure. Pilots vowed action against the government, with the pilots union chief filing an official complaint.

site_title: Worldwide marches in solidarity with France
summary: Worldwide marches in solidarity with France were held on January 11, 2015, in response to the Islamist attacks on the Paris offices of satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, killing 17 people. Millions of people across Europe, the Middle East, and beyond participated in rallies, waving French flags and chanting "Je suis Charlie." The marches were attended by Christians, Muslims, and Jews alike, with messages of unity and support for freedom of expression and the victims of the attacks. The rallies took place in over 100 cities worldwide, including Berlin, Washington, Jerusalem, and Montreal.

images.alt_text: About a hundred thousand people rallied worldwide in solidarity with France on Sunday, with marchers across Europe and the Middle East chanting "Je suis Charlie" and holding pens in the air.

site_title: Compliance crucial for SGX-listed foreign firms
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has a significant number of foreign-listed firms, with 40% of its 766 listed companies based outside Singapore. However, a report by SID-ISCA found that these foreign firms have a lower level of compliance with corporate governance guidelines compared to Singapore-registered firms. Most foreign firms are primary listings, which must fully comply with SGX regulations, but often lack independent directors who can effectively monitor top executives in geographically distant countries. To address these concerns, additional safeguards and disclosure practices are needed to close the information gap for local shareholders.

site_title: 2014's Superlatives
summary: In 2014, Singapore's property market saw significant developments. US mortgage rates rose after a five-week decline, affecting the global market. The Q3 wave of condo launches in Singapore will test demand for prime projects above S$3,000 psf. Manhattan rents reached a record high, with predicted further increases. Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail portfolio in Seoul for 262 billion won. UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, according to a recent index. These trends indicate a shift in the global property market.

site_title: ECB official warns of deflation risk; urges action on bond buying
summary: ECB official Ignazio Visco warns of deflation risk in the eurozone, citing low inflation rates and a risk of a downward spiral. Visco urges the European Central Bank to buy government bonds to prevent deflation, stating it as the most effective means. This comes as eurozone inflation turned negative in December for the first time since 2009, driven by cheap oil. The ECB is considering quantitative easing to address the issue.

site_title: Taking heart
summary: Fortune Bag giveaway: Community Chest will arrange for a Fu Dai (fortune bag) giveaway to beneficiaries of 14 local social service programmes for each S$50 donation. The public can buy a fortune bag online from Jan 5-19. The Wow Experience is celebrating its 10th anniversary with a charity event, donating to selected beneficiaries. Beautex will donate 20 cents to the Rainbow Centre with every purchase of a limited edition Chinese New Year Tissue Box.

site_title: Foreign competition for London commercial property hots up
summary: Foreign investors are increasing competition in London's commercial property market, prompting local investors to seek alternative investment opportunities in regional cities such as Glasgow, Leeds, and Manchester. To avoid auctions and capitalize on rising rents, investors are making private purchases or building office blocks from scratch. This trend is driven by the financial crisis, which has made London a popular safe haven for investors from Russia, China, and southern Europe. As a result, office prices have bounced back strongly, forcing local investors to explore other regions.

site_title: Brace for a volatile ride ahead
summary: The global stock market is poised for a volatile ride in the first half of 2015, following a six-month period of low volatility. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates, which could impact oil prices and inflation expectations. The market is also watching for economic indicators from Europe, China, and Japan, with a focus on oil prices and inflation. The Singapore market is expected to continue its trend of low liquidity, leading to potentially large daily price movements.

site_title: Looking ahead
summary: The Singapore economy is expected to fare moderately well in 2015, driven by the country's strong economic fundamentals and its position as a regional hub. However, the economy is vulnerable to global economic conditions and will face challenges such as rising labor costs and stagnant productivity. Experts recommend businesses adopt information technology more intelligently, leveraging Big Data mining and social media marketing while prioritizing cybersecurity. The government's SG50 celebrations are expected to boost tourism and marketing opportunities, while the Asean Economic Community is set to enhance free trade and economic growth.

site_title: Tight security in Paris to protect marchers
summary: World leaders, including French President Francois Hollande and leaders from Muslim states, gathered in Paris to pay tribute to victims of last week's Islamist militant attacks. Hundreds of thousands of French citizens marched in silence amid high security, with 2,200 police and soldiers patrolling the streets. The attacks, which included a shooting at Charlie Hebdo and a hostage-taking at a Jewish deli, killed 17 people and exposed France's vulnerability to urban attacks. The march reflects shock over the worst militant Islamist assault on a European city in nine years, and raises questions about free speech, religion, and security.

site_title: High-end vibes but needs market focus
summary: Sushi Jin, a high-end sushi restaurant, has opened its doors in Singapore with a 14-seat counter and separate dining room. Despite its upscale ambiance, the menu's price range is erratic, swinging from affordable to fine dining territory. While the raw fish is of adequate quality, the dinner omakase is paltry compared to its more expensive counterpart. The restaurant aims to cater to a mid-range market, but its high-end quality is not enough to compete with established sushi joints like Aoki. With a rating of 6.5, Sushi Jin shows promise but needs to find a strong middle ground to succeed.

images.alt_text: Sushi Jin aims to let you have a six-star dining experience at four-star pricing, a lofty goal for a compact-sized eatery with a 14-seat counter and separate dining room on one end; (above) wagyu don; tai carpaccio; assorted sashimi

Sushi Jin aims to let you have a six-star dining experience at four-star pricing, a lofty goal for a compact-sized eatery with a 14-seat counter and separate dining room on one end; wagyu don; (above) tai carpaccio; assorted sashimi

Sushi Jin aims to let you have a six-star dining experience at four-star pricing, a lofty goal for a compact-sized eatery with a 14-seat counter and separate dining room on one end; wagyu don; tai carpaccio; (above) assorted sashimi

site_title: Greek PM vows to end austerity to overturn opposition's poll lead
summary: Greek Prime Minister Antonis Samaras vows to cut taxes and end austerity measures if re-elected, aiming to overturn Syriza's poll lead ahead of a snap election. He promises tax cuts, reduced corporation tax, and easing financial pressure on Greeks, while Syriza's Alexis Tsipras takes a harder line towards EU/IMF partners, seeking debt relief. Greece's economy has shown signs of growth, but the country remains in a bailout program. The outcome of the election will determine the country's path forward.

site_title: HK homes affordability crisis grows as prices soar to record high
summary: Hong Kong's home prices surged to a record high in 2014, with existing home prices gaining 11% and smaller units rising 12%. The city's affordability crisis worsened, with pro-democracy protests highlighting growing discontent among young people and first-time homebuyers. The government faces pressure to address the issue, with a housing supply target of 480,000 units over 10 years, but experts warn that finding enough land to meet the goal will be challenging. Prices may rise further in 2015, with smaller units and luxury homes potentially seeing significant gains or losses.

site_title: SDP's Chee confident of fielding strong set of candidates
summary: Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) chief Dr. Chee Soon Juan is confident of fielding a strong set of candidates for the upcoming general election, despite losing two of its biggest names from the 2011 election. The SDP plans to contest at least four constituencies, including Sembawang and Holland-Bukit Timah group representation constituencies, and Bukit Panjang and Yuhua single wards. Chee revealed that the party's lineup will include himself and potential candidates such as medical professor Paul Tambyah and veteran politician James Gomez.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Tesla hits roadblocks amid oil rout, growing scepticism
summary: Tesla faces roadblocks as oil prices plummet, casting doubt on its ability to enter the mass market with its Model 3 electric sedan. The company's stock has fallen to $206, with Morgan Stanley predicting Tesla will deliver 300,000 electric vehicles by 2020, short of its 500,000 target. Tesla is investing $5 billion in its Gigafactory to reduce battery costs, but analysts warn this may impact financial results. Despite this, Elon Musk remains optimistic, aiming to triple production to 100,000 vehicles this year and 500,000 by 2020.

site_title: It's time to end EU air-traveller data spat: Merkel
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel urged the European Parliament to reconsider its stance on data-sharing on air travelers, citing last week's terror attacks in France as a reason to re-examine the issue. Merkel stated that the current lack of compulsory information-sharing on travelers to and from Europe puts lives at risk. British Prime Minister David Cameron previously expressed similar concerns, saying foot-dragging over sharing information could put lives in danger. Merkel's call comes as EU ministers are discussing security gaps and how to close them.

site_title: Interest rates, commodity prices will affect market
summary: Singapore's market is expected to be driven by higher interest rates and lower commodity prices this year. Maybank Kim Eng's head of research, Ng Wee Siang, projects a 1% rise in the three-month Singapore Interbank Offered Rate (Sibor) by mid-2015, benefiting banks like DBS, which he has given a "buy" call on. However, the real estate industry is expected to be negatively impacted, while transport stocks such as Singapore Airlines are expected to benefit from lower oil prices. The offshore and marine sector is also expected to be negatively affected due to lower oil prices and potential cutbacks in capital expenditures.

site_title: Keppel Reit secures full occupancy at most of its office towers
summary: Keppel Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, has secured full occupancy at nine of its 11 office towers across Singapore and Australia. The average rental rate for new leases and renewals last year was S$12 psf, with some leases signed at S$15 psf. Occupancy rates have increased, particularly at the Marina Bay Financial Centre, and the company expects further growth in the Raffles Place/New Downtown area this year.

site_title: When autocorrect gets personal
summary: A recent phenomenon of autocorrect errors on social media platforms has led to embarrassing and humorous situations, where users are tagged by the wrong person due to the technology's assumptions. The errors, which have become increasingly advanced, can result in unexpected and sometimes embarrassing messages, as seen in a recent Facebook post where a great-grandmother was tagged as "Great Grandmaster Flash" instead of her actual name. This highlights the limitations and potential pitfalls of autocorrect technology, which can sometimes prioritize familiarity over accuracy.

site_title: World leaders join Paris march to honour attack victims
summary: World leaders from Europe and beyond gathered in Paris to honor the victims of last week's terror attacks in France that killed 17 people. Hundreds of thousands of marchers, including President Francois Hollande and leaders from Germany, Italy, Israel, and others, joined the event. The march took place in the City of Light, with many participants bursting into tears, emphasizing the importance of freedom of speech and liberty. The show of solidarity comes after France's worst terrorist bloodbath in more than half a century.

site_title: Philadelphia refinery partially shut by fire: source
summary: The Philadelphia Energy Solutions' refinery, the largest on the US East Coast, has been operating at less than half its capacity due to a fire in its crude distillation unit. The incident was described as "flaring" by the plant's officials, but a source confirmed it was caused by a fire. The refinery's 200,000-bpd unit was forced to shut, and the plant's overall capacity was reduced to 165,000 barrels per day. The cause of the fire remains unclear, and an investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Ups and downs leave US stocks flat; more of the same to come
summary: US stocks finished a volatile week flat, mirroring expectations for the first week of fourth-quarter earnings season. The jobs report, which showed a puzzling increase in employment, failed to spark gains, and analysts predict a similar lack of movement in the coming weeks. Oil prices remain a concern, with the euro near its 1999 debut value, potentially affecting trade relations and US exports. Despite this, some analysts expect positive surprises from earnings reports, with Standard & Poor's 500 companies forecast to grow at a 4% aggregate rate in the fourth quarter.

site_title: AirAsia to overcome first major crisis: analysts
summary: AirAsia is poised to overcome its first major crisis after the crash of Flight QZ8501, which killed 162 people, with analysts crediting the airline's robust and media-savvy business for its ability to restore trust. CEO Tony Fernandes has taken responsibility, visited victims' families, and vowed to find out what happened, contrasting with Malaysia Airlines' handling of the MH370 disappearance. While some passengers may avoid flying with AirAsia temporarily, the airline's low-cost proposition and ability to mitigate the impact with a public campaign to address shortcomings are expected to help it bounce back.

site_title: Oil, commodity rout 'may severely impact markets'
summary: The Institute of International Finance warns that the collapse in oil prices may lead to a deeper global economic malaise, causing deflation, destabilizing exchange rates, and capital flows. This could negatively impact borrowers in emerging economies, particularly those with external debt. The report highlights "important implications for financial markets" and emphasizes the need for caution in the global economy.

site_title: Critically ill patients see hope in "Right to Try" drugs
summary: Critically ill patients in the US are gaining hope through "Right to Try" laws, which allow them to access unapproved medications not approved by the FDA. These laws, passed in several states, enable terminally ill patients to try experimental treatments outside of FDA supervision. However, critics argue that the laws are "a cruel sham" and could cause harm to patients. Supporters believe that the laws provide terminally ill patients with a choice in their end-stage disease treatment.

site_title: Value Japanese food with no fuss or muss
summary: Koji Sushi Bar, a new restaurant in Singapore, offers budget-friendly Japanese food with no frills. The restaurant serves a variety of sushi options, including affordable sets and ala carte dishes, with prices ranging from $9 to $25. The chefs, led by Benny Cheong, prepare food with care, using fresh ingredients and presenting dishes with attention to detail. Despite its casual atmosphere, Koji Sushi Bar provides good value for money, making it a great option for those looking for a quick and affordable sushi fix.

images.alt_text: Koji Sushi Bar is Singapore's version of the salary man sushi joint - good pricing, adequate portions, no high expectations; (above) sashimi rice bowl; five-piece sushi set
Koji Sushi Bar is Singapore's version of the salary man sushi joint - good pricing, adequate portions, no high expectations; sashimi rice bowl; (above) five-piece sushi set

site_title: Citi to cut traders' bonuses after a weak year-end
summary: Citi has reduced the bonus pool for fixed-income and equities traders and salespeople by 5-10% due to a lacklustre performance in the final weeks of the year. This move is expected to impact around 1,500 traders and salespeople. The exact amount of the reduced bonus is not specified, but the reduction is seen as a sign of the bank's cautious approach to compensation.

site_title: Painful stocktaking for Jurong Aromatics
summary: Jurong Aromatics Corporation's US$2.4 billion petrochemicals facility on Jurong Island has stalled operations just five months after its launch due to a weak market. The company, aiming to be the "most admired aromatics company in the Asia-Pacific," needs a strategy change. Plant operations have been halted since mid-December 2014, raising concerns about the company's long-term prospects.

site_title: Checking email less often may reduce stress
summary: A two-week study found that checking email less frequently can significantly reduce stress. Participants who checked their email only three times a day experienced a 20% reduction in time spent checking emails, and a comparable reduction in stress levels compared to those who checked their email more frequently. The study suggests that the frequency of email checks, rather than the volume, may be the primary cause of stress. The results support the idea that cutting back on email might reduce stress, potentially by reducing the need to switch between tasks and promoting efficiency.

site_title: Goldman, UBS bag Santandar share sale deal
summary: Goldman Sachs and UBS have secured a deal to sell shares for Banco Santander's 7.5 billion euro capital increase, the largest-ever accelerated share sale in Europe. This deal is expected to be one of the most coveted mandates of the year.

site_title: More food centres go for contactless payment
summary: Nets, Singapore's payment system provider, plans to wire 10-20 food centres for contactless payments this year, marking a final frontier for the technology. The penetration rate for card payments in Singapore remains low at 30%, with a comparison to Scandinavian wet markets showing 85% card usage. Contactless payment allows users to wave cards at terminals, reducing queuing time and manpower, and enhancing merchant accountability. The move aims to increase adoption, with three food centres already offering the FlashPay service, which has a S$500 maximum amount payable.

images.alt_text: Three food centres in Singapore now offer Nets' FlashPay service.

site_title: Hackers release Swiss bank data after ransom went unpaid
summary: Hackers released identifying details of 30,000 clients of Banque Cantonale de Geneve after the bank declined a ransom demand of 10,000 euros. The hacking group, Rex Mundi, posted the leaked data online, stating it would not pose a financial risk to clients or the bank. The bank confirmed the data release and said it was conducting deeper analysis with authorities, while a security analyst described the hackers as a serious threat.

site_title: 100% occupancy at most of Keppel Reit's completed office towers in Singapore, Australia
summary: Keppel Reit reports that nine out of 11 completed office towers in Singapore and Australia have reached full occupancy, with average rental rates at S$12 psf per month. Leases signed last year had a 17% positive rental reversion on average. This success is attributed to strong demand in the Raffles Place and Marina Bay precincts in Singapore.

site_title: Spending cuts derail chain of new oil projects
summary: Oil prices have crashed to multi-year lows, eroding profits for producers and crippling growth, with every $10 drop in price erasing $2.8 billion in annual cash flow for Exxon Mobil and $3.85 billion for Chevron. Companies are cutting spending by 17% this year, with some delaying or postponing projects, and energy explorers working to trim costs and delay contracts. A global supply glut, worsened by a US shale production boom, may take months or years to be absorbed, setting up potential for supply shortfalls in the future.

site_title: Indonesia divers find black box of AirAsia jet: Transport ministry
summary: Indonesian divers have found the black box flight recorders of the AirAsia plane that crashed in the Java Sea on December 28, 2014, with 162 people aboard. The divers located the crucial recorders, but were unable to retrieve them immediately due to debris from the plane's main body. The Indonesian transport ministry is working to recover the recorders, which are believed to be stuck on the seabed.

site_title: Bangladesh economy hit hard by transport blockade: business chief
summary: Bangladesh's economy is severely impacted by an ongoing transport blockade, particularly affecting the vital garment industry. The opposition-led blockade, which started after opposition leader Khaleda Zia was confined to her office, has disrupted roads, railways, and waterways. The business sector warns of a significant economic toll, with the garment industry being hit particularly hard. The blockade, which began on January 3, is expected to continue until the opposition's demands are met.

site_title: Singapore's newest international commercial court set to thrive
summary: Singapore's newest international commercial court, the Singapore International Commercial Court (SICC), is set to thrive with a panel of prominent international jurists and a successful arbitration sector. Expected to take off in three years, the SICC aims to be the neutral venue for dispute resolution in the region. With 11 jurists on its international bench, including Justice Vivian Ramsey, the court is poised to provide a neutral platform for international commercial disputes, positioning Singapore as a hub for dispute resolution in the region.

site_title: Rapid growth of BRIC markets waning, fund managers say
