SMCCA's proposed solutions, including more excitement and less regulation, are seen as confusing and potentially detrimental to the interests of Singapore's listed small- and mid-cap companies.

site_title: Why Charlie Hebdo is every reader's business
summary: A mass shooting at Charlie Hebdo, a French satirical magazine, has shaken the media industry, highlighting the delicate balance between press freedom and public safety. The attack, which killed 12 people, has led to a reevaluation of the risks journalists take to report on sensitive topics. The article argues that readers also bear responsibility in supporting the press by engaging with content, subscribing to publications, and critically thinking about the information they consume, as the industry grapples with the consequences of violence against journalists.

site_title: Rare ABBA album fetes 40 years of chart-toppers
summary: ABBA released a new 25-track double record, ABBA Live at Wembley Arena, to celebrate its 40th anniversary. The album features a historic 1979 performance at the Wembley Arena, including the unreleased track "I'm Still Alive" by Agnetha Faltskog. The record was produced by Benny Andersson's son, Ludwig, who used modern editing technology to minimize overdubs and preserve the album's authenticity. This new release is ABBA's final one, as the band stopped performing together in 1982. The album is available on CD and vinyl, along with remastered versions of ABBA's back catalogue.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Joyas gets nod for new nickel business, rights issues
summary: Joyas International Holdings has received shareholder approval to diversify into nickel distribution and trading through a 70% stake in Hong Kong Silver Basic Group for HK$700,000. The company will raise capital through two rights issues, including a warrant and convertible bond offering, to raise S$3.5 million and S$5.3 million, respectively. This move aims to boost Joyas's net tangible asset per share and earnings per share, and will allow the company to take advantage of the growing demand for nickel in Hong Kong and China.

site_title: ECB revises its meeting schedules, introduces voting rotation system
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has revised its meeting schedule, transitioning from monthly meetings to bi-monthly ones, starting from January 2015. The change aims for more open communication and less frequent decisions. This change is part of a year of expansion for the ECB, including a new eurozone member, enhanced bank supervision, and possibly the region's largest monetary stimulus yet.

site_title: Inexpensive gems
summary: A writer revisits Barbera wines from Piedmont, Italy, and finds them to be affordable and enjoyable, with soft, low-tannins, and lush flavors. The writer had previously tasted a Barbera d'Alba Cascina Francia 2009, which was described as a "graceful wine, a joy to drink." Another example is the Luciano Sandrone Barbera d'Alba 2005, which is a very dark red with a soft, lush aroma. The writer suggests that Barbera wines are suitable for everyday drinking, especially for simple meals at home, and can be found at an affordable price, often under $30.

images.alt_text: Barbera d'Alba magnum 2005, Luciano Sandrone and Clos Figueres 2000, Clos Figueras, Grattalops, Priorato exemplify Barbera bounty

site_title: KL move on GLCs' foreign asset buys: low chances of success
summary: Malaysia's move to halt government-linked companies (GLCs) and statutory bodies from buying overseas assets in an effort to stem the outflow of funds has limited success, according to experts. The decision comes amid a deteriorating ringgit, which has fallen to a five-year low due to plunging oil prices. Reduced investment options and lower returns are likely consequences, with GLCs forced to focus on domestic investments. Experts warn that the move may not be effective in stabilizing the ringgit without addressing underlying issues such as oil prices and illicit outflows.

site_title: Five largest healthcare stocks generate 2014 average total return of 11.3%
summary: The Singapore Exchange's Healthcare Index, comprising 28 stocks, generated a 39.1% total return in 2014, surpassing the Straits Times Index's 9.5% gain. The five largest healthcare stocks, including IHH Healthcare and Raffles Medical, yielded an average 11.3% total return, driven by expansion plans in Asia and increased capacity in Singapore. Smaller players, such as Suntar Eco-City and Health Management International, outperformed with average total returns of 70.8%.

site_title: Aviation needs real-time satellite-GPS tracking
summary: The UN is pushing for a better aviation tracking system, citing concerns over safety and the need for real-time satellite-GPS tracking. However, implementing such a system may be costly, with concerns that airlines may not be willing to share the resources.

site_title: Homage to the Music Man
summary: Top entertainers, including Dick Lee, Selena Tan, and Ivan Heng, will gather for a free concert at the Esplanade on Jan 23 to celebrate the life of late music director Iskandar Ismail, who died at 58 last November. The concert will feature his compositions and eulogies from collaborators. Iskandar was a renowned musician and artistic director of ChildAid, a children's concert that raised S$12.13 million for two charities over 10 years. A memorial will be held on Jan 23 at 7:30pm at the Esplanade Concert Hall.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Paris attack likely to boost security surveillance in Europe
summary: A terrorist attack on Charlie Hebdo in Paris, killing 12 people, is likely to increase security surveillance in Europe, with major companies such as G4S and BAE Systems expanding their security divisions. The attack's sophistication and planning have raised concerns among police and intelligence agencies, with France and the US working together to investigate. The incident has also sparked a rise in anti-immigration rhetoric, with right-wing groups using the outrage to advance their own political agendas, while Muslim leaders worldwide condemn the attack and call for tolerance.

site_title: Minimal impact in Singapore as StanChart shaves off business
summary: Standard Chartered announced it would shut its institutional equities business, slashing 2,000 more jobs in its retail sector amid cost pressures. The UK bank will save around $100 million next year by closing the operation, which has lost money. The bank will retain its focus on Singapore, its second-largest market and home to its single-largest shareholder, Temasek Holdings. The move follows the bank's previous sales or closures of consumer banking operations in Asia, highlighting the decline of universal banking dominance.

images.alt_text: Mr Sands aims to save at least US$400 million in costs this year, driven by branch closures and job cuts.

site_title: In Brief
summary: Olam International is changing its fiscal year-end to December 31, from June 30, to comply with its majority shareholder Temasek Holdings' reporting requirements. The company's current fiscal year, which began in 2014, will now end on December 31, 2015. This change will enable Olam to align its financial reporting with its shareholder's group consolidation and reporting requirements.

site_title: Demand in construction sector holding up this year
summary: Singapore's construction sector is expected to secure contracts worth S$29 billion to S$36 billion this year, driven primarily by public sector projects, which are expected to account for 60% of total contracts. Private sector projects are expected to decline, with a forecasted S$11 billion to S$15 billion in contracts. Despite this, the sector is expected to remain strong, with construction output projected to reach S$35 billion to S$37 billion this year.

images.alt_text: Public sector projects will be key demand drivers for the construction sector this year, as private sector projects take a back seat amid wariness among developers.

site_title: Beware of pitfalls in Australian property buys
summary: Australian property investors should be cautious of pitfalls, particularly when buying brand new properties to avoid Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) approval. Non-Australian buyers can only purchase new properties, often at 40% higher prices due to limited supply, leading to resale challenges. Foreigners can work around this by creating a compliant buying entity and purchasing resale properties, avoiding GST and potential price inflation. However, the Australian government is seeking to tighten FIRB powers to ensure compliance with Australian laws, recommending sanctions such as compulsory acquisition and increased fines.

site_title: Raffles Edu's unit eyeing HK$118.8m in listing
summary: Raffles Education Corporation's unit, Oriental University City, is set to raise HK$118.8 million through its listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange's Growth Enterprise Market. The company will place 45 million shares at an indicative price range of HK$2.60-2.68 apiece, with net proceeds expected to be HK$77.8 million. Oriental University City plans to use the funds to construct new dormitories on its campus site, capitalizing on China's ongoing economic restructuring and growing demand for skilled labor.

site_title: Harsh cold puts US networks to the test
summary: The US transportation network faces its first major test of the winter season due to harsh cold and wind chills, with temperatures in the single digits and gusty winds reported in the upper Midwest. Shippers have adjusted schedules, commuters are prepared for delays, and farmers are taking measures to protect crops and livestock. While the cold has not yet caused significant disruptions, it is a test of the network's preparedness after last year's polar vortex.

site_title: Essential guide to the golden jubilee
summary: Singapore is celebrating its Golden Jubilee, marking 50 years of independence. Key events include the Singapore Art Week (Jan 17-25), Chingay Parade (Feb 27-Mar 28), and the Singapore International Festival of Arts (June). Notable films include "Ah Boys To Men: Frogmen" (Jan), "7 Letters" (July), and "Long Long Time Ago" (Dec). The National Gallery Singapore opens in October, and the National Day Parade will be held at the Padang in August. The month of August also features the Sing50 concert, the debut film "1965", and the Singapore Sports Hub hosting the Barclays Asia Trophy.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Tay Suan Chiang
Dylan Tan

site_title: Time for 'QE for the people' in eurozone
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is considering implementing "QE for the people" in the eurozone, printing large sums of money and distributing it to the public to combat deflation. Unlike the US, where QE was successful, the eurozone faces challenges such as tighter household savings and lower equity market valuations, reducing the effectiveness of QE. The ECB must develop a strategy that works in the eurozone's unique system, considering fair distribution of funds to maximize impact. A 500-euro-per-adult-citizen handout could stimulate spending, particularly in struggling countries like Spain, Portugal, and Greece, but raises concerns about costs and potential distributional issues.

site_title: Five works to catch
summary: Five arts exhibitions and performances are set to take place in Singapore. Nguan's photography exhibition, showcasing subtle yet melancholic images of ordinary Singaporeans, runs from Jan 14-25 at ION Art. Dance performances "Loss-Layers" by Yum Keiko Takayama and "Grand Singe" by Nicolas Cantin will be held at the Esplanade Theatre Studio on Jan 16-17 and 22-23, respectively. Theatre productions "Untitled Women" by The Necessary Stage and "With/Out" by Loo Zihan will be performed at Black Box and Centre 42 from Jan 23-25 and Jan 14-18, respectively.

site_title: Triyards' Q1 profit up 13% to US$8.2m on better margins
summary: Triyards Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore engineering group, reported a 13% increase in net profit to US$8.22 million for Q1 FY2015, driven by higher margins from an offshore fabrication project. Revenue declined 37% year-on-year to US$56.7 million due to lower revenue from completed projects. The company announced US$75.4 million in new liftboat orders, bringing its current newbuild pipeline to eight liftboats. Triyards remains confident in its ability to meet industry standards and expectations despite low oil prices.

site_title: Indonesian divers struggle to reach AirAsia plane wreckage
summary: Indonesian military divers have struggled to reach the wreckage of AirAsia Flight 8501, which crashed on December 28, 2015, killing all 162 people on board. Despite reaching the tail section, strong currents and poor visibility have hindered the retrieval of crucial black box data recorders. The search for the wreckage and all bodies continues, despite stormy weather in the Java Sea. The incident remains a major aviation mystery, with the pilots' last words potentially held in the black boxes.

site_title: Hays expects wage growth of up to 3% for British workers
summary: British recruitment firm Hays predicts wage growth of up to 3% for skilled workers this year, signaling an improvement in the job market and economic recovery in the UK. This forecast comes as pay for workers in Britain has only recently started to pick up after a period of stagnant wages. The expected wage growth is closely watched by Prime Minister David Cameron and the Bank of England, which is considering interest rate hikes. Hays' finance director Paul Venables also expects higher wage growth in technical areas, with increases of up to 10%.

site_title: Buy H-shares instead of A-shares: analysts
summary: Analysts recommend buying H-shares over A-shares due to their relatively cheaper prices. Credit Suisse's Vincent Chan and AllianceBernstein's Stuart Rae highlight opportunities in H-share banks and consumer discretionary companies, citing their lower price-to-earnings ratios. Analysts caution that China's A-share market, which has surged 65% in a year, is experiencing a "pure momentum market" and may eventually correct, while some experts predict a potential rate cut by China's central bank to boost liquidity.

site_title: StanChart equities closure is overdue but welcome
summary: Standard Chartered has closed its institutional equities division, cutting 200 jobs and saving approximately US$100 million annually. The decision, aimed at achieving cost savings of at least US$400 million in 2015, marks a rare exception for investment banks, which often struggle to break even on equities services. The move comes as the bank faces pressure to cut costs due to slowing markets and rising bad loans, and is expected to put pressure on other banks to reassess their equities operations.

site_title: Plunging oil prices a double-edged sword for Asia, say economists
summary: Asian economies are bracing for the full impact of plummeting oil prices, which could lead to currency devaluations, inflation rates, and economic growth rates. While some countries like China are benefiting from lower oil costs, others like Malaysia and Indonesia are at risk due to their heavy reliance on commodity exports. Economists warn that governments must use the gains from lower oil costs to implement economic reforms, such as reducing fuel subsidies, to mitigate the effects of the price crash. The IMF expects net positive effects on the region, but warns of potential turbulence.

site_title: Is the economic slog really over?
summary: The US economy is showing signs of recovery, with economists predicting a 3.1% GDP growth and 230,000 monthly job creations in 2015. The country's faster deleveraging and increasing bank capital are expected to lead to full employment, potentially as low as 5.4% unemployment. However, threats to the optimism include potential global recession, higher inflation, and the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. Despite these concerns, many economists believe the economic slog is finally over, offering a boost to Americans' sense of self-worth and altering popular psychology ahead of the 2016 elections.

site_title: Get the Karaoke Party started
summary: Local photographer Lenne Chai is launching a karaoke-inspired video installation, "Karaoke Party," to promote homegrown fashion and music. Inspired by Tokyo's collaborative creatives, the project will feature talented Singaporean artists from various disciplines. The installation aims to tap into the country's love for karaoke, bringing together creatives for a unique experience. Chai hopes to showcase Singapore's vibrant arts scene and foster collaboration among its talented individuals.

site_title: Coffee traders scoop up robusta
summary: Coffee traders have bought robusta futures at record levels amid concerns of dry weather in top growers Brazil and Vietnam, which may reduce arabica bean supplies. Liquidity in fifth-month robusta contracts quadrupled to nearly 20,000 lots in December, peaking at a record 21,702 lots. This shift is driven by roasters buying more robusta to substitute arabica beans and traders seeking to guarantee delivery ahead of seasonal demand. The unprecedented move has led to a one-fifth share of total liquidity in the US$2 billion market.

site_title: 2015 could be year of political left
summary: The year 2015 is expected to be a major election year globally, with key contests in Asia, the Americas, Africa, the Middle East, and Europe. In developed countries, parties of the left and centre-left may capitalize on economic hardship and discontent over stagnant living standards, with leaders like UK's Ed Miliband and Canada's Justin Trudeau gaining popularity. Radical left-wing parties, such as Greece's Syriza and Spain's Podemos, also have a chance to gain power, citing economic inequality and austerity measures. Historically, economic hardship can lead to a shift in voter support towards left-wing parties, but the success of these parties will depend on their ability to develop coherent responses to the economic downturn and other issues.

site_title: Capturing Yin and Yang on paper
summary: Chinese artist Liu Guosong invented a new type of paper, called Liu Guosong Paper, in 1963, allowing for white lines and points in ink paintings. This innovation earned him the title "Father of modern Chinese ink painting" in Taiwan and China. Liu, a renowned art professor, has created over 150 solo exhibitions worldwide and will have a retrospective exhibition at the Museum of Contemporary Arts (MoCA) in Singapore later this month. His art aims to promote and advance ink painting traditions, and he continues to innovate despite his advanced age.

site_title: JPMorgan Singapore's asset mgt arm gets RQFII licence
summary: JP Morgan Asset Management Singapore Limited has received its Renminbi Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (RQFII) licence from the China Securities Regulatory Commission, allowing it to trade offshore yuan funds in China's securities markets. The move comes as Singapore's RQFII quota of 50 billion yuan remains underutilized, with some funds holding unused quotas. CEO Steven Billet expects the licence to meet growing demand for Chinese bonds and stocks, despite economic concerns, and notes that domestic consumption and exports are supporting China's growth.

site_title: Euro falls for 5th day on bets of ECB easing
summary: The euro fell for a fifth consecutive day, reaching a nine-year low of $1.17625, amid expectations of the European Central Bank's potential quantitative easing to ward off deflation. A decline in German industrial orders and eurozone consumer inflation expectations reinforced bearish views, while concern over a Greek general election further weakened the currency. The dollar index hit nine-year highs, and other Asian currencies, such as the Malaysian ringgit, also experienced significant declines.

site_title: US commercial paper supply jumps as year begins
summary: US commercial paper supply surged in early 2015, rising $78.6 billion to $1.086 trillion in the week ending January 7. Domestic non-financial companies issued $45.3 billion in commercial paper, while foreign financial firms added $38.1 billion. The average overnight borrowing cost for top-rated companies remained low, averaging 0.09% for AA-rated non-financial companies. This increase suggests renewed demand for credit to finance payrolls and inventories.

site_title: Ex-MP sets up new networking and business education initiative
summary: Former Singapore MP Leong Horn Kee has launched "The Entre Community," a business education and networking initiative offering classes on starting and expanding a business. The program, which starts in late January, will be taught by Dr. Leong and other notable businessmen and executives. Participants will have access to a panel of around 30 mentors and can join a club to exchange ideas and attend talks by various personalities. The program aims to share the wealth of experience among entrepreneurs and help them grow their businesses.

images.alt_text: Dr Leong will teach classes along with a few other speakers, starting in end-January and early February

site_title: Merkel sets high bar for lifting of Russia sanctions
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel set a high bar for lifting Russia sanctions, stating that Europe cannot consider easing measures until all 12-point peace agreement elements are fully implemented. Merkel expressed "little hope" for lifting the first round of sanctions and ruled out a step-by-step easing based on progress. The announcement came as Merkel praised Ukrainian Prime Minister Arseny Yatseniuk's reform efforts and a meeting between leaders was planned if progress is made on the peace front.

site_title: Three-month Sibor continues to rally while SOR crashes
summary: The three-month Singapore interbank offered rate (Sibor) rose to 0.63920% on Thursday, up 0.00213 points from the previous day, marking a 40% increase from a week ago. In contrast, the three-month swap offer rate (SOR) plummeted 24% to 0.92956% on Monday, with some analysts predicting further volatility due to US dollar strength and market uncertainties. Experts warn that the SOR may drag higher if USD/SGD continues to rally.

images.alt_text: On Thursday, the three-month Sibor rose to yet another high of 0.63920 per cent, up 0.00213 point from Wednesday's 0.63707.

site_title: Disunited? Non, say the French in face of magazine massacre
summary: France has set aside its deep-seated political divisions in response to the deadly Islamist attack on the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, killing 12 people. Citizens from all walks of life gathered in vigils across the country, with even former President Nicolas Sarkozy meeting with President Francois Hollande and far-right leader Marine Le Pen attending an official commemorative march. Religious figures and groups condemned the attack, and a joint statement from Islamic organizations called for national and civic solidarity. The outpouring of solidarity has been particularly acute in France, where people have come together to mourn the victims and defend freedom of expression.

site_title: The dangers posed by a Sibor hike have been overblown
summary: A recent spike in the Singapore interbank offered rate (Sibor) has raised concerns among homeowners, but experts say the situation is manageable. The 17-basis-point increase translates to a less than 20% hike in interest payments for typical borrowers. Most borrowers do not pay just the Sibor rate, and the prevailing spread is around 80-90 basis points. Defaults are expected, but the impact is expected to be limited in the near term, with interest rates likely to rise further in anticipation of a US Federal Reserve rate hike later this year.

site_title: No chance of Opec output cut, even after oil dips below US$50: Gulf delegates
summary: Saudi Arabia and its Gulf Opec allies have ruled out cutting oil production to boost prices, despite oil dipping below $50 a barrel. The group's forecast for an increasing surplus in 2015 is based on rising supplies outside Opec and lacklustre global demand. Gulf members argue that lower prices will slow competing supplies, spur economic growth, and revive demand. Opec ministers and delegates have blamed non-Opec producers for the oversupply in the market, with some predicting a potential price drop to $40 or lower if prices continue to fall.

site_title: Worlds apart - captured in real time
summary: Artist Chen Sai Hua Kuan traveled to Ecuador in 2012 to capture the opposite side of the world from Singapore. He researched his longitude and latitude to reach the Amazon forest, which is directly opposite Singapore. This unique journey aimed to understand what life would be like on the other side of the world.

site_title: StanChart's "snap" decision nearly a year in the making
summary: Standard Chartered CEO Peter Sands made the decision to cut the bank's loss-making equities business nearly a year in the making, citing high cost-to-income ratio and inability to grow. The move was reportedly advised by McKinsey's financial services team, and the bank is now focusing on core, profitable businesses such as trade and fixed income. The decision comes after the bank failed to rank among the top 10 banks globally for research or trading at the end of 2013, and was made despite recent hiring for equities in Asia.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Tiger Airways' stock price fell to S$0.265, 5 cents below the target price of S$0.20. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. Singapore stocks rallied for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed.

site_title: A 'dream of eternity' hewn in granite
summary: Armen Agop, a sculptor of Armenian descent, finds inspiration in the timeless quality of ancient Egyptian art, particularly in the transformation of granite. Born in Egypt, Agop identifies with the concept of survival and eternity, reflected in the dream of eternal existence in both Armenian and Egyptian cultures. He works with granite, a material he considers more consistent and durable, and creates futuristic yet ancient sculptures with unique curves and razor-sharp points. Agop's exhibition, "Transcontemporary," showcases over 20 new granite and bronze sculptures from January 22 to February 21 at the Art Plural Gallery.

site_title: 13 cabin crew say UA fired them for their safety concerns over flight
summary: Thirteen United Airlines flight attendants claim they were illegally fired after refusing to fly on a Hong Kong-bound plane with a "threatening" message under its tail engine in July 2014. The message, which included the words "Bye Bye" and two faces, was found at San Francisco International Airport. The flight attendants filed a complaint with the US Department of Labor, alleging they were fired in violation of federal law. The incident is being investigated by the Department of Labor.

site_title: US securities brokers took $98 bln in assets on the move in 2014
summary: In 2014, 711 top US securities brokers managing $98 billion in client assets left their jobs at major brokerages or started their own businesses. More than half, 391, left the big four wire houses, including Morgan Stanley, Wells Fargo Advisors, Bank of America's Merrill Lynch, and UBS Wealth Advisors. The departures reflect a trend of top teams leaving firms, with UBS and Wells picking up more advisers than they lost. This trend is expected to continue in 2015, according to industry expert Mindy Diamond.

site_title: China smartphone maker Xiaomi's founder wants a bite of Apple's market
summary: Xiaomi's founder, Lei Jun, aims to become the world's number one smartphone company in the next 5-10 years. The Chinese company has excelled in China's smartphone market by offering high-performance products at affordable prices. Xiaomi has become the world's number three smartphone vendor, shipping 17.3 million phones in the third quarter of 2014. However, critics argue that the firm has copied Apple's designs and lacks intellectual property protection, hindering its international expansion. Despite this, Xiaomi has valued at $45 billion after its latest funding round and has launched products outside mainland China, but faces patent issues and low brand recognition outside its home market.

site_title: US jobless claims dip, point to firming labour market
summary: US jobless claims fell to 294,000 in the week ended Jan 3, marking the 17th straight week below 300,000. Economists expect further decline, indicating a strengthening labor market. This trend may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise its short-term interest rate, potentially signaling the end of near-zero interest rates since 2008.

site_title: GM CEO sees US auto market flattening out, but room for growth
summary: GM CEO Mary Barra expects the US auto market to flatten out this year, with industry sales projected to reach 16.5-17 million vehicles, indicating flat to 3% growth. The strong economy and falling gasoline prices are seen as factors contributing to this growth. Despite concerns about a slowing market, Barra believes there is still room for growth due to the labor market, home prices, and fuel price drops. This comes as Toyota and Ford also predict steady sales, with forecasts ranging from 16.7 million to 17.5 million vehicles.

site_title: Car makers pay to keep Chinese dealers happy as market slows
summary: Global automakers are paying hundreds of millions of dollars to keep Chinese dealers happy as the country's car market slows. The China Automobile Dealers Association (CADA) has persuaded BMW to pay $820 million in compensation to dealers for lower-than-expected 2014 profits. Other companies, including Audi and Mercedes, have also agreed to provide subsidies. The move is a sign that the Chinese auto market is shifting from a period of rapid growth to a more mature market where profit margins are lower.

site_title: Hackers try to blackmail Swiss bank after stealing data: report
summary: Hackers stole the personal data of thousands of clients from Swiss bank BCGE, including names, addresses, and account numbers. The hackers, calling themselves Rex Mundi, are demanding 10,000 euros in exchange for not publishing 30,000 emails of the affected clients. Authorities have launched an investigation, and the bank has increased internet security measures to prevent further breaches. Despite the stolen data, the bank reported no financial damage.

site_title: Policewoman shot by gunman near Paris dies: police
summary: A policewoman in Paris died after being shot by a gunman wearing a bullet-proof vest near the city. The attacker escaped and a second victim is in serious condition. The incident occurred just a day after a deadly Islamist assault on Charlie Hebdo, but no link has been established between the two.

site_title: EU to submit new counter-terrorism proposals after Paris attack
summary: The European Commission plans to submit new counter-terrorism proposals in the coming weeks following the deadly attack in France. Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker stated that the EU should not react impulsively to such events, and instead, take a measured approach. The proposals aim to enhance cooperation on counter-terrorism efforts, including the Passenger Name Record (PNR) system to track would-be militants. EU officials will meet in Brussels and Riga to discuss the proposals, amid opposition from civil libertarians who fear the system's potential impact on individual freedoms.

images.alt_text: The European Commission will submit new proposals to fight terrorism in the next few weeks following the deadly Islamist attack in France, Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker said on Thursday.

site_title: As Brooklyn booms, famed music scene under gun
summary: The music scene in Brooklyn's Williamsburg neighbourhood is facing a crisis due to rising rents, with at least five venues shutting down or announcing plans to move in 2014. The area, once a hub for emerging rock bands, has become unaffordable for full-time musicians, with Molly Hamilton of Widowspeak and David Byrne citing the need for a more sustainable and affordable environment for artists. Some venues are relocating to cheaper areas like Bushwick, while others are looking to cities like Detroit and Seattle, which offer more affordable housing and artistic opportunities.

site_title: French Islamic groups urge Muslims to condemn terrorism
summary: French Islamic groups have urged Muslims to condemn terrorism in the wake of the Charlie Hebdo massacre. They called for a minute of silence at midday and for imams to condemn terrorism, following a similar call from the French government. The groups aim to promote unity and reject extremist ideologies. The move comes as France seeks to strengthen its ties with Muslim communities and counter radicalization.

site_title: China planning agency plays down stimulus speculation
summary: China's top planning agency has downplayed speculation about a sharp fiscal stimulus to boost the slowing economy. Deputy head Luo Guosan stated that the government aims to encourage private sector investment in key areas, rather than relying on state entities. The agency plans to spur investment through active participation of social capital, but does not expect a strong stimulus. This move aims to address concerns about the economic slowdown and put pressure on policymakers to take action.

site_title: US: Wall St opens up, on track for second day of gains
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday, tracking a second day of gains, following the S&P 500's break from a five-day losing streak. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 64.51 points, the S&P 500 gained 8.98 points, and the Nasdaq Composite added 38.77 points. Data showed a strengthening labor market, supporting the equities rally.

site_title: The brightest lights in economics now lean Left
summary: Economists at the American Economic Association (AEA) meeting have shifted towards a left-leaning perspective, contradicting the long-held notion of economics as a "conservative science." Protesters, including Harvard economist Carmen Reinhart, criticized the field's emphasis on mathematical formalism, which they argue hinders the development of left-wing economic theories. Reinhart's support for cutting government debt was a major target, as protesters sought to push economics towards a more progressive agenda. This shift marks a significant change in the discipline's direction, moving away from its historical association with conservative free-market theories.

site_title: Europe: Shares advance on "patient" Fed, Tesco rallies
summary: European shares rose 1.8% on Thursday as Tesco's strong Christmas update boosted retailers. The FTSEurofirst 300 index climbed to 1,354.61 points, with the STOXX Europe 600 Retail index up 2.6%. Tesco's 10% gain followed a better-than-expected sales report and plans to sell assets and cut costs. However, Marks & Spencer fell 4.3% after posting a drop in underlying sales. The Federal Reserve minutes showed the central bank could be "patient" in raising interest rates later this year, supporting the market.

images.alt_text: European shares rose on Thursday as a strong Christmas update from Britain's Tesco boosted retailers and Federal Reserve minutes showed it was not in a hurry to start raising rates.

site_title: Google Capital invests in Indian property website Commonfloor
summary: Google Capital has invested in Indian property website Commonfloor.com, providing funds for product technology and marketing. The exact amount was not disclosed. Commonfloor's co-founder and CEO, Sumit Jain, stated that the investment will support the company's growth.

site_title: Bank of England keeps interest rate at 0.5%: official
summary: The Bank of England kept its main interest rate at 0.5% during its first policy meeting of 2015, citing sliding British inflation and low oil prices. The decision maintains the £375 billion cash stimulus, and it is considered unlikely that interest rates will be raised before the end of the year due to economic uncertainty and potential deflationary risks in the eurozone.

site_title: Two seriously hurt after man fires on police outside Paris
summary: A man opened fire with an automatic rifle outside Paris, seriously injuring a policewoman and a city employee. The gunman is still on the run and no link has been established with Wednesday's deadly attack on a satirical magazine. The incident comes as France mourns the deaths of eight journalists, two police, and two others in the Charlie Hebdo attack. The gunman's whereabouts are unknown, and there has been no claim of responsibility for the shooting.

site_title: Suspect's journey from Pizza delivery to French police's most wanted
summary: Cherif Kouachi, 32, and his brother Said, 34, are named as chief suspects in a terrorist attack that killed 12 people in Paris, France. Kouachi, a former pizza deliveryman and rap enthusiast, allegedly radicalized after meeting Farid Benyettou, a Salafist mentor. Kouachi's radicalization began with watching jihadist videos and growing his beard, and he eventually became involved in a cell sending young French volunteers to Iraq. He was arrested in 2005, served 18 months in prison, and was later suspected of being part of a prison break attempt. The attack is described as an "exceptional barbarism" by French President Francois Hollande, raising questions about how Kouachi was able to carry out the attack despite his radical leanings being known to intelligence services.

site_title: International air passenger demand up 5.4% in November: IATA
summary: International air passenger demand rose 5.4% in November, according to IATA, exceeding the 5.7% increase in October. International capacity increased 5.9%, while load factors fell 0.3 percentage points to 75.1%. Total market capacity also rose 5.4% in November.

site_title: China Aviation Oil expects lower profits for Q4 2014 and FY2014
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) expects lower profits for Q4 2014 and FY2014 due to a highly volatile global oil market. The group's financial performance will be weaker compared to FY2013. CAO will announce its Q4 2014 and FY2014 financial results on February 12, 2015. The company continues to be profitable despite the challenging oil trading environment.

site_title: EU lawmakers eye compromise for US on benchmarks
summary: European Union lawmakers are set to ease rules on international benchmarks, addressing US concerns that global investors could lose out. The proposed law would directly regulate benchmarks such as interest rates and currencies, but would allow non-EU benchmarks to be used if they meet strict EU safeguards. The US has refused to adopt equivalent rules, prompting the EU to compromise on the measure. The EU draft law will be voted on in committee on March 5, with lawmakers proposing that non-EU benchmark compilers apply for authorization to be used in Europe.

site_title: Heineken to build beverage plant in East Timor
summary: Dutch brewer Heineken plans to build a beverage plant in East Timor, requiring an investment of US$30-45 million. The facility will manufacture a range of drinks, including beer, soft drinks, and water. The company signed an agreement with the East Timor government, marking a significant move into the Southeast Asian market.

site_title: Update: Indonesian divers struggle to reach AirAsia wreckage
summary: Indonesian divers are struggling to reach the wreckage of AirAsia Flight 8501, which crashed on December 28, killing all 162 people on board. The plane's tail, where the black boxes are kept, was discovered 30 meters underwater, but powerful currents hindered divers' efforts to penetrate the tail. The search for bodies and black boxes continues, with a focus on retrieving the tail to access the wreckage. Weather permitting, retrieval experts will attempt to lift the tail on Friday, allowing divers to search for the black boxes and potentially uncover the cause of the crash.

site_title: Porsche may boost sales to 200,000 cars this year: CEO
summary: Porsche expects to sell 200,000 cars this year, surpassing its long-planned target three years early. The company posted record deliveries in 2014, with a 17% gain on 2013 levels. December sales surged 39% to 20,644, boosting full-year deliveries to 189,849. The Macan compact SUV, introduced last year, attracted 34,000 new customers from rival brands, highlighting Porsche's growth strategy.

site_title: Update: French policewoman killed in shoot-out, hunt deepens for militant killers
summary: A French policewoman was killed in a shootout in southern Paris on Thursday, amid a manhunt for two brothers suspected of killing 12 people at a satirical magazine. The attack occurred while the policewoman and a colleague were responding to a traffic accident. Police sources have not confirmed a link between the two incidents, which were described as an assault on democracy. The brothers are believed to be Islamist militants.

site_title: Hays sees wage growth of up to 3% for British workers
summary: British recruitment firm Hays forecasts wage growth of up to 3% for skilled workers this year, indicating a stabilizing job market and economic recovery. This prediction is a positive sign for Prime Minister David Cameron, who is relying on the economy to carry his party to victory in elections in May. Hays predicts higher wage growth in technical areas, such as construction, property, and IT, with increases of up to 10%. The company also raised its profit guidance for the first half of its financial year due to strong demand from Britain, Australia, and Asia.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 18.88 points to close at 1,728.06, driven by a 1.6 billion lots traded valued at RM1.84 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 555-240. The index's gain came despite global market uncertainty, with stocks in Europe and the US reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Charlie Hebdo will come out next week, despite bloodbath
summary: Charlie Hebdo will publish its next issue next Wednesday, despite the January 2015 attack that killed 12 staff members, according to Patrick Pelloux, a surviving editorialist. The move is intended to show that "stupidity will not win."

images.alt_text: The French satirical newspaper whose staff was decimated in the attack by two gunmen will come out as scheduled next week, one of its surviving editorialists told AFP on Thursday.

site_title: Several attacks against France Muslim targets since magazine killings
summary: France has seen a series of attacks against Muslim targets since the 2015 Charlie Hebdo magazine killings. Overnight attacks targeted a mosque in Le Mans, where three blank grenades were thrown, and a Muslim prayer hall in Port-la-Nouvelle, where shots were fired. The incidents left no casualties, but raised concerns about rising anti-Muslim violence in France.

site_title: Scared but defiant: cartoonists raise pencils to Charlie Hebdo
summary: Cartoonists worldwide, including those from the US, UK, Australia, and Africa, have rallied in support of Charlie Hebdo, publishing their own cartoons and vowing not to be silenced despite fear of being targeted. In solidarity, newspapers republished Charlie Hebdo's cartoons, including those depicting the Prophet Mohammed. However, some editors remain cautious, fearing the backlash from Islamists. Despite this, many cartoonists, including those who have faced threats themselves, have expressed their defiance and commitment to free speech.

images.alt_text: Cartoonists around the world put pencil to paper in solidarity with the Charlie Hebdo artists slaughtered in Paris, admitting their own fear of being targeted but vowing they would not be silenced.

site_title: Update: Standard Chartered axes equities business, retail jobs in cost cut push
summary: Standard Chartered axes its global equities business and announces 4,000 job losses in retail banking as part of a cost-cutting plan targeting $400 million in savings this year. The bank is exiting an unprofitable equities business and cutting 2,000 retail jobs, with 200 job cuts already made in the last 3 months. The move aims to boost profit and reverse the bank's fortunes, which have slumped 40% over the past two years due to falling commodity prices and rising regulatory costs.

site_title: Modi throws open doors to people of Indian origin around the globe
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi has eased visa rules to attract overseas talent, aiming to make the country a top power. With over 25 million people of Indian origin worldwide, Modi appealed to them to return home, citing opportunities and a desire to harness their skills and resources. The move also aims to reverse a decline in foreign investments, which slowed down after the economy's growth stagnated. Lifetime visas and property ownership for those with ancestral ties are also being considered, with officials assisting citizenship efforts for those who left centuries ago.

site_title: Sony to delay sale of PlayStation 4 in China
summary: Sony has delayed the sale of its PlayStation 4 gaming console in China, originally set for January 11, due to prolonged negotiations with Chinese authorities. The ban on foreign gaming consoles was lifted last year, but strict censorship rules and stiff competition from PC and mobile games make the market challenging. A new sale date has not been determined, and Sony's rival Microsoft launched its Xbox in China in September. The delay marks a setback for Sony's entry into China, a market where gaming revenues hit $15 billion last year.

site_title: Southeast Asia's aviation boom shows up patchy safety framework
summary: Southeast Asia's aviation industry is experiencing rapid growth, but a fragmented safety framework is hindering progress. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) lacks a regional agency overseeing aviation safety, unlike in Europe. The crash of AirAsia Flight QZ8501, which killed 162 people, has highlighted the need for streamlined standards on air navigation and staff training. ASEAN aims to establish a single aviation market by 2015, but experts warn that adopting uniform technical and safety procedures will be challenging due to differing national sovereignty and development levels.

site_title: BOJ to project GDP contraction this year, eyes rebound: sources
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to project a slight economic contraction of 0.5% for the fiscal year ending in March, but may revise up its forecast for the following year. The central bank aims to convince markets that its surprise monetary easing in October was strong enough to meet its 2% inflation target. A quarterly review on January 20-21 will finalize the BOJ's long-term economic and price forecasts, with many officials expecting growth to beat forecasts in the next fiscal year.

site_title: EU flags at half-mast, minute's silence for Charlie Hebdo victims
summary: The European Union observed a minute's silence and flew flags at half-mast to honor the 12 people killed in the Islamist attack on Charlie Hebdo magazine in Paris. European lawmakers, commissioners, and the European Commission held a minute of silence in Brussels and Riga, respectively, to show solidarity with France. The EU also halted all activity at its central Brussels offices at midday. The attack has raised fears of other attacks in Europe, with Jihadi fighters returning from Syria and Iraq.

images.alt_text: The EU flew flags at half mast and observed a minute's silence on Thursday to honour the 12 people killed in the Islamist attack on the Charlie Hebdo satirical magazine in Paris.

site_title: Paris killings confirm fears of jihadist threat in West
summary: A deadly attack on Charlie Hebdo magazine in Paris has confirmed Western fears of a jihadist threat in the West, targeting a media outlet that sparked Muslim outrage with cartoons of the Prophet Mohammed. 12 people were killed in the attack, which was designed to cause shock and show the influence of jihadist movements in Europe. The attackers' motivations are unclear, but analysts say it's likely a propaganda tool and potential recruiting tool for extremist groups. The attack comes amid resurgent fears of Islamic extremism targeting Western capitals, with thousands of Europeans believed to have joined militant groups in Iraq and Syria.

images.alt_text: The deadly attack on France's Charlie Hebdo magazine has confirmed the West's worst fears that militants will act on jihadist threats to target Western countries fighting Islamic extremism.

site_title: Indonesian divers struggle to reach AirAsia wreckage
summary: Indonesian divers struggled to reach the submerged tail of crashed AirAsia Flight 8501, which crashed on December 28 during stormy weather, killing all 162 people on board. The tail, where the black boxes are kept, was discovered on Wednesday, but strong currents hindered efforts to retrieve it on Thursday. Divers were able to reach the tail but were unable to penetrate further due to poor visibility. The search for bodies and black boxes continues, with a crane ready to lift the tail out of the water once inspection is complete.

site_title: Man fires on police outside Paris, one seriously hurt: police
summary: A man wearing a bullet-proof vest fired on police officers with an automatic rifle outside Paris, seriously injuring one officer, near Porte de Chatillon. A suspect has been detained. The incident occurred just a day after the Charlie Hebdo attack, which killed 12 people. Interior Minister Bernard Cazeneuve is rushing to the scene.

site_title: Key 3-month Sibor continues to rally while 3-month SOR crashes
summary: The key three-month Singapore interbank offered rate (Sibor) rose to 0.63920% on Thursday, its highest level yet, up 40% from a week ago. In contrast, the three-month swap offer rate (SOR) crashed to 0.70588%, down 24% from its Monday high. Analysts attribute the volatility to the US dollar's strength and market fluctuations, with Sibor lagging behind SOR in its pricing. Despite the decrease, Sibor's rise is expected to continue due to the US dollar's strength.

site_title: UK house prices slow again in December, up 7.8% year-on-year
summary: UK house prices rose 7.8% year-on-year in the three months to December, the weakest increase since January last year, according to Halifax. However, prices in December alone rose 0.9%, the largest monthly increase since last July. Economists had expected 8.0% annual growth and 0.3% monthly increase. Halifax expects house price growth to moderate this year to 3-5%.

site_title: Explosion at kebab shop near mosque in France, no casualties: officials
summary: An explosion occurred at a kebab shop near a mosque in Villefranche-sur-Saone, France, on January 8, 2015, but no casualties were reported. Authorities described it as a "criminal" act, opening a police investigation with no suggested link to the Charlie Hebdo attack.

site_title: Palm oil hits 6-month high on tight supply, monsoon woes
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures reached a near six-month high on January 8, 2015, due to tight supply caused by monsoon rains. The Malaysian Meteorological Department raised its weather warning to an "orange stage," affecting top palm-producing states Johor and Pahang. Traders expect supplies to remain tight until the end of the week, driving prices up to RM2,420 per tonne. The benchmark contract gained 1.7% to RM2,369 per tonne, its highest since July 11.

site_title: China's Xi woos Latin America with US$250b investments
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping pledged $250 billion in investment to Latin America over the next 10 years, aiming to boost China's influence in the region. The investment will focus on energy, infrastructure, agriculture, manufacturing, and technological innovation. China and Latin America are expected to increase two-way trade to $500 billion in 10 years. The move is seen as a challenge to US influence in the region, but improving US-Cuba ties may mitigate this impact. China has already secured investments from countries like Venezuela, Peru, and Brazil.

site_title: Euro drops below US$1.18 to hit 9-year low
summary: The euro plummeted to a 9-year low of US$1.18, surpassing reported option barriers, amid expectations of a European Central Bank quantitative easing program to combat deflation. Data showed a decline in euro zone consumer prices in December, the first annual drop since 2009, fueling ECB action. The euro's decline reinforced bearish views of the single currency, with investors betting on a bond buying program at the ECB's January 22 policy meeting.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 46.75 points to 3,345.11. Trading volume was 1.41 billion shares valued at S$1.15 billion. The rally follows a 5-day streak, ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Taiwan considering allowing Chinese to invest in local stocks, could fuel volatility
summary: Taiwan is considering allowing Chinese investors to trade local shares, potentially fueling market volatility. The move, part of the Taiwan Financial Supervisory Commission's efforts to stimulate the stock market, aims to attract big Chinese investors. Analysts welcome the move, but warn of initial volatility due to the dominance of retail and foreign investors. Business ties between Taiwan and China have strengthened since 2008, with the goal of increasing investment and trade. Implementation details will be available in June, with trading expected to begin in the third quarter.

site_title: Brent bounces around US$51 as traders fish for bottom
summary: Brent crude oil prices bounced around $51 a barrel on Thursday as traders sought a bottom in the second-largest price rout on record. US crude stockpiles unexpectedly dropped last week, and the US economy showed resilience amid slowing global growth. Chinese crude imports likely hit a record high in December, supporting prices. However, Germany's industrial orders fell more than expected, keeping the market fragile. The market remains under pressure, but data releases have been supportive of higher prices.

site_title: Olam changes fiscal year-end from June to December
summary: Olam International has changed its fiscal year-end from June 30 to December 31 to comply with its majority shareholder's group consolidation and reporting requirements. The change affects the company's current fiscal year, which will end on December 31, 2015. Historical pro-forma financial information for previous years will be provided to facilitate comparison. Olam's next annual general meeting will be held no later than April 30, 2016.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end 0.65% higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.65% to 23,835.53 on Thursday, driven by upbeat US data and oil price increases. However, mainland Chinese equities plummeted, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 2.39% due to profit-taking after recent gains.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close 1.67% higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed 1.67% higher on Thursday, driven by a weaker yen and a rally on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index rose 281.77 points to 17,167.10, while the Topix index climbed 1.31% to 1,377.67. The gains follow strong US economic data and amid uncertain trade talks between the US and EU.

site_title: Singapore updates corporate tax guidelines to better align with West
summary: Singapore has updated its corporate tax guidelines to better align with Western governments' crackdown on aggressive tax avoidance practices. The move comes as a response to international taxation scrutiny, sparked by the use of "transfer pricing" to minimize tax bills by multinational companies such as Starbucks, Google, and Amazon. The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore now requires related parties to keep contemporaneous records to support pricing of transactions, and has clarified documentation requirements for transfer pricing. The updates aim to promote transparency and fairness in tax practices.

site_title: Broker's take: OCBC keeps 'sell' call on Tigerair
summary: OCBC has maintained its "sell" call on Tiger Airways Holdings, reducing its fair value estimate from S$0.21 to S$0.18. The bank expects the airline's net loss to narrow from S$6 million to S$1.4 million in FY16, driven by a stronger balance sheet and cash balance post a successful rights issue exercise. Despite lower oil prices and depressed yields, OCBC expects Tigerair's earnings to improve in the latter half of FY16. The airline's share price rose 1.9% to S$0.265.

site_title: KKR partners GIC to set up India real estate lending company
summary: KKR & Co LP has partnered with Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC to establish a non-banking financial company in India for lending to the real estate sector. This is KKR's second non-banking finance company in India. The partnership aims to provide financing options to Indian real estate developers, helping to support the country's growing construction industry.

site_title: Japan household mood worsens to levels before 'Abenomics': BOJ
summary: Japan's household sentiment worsened in December to minus 32.9, its lowest level since 2012, according to the Bank of Japan's quarterly survey. This marks a decline of 12.5 points from September, with households citing rising costs of living and stagnant wage growth as major concerns. The weak reading suggests the effectiveness of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's "Abenomics" policies in reviving the economy is uncertain, despite initial success in weakening the yen and boosting stock prices.

site_title: Tesco begins fight back with cost cuts and asset sales
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest grocer, plans to sell assets and cut costs to fund lower prices in stores as it fights back from its biggest crisis in 95-year history. The company will reduce capital expenditure to $1.5 billion and cut costs by $250 million annually. It will also explore the sale of its Dunnhumby data business and close its defined benefit pension scheme. New boss Dave Lewis said the steps are just the first in a drive to strengthen the balance sheet and increase shareholder value.

site_title: 'Seven detained' in hunt for Paris media killers
summary: Seven people have been detained in connection with the Paris attacks on Charlie Hebdo magazine, where 12 people were killed. The suspects, brothers Cherif Kouachi, 32, and Said Kouachi, 34, were born in Paris and have been linked to jihadist activities. They were known to intelligence services and were reportedly being followed before the attack. Police have issued arrest warrants for the brothers and men and women close to them are being questioned. The investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Universal Robots opens Asia-Pac HQ in Singapore
summary: Universal Robots, a Danish robot manufacturer, has opened its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore, marking its sixth global office. The move aims to expand its client base and operations across the region. The company plans to increase its presence in Asia-Pacific, with the Singapore office responsible for regional expansion and training distributors on its latest technologies. CEO Enrico Krog Iversen expressed confidence in the company's growth, citing the benefits of being closer to customers.

site_title: German industrial orders slump in November
summary: German industrial orders dropped 2.4% in November, the lowest since May, due to falling domestic orders. This marks a significant decline from the 2.9% increase in October. The data suggests a weakening economy, which may put pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: German industrial orders, a key measure of demand for German-made goods both at home and abroad, fell sharply in November, weighed down by falling domestic orders, data showed on Thursday.

site_title: Mourning and manhunt after French magazine massacre
summary: A national day of mourning was declared in France after 12 people were killed in a terrorist attack on the satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, France's bloodiest attack in half a century. The attack was carried out by two brothers suspected of Islamist motives. President Francois Hollande called the attack "an act of exceptional barbarity" and "undoubtedly a terrorist attack." Spontaneous demonstrations of solidarity, known as "I am Charlie," took place worldwide in support of press freedom and the victims.

site_title: Second Pinnacle@Duxton flat sold on resale market for S$918,000
summary: A second unit at Pinnacle@Duxton, a Singapore Housing Board project, has sold on the resale market for S$918,000, with the five-room, 106 sq m flat on the fifth floor changing hands on Monday.

site_title: Lacklustre stock market expected in Singapore; overseas listings an alternative: SMCCA
summary: Singapore's stock market is expected to have a lacklustre showing this year due to an uncertain economic outlook, according to the Small and Middle Capitalisation Companies Association (SMCCA). Competition for conventional funding is expected to increase, making alternative funding options, such as overseas listings, more attractive. Companies with substantial overseas operations are likely to perform better than those relying on the domestic market. The market has been in a downtrend for five years, with trading liquidity decreasing since 2009.

site_title: Two dead, unknown number missing in Myanmar jade mine landslide
summary: A landslide at a jade mine in northern Myanmar's Hpakant town killed at least two people and left an unknown number missing. The landslide, triggered by heavy rain, occurred after debris collapsed beside the mine. Rescue teams are using hoes to search for the missing, but it's challenging due to the rubble and lack of information about the workers. The jade trade remains lucrative in Myanmar, with some revenue going to Kachin rebels, amidst ongoing tensions and violence in the region.

site_title: Seoul: Shares bounce sharply on positive US data; won firmer
summary: South Korean shares rebounded sharply, ending 1.1% higher at 1,905.65 points, driven by positive US jobs data and a pause in tumbling global oil prices. The won also edged higher, supported by foreign capital inflows as risk appetite increased. This follows 16-month lows hit earlier in the week, with the rally attributed to improved market sentiment.

images.alt_text: South Korean shares rebounded sharply from 16-month lows hit this week, with Thursday's trading supported by upbeat US jobs data and a pause in tumbling global oil prices.

site_title: UK should move to inflation measure that includes housing: review
summary: Britain should switch to using the CPIH index, which includes more housing costs, as its main gauge of inflation, according to a review. The CPIH index, launched in 2013, better reflects housing costs than the current Consumer Price Index. The CPIH and CPI have been the same since August, but the review recommends a switch to the CPIH.

site_title: Suspects in Charlie Hebdo attack well-known to anti-terror police
summary: Cherif Kouachi, 32, and his brother Said, 34, are suspects in the Charlie Hebdo attack, which killed 12 people. Kouachi has a history of terrorism, including a 2008 conviction for sending fighters to Iraq, and was part of the "Buttes-Chaumont network." His brother Said was also known to authorities and was suspected of participating in militant training programs with Djamel Beghal, who spent 10 years in prison for planning attacks. Their presumed accomplice, 18-year-old Mourad Hamyd, handed himself in to police after seeing his name on social networks.

images.alt_text: Cherif Kouachi, the 32-year-old hunted along with his older brother Said for the attack on satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo is a jihadist who has been well-known to anti-terror police for many years.

site_title: Malaysian ringgit recovers a bit, rest steady as oil slide pauses
summary: The Malaysian ringgit recovered 0.4% from 5-1/2-year lows against the dollar, stabilizing after a pause in global oil prices and better US jobs data. This follows Wednesday's trade data showing strong export growth and the largest trade surplus since 2011. The currency had been under intense selling pressure due to concerns over the impact of falling oil prices on Malaysia's trade and fiscal balances. The rally is seen as a positive sign for emerging markets and riskier assets.

site_title: Public sector projects to prop up construction demand in Singapore this year
summary: Singapore's construction contracts are expected to reach S$29 billion to S$36 billion in 2015, driven by a healthy pipeline of public sector projects. This is a decrease from last year's record high of S$37.7 billion. The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) attributes the growth to public sector projects, indicating a positive outlook for the construction industry this year.

site_title: Malaysia Nov factory output may slow on weaker commodities demand: Reuters poll
summary: Malaysia's industrial output in November likely slowed to 4.0% year-over-year, its third straight month of decline, due to weaker commodities demand. However, the electronics sector is expected to cushion the drop. In contrast, October's output rose 5.0% year-over-year. The decline in commodities, including palm oil, liquefied natural gas, and refined petroleum products, was partly offset by a stronger electronics sector.

site_title: China pushes for bigger Latin America, Caribbean role
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has pledged to increase cooperation with Latin America and the Caribbean, aiming to expand economic ties and increase regional influence. China has set a goal to raise annual trade to $500 billion and direct investment to $250 billion in the region within a decade. The move comes as China seeks to offset US dominance in the area and promote its own vision for a harmonious international order. China has already secured deals with several Latin American countries, including Venezuela and Ecuador, and plans to invest $20 billion in oil-rich Venezuela.

site_title: Charlie Hebdo Is Every Reader's Business
summary: The mass shooting at Charlie Hebdo, a French satirical magazine, has raised concerns about the relationship between the press and the public. The attack, which killed 12 people, has made editors weigh the risks of publishing controversial content, as violence has been brought to the "war of words." The incident has sparked a debate about the defense of a free press and the right to offend, with some publications urging readers to prove their worth by engaging with the news. The article concludes that readers need to be more active and engaged in consuming news, rather than simply passingively scrolling through it.

site_title: Is Cuba ready for life without US trade embargo?
summary: Cuba is poised to face an economic tidal wave if the US trade embargo is lifted, with estimated damages of $100 billion over 50 years. The embargo, in place since 1962, severely restricts economic and financial transactions with the communist-run island. Cuban officials argue that the sanctions hinder development, while opponents blame the regime for the island's troubled economy. The US Congress must approve lifting the embargo, which is expected to allow an influx of US capital and introduce new products, but Cuba's state-controlled economy is not ready to welcome international investors.

images.alt_text: As US President Barack Obama prepares to ask Congress to lift the Cuban trade embargo - in line with his decision to normalize diplomatic ties - some Cubans wonder if they're ready for such an economic tidal wave.

site_title: Raffles Education's Oriental University City to raise HK$118.8 million on HK exchange
summary: Raffles Education's Oriental University City Holdings is set to raise HK$118.8 million on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange through an initial placing of 45 million shares priced between HK$2.60 and HK$2.68 per share. The company expects to gain from China's economic restructuring, increasing demand for skilled labor and education facilities. Trading is expected to begin on January 16, with BNP Paribas Securities Asia serving as the sole sponsor, bookrunner, and lead manager of the placement.

site_title: Standard Chartered to axe 4,000 retail bank jobs: memo
summary: Standard Chartered plans to axe 4,000 retail bank jobs globally to achieve cost cuts of around $200 million in 2015, with 2,000 jobs already cut or announced. The bank also exits its global equities business, expected to generate $100 million in savings. The cost cuts are part of CEO Peter Sands' efforts to return the bank to past glory.

site_title: Sri Lanka votes in tightest election in decades
summary: Sri Lanka holds its tightest election in decades, with President Mahinda Rajapakse battling for survival amid accusations of corruption and failure to achieve national reconciliation. The opposition, led by Maithripala Sirisena, has gained momentum, with Sirisena promising a new political culture and receiving support from the country's minority groups. Turnout is expected to be high, and voting will continue under tight security, with results expected on Friday. The election comes days ahead of a visit by Pope Francis, which has raised concerns about politicization.

site_title: Oil halts 4-day drop, US stockpile data supports
summary: Oil prices rose above $51 a barrel, halting a 4-day decline, after US crude stocks fell 3.1 million barrels, exceeding analyst expectations. The data also showed a surge in gasoline and distillate fuel stocks. Oil prices were bolstered by Chinese crude imports likely hitting a record high in December and resilient US economy data. Despite key producers showing no signs of cutting output, sentiment towards the oil market remains negative, with economists raising estimates for US fourth-quarter growth.

site_title: China sets stage for trading 10-year govt bond futures
summary: China's Financial Futures Exchange (CFFEX) has issued draft rules for the launch of 10-year government bond futures, marking another step towards interest rate liberalization. The futures will be based on long-term government bonds with a face value of 1 million yuan and a nominal interest rate of 3%. Trading will be subject to margin requirements of at least 2% and a range of settlement prices of 2% up or down. The new futures are expected to be launched in the near future, following the re-launch of government bond futures in September 2013.

site_title: JPMorgan Asset Management Singapore gets licence to trade in China's securities markets
summary: JPMorgan Asset Management Singapore has received a Renminbi Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor (RQFII) licence from the China Securities Regulatory Commission, allowing it to trade offshore renminbi funds in China's securities markets within approved quota. The licence will help meet growing investor demand for Chinese bonds, stocks, and money-market instruments, despite expected downward pressure on the Chinese economy. JPMorgan plans to extend its range of renminbi product offerings to clients and has already received a RMB1 billion investment quota from SAFE in Hong Kong.

site_title: China dating app helps gay men banish the blues - and AIDS
summary: A Chinese dating app, Blued, has helped gay men in China connect with each other and gain a positive self-image, despite the country's taboo on homosexuality. The app, launched by former policeman Ma Baoli, has added 15 million users in two years and provides free HIV tests and AIDS information. Blued's success has been recognized by the government, which is promoting safe sex among gay Chinese. The app has also helped researchers reach out to a high-risk group, with Blued users able to access information on condom use and AIDS through a red ribbon icon on the app.

site_title: Divers search wreckage of AirAsia jet's tail for black boxes
summary: Divers in the Java Sea are searching the wreckage of AirAsia Flight QZ8501 for the black boxes, which could reveal the cause of the crash that killed 162 people. The tail of the plane was found on Wednesday, 20 miles from the last known location, and 84 divers are searching the area. If the black boxes are found, the tail will be lifted out of the sea using a crane. Weather conditions are expected to worsen from Friday onwards, but officials are confident that the recorders will be found soon, with some speculating that the pinger locators are no longer necessary.

site_title: HDB resale prices hit 41-month low in Dec 2014: SRX
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore dropped to a 41-month low in December 2014, with a 6.1% decline from the previous year. Prices for four- and five-room flats fell 0.7% and 0.3% respectively, while three-room flats remained steady. Executive flats saw a 1.8% price jump. The median transaction over X-Value (T-O-X) was negative, indicating overpaying or underpaying the estimated market value.

site_title: China's yuan slips after central bank fixes midpoint at 1-month low
summary: China's yuan weakened to a 1-month low against the US dollar after the People's Bank of China set the daily midpoint rate at 6.1302 per dollar. The spot market opened 1.4% weaker than the midpoint, with offshore one-year non-deliverance forwards contracts trading at 6.323, 3.05% weaker. The weakened yuan comes as China's manufacturing activity has slowed and the property market has softened, potentially prompting the central bank to cut interest rates. This could reduce the currency's attractiveness.

site_title: China launches pilot 'parallel import' for foreign cars
summary: China has launched a pilot "parallel import" program for foreign cars, allowing selected dealers in Shanghai's free trade zone to import and sell cars without foreign manufacturers' consent. The program, which affects premium models, may put downward pressure on prices. Dealers with at least five years of operation history and three consecutive years of profit can apply for the program, which will be responsible for quality and after-sales service. The move could weaken carmakers' control over prices, but luxury brands have previously stated it would have little impact on their businesses in China.

site_title: Don't overlook cheaper H-shares: Credit Suisse
summary: Credit Suisse's Vincent Chan advises investors not to overlook cheaper H-shares in Hong Kong, citing potential upside in H-share banks and consumer discretionary companies. Chan sees a "pure momentum market" in China, where the Shanghai Composite Index has surged 65% from last year, but notes the entire market is turning over every three weeks. His 12-month target for the Shanghai Composite Index is 2,800 points.

site_title: Update: Mourning and manhunt after French magazine massacre
summary: Two brothers, Cherif Kouachi, 32, and Said Kouachi, 34, suspected of a gunning down 12 people in an Islamist attack on a French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, are still on the loose. The attack, which occurred on Wednesday, triggered widespread demonstrations and solidarity around the world. President Francois Hollande declared a national day of mourning and called the bloodbath "an act of exceptional barbarity." Police issued arrest warrants for the brothers, who are known to intelligence services and are considered armed and dangerous. The attack marked France's bloodiest in half a century, with the country on high alert following recent terrorist attacks.

images.alt_text: French security forces were on Thursday desperately hunting two brothers suspected of gunning down 12 people in an Islamist attack on a satirical weekly, as a stunned and outraged France mourned the victims.

site_title: Update: Standard Chartered axes equities business, retail jobs in cost cut push
summary: Standard Chartered is closing its global equities business and laying off 4,000 retail banking jobs as part of a cost-cutting plan to reverse the bank's fortunes. The move is expected to save around $100 million in 2016 and $200 million in 2015. The bank is exiting its stock broking, equity research, and equity listing desks worldwide, marking a reversal in strategy after struggling to make headway in the business. The decision comes after a credit rating downgrade and three profit warnings in less than 12 months.

site_title: Marks & Spencer Christmas spoiled by online delivery woes
summary: Marks & Spencer reported a 5.8% drop in underlying sales of clothing, gifts, and homeware in its Christmas quarter, with online delivery issues exacerbating the decline. This was the 14th consecutive quarterly decline in general merchandise sales, outperforming analyst expectations for a 3% drop. Food sales rose 0.1%, lower than the 0.9% expected. The retailer's poor performance in the quarter has raised concerns about its ability to adapt to changing consumer habits.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 5.73 points to 3,304.09. Gainers outnumbered losers 95 to 40, with volume reaching 60.3 million shares valued at S$100.6 million. The rally came ahead of GDP data and despite tariff uncertainty, with investors staying positive.

site_title: China sacks Nanjing city party chief amid probe
summary: China has removed Yang Weize, 52, from his post as Nanjing city party chief amid an investigation into allegations of corruption. Yang was suspected of "serious discipline and law violations" and has spent his entire political career in Jiangsu province. The move is part of China's anti-graft campaign, led by President Xi Jinping, which aims to target corruption among high-level officials. The case is linked to Zhou Yongkang, China's former security chief, who was arrested and expelled from the ruling party last month.

images.alt_text: China has removed the Communist Party chief of Nanjing city from his post for violating the law, state media said Thursday, after Beijing's corruption watchdog said it was investigating him amid allegations of corruption.

site_title: Fire at SP PowerGrid's Labrador sub-station on Wednesday
summary: A fire broke out at SP PowerGrid's Labrador sub-station in Singapore on Wednesday at 3pm. The 230 kilovolt transformers were unaffected, and no injuries or electricity supply disruption occurred. All staff were safely evacuated, and the company is investigating the cause of the fire and assessing damage.

site_title: Youngest of three suspects in Paris attack surrenders to police: source
summary: An 18-year-old suspect, Hamyd Mourad, surrendered to Paris police after seeing his name circulating on social media. He is implicated in the attack on a satirical weekly in Paris alongside two brothers. Mourad handed himself in on Wednesday and has been arrested and taken into custody.

site_title: Euro gets deflation jitters, dollar climbs
summary: The euro fell near a nine-year low against the US dollar, reaching as low as US$1.1826, amid growing deflationary pressures in the euro zone. The European Central Bank is expected to take bolder stimulus steps to combat the issue, with some speculating the ECB could launch quantitative easing.
