In contrast, the US Federal Reserve is still expected to lift interest rates, although the timing remains unclear. The dollar index climbed to nine-year highs, while sterling sank to its lowest in over 17 months.

site_title: Foie gras back on menu in California
summary: A federal judge in California has overturned the 18-month ban on foie gras sales in the US state, allowing it to be served again in restaurants. Chef Sean Chaney of Hot's Kitchen in Hermosa Beach plans to start serving foie gras immediately. Opponents of foie gras criticized the ruling, citing animal welfare concerns.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, rising 5.21 points to 1714.40. The market saw 127 gainers for every 36 losers, with a total volume of 34.19 million lots worth RM13.41 million.

site_title: Shanghai bourse bans individuals from trading "junk bonds"
summary: The Shanghai Stock Exchange has banned individuals from trading "junk bonds" issued by small and medium enterprises (SMEs), effective immediately. The ban also prohibits institutions from selling individual investors these products. The move aims to tighten regulatory control of the high-yield, high-risk fixed income market, which analysts have warned can distort investors' behavior. The ban follows previous steps by Beijing to suppress the high-yield bond market and prevent a potential explosion in non-performing debt.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up 1.08%
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.08% on Thursday, driven by solid US data and the yen's drop against the dollar. The Nikkei 225 index increased 182.07 points to 17,067.40. The market followed a strong start on Wall Street, where stocks jumped on Wednesday.

site_title: South Korea Dec foreign portfolio outflows at 10-mth high: regulator
summary: South Korea saw its largest foreign portfolio outflows in 10 months in December, with a net 2.0 trillion won ($1.82 billion) sold from local bonds and stocks. The majority of the outflows were in stocks, amid a global market rout and concerns over growth. Investors in the US, UK, and Saudi Arabia were the largest sellers. South Korean stock prices have declined steadily since July last year, and foreign investors lowered their bond holdings for the first time in four months, but boosted their bond holdings in November.

site_title: White House to release Obama's 2016 budget on Feb 2
summary: The White House announced it will release President Barack Obama's 2016 budget on February 2, meeting a deadline under law. This marks a return to regular budget process after past missed deadlines.

images.alt_text: The White House will release President Barack Obama's budget for fiscal year 2016 on Feb. 2, a spokeswoman said on Wednesday, meeting a deadline set under law that the White House has often missed in the past.

site_title: Singapore's DPM offers 'deepest condolences' over Paris massacre
summary: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean expressed "deepest condolences" over the Paris massacre that killed 12 and injured over 20 after gunmen attacked the Charlie Hebdo office. He urged Singaporeans to report suspicious activities and strengthened security patrols. The attack was carried out by heavily-armed gunmen targeting the magazine over its controversial Prophet Mohammed cartoons.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
SINGAPORE'S Deputy Prime Minister Teo Chee Hean expressed his sadness after a shocking attack at the office of satirical French magazine Charlie Hebdo left 12 dead and more than 20 injured.

site_title: Samsung Electronics says Q4 operating profit likely down 37.4% y-o-y
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 37.4% year-over-year decline in Q4 operating profit to 5.2 trillion won (US$4.74 billion), beating analyst expectations. This marks the company's fifth consecutive quarter of declining operating profit and its first annual profit decline in three years. Q4 sales likely fell 12.3% to 52 trillion won, compared to a forecast of 51.9 trillion won.

site_title: Asian markets boosted by US data, Europe easing talk
summary: Asian markets rallied on Thursday following strong US data and expectations for eurozone stimulus measures, boosting confidence and oil prices. The US Federal Reserve's minutes suggested it won't hike interest rates before April, fueling hopes for quantitative easing. Markets rose across Asia, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Sydney gaining ground, while Shanghai remained flat. The eurozone's consumer price deflation sparked expectations of an ECB bond-buying program, but the euro strengthened against the dollar. US stocks also rallied, with the Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Triyards profit climbs 13% in Q1 FY15
summary: Triyards Holdings, an offshore engineering group, reported a 13% increase in net profit to US$8.2 million in Q1 FY15, driven by higher margins from an offshore fabrication project. Revenue declined 37% to US$56.7 million due to lower contributions from completed projects. The company expects continued demand for its offerings despite a challenging environment. Triyards' share price rose 2.02% before market opening.

site_title: French raid under way after 12 killed in magazine attack
summary: French anti-terror police launched a late-night raid in Reims after 12 people, including 11 journalists and cartoonists, were killed in a magazine attack in Paris. The attack on Charlie Hebdo, a satirical weekly, was condemned globally, with President Francois Hollande declaring a day of national mourning. The killers, identified as three suspects, including two brothers, shouted "Allahu akbar" as they carried out the attack, which was described as an "act of exceptional barbarity." The incident sparked widespread outrage and solidarity across the world, with over 100,000 people gathering in France to protest.

site_title: UK businesses enjoy strong end to 2014, confident about prospects: BCC
summary: British businesses concluded 2014 on a strong note, with rising demand at home and abroad and a record number of companies hiring staff, according to the British Chambers of Commerce's quarterly economic survey. Manufacturing and services companies were in a fairly confident mood about 2015 prospects. The positive findings will be welcome for the Conservative government ahead of the national election.

site_title: China smartphone maker Xiaomi wants a bite of Apple
summary: Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi aims to become the world's number one smartphone company in the next 5-10 years. The company, founded by Lei Jun, has excelled in China's smartphone market by delivering high-performance products at affordable prices, shipping 17.3 million phones in the third quarter of 2014. Xiaomi claims sales of over 61 million smartphones last year, with turnover more than doubling to $12 billion. However, critics say the firm has copied Apple's designs, and the US giant's senior vice president of design has called similarities "theft." Despite this, Xiaomi remains a major player in China, but patent issues and low brand recognition outside its home market are obstacles to its international expansion.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.86% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.86% lower on Thursday, reversing a previous rebound. The Hang Seng Index rose 202.69 points to 23,883.95, driven by a pick-up in oil prices and expectations of European monetary easing.

site_title: Holiday season US store sales down 8% in 2014
summary: US retail store sales declined 8% during the 2014 holiday season, despite a late shopping surge. Foot traffic dropped 8.3% at specialty stores and large retailers, but customers spent more on average. Stronger online buying is expected to offset this decline, with holiday sales projected to rise 3.5-4% from last year.

site_title: Brent oil slumps under US$50 for first time since 2009
summary: Brent oil prices dropped under $50 for the first time since 2009, reaching a low of $49.66 per barrel in London deals, before recovering to $51.14. The decline was attributed to mixed demand signals in the US and a strong dollar, which makes dollar-priced oil more expensive for buyers using weaker currencies. Analysts expect prices to continue to decline, with some predicting a potential drop to $40, driven by weak growth and demand in China and Europe, and OPEC's decision to maintain production levels.

site_title: 'I Am Charlie': Mass rallies for French massacre victims
summary: More than 100,000 people gathered across France to pay tribute to the 12 victims of the January 7 massacre by Islamist gunmen at Charlie Hebdo magazine, with similar rallies held in European cities. The "I Am Charlie" hashtag spread globally, with thousands wearing black stickers and banners supporting freedom of the press. Demonstrators also shared online tributes and cartoons, with many referencing the slain editor-in-chief Stephane Charbonnier's defiant statement: "I prefer to die standing than live on my knees."

site_title: Global oil and gas exploration spending to slide 17%: Cowen
summary: Global oil and gas exploration spending is expected to decline 17% this year due to a slump in crude oil prices. The estimated global expenditure will be $571 billion, with a 22% drop in North American spending and a 15% decline in international spending. Companies like ConocoPhillips and Continental Resources Inc have already reduced their budgets, with ConocoPhillips cutting spending by 20% and Continental Resources Inc by 40%. The decline is attributed to weak global demand and growing oil supplies.

site_title: Stocks to watch: EMAS Offshore, Triyards, Yuuzoo
summary: EMAS Offshore reported a 10-fold jump in Q1 FY15 net profit to US$148.4 million due to a US$137.5 million gain from consolidation, but revenue slumped 9% to US$72.7 million. Triyards Holdings' Q1 FY15 net profit rose 13% to US$8.2 million, driven by higher margins from an offshore fabrication project, but revenue fell 37% to US$56.7 million.

site_title: Spain tightens security after Paris attack
summary: Spain upgraded its anti-terrorist security level after the Paris attack on Charlie Hebdo, which left 12 dead. The move was precautionary, with no evidence of an additional threat in Spain. A suspect package was evacuated from the Madrid headquarters of El Pais newspaper, but was later found to be non-dangerous. The Interior Minister stated that the rivalry between Al-Qaeda and Islamic State leaders could lead to an escalation in attacks, but there was no concrete evidence of an imminent threat in Spain.

site_title: Queen Elizabeth sends 'sincere condolences' over Paris massacre
summary: Queen Elizabeth II sent "sincere condolences" to the families of those killed and injured in the Charlie Hebdo attack in Paris, offering "thoughts and prayers" to those affected. The attack, carried out by heavily-armed gunmen, resulted in the deaths of 12 people and injured many others. The Queen's message was sent from her private residence, Sandringham House, in response to an international news event.

site_title: EMAS Offshore profit jumps more than 10 times in Q1 FY2015
summary: EMAS Offshore Limited, the operating brand for Ezra Holdings, reported a net profit of US$148.4 million in Q1 FY2015, a 10-fold increase from the previous year. The surge was driven by a US$137.5 million gain from consolidating EOC Limited and EMAS Marine. However, revenue declined 9% to US$72.7 million due to the return of a leased-in vessel and weakness in the shallow water platform support vessels segment. The company aims to streamline operations and focus on building backlog contracts to improve performance.

site_title: China-Brazil trade down 6% y-o-y
summary: Brazil's trade with China fell 6% in 2014 to $77.9 billion, down from $83.3 billion in 2013, due to decreased demand for commodities. Brazilian exports to China dropped 12% to $40.6 billion, while imports rose 0.1% to $37.3 billion, resulting in a bilateral surplus of $3.2 billion. This decline follows a peak in 2013, when China overtook the US as Brazil's leading trade partner.

site_title: US small-business hiring picks up in December
summary: US small businesses increased hiring in December, adding an average of 0.2 workers per company, up from 0.05 in November. This signals a strong labour market for 2015, driving wages higher and supporting consumer spending. The National Federation of Independent Business and ADP reported 241,000 private employer job gains in December. The unemployment rate is forecast to slip to 5.7%, the lowest since June 2008, as a quarter of small business owners said they had job openings they could not fill.

site_title: Blow-by-blow account of Paris massacre
summary: Two masked men, armed with Kalashnikovs, attacked the Charlie Hebdo office in Paris, killing 12 people, including journalists and cartoonists, and wounding one. The assailants, who yelled "we have avenged the prophet" and "Allahu akbar," escaped in a car, leading to a shootout with police. They abandoned the vehicle and hijacked another, fleeing the scene. The attack was described as "blood-curdling calm" and "cold-blooded," with witnesses noting the killers' methodical and deliberate actions. The motive behind the attack is unclear, but it is believed to be linked to the satirical magazine's publication of cartoons deemed insulting to Islam.

site_title: Obama touts auto bailout success, Michigan worries about trade
summary: President Barack Obama visited a Ford Motor Co plant in Michigan to tout the success of the auto industry bailout, which he said paid off for America. However, his push for new trade agreements, such as the Trans-Pacific Partnership, is met with concerns from Michigan officials and advocates that they harm the manufacturing sector. Obama will deliver his State of the Union address on January 20, with the White House hoping to make progress on issues like tax reform and trade with a Republican-controlled Congress.

site_title: Police hunt three Frenchmen after Paris attack
summary: Police are hunting three Frenchmen, including two brothers, for their alleged roles in a deadly attack on the Paris office of satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, which left 12 people dead. The attack, carried out by hooded assailants, was the deadliest on French soil in decades. The suspects, identified as Said Kouachi, Cherif Kouachi, and Hamyd Mourad, were last seen fleeing in a car after shooting dead some of France's top cartoonists and two police officers. A massive manhunt has been launched across the capital, with 800 soldiers deployed to shore up security.

site_title: Global condemnation, solidarity after 'barbaric' Paris attack
summary: A terrorist attack on the French magazine Charlie Hebdo left 12 people dead, in an attack on freedom of speech in Europe. Global leaders, including US President Barack Obama, Queen Elizabeth II, and Pope Francis, condemned the attack, calling it "barbaric" and "cowardly." The UN Security Council also condemned the attack, and many countries expressed solidarity with Charlie Hebdo through social media using the hashtag #JeSuisCharlie. The attack was described as a brazen assault on free expression and a threat to European values.

site_title: United Airlines attendants claim fired over their security concerns
summary: Thirteen United Airlines flight attendants, with 18+ years of experience, claim they were illegally fired after refusing to fly on a Hong Kong-bound plane in July due to a "threatening" message scrawled under the tail engine. The message included "Bye Bye" and two faces, which the attendants believed posed a security risk to the 300 passengers and crew. The airline denied the claims, stating there was no credible security threat, and the attendants are seeking reinstatement, back pay, and damages under a federal whistleblower law.

site_title: Fed worries about international risks to US economy
summary: The Federal Reserve expressed concerns about international risks to the US economy, citing weaker-than-desired inflation and potential declines in oil prices and global economic growth. Despite these risks, the Fed may raise interest rates, as lower oil prices have boosted the labor market and supported economic recovery. Policymakers expect inflation to rise gradually, and the risks to the outlook are seen as nearly balanced. The Fed may begin normalization at a time when core inflation is near current levels, potentially as early as April.

site_title: Fed looks past a world in turmoil, confident in US recovery
summary: The US economy has shown signs of a strong recovery, with trade data and consumer spending confirming the nation's resilience despite global uncertainty. The Federal Reserve, in its December policy-setting meeting, remains confident in the US recovery, citing a boost from lower energy prices and strong consumer spending. Despite concerns over emerging markets and potential economic downturn, the Fed is poised to continue its policy divergence from other major central banks, with analysts predicting a positive impact on the economy.

site_title: Euro at nine-year low as European inflation turns negative
summary: The euro has hit a nine-year low at US$1.18020 after euro zone inflation turned negative for the first time since 2009, increasing pressure on the European Central Bank to loosen monetary policy. Investors expect the ECB to take bold action to stimulate economic growth, rekindling a trade of selling the euro short. The euro fell 0.39% on the day, with the market pricing in ECB easing at the end of the month, and is expected to continue losing value.

site_title: Call for holistic SME development in Budget 2015 recommendations
summary: Singapore's SME Committee has recommended a more holistic approach to SME development, calling for more comprehensive data and a single SME authority to champion the rights of SMEs. The committee's Budget 2015 recommendations focus on three areas: a more holistic approach to SME strategy, targeted measures to help SMEs transform, and assistance for SMEs to grow through internationalization, innovation, and collaboration. The committee also recommends a Restructuring Loan Scheme and lower financing costs, as well as deferring planned increases in foreign worker levies to help SMEs lower costs.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Samsung Electronics to record first annual profit fall in three years
summary: Samsung Electronics reported a 37.4% decline in fourth-quarter profit, its first annual profit fall in three years. The company's annual profit is likely to be 25 trillion won, the lowest since 2011, due to increased competition from Apple and Chinese rivals. The mobile division's profit improved slightly, but overall smartphone shipments fell, offsetting gains from mid-to-low tier smartphone sales. Analysts predict a second straight annual decline in profit if the profit guidance is confirmed.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics on Thursday said its fourth-quarter profit likely fell 37.4 per cent, confirming its first year of annual profit decline since 2011 as it struggles to retain its crown as global smartphone leader.

site_title: Fresh allegations against Brazil's Petrobras emerge
summary: Brazil's state-owned oil giant Petrobras is being probed for allegedly over-charging on a gas pipeline contract and using a front company. Petrobras denied setting up a front firm and claimed the cost overrun was "admissible." The project cost 6.3 billion reais, with a suspected 1,800% surcharge. The company's chair, Graca Foster, signed a document in 2007 calling for the creation of a company linked to the project, which Petrobras denies was a "phantom company." The investigation is the latest in a series of corruption allegations against Petrobras, which is already embroiled in an investigation into alleged kickbacks for politicians.

site_title: J C Penney holiday season sales rise 3.7%, stock jumps 20%
summary: J C Penney reported a 3.7% increase in same-store sales for November and December, boosting its shares by 20% in after-hours trading. This is the first major retailer to report holiday season results, suggesting a strong holiday shopping season. Analysts attribute the sales growth to increased consumer spending, particularly in women's accessories and gift cards, with some predicting above-expectations sales growth. This positive trend is expected to be followed by Macy's Inc., which has projected comparable sales growth of 1.8-2.8% during the holiday quarter.

site_title: Rocket glitch forces SpaceX to abort landmark launch
summary: SpaceX was forced to abort its historic attempt to land the first stage of the Falcon 9 rocket on an ocean platform due to a glitch in the second stage's thrust vector control actuator. The rocket was launched on Tuesday, but the issue led to a launch abort. SpaceX plans to attempt the landing again on Friday. The company aims to revolutionize rocket science by making technology that allows rockets to return to Earth intact for reuse. The mission's primary goal is to deliver supplies to the International Space Station.

site_title: Chinese entrepreneur buys Bordeaux wine estate
summary: Chinese entrepreneur James Zhou has acquired Chateau Renon, a 19th-century Bordeaux wine estate in France, in a two-transaction deal. The estate's vineyards, covering 8 hectares, were managed separately in recent years. This is one of over 100 Bordeaux wine estates bought by Chinese investors since 2010. Zhou plans to use French winemakers and local expertise, and the deal allows for wine to be shipped to the Chinese market. The transaction price was not disclosed, with the chateau's condition described as "outstanding".

site_title: China to invest US$20b in struggling Venezuela: Maduro
summary: China has agreed to invest over $20 billion in Venezuela, according to President Nicolas Maduro, who met with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing. This investment comes as Venezuela faces a financial crisis due to falling oil prices. Maduro stated that the investment will help alleviate the country's economic struggles. The deal was made during a critical time for Venezuela, highlighting China's growing influence in the region.

site_title: Merkel gives little ground to Cameron over EU reform on visit
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said she would help UK Prime Minister David Cameron tackle EU migrant welfare abuses but refused to compromise on the EU's freedom of movement principle. Merkel, meeting with Cameron in London, supports his proposal to renegotiate EU ties before a 2017 referendum on Britain's membership. This comes as Cameron's Conservatives face a growing threat from the Eurosceptic UK Independence Party ahead of the May election.

site_title: US lawmakers' vote paves way for tax cuts
summary: US lawmakers voted 234-172 to adopt a rule allowing them to assume lower taxes boost the economy and cover budget costs, giving Republicans greater leeway to implement tax policies. This "dynamic scoring" policy change was part of a package of House rules changes. The move aims to reflect how fiscal policy can expand the economy, but critics argue it may increase the budget deficit.

site_title: Bonds listings on SGX and proceeds raised hit new highs
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) saw a record-breaking year in 2014, with 521 new bonds listed and a total of S$213 billion raised. This represents a significant increase from 465 bonds listed and S$176 billion raised in 2013. Japanese companies led the way, accounting for 11.5% of new bond listings and 22% of total proceeds raised. The SGX reported an increase in floating rate notes and convertible bonds issued by Japanese firms, as well as a shift towards making wholesale bonds more accessible to the broader market.

site_title: World Bank sees slower track for global trade engine
summary: The World Bank forecasts a slower expansion of global trade over the next decade, citing slower economic growth and shifts in trade patterns. After expanding at 7% a year for 30 years prior to the 2007-2009 financial crisis, trade growth has fallen to 5% a year. This decline is attributed to factors such as a lackluster recovery from the crisis, weak investment spending, and countries making more inputs closer to home. Policymakers hope regional and global trade pacts can help regain lost momentum, while the World Bank suggests integrating South Asia, sub-Saharan Africa, and South America into global supply chains could also boost trade.

site_title: Coal workers strike in India against privatisation
summary: Coal workers in India have gone on strike against plans to privatize the industry, with unions vowing the largest walkout in four decades. The strike, led by state-run Coal India Ltd, has shut down some mines and disrupted supply at others. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's plans aim to end the state monopoly in the industry, but the strike is intended to halt the move. The strike is the largest in four decades, with all workers at some mines walking out and others partially closed.

site_title: Europe needs to change attitude to work, family and immigrants
summary: Europe's economic struggles are rooted in demographic issues, not economic policies. The region's aging population and low fertility rates are expected to lead to decreased productivity and investment in future generations. By 2030, nearly half of Western Europeans will be 65 or older, and fertility rates have fallen to replacement levels since the 1970s. Anti-immigrant sentiment is also on the rise, despite immigration being a potential solution. To address these issues, Europe needs visionary leaders and a social movement to prioritize family, work, and openness to immigrants.

site_title: BT, Maybank tie up for 2nd Asian investment seminar
summary: THE Business Times (BT) has partnered Maybank Kim Eng for its second Asian investment outlook seminar, set to take place this Saturday at the Grand Hyatt in Singapore. The event will feature presentations by Maybank Investment Bank's chief economist Suhaimi Ilias, head of research Ng Wee Siang, and Aggregate Asset Management's executive director and head of research Teh Hooi Ling. The seminar will focus on "Spotting Opportunities in Asian Markets" and aims to provide insights on macroeconomic themes and market trends.

site_title: Coach to buy Stuart Weitzman for up to US$574m
summary: Coach is planning to acquire luxury shoe brand Stuart Weitzman for up to $574 million, aiming to reassert its position as a high-end fashion house. The deal could potentially strengthen Coach's luxury credentials.

site_title: Oil rout will boost Asian economies, analysts say
summary: A global oil price slump is expected to boost Asian economies, particularly those heavily reliant on oil imports, by easing inflationary pressures and reducing energy costs. Analysts say the opportunity should be seized to implement structural reforms, such as cutting energy subsidies, which have contributed to fiscal deficits and social unrest in the past. Countries like Malaysia, Indonesia, and India have already made cuts to fuel subsidies, while others, like India, are expected to benefit from lower oil prices, which could lead to interest rate cuts and reduced inflation.

site_title: Oil rout mars reputation of Canadian banks as world's safest lenders
summary: Canadian banks' reputation as the world's safest lenders is being eroded due to record consumer debt and an overvalued housing market, exacerbated by the collapse of crude oil prices. The country's banks, which were once favored by investors for their higher capital requirements, are now facing increased competition from foreign banks. With oil prices at their lowest since 2009, Canadian banks may see a significant portion of their revenue impacted, and investors are demanding higher yields for their debt.

site_title: Heads-up technology puts data on car windshields at CES
summary: Heads-up displays, projecting data on car windshields, have been showcased at the CES, with carmakers and tech start-ups offering features such as speed, directions, and cellphone notifications. While carmakers argue that the displays are a safety measure, safety advocates claim they divert drivers' attention from the road, increasing the risk of accidents. The technology is becoming increasingly ubiquitous, with some displays offering vivid, high-definition information, but experts warn that the science on its safety is lacking, and the displays could lead to "inattentional blindness" or tunnel vision.

site_title: Non-performing mortgage loan risks to persist in banks
summary: Singapore banks face risks from non-performing mortgage loans, although the risks have shifted from foreigners defaulting on luxury homes to locals on suburban homes. Despite regulators' tighter credit criteria, some banks, like United Overseas Bank, have seen significant increases in non-performing loans. Analysts predict a mild impact on banks this year, citing the Monetary Authority of Singapore's controls and the lower loan-to-value ratios. However, banks like OCBC remain at higher risk due to their rapid loan growth during the early housing boom.

site_title: In Japan, "meddlesome" guides seek confused tourists
summary: In Japan, a volunteer organization called "Osekkai (meddlesome) Japan" provides assistance to confused tourists, especially in areas like Tokyo's Ginza district. The group, made up of around 40 students and adults, guides people and acts as interpreters, even if not asked. Their efforts have gained recognition, with some tourists expressing gratitude and even offering to host them in their homes. The organization aims to promote Japan's hospitality, "omotenashi," and improve the country's tourism industry, which is expected to reach 20 million foreign visitors by 2020.

site_title: Bats suggests cutting fees to improve US equity market
summary: Bats Global Markets Inc, a leading US stock exchange operator, suggests cutting fees for buying and selling some stocks to improve the US$24 trillion equity market, potentially saving $850 million. The proposal differs from New York Stock Exchange's plan, which would cut fees to 5 cents per 100 shares. Bats wants to maintain a maker-taker system, providing rebates to traders for liquidity, and believes it promotes narrow spreads. The move follows a set of proposals from the NYSE, which has been circulating among asset managers and broker-dealers.

site_title: Obama takes US economic bright spell on the road
summary: President Barack Obama is embarking on a US economic tour to highlight the country's improved numbers, riding a "bright spell" of economic growth. Despite a combative year ahead with a newly elected Congress and 2016 elections, Obama is confident in the economy's trajectory. The article does not provide further details on the tour's specifics or expected outcomes, focusing instead on the economic context and Obama's approach.

images.alt_text: Riding high on a stronger economy, President Barack Obama is setting out on a US tour to highlight the improved numbers, with hopes that his approval rating follows suit.

site_title: Thesis on America's decline not panning out
summary: The US economy has defied predictions of decline, with growth rates surpassing those of Japan and the European Union. Despite concerns about aging population, infrastructure, and poverty, the US has continued to recover faster than other economies, with a 2.6% growth rate last year and an expected 3% growth rate this year. The US unemployment rate has fallen to 5.8%, and the economy is expected to normalize monetary policy. The country's structural advantages, including its cultural and geographical strengths, ensure its ability to bounce back from crises.

site_title: Trade deficit hits 11-month low
summary: The US trade deficit fell to an 11-month low in November, largely due to declining crude oil prices. This decrease in imports outweighed a drop in exports, possibly related to a labor dispute at a key port. Meanwhile, private employers increased hiring in the US, indicating a strong economy despite slowing growth abroad.

site_title: HK home prices in Nov hit record high for 7th straight month
summary: Hong Kong home prices reached a record high for the seventh consecutive month in November, with a 3.7% month-on-month increase, according to official data. The index rose 12% in the first 11 months of 2014, driven by pent-up demand for smaller units. Developers continued to offer discounts, with one selling 300 units within nine hours of launch at discounts of up to 10.5% off. Analysts expect home prices to edge up 3-5% this year, with demand boosted by cooling measures.

site_title: Canadian ghost town sold to Chinese developer
summary: A Chinese real estate developer, China Zhong Ya Group Hebei Canada-China Co, has acquired Bradian, a Canadian ghost town 230km north of Vancouver, for under C$1 million. The town, which was once home to workers from a nearby gold mine, was abandoned after the mine closed in 1971 and later sold to a couple in 1997. The new owner plans to rehabilitate the town, but the planning process is expected to take considerable time. This sale marks a new trend of Chinese investors buying rural properties in Canada.

site_title: US: Wall St ends up more than 1%, boosted by jobs data, Fed
summary: US stocks rose 1.2% on Wednesday, their largest daily gain in two weeks, after strong private sector jobs data and minutes from the Federal Reserve meeting reassured investors about the bank's intentions to raise interest rates later this year. The S&P 500 retraced its 4.2% loss from the previous five sessions due to plunging oil prices and global economic concerns. Fed officials expressed patience in deciding when to begin raising interest rates, comforting investors that rates won't rise soon.

site_title: Paris on highest terror alert after 12 killed in magazine office attack
summary: A deadly attack on the office of satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo in Paris killed at least 12 people, with four more in critical condition and 20 injured. The attackers, described as hooded individuals, shouted "Allahu Akbar" before fleeing. France has raised its terror alert level to its highest level, and President Francois Hollande has vowed to protect potential targets. This attack is France's worst in decades, and comes after a series of recent foiled incidents. The magazine's offices were firebombed in 2011 after publishing a special edition featuring the Prophet Mohammed.

site_title: QT Vascular balloons on clinical trial update
summary: Shares in QT Vascular jumped 12.5% to 36 Singapore cents after a Tuesday night update on enrolment for its clinical trial of a product. The stock ended the day at 35.5 Singapore cents, 10.9% higher than the previous closing. This increase came after the company reported positive news on its clinical trial update.

site_title: Drones swoop into Consumer Electronics Show as interest surges
summary: Drones are gaining popularity at the Consumer Electronics Show, with 400,000 consumer drones worth $130 million forecasted to be sold globally in 2015, a 55% increase from last year. Companies are developing drones to capture extreme sports footage, such as surfing and skiing. The AirDog drone was showcased at the event, designed for capturing intense sports activities.

site_title: Dismantling a Chinese developer could get ugly
summary: Chinese developer Kaisa is heading towards a debt restructuring after defaulting on a HK$400 million bank loan. The company has warned of automatic defaults and has seen its chairman step down due to health concerns. Foreign investors who purchased Kaisa's Cayman Islands vehicle have limited claims on onshore assets, and the company's 14 billion yuan bank borrowings add uncertainty. Politicians will prioritize safeguarding homebuyers' interests, which may involve raiding pre-payments or selling projects at fire-sale prices, leaving anxious foreign investors with limited returns.

site_title: SIA's key strategies taking shape
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) faced significant challenges in 2014, including overcapacity, yield pressures, currency volatility, and fuel price volatility, amidst intense competition from budget carriers. These issues are expected to persist in 2015. Despite efforts to address these challenges, SIA's 2014 performance was likely turbulent. The airline's key strategies are taking shape, but it remains to be seen how they will impact the company's future performance.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Board overseeing BOE failed in its duty during 2007 crisis
summary: A senior British lawmaker has criticized the Board overseeing the Bank of England for failing to hold the central bank accountable during the 2007-09 financial crisis. The minutes of the Bank's Court show a lack of effective challenge to the governor, Mervyn King, and a failure to understand deposit insurance. The central bank struggled to deal with Britain's first bank run in over 100 years and took steps to ensure banks had enough liquidity, but its efforts were criticized for not addressing underlying problems. The lawmaker, Andrew Tyrie, said the Board's failure to act was "alarming" and contributed to the crisis.

site_title: New World Trade Center gets a different mix of tenants
summary: The new World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan has seen a shift in tenants, with technology, media, and advertising companies making up the majority of space. Financial firms, which dominated the original twin towers, are scarce among tenants. As of 2019, the towers were expected to reach 95% occupancy, but leasing has been slow, with only 3.3 million sq ft rented out of 6.2 million sq ft. Companies like High 5 Games and xAd Inc have taken space, drawn by the area's growing reputation as a hip destination. Leasing is expected to pick up in the coming year.

site_title: Euro hits new 9-year low against greenback
summary: The euro has hit a new 9-year low against the US dollar, falling to a 0.2% annual decline in eurozone consumer prices in December due to cheaper energy. This data has raised pressure on the European Central Bank to take bold policy action.

site_title: Wages still flat despite US economic boom
summary: The US economy has experienced a boom, with the lowest unemployment rate in six years, but wages remain stagnant. Despite a 2.1% annual wage growth rate, wages have barely risen in real terms, with 15% of Americans seeing no wage gain in the past year. The average hourly salary is only slightly higher than the 1964 rate, and lower-income workers have seen their pay shrink 3.7% since 2000. Experts attribute the anomaly to a weak labor market, the rise of temporary jobs, and the decline of workers' unions, with some suggesting a federal minimum wage increase could help push pay higher.

site_title: Shell to pay out £55m in compensation for Nigeria oil spills in 2008
summary: Royal Dutch Shell will pay £55m in compensation for two 2008 oil spills in Nigeria, with £35m shared among 15,600 individuals and £20m set aside for community projects. The payment is the largest out-of-court settlement for oil spills in Nigeria and marks a significant step forward for the Niger Delta region.

site_title: Sri Lanka polls result critical to top investor China
summary: China's largest investor in Sri Lanka, President Xi Jinping, has a stake in the country's presidential election. Mahinda Rajapaksa, who has shifted Sri Lanka towards China since 2005, is facing a challenge from Maithripala Sirisena, who has promised a more balanced foreign policy. Sirisena's manifesto calls for equal relations with India, China, Pakistan, and Japan, and he has vowed to backtrack on projects built with Chinese credit. If Sirisena wins, China's influence in the Indian Ocean region could be at risk, and the country's military presence may be scaled back.

site_title: French court blocks LVMH's plans for iconic Paris building
summary: A French appeals court blocked LVMH's plans to renovate and redevelop the iconic former Parisian department store La Samaritaine, citing that the modern makeover would clash with its historic surroundings. The renovation, which included a massive undulating glass facade, was cancelled after a court previously cancelled one of the permits due to the design's impact on the area's aesthetic. LVMH plans to appeal the decision and redevelop the site into a five-star hotel, offices, shops, and flats at a cost of 460 million euros.

site_title: GLP inks Japan leasing deals
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has signed four lease agreements totaling 70,000 square meters in Greater Tokyo with industry-leading retailers and a third-party logistics provider. The agreements support domestic distribution needs for retail stores and e-commerce, including two with existing customers Senko and H&M Hennes & Mauritz Japan.

site_title: Fragrance puts Geylang building on market
summary: Fragrance Group Limited is selling a 60-year-leasehold light industrial building in Geylang, Singapore, with an indicative price of S$115 million. The building has a total provisional strata floor area of 237,000 sq ft and can be strata-subdivided for sale only 10 years after Temporary Occupation Permit (TOP). The development has a range of recreational facilities, including an outdoor tennis court and swimming pool, and is zoned for "Business 1" use. The sale is seen as an attractive investment opportunity for institutional investors due to its long lease tenure and proximity to amenities.

site_title: Discount chains emerge as holiday winners while clothing retailers suffer
summary: Discount chains such as Wal-Mart and Costco posted their best monthly sales gain in over two years, with a 8.3% increase in December. This trend suggests Americans are staying frugal, diverting discretionary spending to monthly costs. Clothing retailers, including department stores, experienced sales declines, with spending on apparel decreasing from 5% to 2.8% of a typical US household's budget. Retail overall rose 2.5% in December, with grocery stores also posting robust sales.

site_title: Two wireless charging industry groups merge
summary: Two major wireless charging industry groups, the Alliance for Wireless Power and the Power Matters Alliance, have merged to form a new entity aimed at accelerating wireless charging adoption. The merger, backed by Intel, Qualcomm, Samsung, Procter & Gamble, and Starbucks, brings consumers closer to ditching power cords. The combined group's standards are interoperable, and the market is expected to reach $8.5 billion by 2018. This move follows the success of the Wireless Power Consortium's "Qi" standard, which is used in about 20 million devices worldwide.

site_title: Italy's record jobless high contrasts with new low in Germany
summary: Italy's jobless rate unexpectedly rose to a record high of 13.4% in November, more than double Germany's 6.5% rate, which fell to its lowest in over two decades. The euro region jobless rate is 11.5%. The data contrasts with Germany's economic growth and raises concerns about a deflationary spiral in the euro area. Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi is pushing reforms to help the labor market, while Germany's labor agency president says full employment is within reach with proper implementation.

site_title: Restructuring yoke to weigh on Singapore this year: DBS CEO
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta notes that 2015 is a crucial year for Singapore's economy restructuring, amid concerns over inflation and weakening economic prospects. Gupta emphasizes the importance of the US economy powering Asia's export engines, suggesting that Singapore's efforts will be critical in this year.

images.alt_text: Mr Gupta spots two "deflationary drives" - the productivity drive and the property cooling measures.

site_title: Draghi squeezes call option out of Danish bonds
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi is set to purchase euro-area bonds, with Denmark's mortgage banks already issuing loans backed by 30-year bonds at a 2% fixed rate, the cheapest ever. This has led to an estimated 500 billion kroner (S$107 billion) in mortgages being converted to take advantage of the low borrowing cost. The record-low borrowing cost also reduces the risk of bonds being called in by homeowners, making them more attractive to investors.

site_title: Tooth found with fries in McDonald's Osaka outlet: reports
summary: A customer in Japan found a human tooth in their serving of french fries at a McDonald's outlet in Osaka, according to reports. Independent investigations by McDonald's confirmed the object was a tooth, which was reportedly "fried". The incident is the latest in a series of contaminated food incidents for the company in Japan, including a vinyl found in a chicken nugget and a plastic piece in a sundae. The company apologized and attributed the tooth to a low possibility of contamination at the US factory that shipped the chips.

site_title: Japan Government Pension Investment Fund raises pay of chief
summary: The Japan Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) has raised the pay of its president by 64% to approximately 31 million yen (S$348,000), effective this month. The increase is aimed at attracting more private sector money managers to join the fund. This move comes as the fund seeks to diversify its management team and boost its investment performance. The salary hike is part of efforts to improve the fund's competitiveness in the global investment landscape.

site_title: Kerry to attend investor forum in India before Obama's visit
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry will attend a global investors summit in Ahmedabad, India, on Saturday to pave the way for US President Barack Obama's visit. This is the first time the US joins the Vibrant Gujarat Global Investors Summit as a partner country. The trip aims to boost trade and investment between the two countries, which currently stand at $100 billion, with a goal to reach $500 billion. Kerry's visit comes after a diplomatic spat between the US and India in 2013, and follows recent settlement of a food subsidy row between the two countries.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Regulatory risks in Singapore pose a threat to telcos, particularly M1 and StarHub, who lack overseas operations. This could limit upside investing in telcos. Additionally, the potential reversal of yield compression reduces the upside.

site_title: UN pushes for better aviation tracking system
summary: The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) is proposing a new standard requiring commercial aircraft to report their position every 15 minutes as part of a global tracking initiative. This comes after the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, and ICAO aims to improve tracking for safety. The standard, if adopted, would not require new technology on planes and could be implemented in the near term. Airlines are already tracking planes using satellite systems, but gaps in coverage exist, particularly along polar routes. ICAO is seeking consensus from its 191 member states to implement the standard.

site_title: Morgan Stanley fund mulls bulk sale of luxe units
summary: A Morgan Stanley fund is exploring a bulk sale of its 23 luxury units in Singapore's Draycott Eight condo, with an asking price of S$157.4 million (S$2,300 per square foot). The units, mostly leased, could yield a 2.7% net yield if sold at S$150 million. This follows a deal by Blackstone for 21 units in Anderson Royal Oak Residence, also valued at S$164 million (S$1,917 per square foot). The bulk sales indicate a momentum for high-end transactions in Singapore's luxury property market.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Rolls-Royce will decide on SUV segment this year
summary: Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Ltd is set to decide this year whether to enter the SUV segment, following Bentley's lead, after a five-year streak of sales records. The company delivered a record 4,063 cars in 2014, with global sales quadrupling since 2009. A new convertible is planned for mid-2016, and Rolls-Royce is preparing for a potential SUV launch, with a price increase in Russia to counter the ruble's slump. The company faces increasing competition from other luxury brands, but is focusing on made-to-order flourishes and limited editions to maintain its premium image.

site_title: Sakae pursues advisory business with sushi growth in mind
summary: Sakae Holdings, the parent company of Sakae Sushi restaurants, has set up a corporate advisory arm to help Q&M Dental, its first client, tap European and US investors. The two-year deal will focus on marketing Q&M to investors and enhancing its business model. Sakae Holdings aims to expand its 200 restaurants to 30,000 outlets worldwide, and the advisory business will aid in this growth plan. The unit is fully owned by Sakae Holdings and will employ at least five finance industry veterans, with an initial investment of S$10.5 million.

site_title: COE premiums edge up across the board
summary: Singapore's certificates of entitlement (COE) premiums rose across the board in the first bidding exercise for 2015, with Category A increasing by S$121 to S$66,010, and Category B rising by S$1,289 to S$75,289. The longer interval since the last COE tender and more aggressive bidding may have contributed to the increases. Despite this, demand in the market has been patchy, and the market is expecting a larger quota for February to April 2015, which could eventually lower COE premiums.

site_title: Asia-Pac M&As at historic high
summary: The Asia-Pacific region saw a record-breaking year for merger and acquisition (M&A) deals in 2014, with a total value of US$591.6 billion and 3,250 transactions. This surpassed the previous record set in 2013 by 43.4%. The majority of deals were dominated by US and European buyers, highlighting the region's increasing attractiveness for foreign investors.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam
Last year was a record-busting year for merger and acquisition (M&A) deals in the Asia-Pacific (excluding Japan) - in number of transactions and their total value.

site_title: Intel allocates millions to boost staff diversity in workplace
summary: Intel announces a $300 million plan to boost staff diversity in its workplace, aiming to increase the proportion of women, blacks, Hispanics, and other underrepresented groups by at least 14% within five years. The company will invest in engineering scholarships, historically black colleges and universities, and efforts to bring more women into the games business. Intel's CEO, Brian Krzanich, says the plan is a "bold statement" and a step towards creating a more diverse industry. The move follows criticism from civil rights leaders and feminist critics, and is seen as a positive step towards addressing the lack of diversity in the tech industry.

site_title: Reit takeovers to climb in US with push from activist investors
summary: US real estate investment trusts (Reits) are expected to see an increase in takeovers due to growing shareholder activism and executives' receptiveness to deals. According to Green Street Advisors, the number of Reit transactions has declined 80% since 2000, but now "appear ripe" to end the drought. This surge in activism is likely to accelerate Reit takeovers, driven by activist investors pushing for deals. The report suggests conditions are favorable for a resurgence in Reit M&A activity.

site_title: Eurozone's December inflation turns negative
summary: The Eurozone's December inflation rate turned negative for the first time since 2009, with prices 0.2% lower than the previous year, driven by cheap oil. This may prompt the European Central Bank to start government bond-buying, or quantitative easing, to boost the economy and combat deflation. Economists expect the ECB to respond to the lurch into deflation, with some predicting a decision to launch a QE programme at the ECB's next meeting on January 22.

site_title: Subhas Anandan had 'a heart of gold beneath tough exterior'
summary: Subhas Anandan, a prominent Singaporean lawyer, has died at 67 due to heart failure. The 67-year-old lawyer, known for his tough exterior and "heart of gold," was a respected figure in the legal fraternity for his pro bono work and dedication to access to fair representation for accused persons. Tributes poured in from the legal community, with friends and colleagues praising his compassion, selflessness, and commitment to justice. Anandan's legacy includes establishing Singapore's first criminal legal aid scheme and launching the Yellow Ribbon Fund Subhas Anandan Star Bursary Award.

site_title: EU Parliament head berates "irresponsible" Merkel over Greek plight
summary: German EU Parliament President Martin Schulz accused Chancellor Angela Merkel of "irresponsible speculation" over Greece potentially exiting the eurozone if a far-left party wins elections. Merkel has been cited as prepared to let Greece leave the eurozone if a government that jettisons austerity is elected, sparking concerns it could push voters into radical forces. The EU Commission has stayed out of the argument, while French Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron urged Berlin and the European Central Bank to focus on Greece's economic recovery.

site_title: DASH named best overall diet for 5th year
summary: The DASH diet, rich in vegetables, whole grains, and low-fat dairy, has been named the best overall diet for the fifth consecutive year by US News & World Report. It was also chosen as the top diabetes diet and best plan for healthy eating. Weight Watchers retained the No. 1 spot for weight loss, while the TLC diet came in second. A panel of health specialists rated 35 eating plans, considering sample menus, medical studies, and factors such as ease of following and overall health benefits.

images.alt_text: The DASH diet is rich in vegetables, whole grains and low-fat dairy, and was developed to lower blood pressure.

site_title: HK to up trading through Shanghai stock link
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange, HKEx, is expanding its trading link with the Shanghai exchange, allowing foreign investors to access more dynamic private companies. A separate link with the Shenzhen exchange is also in talks, offering foreign investors access to smaller companies in technology and healthcare. The Shanghai-Hong Kong connect has seen limited interest, with only 25% of the quota filled, but HKEx aims to test a new system in February and launch it in March, enabling fund managers to sell Shanghai-listed shares.

images.alt_text: A link with the Shenzhen exchange would allow foreign investors access to some of the nation's most dynamic private companies in the technology and health care industries.

site_title: Signs China may throw lifeline to Venezuela
summary: China and Venezuela announced plans to strengthen their economic cooperation, with China potentially providing a lifeline to Venezuela's struggling economy. The two leaders agreed to deepen cooperation in various sectors, including finance, amid Venezuela's recession due to falling oil prices. China, a major investor and oil customer, has extended $42 billion in loans to Venezuela and imports 640,000 barrels of oil daily. The deal aims to boost bilateral trade and oil purchases, with Venezuela seeking to increase oil sales to China.

site_title: European airlines 'cannot keep up': Qatar Airways chief
summary: Qatar Airways chief Akbar Al-Baker stated that European airlines "cannot keep up" with competition from Gulf carriers, citing his airline's rapid growth. Qatar Airways welcomed its first Airbus A350 plane, highlighting the Gulf carriers' leading position in the aviation industry. Al-Baker emphasized the growing concern for European airlines struggling to match the Gulf carriers' success.

site_title: China premier said to be planning Davos trip to assuage concern over slowing economy
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang is planning a trip to the Davos economic forum to reassure international decision-makers that the country's economy is open for business despite slowing growth. The visit aims to dispel concerns over China's openness and reform efforts, following criticism from foreign business groups. Li's trip comes as China accelerates infrastructure projects to boost growth, with plans to invest in 300 projects valued at $1.5 trillion. The visit is seen as a crucial move to show China's confidence in its "new normal" economy.

site_title: Grim new reality for once popular American TV genre
summary: Reality TV shows in the US are facing a grim new reality, with falling ratings and cancelled shows. Despite hits like Survivor and American Idol, the genre has struggled to find another hit ratings blockbuster since 2005. New shows, such as Utopia, have flopped, and others, like Duck Dynasty and Dating Naked, have been marred by scandals. Experts say the genre is stalled due to a lack of creativity and over-reliance on imported formats, and that it needs to adapt to changing audience needs and offer interactive experiences across platforms.

site_title: Budget deficit puts Modi's pledge in doubt
summary: India's budget deficit has reached 99% of the full-year target in just 8 months, raising doubts about Prime Minister Narendra Modi's pledge to narrow the gap to a 7-year low. The shortfall, 4.1% of GDP, would disappoint global investors who parked a record $26.4 billion in local debt in 2014. Fiscal indiscipline may hold up rate cuts by the Reserve Bank of India, which is pressuring the government to fix the economy.

site_title: STI up 16pts on likely Wall Street bounce
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rebounded 16.41 points to 3,298.36 on Wednesday, likely due to short-covering ahead of expected Wall Street gains. Hongkong Land contributed the most to the index's rise, with its shares jumping 4.8% to a 52-week high. Bank stocks, such as UOB and OCBC, also performed well, while DBS fell. Analysts expect modest growth in the banking sector in 2015, but warn of liquidity and customer leverage headwinds.

site_title: Asia's central banks behind rate-cutting curve
summary: Asian central banks are failing to address growing concerns about disinflation, with interest rates remaining stagnant despite a significant decline in 10-year sovereign bond yields. The region's monetary authorities are risking financial stability and GDP growth as investors push down interest rates, while short-term policy rates remain unchanged. The delay could be due to concerns about a repeat of the 2013 "taper scare," but experts warn that cheaper energy will not reignite growth and could instead lead to lower inflation expectations, worsening debt burdens in countries like China and Malaysia.

site_title: EU vows terror fight after Paris attack
summary: The European Union strongly condemned a deadly attack on Charlie Hebdo magazine in Paris, killing 12 people. EU President Donald Tusk expressed solidarity with France, vowing to fight terrorism and protect fundamental values, including freedom of expression. The EU stands "beside France after this appalling act," Tusk said, condemning the attack as "brutal" and "revolting."

site_title: Oil slump pushing industry into 'sharp recession'
summary: Oil prices plummeting to historic lows will force energy companies to slash capital spending globally by 10-15% in 2015, with North America seeing a 25-30% cut. The industry is contending with lower cashflow and reduced access to capital, particularly for independents. However, investment in Africa and the Middle East is expected to rise, driven by producers seeking to boost long-term output. The report warns of a "sharp recession" in the global oilfield, with US crude prices at $47.93, down from nearly $107 in June.

site_title: Vietnam devalues dong to boost exports as regional currencies fall
summary: Vietnam's State Bank of Vietnam devalued its currency, the dong, by 1% to 21,458 dong per dollar, in an effort to boost exports amid a decline in regional currencies. This move aims to support the country's economic growth, which expanded 5.98% last year, and maintain competitiveness against rivals. The devaluation is seen as a necessary step to address pressure on the currency, with the central bank likely to allow it to fluctuate within a 1% range.

site_title: Surprise rise in Malaysia's Nov exports; trade surplus at 3-year high
summary: Malaysia's exports rose unexpectedly in November, defying the impact of tumbling world oil prices. This surge in exports helped the country achieve a trade surplus at a 3-year high. Despite the positive economic data, concerns remain about the government's budget deficit target and the potential impact on its sovereign ratings. The country is grappling with slowing growth in Europe and China, adding to pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: ANZ said the trade balance could potentially be Malaysia's "Achilles' heel" in 2015, despite an encouraging November print.

site_title: Working hard, but working poor, in developing countries
summary: The percentage of people living in extreme poverty in developing countries has decreased from 52% in 1980 to 22% today, with China experiencing a 500 million drop in poverty. Despite this progress, many in the developing world struggle with low-paying, self-employment jobs due to a lack of social welfare systems. This leads to lower unemployment rates, with over 150 million people in developing countries being employed, compared to 4 in 5 unemployed workers globally. Creating better jobs, rather than just more, is key to addressing poverty in the developing world.

site_title: Washington's big opportunity on securing historic trade deals in 2015
summary: In 2015, the US was poised to secure historic trade deals, with President Obama committed to concluding the Trans Pacific Partnership (TPP) with 12 Pacific nations and the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) with the European Union. Republicans were set to take control of Congress, promising to enact free trade legislation, including the TPP and TTIP. This alignment of political forces suggested a promising year for liberalizing global trade.

site_title: Singapore's tax system toughens up
summary: Singapore has strengthened its tax system to align with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's (OECD) Action Plan on Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS). The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) is now conducting tougher tax audits, requiring more substance in transfer pricing and Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) claims. The government is also increasing scrutiny of tax incentives, with companies needing to demonstrate higher headcounts and business spending in Singapore. Additionally, the IRAS has introduced new transfer pricing guidelines requiring contemporaneous documentation, although it has not adopted the OECD's "country-by-country reporting" (CBCR) template.

site_title: Tail of aircraft found underwater, black box may be close by
summary: Indonesia's search and rescue agency found the tail of the crashed AirAsia jet, Flight QZ8501, underwater about 30km from the plane's last-known location. The tail is upturned, indicating the crucial black box recorders may be nearby. The jet vanished on Dec 28, killing all 162 people on board, and has been the subject of a search operation.

site_title: Boeing beats Airbus on deliveries but loses out on new orders: source
summary: Boeing delivered 723 jetliners in 2014, setting an industry record and retaining its title as the world's biggest plane maker. However, the company lost out to Airbus on new orders, despite booking 1,550 gross and 1,432 net orders worth $232.7 billion. Boeing's deliveries exceeded its forecast, with 45 more 737s and one more 777 than in 2013. The performance supports profit estimates above consensus.

site_title: At least 12 dead in Paris after attack on satirical newspaper
summary: At least 12 people, including two police officers, were killed in a militant attack on the Paris offices of satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, which has been known to lampoon radical Islam. The attack, claimed by no group, occurred after hooded gunmen stormed the building, firing multiple shots. The incident raises concerns about rising xenophobia in Europe and has led to increased security measures across France. The French government has raised its security level to the highest notch and scheduled an emergency cabinet meeting.

site_title: Coming: budget of celebration and challenges
summary: Singapore's government is expected to deliver an expansionary budget on February 23, 2015, to celebrate the country's 50th anniversary of independence. The budget is seen as a pre-election budget, with economists predicting a generous allocation of funds to the middle class and incentives to drive productivity. The budget will also address social challenges, including the rapidly ageing population, with initiatives such as the Silver Support Scheme and a review of the Central Provident Fund system. The government is also expected to focus on economic restructuring and productivity growth, with a shift towards targeted measures to boost industry-specific growth and enhance the top line of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

site_title: US private-sector hiring slows
summary: US private-sector hiring picked up pace in December, adding 241,000 jobs, exceeding analysts' expectations. The gains were spread across various companies, with small businesses leading the way. The strong hiring news is seen as a positive sign for economic growth, with analysts expecting the government to report 245,000 jobs added in December and an unemployment rate of 5.7%. This news provides relief ahead of Friday's official jobs report, which is expected to confirm these numbers.

site_title: Qatar Airways to cut surcharge following oil price drop
summary: Qatar Airways will cut its fuel surcharge following a decline in crude oil prices, according to the airline's CEO Akbar Al Baker. The fuel surcharge reduction will not impact ticket fares, but the airline expects to return to profitability. This move follows similar actions by airlines in China and a call from the British government to pass on fuel price benefits to consumers. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) predicts a record-breaking profit margin for airlines in 2015 due to falling fuel prices and stronger economic growth.

site_title: Obama condemns 'horrific' attack on French newspaper
summary: US President Barack Obama condemned the attack on the Charlie Hebdo newspaper in Paris, calling it a "terrorist attack" that left 12 dead. The attack, which targeted the weekly's offices, was sparked by the publication of satirical cartoons of the prophet Mohammed. Obama pledged US assistance and praised France as "America's oldest ally" in the fight against terrorism. He also honored the victims and their families, stating that France's commitment to universal values would endure. The US president expressed his support for the French people during a difficult time.

site_title: Battleground Europe looms
summary: Greece is set to hold an election on January 25, which may lead to the country's first national government fully opposed to the eurozone's austerity politics. The election follows Greece's left-wing Syriza party's refusal to vote for the coalition's presidential candidate, triggering the election. This month's polls across Europe will decide whether voters endorse existing governments, be tempted by populist anti-EU parties, or abstain. Elections in Finland, Spain, Poland, Denmark, and Britain will also take place, testing the evolving European political system, which may shift towards a hybrid model with populist identity parties and liberal parties.

site_title: Financials shine in 2014; outlook positive this year
summary: Singapore's financial sector outperformed the broader market in 2014, with the FTSE ST Financials Index rising 10.3% in price gains, compared to the 6.2% rise in the Straits Times Index. The three local banks added S$22 billion in value to the market. Despite recent bank stock sell-offs, analysts remain optimistic for the sector this year, driven by US rate hikes benefiting banks. However, Reits are expected to diverge in performance, with a rise in interest rates potentially causing negative growth in distribution per unit.

site_title: Swiss citizens come clean on undeclared funds following probes
summary: Swiss citizens have been coming forward with undeclared funds following international pressure, particularly from US investigations into Swiss banks' role in hiding American assets. Since a 2010 amnesty, 15,039 Swiss residents have filed voluntary disclosures, with a significant jump in 2014 to 1,500 last year, resulting in 1.06 billion Swiss francs (US$1.04 billion) in lost taxes. The increased transparency is attributed to public debate and planned changes in law, as Switzerland prepares to share tax information with foreign governments.

site_title: EU hopes for 'skeleton' of US trade deal by year-end
summary: The EU hopes to have the "skeleton" of a massive trade deal with the US by the end of 2015, with talks on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Pact (TTIP) underway for 19 months. EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstroem stated that both Democrats and Republicans in the US Congress are willing to work together for a deal, despite being divided on other issues. The European Commission has released more documents on the trade pact, which has drawn criticism from labour unions and activists, particularly over the investor-state dispute settlement clause.

site_title: Arab League and top Muslim body condemn Paris attack
summary: The Arab League and Al-Azhar, a Sunni Islam's prestigious centre of learning, have condemned the deadly attack on Charlie Hebdo newspaper in Paris, killing at least 12 people. The attackers chanted "Allahu Akbar" and targeted the newspaper for publishing cartoons of the prophet Mohamed. Al-Azhar stated that "Islam denounces any violence" and emphasized that using violence is not acceptable, even in response to an offense against Muslim sentiments. The condemnation highlights a rare show of unity among Muslim leaders against terrorism.

site_title: Spain shows signs of being on the mend
summary: Spain's economy shows signs of recovery after six years of financial crisis, with fewer jobless people, rising consumer spending, and increased lending. The number of unemployed individuals decreased by 253,627 to 4.45 million in 2014, and consumer spending rose. Retail sales posted a 1.9% increase, and new car sales jumped 18%. The government's tax reform may also boost the economy, reducing the tax bill of the lowest-income groups. Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy's government estimates the economy will expand by 1.3% in 2014 and 2.0% in 2015.

site_title: Cold-blooded killers sow terror in Paris street
summary: A mass shooting occurred in Paris, France, on January 7, 2015, when masked gunmen stormed the offices of Charlie Hebdo magazine, killing 12 people, including the editor-in-chief and four cartoonists. The attackers also shot and killed a police officer, shouting "we have avenged the prophet" and "Allahu akbar." The attack sent panic through the streets, with witnesses describing "rivers of blood" and "bodies on the ground." The incident sparked widespread shock and outrage, with many calling for solidarity against terrorism.

site_title: US crude oil exports in November reach record high: US Census
summary: US crude oil exports reached a record high of 501,766 barrels per day in November, surpassing the previous record from 1957. Most of the exports (455,000 bpd) went to Canada, with increases in exports to China (9,600 bpd) and Switzerland (12,700 bpd). The record high is attributed to a 126,000 bpd increase from the previous month, with exports to Canada largely allowed under US law.

site_title: Attacked French weekly often lambasted religion, especially Islam
summary: Charlie Hebdo, a French satirical newspaper, was attacked, killing at least 12 people, in retaliation for its criticism of Islam and other religions. The weekly had a history of publishing cartoons and caricatures that mocked Muslims, including the Danish cartoons of Mohammad in 2005. Despite court cases and threats, Charlie Hebdo defended its right to free speech, citing France's separation of church and state. The attack is seen as a form of terrorism, with police suspecting Muslim extremists.

site_title: US mortgage applications rise in latest week: MBA
summary: US mortgage applications increased 11.1% in the latest week, driven by dipping interest rates, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. Refinancing applications rose 16.0% and home purchase demand rose 4.5%. The increase is seen as a positive sign for the housing market, with the data suggesting a potential boost to home sales.

site_title: IATA says expects air freight markets to expand 4.5% in 2015
summary: IATA expects global air freight to expand 4.5% in 2015, driven by growth in cross-border trade, particularly in Asia-Pacific and Middle East regions. Demand rose 4.2% in November, with European airlines seeing a 0.9% increase, largely due to the Eurozone economy and sanctions concerns.

site_title: France's Muslim leaders denounce 'barbaric' attack
summary: France's Muslim leaders have condemned a "barbaric" attack on a satirical weekly that left 12 people dead, calling it an assault on press freedom and democracy. The attack, carried out by two or three heavily armed gunmen, was motivated by the publication of cartoons of the Prophet Mohammed. The French Muslim Council and the Union of French Islamic Organisations have urged calm and warned against extremist manipulation. The Great Rabbi of France has also called for national unity to defend freedoms, including freedom of expression.

images.alt_text: France's Muslim leadership sharply condemned the shooting at a Paris satirical weekly that left at least 12 people dead as a "barbaric" attack and an assault on press freedom and democracy.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower, closing at 1,709.18 after a 7.4-point drop. Trading volume reached 1.61 billion lots valued at RM2.04 billion, with 413 gains and 352 losses.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end higher
summary: Singapore shares ended higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 16.41 points to 3,298.36. Traders brushed off new Trump threats, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records. The STI also rose 0.4% on Thursday, with investors staying positive despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Japan government sees economic recovery in FY15/16 after contraction: sources
summary: Japan's government projects a 1.5% real economic growth for the next fiscal year, following its first contraction since the global financial crisis. The economy is expected to recover due to falling oil prices. The government also forecasts nominal growth of 2.7% and tax revenues of 54.5 trillion yen (US$457.45 billion), a 24-year high. The projection is in line with the Bank of Japan's estimate and marks a shift from the previous forecast of 1.4% growth. The economic policies will be based on this projection, which will be decided on January 14.

site_title: China regulators likely to allow a wave of share offerings in 2015
summary: China regulators are likely to allow a surge in share offerings in 2015, with proceeds potentially doubling to $20 billion, as the market's recent rally reduces concerns about increased supply spooking investors. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has approved listings by 20 firms, more than twice the average monthly average last year. Analysts believe the move aims to balance the market and prevent a crash, with the regulator seeking to "suck up some of the liquidity" from new IPOs.

site_title: Oil creeps back above US$50 as investors consolidate
summary: Brent crude oil prices rose to above US$50 a barrel, rebounding from a 25-cent decline. The price drop was attributed to a supply glut and weak global demand. Analysts expect the price to consolidate around US$50 as investors reassess their positions. This marks the first time the price has fallen below US$50 since May 2009.

site_title: Deaths, costs from global disasters fell in 2014: Munich Re
summary: Munich Re reported a decline in global disaster deaths and costs in 2014, with 7,700 fatalities and US$110 billion in losses. Insurance coverage accounted for 28% of total losses, with Cyclone Hudhud in India causing US$7 billion in damage. The company notes that despite improved early warning systems, the risk situation remains unchanged, and insurance could play a greater role in supporting economic recovery, particularly in emerging markets.

site_title: Emerging currencies face bumpy year but much already priced in
summary: Emerging market currencies are expected to face a bumpy year in 2015, with all major currencies except the Mexican peso forecast to drop further. The Brazilian real, Turkish lira, and South African rand are expected to slide 1-5% through 2015, while the Russian rouble is expected to strengthen or fall 30%. Tighter monetary policy in the US, falling commodity prices, and weaker Chinese growth are major factors contributing to the expected decline. However, some analysts believe that emerging market currencies may regain ground later in the year if the Fed tightens monetary policy too slowly.

site_title: Oil price to fall until major Asian manufacturers feel the benefit
summary: Oil prices are expected to continue falling due to weak demand and a strong US dollar, with markets only expected to rebound once major Asian manufacturers feel the economic benefits of cheaper energy. Since last June, oil prices have halved to near 6-year lows, and analysts predict further declines before a rebound. Supply increases from US shale producers and Opec members, as well as slowing economies and improving energy efficiency, are contributing to the downward pressure on prices.

site_title: Bond listings on SGX hit record highs in 2014
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) saw a record high in bond listings and proceeds in 2014, with 521 bonds listed and S$213 billion raised. This was largely driven by the low interest rate environment and the search for yield, compared to 465 bonds listed and S$176 billion raised in 2013.

images.alt_text: The total number of new bond listings, as well as proceeds raised, hit new highs on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in 2014.

site_title: Palm hits highest in over 2 months on weak ringgit, flood worries
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures reached their highest in over two months due to the weakening of the ringgit against the US dollar and concerns about monsoon flooding that may impact supplies. The ringgit dropped 0.8% to its weakest in 5.5 years, making palm oil cheaper for foreign investors. Traders expect a fresh wave of monsoon flooding to squeeze supplies, boosting palm oil prices. A trader noted that the weak ringgit could attract key buyers such as China, adding to the upward pressure on palm oil prices.

site_title: VW's Bentley posts 2014 record sales on China rebound
summary: Bentley Motors, a Volkswagen-owned luxury car brand, posted a record 11,020 sales in 2014, a 9% increase from the previous year. China, Bentley's second-largest market, saw a 22% surge in sales to 2,670 cars.
