The brand is diversifying its model line-up, planning to expand into luxury sport-utility vehicles in 2016, and aims to decide on a fifth model line by autumn. European deliveries rose 4% to 1,539 models, while American sales edged up 1.5% to 3,186 cars.

site_title: US trade deficit shrinks sharply in November
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed sharply in November to $39.0 billion, its smallest gap in nearly a year, as imports fell more than exports. The decline was driven by lower prices for crude oil and petroleum imports, with imports of petroleum products plummeting 11.8% to $23.1 billion. Exports of goods and services fell to $196.4 billion, while imports dropped to $235.4 billion. The trade deficit with China narrowed by 8.0% to $29.9 billion, and the overall US trade deficit rose $22.3 billion for the first 11 months of the year.

site_title: Land prices in China's capital hit record amid improved sales
summary: China's capital, Beijing, saw a record-breaking land sale of 8.63 billion yuan (US$1.39 billion) for a 155,675.9 square metre plot. The sale, which was 22% above the starting price, highlights strong demand for property in big cities despite a cooling market. This contrasts with the overall market, demonstrating resilient demand in China's major cities.

site_title: Eurozone's first fall in prices for five years raises deflation fears
summary: The Eurozone's consumer prices fell 0.2% in December, marking the first time in five years and entering negative territory, raising fears of deflation. The drop was attributed to plummeting oil prices, which also led to a 6.3% decrease in energy prices. This raises pressure on the European Central Bank to stimulate price rises and triggers concerns of a vicious spiral of delayed purchases, recession, and job losses. Unemployment remains at 11.5%, and the ECB's target of a near 2% increase in prices is still unmet.

site_title: Petronas may slash domestic investment 30% as crude slumps: sources
summary: Malaysia's state oil firm Petronas may slash domestic investment by 30% due to the slump in oil prices, which has hurt revenue. The decline in oil prices has made domestic projects unprofitable, with some potentially being shelved or cut. Petronas' capital expenditure could be cut by 15-20% this year, and operations abroad may also be impacted. The move comes as Petronas reported its worst quarterly profit in three years, with net profit falling to RM15.07 billion from RM17.2 billion a year ago.

site_title: Indonesia search chief says AirAsia jet tail now found
summary: Indonesian search and rescue teams have located the tail of the AirAsia passenger jet, which crashed into the Java Sea on December 28, killing all 162 people on board. The tail, containing the black box voice and flight data recorders, was found underwater in a second priority sector. The discovery brings the search closer to finding the rest of the aircraft.

site_title: Singapore firm launches mobile app for halal foodies
summary: A Singapore-based company launched the free "HalalTrip" app, allowing Muslim foodies and travelers to discover and share halal restaurants worldwide. The app features photos, comments, and social media sharing capabilities, with English and Arabic interfaces. HalalTrip aims to cater to the growing Muslim travel market, predicted to reach $192 billion by 2020. The app uses location-based features to display nearby halal restaurants, making it easier for users to find halal food options while traveling.

site_title: German jobless rate hits record low in December
summary: Germany's unemployment rate dropped to a record low of 6.5% in December, according to Labour Office data, with 2.841 million people out of work. This is the lowest level since German reunification in 1990. The rate fell 27,000 from November, beating the forecasted decrease of 6,000. The strong labor market suggests continued growth in Europe's largest economy at the start of 2015.

site_title: German retail sales rise in November: data
summary: German retail sales rose for the second consecutive month in November, increasing 1.0% from October. However, on a 12-month basis, sales decreased 0.8% compared to the same period last year, largely due to an extra shopping day in 2013. Over the 11-month period, retail sales rose 1.1% year-over-year, with the statistics office expecting a 1.1-1.3% increase for the full year.

site_title: AirAsia jet tail found underwater, black box may be close
summary: The tail of the crashed AirAsia jet has been found 30 km from the plane's last known location in the northern Java Sea. The crucial black box recorders may be nearby, as the cockpit voice and flight data recorders are located in the rear section of the Airbus A320-200. Indonesia's search and rescue agency is now desperately trying to locate the black box. The finding of the tail has been a priority due to its location, and the area where the plane was lost is known for intense seasonal storms.

site_title: China's Xiaomi tests selling phones in stores to pep up India sales
summary: Xiaomi, a Chinese smartphone maker, plans to sell its Redmi Note 4G handsets through Bharti Airtel Ltd stores in India. If successful, this will allow Xiaomi to sell more models in physical stores while maintaining its online-only strategy. This approach reduces marketing and distribution costs, enabling the sale of feature-rich phones at low prices. Xiaomi entered the Indian market through online retailer Flipkart.com in July 2014, using flash sales to limit availability and drive demand.

site_title: Barclays 'bad bank' chief Bommensath to quit at end-January
summary: Barclays' "bad bank" head Eric Bommensath will leave the bank at the end of January after 17 years. He was tasked with disposing of unwanted assets, primarily from the investment bank, to cut costs and improve returns for shareholders. The bank's bad bank, established in May, has already reduced its risk-weighted assets from 115 billion pounds to 81 billion pounds by the end of September. Two new co-heads, John Mahon and Harry Harrison, will take over the business.

site_title: Thai government expects to budget US$1.52b in 2015/16 to repay subsidy loans
summary: The Thai government plans to allocate US$1.52 billion from its 2015/16 budget to repay subsidy loans for rice and rubber farmers, totaling 50 billion baht. The move aims to avoid burdening a future administration, following a costly rice subsidy scheme under the previous government. The decision was made by Deputy Prime Minister Pridiyathorn Devakula, who proposed the allocation to repay debts arising from the subsidy schemes.

site_title: Monster sues Apple's Beats over headphone technology
summary: Monster LLC is suing Apple's Beats over claims of ripping off headphone technology ahead of its sale to Apple for over $3 billion. The lawsuit alleges Beats co-founders Jimmy Iovine and Dr Dre pirated Monster's "Beats By Dr Dre" headphone line and had "fraudulently acquired" the line in a sham transaction with HTC. Monster claims it lost millions, while Beats made millions. This is the second lawsuit against Beats, following a settlement with Bose over patented technology.

site_title: Vietnam devalues dong to boost growth
summary: Vietnam's central bank devalued the dong currency by 1% to 21,458 Vietnamese dong per dollar, aiming to boost exports and drive economic growth. The move is in line with market expectations of a weaker currency and follows a similar devaluation in June 2014. The new reference rate allows the currency to fluctuate between 21,243 and 21,673 dong, with economists predicting further devaluations in 2015. The move aims to control inflation and push up economic growth, with the government targeting 6.2% GDP growth this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks mixed by the close
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index closed in positive territory, rising 2.14 points to 16,885.33, after several days of losses. Sony surged 4.63% to 2,552.5 yen, driven by its best-grossing online film "The Interview" making over $31 million. The broader Topix index finished down 0.10%. The US service sector slowed in December, and investors are watching Greece's general election and potential exit from the currency bloc.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end 0.83% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.83% on Wednesday, driven by bargain-hunters, amid a recent sell-off fueled by tumbling oil prices and concerns about Greece. The Hang Seng Index rose 195.85 points to 23,681.26, while mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.67% to 3,373.95, its highest finish since August 2009.

site_title: Brent oil drops under US$50 for first time since 2009
summary: Brent oil has dropped under US$50 per barrel for the first time since 2009, according to London deals. The decline is attributed to Opec's production stance, oversupply, weak demand, and a strong dollar. Analysts predict further declines, potentially reaching US$40, driven by weak growth and demand in China and Europe. Opec's decision to maintain its oil output ceiling at 30 million barrels per day despite ample global supplies has exacerbated the supply glut, leading to a significant loss of over half its value since June.

site_title: Oil plunge a 'golden opportunity' for Asia economies
summary: Asia's oil-guzzling economies are expected to benefit from a global oil price plunge, with lower prices easing inflationary pressures and allowing central banks to implement interest rate cuts. Analysts say the opportunity should be seized to cut expensive energy subsidies, particularly fuel subsidies, which have sparked violent protests in the past. Countries such as Malaysia, Indonesia, and India have already made cuts to subsidies, while experts warn that failure to do so could lead to public resistance.

images.alt_text: The plunge in crude prices will give a much-needed boost to Asia's oil-guzzling economies and provides governments a "golden opportunity" to implement crucial structural reforms such as cutting expensive energy subsidies, analysts say.

site_title: Hershey appoints Steven Schiller regional president
summary: Hershey appoints Steven Schiller as regional president for Asia, Europe, Middle East, and Africa (AEMEA), effective January 1, 2015. Schiller, previously senior vice-president for Hershey's sweets & refreshment strategic business unit, aims to accelerate international growth to reach $10 billion in sales by 2017, focusing on Chinese, Mexican, and Brazilian markets. With over 19 years of experience in the region, Schiller will lead out of Hershey's regional headquarters in Singapore, building on the company's existing investments in Asia, including a research and development hub and a $250 million manufacturing plant.

site_title: Australia: Shares end down, pare losses as bargain hunters emerge
summary: Australian shares dropped 0.2% on Wednesday, closing at 5,353.6, despite recouping some morning losses as energy-related stocks continued to slide due to falling oil prices. Bargain hunters picked up banks and junior miners, stabilizing the market. The S&P/ASX 200 index barely moved in 2014 and has started the year on a tepid note.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.76 points to 1714.70. Losers outnumbered gainers 79 to 34, with a total of 21.07 million lots traded worth RM8.55 million.

site_title: Neil Young brings high-res music player to the masses
summary: Rock star Neil Young announced his high-resolution music player, Pono, to the public after delivering 20,000 devices to Kickstarter supporters. The Pono Player samples music at 96,000 times per second, offering a higher audio quality than most formats. Young aims to promote digital music's highest quality format, which is now available for purchase online and through 80 US retailers for $399, with downloads of two million songs available. The player was funded via Kickstarter, raising $6.5 million, and Young has no marketing plan or sales target.

site_title: COE premiums up across the board
summary: COE premiums rose across categories in Singapore's first bidding exercise for 2015, with Category A increasing by S$55,000 to S$66,010, and Category B rising by S$1,289 to S$75,289. Category E, the open category, rose by S$1,210 to S$75,200. Category C for goods vehicles increased by S$2,911 to S$55,011, and Category D for motorcycles rose by S$91 to S$4,403. These price hikes reflect a return to the showroom by buyers for the start of the new year.

site_title: China's Bank of Communications to cut top executives' pay: memo
summary: China's Bank of Communications plans to significantly cut the pay of its top executives and tie a larger portion of employees' pay to performance, according to an internal memo. The reforms aim to implement market-based mechanisms and address uneven pay structures. This move is part of Beijing's push for pay reforms at state-owned enterprises, which have faced criticism for inefficiency and lack of innovation. The bank will not cut the fixed portion of employees' pay, but rather make performance-based payments for living expenses.

site_title: Vietnam devalues dong to boost growth
summary: Vietnam's central bank devalued the dong currency by 1% to 21,458 Vietnamese dong per dollar, aiming to control inflation and boost economic growth. This is the second devaluation in eight months, following the State Bank of Vietnam's decision to lower the reference rate. The move is intended to create stability in the forex market.

site_title: SGX queries JES on unusual trading activity
summary: The Singapore Exchange has queried JES International Holdings, a Chinese shipbuilder, due to unusual trading activity that saw 107.861 million shares switch hands, resulting in a 17.65% increase in its share price. The company's share price jumped 0.06 cents to S$0.04. The exchange is investigating the unusual trading.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices in Nov hit record high for 7th straight month
summary: Hong Kong's home prices reached a record high for the seventh consecutive month in November, with a 3.7% month-on-month increase, according to official data. This follows a 12% rise in home prices for the first 11 months of 2014. Developers are offering discounts to attract buyers, with some units sold at 10.5% discounts. Analysts expect pent-up demand to continue boosting sales in 2015, with home prices forecast to edge up 3-5%.

site_title: 2015 Singapore Budget statement to be delivered on Feb 23
summary: The 2015 Singapore Budget statement, set to be delivered by Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam on February 23, will be broadcast live on television and radio, as well as a webcast on the Singapore Budget website. The statement will also be uploaded to the website after delivery.

site_title: UPDATE: Veteran criminal lawyer Subhas Anandan dies
summary: Veteran Singaporean lawyer Subhas Anandan, 67, died Wednesday from heart failure while undergoing dialysis at Singapore General Hospital. The family expressed gratitude for condolences and asked to grieve privately. The cause of his death is unrelated to his professional life.

site_title: Asian stocks edge up, Greek woes weigh on euro
summary: Asian stocks experienced a mild recovery on Wednesday, driven by gains in Tokyo and Shanghai, but were weighed down by concerns over Greek political turmoil and low oil prices. The euro fell, while US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. Investors await the release of US Federal Reserve minutes and jobs data on Friday.

site_title: Seoul: Shares edge up as battered firms get some respite; won down
summary: South Korean shares edged up 0.07% on Wednesday, rebounding from a 0.3% deficit in early trade, as investors sought bargain hunting opportunities in battered stocks. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed at 1,883.83 points. The won, however, edged lower at 1,099.9 to the dollar amid concerns about backing the currency amid global risk aversion. The move reverses a 1% gain in the previous session, which was the market's biggest one-day slump in a year.

site_title: Veteran criminal lawyer Subhas Anandan dies
summary: Veteran Singaporean lawyer Subhas Anandan, 67, died Wednesday at the Singapore General Hospital while undergoing dialysis. He had long-standing heart and kidney ailments and was president of the Association of Criminal Lawyers of Singapore. Anandan handled high-profile cases, including those of convicted murderers. His death comes as a loss to the legal community, known for his compassion.

images.alt_text: Subhas Anandan, one of Singapore's leading criminal lawyers, died in the late morning on Wednesday at the age of 67.

site_title: Korean Air chairman's daughter charged over nut case outburst
summary: South Korean prosecutors charged Heather Cho, daughter of Korean Air Lines chairman, for delaying a flight after she became enraged over being served nuts in a bag instead of on a dish. Cho, a former airline executive, had demanded the chief steward be removed from the flight, which arrived 11 minutes late. The incident, dubbed "nut rage," has sparked public outrage and ridicule, aggravating resentment towards South Korea's powerful family-run conglomerates. Cho faces charges of violating aviation security law and obstructing a government investigation.

site_title: Hong Kong stock exchange seek to reassure investors over Shanghai trading link
summary: The Hong Kong stock exchange has denied claims that its Shanghai trading link is being hindered by overseas regulatory hurdles, amid growing investor protection concerns. The exchange stated that it has worked with overseas investors and regulators to address concerns, with relevant regulators gaining a clearer understanding of the link. However, technical and legal issues, including settlement rules and shareholder rights, remain unresolved, affecting US and EU-regulated funds. The exchange aims to reassure investors and promote trading volumes, despite the challenges.

site_title: Malaysia Nov exports beat expectations, trade surplus highest since Nov 2011
summary: Malaysia's exports in November rose 2.1% from a year earlier, exceeding expectations, driven by electrical and electronic products. The trade surplus expanded to 11.13 billion ringgit (US$3.12 billion), the highest since November 2011. Imports were flat, lower than the expected 8.2% rise. The November forecast had been 4.9 billion ringgit, with October's trade surplus at 1.2 billion ringgit. This positive trade data suggests a strong economic performance for Malaysia.

site_title: Drones swoop into electronics show as interest surges
summary: Drones made their debut at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, with over a dozen companies showcasing various models for extreme sports, filmmaking, and industrial applications. Companies like AirDog, Hexo+, and Nixie are offering drones that can be pre-programmed to follow and film individuals or objects, while others, such as Byrobot and Torquino Group, are focusing on aerial combat and nano-drones. The market for consumer drones is expected to reach $1 billion in revenue within five years, with unit sales predicted to reach 400,000 in 2015.

site_title: Spanish economy shows signs of getting back on track
summary: Spain's economy appears to be recovering from a six-year financial crisis, with 253,627 fewer people registered as unemployed in 2014, bringing the total to 4.45 million. Consumer spending increased and banks boosted lending, leading to a rise in sales and new car sales. The government estimates the economy will expand by 1.3% in 2014 and 2.0% in 2015. Foreign investors also returned to Spain, with $55 billion invested in the country last year.

site_title: Euro struggles in Asia on Greek eurozone exit fears
summary: The euro strengthened against the dollar in Asia, rising to 141.27 yen after falling to a nine-year low, amid fears of a Greek eurozone exit. Despite the euro's recovery, it remains under pressure due to concerns about Greece's economic situation. The eurozone's instability has led to increased uncertainty, affecting global markets.

site_title: UK banks said please block dividends under 2008 bailouts: BoE
summary: UK banks, including Royal Bank of Scotland and Lloyds Banking Group, were told to block paying dividends if they received a bailout from the government in 2008, according to Bank of England meeting minutes. The banks were recapitalised in October 2008 and were left part-owned by the government. Lloyds plans to resume dividend payments next month, while RBS is not expected to start until 2016. The Bank of England will need to approve their plans, and the minutes suggest a collective approach to changing bank compensation culture would be more effective.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.38% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.38% on Wednesday, following a global sell-off due to tumbling oil prices and a Greek political crisis. The Hang Seng Index dropped 88.71 points to 23,396.70.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corporation's wholly-owned subsidiary, Keppel Singmarine, has clinched two contracts worth over S$65 million.

site_title: Hot stock: QT Vascular inches up on positive enrolment of clinical trials
summary: QT Vascular's shares rose 1.56% after exceeding clinical trial enrolment milestones in the fourth quarter of 2014, with nearly double the 30 patient target for its Chocolate Touch drug-coated peripheral balloon. The balloon is designed for treating peripheral arterial disease and is expected to receive regulatory approval in Europe by the second half of this year. QT also plans to commercialize the product late this year, with CEO Eitan Konstantino stating the company aims to capitalize on the product's success.

site_title: Nissan says 2014 China sales up 0.5%
summary: Nissan Motor Co reported a 0.5% increase in 2014 China sales, with 1.22 million vehicles sold, compared to 1.215 million the previous year. However, December sales declined 9.1% to 121,900 vehicles, marking the sixth straight month of decline in China. The slowing Chinese economy and political tensions between Beijing and Tokyo have affected Japanese carmakers in the country, with the auto market's growth rate halving to around 7% in 2014.

site_title: Oil prices remain weak on supply glut, low Asian and European growth
summary: Oil prices remain near five-and-a-half year lows at $50.95 a barrel, down 15 cents from their last close, due to a supply glut and low demand in Europe and Asia. The glut is attributed to high output from North American shale producers and Opec's resistance to cut production. Analysts predict further falls, with some forecasting a potential drop to $41.99 a barrel, before a possible price recovery.

images.alt_text: Oil prices remained near five-and-a-half year lows in early Asian trading on Wednesday after prices saw yet more heavy falls in the previous session, and analysts said a supply glut meant that more falls were likely before a rebound.

site_title: Hong Kong takes next step on political reform
summary: Hong Kong is set to unveil new proposals for the city's next leader, following a two-month period of mass protests over the right to fully free elections. China has pledged that voters in Hong Kong can elect the city's chief executive in 2017, marking a first for a public vote. The move comes after pro-democracy campaigners failed to win concessions, but tensions remain high. The proposals are expected to be released on Wednesday, as the city takes the next step in its contentious political reform process.

site_title: Seoul: Shares drift after worst fall in a year; won lower
summary: South Korean shares fell near 16-month lows on Wednesday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) down 0.01% at 1,882.21 points. The main bourse had its biggest one-day fall in a year due to global risk aversion and oil price concerns. Key losers included Korean Air, which plummeted 10% after announcing new shares, and bank shares such as Shinhan Financial Group and Industrial Bank of Korea. However, commodity-linked assets edged higher, and LG Display rallied 3% after analysts predicted a rosy first quarter outlook.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 0.16 to 3,281.79. Volume reached 66.4 million shares worth S$84.9 million. Despite a 5-day rally, investors remain cautious ahead of GDP data and the US-EU trade talks. In other news, Airalo raised US$220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion, and the US stock market edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: EU parliament head berates "irresponsible" Merkel over Greek plight
summary: EU parliament president Martin Schulz criticized German Chancellor Angela Merkel for "irresponsible speculation" about Greece potentially exiting the eurozone if the far-left wins elections. Merkel's comments sparked concerns that they could influence voter decisions. The EU Commission has stayed out of the argument, while French Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron urged Berlin and the European Central Bank to work towards Greece's economic recovery.

site_title: UN aviation body to propose 15-minute flight tracking standard
summary: The United Nations' International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) is set to propose a 15-minute flight tracking standard for commercial aircraft, following the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370. The proposal aims to improve tracking and pinpointing aircraft routes. ICAO members will discuss the proposal at a safety conference in Montreal next month, with the goal of implementing the standard in the near term. Airlines already use satellite systems for tracking, but gaps in coverage along polar routes may require alternative methods, such as voice communication.

site_title: US Embassy in Nicaragua voices concerns over Chinese-led canal
summary: The US Embassy in Nicaragua expressed concerns over the planned $50 billion, Chinese-led canal that would bisect the country. The embassy called for transparency and disclosure of project details, including environment studies and tenders. The project, which began in December 2014, has been met with widespread skepticism due to a lack of information from its Hong Kong-based developer. The embassy's concerns come as clashes between police and protesters opposed to the construction of the canal resulted in at least 21 injuries. The project's Chinese involvement poses a challenge to the Panama Canal and gives China a foothold in Central America.

site_title: Retail banks' IT investments to focus on revenue growth: survey
summary: Retail banks' IT investments this year will focus on revenue growth, with 43% of senior IT executives citing it as a top priority. Mobile and online banking will see the greatest spending, with 52% and 51% of banks respectively increasing their budgets. Improving internal business processes and enhancing platform functionality will also be key, with 38% and 53% of banks highlighting these as priorities, respectively. The trend of "consumerisation" in retail banking is driving these investments, with users expecting a rich, interactive experience from their banking platform.

images.alt_text: Retail banks' IT investments this year will be focused on fuelling revenue growth, technology research and advisory firm Ovum said on Wednesday.

site_title: Google domain grows as Android takes root in TVs
summary: Google-backed Android software is expanding to smart televisions, with major manufacturers such as Sony announcing their 2015 models will run on the Android TV platform. This marks a significant growth in Google's domain, following the success of Android in the smartphone market. The move is seen as a strategic expansion for Google, allowing the company to further integrate its ecosystem and increase its presence in the consumer electronics market.

site_title: Nissan targets growth in Brazil despite sales slump
summary: Nissan plans to maintain its investment in the Brazilian auto market despite a 7.15% drop in car sales in 2014. CEO Carlos Ghosn expressed disappointment but confidence in Brazil's potential, stating the firm will continue to invest. Nissan aims to increase its share in the market, despite the sales slump.

site_title: Morgan Stanley hires 8 brokers who managed US$6.5b at Merrill
summary: Morgan Stanley has hired eight high-net-worth brokers from Bank of America Merrill Lynch's Private Banking and Investment Group, managing a combined $6.5 billion in client assets. The group, led by Linda Stephans, Kristina Van Liew, and Erik Oiler, joined Morgan Stanley's Graystone Consulting unit in Chicago, focusing on institutional clients. The move follows a significant start to the year for the elite team, who will continue to work with ultra-high net worth individuals and institutional clients.

site_title: Snow snarls traffic in Washington; US Midwest braces for more cold
summary: Heavy snowfall in the US, particularly in Washington and the Midwest, caused significant disruptions on Tuesday. Up to 5 inches of snow was reported in the Washington area, leading to hundreds of car crashes, flight delays, and school closures. The Midwest braced for another round of harsh winter conditions, with temperatures expected to drop 25-30 degrees below average on Wednesday. Several schools in the region canceled classes, and law enforcement agencies warned residents to prepare for bitter cold. The coldest day of the week is expected to be Thursday, with lake-effect snow showers forecast for the Great Lakes region.

site_title: China expands Central America footprint with Costa Rica pact
summary: China has signed a partnership agreement with Costa Rica, aiming to create a "Special Economic Zone" for Chinese companies, potentially leading to the production of cars and solar panels. The agreement follows another Chinese-led project in Nicaragua, a proposed $50 billion waterway rivaling the Panama Canal. The feasibility study for the zone will be completed by October 2015, solidifying China's expanding influence in Central America.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.44% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.44% lower on January 7, 2015, amid concerns over Greece's eurozone exit and European deflation. The euro hit a nine-year low against the dollar, and oil prices plummeted to a fresh multi-year low. Experts expect Tokyo stocks to remain pressured, but buying by the Bank of Japan and the governmental pension fund may limit drops. The US economy's service sector slowed in December, contributing to a decline in the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Xpress, Keppel, Global Logistic Properties
summary: Keppel Corporation's wholly-owned subsidiary, Keppel Singmarine, secured two contracts worth over S$65 million. Xpress Holdings raised up to S$23 million through a placement agreement with Chinese investor Ma Wei Dong. Global Logistic Properties signed new leasing agreements with six third-party logistics providers in China, totaling 84,000 square meters. These announcements may impact trading activity.

site_title: As Myanmar opens up, miners weigh potential versus risk
summary: Myanmar is poised to experience a mining boom as it opens up its economy, with abundant mineral wealth including jade, rubies, copper, and coal. Despite 49 years of military rule, the quasi-civilian government has encouraged foreign investment, with 69 foreign firms registering to work in the mining sector. However, security and regulatory risks remain, and only 11 firms are currently operating. The country's lack of transparency and regulatory framework is deterring big firms, and commodity price fluctuations may also impact investment.

site_title: Motor racing: Korean Grand Prix dropped from F1 calendar
summary: The 2015 Korean Formula One Grand Prix has been formally dropped from the calendar due to its non-viability. The decision was made after the local South Korean promoters expressed no desire to hold the May 3 race, despite a contract obligation. The revised 20-race calendar, starting in Australia on March 15, leaves a three-week gap between Bahrain and Spain. The decision was also influenced by the teams' ability to have five engines per car, but this stipulation is no longer necessary. The move comes after a decision to allow limited in-season development for existing engine manufacturers.

site_title: Sony's 'The Interview' earns US$31m online, US$5m at theatres
summary: Sony's film "The Interview" generated $31m online and $5m at theatres following a cyber attack in November, despite the US government blaming North Korea for the attack. CEO Kazuo Hirai said the attack won't have a significant financial impact. The film, which was released two weeks after the attack, has earned a total of $36 million. Hirai stated that he had signed off on all major decisions in response to the attack.

site_title: Nasa closer than ever to finding Earth's 'twin'
summary: NASA is closer to finding Earth's "twin" with the discovery of eight new planets in habitable zones of their stars. Two of the planets, the most Earth-like found outside our solar system, are likely to have hard, rocky surfaces and an orbiting distance suitable for water and possibly life to exist. These findings were announced at the American Astronomical Society meeting in Seattle, Washington.

site_title: McDonald's Japan to brief on chicken nugget woes on Wednesday: NHK
summary: McDonald's Japan is holding a news conference on Wednesday to address concerns over a vinyl piece found in a Chicken McNugget sold in Aomori, northern Japan. The company halted sales of nuggets made at a Thai plant on the day of production. This comes after a food safety scandal at a Chinese supplier last summer, when McDonald's Japan switched to sourcing nuggets from three Thai plants. The incident follows a previous issue with vinyl found in nuggets sold in Japan in 2014.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz says will move US headquarters to Atlanta
summary: Mercedes-Benz will relocate its US headquarters from northern New Jersey to Atlanta, Georgia, affecting approximately 1,000 employees. The move aims to reduce costs, including living expenses and taxes, by being closer to its assembly plant in Tuscaloosa, Alabama, and port in Brunswick, Georgia. The company cited a need for sustained, profitable growth and efficiencies for the future, stating that the new location will "better serve its growing customer base and strengthen the company's position for long-term, sustainable growth."

site_title: UK new car sales highest in 10 years in 2014
summary: British new car registrations reached their highest point since 2004 in 2014, with sales expected to remain strong in 2015. The industry's chief executive, Mike Hawes, attributed the surge to Britain's economic recovery and low interest rates, which facilitated financing deals. However, production was disappointing due to weak exports to the euro zone and Russia. Hawes predicted a small increase in sales in 2015, despite a potential increase in taxes for motorists as the next government focuses on Europe's largest budget deficit.

images.alt_text: British new car registrations last year reached their highest point since 2004 and the outlook for 2015 is for a similar level of sales, the head of an industry body said on Tuesday.

site_title: Shell to pay out US$83m to settle Nigeria oil spill claims
summary: Royal Dutch Shell will pay US$83.4 million in compensation for two oil spills in Nigeria in 2008, the largest out-of-court settlement for oil spills in the country. The payment will be split between 15,600 individuals and a trust fund for projects, with each individual receiving approximately US$3,249. Shell accepted responsibility for the spills, caused by corrosion, and has agreed to a major remediation operation.

site_title: UK shop prices fall less sharply in December: BRC
summary: UK shop prices fell 1.7% in December compared to the previous year, a slower pace than the 1.9% decline in November, the British Retail Consortium reported. This marks the first time food prices have increased since November. The slower price drop is attributed to plummeting inflation, boosting consumer spending power. Retailers are expected to remain cautious about price increases, leading to deflation for at least the first part of 2015.

site_title: US anger at raising of Taiwan flag in Washington
summary: The US government has expressed disappointment and frustration over the raising of Taiwan's flag at the US-Taiwan relations compound in Washington, which it claims violates a long-standing pact. The US has maintained a one-China policy and does not have full diplomatic relations with Taiwan. The flag-raising ceremony, which has not occurred in 36 years, was done without prior US notification. US officials are discussing the issue with Taiwanese counterparts, emphasizing the distinction between cultural and diplomatic relations.

site_title: John Boehner re-elected US House speaker
summary: US House Speaker John Boehner was re-elected with 216 votes, defeating Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi's 164 votes. Despite 25 Republicans voting against him, Boehner won the majority. This outcome was seen as expected, as Boehner had a strong majority among Republicans.

site_title: California leaders set sights on high-speed rail construction
summary: California's business leaders broke ground on the country's largest high-speed rail project, aiming to transport passengers between Los Angeles and San Francisco in under three hours. The $68 billion project, initially approved in 2008, is expected to be completed in 2029 and connect 800 miles of California, reducing travel time in half. Despite environmental lawsuits and land disputes, construction began last year near Fresno, where it's creating jobs and revitalizing the local economy, with the US EPA touting it as a step towards reducing petroleum use and cleaner air.

site_title: Price fall to push oil industry into sharp recession: report
summary: Oil prices have plummeted, forcing energy companies to slash capital spending in North America, Europe, and Asia by 10-15% and 20% respectively in 2015. However, investment in Africa and the Middle East is expected to rise as producers seek to boost long-term output. Companies are cutting back on high-cost projects, such as Arctic drilling and Canadian oil sands, due to lower oil prices. The industry is bracing for a sharp recession, with investment bank Evercore estimating a 25-30% decline in North American spending.

site_title: At your service
summary: A specialist centre for Royal Healthcare is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka, Japan, following Sojitz's takeover. Meanwhile, a startup from NUS researchers aims to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Tenants at Hao Mart's Taste Orchard lament poor footfall and vacant units, while OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec has shut its Orchard campus and training restaurant, cutting 42 staff and putting the building up for sale. Chinatown Business Association seeks S$77,700 from Nanyang Old Coffee over the use of an outdoor area.

site_title: Uber vehicles impounded in South Africa: executive
summary: Uber vehicles in Cape Town, South Africa, were impounded over a permit dispute with the city, with 33 cars taken into custody. The issue stems from the city's requirement for a metered-taxi license, which Uber drivers have struggled to obtain due to business case and other requirements. However, Uber remains operational in the city and has committed to engaging with authorities to find a solution, with some cars already being released. The dispute is the latest regulatory setback for the ride-hailing service.

site_title: Tennis: Nadal suffers shock defeat in first match of season
summary: Rafael Nadal suffered a shock defeat in his first match of the 2015 season, losing to qualifier Michael Berrer 1-6, 6-3, 6-4 in Qatar. Nadal, recovering from an appendectomy and back and wrist injuries, appeared to be in doubt about his ability to compete at the Australian Open, which starts in less than two weeks. Despite acknowledging his struggles, Nadal expressed determination to work towards being ready for the tournament, while Berrer praised the opportunity to beat one of tennis' greatest players.

site_title: Dollar, euro swings set to reshape terms of trade globally
summary: The US dollar is experiencing a significant surge, trading below €1.19 and up 15% since June 30, reshaping global economic interactions. The dollar's rise is driven by the US economy's strong growth, while the European Central Bank and Bank of Japan are expected to adopt easier monetary policies. This shift has implications for global trade, with US companies facing increased competitiveness challenges, while European exporters may benefit from cheaper imports. The dollar's appreciation is also expected to push US inflation down and European inflation up.

site_title: Paris Louvre is world's most-visited museum
summary: The Louvre in Paris retained its title as the world's most-visited museum, with 9.3 million visitors in 2014, a 100,000 increase from the previous year. Foreign visitors made up 70% of ticket sales, with Americans, Chinese, Italians, British, and Brazilians being the top groups. The museum also saw a significant increase in young visitors, with over half under the age of 30. The Louvre's popular attractions, including Da Vinci's Mona Lisa and the ancient Greek marble sculpture 'Winged Victory of Samothrace', drew in crowds.

site_title: Newly registered companies
summary: Newly registered companies in Singapore include companies with issued capital between $200,000 and $5 million from September-October 2014. Meanwhile, Royal Healthcare is set to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka after Sojitz took control. Researchers at NUS are working on a startup to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. OCBC aims to provide $5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec has shut its Orchard campus and training restaurant, cutting 42 staff and putting the building up for sale.

site_title: Euro hounded ahead of inflation data, yen on firm footing
summary: The euro fell to a nine-year low against the dollar as investors awaited inflation data expected to show a drop in consumer prices in the euro zone. The data, due later in the day, is seen as supportive of European Central Bank quantitative easing operations beginning in January. The euro slid to US$1.1842, its lowest since 2006, amid concerns of weak inflation and potential policy stimulus.

site_title: Flying colours
summary: Orangetee.com, a company that bucked the trend by keeping its ".com" name despite the dot-com bubble, continues to innovate. Meanwhile, Royal Healthcare plans to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka after being taken over by Sojitz. Researchers at NUS are working on sustainable marine fuel, aiming to halve its price. Tenants of Hao Mart's Taste Orchard lament poor footfall and vacant units. OCBC targets $5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028, while Shatec shuts its Orchard campus and puts its building up for sale, cutting 42 staff.

site_title: US: Wall St ends down 5th session; oil prices fall further
summary: US stocks ended lower for a fifth session on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 falling 1.4% and breaking below the 2,000 level for the first time since December 17. The energy sector fell 1.3% as oil prices slid 4.2% to $47.93 a barrel, with shares of energy companies tumbling. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.74% and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 1.29%. The decline is attributed to slowing growth in the US service sector and mounting worries about a supply glut.

site_title: Oil down almost 10% in 2 days as hunt for bottom continues
summary: Global oil markets slumped for a fourth straight session, with crude prices down almost 10% this week to hit their lowest since spring 2009. Brent crude settled at $51.10 a barrel, and US crude finished at $47.93, a 4.2% drop. The selloff began six months ago due to concerns of oversupply and accelerated after the Opec meeting in November. Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah ruled out production cuts, adding to the bearish sentiment. Oil prices have plunged 55% since June, with refined products like gasoline settling 2% down.

site_title: China's services PMI grows; further stimulus expected
summary: China's services sector grew at its fastest pace in three months in December, with a PMI of 53.4, contrasting with manufacturing activity slowdowns. The robust services sector, including new orders and labor market expansion, suggests further stimulus measures are likely, including interest rate cuts and reserve reductions, to support economic growth. Despite a slowing economy, Chinese leaders are tolerating slower growth as long as labor markets remain healthy, but services firms are pessimistic on the outlook.

site_title: Beijing okays 7 trillion yuan projects for this year
summary: China's government approved 7 trillion yuan worth of infrastructure projects for 2015, including oil and gas pipelines, health, clean energy, and transportation. The projects, valued at over $1.5 trillion, aim to boost growth, which is in danger of slipping below 7%. The move follows a broader 10 trillion yuan plan to stimulate growth, with funding from central and local governments, state-owned firms, loans, and the private sector. The approvals contrast with past individual project approvals and aim to stabilize growth momentum.

site_title: Romance novelist Nicholas Sparks, wife break up
summary: Romance novelist Nicholas Sparks and his wife of 25 years, Cathy Cote, have separated. In a statement, Sparks described the decision as not made lightly, while emphasizing their close friendship and love for their children. The couple married in 1989 and has three sons and two daughters. Sparks credited his wife as a source of inspiration for his novels, including "The Notebook," which was adapted into a successful movie.

images.alt_text: Romance novelist Nicholas Sparks(right), whose bestsellers about ever-lasting love have been spun into a series of popular Hollywood films, is breaking up with his wife of 25 years.

site_title: Reaping the rewards of sustainability
summary: Asia is experiencing unprecedented growth, and cities like Singapore must prioritize sustainable development and city management to make them livable and desirable. Climate change is driving businesses to adopt low-carbon practices, and Singapore can capitalize on this trend. Meanwhile, a NUS researcher's startup is working to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, while OCBC aims to provide $5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Other news includes the opening of a specialist healthcare center in Japan and the modernization of traditional snacks in Singapore.

site_title: Morgan Stanley probes leak, sale of client data
summary: Morgan Stanley is investigating a data breach involving a financial adviser, Galen Marsh, who allegedly leaked client data, including passwords and login information, from the bank's New York offices. The breach, which involved about 10% of Morgan Stanley's 3.5 million wealth management customers, was discovered in mid-December and resulted in the adviser being fired and placed under FBI investigation. Despite the breach, Morgan Stanley found no evidence of customer losses, but the incident highlights the vulnerability of banks to inside threats and the need for improved data security measures.

site_title: Boeing plane deliveries hit record; Airbus wins on orders
summary: Boeing delivered a record 723 jetliners in 2014, surpassing its target and retaining its title as the world's largest plane maker. The company booked 1,550 gross orders and 1,432 net orders worth $232.7 billion. However, Airbus won on new orders, setting it up to announce it was ahead of Boeing in both gross and net orders. Despite this, Boeing's deliveries measure its ability to convert orders into cash, and the company delivered 485 737s and 12 787s per month, exceeding production targets.

images.alt_text: Boeing Co said on Tuesday that it delivered 723 jetliners in 2014, hitting its own target, setting an industry record and retaining its title as the world's biggest plane maker, besting rival Airbus Group.

site_title: Brokers' Take
summary: Libra Group's shares rose after winning S$11.3 million in M&E contracts, with year-to-date order book at S$105.6 million. OCBC Investment Research reiterates a "buy" rating with a target price of S$0.33. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding announced nine new shipbuilding contracts worth US$1.8 billion in Q4 2014. DMG & Partners Research maintains a "buy" rating with a target price of S$1.68, citing a strong US dollar and global growth. KrisEnergy secured approval for its Lengo Gas Development in East Java, with Macquarie Research expecting a hockey-stick production profile.

site_title: Analysts favour developers, warn of Reit downside
summary: Analysts favor buying developer shares over real estate investment trusts (Reits) in Singapore due to low valuations and risks facing Reits. Reits face risks including operational pressures, interest rate hikes, and expiring incentives, which could lead to lower unit prices. In contrast, developer shares have already priced in a significant price fall and offer cheap valuations, with some analysts predicting a 40% discount to revalued net asset values. The Singapore government may extend incentives to Reits, but a more likely outcome is a partial extension, which could be negative for Reits.

site_title: Junk debt in Singapore getting riskier
summary: Singapore's junk debt market is becoming increasingly risky, with three out of 10 notes sold last year yielding over 6%. This is driven by demand for higher returns from private banking clients, which has led to greater risks for companies such as Halcyon Agri Corp and VTB Capital SA. Junk-rated companies in Singapore face significant debt repayment obligations this year, totaling US$2.1 billion. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is considering new regulations to protect individual investors, including stricter credit requirements and restrictions on convertible bonds.

site_title: JPMorgan settles forex manipulation lawsuit in US
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has settled a US antitrust lawsuit alleging price rigging in the US$5 trillion-a-day foreign exchange market. The largest US bank will pay approximately US$100 million. This is the first bank to settle such a lawsuit involving 12 major banks. The settlement was reached in a letter filed with the US District Court in Manhattan.

site_title: China grants US$5.3 billion credit line to Ecuador
summary: China has granted Ecuador a $5.3 billion 30-year credit line with a 2% annual interest rate to help the oil-reliant nation reorganize its finances after a 55% drop in global oil prices. Ecuador will use $1.5 billion of the loan this year for social projects, transport, and infrastructure. The loan comes as Ecuador faces challenges from the decline in oil prices, which have forced the government to cut its 2015 budget by 4%. This is the latest in a series of financial support from China to struggling nations.

images.alt_text: The loan, granted during an official visit to China by Ecuador's President Rafael Correa, comes as OPEC's smallest member faces challenges from a plunge in global oil prices which on Monday forced the government to cut its 2015 budget by 4 per cent.

site_title: For bond investors, sometimes it's best not to pay heed to advice
summary: Investors in bonds were repeatedly advised to sell due to rising inflation and interest rates, but the opposite occurred over the past three Januarys, with inflation failing to materialize and interest rates decreasing, resulting in bond holders making money. This contradicts historical data and warnings from 2008, highlighting that relying on past trends may not be effective in investment decisions.

site_title: US carmakers set to reap further gains as oil falls
summary: US carmakers such as GM and Ford are expected to reap further gains in 2015 as oil falls below $50 a barrel for the first time in a half decade. Light-vehicle sales may reach 16.7 million or more, with trucks dominating the market. This marks a sixth year of growth for the US car industry, following a 16.9 million annualized pace in December.

site_title: Hedge funds resume bullish gold bets on Greek turmoil
summary: Hedge funds have increased their bullish bets on gold for the first time in three weeks, with bullish wagers more than doubling since mid-November. The move comes as Greece faces political turmoil and Asia governments take actions that have driven gold prices to their biggest monthly advance since June. Short holdings have also dropped for the sixth week in seven, as gold rose for a second straight month in December.

site_title: More buys than sells in Singapore stocks
summary: Global mutual funds were net buyers of Singapore shares in the three months to Dec 31, with S$639.4 million worth of shares purchased compared to S$605.4 million sold. OCBC was the top stock bought, with S$129.7 million invested, while SingTel was the top stock sold, with S$98.6 million sold. The data, provided by ShareInvestor and Ipreo, offers insight into fund manager attention and market trends, but may not reflect the full picture of trading activity.

site_title: Game of Thrones to be shown in Imax theatres in the US
summary: Game of Thrones will be shown in Imax theatres in the US, starting January 23-29, in 150 Imax screens nationwide. This marks the first time a TV series has appeared on Imax screens. The exclusive trailer and final episodes of the previous season will be shown. The move signals the blurring of media platforms and a shift towards turning blockbuster hits into mega events. Imax is expanding its programming to include TV series and live sports, and has tested technologies for music concerts. The partnership is an experiment to showcase the high production quality of Game of Thrones.

site_title: Murakami comes out of exile to engage readers
summary: Japanese author Haruki Murakami has emerged from his reclusive nature to engage with readers, addressing concerns about the meaning of life and reality. Despite being a perennial Nobel Prize contender, his whereabouts remain unknown, fueling his enigmatic persona. Murakami is known for his surreal works, and fans are eagerly awaiting his thoughts on these topics.

site_title: Accountants need to be strong in their ethical principles
summary: A former financial controller of Singapore Technologies Marine was charged with making fictitious petty-cash claims totaling over $500,000. The incident sparked concerns about the integrity of accountants, but experts argue that one bad apple should not define the entire profession. Accountants are trained on ethics standards and bound by a code of ethics to prepare information fairly and honestly. However, they may face pressure from superiors to breach ethical principles, and the consequences of staying put can be severe. Experts suggest that accountants must be strong in their ethical principles to avoid compromising their values and the law.

site_title: Euro countries take tough line towards Greece
summary: European leaders, including Germany, France, and Brussels, are taking a tough line towards Greece, urging the country to stay in the eurozone despite growing fears of a potential exit. Greece's narrow front-runner for the January 25 election, Alexis Tsipras, has vowed to renegotiate Greece's debt and roll back austerity measures, which could cost creditors tens of billions of dollars. Despite this, officials emphasize that membership in the euro bloc is "irrevocable" and that Greece's creditors would lose billions if it were to leave.

site_title: US drivers will pay up to US$1,499 for technology features
summary: US drivers are willing to pay up to $1,499 for high-tech entertainment and safety devices in their vehicles, according to a Harris Poll survey. The top desired features include back-up cameras, USB ports, and smartphone charging. A majority of drivers (55%) also want music streaming services to enhance their driving experience. The demand for in-vehicle technology is on the rise, with internet-connected cars expected to grow fourfold by 2020. Carmakers are seeking to capitalize on this trend, with many showcasing advanced features at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

site_title: When Facebook's head honcho likes a book, sales surge
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg made a New Year's resolution to read two books a month, inviting his 31 million friends to join him. He created a Facebook page, "A Year of Books", where he shares his selections and discusses them with readers. The announcement boosted sales of his first chosen book, "The End of Power", by Moises Naim.

site_title: Holiday demand pushes Sony's PlayStation 4 sales to over 18.5m units
summary: Sony's PlayStation 4 sales exceeded 18.5 million units as of January 4, up from 13.5 million at the end of October, driven by strong holiday demand. This marks a relief for the company, which is recovering from a massive cyber-attack and faces weak sales of smartphones and TVs. CEO Kazuo Hirai reaffirmed Sony's commitment to free speech after reversing the cancellation of the film "The Interview," which was a target of the cyber-attack.

images.alt_text: Sony said last month that holiday sales in Europe were so strong that it was fighting to keep up with demand.

site_title: Cathay CEO Suhaimi to quit to 'pursue other interests'
summary: Cathay Organisation CEO Suhaimi Rafdi will leave the company on February 20, citing a desire to "pursue other interests." Managing Director Choo Meileen will resume the responsibilities Suhaimi was assigned in 2008. Suhaimi spent nearly 20 years at Cathay, citing that he learned his management and business skills there.

site_title: Obama to be the trade president?
summary: US President Barack Obama may become known as the "Trade President" if he secures the passage of major global trade deals, including the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) and the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP), in 2015. Despite Republican opposition, the White House and Republican congressional leaders support the deals, which could benefit the US economy and create new jobs. However, Democratic lawmakers, including Senator Elizabeth Warren, have expressed reservations about the TPP, which could lead to a split within the Democratic Party ahead of the 2016 presidential election.

site_title: Oil fall, "Grexit'' fears send prices tumbling
summary: The Straits Times Index fell 46.33 points or 1.4% to 3,281.95, following a steep plunge on Wall Street due to sliding oil prices and Greek political uncertainty. The banking sector was hit, with UOB plummeting 2.7% and oil-related stocks like Keppel Corp and Sembcorp Marine also dropping sharply. The "Grexit" worries have resurfaced, and investors are advised to exercise caution.

site_title: In Brief
summary: QT Vascular's clinical trial for its Chocolate drug-coated balloon has exceeded patient enrolment goals, aiming for CE marking regulatory approval in the second half of 2015. Accordia Golf Trust's golf course holding company received a BBB+ rating from Japan Credit Rating Agency for $504 million in asset-backed loans. Singapore Shipping Corporation Limited secured a $16.5 million term loan facility to acquire a Pure Car Truck Carrier vessel. Sakae Holdings diversified into corporate advisory services, advising Q&M Dental Group for two years.

site_title: The glow of the green light
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Several business and market trends are emerging. A specialist healthcare center is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Japan's Sojitz takes control. Researchers at NUS are working on a startup to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Meanwhile, tenants at Hao Mart's Taste Orchard express concerns about poor footfall and vacant units. OCBC aims to provide S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Other businesses are adapting, such as Shatec's decision to shut its Orchard campus and rebrand heritage for the younger generation. Chinatown Business Association is seeking compensation for outdoor area use.

site_title: 2015 will be a turning point for Japan, say nation's biggest trading houses
summary: Japan's largest trading houses predict 2015 as a pivotal year for the country's economy, driven by cheap oil, easy money, and a weaker yen. This promises to boost growth in areas such as employment, agriculture, and health. CEO Fumiya Kokubu of Marubeni Corp notes that Japan is at a turning point, with potential for "painful improvement." The country's economy is 25 years past the bursting of its bubble economy, which led to two decades of deflation.

site_title: Kaisa bonds sink to new lows on fresh default fears
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd bonds fell to record lows amid speculation the Chinese developer will miss debt obligations, with yields rising to 56.6% on its 8.875% notes due 2018. Standard & Poor's cut its credit rating to selective default, citing a "high likelihood" of default on upcoming obligations. Kaisa's stock remains suspended, and Moody's downgraded its rating to Caa3 with a negative outlook. The company's debt liabilities have become "due and payable," and two business partners have terminated joint ventures, demanding repayment.

site_title: Manhattan apartment prices at 6-year high
summary: Manhattan apartment prices have reached a 6-year high, with the median price of all condominiums and co-ops selling for $980,000 in the fourth quarter of 2014. This represents a 15% increase from the previous year and the second-highest price in 25 years. The limited supply of homes, with only 4,995 apartments on the market, has driven up prices, with buyers competing for deals in new luxury developments.

images.alt_text: Price gains are accelerating as demand from domestic and international buyers alike outpaces the number of properties for sale.

site_title: Public spending in Philippines stalls amid fight against graft
summary: The Philippines ended 2014 with its weakest economic report in almost three years, with public spending stalled amid a fight against graft and abuse of power. The country's economic growth is expected to slow to 6% in 2014 and this year, from 7% in 2013, due to a lack of spending. The government's anti-corruption drive has led to stricter disbursement procedures, causing civil servants to delay projects and reducing state spending. The country's President Benigno Aquino faces a challenge in convincing officials to unclog the logjam and boost investment and expansion.

site_title: Analysts say 'Grexit' unlikely; oil price slump overdone
summary: Analysts say a Greek exit from the eurozone is unlikely and the oil price slump may be overdone. A Greek debt default and exit would be a "low probability event" due to little economic interest, and the country's economy is relatively small. Weak global demand will keep oil prices low. Despite uncertain European politics, analysts remain positive on stocks, citing low inflation and interest rates, and additional central bank stimulus. They expect oil prices to rebound, with some predicting a floor around $40-$50 a barrel.

site_title: Hong Kong Chief Executive warns against protests ahead of election reform talks
summary: Hong Kong Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying warned against fresh pro-democracy protests ahead of election reform talks, stating that coercive actions would not sway authorities in Hong Kong or Beijing. A new report on the mass rallies sparked widespread anger, with democracy campaigners criticizing its lack of emotion and failure to identify the cause of the protests. The government will launch a second round of public consultation on the process for electing the city's next chief executive in 2017, despite concerns that it will not offer meaningful proposals.

site_title: Grexit fears return, but eurozone problem is more than about Greece
summary: Financial markets are on edge due to concerns over Greece's upcoming general election, which could lead to a Syriza-led government that will implement anti-austerity policies and a moratorium on debt payments. This could destabilize the eurozone, with Germany preparing for a potential Greek exit, which economists warn would have catastrophic consequences for Greece and the eurozone. The issue is not unique to Greece, with Spain, Italy, Portugal, and France also struggling with austerity and unemployment, and radical politicians gaining popularity.

site_title: American, Hawaiian bid to take Haneda slot from Delta
summary: American Airlines and Hawaiian Airlines have formally bid to take control of a key slot at Tokyo's Haneda Airport from Delta Air Lines. The US carriers are seeking to increase their presence in Asia, lobbying the US Department of Transportation to rescind Delta's slot. This move comes as part of an international agreement between the US and Japan, which allocates four daily slots to US carriers. The outcome of the bid is yet to be determined, but the airlines' efforts aim to strengthen their foothold in the Asian market.

site_title: Mobile shopping up, but more sales coming from desktops: IBM data
summary: Shoppers spent more time browsing and purchasing gifts on smartphones and tablets during the 2014 holiday season, with 27% increase in mobile sales, but desktops still accounted for 77% of online sales.

site_title: Free money in bond markets shows global economy still struggling: Citi
summary: Global bond yields have dropped below 1% for the first time, indicating investors expect a prolonged economic slowdown. This low yield suggests investors think the global economy is "going nowhere for a long time". The US, Japan, and Germany's 10-year bond yields have fallen to record lows, with the effective yield of the Bank of America Merrill Lynch Global Broad Market Sovereign Plus Index reaching 1.28%. Experts attribute the low yields to secular stagnation or a lack of innovative monetary policy, with some forecasting a global rate as low as 1% if oil remains below $60 a barrel.

site_title: Developer denies reports of shrinking size of Johor reclamation project
summary: Country Garden Pacific (CGP) has denied reports that the 1,600-hectare Forest City reclamation project in Malaysia has been shrunk to 405 hectares due to Department of Environment (DoE) directions. The developer claims no discussions were held about limiting the project's size, contradicting reports from The Malaysian Insider. CGP stated it would release project details once its metrics and monitoring initiatives are finalized, emphasizing its commitment to environmental and community considerations. The project's original size was 2,000 hectares, and its split into four man-made islands reduced the total land size.

site_title: Going green
summary: A company, Biomax, was founded after its CEO challenged its CTO to develop an enzyme to convert organic waste into fertilizer in 24 hours. The company aims to address wastage in the food and beverage industry. Meanwhile, a specialist centre for Royal Healthcare is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Japan's Sojitz takes control. Researchers at NUS are working on reducing the price of sustainable marine fuel. Additionally, several businesses, including Hao Mart's Taste Orchard and Shatec, have faced challenges such as poor footfall and vacant units, prompting concerns about their long-term viability.

site_title: Keppel O&M unit bags two deals worth S$65m
summary: Keppel O&M's wholly owned unit, Keppel Singmarine, secured two contracts worth over S$65 million. The first contract involves building a multi-task anchor handling tug vessel for Seaways International, set to be completed in Q2 2016. The second contract, with Nakilat-Keppel Offshore & Marine, involves providing technical services for a liftboat construction project. The contracts are not expected to significantly impact Keppel Corporation's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year.

site_title: GLP in leasing deals with 6 logistics players
summary: Global Logistics Properties Limited (GLP) signed new leasing agreements totaling 84,000 square meters with six leading logistics providers in China. The deals support e-commerce and food-related product distribution needs, driven by domestic consumption and e-commerce growth. This follows recent lease agreements totaling 80,000 square meters in China, with GLP's largest lease agreement in Brazil completed last January.

site_title: Prime Leng Kee Rd property may have changed hands
summary: Automotive group Eurokars is speculated to have bought a prime piece of Leng Kee Road property in Singapore, adding to its growing land bank in the prime motor belt. The vacant car showroom currently standing on the site is expected to be demolished. Eurokars declined to comment on the purchase. This acquisition may further solidify the company's presence in the region, although the details of the deal remain unclear.

site_title: Petrodollar drought is new risk for markets
summary: The "petrodollar drought" poses a new risk to financial markets, as low oil prices have left energy producers with a cash shortfall. For the first time in nearly two decades, they are expected to dip into savings rather than add to them, potentially drawing down reserves by $211 billion in 2015. This shift in cash flow could lead to a decrease in bond prices and may exacerbate falls in other assets, including shares.

site_title: China quietly lifts its rare earth export quotas
summary: China has lifted its export quotas for rare earth minerals, a move that could significantly impact industrial nations reliant on Beijing's supplies. The quotas, imposed in 2010, had been a major point of contention between China and Japan, among others, and had led to a global scramble for alternative sources. The removal of the quota system is expected to increase competition and push up prices, but analysts say it will also drive efforts to find alternative supply sources, as China traditionally supplies over 90% of the world's rare earths.

site_title: All charged up
summary: Greenlots, a Singapore-based cleantech start-up, aims to increase electric vehicle adoption by building charging infrastructure. The company believes Singapore's reliable power grid and small size make it an ideal location for this initiative. Greenlots' product manager and field operations manager are optimistic about the potential for widespread EV adoption.

site_title: New and improved
summary: A Companies (Amendment) Bill passed in Parliament last year aims to reduce regulatory burden, provide business flexibility, and improve corporate governance in Singapore. The changes were the largest since the Companies Act was enacted in 1967. Meanwhile, NUS researchers are working on sustainable marine fuel, and OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Other news includes the shutdown of Shatec's Orchard campus, the rebranding of an otah business, and the modernization of traditional min jiang kueh as a 'national snack'.

site_title: Take a bow
summary: The 14th Grand Prix d'Horlogerie de Geneve awards ceremony took place in Geneva, Switzerland, last October. Breguet's Classique Chronometrie won the Aiguille d'Or Grand Prix for the best overall watch. Independent watch brand Urwerk received two prizes, including Mechanical Exception Watch and Innovation Watch.

site_title: McDonald's joins breakfast war with free-coffee Mondays
summary: McDonald's is launching a free-coffee Monday promotion in the Washington region, offering small iced or hot coffee for free at participating branches until the end of the year. The move is part of the company's efforts to boost sales, which have fallen at stores open for at least 13 months. McDonald's believes coffee drives breakfast visits and aims to attract customers to its doors, where it serves breakfast until 10:30 am. The promotion comes as the fast-food industry faces increased competition from chains like Taco Bell, which has successfully introduced breakfast items to its menu.

site_title: AirAsia shares take a beating as bad news piles up
summary: AirAsia shares plummet 5% to RM2.49 on Tuesday, taking the total loss since the Dec 28 crash of QZ8501 to 15%. The Indonesian authorities are investigating whether AirAsia Indonesia breached its licensing conditions by flying on Sunday, outside its authorized flight schedule. The incident follows allegations that AAI owed RM1.3 billion in receivables, which could be impaired. Singapore confirms the Sunday flight was approved, adding to the confusion. The crash remains under investigation, with 162 people on board still unrecovered due to bad weather.

site_title: Search teams take advantage of respite from bad weather
summary: Search teams for the crashed AirAsia jet have resumed operations after a nine-day hiatus due to bad weather. Indonesian officials believe they may have located the tail and parts of the fuselage of the Airbus A320-200 in the Java Sea. Strong currents and high winds have hindered previous attempts to investigate. The search is focused on 90 nautical miles off Borneo, where five large objects believed to be parts of the plane have been spotted. The cause of the crash remains unknown, but officials suspect seasonal tropical storms were a factor.

site_title: SingTel to offer scholarships at two polytechnics
summary: SingTel has partnered two polytechnics, Singapore Polytechnic and Republic Polytechnic, to launch a diploma scholarship programme worth over S$2 million annually. The programme, called the SingTel Cadet Scholarship Programme, will benefit 90 students each year and provide industry-relevant training, employment, and progression opportunities. Upon graduation, recipients will join SingTel and serve a one-year bond, performing technical or customer-experience management roles. The programme aligns with the government's SkillsFuture movement and aims to develop skills for the future economy and make the workplace a place for learning.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Tale of two ships - one beached, another sinks
summary: A 57,000-tonne car transporter, the Hoegh Osaka, was deliberately beached off the UK port of Southampton to prevent capsizing after listing, saving its 1,400-car cargo and crew. In contrast, a 272-foot bulk-cement carrier, the Cemfjord, capsized and sank off northern Scotland during a storm, killing its eight-member crew. The cause of the Cemfjord's sinking is unknown. The Hoegh Osaka's crew took a calculated risk to save the ship, and rescue operations are ongoing to free the vessel from the Bramble Bank.

site_title: S'pore hedge funds join global leaders
summary: Singapore-based hedge funds, Quantedge Capital and Dymon Asia Capital, have ranked among the top 10 best-performing large hedge funds globally, according to Bloomberg's rankings. Quantedge Global returned 32.3% in 2014, while Dymon Asia Macro returned 17%. Both funds have assets of over $1 billion and $3.5 billion, respectively. They employ diversified and systematic models, with fixed income and equity positions contributing to their gains in 2014. The success of these Singapore-based funds highlights the country's potential as a hedge fund hub.

site_title: Reform in Ukraine a gamble worth taking by the West
summary: Ukraine's government, formed after a free and fair election, faces a severe economic crisis, with a steady drain on bank deposits, large fiscal deficits, and significant external debt payments. The country needs $15 billion in outside help this year, in addition to a $17 billion bailout received last year. To stabilize its economy, Ukraine must implement deep domestic reforms, including cutting energy subsidies and recapitalizing banks. However, financial instability and a lack of political will hinder the country's ability to implement these reforms, making aid from the EU and IMF crucial to avoid a potential economic and political meltdown.

site_title: Pipeline partnerships ride rise in oil output
summary: US pipeline partnerships, also known as Master Limited Partnerships (MLPs), have seen a rise in oil output and value to investors despite plunging oil prices. MLPs, which own pipeline and storage tanks, typically have long-term contracts and are less vulnerable to price swings. This has led to a surge in interest from producers seeking to raise cash, with Hess Corp planning to raise cash through an MLP IPO. The number of tax-advantaged partnerships has proliferated due to demand for steady returns, and analysts expect continued demand for assets involved in commodity transportation and processing.

site_title: Good deeds
summary: Most small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) practice some form of corporate social responsibility (CSR) without formally incorporating it, citing lack of time. A specialist centre in healthcare is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka, while researchers aim to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Tenants at Hao Mart's Taste Orchard lament poor footfall and vacant units, while OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec cuts staff and puts a campus up for sale, and businesses are rebranding heritage and modernising traditional snacks for younger generations.

site_title: As go Korea and Vietnam, so can Korea and Japan?
summary: South Korea and Japan, despite extensive bilateral trade, have stalled progress on new open trade arrangements due to old animosities. In contrast, Korea and Vietnam have concluded a significant free-trade agreement, overcoming historical tensions. The agreement has led to substantial economic growth between the two countries, with combined exports increasing from $500 million to $21.2 billion in 21 years. To foster economic peace, Korea's government should adopt the same pragmatism and willingness to let go of past frictions as it has with Vietnam.

site_title: Cost cuts, asset sales and property write-downs in store for Tesco
summary: Tesco's new CEO Dave Lewis is set to provide an update on his plans to revive the struggling British grocer's fortunes, focusing on cost cuts and asset sales. The company may detail substantial property asset write-offs, including write-downs on large out-of-town stores and development land. Tesco is also expected to report on third-quarter sales and Christmas trading, with analysts predicting a 2.5% drop in like-for-like sales. The company's debt is rated one notch above junk status, and analysts expect cost cuts to be made through reducing head office staff and consolidating offices.

site_title: Developing apps that talk to one another
summary: Silicon Valley companies, including Google and Facebook, are working on deep linking, a technology that allows apps to communicate with each other like web pages do. This is a significant challenge, as mobile apps lack links and web addresses, making it difficult to share information within them. Companies like Branch Metrics, URX, and Quixey are developing solutions to overcome this hurdle, with the goal of creating a universal web address that works across apps and the web.
